Author몭s Preface
I wrote this book because I wanted to give readers real access into every word of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. This book is my attempt to present it in a new, easy-to-read version.
In this book, you will find real examples from military history illustrating every military principle from Sun Tzu몭 s The Art of War. To help readers fully understand the nuances of how certain military campaigns were fought, some of these examples make multiple appearances in different chapters, each time providing the reader with a different angle. As readers make their way through the book, they will learn about the various concepts, strategies, tactics and ways of thinking that make up the art of war. The reading experience is designed to be like a personal helicopter ride, transporting you to the skies above ancient battlefields, with Sun Tzu himself sitting in the seat next to you, explaining in real time how each side is maneuvering their way through the battle, blow by blow.
My personal background is in entrepreneurship, so some chapters contain brief discussions of lessons for corporate management and entrepreneurial competitiveness mixed in with the primary content. But, these are side-notes to the main historical narrative, and a part of my writing process of following where my thoughts take me. This book is not about looking at 몬corporate warfare몭 through the lens of The Art of War. Rather, it is about really getting to the heart of Sun Tzu몭s masterwork as an ancient text, and understanding what it means in its original context.
This book has been built on the shoulders of generations of Chinese scholars who have continued Sun Tzu몭s life몭s work by writing their own commentaries about The Art of War. Specifically, this book is based on the writings of 11 commentators who have forged a place in history, and whose work was first compiled in a Song dynasty (960-1279 CE) book, Eleven Commentaries on Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. Each chapter in my book begins with a  brief review of their work, before swiftly delving into a deeper analysis and discussion2.
So, who are 몬The Eleven Commentators?몭 If you want their names, they are Cao Cao, Meng Shi, Li Quan, Gu Lin, Du You, Du Mu, Chen Hao, Wang Xi, Mei Yaochen, He Shi and Zhang Yu.
But who were they, really? The first to write a commentary on Sun Tzu몭s work was Cao Cao, who jotted the following musings about his contribution: 몮I have read many books about war and heard of many military strategies, and of all of these Sun Tzu몭s writings are the most profound. But it would be impossible for ordinary people to grasp the lessons within, and there is much that is superfluous, and so this text is unable to fulfill its purpose in the world. For this reason, I have written a commentary to elucidate its meaning.몯
Cao Cao spent a lifetime on the campaign trail during the Three Kingdoms period (220-280 CE). He is a giant figure in the annals of Chinese history, not only for his peerless military mind but also as a rare talent in the art of governance. Because of his towering historical stature, his commentary has received the most serious attention, and I would assert that his is also the most accurate of all the commentaries. Large parts of this book follow Cao Cao몭s lead. Sadly, Cao Cao was very sparing with his words, and what he did write is succinct to a fault. He even said that Sun Tzu was too wordy! After all, Cao Cao was a professional 멨 a powerful warlord and a poet 멨 and he was not writing for the benefit of ordinary people. As much as we might wish otherwise, he has left us even fewer words than Sun Tzu himself.
About our second commentator, Meng Shi, not much is known regarding his real name, his place of birth, and most other details about his life. We don몭t even know for sure during which dynasty he lived, although it몭s possible he lived during the Liang dynasty of the Southern dynasties (420-589 CE) period. Not much of his commentary is still with us today, but he did leave us some useful material to work with.
Next up, Li Quan lived during the Tang dynasty, probably during the reign of Emperor Xuanzong (846-859 CE). He spent part of his life living as a religious hermit, practicing the Dao on Shaoshi Mountain near the Shaolin monastery. He later was plucked from his humble mountain life, appointed as an administrative assistant to the military commissioner of Jingnan, and later rose to the rank of Censor. He had a lot of opinions and wasn몭t afraid to speak his mind. For instance, he said that Cao Cao몭s commentary was riddled with mistakes, and so he took it upon himself to write a new interpretation. Though I haven몭t managed to find any errors in Cao Cao몭s work, Li Quan몭s commentary is nonetheless very well written.
The commentator Gu Lin lived during the Tang dynasty. During the reign of Emperor Dezong (779-805 CE) he served as an advisor to the military governor of Zhaoyi, a man named Li Baozhen. Li sent Gu Lin to bring a rebellious general, Wang Wujun, back in line, which he successfully did. As a result, he also managed to destroy Zhu Ci, another general who had rebelled and attempted to establish his own dynasty. Gu Lin was rewarded with noble titles: King of Wuwei Commandery, and Commander-General of the Shence Army. So, this commentator was himself a real military man, and perhaps because he was constantly busy fighting, his observations are short and succinct. We can only guess he didn몭t have much time for writing.
Du You is a particularly special character. He served as prime minister of the Imperial court during the middle part of the Tang dynasty, and he lived through the catastrophic An-Shi rebellion that tore China apart. His experiences during this hugely destabilizing conflict inspired him to take up the mission of 몬devising methods to enrich the country and bring peace to the people몭몯 He spent 36 years of his life painstakingly reviewing ancient texts, and the works of generations of respected scholars. He traced the origins of contemporary government institutions, decrees and administrative frameworks, all with the aim of learning the lessons of the past to hold up as a mirror to the problems of his own day. He compiled his research into an encyclopedic tome, known as The Tongdian. Unsurprisingly, Du You몭s commentary is hugely respected and is an authoritative source.
Our next commentator, Du Mu, was Du You몭s grandson, and after Cao he was the most successful and influential of the reviewers. His output contains a large body of writings, many of which reference examples from various historical battles. In this book, I have used Du Mu몭s commentary more than any other. Du Mu was also an extremely famous poet of the Tang dynasty poetic elite, and memorizing his poems is still homework for students across China. Here몭s one of  them:

Raindrops pelt down on Qingming Festival,
On the road, miserable travellers몭 drooping heads

May I ask, where is the wine shop?

The shepherd boy points to Apricot Blossom Village, far, far away.

~

High above in the distance a zigzag stone path
Deep in white clouds, there몭s someone몭s house
I halt my carriage, entranced by evening wind through maple trees
Frost-coated leaves redder than spring flowers

Then there is this Du Mu poem, about his family, which is not so well known:

In the center of the capital city, an old mansion몭s red gate opens
No clutter inside this house, but shelves of books, ten thousand scrolls!
We are a house of two hundred volumes, kept always busy serving Emperors

The line, 몬We are a house of two hundred volumes,몭 is a reference to the 200 scrolls of his grandfather Du You몭s monumental work of scholarship, the Tongdian.
It몭s hard not to be a little arrogant when you몭re the scion of a wealthy noble house, and blessed with an outsized amount of talent on top of that. No matter how brilliantly Du Mu lectures on military theory, his manner can be overbearing. For example, a phrase that features regularly in his commentary is, 몬Cao is mistaken!몭 This is invariably followed by Du Mu몭s own explanation of what he believe was actually happening. 
In any head-to-head comparison between Cao Cao and Du Mu, it would only be natural to trust Cao Cao more. He was, after all, the only one of the two who had actual experience leading troops into battle. But, this doesn몭t mean that Du Mu's different interpretations of things were entirely wrong. Generally, when Du Mu says that Cao Cao몭s wrong about something, the two commentators were talking about different things. Du Mu was a better poet than Cao Cao, who also happened to be a famous poet in his own right. He was certainly very talented, but he couldn몭t necessarily understand what Cao Cao was talking about, since he had no battlefield experience and wasn몭t quite on the same level as Cao Cao academically.
There is a Confucius quotation: 몬Be always respectful, and you will never face humiliation.몭 This idea is also in the Confucian text, The Great Learning: 몮The ruler몭s words going forth contrary to right, will come back to him in the same way3.몯 The idea is that if you bad-mouth someone, someone else will inevitably bad-mouth you. Because Du Mu made a habit of saying that Cao Cao was wrong, another writer naturally went out of his way to tell the world that actually it was Du Mu who was wrong.
That writer was Chen Hao, the next of our 11 commentators. Chen Hao thought that Du Mu had muddied the waters by discrediting Cao Cao at almost every turn, and so he felt compelled to set the account straight. The words 몬Du Mu is wrong, Cao Cao is right몭 appear often in his commentary, part of his attempt to restore order to academic discussion of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War.
Chen Hao lived towards the end of the Tang dynasty, and his views about earlier commentators are summarized in historical records: 몮Chen Hao considered Lord Cao몭s commentary profound and cryptic, while he considered Du Mu몭s commentary broad and sweeping. Chen Hao wrote his commentary in order to moderate the gap between Cao and Du.몯 Chen also respected the commentators who came before him as men of great wisdom, and made it his mission to carry their work forward. His thinking was: Sun Tzu has left us this remarkable book, but it몭s difficult for people to understand it through Cao Cao몭s commentary because it몭s just as brief and technical as the main text itself. On the other hand, he ventured, people might be misled by Du Mu몭s commentary, which although detailed and comprehensive is also undermined by sloppiness and even inaccuracies in some areas. So, Chen Hao decided to build on the foundation left by Cao Cao and Du Mu, and wrote a new commentary.
Chinese historians have grouped together these three commentaries 멪 by Cao Cao, Du Mu and Chen Hao 멪 and given them a name: Commentaries of the Three Masters. By studying them together, students stand to gain deeper insight.
Five of the 11 commentators lived during the Tang dynasty: Li Quan, Gu Lin, Du You, Du Mu and Chen Hao. This high concentration is because China became very unstable during the second half of the Tang dynasty, after the An-Shi rebellion. There was war almost every year, and so scholars were preoccupied with studying military theory much more than usual. This explains why Du Mu, whose grandfather had been a prime minister, became interested in military issues even while he was making a name for himself as a great poet. In this sense, he was very much a product of his times.
After the Tang dynasty, the dynasty most preoccupied with military matters was the Song dynasty. It started with a period of relative peace, but then a series of events put the country under constant military pressure. There was constant tumult, from the Tangut rebellion, started by Li Yuanhao몭s declaration of a rival 몬Western Xia몭 dynasty in the northwest, to conflicts with minority ethnic groups in the north. As problems piled up, the Song court was short on both competent generals and experienced troops. What was to be done? Desperate, the dynasty몭s leaders turned to books in search of answers.
The country devoted itself to studying the art of war, culminating in the government-compiled primer for military studies, called Seven Military Classics. The first of the seven classics was Sun Tzu몭s[bd4] The Art of War, which is how it first became established as a classic text 멪 thanks to the Song government.
Against the backdrop of the Song dynasty몭s military problems, Wang Xi wrote a new commentary. However, details of his life cannot be verified in any detail due to a lack of sources.
Mei Yaochen was another commentator who몭s also known as a great poet, and he was a good friend of Ouyang Xiu, one of China몭s greatest-ever poets. I have used his work often in this book, because his commentary is of a high quality; it is quite succinct and exacting.
Not much is known for sure about the commentator He Shi, not even what his real name is or during which dynasty he lived. We don몭t have much commentary from him either, but what we do have is worth keeping.
Our final commentator is Zhang Yu, who lived during the Southern Song dynasty. His other writings include a book titled, Biographies of One Hundred Generals. He put a great deal of work into his writings, producing a high-quality commentary that I have used a fair amount throughout this book.

~
 
That concludes my introduction of the wise and esteemed 11 commentators of the ancient world. Although they were definitely wise, they and their writings belong to antiquity in many ways. I still had questions that I couldn몭t find a proper explanation for, so I began to search for commentaries by modern writers. There is no shortage of specialist commentaries about Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, but most of them are concerned more with academic research than actual military studies. They are first and foremost works of scholarship, and they aren몭t concerned with war per se. When a writer writes about war, but is not motivated primarily by actual war, he ends up writing in a certain way, and about certain things 멪 sometimes in a way that seems to actually move the discussion further away from the inherent subject matter.
Eventually, I found a book titled, A Translation and Commentary of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War4, written by Guo Huaruo and published by the Shanghai Ancient Books Publishing House. 
This writer, Guo Huaruo, was a Lieutenant General in the People몭s Liberation Army (PLA) of China. He graduated from the Whampoa Military Academy and was involved in the Northern Expedition military campaign (1926-1928 CE). He also served as second-in-command of the Nanjing military district, and as the vice-director of the Chinese Academy of Military Science. His commentary on Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War is extremely insightful, and I have used it as a reference guide whenever I몭ve been unsure about something, or when different ancient commentators몭 accounts give contradictory information[bd5].

The highest pursuit in Chinese scholarship is, in the words of Song dynasty Confucian scholar Zhang Zai, 몮To establish one몭s heart for heaven and earth, to establish one몭s life for the people, to uphold the works of past sages, and to bring a peace that lasts for ten thousand generations.몯
I hope that this little book may help you, the reader, and that it may honor and carry forward Sun Tzu몭s work and tradition.
	
Hua Shan
28 December 2014[bd6]
The Huayuhua Reading Room, Shanghai




Chapter One of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of war: Calculations

The value system of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War

The very first word of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War is so often misread. The unwitting reader then veers far off course and away from the actual meaning 멪 and it몭s all because of differences in value systems. The word in question is the first word in the title of the first chapter, 몬Ji몭 (?[bd7][TT8]), which is translated as 몬plan,몭 in the chapter title: Calculations.
The[bd9] Chinese word 몬ji몭 has another meaning 멪 몬stratagem몭멪 and also forms part of the title of another ancient Chinese military text, The Thirty-Six Stratagems. Readers often lump Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War and The Thirty-Six Stratagems in the same category. In fact, the two texts have been combined in a single book: Sun Tzu몭s Art of War and The Thirty-Six Stratagems. And yet, they are not at all the same. Both feature this word ji, but in The Thirty-Six Stratagems, it means something like, 몬ingenious strategies,몭 or 몬wily maneuvering.몭 In The Art of War, ji has nothing to do with ingenious strategies; what he meant by ji is 몬making careful calculations.몭
So, what does the word ji being interpreted to mean 몬ingenious strategies몭 have to do with value systems? Well, this question touches upon a very human weakness 멪 the desire to come up with some brilliantly clever strategy that can deliver rapid, definitive results. But this mentality is exactly what Sun Tzu was speaking out against. The Art of War is a book that teaches victory by means of actual, solid strength, not by sneaky stratagems. 
To Sun Tzu, ji (planning) is a fundamental principle, not a specific strategy that a commander can deploy in battle. It is obvious and inelegant rather than ingenious and subtle. It몭s about calculating the balance of power in concrete terms 멪 몬the five factors and seven considerations.몭
The 몬five factors몭 are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and Discipline. The 몬seven considerations몭 are: (1) Which of the two kings is imbued with the Moral Law? (2) Which of the two generals has the most ability? (3) With whom lie the advantages derived from Heaven and Earth? (4) On which side is discipline most rigorously enforced? (5) Which army is stronger? (6) On which side are officers and men more highly trained? (7) In which army is there the greater consistency both in reward and punishment?
Basically, it몭s about comparing the two sides몭 political situation, timing, geographical conditions, personnel talent, discipline and institutional frameworks. Actually, what Sun Tzu means by ji is the equivalent of the modern-day management studies concept of SWOT, which is used to compare both sides몭 Strength, Weakness, Opportunity and Threat.
But then, what is the objective of 몬Calculations?몭 It몭s all about knowing which side will win. By comparing each side몭s 몬five factors and seven considerations,몭 you can determine before the war has even begun who will win and who will lose, and thus whether or not your side has the formula for success.
The writer Du Mu, in his commentary on The Art of War, offers a clear explanation of the original text:
몮몬Plan몭 멪 that is, to 몬calculate.몭 Someone asks: 몬What does it mean to calculate?몭 Someone else responds: 몬At its core, it refers to the five factors, which are called: The Moral Law; Heaven; Earth; The Commander; Method; and Discipline.몭 The first thing to do is to go to the temple and calculate the five factors of your own forces and those of your adversary. After having done this, one can determine who will be the victor and who will be the vanquished. When victor and vanquished are determined, then shall you summon the generals and mobilize the people. In the art of war, nothing precedes these five factors. That is why they appear in the first chapter.몯
What we call the 몬formula for success몭 means first calculating who will win and who will lose, and only going to war once victory is already yours. This is the very core of Sun Tzu몭s way of thinking 멪 몬First obtain victory, then go to war.몭 Or, as I like to put it, 몬Win first, fight later.몭
In all of Chinese history, who was the most brilliant and effective strategist? When Chinese people hear the word ji, the first historical figure who comes to mind is Zhuge Liang. When the word ji is used to talk about him, it is in the sense of 몬ingenious strategies,몭 and not referring to the five factors and seven considerations. He would never pass muster if judged by these standards 멪 Sun Tzu몭s standards. He held not a single advantage over his enemy, the state of Wei, in terms of either SWOT analysis or the Moral Law, Heaven, Earth, Commanders, Method or Discipline. But, he had a dream, and so he summoned his generals, mobilized his people, marched out from the mountains of Qi and rapidly stormed onto the central plains. His war brought ruin on the country and the people, and left the fields strewn with corpses. He took huge risks, and the fact that he won involved a generous helping of luck. Yet, despite this, he also had a reputation as the most cautious person alive, someone who never engaged in a battle that he didn몭t have complete control over, and who retreated at the first sign of a problem. This begs the question: why did he feel the need to mobilize his troops and start a war in the first place?
Zhuge Liang몭s 몬strategy몭 was a muddled, sloppy version of the concept ji. So, then, why is Zhuge Liang so famous and beloved by the people of China? The answer is that people love a good story, and he is at the center of a truly great one. Good stories are a common by-product of 몬ingenious strategies.몭
True strategy, and true victory, do not make for good stories. In fact, they usually seem quite dull. This point actually comes up in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몮Good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage.몯 Zhuge Liang became more renowned for his wisdom than anyone else throughout 5,000 years of Chinese history. Yet, 700 years before Zhuge Liang was born, Sun Tzu said: 몮Good fighters have no reputation for wisdom.몯 In other words, if a man is renowned for his wisdom, he is not a good fighter. When a good fighter does go to war, it몭s a dull event 멪 not at all story-worthy. This is one of the key lessons we have to learn from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. Where the layman sees only what is dull and unremarkable, that is where we will find the great way of the masters. That is where we must go to learn the true skills of the greats.


Sun Tzu몭s 몬Reverent Wariness몭
For Sun Tzu, 몬the art of war몭 is not the art of fighting battles, but the art of not fighting battles. It is not the art of winning by fighting battles, but the art of winning without fighting battles. It is not the art of fighting battles first and winning later, but the art of winning first and then fighting battles later.


Extract from the original text:
몮The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin. Hence, it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected.몯

Analysis:
Sun Tzu made it quite clear that military affairs are of huge national importance 멪 literally a matter of survival and ruin, life and death. Military affairs must be carefully scrutinized, and never taken lightly. Sun Tzu considered this point so fundamental to war that he made sure to address it before anything else, at the start of the first chapter of The Art of War. Like Sun Tzu, Confucius also attached great importance to wariness. In the major Confucian text, The Doctrine of the Mean, while expounding its version of the Dao, heavy emphasis is laid on the idea of 몬caution and fear.몭 This is the idea that one should be cautious and not take risks; that one should be scared of the unknown, and always be alert and constantly scrutinizing not only yourself but also anything you may have overlooked or don몭t know about. 
At this point, I think we몭ve made it pretty clear that the idea of not fighting battles is a major motif in The Art of War. If a leader puts into practice all of Sun Tzu몭s teachings, they will successfully bend their enemy몭s troops into submission, all while never having to fight a battle.
It would be perfectly correct to say that The Art of War is more a study of how not to fight wars than how to fight wars. This partly explains why the only biographical information we have about Sun Tzu몭s life is very vague, while other generals of the same time period, like Wu Zixu, left many a fabulous tale behind.
Consider these words: 몮Good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage, but excel in winning easy battles.몯 When Sun Tzu wrote about 몬victory,몭 he meant the kind of victory that is sealed in the temple while plans are being drawn, not the kind that몭s snatched from the enemy on the battlefield. This ideal of victory is, from the start, contemptuous of the kind of stirring war stories that become inspiration for poems and songs. Sun Tzu seeks victory long before battle erupts, a victory in which his troops need never dirty their blades with enemy blood.
Do Sun Tzu몭s warnings about war being 몬a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin몭 only apply to military leaders with armies behind them? Not at all; these words hold meaning for each and every one of us. For example, behind every move in a company몭s business operations, behind every pen-stroke, fortunes hang in the balance, lives could be changed, and reputations made or broken. The pen can be straight or crooked, wielded with truth or falsehood. One false move, and you can be sure it will come back to bite you, even if in the short term there seems to be no ill effect. 
How much life and money could be saved if we all embraced this 몬reverent wariness,몭 and this sense of responsibility, and recognized that every move we make could mean either a new lease on life or abject ruin for ourselves, our families, our companies and clients, and indeed for other people and society at large?
If I have a job, my workplace is an arena. It몭s a place where life and death face off. The way I carry myself through life affects the balance of life and death. This is the wariness and sense of responsibility that I hope every one of us can take into our hearts.

	
Sun Tzu몭s analytic method for strengths and weaknesses: 몬The Five Factors몭

Extract from the original text:
몮The art of war, then, is governed by five constant factors, to be taken into account in one몭s deliberations, when seeking to determine the conditions obtaining in the field. These are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and Discipline.몯

Analysis:
I have already mentioned that the concept of ji (plans) in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War is the way of calculating the balance of strengths and weakness between one몭s own forces and the enemy. As noted, it몭s in fact very similar to the SWOT analytic model used today in corporate strategy to calculate strengths, weakness, opportunities and threats.
Now, let몭s talk about how the balance of the five factors is calculated: The Moral Law, Heaven, Earth, the Commander, and Method and Discipline.
The 몬Moral Law몭 (the Dao) is about the ruler몭s ability to obtain the compliance of the people, which is achieved by winning their trust through demonstrating grace. Basically, it몭s about whether the people do what you tell them to do. It몭s about whether your ruler is an enlightened lord who possesses the Moral Law, or a crass despot to whom such a thing is a foreign concept. The Moral Law is about comparing each side몭s political situation, and the leadership ability of each side몭s ruler.
몬Heaven몭 and 몬Earth몭 form a pair. Heaven is about following the timing of nature (몬heaven몭), and Earth is about having knowledge of the lay of the land. Even if the way you carry out a mission is the same regardless of when you do it, you still have to consider the timing. If the timing is right, success will follow. But if the timing is wrong, nothing you can do will make it work.
Once you have compared the idiosyncrasies of each side몭s ruler, the natural timing, and the advantageousness of the terrain, it is time to compare 몬the Commander.몭 Whose general is more skillful? This is about appointing someone who is wise, competent and even-handed: a sage. This is why moles are often used during war 멪 agents who are sent to bribe the enemy ruler몭s most trusted advisors and ministers. This is the 몬stratagem of sowing discord.몭 Your agent infiltrates the enemy court and feeds the ruler incriminating information about his most capable generals. The aim is for him  to call these generals back to court and away from the front lines, and then send out some moron in their place. It몭s then that you strike.
Finally, we compare 몬Method and Discipline몭 (discipline is normally translated as 몬law몭). This has nothing to do with a country몭s politics, which is about the Moral Law, or the Dao, more than anything else. 몬Method and Discipline몭 are about military law.
The commentator Wang Xi wrote, 몮The art of war is governed by five factors. The Dao of using military force is about harmonious inter-personal relations (this is the most fundamental) and natural timing and favourable terrain (this is auxiliary).몯 One should only raise an army when all three of these factors have been achieved. Once you몭ve decided to raise an army, you have to choose your generals and your commander-in-chief. Once the commander-in-chief has been selected, it몭s time to drill method and discipline. The commander-in-chief must have strong abilities in leadership, formulating clear and strict rules and orders, and ensuring strict obedience.
That wraps up our explanation of the order of the five factors: first the 몬Moral Law,몭 then 몬Heaven,몭 followed by 몬Earth,몭 몬the Commander,몭 and finally 몬Method and Discipline.몭
The commentator Zhang Yu also makes a point of explaining the order of the five factors. He said the reason 몬the Commander몭 and 몬Method and Discipline몭 are put in last place is that whenever a ruler decides to raise an army to attack some neighboring despot, the first thing to be done, when you몭re planning in the temple, is to analyze how much loyalty each side몭s ruler inspires in their people. Are they are willing to die for him? The next step is to gauge the natural timing: whether going to war would be in keeping with the timing or in conflict with it. Then, the terrain must be analyzed 멪 is it easy or treacherous? When these three factors are in place, it몭s time to send your general out into the field. Once your troops have crossed the border and left your country, 몬Method and Discipline몭 are entirely in the hands of your commander.
That is why the five factors are put in this order. They are used in sequence to calculate and compare each side몭s strengths and weaknesses, and to form a picture of the prospects of victory or defeat.


Victory belongs to the side that is united in desire, from the highest general to the lowest soldier
	
Extract from the original text:
몮The Moral Law (Dao) causes the people to be in complete accord with their ruler, so that they will follow him regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger.몯

Analysis:
Sun Tzu몭s interpretation of the Dao is very clear. It is the 몬Moral Law몭 멪 the ability to make the people of one mind with their ruler, and the soldiers of one mind with their general. The winning side will be the one that can achieve this.
When the people and the leaders are united, share common moral values and have the same desires, the country has the internal foundation for waging war. This boils down to whether or not the people support the war effort. You should only fight if the whole country supports you. If you don몭t have unanimous support, you shouldn몭t make any rash moves.
This should not be confused with the righteousness of any given war; that is not what Sun Tzu is talking about. He is concerned with a different question: do the people support the war? Japan몭s pre-Second World War invasion of China is a good example. If the Dao was about having a righteous cause, then of course Japan did not have the Dao. However, that몭s not the answer you get if you look at it in terms of whether 몭the people are in complete accord with their ruler.몭 Japanese militaristic propaganda had already whipped the country into wild enthusiasm for war. The conditions existed where 몬they will follow their ruler regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger.몭 For the Japanese people, whether they lived or died did not even enter into the equation, with the most extreme example being the suicidal kamikaze fighter pilots.
If you look at China during the Japanese invasion and occupation (1937-1945 CE), it was not a unified state. There was constant fighting between regional warlords, on top of which, the Nationalist Party and the Communist Party were engaged in a civil war. The common people yearned for peace. They had no appetite for war, nor did they have a unifying Emperor who could inspire universal loyalty. China was on the losing side of the Japanese invasion for eight years, and lost at the very first of the five factors 멪 Moral Law, which compels people to be 몬in complete accord with their ruler.몭
The Dao, as it is interpreted by military men, is not about cosmic truths. To them, it몭s a simple question of whether the people support your war or not. Are they loyal to the ruler, or aren몭t they? Are they willing to lay down their life for their country? It몭s irrelevant whether the war is 몬just몭 or not. Anyone who goes to war will claim that they are on the right side. So, how do we know who is on the side of good? We can only even begin to see who 몬the good guys몭 were several years, or perhaps a decade or more, after the war has ended. After that, it takes many decades, or a century, before there is any kind of unanimous verdict. If you want to use the Dao to win a war, the key is to get three things right: policy, publicity (propaganda) and the mind-set of your troops. If you can do that, people will willingly fight by your side.
If you make the Dao your first priority, you understand that in war, the state몭s propaganda machine is just as important as its war machine. One could argue that몭s it몭s even more important. The Mao-era army leader, Lin Biao, realized the truth of this when he said that anyone attempting to seize power must rely on two barrels: the barrel of the gun, and the barrel of the pen. These same two barrels also are vital tools for solidifying power.
Some historians in the field of communications studies consider Sun Tzu the first thinker to write about propaganda, and indeed the origins of communications studies lie in military propaganda. Propaganda Technique in the World War, a book written after the First World War by American political scientist Harold Lasswell, became one of the seminal works of communications studies, and many of its ideas are identical to those of Sun Tzu.




Heavenly Timing: Military uses of meteorology
	
Extract from the original text:
몮Heaven signifies night and day, cold and heat, times and seasons.몯

Analysis:
Cao Cao commented on this passage: 몮When launching an attack, conform with Heaven on the basis of Yin and Yang and the four seasons. Hence, it is written in The Methods of the Sima (another of the Seven Military Classics, written by Sima Rangju): 몬One does not mobilize troops in winter or summer; this is how one extends love toward the people.몭몯
But, did Cao Cao stick to his own rules? Not at all. In fact, he suffered a famous defeat precisely because he didn몭t heed his own words 멪 the Battle of Redcliff. Before the battle, his adversaries Zhou Yu and Sun Quan had essentially carried out a SWOT analysis. They wrote: 몮Now is a time of great cold; the horses have no grass to eat, and Cao몭s troops have travelled far from the Chinese heartland; they are unfamiliar with the conditions in the south and are not yet acclimatized, so they are vulnerable to infectious illnesses; this is not the way one should handle one몭s army.몯
Yin and Yang, cold and heat, and the four seasons are a progressive series of concepts. Heaven is made up of two kinds of qi, Yin and Yang. When one expands, the other contracts, and it is this fluctuating dynamic that gives rise to cold and heat. The changing balance of cold and heat is marked by the four seasons.
In fact, in military discussions there are three layers of meaning within 몬Heaven몭:
1) The grand scheme of things in the world at large (몬all under heaven몭). This is about conducting one몭s worldly business in a way that conforms with Heaven.
2) Observing the stars, the clouds, and qi; burning turtle shells and divining the meaning in the cracks that form.
3) The four seasons; weather forecasting and using weather conditions to one몭s advantage in war.
The first point is about the macro-level situation and grand strategies. Questions relating to this point are worked out long before raising an army.
In discussions of the third point, strategists such as Wu Qi in his Warring States-era (475-221 BCE) book, The Wuzi, analyze weather conditions using a standard set of terms. These include 몬strong winds,몭 몬time of great cold,몭 몬midsummer몭 and 몬blistering heat.몭 Different decisions are made depending on the benefits or dangers of the conditions at hand. Weather can even be used as a weapon. For example, if you plan to use fire against your enemy, you몭ll need to rely upon the wind, which essentially means relying on 몬Heaven.몭
Of all three of the aspects of 몬Heaven,몭 the second one is the most talked about: divination. However, talking about it is precisely the key; it is about making sure everyone hears what you are saying. Basically, it몭s a kind of propaganda 멪 a useful kind of nonsense that몭s used to fool one몭s enemies 멪 but which one should never actually believe in. The famous military leader, Lord Jiang, who advised the first king of the Zhou dynasty, expressed it like this: 몮A wise man does not personally follow such things, though fools preoccupy themselves with them.몯
When Zhou Wu, who was to become the first King of Zhou, launched his attack on the tyrant king of the Shang dynasty, his troops were deployed for battle at Gongtou Mountain in Sishui. The weather that day was foul, with wild winds, torrential downpours, and thunder and lightning. The wind ripped the troops몭 battle flags and drums to shreds, and as Zhou Wu stood on his war chariot, his bodyguards were scared stupid.
Faced with this situation, Lord Jiang said: 몮In war, it is not necessarily always auspicious to conform with Heaven and the Dao, and likewise it is not always inauspicious to turn against them. However, if you lose control of events and of people, your whole army will be destroyed and you will be lost. As for ghosts and gods, Heaven and the Dao, these are things that cannot be seen, cannot be heard. Therefore, a wise man does not concern himself with such things, while fools allow themselves to be constrained by them. Here, today, you have capable and worthy men. The time to make your move and gain victory is not determined by the auspiciousness of the date, but by the favourableness of events; not by readings of yarrow stalks, but by the auspiciousness of the actual situation. Do not wait and pray, and blessings will follow.몯
Imediately after Lord Jiang said this, he gave the order to attack. Zhou Wu, the king-to-be, protested: 몮If we attack now we will be going against the god Taisui! The turtle shell readings are not propitious, the readings from the yarrow stalks are inauspicious, and the stars spell disaster! Please withdraw the troops.몯
Lord Jiang was infuriated, and said to Zhou Wu: 몮In our time, the Shang king has executed the sage Bi Gan, imprisoned the sage Qizi, and rules the land with the evil minister Fei Lian. Why should we not overthrow him?몯
Lord Jiang then said that the yarrow stalks and turtle shells used in divination were nothing but 몮dead, dry grass and moldy old bones.몯 He ordered one of his men to bring the stalks and shells to him, and had them burned. Then, he personally led his men into battle. Zhou Wu followed his lead, and on that day, their enemy 멪 the Shang king 멪 was destroyed.
In another example, Liu Yu, founder of the Song of the Southern dynasties, was advancing upon the city of Guanggu, having managed to surround the forces of the non-Chinese Murong people. He was about to give the order to attack when his generals decided to consult a calendar. They realized that it was an inauspicious day: 몬The day of moving toward destruction.몭 Each of the generals in turn insisted in no uncertain terms that they could not make any moves. But, Liu Yu said to them: 몮Huh! Moving toward destruction멞 this is very auspicious! I will be moving towards their destruction!몯 Liu Yu did indeed take the city of Guanggu on that day.
There is a popular Chinese saying to express the idea of 몬when the time is right.몭 It translates as: 몬When the Heavenly timing is good, when the land is favourable, and when the people are in harmony.몭 Here, we have seen that 몬Heavenly timing몭 is actually about people being in harmony 멪  all people under heaven being in harmony, not just one몭s own people.
For military men, the concept of 몬Heaven몭 is just military meteorology. It all boils down to things like reading the stars, the clouds and qi. Making divinations from yarrow stalks and burning turtle shells are just a part of propaganda. People who were in power, and who really controlled military situations, never actually believed in such superstitious things.




When on the march, you must move through uninhabited areas; the Enemy should be engaged in favourable terrain

Extract from the original text:
몮Earth comprises distances, great and small; danger and security; open ground and narrow passes; the chances of life and death.몯

Analysis:
Cao Cao wrote in his commentary: 몮Here, Sun Tzu is speaking about the nine different kinds of terrain, and their favourableness in different seasons. For a discussion of this, refer to the chapter entitled The Nine Situations.몯
The Nine Situations is found near the end of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, and it contains a detailed analysis of the features and uses of nine distinct types of terrain. Hence, the discussion of terrain in this part of the book is rather brief.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Whenever troops are to be used, it is valuable to first know the lay of the land. When you are familiar with the distances, you can use the stratagem of directness and indirectness.몯 You can know whether to take a direct route or a meandering one. When you know how difficult or easy the terrain is to traverse, you know where foot soldiers and cavalry have unique advantages, and thus where to deploy them. 몮When you know the locations of open ground and narrow passes, then you can gauge how many or how few soldiers you can use.몯 You can know where to spread your troops out, and where a bottleneck can be defended by a single man. 몮When you know the chances of death and life in various positions, then you can identify the positions that are amenable to fighting and to retreating.몯 For example, if you deploy soldiers in a position where there is a high 몬chance of death,몭 you know there will definitely be heavy fighting in this position. Conversely, if you deploy them in a position with a high 몬chance of life,몭 it will be easy to retreat and disperse.
Of all the generals of the early People몭s Liberation Army, the most capable was Su Yu. Among his admirers was Lin Biao, who said that Su was like a god of war, always descending upon his enemy from the sky. So, what were the bedrocks of Su몭s battle craft? Two things: maps and marching. Using maps, he would learn battlefield terrain by heart, and apparently would use maps so heavily that they were worn down into scraps of paper.
Marching and moving one몭s troops is a crucial part of fighting battles 멪 perhaps even more important than directly engaging the enemy. People often think that a battle has only really started once guns are being fired, but in reality, by the time that몭s happening the winner and loser have already been decided. And, crucially, they have been decided by troop movement: bringing soldiers into battle in the right place, at the right time, and with the right level of force. 	
This is known as 몬mobile warfare.몭 So, when people say that Su Yu was the most capable PLA commander, what they몭re really saying is that he was the most capable mover of troops. He invested more work and nuance than anyone else in studying and making use of terrain. During the Huaihai campaign of 1948-1949, Su Yu몭s troops were constantly moving around the war zone. They followed the principles of moving only through places where there were no other people, and engaging the enemy only when he enjoyed the advantages of favourable terrain and superior firepower. Fighting in this way, Su Yu was able to split a single army unit into ten mobile strike forces. He was like a master butcher, blades dancing everywhere, appearing and disappearing at will, like a ghost, and descending upon the enemy as if from the sky.
Along with troop movement, camping is also an important part of fighting wars. Campsites must be chosen on the basis of one몭s battle plan, and this is not only a matter of terrain but also of troop morale and battle effectiveness. Napoleon famously said that no matter how heavy the losses an army suffers in battle, it still does not have as negative an impact on the army as an unhygienic campsite.
We can see now that most of the work that determines a battle몭s outcome has nothing to do with what we hear about in the epic stories and the songs. The important parts happen well before the two sides engage 멪 by then, all that몭s left to do is watch the pre-determined result unfold. Isn몭t it the same in our day-to-day lives, in the world of work?




Be mindful of other people몭s interests, and make sure they know
	
Extract from the original text:
몮The Commander stands for the virtues of wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness.몯

Analysis:
Here, Sun Tzu tells us the order of importance of different personality traits that 몬The Commander몭 must possess. This is another case where his value system shows through 멪 he put 몬wisdom몭 in first place, whereas 몬courage몭 is relegated to fourth. Sun Tzu emphasizes wisdom because he wants to win before committing to battle, or even without fighting at all, rather than strong-arming the enemy몭s troops into submission by force. There is a Chinese four-character saying5 that translates as: 몬A man who is both wise and courageous.몭 Yet, Sun Tzu has split these two virtues apart, and put 몬sincerity몭 and 몬benevolence몭 between them. What should we make of this? 	
First of all, what exactly is 몬wisdom?몭
Du Mu wrote in his commentary: 몮The Dao of the ancient kings was predicated above all else upon benevolence. Meanwhile, among military commanders it is prevalent to prioritize the use of wisdom.몯 With wisdom, a commander can identify shifts in political currents and be agile enough to react effectively.
Shen Baoxu, who was a senior official during the Warring States era (475-221 BCE), said: 몮Without wisdom, one cannot have knowledge of the people몭s limits, and one is unable to gauge the number of people in the world.몯 Wisdom underpins the ability to understand the limits of one몭s own strength, the balance of power and the overall situation in the world, as well as the ability to plan properly and to adapt to changing circumstances on the battlefield.
That being said, it몭s not quite as simple as putting wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness in order. None of these virtues can exist independently of each other; if you have one, you must have them all.
Now, let몭s look at what our commentators have to say about this passage. Only three of them wrote about it.
Gu said: 몮With wisdom alone, man becomes treacherous; if a man showers benevolence on all without discrimination, he becomes weak; if a man is obstinately sincere, then he is a fool; if man knows only courage and force, then he becomes brutal; if a man is too strict when he gives commands, then he becomes cruel. The only way to become a worthy Commander is to possess all five of these qualities and to use each only when appropriate.몯
Mei Yaochen said: 몮With wisdom, a man can formulate plans; with sincerity, a man can hand out both rewards and punishments; with benevolence, a man can maintain closeness with the people; with courage, a man can make decisions resolutely; with strictness, a man can establish his power.몯
Wang Xi said: 몮The wise man looks first, and feels no doubts, but is able to reflect, plan, and fully understand changes in the currents of politics; the sincere man is consistent in what he says and in the orders he gives to subordinates; the benevolent man is devoted to compassion, and thus gains people몭s hearts; the brave man defends what is right and has no fear, and is decisive and resolute; the strict man uses his prestige to rectify the hearts of the masses. These five qualities all need each other; not a single one may be lacking.몯
Next, what is 몬sincerity?몭
Du Mu gives an accurate answer: 몮Sincerity means making clear criteria for rewards and punishments so that everyone is extremely clear about what punishment they can expect for each kind of violation and what reward they can expect for each kind of meritorious deed.몯
For the kingdom of Qin, the first to rise above the other warring Chinese states and form an all-China empire, 몬sincerity몭 was the key that unlocked the destruction of its six rival kingdoms. The Qin leaders몭 sincerity was not directed toward its rivals, but toward the armies and common people of the Qin kingdom. Particularly noteworthy was the mechanism by which deserving subjects were granted titles within the nobility, which was completely tied to military merit. A good example is the old Chinese word shouji (솤?[bd10]): shou means 몬a person몭s head,몭 ji means 몬grade/rank,몭 and together shouji means 몬a severed head.몭 The word comes from the Qin convention of elevating a person by one grade within the hierarchy of nobility each time they cut off an enemy몭s head! This was a way of implanting the codes of reward and punishment into the very language people spoke 멪 a person몭s head no longer just meant 몬a person몭s head,몭 but 몬one rank higher in the nobility.몭 The people of Qin were brave and eager to be at the front of the charge 멪 who wouldn몭t be with such rewards waiting to be claimed?
When the pioneering Qin minister, Lord Shang Yang, instituted a series of reforms, the first thing he did was establish a reputation for sincerity. He did this by planting a wooden pole in the ground by the south gate of the capital city. He stuck a notice on the pole, which said that whoever took the pole and carried it to the north gate would be awarded ten taels of gold. No one actually believed the notice. So, a new notice was written, raising the award to 50 taels of gold! This was enough for someone to give it a try, and sure enough, the man got his 50 taels of gold. From then on, the people believed whatever the government said.
Sincerity 멪 with it, the people몭s hearts and muscles are at your disposal; without it, the people몭s hearts and muscles are not yours to use.
There is another type of sincerity beyond just clear criteria for rewards and punishments, and that is 몬unspoken sincerity.몭 Only kings and the highest-ranking generals have total power to set rewards and punishments, but lower-ranked commanders still need to be able to lead troops into battle. Addressing this need, The United States Military Academy (also known as 몬West Point,몭) makes a specific demand of its students, and it몭s about leadership skills: Always be mindful of other people몭s interests, and make sure they are aware that you are doing so.
Sincerity is not just an administrative mechanism; more importantly, it is also a personal force that people can exert on others. Fundamental to this side of sincerity is the ability to include other people in your considerations. Without doing this, you cannot hope to truly have sincerity. The second most fundamental thing is the ability to make other people aware that they are a factor in our thinking. Otherwise, even if you are mindful of other people몭s interests, they won몭t know that and aren몭t likely to stick around at your side for long.
Next on the list of five virtues is 몬benevolence.몭
Du Mu comments: 몮The benevolent man loves the people and cherishes objects, and knows what it is to work diligently.몯
Both 몬loving people몭 and 몬cherishing objects몭 are fundamentally important. Valuing public property is part of being benevolent, and vice versa: if you don몭t place importance on resources, and instead use them wastefully, you cannot have 몬benevolence.몭 For example, imagine you몭re working overtime at the office. You몭re the last to leave, but you don몭t turn off your computer or the air conditioning, and you even forget to hit the light switch on your way out 멪 this behavior means that you don몭t have benevolence, because you don몭t 몬cherish objects.몭
In war, a benevolent general is one who loves his soldiers as though they were his own sons. In China, there is a famous story about the Warring States era (475-2221 BCE) general, Wu Qi. It몭s said that one of Wu Qi몭s men had a problem with his feet, which had become covered with festering wounds that oozed puss. When Wu Qi saw this, he got down on the ground, pressed his mouth to the soldier몭s feet and began to suck the puss out of his wounds. Later, the soldier몭s mother heard what had happened, and she was so distressed that she began to wail and cry. Someone asked her why she was crying 멪 after all, the great general had been so kind to her son. The mother replied, 몮My husband was a soldier too, and he had the same problem with his feet. General Wu did the same thing for him as he did for my son, and my husband was so moved by the general that he ended up sacrificing himself in a battle. Now that it몭s happened again, I몭m certain my son몭s going to give his life away, too!몯
Next: 몬courage.몭
Du Mu comments: 몮The brave general decisively orchestrates victory and forges ahead with momentum; he never hesitates, never yields an inch.몯
Chinese has a four-character phrase that translates directly as 몬fond of planning but lacking resolve,몭 which military experts use to describe someone who is always plotting and planning, but can never quite come to a firm decision. Why do people have this problem? It is because they have no courage! This behavior type is also common in the modern workplace: When you hear a colleague saying that a certain person can never seem to get things done, the basic problem with that person is a lack of courage, which causes them to be hesitant, slow and overly cautious. When someone behaves like this, it makes the people around them anxious.
Lack of courage in a general causes problems at two different stages of war. First, they몭re incapable of making a clear decision; and second, when they finally do settle on a decision, they don몭t have the resolve to execute it properly, and tend to flinch away from their work, ultimately backing themselves into a corner. 
No matter what you몭re setting out to achieve, it몭s important to embrace the spirit of self-sacrifice and to be willing to look death in the face and wrestle life from its jaws. It몭s worth mentioning here that although our stated aim in this book is to win first and fight later, there is no such thing as guaranteed success in this world. That몭s why you need courage to actually get things done.
Finally, let몭s look at 몬strictness.몭
Du Mu comments: 몮A strict general uses punishments and the prestige his name commands to maintain discipline among his forces.몯
Du Mu몭s commentary shows why, since ancient times, whenever a famous general first assembles troops ahead of launching a campaign, he always finds a reason to kill someone. It몭s a way to establish respect and fear. The ideal candidate for this kind of execution would be someone with high social status, perhaps a person who is trusted by the Emperor, and who considers themselves 몬untouchable몭 because they feel safe, sheltered in the shadow of the emperor. For example, Sun Tzu personally killed one of the King of Wu몭s favorite concubines, while the commander and author of one of the seven military classic, Sima Rangju, killed the Emperor몭s trusted aide, Zhuang Gu. The reason these people end up getting killed every time there몭s a war is that they didn몭t read the history books! People who believed themselves safe in the shelter of their titanic protectors were the easiest victims whenever there was a new war or political reform, because their status meant they were highly visible in the public eye, and yet they had no practical value to the state. Killing them is a way to enhance your authority without incurring any real losses for the state.
There몭s a life lesson here: no matter what you do, don몭t seek shelter between the legs of giants, because as soon as another giant so much as pats your protector on the back, you몭re liable to get squashed underfoot. You may think that you몭re as important as an extension of the Emperor몭s body, but you몭re not. As soon as the next political storm breaks, you몭ll be blown away like a speck of dust, or worse, your protector will be toppled and you몭ll be buried alive. This is one of the reasons why people of acumen follow the Confucian teaching of 몬walking the middle path몭 멪 they rely not on a protector but on their own independent personhood, their own value. They know their own value. They take care of themselves, make their own way in the world, are self-disciplined, follow the law, and do not overstep any boundaries. Only small-minded people seek out a protector, and their lives can never amount to much. 
		                                               ~
We몭ve now talked about 몬wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness.몭 It몭s easy enough to talk about, but another matter entirely to put these virtues into practice. So, how is it done?
In the waning years of China몭s last empire, a Qing dynasty scholar and politician named Zeng Guofan was tasked with leading an army. He was a bookish man, and every day he would page through Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. He measured himself against the standards of the five virtues, and it was clear that he didn몭t have any wisdom. After all, he몭d never even fought in a battle before! He could, at a stretch, claim to have sincerity and benevolence. As for courage, although he wasn몭t especially scared of dying, a lifetime devoted to scholarship had left him physically weak. His wrists were so limp, he didn몭t even have the arm strength to wring a chicken몭s neck! So, he could have had all the courage in the world, but he would never be warlike or fierce. The one virtue he really put into practice was 몬strictness.몭 The world around him had been in a state of chaos for his whole life, and he had a decades-long list of people who deserved to die. As far as he was concerned, the greatest act of benevolence for the people would be to 몮strew the country with evil men몭s corpses; then, benevolence and righteousness will once more return to the world.몯 In the end, he became known as 몬Zeng the scalp-shaver.몭
So, how did Zeng compensate for his lack of wisdom and courage? As far as he could see, there was no getting around the fact that he was basically inadequate, and the officers under his command were even worse 멪 they were just a motley bunch of peasants. His solution was to come up with two new virtues: 몬incorruptibility몭 and 몬clarity.몭
Zeng몭s reasoning for increasing the five virtues to seven was this: Ordinary soldiers are not qualified to demand that their leaders be wise, resourceful battle commanders; however, every person alive has a keen sense of their own interests, and soldiers are very aware of whether their leaders are clean in the way they handle money and fair in who they select for promotions. As a commander, to earn the respect of your men you cannot be greedy with money. Having 몬incorruptibility몭 means that you are transparent and always above board in the way you manage the accounts, and this is essential to gaining your subordinates몭 trust. When corruption is rampant in an army, there몭s no way that army is going to be able to fight. If you want your subordinates to trust and follow you, you should be stingy with yourself, but at the same time make sure that you regularly give out small rewards of money to your men, so that everyone is getting a piece of the pie.
Having 몬clarity몭 means that you keep careful notes about each of your subordinates몭 performance. You need to know who is always at the front of the charge, who is always close behind and ready to assist, who is always willing to risk their life and stand their ground, and who is always trying to stay out of danger. When you몭re not fighting, you should also closely watch who몭s hardworking and who몭s lazy. If you do this, you can give out the correct rewards and punishment, at the right time and in the right way.
As a commander, the question of whether you should be at the head of the charge is actually not very important, because you will often need to be directing proceedings from the rear. It몭s not even of primary importance to come up with ingenious plans and command every detail of what몭s happening on the battlefield. What몭s really important is to fairly distribute resources and have a clear idea of who is making a good example of themselves through excellent service, so you can achieve the correct balance between rewards and punishments. If you can do this, your men will be relaxed. When soldiers are relaxed, bravery comes easily, and they will be willing to lay down their lives for you.
The lesson here is that, as a leader, you need to not just pay attention to events, but to people as well. Don몭t make the mistake of thinking that if events are going in your favor, all is as it should be. Instead, you should make sure you know exactly what role each of your men is playing in the process of 몬everything going well.몭 You also need to have the ability to hand out both rewards and punishments. This is the only way to constantly improve your results.
People say that during the Chinese civil war (1927-1950 CE), the difference between the Communist army and the Nationalist army was that in the Communist army, the generals would shout: 몬Forward with me!몭 whereas the Nationalist generals would just shout: 몬Forward! For your commander!몭 This is actually nothing more than a myth. If you몭re the commander, and you몭re at the head of the charge, who will give the commands when you die? Who will be in charge of recognizing merit and giving rewards? Who will the soldiers follow? 
In the wars before the Han dynasty (206 BCE-220 CE) was formed, there was a warlord called Xiang Yu the Conqueror who always was at the front of the charge and in the thick of the fighting. But, the man who ultimately emerged victorious and founded the Han dynasty, Liu Bang, concerned himself only with rewards, punishments and working out who was serving him well and whose conduct fell short. It is far more important for a commander to have a clear picture of the conduct of his men than it is to fight alongside them. 
Zeng Guofan said that if you make 몬incorruptibility몭 and 몬clarity몭 your foundation, then 몬wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness몭 naturally and gradually follow. But, if you don몭t have this foundation, you cannot win the trust of your men, you won몭t be able to properly distribute rewards and punishments, and so the other five virtues become meaningless.



The bulk of a general몭s work is setting military discipline

Extract from the original text:
몮By method and discipline are to be understood the marshaling of the army in its proper subdivisions, the graduations of rank among the officers, the maintenance of roads by which supplies may reach the army, and the control of military expenditure. These five heads should be familiar to every general: he who knows them will be victorious; he who knows them not will fail.몯

Analysis:
몬Method and Discipline몭 occupy last place in the line-up of the 몬Five Factors몭 (몬the Moral Law,몭 몬Heaven,몭 몬Earth,몭 몬The Commander몭 and 몬Method and Discipline몭). So, it is often not taken very seriously. Readers tend to think of it simply as meaning 몬keeping discipline tight,몭 but in reality it몭s much more complex and technical. This is where the bulk of a general몭s work is to be done, rather than in actual battles, which are only a small blip on the timeline in comparison. 
The original wording of this passage is quite arcane, but luckily Cao Cao elucidated the practical meaning in his commentary. 몬The marshaling of the army몭 refers to the framework of an organization 멪 its structure 멪 and to the system through which commands are given and relayed. 몬Graduations of rank몭 basically refers to 몬human resources몭 systems.
몬Method and Discipline몭 is another way of saying 몬management,몭 and it encompasses a range of management solutions. Of course, in today몭s world, 몬management몭 is a technical business term, but the modern concept of 몬management studies몭 traces its earliest roots back to the military management of armies.
The topic of an army몭s organizational framework is a very complicated one. There are similarities with business 멪 when a company grows at a faster rate than the management is able to keep up with, it몭s doomed to collapse. When rapid business development happens, it몭s common for the organizational framework to become unclear and the structure confusing and strange. It몭s important to bring in organizational change at regular intervals; when this is done well, the company can unleash huge amounts of energy, but when it몭s done poorly, it can be brought to its knees.
In modern China, the process of 몬Reform and Opening Up몭 brought about many structural changes, as well as changes to 몬the graduations of rank몭 among officials, and to infrastructure. It also led to the creation of many small government organizations of all kinds, and so cross-departmental organizations were introduced to coordinate the new structures and ensure that new reforms could keep moving forward.
In China, a common definition of a 몬hero몭 is someone who is possessed of both great natural talent and great strategic abilities. The early 20th century general Zhang Xueliang, who inherited control of the northeast of China from his father after he was assassinated, said: 몮My father had the natural talent, but not the strategic ability, and Chang Kai-Shek (the Nationalist leader who was defeated by the Communists) had the strategic ability, but not the natural talent.몯
Very well put! 
Zhang몭s father was one of the most talented men of his generation, but he lacked an advanced understanding of politics. Meanwhile, Chiang Kai-Shek always had well-formulated plans, but didn몭t quite have the talent to execute them. Coming back to the 몬Five Factors,몭 these two qualities of a well-rounded 몬hero몭 can be divided like this: 몬strategic abilities몭 fall under the domain of 몬the Moral Law,몭 몬Heaven몭 and 몬Earth,몭 while 몬The Commander몭 and 몬Method and Discipline몭 fall under 몬natural talent.몭 A commander must have natural talent in order to effectively organize an army, mobilize troops, and provide guidance and driving force for an army in motion.
In business, successful entrepreneurs are both naturally talented and adept at strategy. However, between these two qualities, natural talent is more important. That몭s because you can always ask other people몭s advice on strategy or hire consultants, but the talent to execute can only come from yourself. If you have talent, it몭s possible to become a successful entrepreneur even without strategic ability. If you have strategic ability but little natural talent, the obvious choice in ancient times would be to become an advisor. In modern times, your best bet would be to start a consulting business.
Throughout Chinese history, the forces that have founded new dynasties have always been a perfect alliance of talented leaders and strategically sharp advisors. Some examples include Liu Bei (the founder of the Han kingdom of Shu, in modern-day Sichuan Province;  Zhuge Liang; Zhu Yuanzhang, the first Emperor of the Ming dynasty; Liu Bowen; Liu Bang, the first Emperor of the Han dynasty; and Xiao He.



The Dao is really just soft power

Extract from the original text:
몮Therefore, in your deliberations, when seeking to determine the military conditions, let them be made the basis of a comparison, in this way: (1) Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Dao (Moral Law)?몯

Analysis:
Sun Tzu took a seven-point approach to weighing the balance of the 몬Five Factors몭 between opposing forces, and the first point is represented by the question: 몬Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Dao?몭
Earlier in this book, we saw that the Dao is defined as 몬causing the people to be in complete accord with the ruler.몭 To achieve this, the ruler must widely share the fruits of victory, govern the people with appropriate policies, and not be stingy in handing out rewards and noble titles.
Commentators from different eras used the same historical example to illustrate this line from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: The general Han Xin몭s choice during the wars following the collapse of the Qin dynasty to fight for Liu Bang (who went on to become the first Emperor of the Han dynasty) instead of his rival warlord, Xiang Yu. 
Liu Bang apparently asked Han Xin: 몮Why have you chosen to follow me now, and not Xiang Yu?몯
Han Xin replied: 몮Xiang Yu treats the people cruelly, and is always reluctant to reward those who serve him. He has a big official stamp, specially made to mark letters of ennoblement and reward, yet he is loath to use it and always hasty to snatch it back to his bosom. He keeps it close to him and caresses it so much that its corners have become worn and rounded. But you, my lord, are different 멪 you govern the people with clear and simple rules, you reward your followers, and you set slaves free.몯
Being willing to spend money was an excellent choice by Liu Bang. After all, no matter how big the checks he wrote, it was always someone else who had to pay, because at that time he was a revolutionary in a crumbling empire that did not yet belong to him. But, he also did not hesitate to use what money he had already secured in his purse. He bought the loyalty of his enemies몭 generals with the help of his advisor, Chen Ping, who did his dirty work for him. He didn몭t seem to have a budget, and even after emerging victorious as Emperor of China, he continued to spend at will. When he first announced new policies as Emperor, he declared that whoever brought him Xiang Yu몭s head would be made a lord of 10,000 households and granted the title of Marquis. When Xiang Yu finally gave up at the River Wu, just before he slit his own throat, he was looking at the crowd of Liu Bang몭s soldiers surrounding him when he saw a man who used to fight for him, Lu Matong. Xiang Yu cried out to Lu: 몮Lu Matong, my old friend! My head is yours!몯 Then Xiang Yu drew his knife and cut his own throat. The other warriors didn몭t pay any attention to Xiang Yu몭s last words, and hurried to seize the warlord몭s body for themselves. After the body had been hacked to pieces, five different men ended up with Xiang Yu몭s body parts. They all went to Liu Bang, each seeking credit for bringing Xiang Yu to their lord.  Liu Bang didn몭t ask any questions, and immediately settled the matter by making all five of the men Marquises.
The Dao of Liu Bang was to orient himself downwards, towards the people; his Dao manifested in the rewards mechanisms he used and in his methods of governing his people. His approach to politics and governance was miles apart from Xiang Yu몭s. For example, after Liu Bang delivered the finishing blow to the collapsing Qin dynasty, he didn몭t touch the fallen empire몭s treasure troves or the women. He didn몭t move into the imperial palace, and he immediately sealed the state treasury. He withdrew his troops, and established just three laws: anyone guilty of murder will be executed; anyone guilty of harming another person will be beaten; and anyone guilty of theft will be punished accordingly. He then abolished all of the harsh laws and draconian punishments that had been enforced under the old Qin legal code. Because of Liu Bang몭s actions, the people of Qin loved him devotedly. They continued to whole-heartedly support him from behind the lines during the wars that followed.
But after Xiang Yu declared himself Emperor and banished Liu Bang, he slaughtered the people of the old Qin capital, Xianyang, and killed the Qin king, Ziying, whose life had originally been spared by Liu Bang after he surrendered. Xiang Yu then loaded up wagons with Qin몭s riches and women and carted them away before setting fire to the Qin palaces and government buildings. The fire burned for three months. So, why did Xiang Yu kill those people when peace had already been secured? He did it so that he could take their women and valuables. Xiang Yu몭s actions show that he didn몭t comprehend how to take possession of an empire; his desires went no further than riches and women.
After Xiang Yu seized the women and wealth of Qin, he split the state in three, and in each of these three areas he installed one of his followers, giving them the title of 몬king.몭 Because of this, people in the province of Shaanxi even today talk about 몬the three Qin regions.몭 So who did Xiang Yu pick to be the three kings of Qin? In fact, they were all former generals of the Qin Empire who had surrendered: Zhang Han, Sima Xin and Dong Yi. What kind of background did these men have? Between them, they had been in command of 200,000 Qin troops when they surrendered to Xiang Yu. Accepting their surrender, Xiang Yu had all 200,000 of their men buried alive. Only the three generals were spared. Because of this, the people of Qin hated their guts; these men had betrayed 200,000 of their own countrymen and had acquired vast riches and status for their deeds. These were the men who Xiang Yu later charged with the vital task of leading armies raised from among the people of Qin to block Liu Bang몭s advance at the strategic mountain pass town of Hanzhong. But, given their past, how could they be expected to succeed?
By asking the question, 몬Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Dao,몭 we can see why Xiang Yu lost so badly against Liu Bang.
Even further back in history, the first leader who really had the Dao was Lord Tang of the state of Shang, who became the first King of the Shang dynasty. It is said that when he was digging foundations for a house, he unearthed some human remains that had been buried without any plaque identifying the deceased몭s name. Tang treated the remains respectfully, and gave them a proper burial. Word spread of this deed, and people said: 몮Tang of Shang is so respectful to dead people; he must be even more respectful of living people!몯 Later, Tang saw peasants who had set up nets in the shape of a closed rectangle, to catch birds. He ordered them to take down the nets on all but one side, urging them not to kill wantonly, but to give the birds a chance. When word spread of this deed, people said: 몮Tang of Shang treats animals so well; he must treat people even better!몯 
Because of Tang몭s reputation, when he launched military campaigns to attack states in the east, people in states to the west complained: 몬Why won몭t he attack us?몭 Likewise, when he attacked states to the east, people in the states to the west were offended. Everyone wanted Tang as their ruler.
Having the Dao 멪 the Moral Law 멪 is the same as having soft power. Liu Bang had soft power, whereas Xiang Yu relied entirely on hard power. 몬Having the Dao몭 is another way of saying that someone has great charisma. It is also the same as the Confucian concept of having the 몬Way of the King.몭 The Confucian philosopher Mencius explained that there is a difference between The Way of the King and The Way of the Hegemon. The Way of the Hegemon requires control over a huge country and relies on the power brought by extensive territory and well-stocked armories. When a ruler follows The Way of the Hegemon, the extent of his kingdom is directly proportionate to his material power. By contrast, The Way of the King does not require a large state; it can be practiced just as well in a small state, and then used to expand the small state until it covers the entire known world. Lord Tang originally ruled over a very small state, and King Wen, the first King of the Zhou dynasty, only had a slightly larger state; both men were rulers of small fiefdoms, but both won the hearts of people all over China by practicing The Way of the King.
Mencius몭 words offer great insight to those of us engaged in smaller-scale endeavors. The Way of the King is not only for kings; it is about how to become a king. What about you? Are you imbued with the Dao? Is your boss imbued with the Dao?


Figure out the 몬Five Factors and Seven Considerations몭 and you몭ll learn who will win and who will lose. Then, it is time to send your army to deliver your result on the battlefield
 
Extract from the original text:
몮(1) Which of the two sovereigns is imbued with the Dao (Moral Law)? (2) Which of the two generals has most ability? (3) With whom lie the advantages derived from Heaven and Earth? (4) On which side is discipline (laws and commands) most rigorously enforced? (5) Which army is stronger? (6) On which side are officers and men more highly trained? (7) In which army is there the greater constancy both in reward and punishment? By means of these seven considerations I can forecast victory or defeat. The general that hearkens to my counsel and acts upon it will conquer: let such a one be retained in command! The general that hearkens not to my counsel nor acts upon it will suffer defeat 멪 let such a one be dismissed!몯

Analysis:
The second question, 몬Which of the two generals has most ability,몭 is about comparing the skills of each side몭s commanders. There is a common scenario in war, where one side knows that the enemy has a dangerously good general and so refuses to engage in battle. Instead, they send agents to pay off the enemy king몭s advisors and ministers, and sow division in the enemy ranks, souring relations between the king and his star general. Then, the enemy king recalls the general and sends out an unqualified fool to take command of the front line. As soon as this happens, you can attack and win the war in one fell swoop.
The third question is about who holds the advantages that come from heaven and earth, including timing and terrain. A good example of this is when Russia annexed the Crimea in 2014. Russia held all the advantages of terrain and timing, and America and the European Union could only watch helplessly from the sidelines.
The fourth question is: 몬On which side is discipline most rigorously enforced?몭 Cao Cao comments: 몮When laws are established they are not to be broken, and if they are broken, the offender must be executed.몯 There is a story about Cao Cao honoring this principle. He was on the march with his army, and it was the season when wheat was just about ripe. He told his men that anybody who damaged any wheat would be separated from their head in swift order. Little did he expect that his own horse, taking fright, would bolt into a wheat field and trample the crops. This was a conundrum. He obviously couldn몭t cut off his own head, so instead he drew his sword and cut off his beard.
In the original text, the words 몬laws몭 (fa) and 몬commands몭 (ling) are used (translated together as 몬discipline몭 in the English version). Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Laws should be used to bring the people together, and commands should be used to make them as one.몯
