The fifth question is, 몬Which army is stronger?몭 Du Mu comments: 몮Leaders and followers must be in harmony; the side that has the courage to fight and which also has more soldiers and chariots is the stronger.몯 Zhang Yu comments: 몮The stronger side has sturdier chariots, stronger horses, braver soldiers, and sharper weapons; when the men hear the war drums they feel joy, and when they hear the gong (which signals retreat) they feel filled with anger.몯
The sixth question is, 몬On which side are officers and men more highly trained?몭 This question is loaded with meaning, and is not at all the same as asking which army is stronger. In general, people have a high potential to be moulded, meaning that any ordinary, run-of-the-mill person can become a professional in any field of work, provided they have the right training. Even more so, it몭s important to be aware that if a person spends their whole life training in only one thing, they can become world-class in that one thing.
If you put in work and sweat during peacetime, less blood will be spilled in times of war. For example, what makes 몬special forces몭 special is not that they are full of superhumans, but rather the training they receive, and the massive investment that goes into that training. Before a mission, they train for months on end in a location modeled to simulate the mission location, rehearsing again and again all of the potential scenarios that might arise during the actual mission. Training is everything; it is indispensable to achieving goals, whatever they may be.
The seventh and final question is, 몬In which army is there the greater constancy both in reward and punishment?몭 Reward and punishment is a field of study all its own, and it wouldn몭t be wrong to call it the factor that determines an army몭s combat effectiveness. Reward and punishment hinge on two vital requirements: they must be both timely and appropriate.
To quote from the ancient military text, The Methods of the Sima: 몮By not delaying in giving rewards, the people are able to quickly realize the benefits of good behavior. By not making exceptions in dispensing punishments, the people will quickly witness the dangers of bad behavior.몯 If the leader doesn몭t hand out rewards and punishments at the right times, his effectiveness will be heavily compromised.
Another early commentator on Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, a man named Wangzi, comments: 몮If rewards do not fit with what is called for, then they only lead to waste and not to gratefulness; if punishments do not fit with what is called for, then they lead only to slaughter and not to reverence.몯 People won몭t be grateful for what you give them if you hand out rewards casually, and if you use punishments excessively, all you몭ll get is people몭s hatred and anger.



The 몬Way of righteousness몭 and the 몬Way of deception몭

Extract from the original text:
몮While heeding the profit of my counsel (ji6), avail yourself also of any helpful circumstances over and beyond the ordinary rules. Accordingly, as circumstances are favourable, one should modify one몭s plans.몯

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: 몮This lies beyond ordinary methods.몯
Li Quan elaborates in his commentary: 몮When a favourable plan has been decided upon, then harness the changes in circumstances; 몬helpful circumstances over and beyond the ordinary rules몭 means 몬that which is beyond ordinary methods.몭몯
Du Mu comments: 몮Calculating advantages and dangers is fundamental to all military matters. When the advantages and dangers have been identified, then one may seek additional opportunities beyond the ordinary methods in order to press one몭s advantage.몯
Although I previously said that Sun Tzu몭s approach to planning is about calculating and comparing the positions of both sides, rather than coming up with ingenious tricks and ploys, he actually doesn몭t take tricks and ploys entirely off the table. They occupy one section of The Art of War, which begins with the line: 몮All warfare is based on deception.몯
Planning, along the lines of the SWOT analytical model, is fundamental 멪몬heeding the profit of my counsel몭 means determining through calculations that the odds of victory are on your side. Once you몭ve done this, it몭s time to go to war. But, beyond the fundamentals, Sun Tzu says that you should 몮avail yourself also of any helpful circumstances over and beyond the ordinary rules.몯 What he means by this is that you should adjust your plans to take advantage of opportunities.  
Du Mu comments: 몮It is impossible to foresee what we call 몬circumstances.몭 Circumstances may be favourable to the enemy and thus disadvantageous to me, or they may be disadvantageous to the enemy and thus favourable to me; when circumstances reveal themselves, then you can begin to create from them an advantage, and thus secure victory.몯
Wang Xi comments: 몮As concerns 몬circumstances,몭 they are about harnessing changes.몯
And so, this passage opens a discussion about how to gain advantage from the changing circumstances of a battle, while avoiding the dangers; how to turn disadvantages into advantages, respond to opportunities and seize the initiative, master the shifting contours of a battle in real-time, and create momentum. These topics are discussed in detail in The  its 몭s fifth  chapter (Formation), and sixth chapter (Energy), which together embody the essence of Sun Tzu몭s insights.




Inability to wait is a major character flaw

Extract from the original text:
몮All warfare is based on deception. Hence, when able to attack, we must seem unable; when using our forces, we must seem inactive; when we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away; when far away, we must make him believe we are near. Hold out baits to entice the enemy, spreading disorder. Then, crush him. If he is secure at all points, be prepared for him. If he is in superior strength, evade him. If your opponent is of choleric temper, seek to irritate him. Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant. If he is taking his ease, give him no rest. If his forces are united, separate them. Attack him where he is unprepared, appear where you are not expected. These military devices, leading to victory, must not be divulged beforehand.몯

Analysis:
In this rapid-fire passage, Sun Tzu reels off twelve deception-based strategies, most of which aim to trick the enemy into making an error of judgment. It몭s about using temptation to force a mistake. But, what do you do when the enemy doesn몭t fall for your trick? What you do is wait. In this game, you need to out-wait the enemy, send agents to infiltrate their camp, and make all kinds of arrangements for different scenarios. Essentially, you have to wait until the balance is broken and the odds of victory tip in your favor; only then can you engage in combat.
Sun Tzu몭s basic principle is to win first and fight later. Or, if you can몭t win, you don몭t fight. If the odds aren몭t in your favor, you wait.
This is precisely why it is a major character flaw to be incapable of waiting. People often think that real men, or heroes, have to fight. They don몭t understand that waiting is actually part of fighting, and an extremely important part at that.
There is a passage in the ancient Tang dynasty military text, Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Duke Li of Wei, in which the Emperor says: 몮Through my readings of military books both ancient and new, I have discovered that there is but one crucial teaching 멪 use a multitude of diverse methods to fool one몭s foe. That is, it is necessary to think of every possible way to entice the enemy into making a blunder; he makes one false move, and you expose his weaknesses.몯 
Duke Li of Wei, a prominent Tang dynasty general, replies in the text몭s dialogue: 몮That is correct. War is like chess: one false move, and you lose control of the entire board. Nothing you do after that can restore what you have lost.몯
Unfortunately, Emperor Taizong몭s grandson, Xuanzong, lacked his grandfather몭s wisdom. At a key moment of the devastating An Lushan Rebellion, imperial general Geshu Han was in possession of an impregnable fortress at the mountain pass of Tongguan, blocking the path of the rebel An Lushan몭s armies towards the capital, Chang몭an. Geshu Han was intent on holding his position, and dead set against marching out to engage the enemy. But Xuanzong was eager to end the rebellion, and ordered Geshu Han to attack An Lushan in the open field. Geshu Han was faced with a difficult choice. Xuanzong had previously executed two of the Empire몭s leading generals, Feng Changqing and Gao Xianzhi, because he considered them inept. Even though Geshu Han knew that attacking An Lushan would doom his army, he also knew that if he refused to attack it would cost him his own head, with some other general being sent to take his place. So, he was forced to lead his forces out of the fortress. His 200,000-strong army was annihilated and Tongguan Pass was lost. When Xuanzong realized in a panic that the capital was vulnerable, he fled for Sichuan.
Our commentators had a lot to say about these twelve stratagems of deception, so in the following chapters we will take a closer look at each of the stratagems in turn.


       
Truly great generals only need one decisive battle to win a war
     
Extract from the original text:
몮When able to attack, we must seem unable.몯
       
Analysis:
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Seeming weak when in fact you are strong, seeming timid when in fact you are brave; this is how Li Mu defeated the Xiongnu, and how Sun Bin destroyed Pang Juan.몯
Li Mu, a general from the state of Zhao, was one of the four great generals of the Warring States period (475-221 BCE), the other three being Bai Qi, Lian Po and Wang Jian.
Li Mu was in charge of the garrisons of the Dai and Yamen commanderies, tasked with fending off the Xiongnu, who were nomadic warriors from the steppes to the north of China. Li Mu treated his soldiers exceptionally well, trained them rigorously and carried out frequent inspections. He insisted that his men obey just one order: Fighting the enemy is forbidden! He decapitated anyone who had the audacity to leave camp looking for a fight. For years, Li Mu studiously avoided fighting. Because he had a strategy of 몬fortifying the walls and evacuating the countryside,몭 which required all of the local people to retreat behind the fortified walls of his garrison camp, when Xiongnu raiders came prowling there was nothing for them to loot. 
Li Mu continued with this strategy for several years, never engaging in a fight. This was distressing not only for the Xiongnu raiders, but also for his own men, and for his king. Believing Li to be a coward, the King of Zhao recalled him and sent a new general in his place. The new general scrapped Li Mu몭s strategy, and made regular trips out of the camp with his troops to attack the Xiongnu. This didn몭t go well; he lost more battles than he won, and suffered heavy losses in the process. The King of Zhao had no choice but to ask Li Mu to return to his old post, but Li Mu declined, pleading bad health. 
The King of Zhao, now out of options, promised Li that he would never again meddle in his military strategy. So, Li Mu returned to his post and reinstated his strategy of 몬absolutely no fighting.몭 However, this did not mean he was idle during those years 멪 in fact, he was even busier than if he몭d been at war the whole time, personally running an intense training regime for his troops. After years of training in camp, Li Mu몭s border defense army was in excellent shape, morale was high, and his men were so eager for action that they would have been willing to go without pay or reward just for one proper fight against the Xiongnu. Meanwhile, the Xiongnu had grown complacent.
Finally, Li Mu decided the time was right for a decisive battle. He carefully selected his best troops and equipment 멪 1,300 war chariots, 13,000 war horses, 50,000 foot soldiers brave enough to charge the enemy lines head-on, as well as 100,000 archers 멪 and he marched to war. Li employed the stratagem of 몬luring the enemy in deep,몭 first sending a large number of nomadic herders with accompanying livestock out into the countryside. The Xiongnu sent a small force to intercept the nomads and steal their livestock, and Li Mu allowed them to 몬win,몭 intentionally losing several thousand men to the Xiongnu. The Xiongnu were elated by their little victory, and their chieftain, Chanyu, decided to launch a full invasion with a much larger force. As the Xiongnu advanced, Li Mu spread his troops wide in an ambush formation, surrounding the invaders on two sides. With one stroke, Li eliminated 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry. The Xiongnu chieftain fled into the wilderness, while the victorious Li Mu took full advantage of the momentum his victory gave him to attack and destroy two other nomadic tribal confederations, the Chanlan and the Dong Hu, while also subjugating the Lin Hu. For more than ten years after this battle, the Xiongnu didn몭t once come near the borders of Zhao. 
Military thinkers put great store in the ability to win a war with a single, decisive battle. War should not be a back-and-forth process; instead, generals should save their energy and build their strength, waiting for the opportune moment to end the war in a single move. Some might consider a general to be 몬great몭 if, during a ten-year command at a frontier fortress, he fought 100 battles and won all of them in spectacular fashion. But, what if the price of this general몭s valor is 10,000 corpses on the battlefield? The general retires with a glittering record, yet not a single problem has been solved. Then, the next 몬great몭 general is sent out to carry on doing the same thing: to keep on fighting. Li Mu was an exception. He bided his time and didn몭t fight a single battle for ten years, and when the time finally came, he fought just one battle, and in doing so he actually solved a problem for his country.
I hope I have now shown why the ability to win a war with a single battle makes a general truly great. What good are a hundred victories? All it means is that you몭ve fought many, many times without solving the problem, and at the end of those 100 battles, you still have to keep on fighting! A general with a 100% record in 100 fights is actually incompetent, lacking even a basic understanding of the art of war. Anyway, the example of a hundred-victory general is hypothetical 멪 have you ever heard of a general with that good a record? Anyone who would make that claim isn몭t telling the whole story. The truth is that a certain number of losses are inevitable.
The principle of this chapter can be applied to anything you do, and summarized as: 몬When the time isn몭t right, don몭t do a thing. When the time comes, use only a single move, and make sure it solves your problem.몭 The undoing of many a project comes from chronic over-activity, and the motivation behind chronic over-activity invariably boils down to some kind of anxiety complex. If you ask Li Mu what losses he incurred by refusing to fight, the answer would be 몬none.몭 But, that didn몭t prevent the troops under his command, or the Xiongnu, or the King of Zhao from feeling anxious. Anxiety is what caused the King of Zhao to act, recalling and replacing Li Mu, rather than any reasonable objection to Li몭s performance. After all, Li had done his job, which was to defend the border, flawlessly. The king몭s anxiety made him feel that he had to do something, and that only by doing something would he relieve himself of this feeling of anxiety. 
Beware of acting from a place of anxiety; it will very likely be your undoing.
Remember to focus on the work that is actually important: 1) Preparation; and 2) Waiting.
Preparation is up to you. It involves building strength, training your forces and drumming up morale. Waiting, on the other hand, means waiting for the enemy to make a mistake, for an opportunity to present itself. If the enemy doesn몭t make a mistake, it will be very difficult to win. As Emperor Taizong said, the art of deception in war is about making use of various solutions in order to lure the enemy into slipping up. The main way of doing this 멪 the most frequently used way 멪 is expressed in Sun Tzu몭s line: 몮When able to attack, we must seem unable.몯 It has worked time and time again.
Li Mu몭s example, biding his time for ten years, is an extreme one. But, it is not the most extreme. That accolade might go to King Gou Jian of the Warring States kingdom of Yue, who waited for 18 years to destroy his rival, Fuchai, King of Wu.



Only a handful of simple stratagems exists to choose from. The key is knowing how to put on a show

Extract from the original text:
몮When using our forces, we must seem inactive.몯

Analysis:
The meaning of this line is the same as the previous one (몬When able to attack, we must seem unable몭). Let몭s look at another classic case study: the battle of Baideng during the early years of the Han dynasty.
After Liu Bang established the Han dynasty in 206 BCE, he launched a campaign against the Xiongnu, the same northern nomads who featured in the previous chapter. At first, Liu Bang, now known as Emperor Gaozu, won victory after victory. Pleased with his achievements, the Emperor was keen to launch an all-out assault on the Xiongnu and root them out once and for all. He sent over a dozen reconnaissance agents to the Xiongnu area, all of whom came back telling of depleted Xiongnu armies 멪 no warriors and no horses. The time was ripe to attack, they said. Emperor Gaozu sent another advisor, Lou Jing, to carry out further reconnaissance. Lou Jing returned from his mission and told the Emperor that he must not attack. When the Emperor asked why, Lou Jing replied that it is normal when two countries go to war for each side to show off their power. Yet, all that he saw in the Xiongnu lands was emaciated horses and listless soldiers; all the men seemed old, feeble, disabled or sick. Obviously, this was a Xiongnu trick to lure us in, a show that they were putting on for our benefit, he said.
But Emperor Gaozu had already made up his mind to go to war. As he listened to Lou Jing, he flew into a rage and had Lou thrown into a dungeon. He accused the man of distracting him from his battle plans, and threateningly told him he몭d deal with him after he returned victorious from the war. 
Emperor Gaozu mobilized all the forces at his disposal and gave the order to march. He and his armies were camped on the Baideng plateau when they were ambushed by the Xiongnu chieftain. A force of 400,000 Xiongnu warriors completely surrounded Emperor Gaozu. The enemy was not exactly 몬depleted,몭 after all. They had plenty of horses, too 멪 a mass of white horses hemmed in the Chinese forces from the east, black horses from the west, and red horses from the north. To put the two sides몭 cavalry resources in perspective, Emperor Gaozu couldn몭t muster up a handful of uniformly white horses to pull the chariots for his honor guard on the day he ascended his throne as Emperor of all China.
The Han army was besieged for seven days and seven nights, despite several desperate attempts to break through the enemy encirclement. Hunger exacerbated the effect of freezing temperatures, and many soldiers lost fingers to frostbite. Emperor Gaozu knew that he was trapped, and he turned to his spy, Chen Ping, for advice. Chen Ping, a past master in the arts of deception and inciting insurrection, hatched a plot. Chen went to the Xiongyu chieftain몭s queen, offering her a bribe and telling her: 몮The Han Emperor is no ordinary mortal; he is favored by the gods. Have you heard how he beheaded the white snake at the beginning of his rebellion against the old Emperor? If your people keep fighting him, there is no way to know if it will bring fortune or ruin to the Xiongnu, but for you personally, it몭s sure to bring ruin.몯 The queen asked Chen Ping: 몮What ruin do you speak of?몯 Chen replied: 몮You Xiongnu are not used to life in southern lands, so it will bring you nothing good if you seize our land. The only reason your people fight against us Han is because you want our women, our gold and our silk. There are a great many beautiful women in our lands, and men are easily corrupted by money; if your chieftain gets hold of our gold, silk and beautiful women, he is sure to lose his affection for you, my lady. But there is another way: we can give you gold and silk right now, and you can make sure that your husband does not lay hands upon any beautiful women.몯
The queen was impressed by Chen Ping몭s reasoning, which seemed to her to get right to the heart of the matter. What good was it to her whether or not her husband became even greater than he already was? What mattered to her was that she could use her husband for her own benefit. So, one night in bed with the chieftain, she began to push the idea that Emperor Gaozu had the gods on his side, and she urged her husband not to do anything extreme.
The Xiongnu chieftain felt ill at ease 멪 not least because Emperor Gaozu had always had an aura of power about him 멪 and he began to feel uncertain about what the next day might bring, not to mention the worrying failure of his two allies to arrive at the agreed time. What if they had turned against him and joined Emperor Gaozu? The chances of this were not small. After all, his wife had already been turned against him. So, the chieftain decided to quit while he was ahead. He negotiated a treaty, took his money and allowed Emperor Gaozu to return home.
Anyone can see how simple Sun Tzu몭s stratagems are. Nobody actually needs thirty-six stratagems anyway; four or five are enough to cover any situation. The important part is the execution. When you put on a show for your enemy, you have to know how to scratch their metaphorical itch. And, when you몭re on the receiving end of one of these 몬shows,몭 you몭re in a similar position to a soccer goalkeeper getting ready to defend a penalty shot. As you watch the striker, you know for sure that, no matter what trickery he tries, he몭s either going to shoot to the left or to the right. But, what you can never know is which way he will shoot on this particular occasion 멪 left or right? This means that if you fall for the trick this time, this doesn몭t mean you won몭t fall for the same trick again next time. It몭s the same with the reports about the Xiongnus몭 emaciated horses and listless warriors: it몭s possible that this represents the real situation, but it몭s also possible that it몭s a trick. Emperor Gaozu, just like a goalkeeper choosing between left and right, made a judgment call. Based on what he knew, he decided that the reports coming in from his reconnaissance agents did in fact represent the Xiongnus몭 real situation. At that point, it was impossible to say if he몭d fallen for a trick. His agents could just as easily have come back with reports of powerful Xiongnu armies, and Emperor Gaozu might have determined that this was a trick, and attacked anyway.
Even more rational decision-making was demonstrated by the Xiongnu chieftain and his queen 멪 you certainly couldn몭t say in that situation that the chieftain was fooled by Emperor Gaozu.
One positive trait about Emperor Gaozu emerged from this story. When he returned with his army, he set Lou Jing free and granted him a noble title. Gaozu had the courage to admit when he was wrong. However, he also executed every one of the reconnaissance agents who had told him he should attack the Xiongnu. It turns out he wasn몭t so good at taking responsibility for decision-making.
On the subject of taking responsibility for decision-making, the Qing dynasty scholar and general, Zeng Guofan, offers his thoughts: 몮I am the decision-maker, and the responsibility for my decisions lies with me, not with my advisors. There is no such thing as a certain outcome, and one cannot simply look at outcomes, nor blame advisors.몯 He also critiqued himself in his diary: 몮Even though I know not to, I still find it difficult not to scowl when I cross paths with someone whose advice I have listened to with the result that I have got something badly wrong. But this is my problem, and I need to pay more attention to that fact.몯
If Emperor Gaozu devoted half the thought to these things that Zeng Guofan did, a dozen or more families would have been spared a terrible fate.



No certainties in victory and defeat 멪 the leader must take responsibility for decisions

When Emperor Gaozu withdrew his army from Baideng, he freed from prison the advisor who had urged him not to go to war, Lou Jing, and gave him a noble title. In this respect, he did a better job than Yuan Shao, a general of the late Han dynasty, and subsequently a warlord after the Han dynasty collapsed.
Before the battle of Guandu, after which Cao Cao established dominance over north China, Yuan Shao몭s advisor, Tian Feng, told his lord that it would be better to hold his position than to attack. In response, Yuan Shao repeated Emperor Gaozu몭s words of several hundred years earlier, to the effect that Tian Feng몭s advice was distracting him from his planning. Yuan Shao threw Tian Feng in a dungeon and threatened to deal with him upon his victorious return. But, Yuan Shao lost his battle. When news of the defeat spread, the jailer told Tian Feng: 몮Looks like you몭ll be alright this time.몯 But Feng Tian replied: 몮You don몭t know our lord. If he몭d won, he몭d be in a fine mood and would forget about how I wronged him. But if he really has lost, he몭ll feel humiliated by the very sight of me. Killing me will be his way out of having to face that humiliation.몯 Sure enough, Yuan Shao accused Tian Feng of gloating over his lord몭s defeat and put him to death.
While Emperor Gaozu cannot be directly compared with Yuan Shao, Gaozu did kill the advisors who told him the Xiongnu were open to attack, because of his own failure to take responsibility for his decisions, choosing to outsource it to them instead.
Zeng Guofan dedicated part of his writings to the need for leaders to stand up and take responsibility for their decisions. He felt compelled to do this because he knew there are no certainties in victory and defeat, and these things are not simply a matter of planning.
Zeng included five different examples to illustrate his points, of which three address the same subject: various Emperors몭 attempts to weaken overly powerful feudal lords and bring them to heel.
The first example is from the Han dynasty. An advisor named Chao Cuo advised Emperor Jing to do something about the dangerously powerful feudal lords, and as a result, six regional 몬kingdoms몭 rose up in rebellion, demanding that the Emperor 몬cleanse himself of evil influences몭 by executing Chao Cuo. In a panic, Emperor Jing hastily complied, executing Chao Cuo. But this didn몭t stop the King of Wu from continuing his insurrection. Eventually, Emperor Jing emerged victorious, and so the outcome in this case was that the Emperor successfully wrested power away from his feudal vassals.
Much later, during the Ming dynasty, two advisors, named Qi Tai and Huang Zicheng, urged the Jianwen Emperor to do the same thing, with the result that the King of Yan rebelled and similarly demanded the execution of Qi Tai and Huang Zicheng. The Emperor did indeed kill them, but of course this did not persuade the King of Yan to stand down his troops, and in the end the Emperor was defeated. In this case, the attempt was unsuccessful.
Finally, a Qing dynasty advisor named Mi Sihan gave the same advice to the Kangxi Emperor. The general Wu Sangui, who had previously helped establish the Qing dynasty, rebelled. However, the Kangxi Emperor did not execute Mi Sihan, and eventually managed to put down Wu Sangui몭s revolt. In this case, the outcome was a success.
These three examples are similar in terms of circumstances and historical background, but differ in the way that the various Emperors dealt with them and in their outcomes. So, when dealing with momentous issues, or when making decisions in the face of uncertainty and doubt, it몭s important to think deeply about what is right and what is wrong. It몭s equally important not to cling to past successes or defeats. When faced with an intense situation, do not fold 멪 situations are always temporary. And, be even more careful not to blame your advisors.
Now, let몭s move on to Zeng Guofan몭s two remaining examples:
In the twilight years of the Tang dynasty, Emperor Zhaozong had become very angry about his subjects몭 lack of respect for the Imperial house. Wanting to march in force against the warlord Li Maozhen, he asked his prime minister, Du Neng, to take charge of his army. Du Neng refused in no uncertain terms, telling the Emperor: 몮If I go, all that will happen is that I몭ll end up executed just like Chao Cuo, and it will do nothing to stop disaster befalling the realm!몯 Emperor Zhaozong did not accept Du Neng몭s refusal, and Du was left with no choice but to go.
In the end, the Tang imperial army was no match for the warlord Li Maozhen, who sent a formal petition to the Emperor, demanding that Du Neng be executed. When Du Neng heard about this, he said to Emperor Zhaozong: 몮This is exactly what I said would happen!몯
Emperor Zhaozong did not have the makings of a hero. In the pressure of the moment, all he could do was sob and snivel. He told Li Maozhen that he would let Du Neng decide what to do about the situation. Then, he demoted Du Neng to the post of governor of Wuzhou, before 몬allowing몭 him to commit suicide.
In this case, Du Neng suffered an even more unjust fate than Chao Cuo, Qi Tai and Huang Zicheng.
In his writings, Zeng Guofan had sharp words for Emperor Zhaozong, condemning him for forcing Du Neng to act against his will and then turning around and selling Du Neng out, having him killed. Such behavior, Zeng wrote, is that of a king who will not have a country to rule for much longer. Zeng criticized himself too, writing: 몮In my fighting days, sometimes I would make plans on the basis of some advisor몭s counsel, and subsequently suffer defeat. Perhaps I did not directly blame the advisor, but I몭m sure that the next time I saw him, the ugly feelings I felt would have been plain to see on my face. I must attribute this to a lack of insight on my part; I was not thorough enough in my own training.몯
Zeng went on to reflect on the 몬ugly feelings몭 on his face by writing about one more historical example:
The last Emperor of the Tang dynasty, Emperor Mo, was deeply worried, suspecting that a man named Shi Jingtang was plotting rebellion. The Emperor몭s advisors, Li Song and Lu Qi, told him that if Shi Jingtang really was considering rebellion, he would need support from the Khitans (a non-Chinese nomadic people from the far northeast). They advised that if the Emperor could establish good relations with the Khitans, Shi Jingtang would no longer have the opportunity to rebel. The Emperor decided to use their plan. Yet, a different advisor, Xue Wenyu, sowed seeds of doubt in his mind, questioning how the Emperor, the very Son of Heaven, could stoop so low as to treat barbarian savages as honored guests in his court. Xue mockingly quoted a poem about the female poet Zhaojun to drive his point home: 몮The country relies on a clear-sighted sovereign; how can our safety be left to women?몯 Emperor Mo was persuaded to change his mind. He berated Li Song and Lu Qi, accusing them of trying to doom his daughter to an early grave. The two advisors fell to their knees and apologized profusely, but apparently Lu Qi wasn몭t fast enough to kneel 멪 he had a medical problem with his legs 멪 and Emperor Mo accused him of arrogance. Lu Qi protested, pointing out that the Emperor was well aware of his bad legs, but Emperor Mo demoted him anyway.
Just as the advisors predicted, Shi Jingtang ended up joining forces with the Khitans, and eventually destroyed the Tang imperial armies. Emperor Mo knew then that he shouldn몭t have listened to Xue Wenyu, and he felt full of rage. He summoned Xue for a drubbing, shouting at the man: 몮You horrid thing! The very sight of you makes me tremble with rage!몯 He almost pulled out a knife to stab Xue, there and then. Emperor Mo was doomed; he ended up vanquished at the hands of Shi Jingtang.
Summing up, Zeng Guofan wrote: 몮In most cases, those who, suffering defeat, blame their chief advisors, are simply expressing their nature, which is that of a mediocre person.몯
So, there is no certainty in victory and defeat. The fact that there are success stories from the past does not mean that they can be replicated, but it also does not mean that they can몭t be replicated.
Leaders must take responsibility for their decisions. If things end up in a mess, blaming the person whose idea it was does nothing more than prove that you몭re a 몬mediocre person.몭



Ballplayers feint with every step, but do not confuse this with the real fundamentals of winning

Extract from the original text:
몮When we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away.몯

Analysis:
What Sun Tzu is talking about here is 몬strategic deception,몭 which at its core means making the enemy unprepared and unable to defend themselves. If the enemy is prepared and able to defend themselves, the odds are against you. If the enemy is unprepared, and unable to defend themselves, you can bring all of your strength to bear on them, and they will buckle under the pressure.
A famous example of this principle is the story of Han Xin crossing the River Wei using water pitchers.
During the time when Liu Bang was fighting against Xiang Yu in the war between the new states of Chu and Han, following the collapse of the Qin Empire, Liu Bang was, for a while, in a precarious position, and his ally king Wei Bao decided to switch allegiance, going over to Xiang Yu몭s side. On the pretext that his mother was ill, Wei Bao asked Liu Bang to allow him to return home. Then, he about-faced and declared for Xiang Yu. Liu Bang immediately sent his general Han Xin to fight Wei Bao. The two armies arrived at Linjin, where they were separated from each other by a river. Han Xin promptly assembled over 100 boats, and lined them up by the riverbank. Every day Han Xin put on a show, making it look like he was just about to lead his army across the river. On the opposite bank, Wei Bao kept his troops in battle formation, ready to fight. Meanwhile, Han Xin was secretly sending men to buy and make wooden and clay water pitchers 멪 round at the bottom, with a narrow spout. Eventually, Han Xin moved a large force along the river to Xiayang, where he had his men lash the pitchers together into rafts. His army floated across the river, and attacked the town of Anyi on the far bank. Wei Bao was now outflanked, and ended up getting captured.
When Wei Bao heard that Han Xin had crossed at Xiayang, he was shocked: 몮There are no boats at Xiayang!몯 he cried. 몮Where did he get boats?몯
In this example, Wei Bao failed to grasp the concept of using 몬substitution몭 as a problem-solving technique. Just because you don몭t have boats doesn몭t mean you don몭t have other tools for crossing a river.
Han Xin was using the stratagem of 몬being near but making the enemy believe you몭re far away.몭 If you want to attack the enemy from afar, you have to put on a show for them nearby. 
Another example of this stratagem comes from the struggle for supremacy between the states of Wu and Yue during the final years of the Spring and Autumn period (771-476 BCE). The Wu and Yue forces stood on either side of a river, so the Yue commander sent troops in both directions, up and down the river. Positioned a few miles apart, they waited for night and then began beating war drums and moving toward the Wu forces. The Wu commander was forced to split his army and send men in both directions to face the advancing Yue soldiers. However, the reason the Yue commander waited until night to stage his little show was that in fact the forces he had sent up- and down-river had more drums than fighting men. It was a bluff. With the Wu forces divided, the Yue commander crossed the river with his main force and attacked the Wu army head-on, routing their soldiers and dealing a massive blow to the kingdom of Wu.
In this case, both sides understood the concept in play 멪 the bluff 멪 also known in Chinese as 몬threatening from the east, striking from the west.몭 But, of course, bluffs are not always bluffs, and threatening from the east does not necessarily mean the strike will come from the west. It몭s entirely possible that the strike will come from the same direction as the threat. The analogy of the soccer penalty shot serves well here. The goalkeeper knows very well that the striker will use a feint, but also that the feint might not be a feint. In other words, the striker might be feinting a feint. In this confusing tangle of deception and reality, who can win? The striker can win if they are steady, accurate, and powerful. But if the striker lofts the ball above the goal, it won몭t go in regardless of what the goalkeeper does. For the goalkeeper to win, he needs fast reactions and a bit of luck. The goalkeeper also has the option of using a feint against the striker.
But what does the daily training of both strikers and goalkeepers consist of? Do they spend all day practicing feints? No, of course not. Their training has three main parts: physical fitness, skills and team tactics. These three things also happen to be the essence of warfare.
If you believe the historians, you몭d think that what made Han Xin a great general was his craftiness and his cunning tricks, but would be a mistake to say that this is what war is all about. Great generals are just like CEOs 멪 the fundamentals of their work consist of operations management. Operations management is why Han Xin once said that, while Liu Bang could not lead more than 100,000 soldiers with any effectiveness, Han Xin himself would take all the soldiers he could lay his hands on. You could give him a million men, and he몭d still be able to control them as if they were extensions of his own hands. If you want to know what Han Xin몭s true strength was, look no further than this.
The Thirty-Six Stratagems is an entertaining story, but it doesn몭t represent the reality of war. Zeng Guofan actually said he was doubtful that the story of Han Xin crossing the river with water pitchers is really true. His reasoning was that it would be physically impossible to make rafts out of clay water pitchers that would be capable of ferrying a large army across a river. Zeng Guofan also debunked the other most famous story about Han Xin몭s exploits, in which Han Xin erected a makeshift dam using sacks of earth. According to the story, after the dam was built, the water downriver was shallow enough for the enemy army to cross, but when they몭d only crossed halfway, Han Xin had the sacks of earth torn down, effectively bursting the dam and drowning the enemy army. Zeng Guofan pointed out that it would be impossible to dam a large river just with a group of men throwing sacks of dirt in the water, and it would be even more impossible to instantly tear down such a dam. Who exactly was supposed to have done the demolition job, and how? The answer is that nobody did it, because it몭s impossible.
Zeng wrote: 몮After certain battles that I won with the Hunan army, I read some reports that writers were publishing about my victories that I found quite astonishing. I had no idea that this was how the battles had actually been fought! 몬Strange,몭 I thought to myself, 몬it can몭t have been me they were writing about!몭몯
In his conclusion, Zeng mused: 몮I몭m not yet one of history몭s dead generals, and yet these battle reports have morphed so beyond recognition in my own lifetime that I scarcely dare believe it. Well, Sima Qian (a great historian of the Han dynasty) was after all a writer, too 멪 there can be no doubt that some sensational and embellished sources must have figured in his research into the stories of Han Xin.몯
There aren몭t many stratagems, and they몭re all well-worn tools of the trade, familiar to commanders on either side of any conflict, all of whom have read the same military books. Any time there is a battle, the same old stratagems are sure to be used. For example, you might (in your head) say to your adversary: 몬Regardless of where I attack you, I must find a way to trick you into thinking it will be somewhere else. You know that I몭m trying to trick you, and you know I might be trying to trick you into thinking I몭m tricking you, when in fact I haven몭t tricked you, and I really am going to attack in the place where it looks like I몭m going to attack.몭
What does all this amount to?
Ballplayers feint with every step, but do not confuse this with the fundamentals of winning.



Want great success? You몭ll have to give up three things. Number one: Greed

Extract from the original text:
몮Hold out baits to entice the enemy, spreading disorder. Then, crush him.몯

Analysis:
Li Quan comments: 몮An enemy who is greedy for gain will inevitably become disordered. An enemy who is disordered can be crushed.몯
I몭d like to re-use a previous chapter몭s historical example to illustrate this: the story of how Li Mu defeated the Xiongnu.
Li Mu몭s strategy of fortifying his defenses and clearing the countryside, and then closing the gates for ten years without ever coming out to fight, left his own men as well as the enemy beside themselves with pent-up frustration. Li Mu몭s men had their fill of good food and drink every day, and they were also receiving excellent training 멪 their frustration came from a desire to serve their country on the battlefield, to repay the kindness they had enjoyed. The enemy, on the other hand, had been deprived by Li Mu몭s strategy of things to steal or loot. After ten years, they몭d been reduced to miserable poverty.
A decade into the standoff, the moment came when Li Mu decided the time was right to go out and fight. Though he was quite content to not fight at all, once he decided to move against the enemy, he did so with overwhelming force, mustering all his strength and aiming of settle the score with a single battle. This was his choice, and his enemy had no idea that he meant for this battle to be the only, and final, battle of the war.
The first thing Li Mu did was to order a massive number of local nomads to release their livestock to graze on the plains 멪 the countryside was instantly filled with herders. The Xiongnu responded by sending out a small mounted invasion force. Li Mu intentionally lost the first engagement with the Xiongnu force, sacrificing a few thousand men to the enemy. The Xiongnu chieftain was delighted when he heard about this and, licking their lips at the thought of the loot waiting to be pillaged, the Xiongnu followed their leader in an invasion of the border country. Meanwhile, Li Mu had deployed his men in a pincer formation around the Xiongnu몭s flanks, catching them in an ambush and vanquishing over 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry. Li Mu routed the Xiongnu chieftain, destroyed the Chanlan people, defeated the Dong Hu barbarians, and forced the Lin Hu barbarians into submission. For the next ten years, the Xiongnu didn몭t once dare to set foot over the border into the state of Zhao.
Greed is a huge weakness of human nature. During the Warring States period (475-221 BCE), Duke Mu of Qin once asked his advisor Jian Shu what he needed to do to claim dominion over the entire world. Jian Shu replied: 몮Those who would rule over all the world must renounce three things: greed, anger and haste. Greed brings much loss, anger brings much difficulty, and haste brings many mistakes. If one can thoroughly examine the scale of potential harms and benefits, and plan accordingly, what need is there for greed? If one can think from one몭s counterpart몭s position and weigh one몭s own position against theirs, what need is there for anger? If one can accurately measure the amount of time required for various things, slow or fast, and plan unhurriedly, what need is there for haste? My lord, if you can renounce these three things, dominion will not be far away.몯
Any time you need to make a judgment call or get something done, you need to have a good grasp on two concepts:  go after things that benefit you, and stay away from things that put you in danger. These two concepts are equally important, but although people should in theory maintain a 50:50 balance between them, more often than not the ratio is somewhere between 70:30 and 90:10, in favor of going after benefit. The reason for this is that things that are beneficial tend to be highly visible, and they몭re more exciting. Meanwhile, danger tends to lurk in the shadows, and because it seems so far away, people tend to think they can get away with leaving such things to chance. We often see people doing high-risk things even though the payoff is extremely small. This is because the payoff is immediate, while the danger, no matter how obvious, can be dismissed by the hopeless logic of 몬Maybe it won몭t happen.몭
If you몭re not greedy, you can몭t be tricked. All tricks basically boil down to greed. When you몭re defrauded in some get-rich-quick scheme, the person who몭s tricked you is actually yourself.
This is how people are. When they see profit, they몭re capable of going to extraordinary lengths to trick themselves, using self-talk like: 몬Go for it! You몭ll be fine!몭
It몭s important to not let your desires sway your judgment when profit and danger are involved.


If you can몭t win, you must be able to wait

Extract from the original text:
몮If he is secure at all points, be prepared for him. If he is in superior strength, evade him.몯

Analysis:
If the enemy is 몬secure at all points,몭 meaning that they hold a strong military position, victory is out of reach. In that case, you have to employ the stratagem of waiting, and avoid making any rash moves. The Tang dynasty military strategist, Duke Li of Wei, put it like this: 몮If you see that the enemy is exposed, then attack; if you see that the enemy is secure, then halt.몯
As for the line, 몬If he is in superior strength, evade him,몭 Mei Yaochen comments: 몮If my enemy has superior strength, I must stay clear of the sharp edge of his sword.몯
Du You comments: 몮If the enemy몭s treasury is well supplied and his soldiers are filled with vigor, then you must retreat and wait for him to slacken; watch for changes and respond accordingly.몯
People often think that the only way to get opportunities is to take action first, but this is a mistake. That몭s because they forget to look at the other side of things, and there몭s always a price to be paid for any action. There몭s a common modern Chinese saying that expresses this quite well: 몬If you go looking for ways to die, then you몭re going to die.몭
We are reminded of the truth in this by the opening words of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몮The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin.몯 
In war, every move is a matter of life or death, not just for the soldiers out fighting battles, but also for the state itself. Above all else, be as careful as you possibly can. This is the first of three principles at the heart of this chapter.
The second principle is the concept that the best thing you can do is to know ahead of time who is going to win; you can몭t just make victory happen. If you properly analyze your own situation and the enemy몭s, you can work out whether or not the odds of victory are on your side. If they몭re not, you can march to war and fight as hard as you like, but victory will always slip away from you. It simply cannot be forced. If the enemy is as battle-hardened as you are, no amount of cheerleading or chest thumping will help you win, especially since the enemy will be thumping their own chests just as hard.
The third principle is the idea of not trying to fight 100 battles and win 100 victories, but finishing the war with a single battle. Fighting a long war back and forth, without having something to show for your efforts, is a waste of blood, money and rations, particularly because once you몭re in that situation, you have to keep going. Any general who gets stuck in the mud like this is committing a deadly sin. You need to get the timing right, move from a position of stability, and fight with overpowering strength when the time comes. This is how to solve problems.
 So, the steps to be followed when the enemy has greater strength and holds a solid position are: 1) Be prepared and avoid fighting; 2) Be patient and keep yourself under control; 3) Use smooth diplomacy; 4) Wait for the enemy to let down their guard or make an unforced error, and then trick them into more mistakes (as Emperor Taizong said: 몮Use a multitude of diverse methods to fool one몭s foe몯); and 5) Get your timing right, and strike while the iron is hot.
For a classic demonstration of these principles, let몭s turn to the War of the Three Kingdoms, which followed the collapse of the Han dynasty, and look at how the Wu general Lu Meng defeated the renowned Han loyalist general, Guan Yu.
We begin with Guan Yu in the Yangzi River province of Jingzhou. He commanded a powerful army and could boast of 몬a hundred victories in a hundred battles.몭 He had even received the surrender of one of the state of Wei몭s most feared generals, Yu Jin, and his name inspired popular rebellions that he directed from afar against his enemy, Cao Cao, in many parts of north China. The name of Guan Yu inspired awe throughout all of China, to the extent that Cao considered changing his capital city to put more distance between himself and the spearhead of Guan Yu몭s forces. But Cao Cao몭s general, Sima Yi, had a plan. He claimed that there was no way the neighboring state of Eastern Wu would want to see Guan Yu become any more powerful, so Cao Cao should form an alliance and join forces with them to deal with Guan Yu together. That is exactly what happened.
Guan Yu actually only had control of Jingzhou because his commander-in-chief, Liu Bei, had borrowed the province from Eastern Wu몭s Emperor, Sun Quan. Of course, Liu Bei was reluctant to give it back, and following negotiations it was divided up. Half went back to Eastern Wu and half remained in Liu Bei몭s hands. This situation was a sore point for Eastern Wu. At the same time, Guan Yu was becoming recklessly arrogant. When Yu Jin surrendered, 30,000 men and horses under his command were handed over to Guan Yu. Without enough provisions to feed these extra mouths, Guan Yu made a shocking move 멪 he seized granaries controlled by Eastern Wu, adding insult to injury. Emperor Sun Quan made up his mind to do something about it.
Liu Bang and Sun Quan were allies, and Guan Yu몭s main aim in Jingzhou was to use it as a base to launch campaigns against the state of Wei. Guan Yu was obsessed with capturing the Wei fortress of Fancheng, but at the same time he was wary of the potential threat posed by Eastern Wu. He feared that if he made moves to attack Fancheng, he would make himself vulnerable to attack from behind by Eastern Wu general Lu Meng. Because of this, Guan Yu left a large reserve force behind to defend Jingzhou.
As for Cao Cao, he could see that Guan Yu was too powerful to fight, and was keen to stay away from him. Likewise, Lu Meng could see that Guan Yu held a strong position, and so spent his time making preparations. For Lu Meng to stand a chance of taking Jingzhou, he would have to make Guan Yu pull out his defensive forces. In other words, Jingzhou would have to pivot from a 몬secure몭 situation to an 몬exposed몭 one.
Guan Yu faced a dilemma: he needed to transfer some of his forces from Jingzhou to the front line in the north, because he didn몭t have enough manpower to take the fortress at Fancheng. Yet, at the same time, he needed to leave enough troops in Jingzhou to guard against a possible attack from Lu Meng. This was the situation when Lu Meng came up with a plan: he would pretend to be sick.
It actually wasn몭t hard for Lu Meng to convince people he was sick, because he really did get ill quite often, and this was already common knowledge. In fact, he did actually die of an illness after this part of the war was over. So, pleading sickness, Lu Meng returned to the capital city of Jianye and sent Lu Xun to command the garrison in Lukou in his place.
At the time, Lu Xun was still a young man, and very much an unknown entity. When he arrived in Lukou, he wrote a letter to Guan Yu, waxing lyrical about how much he admired the great general. He essentially claimed to be Guan Yu몭s number one fan, and breathlessly told him how it was the honor of his life to be his neighbor, and that he hoped Guan Yu would be like an uncle to him, looking out for him while he was still young and inexperienced. Lu Xun also made it very clear that he would never dare make an enemy of the great Guan Yu.
Guan Yu was disarmed, and marched his Jingzhou garrison forces to the front line at Fancheng with peace of mind. Immediately, Lu Meng pounced from the sideline at the head of a large army, taking Jingzhou and cutting off Guan Yu몭s line of retreat. The war was soon over; Guan Yu was captured and promptly beheaded.
Guan Yu몭s defeat was the root of Liu Bei몭s ultimate failure. Jingzhou was the key to controlling the Central Plain of the Yellow River; once it was lost, Liu Bei was no longer a contender in the contest to unify all the lands of China. After losing Jingzhou, Liu Bei몭s brilliant general, Zhuge Liang, was forced to launch a doomed assault on the central plain by traversing the famously impassable Daba and Qinling mountain ranges from the Shu city of Hanzhong. Rugged terrain made transporting food supplies very difficult, even with Zhuge Liang몭s legendary invention, the wheelbarrow. Tragically, Guan Yu몭s death led directly to the deaths of his sworn brothers, Zhang Fei and Liu Bei, about whom so many stories were written.
Guan Yu is a classic example of the concept, 몬A hundred fights and a hundred victories means that one defeat will spell ruin.몭 Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War tells us that 몮good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage.몯 This is precisely because good fighters don몭t fight many battles, and the battles they do fight are easy, uneventful and certainly not epic. They don몭t make for good stories.
Anyway, stories are only good for entertaining civilians. Guan Yu was the exact opposite of Sun Tzu몭s model general 멪 his glory echoed all across the land, and he was immortalized by ordinary people everywhere for being a perfect combination of virtue, wisdom and strength. But professionals have a different take: Guan Yu was a leader who led his country to ruin.



Pay attention to this stratagem. Forgetting it is a common mistake

Extract from the original text:
몮If your opponent is of choleric temper, seek to irritate him.몯

Analysis:
Du Mu comments: 몮A general who is of fierce, unyielding temperament may be provoked into a rage; then, he will pursue gratification and pay no mind to his best-laid plans.몯
Being able to trigger an enemy몭s rage is like casting a magic spell. They will forget all about what they were trying to achieve, and instead will instantly do whatever it takes to free themselves of their hate and anger. In the end, they throw their life away, without ever relieving themselves of the emotions that doomed them.
This stratagem is basically a trick designed to trip up proud and hot-headed generals. One of the seven ancient military classics, The Wei Liaozi, notes: 몮A broad-minded man cannot be provoked into rage.몯 When your enemy is a relaxed kind of person, it won몭t be easy to trick them by making them angry.
A classic example of this stratagem is the defeat of Cao Jiu by Liu Bang몭s forces during the battle of Sishui River, before the establishment of the Han dynasty.
Xiang Yu held a position at Chenggao, and a face-off there against Liu Bang had sunk into a deadlock. Liu Bang몭s gambit was to hit Xiang Yu from behind. He sent his commanders, Lu Wan and Liu Jia, across the White Horse Ford at the head of over 20,000 men, to link up with Peng Yue, duke of Jiancheng. Their combined force attacked the region of Liang beyond Xiang Yu몭s forces, successfully taking around a dozen cities and cutting Xiang Yu몭s supply line.
Xiang Yu몭s hand was forced. He split up his army and personally led part of his forces to backtrack and attack Peng Yue, leaving General Cao Jiu in charge of holding Chenggao. Just before Xiang Yu left, he gave Cao Jiu detailed instructions: 몮Make sure you hold Chenggao. If the Han army tries to attack, stay well clear of them; don몭t give battle, don몭t let them take the east. Within 15 days, I몭ll have Peng Yue몭s head and the Liang region will be under my control. Then I몭ll come back and resume command.몯 
After Xiang Yu left, Cao Jiu did what he몭d been told, holding his position and refusing to come out. This is where our stratagem of the day makes its appearance. Liu Bang built a raised platform just outside Chenggao몭s walls, which he used as a launchpad for shouting a constant stream of verbal abuse at the enemy. He kept the insults coming for five or six days without stopping, until the enemy troops couldn몭t stand to listen for a single second longer. Cao Jiu lost his temper. Forgetting all about Xiang Yu몭s plan, and what he was supposed to be doing, he became hell-bent on going out to teach this pack of rascals a lesson. Cao Jiu stormed out through the gate with his army behind him, wading across the Sishui River. Unsurprisingly, Liu Bang used the standard tactic of attacking when the enemy was still in the river. Cao Jiu was badly beaten, Chenggao was lost, and the tide of the war turned. Knowing his career was over, and too ashamed to face Xiang Yu, Cao Jiu slit his own throat by the riverbank.
This stratagem was also attempted by Zhuge Liang against Sima Yi, but on that occasion he wasn몭t able to pull it off.
Because Guan Yu had lost the province of Jingzhou, the only way for Liu Bei몭s Han forces to move north. out of the area that is now Sichuan Province. and attack Cao Cao몭s state of Wei was to cross through the steep and inhospitable mountains between Han and Wei. Zhuge Liang attempted to do this many times, but the problem was that the terrain made it impossible to bring enough food supplies, which is the main reason each campaign ended with Zhuge Liang pulling up short before the finish line. The campaigns lasted roughly a month each time, which was the maximum period Zhuge Liang could stay in the field without being forced to head home without enough rations to get his men back over the mountains. So, Zhuge Liang had to fight fast, ideally only in pitched battles in open country. Cao Cao and his generals knew the score 멪 all they had to do was hold firm for a month and hunger would force the enemy to go home. If they could avoid fighting, victory was theirs, but if they did fight things became a lot more uncertain. Of course, not fighting quickly became the unquestioned strategy of all of Cao Cao몭s commanders. 
During Zhuge Liang몭s final drive north into Wei, his army came face-to-face with Sima Yi몭s forces on the Wuzhang Plain. As usual, there was no way Sima Yi was going to get involved in a fight, despite all kinds of provocations by Zhuge Liang, including insult of gifting Sima Yi with a set of women몭s clothing. Sima Yi wasn몭t falling for it; he was not going to get dragged into a fight. Zhuge Liang was so exhausted by his efforts, physically and mentally, that he got sick and died while still in the field. His death marked the end of Liu Bei몭s northern expeditions.
Sima Yi is a strong example of a player who has his head in the game. He never forgot what his goals were, and he stuck to the basic playbook. 
Forgetting our intentions is a mistake that we all make, and the reason isn몭t always anger. Any kind of distraction can pull us further and further away from what몭s important, without our even realizing it, and we end up chasing after unimportant details while losing sight of the essentials.
This is why the Buddhist scriptures tell us: 몮Never forget why you started; this is the only way to accomplish your mission.몯
Every day, we should evaluate everything we do against our original motivation, our plan. At the same time, we have to say 몬no몭 to unhelpful urges, stay strong in the face of temptation, block out distractions, stick to our plan, and never forget why we started.



No shame in showing weakness. Whatever you do, don몭t fight for the recognition of others, especially temporary recognition 

Extract from the original text:
몮Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant.몯

Analysis:
The goal of 몬pretending to be weak, that the enemy may grow arrogant몭 is to make your enemy underestimate you. If the enemy underestimates you, they won몭t prepare properly, and so they will be vulnerable to sudden attack.
A classic example of this stratagem is the Xiongnu chieftain Modun몭s invasion of the Donghu barbarians.
Modun came to power as chieftain of the Xiongnu Empire at the same time that the Qin dynasty was crumbling. The Donghu were very powerful at the time, and sent a messenger to ask the Xiongnu chieftain a favor: 몮Your father, Touman, had a terrific horse,몯 the messenger said, 몮a very fast horse. How about you hand it over?몯
Modun looked around at his advisors, and asked them: 몮Well, should I give them the horse?몯 The advisors responded that this was terribly rude of the Donghu. Modun몭s father몭s horse was a treasure of the Xiongnu people; why should they give it up for no good reason?몯
But Modun said, 몮It몭s good to be kind to our neighbors, and after all, it몭s only a horse! I will gladly give it to them.몯
Not long after this incident, a Donghu messenger came again, and delivered this message to Modun from his chief: 몮You have an awful lot of wives; why don몭t you give one of them to me?몯 Modun몭s advisors were furious, and shouted: 몮You have gone too far, Donghu! How dare you come to our chieftain asking for wives! We should send our warriors to punish you!몯
But, once again, Modun said: 몮It몭s good to be kind to our neighbors, and all they want is a girl; why be so stingy? Give them what they want!몯
More time passed, and the Donghu messenger came again. This time, he said: 몮You have thousands of miles of land that you몭re not using; why not give some of it to us?몯
Modun asked his advisors what they thought. They hesitated. Since their lord had been willing to give up his own wife to these people, they weren몭t sure what they were supposed to say. In the end, they mumbled something non-committal, along the lines of, 몮Well, we could give them the land, or we could not, either way...몯
Modun went ballistic. 몮The land is the very substance of our country,몯 he raged. 몮How could I give it away?몯 He immediately beheaded all of the advisors who몭d said, 몬give them the land,몭 and then he sent his warriors to attack the Donghu. The Donghu, unprepared because they hadn몭t taken Modun seriously, were wiped out. Now that Modun was on the warpath, he didn몭t stop. He annexed in one fell swoop the Yuezhi nomads in the west, Loufan, Baiyang, the Great Bend of the Yellow River in the south, and Yan and Dai in the north. By the time Modun몭s rampage was finished, he몭d reclaimed all of the Xiongnu territory that had been lost during their war against the Qin dynasty general, Meng Tian. It was also Modun who later surrounded Liu Bang (Emperor Gaozu) in the battle of Baideng, and signed a peace treaty with the Chinese Emperor granting him equal status as the Emperor몭s 몬brother.몭
When Emperor Gaozu died, Modun had ideas of invading Han dynasty China. Modun몭s queen had recently died, so he decided to send an envoy to Emperor Gaozu몭s widow, Empress Lu, with a highly improper message. It read: 몮I am now a lonely lord멞 and I yearn to visit China. Your majesty, you too must be lonely now, living all alone. Since we two have both been saddened by unhappy circumstances, I express my wish for us to have once more what we have lost.몯
Modun was in effect asking the Chinese Empress if she몭d like to marry him.
Of course, Empress Lu was livid, as were the ministers in the Han court, and an old general named Fan Kuai even asked permission there and then to lead 100,000 crack troops to sweep the Xiongnu into oblivion. But the General of the Household, Ji Bu, shouted: 몮Fan Kuai, you should be executed for such a suggestion! Do you forget that our late lord the Emperor once led a host of over 400,000 men against the Xiongnu, and yet he was surrounded at Baideng? How, Lord Fan Kuai, do you propose to 몬sweep the Xiongnu into oblivion몭 with only 100,000? To even suggest that you could do this is tantamount to lying to your Empress!몯
Empress Lu had the final say. She decided not to go to war with Modun, but to continue with the old policy of appeasement. She sent a letter back to him, in which she wrote: 몮My thanks to the great chieftain for thinking of us in these times. However, I fear that we have nothing here that is worth seeing, only endless mountains, treacherous passes and soldiers. If the great chieftain insists on visiting, I am afraid he will find that our poetry and books are rather dull, and the best thing to do would be to allow our fine soldiers to guide you on a hunting foray. As for me, I am old and frail, and my teeth and hair are falling out. But if it몭s hunting that interests the great chieftain, we will be delighted to accommodate him!몯
Modun could see from the Empress몭 letter that she was fully in control, so he shrugged and let go of his invasion dreams. After all, he몭d only been testing the waters to see if the Emperor몭s death might have opened an opportunity to add China to his collection of territories. 



Fighting tired

Extract from the original text:
몮If he is taking his ease, give him no rest.몯

Analysis:
The idea is to be well rested while the enemy is exhausted. If you find yourself facing an enemy who is 몬taking his ease,몭 then harass him, causing him headaches however you can. Make him so tired that he doesn몭t have the energy to fight all-out on the battlefield.
A classic historical example of this stratagem is the war between the states of Wu and Chu during the Spring and Autumn period (771-476 BCE).
When king Helu of Wu attacked Chu, he asked for advice from General Wu Zixu, who responded: 몮You may divide your army between three commanders. First, order only one commander to attack. The enemy is sure to counter-attack with all the force at their disposal, and then our commander should order his men to retreat. Then, wait until the enemy has withdrawn their forces, and immediately launch a new attack led by the second of your three commanders. When the enemy marches out to fight, retreat once more. Continue in this way, constantly forcing the enemy into action, employing a multitude of deceptions, until they are too exhausted to fight with conviction. Then, attack with all three commanders, and the enemy will fall at once.몯
King Helu did exactly as Wu Zixu advised, and over the course of the next year, the Chu general Zi Chong led his forces out to fight seven times, never successfully, and giving all that he had in the effort. Finally, the Wu army launched an all-out assault, and captured the Chu capital, the city of Ying.
Much later, in the beginning stages of the War of the Three Kingdoms, Cao Cao was locked in a struggle with a northern warlord named Yuan Shao. Just before the two sides clashed in the decisive Battle of Guandu, the strategist Feng Tian presented a war plan to Yuan Shao, but Yuan refused to listen. This was Feng Tian몭s plan:
몮Cao Cao is a skilled military commander, and he will not easily be bested. It would be best to settle in for a long conflict. You have a secure position because of the four provinces under your control, which affords you the protection of mountains and rivers. You should focus on the external and the internal at the same time. Externally, seek alliances with strong generals; internally, focus on improving the state of both your fighting men and agricultural production. After honing your men몭s fighting skills, divide them into multiple stealth units, and send them south of the Yellow River to harass whichever regions are vulnerable. Then, if the enemy counter-attacks from the right, strike to the left, and if they counter-attack from the left, strike to the right. In this way, the enemy will become too exhausted to fight effectively, and their people will be unable to go about their daily work in peace. You will wear the enemy down without any hard work on your part. Within three years, you can defeat them. This is the strategy I present to you today. But if you have already made up your mind to claim victory now, in a single battle, or else be vanquished in the attempt, there will be no use for regrets after it is done.몯
Chairman Mao Zedong expressed the same basic ideas as Feng Tian when he summarized the Red Army몭s strategy during the Chinese Civil War: 몮The enemy advances, we retreat; the enemy camps, we harass; the enemy tires, we attack; the enemy retreats, we pursue.몯 
The art of war is actually very simple. What몭s difficult is making good judgment calls. For example, when you see enemy forces approaching, how do you know if they몭re just planning to harass you a little bit and then leave, or if they몭re launching a full-on attack? In truth, there몭s no way of knowing. That몭s why Chairman Mao also said: 몮On the battlefield, all strategy is forgotten.몯 In the heat of battle, you constantly have to respond to emergency situations at a moment몭s notice, which leaves no time or mental capacity to think about things like strategy or the art of war.
The way to deal with this problem is to stay away from the overall situation, and also to stay one step ahead of the enemy, so that they go where you want them to, rather than the other way round. 
In terms of your own position, you have to set yourself up in an impregnable position, protect yourself, and do not rashly commit to a fight if it means moving away from your position. Be like Li Mu, building up your defenses and sheltering your resources in the safety of your walls, closing your gates and not allowing yourself to be provoked into coming out until you몭re ready. If you몭re not ready after a year, keep preparing. If you몭re not ready after ten years, still keep preparing. Then, the moment you are ready and an opportunity arrives, blow your enemy away in a single battle.
In terms of dealing with the enemy, remember how Emperor Taizong summarized 몬all the books on war, ancient and new.몭 He said it all boils down to: 몮Using a multitude of diverse methods to fool one몭s foe.몯 Do whatever it takes; use your imagination.
All of the ancient generals read the same military texts. And they didn몭t just read them 멪 they memorized these books by heart. So, why was there such a huge gap between their abilities to get results? The distinguishing factor is whether or not generals have good judgment. Without it, you can몭t effectively judge the situation in front of you. On the surface, the problem seems to be that you misjudged the enemy, but the real problem is misjudging yourself. As long as you can make accurate judgments about yourself, whatever the enemy does, you will naturally know how to deal with them.



Why do we let enemies turn us against our friends?  

Extract from the original text:
몮If his forces are united, separate them.몯

Analysis:
Li Quan comments: 몮Sabotage their diplomatic efforts, create schisms between king and minister, and thus transform them.몯
During the Warring States period, the states of Qin and Zhao fought against each other in a conflict called the Battle of Changping (262-260 BCE). A Zhao general named Lian Po found himself on the losing end of several battles, and decided to hole up in the safety of a fortress. The Qin forces saw that Lian Po had no intention of coming out to fight, so they sent agents to Zhao to spread rumors that the Qin commanders didn몭t think Lian Po would be difficult to deal with, and that they were much more worried about another Zhao commander, named Zhao Kuo. The Zhao king fell for the Qin trickery and, ignoring the desperate pleas of Zhao Kuo몭s mother and his advisor Ling Xiangru not to do it, sent Zhao Kuo to take over Lian Po몭s command. In the end, this led to a terrible tragedy 멪 the Battle of Changping ended in the brutal deaths of 400,000 Zhao troops.
Why did the King of Zhao fall for the Qin trick? Even before the Qin agents spread their rumors, the king was not at all pleased with Lian Po몭s losing record, nor his subsequent unwillingness to fight more battles. However, the king didn몭t have a good excuse to replace Lian Po. That is, not until the Qin agents did their dirty work. So, as far as the king was concerned, these rumors had been a great help; they even saved him the effort of working out which general to send out to replace Lian Po.
Let몭s turn again to the wars between Liu Bang and Xiangyu following the collapse of the Qin dynasty. Liu Bang spent a year trapped by Xiang Yu in the city of Xinyang, cut off from outside help and supplies. Luckily, Liu Bang몭s advisor, Chen Ping, had a plan. He pointed out that Xiang Yu only had a handful of capable men giving him advice: Fan Zeng (whom Xiang Yu so respected that he called him his 몬second father몭), Zhong Limei, Long Qie and Zhou Yin. If a wedge could be driven between people in Xiang Yu몭s camp, these four men could be eliminated, and Xiang Yu would become much easier to deal with.
Liu Bang gave Chen Ping 40,000 catties of gold, which he used to bribed a few of Xiang Yu몭s officers to spread rumors that Fan Zeng and Zhong Limei were dissatisfied that, despite doing more than anyone else for Xiang Yu, they hadn몭t got what they deserved: the title of 몬king.몭 According to the rumor, Fan Zeng and Zhong Limei had already entered into a secret alliance with Liu Bang to destroy Xiang Yu, and that afterwards they would split Xiang Yu몭s kingdom between them. 
When the rumor reached Xiang Yu몭s ears, he became suspicious. He started to doubt Zhong Limei몭s loyalty, and stopped talking with him about important issues. He even suspected Fan Zeng of secretly communicating with Liu Bang, and began to treat him quite rudely.
To put one more nail in Fan Zeng몭s coffin, Chen Ping contrived to put on a show. One day, when a messenger from Xiang Yu visited Liu Bang몭s camp, Chen Ping ordered servants to lay out an exquisite spread of fine meats and wines for the messenger. He then asked the man: 몮What instructions from Lord Fan Zeng?몯 The messenger, perplexed, responded: 몮I was sent by Xiang Yu, not Fan Zeng.몯 Immediately, Chen Ping changed his tune. 몮Oh! We thought you몭d been sent by Fan Zeng!몯 he said, and ordered the servants to take away the fine meats and wines, and ushered the messenger into another, much less comfortable room, where he was served cheap tea and plain rice. Then, Chen Ping walked out, leaving the messenger to his own devices. Of course, the messenger was outraged. He had not expected to be humiliated like this. When he returned to his own camp, and told Xiang Yu what had happened, Xiang Yu became fully convinced that Fan Zeng was in cahoots with Liu Bang.
Fan Zeng kept on trying to give Xiang Yu advice 멪 he suggested stepping up the siege efforts, but Xiang Yu blankly refused to listen. Fan Zeng knew why his lord was behaving so out-of-character: it was because of outside forces spreading rumors that he was in league with Liu Bang. He knew that Xiang Yu had been tricked, and so he asked for permission to return home. Xiang Yu let him go without a second thought.
Chen Ping몭s little show was far from subtle, so why did Xiang Yu fall for it? It was because Xiang Yu was already suspicious, and because the rumors were mostly true. For instance, it was true that Zeng Fan and Zhong Limei had made a bigger contribution than anyone else to Xiang Yu몭s rise, and it was true that they did not hold the title of 몬king.몭 Xiang Yu had always been stingy, and reluctant to reward his men. As Han Xin said, Xiang Yu owned stamps specifically carved to grant people the titles of 몬king몭 and 몬duke,몭 and yet he could barely bring himself to let them out of his grasp. On the rare occasions that he did, he quickly snatched them back. This was a weakness in his psyche, and the rumor played to this weakness perfectly 멪 he couldn몭t help but believe it.
What about Fan Zeng? Did he do anything wrong? Actually, yes. Before the war began, Xiang Yu once had a chance to kill Liu Bang at the Feast of Swan Goose Gate, but let him go despite Fan Zeng urging him to take advantage of the opportunity to eliminate his rival. After Liu Bang made his get-away, Fan Zeng was furious, and shouted abuse at Xiang Zhuang, the would-be assassin whose job it had been to kill Liu Bang while entertaining the banqueters with a 몬sword dance.몭 몮Impudent boy! You don몭t even deserve my counsel!몯 Fan Zeng thundered. Everyone there knew very well who Fan Zeng몭s words were really meant for 멪 Xiang Yu himself. So, although Fan Zeng was a talented man, gifted with many kinds of wisdom, he lacked the wisdom to get along with Xiang Yu, which happened to be the most vital thing. It was the thing that he absolutely had to get right if he ever wanted to accomplish his ambitions on the world stage.
Why did events happen the way they did? It all comes down to a very human weakness: as close a relationship you may have with someone, there몭s naturally a corresponding build-up of resentment. 
Our relationships with enemies are very simple 멪 it몭s about a clash of interests, to be solved either by fighting or by negotiating. But close relationships of any kind are more complex, because they몭re full of strong emotions, spanning a broad range from love to hate. The relationship you have with your enemies is based on competition; this is a normal social mechanism. But, there is also internal competition between members of the same organization, because organizations are essentially mechanisms for competition and distribution of resources. The stratagem of dividing one몭s enemies is about external competitors crossing the boundaries of competition itself, and taking part in their enemy몭s internal competition. The results can be magic.
Castles always fall from the inside. If you don몭t want to fall prey to the stratagem of division, make sure your leader is broad-minded and of strong character. 
       


       
Stay alert, don몭t slack off
     
Extract from the original text:
몮Attack him where he is unprepared, appear where you are not expected.몯
       
Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: 몮Attack where they are lax, appear where they are exposed.몯
There is a phrase coined by the ancient strategist Wu Qi: 몮When you step out of your door, act as though the enemy몭s in your yard.몯 It means that you should always be vigilant.
The Confucians also liked to talk about caution and fear: 몮Be cautious of what you cannot see, and be fearful of what you do not know.몯 Stay on the alert, and pay attention to things that you don몭t know, and things that you might not notice. The ancient Classic of Poetry says: 몮Tremble with fear, as though near the edge of an abyss, as though treading o몭er thin ice.몯
When I was in elementary and middle school, the school buildings had big slogans painted on them: 몬United 멪 Alert 멪  Earnest 멪 Active.몭 But what does the word 몬alert몭 really mean to school kids?
