Before Cao Cao몭s unfortunate run-in with the fire ships, he had successfully marched his armies south of the Yangzi River, where he accepted the surrender of General Liu Cong, and even got his hands on naval forces formerly under the command of Cai Mao and Zhang Yun. This is a good example of Sun Tzu몭s dictum: 몮The best thing of all is to take the enemy몭s country whole.몯 But, Cao Cao몭s winning streak came to an end when Sun Quan, Emperor of Eastern Wu, refused to surrender. The Battle of Red Cliffs happened not long after, dealing Cao Cao a catastrophic defeat. His forces never again set foot in Eastern Wu.
During the wars between Liu Bang and Xiang Yu, Liu Bang once entrusted a mission to his advisor Li Yiji: to go to the state of Qi and convince its king, Tian Guang, to surrender. The mission was a success, and another example of Sun Tzu몭s dictum. Li Yiji stayed in the Qi capital as a voluntary hostage, and told the king that if Liu Bei몭s Han armies ever invaded Qi, the king could throw him in the soup pot and boil him alive. Every day, the king and Li Yiji drank and ate together, and eventually the king did as Li Yiji said, dissolving the Qi garrison.
Unfortunately, one of Liu Bei몭s generals, Han Xin, felt a little bothered by Li Yiji몭s success, using his powers of persuasion to talk the mighty state of Qi into surrendering. Han Xin몭s thinking was probably something along the lines of: 몬Why should a bookish weakling like Li Yiji get more credit than me?몭 So, Han Xin secretly plotted to make a move of his own 멪 a sudden attack on the Qi army, which was stationed in Lixia. The state of Qi was caught with its defenses down, and Han Xin몭s army rolled over it like a wave. The Qi king was sure that he had been betrayed by Li Yiji, and sure enough, threw the man in a soup pot and boiled him alive. As for the king, he got caught up in the fighting and was killed. 
One might wonder if Han Xin didn몭t grasp the concept that 몬The best thing of all is to take the enemy몭s country whole.몭 Of course he understood the concept. He had put it into practice himself against the kingdom of Yan. He cowed the Yan king into submission with the fearsome reputation he had made for himself by capturing Xia Shuo and King Bao of Wei, and by executing the Lord of Cheng몭an. All it took for Yan to surrender was one messenger and a single letter. 
Just like Yan, Qi had surrendered. But the difference was that it wasn몭t he, Han Xin, who had made them surrender, but one of his colleagues. So, Han Xin decided to go for the next-best thing: 몬A broken country.몭 He destroyed Qi and killed its soldiers and war horses, even though they were already Liu Bang몭s property. When he몭d finished, he went straight back to Liu Bang and tried to twist his arm into granting him the title of 몬King of Qi.몭 In reality, Han Xin was sowing the seeds of not just his own downfall, but the destruction of his entire family line.
The Ming dynasty writer Wang Fuzhi said there was nothing unjust about Han Xin몭s death, because in his heart he was not truly loyal to Liu Bang. For Han Xin, his relationship with Liu Bang was about trying to extract as much as possible from his lord; it was about benefitting himself. Wang Fuzhi put it like this: 몮He poisoned the whole world, and then succumbed to his own poison; he was nothing more than a man greedy for credit! Sir Li persuaded Qi to surrender, and Qi was prepared to accept this counsel. With this achieved, there was no longer cause for worry in the Northeast, and Xiang Yu몭s right-hand line of support was severed. Consider Jing Bu 멪 he was a criminal, and yet having once turned away from Xiang Yu and come to Liu Bei몭s side, it was out of the question that he would ever rebel against Liu Bei. How much more could the Qi king Tian Guang be trusted? He is an upright man, and there is no doubt that he would not have been the cause of any concern for Liu Bei. Yet, Han Xin hankered after success, and so followed after the example of Kuai Che, frenziedly attacking Qi, though Qi had already relented. As a result, Sir Li was hurled into a boiling vessel, and the Qi army was slaughtered at Li Xia, so that rivulets of blood flowed o몭er the open country. King Tian Guang and his entire family were exterminated. The tragedy of it! The stirrings of greed originated in ethereal darkness, and ended with soldiers몭 shields floating away on currents of blood.몯  
Wang Fuzhi explained why there was nothing unjust about Han Xin몭s death, and pointed out that if anyone died unjustly, it was King Tiang Guang and Li Yiji.	 몮It is better to recapture an army entirely than to destroy it, to capture a battalion, a company or a squad entirely than to destroy them.몯
This line delves into the organizational divisions within an army. Here, an 몬army몭 refers to 12,500 men; a battalion is 500 men; a company is 100 men; and a squad, the smallest unit, is five men. The basic message is that no matter what scale or level you몭re working at, from a whole country down to a single squad, you should always strive to keep everything whole and intact, and remember that winning without fighting is the perfect way to do this.
This is why there몭s nothing particularly great about fighting and winning a hundred battles. In the words of the Warring States period polymath, Li Kui, when he was advising Marquess Wen of Wei: 몮With many victories comes certain ruin.몯 This is because in every battle fought, something is used up and depleted; there is always a price to be paid. After a hundred battles, the people are exhausted; after a hundred victories, the ruler becomes arrogant. When the people are exhausted and the ruler is arrogant, the enemy is likely to find a long-repressed reserve of strength, and when the next battle comes, suddenly the tables will turn. And that몭s not to mention that if you몭re still fighting after a hundred victories, clearly the 몬victories몭 you몭ve been winning aren몭t exactly of the highest quality, because you still haven몭t solved your problem.
This is why causing your enemy to submit without fighting him is 몬supreme excellence.몭 It몭s possible to finish your business just by writing a letter; the pen has the power to bring peace to the realm. If that doesn몭t work out, the next best thing is to solve your problems in a single battle. When you find yourself having won a hundred battles, that in itself is a problem.
The supreme strategy is to attack and sabotage the enemy몭s plans

Extract from the original text:
몮Thus, the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy몭s plans; the next best is to attack the enemy몭s alliances; the next in order is to attack the enemy몭s army in the field.몯

Analysis:
몮The highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy몭s plans.몯 You don몭t have to use stratagems to fight a war. What Sun Tzu is telling us here is that you should disrupt the enemy몭s stratagems. In war, both sides finalize their stratagems before making their first move, so if you can destroy your enemy몭s stratagem, they won몭t be going anywhere.
The all-time classic historical example would be when Kou Xun attacked Gao Jun during the Eastern Han dynasty (23-221 CE). Gao Jun sent an agent, Huang Puwen, to visit Kou Xun. Without the slightest hesitation, Kou Xun had the agent killed. Then, he sent a letter back to Gao Jun, saying: 몮Your general was very rude, so I took his head. If you몭re going to surrender, be quick about it. If not, you몭d better dig in tight!몯 The same day that Gao Jun received the letter, he opened his gates and surrendered.
The generals didn몭t understand, and asked Kou Xun: 몮These are two states that have always settled things in battle, not by decapitating emissaries. Why did he fall over backward to surrender to you just because you executed his envoy? You weren몭t even at war at that point!몯
Kou Xun explained: That 몬envoy,몭 Huang Puwen, was Gao Jun몭s chief general, the man he relied on more than anyone. The reason Gao Jun sent him to me was to see what my strengths and weaknesses are, so that he could go back with the information and get down to planning. If I몭d spared him, he would have given Gao Jun a stratagem, but as it happened, I killed him, and Gao Jun lost his nerve.몯
Killing Huang Puwen ensured that Gao Jun was left with no ideas, and no guts, either. This is exactly what it means to say 몬The highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy몭s plans.몭
Kou Xun몭s story is an extreme case, in which he took the most direct route possible: killing the enemy몭s planner-in-chief. Under normal circumstances, this kind of opportunity doesn몭t just present itself. Instead, you have to focus on analysis and clarity of judgment as a way to sabotage the enemy몭s plans.
This chapter몭s second example is about the origins of a Chinese idiom that basically means, 몬To win by diplomacy.몭 The literal translation is 몬Block the enemy몭s charge with vessels of wine.몭 The wording of 몬block the charge몭 comes from the name of a type of ancient Chinese war chariot, the zhechongqi, which was designed to sever an enemy charge in a similar way to snapping a knife blade. The basic idea is to pluck victory from negotiations at the banquet table, rather than resorting to violence. The idiom is based on the story of Yan Ying, a famous statesman from Qi who lived during the Spring and Autumn period.
Duke Ping of Jin had designs on attacking Qi, so he sent Fan Zhao as an envoy to gather information. When Fan Zhao arrived, Duke Jing of Qi held a banquet to welcome him. The wine was half drunk, and Fan Zhao suddenly said to Duke Jing: 몮Would it be permissible for me to request a drink of wine from your cup?몯 Duke Jing replied: 몮I see no reason why not, since you are my guest! Come, a servant will pour my wine into your cup!몯
Fan Zhao downed Duke Jing몭s wine in one gulp, and just as a servant was about to pour more wine for both of them, Yan Yin shouted: 몮Wait a moment! Bring a new cup for our lord!몯
Fan Zhao was none too pleased by this. He got up and, pretending to be drunk, began dancing and shouted over to the Grand Preceptor,  a high-ranking official: 몮I want to have a dance! Can you play some music from Chengzhou?몯 The Grand Preceptor몭s reply was icy: 몮Nobody present is capable of playing the music you speak of.몯 This seemed to irk Fan Zhao, and he soon took his leave.
As the banquet drew to a close, Duke Jing said to his advisers: 몮What got in to you today? That man is the envoy of a powerful state, who came here to observe our ways of governance, and you몭ve all annoyed him. What good does that do us? Won몭t this just bring us more trouble?몯
Yan Ying replied: 몮He came to observe our ways of governance, and that몭s exactly what we showed him. You see, my lord, it몭s not that this Zhao Fan fellow doesn몭t understand proper etiquette; he was intentionally behaving in a belligerent manner. There is a clear difference of rank between rulers and ministers 멪 demanding the wine from a duke몭s goblet is a provocation. He was testing us. That몭s why I had your cup changed, my lord, so as not to throw the proper hierarchy into disorder by drinking from the same vessel as him.몯
The Grand Preceptor had his own piece to say: 몮The music of Chengzhou is sacred music. It belongs to the Son of Heaven (the Zhou king), and it is not for ministers or anyone else to dance along to. So, of course I couldn몭t play it for him.몯
Fan Zhao returned to Jin, and made his report to Duke Ping: 몮Do not invade Qi. I tried to humiliate their duke, but Yan Ying saw through me. Then, I tried to dishonor their ceremonial rites, but this time the Grand Preceptor called me out. Qi is a state with capable, virtuous ministers!몯
Confucius himself once praised the ministers of Qi, exclaiming: 몮Without taking the matter beyond wine vessels, Yan Ying blocked his enemy몭s attack from a thousand li distant.몯 
This is a man who, amid raised glasses and courteous smiles, destroyed the Jin plan to assault Qi, and beat the enemy back 1,000 li. This is the epitome of 몬attacking the enemy몭s plans.몭
Our third example comes from the Qin invasion of Jin, also during the Spring and Autumn period. The man in charge of the Jin army sent to stop the Qin was named Zhao Dun, but the Jin prime minister and overall military leader, Yu Pian, had his own idea: 몮The Qin army has travelled a long way, so they won몭t be able to stay long. We should build our walls higher and dig our moats deeper. All we need to do is wait around for the Qin soldiers to give up and go home.몯
The plan was put into action, and the Qin army was stuck. There was no fighting to be had, but they  couldn몭t retreat with nothing to show for it. Duke Mu of Qin asked his adviser Shi Hui what could be done. Shi Hui said: 몮I몭m absolutely positive that this is Yu Pian몭s idea. But there몭s another general in the Jin army, a young man named Zhao Chuan. He몭s Zhao Dun몭s nephew, and also the son-in-law of the Jin duke. He has no understanding whatsoever of military affairs, he몭s been spoiled to the point of arrogance, and he has a romantic love of bravery that renders him reckless. Importantly, he is not at all keen on Yu Pian being given the position of prime minister. If we can provoke Zhao Chuan몭s men, he몭s sure to come out and fight.몯
The Qin army did just that 멪 they harassed Zhao Chuan. Sure enough, Zhao Chuan led his men out in pursuit of his tormenters, but he couldn몭t catch them. Furious, he went back and fumed: 몮What are we doing here? Here we are, wearing armor and with food provisions ready, precisely so that we can kill our enemies. And yet we몭re not fighting! Why?몯 One of his men told him that they were waiting for the right opportunity, but Zhao Chuan didn몭t listen. 몮I don몭t care if they have some clever stratagem. If the others won몭t fight, I몭ll fight on my own!몯 he retorted, and promptly led his men out to fight. When Zhao Dun heard what his nephew had done, he was frustrated, but he didn몭t have a choice. He had to save Zhao Chuan, so he led out the entire Jin army and fought a terrible, daylong battle with the Qin army. At the end, it was unclear who had won and who had lost.
Each of the above three cases is different 멪 Kou Xun killed his enemy몭s planner-in-chief, Yan Ying nipped his enemy몭s plan in the bud, and Shi Hui sabotaged his enemy몭s plan when it was already in motion. But, each of them is a classic example of 몬attacking the enemy몭s plans.몭



Don몭t act like a dunce just because your teammate is a dunce

Extract from the original text:
몮Thus, the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy몭s plans; the next best is to attack the enemy몭s alliances; the next in order is to attack the enemy몭s army in the field.몯

Analysis:
In the previous chapter, we established that 몬attacking the enemy몭s plans몭 is about attacking the enemy몭s thoughts and rooting out their ideas. This forces them to realize: a) They몭re unprepared; b) Their odds are lousy; c) Attacking you would be very risky; and d) They should give up on their plan.
In this chapter, we move on to look at 몬attacking the enemy몭s alliances.몭 This is the practice of diplomacy (and counter-diplomacy) as a part of war. 
Historians of ancient China often talk about the 몬Vertical and Horizontal Alliances of the Roaming Diplomats,몭 during the Warring States period. There were two main ideas: that the various states lying on the east-west (horizontal) axis should form an alliance on the one hand, and on the other hand, that a north-south array of states should join together. The most famous diplomats behind them were, respectively, Zhang Yi and Su Qin. Su Qin몭s 몬vertical alliance몭 idea aimed to unite six states to jointly resist Qin, which had become a formidable power. The 몬horizontal alliance몭 idea came later, and Zhang Yi toured each of the six states in the vertical alliance, lobbying their rulers to ally with Qin. He pushed the line that cosying up to Qin would at least give them some respite from the constant fighting. Zhang몭s real aim was to dismantle the vertical alliance and isolate the six states. Then, Qin would destroy them, one by one. This historical era still echoes in the Chinese language today 멪 몬vertical-horizontal몭 is a commonly used Chinese word with a range of applications. It often means 몬interconnected.몭
A classic story from this period, and one that nicely demonstrates Sun Tzu몭s principles, is the tale of how Zhang Yi attacked the alliance between the state of Qi and King Huai of Chu.
First, Zhang Yi visited Chu, where he tried to tempt King Huai by offering him 600 li of land in Shangyu if he cut off his alliance with Qi and formed a new one with Qin. King Huai was delighted by this offer, and wasted no time accepting. He cut his ties with Qi, and sent a general to Qin to take possession of the land that had been promised him. But, Zhang Yi would not grant an audience to the visiting Chu general, claiming he was ill. King Huai began to ask himself questions. 몮Zhang Yi probably doesn몭t believe that I몭ve already called off my alliance with Qi,몯 he thought. So, he devised a way of showing his loyalty to Qin: he sent a warrior to Qi with instructions to insult and humiliate the Qi king. The Qi king was stunned by this sudden reversal, and stung by the humiliation, and flew into a rage. He retaliated by announcing that he was personally ending his alliance with Chu, and not only that, he also immediately allied himself with Qin.
Zhang Yi picked this moment to finally talk with the visiting Chu general, and fulfill his promise. That is, he partially fulfilled it. Of the 600 li of land he originally offered, he handed over only 6. Two zeros had gone missing
King Huai of Chu was outraged when he heard this, and immediately launched an attack on Qin. But, without the helping hand of their former ally, Qi, Chu was much too weak to beat Qin. Chu몭s defeat was catastrophic, and marked the beginning of the end 멪 Chu quickly fell into terminal decline.
The lessons to be learned from this story don몭t just come at the expense of King Huai of Chu, but also from the reaction of Qi. When Qin attacked Chu몭s alliance with Qi, shouldn몭t it have been  obvious that this also represented an attack against Qi; an attack on its own alliance with Chu? If your teammate acts like a fool, that doesn몭t mean that you should also act like a fool. When Chu attacked Qin, Qi could have come to their former ally몭s aid. Then, the Chu ruler would have felt both ashamed and grateful, and as a result the Chu-Qi alliance would be stronger than ever. Meanwhile, the real enemy, Qin, would have been thwarted, their plan a bust. As it happened, King Huai was not the only fool in this story; the King of Qi was just as foolish.
In the last chapter, we saw an example of a brutally direct way of 몬attacking the enemy몭s plans몭 멪 killing their chief planner. Similar to 몬attacking the enemy몭s alliances,몭 there are a surprising number of cases where a state has defeated the enemy by killing their diplomats.
During the wars between Liu Bang and Xiang Yu, both had sent envoys to try to persuade the rebel leader Ying Bu, who was sitting on the fence, to join their side. Ying Bu seemed to be leaning toward joining Liu Bei, but he was hesitant to commit. Meanwhile, he was still meeting and chatting with Xiang Yu몭s messenger, in the inn where Xiang Yu몭s man was staying. During one of these conversations, Xiang Yu몭s messenger chose his moment, and began pressing Ying Bu to send troops to help Xiang Yu.
Liu Bei몭s messenger, Sui He, knew what was happening, and made a quick decision. He burst into the room where the two men were talking, sat down in his counterpart몭s seat, and shouted: 몮The King of Huainan has already declared for Liu Bei. What are you talking about 멪 몬send troops?몭몯 Xiang Yu몭s envoy was startled, and made to leave the inn. Ying Bu seemed frozen to his seat. 몮We can몭t let him go. Kill him!몯 Sui He shouted. Ying Bu found himself forced into a corner. He had to make a decision now, even if he didn몭t want to. In fact, he did as Sui He said. He killed Xiang Yu몭s envoy, and led his soldiers to Liu Bei몭s in Han.
There몭s another famous example of destroying an alliance by killing a diplomat: the story of an Eastern Han dynasty general and diplomat named Ban Chao. He was sent on a diplomatic mission to the state of Shanshan in the western territories of the empire (a Central Asian region southwest of the Lopnor salt lake in modern-day Xinjiang autonomous region). At first, Ban Chao and his fellow travelers were warmly welcomed by the King of Shanshan. Yet, within a few days the mood turned cold. Ban Chao made enquiries high and low, and learned that the Northern Xiongnu had also sent an envoy to Shanshan. It seems that the King was trying to make his mind up about whom to ally himself with.
Ban Chao was nothing if not bold. He gathered 36 of his men and in the middle of the night launched a surprise attack on the inn where the Xiongnu envoy was staying, killing every member of their diplomatic team. Then, he took the envoy몭s head and went to see the King of Shanshan. The King was scared witless 멪 how could he explain to the Xiongnu why their envoy had died in his country? He couldn몭t, so his only option was to submit to the Han Emperor. He sent Ban Chao back to the capital, Chang몭an, with his own son, the prince, as a hostage to guarantee the new relationship between Shanshan and Chang몭an.

몮The next best thing is to attack the enemy몭s army in the field.몯 

This last option is saved for when you몭ve tried the first two, but they haven몭t worked. The first Zhou King몭s advisor, Jiang Ziya, said: 몮A leader who seeks victory by the blade of his sword, does not a good general make.몯
	



You don몭t win just by beating the enemy. The real test is: have you grown stronger, or weaker?

Extract from the original text:
몮Besieging walled cities is an option chosen only when nothing else is successful. The preparation of mantlets, armored wagons, and various implements of war will take up three whole months; and the piling up of mounds over against the walls will take three months more. The general, unable to control his irritation, will launch his men to the assault like swarming ants, with the result that one-third of his men are slain while the city still remains untaken. Such are the disastrous effects of a siege.몯

Analysis:
몬Mantlets몭 are a kind of large shield, which can cover a soldier몭s entire body, while 몬armored wagons몭 were leather-covered, four-wheeled troop-carriers, especially designed for sieges. Basically, they were the ancient Chinese equivalent of an armored personnel carrier. One wagon could carry several dozen men directly to the base of the enemy몭s city wall. Other siege equipment 멪 like siege towers and ladders, shelters made of wooden planks and catapults 멪 would take at least three months to build and prepare for battle. 
It would also take three months to finish various siege-related engineering projects, like shifting earth to make tuyin, a kind of mound used to give your soldiers access to the top of the enemy몭s walls, digging tunnels, and dealing with moats either by building bridges or filling them with earth.
Besieging a city is a slow grind, but it also requires attention to detail. If the besieging army몭s general is impatient, he might opt for the 몬swarming ants몭 tactic and end up losing a third of his men while still not capturing the city 멪 a disastrous scenario. It몭s not hard to imagine what a tactic named 몬swarming ants몭 entails. Basically, you cluster your soldiers into a dense mass and swarm up the city walls like ants. Of course, they몭ll be greeted on the way with arrows, rocks, boiling water, sizzling oil and fire. 몬swarming ants몭 is also known as 몬fluttering moth.몭 Perhaps this captures the image better.
This is why assaulting a city is a pretty desperate option, reserved only for when your original backup plan몭s backup plan has already fallen through. 
Sun Tzu몭s philosophy has a consistent thread: put aside all thoughts of winning and not winning, and instead concern yourself with making sure you don몭t lose. What really matters is whether you몭ve grown stronger or weaker. Don몭t put yourself in a position where your losses outweigh your gains, and don몭t throw away human lives. Life has value.
A classic example is the non-Chinese Tuoba Emperor Taiwu, of Northern Wei몭s attack on the Liu Song dynasty in Xuyi. Perhaps our ethnic minority cousins are naturally less constrained, but he was certainly playing loose when, on his way to attack a Liu Song city, he sent an envoy ahead to demand wine from the Liu Song garrison commander, Cang Zhi. The commander apparently wasn몭t in the mood to be accommodating. He produced several jars, and ordered his men to urinate in them. He gave them to the Tuoba envoy and sent him back. The Tuoba Emperor was furious, and immediately gave the order to storm the city. He commanded his men to scale the walls in waves, and warned that anyone who retreated would be executed. This went on for a month, and in the end, Tuoba bodies were piled as high as the city walls. Over half of Emperor Taiwu몭s men lay dead, he몭d killed his own vanguard leader, Gao Liangwang, and he still hadn몭t captured the city.  Finally, seeing his camp full of wounded and diseased soldiers, and fearing that his escape route might be cut off, he lifted the siege and beat a retreat, taking his grudge with him.
There was a general during the Republic of China period (1912-1949 CE) named Fu Zuoyi, who became famous for peacefully liberating the city of Beijing. But the moment that defined him was the battle of Zhuozhou, and the way he really made his name was as a formidable defender. No one was better than him at holding a city during a siege. 
During the war between the Zhili and Fengtian warlord cliques, although Fu Zuoyi몭s enemies, the Fengtian clique, had just won, he led a small, isolated force, determined to hold Zhuozhou against the enemy. He had no food, and he was cut off from all outside support, yet he refused to surrender. He was besieged by a Fengtian army of 50,000 men, while he had only several thousand. The siege went on for two months, with indiscriminate firebombing. The Fengtian commander, Zhang Xueliang, was hell-bent on leveling the city, and yet Fu Zuoyi kept on fighting. Eventually, the Fengtian commander-in-chief, Zhang Zuolin, let his anger at being denied victory make his decisions for him 멪 never a good idea! But Zhang didn몭t try the 몬swarming ants몭 tactic. Instead, he wanted to put Fu Zuoyi in his place by using some high-tech weaponry: poison gas canisters, 500 of them, hurled into the city.
After the noxious haze cleared, the Fengtian attacked one more time, but Fu Zuoyi was still there, and managed to push the Fengtian forces back again!
Zhang Zuolin gave up. 몮This kid몭s not going to surrender,몯 he told Zhang Xueliang. 몮No more trying to fight him. We몭ll starve him instead! Keep the city surrounded!몯
At that point, the Zhili clique leader, Yan Xishan, decided there wasn몭t much need to keep on fighting, so he instructed Fu Zuoyi to sue for peace. Only then did Fu Zuoyi finally sign a treaty and accept the Fengtian forces몭 terms.
A couple of decades later, when Communist Party General Lin Biao was besieging the city of Changchun, he used the same tactic that Zhang Zuolin eventually settled for: he surrounded the city and waited. Eventually, the Nationalist army starved, and it ultimately surrendered.



Adopt failure as the premise of your thinking; This is the foundation of military wisdom

Extract from the original text:
몮Therefore the skillful leader subdues the enemy몭s troops without any fighting; he captures their cities without laying siege to them; he overthrows their kingdom without lengthy operations in the field. With his forces intact he will dispute the mastery of the Empire, and thus, without losing a man, his triumph will be complete. This is the method of attacking by stratagem.몯

Analysis:
This is Sun Tzu몭s summary of 몬Planning Assaults.몭 He shows that, at its root, it is about planning to maintain 몬wholeness.몭 This not only ensures that you don몭t suffer any losses, but you also avoid damaging the enemy몭s assets, and fully benefit from taking them for yourself. To achieve this, you have to follow the three no몭s: no fighting, no assaulting and no prolonging. Again, the idea is to subdue the enemy몭s troops without fighting, take his city without assaulting it, and destroy his country without a long war.
In Sun Tzu몭s philosophy, there is a checklist with three things that you must do before embarking on any undertaking: (1) Think through the risks; (2) Think through the price you몭ll have to pay; (3) Think through how your undertaking will benefit you.
Two things above all else drive people into making mistakes: one is temptation, and the other is anxiety. 
There is a Chinese four-character idiom that describes this aspect of human psychology 멪it translates as, 몬Forgetting principle at the sight of profit.몭 But, this doesn몭t tell the whole story. A more universal version of the idiom would be: 몬Forgetting danger at the sight of profit.몭 For many people, it몭s hard to resist the tantalizing attraction of financial reward, even if it means risking their life. Some people even die for pennies.
Then there몭s anxiety. The reason it forces mistakes is that when people are in an anxious state, they feel a need to do something, anything. When people are in this frame of mind, how can you expect them to wait patiently, and not fight or attack the enemy몭s city? The battlefield is a place that teeters between the worlds of life and death. It is no place for a perennially anxious commander, because when anxiety distorts your every thought, mistakes crop up with alarming ease.
What can you do to avoid making mistakes? The answer is to adopt failure as the premise behind your every thought. Normally, we tend to do the opposite, predicating all our thoughts on the idea of success, because when we do something, the aim is to do it successfully. So, isn몭t it natural to put success at the center of our thinking, planning, policy-making, critical analysis and judgment calls? If your strategy teacher doesn몭t teach you about success, is it really 몬the art of war몭 that they몭re teaching?
Well, The Art of War doesn몭t take this approach, and instead relates everything back to failure. For everything Sun Tzu wrote about achieving, he first hypothesized that the outcome would actually end in failure. His analysis, planning, policy-making and assessments all revolve around avoiding failure, and decreasing any losses you may have to incur. The way things should be done, according to Sun Tzu, is to first set yourself up in a position where you can몭t be defeated, carry out your plan, wait for an opportunity and, finally, resolve the conflict with a single move.
It몭s the same in the business world, and it몭s why a person who has the ability to focus, be consistent, and stay under the radar 멪 while steadily perfecting their particular craft over the course of years 멪 can make it as a leading figure in their industry. Then there are people who are always looking around for something new to do, regularly hopping from one thing to another, and riding the turbulent waves of life as an entrepreneur.  The difference between these two types of people is essentially about their ways of thinking. The former is not necessarily particularly wise; they몭re just people who think a lot about failure, and make it the premise of their planning. They몭re the kind of person who, whenever you tell them about some new idea, tells you that your idea is risky. They first think about new things in terms of how they might fail, and only continue pursuing things they몭ve already experienced some success with. And so, eventually, their work culminates in massive success. On the other hand, the latter type of person 멪 the type who thinks a lot about success 멪 only has ears for opportunity. They believe that big opportunities absolutely cannot be missed, and so they spend their whole lives starting new businesses.
The Hong Kong business magnate Li Ka-shing once said: 몮Whenever you set out to do something, first reflect on failure.몯 This is the fundamental wisdom of 몬the art of war.몭 When we talk about 몬masters,몭 what makes one a master is that they know they몭re the same as everyone else. Thy recognize that at least half of the projects that present themselves will end in failure if attempted, so they몭re extremely cautious. If someone boasts that there몭s nothing they can몭t do, you know they몭re not a master. The only 몬greatness몭 they몭re setting themselves up for is great disappointment.
The last of Sun Tzu몭s three is 몬no prolonging.몭 Basically, this means you should make as few moves as possible, and then, at the crucial moment, play your hand. The worst thing you could do is spend every day trying new things, making new moves, and repeating things you몭ve already done. The more you do, the more mistakes you make.



Concentrate a superior force and aim to annihilate the enemy

Extract from the original text:
몮It is the rule in war, if our forces are ten to the enemy몭s one, to surround him; if five to one, to attack him; if twice as numerous, to divide the army9 into two. If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him. Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force.몯

Analysis:
Sun Tzu takes great pains to emphasize the principle of military strength, which means only fighting when you have absolute advantage over your enemy. Only try to surround your enemy if your men outnumber his by ten to one, and only consider making a frontal attack if your men outnumber his by at least five to one. This is the idea behind the title of this chapter, which is a quotation from Mao Zedong. 
If you only outnumber the enemy two to one, you don몭t have absolute advantage, and you should 몮divide the (his) army into two.몯 Manipulate him into cutting his own army in two, because then you can manufacture a position where you have absolute advantage. This is another way to describe Mao Zedong몭s style of mobile warfare. It involved leveraging a large amount of space where battles could potentially happen in order to buy himself time, which he used to maneuver his troops into position and surround the enemy. Mao몭s strategy was one of using absolute advantage to fight quick, decisive battles. He summarized his approach as: 몮Evading the enemy몭s main force, luring the enemy deep into the country, concentrating our own forces in advantageous positions, and destroying the enemy몭s fragmented forces, one piece at a time.몯

몮If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy.몯

If your forces are equally matched with the enemy몭s, and you are unfortunate enough to meet them on the field, determine whether you몭re capable of beating them, and then stand and fight. If not, run as fast as you can and get out of sight. As Mao put it: 몮If you can fight and win, then fight; if not, then run.몯
What will happen if you don't run? 몮Though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force.몯 



Divide your enemy몭s army and fight: The method

Extract from the original text:
몮If our forces are ten to the enemy몭s one, surround him; if five to one, attack him; if twice as numerous, divide the army into two.몯

Analysis:
몮If our forces are ten to the enemy몭s one, surround him.몯 Once you have the enemy surrounded, you can force him to surrender, or annihilate his army.
It몭s said that 몬One woman on a city wall can beat ten men outside.몭 The same idea is presented in the ancient military text, the Wei Liaozi: 몮One man becomes as ten men, ten men as a hundred, a hundred as a thousand, and a thousand as ten thousand.몯 If defenders have a ten-to-one advantage, naturally their enemies will need an advantage of at least ten-to-one to stand a chance.
Du Mu elaborates on this, pointing out that to surround the enemy means sealing him in on four sides. The purpose is not only to defeat him, but also to prevent him from escaping. To achieve a full encirclement of the enemy, you몭ll need to choose a place that몭s both far away from the enemy몭s cities and has a wide expanse of open ground. Then, you have to enforce the encirclement by vigilantly guarding the trapped enemy forces. If you don몭t have enough men, there will be gaps in your encirclement, and 몬leaks몭 are bound to happen.

몮If five to one, attack him.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮With five to one, take three as your main force and two as a surprise force.몯 This means that, assuming the enemy has closed his ranks and adopted a defensive position, you should attack with three fifths of your army while keeping two fifths in reserve. And then, later, use your reserves to secure your victory in a surprise attack.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮You must surprise him from the front and harass him from the rear; feint east and strike west. If you do not possess a five-to-one advantage, you will be unable to divide as many of his troops.몯
He Shi comments: 몮If I have five times as many soldiers as the enemy, then I can attack the city walls with three fifths of my forces, and use two fifths to seal victory using my auxiliary force.몯
A good historical example of this in action is the story of Dugu Xin attacking Yuwen Zhonghe in Liang Province, during the time of the Western Wei dynasty.
The Western Wei government had appointed the governor of Yi Province, a man named Shi Ning, to be the new governor of Liang province. But Liang Province몭s resident governor, Yuwen Zhonghe, refused to be replaced and stayed put. Prime Minister Yuwen Tai decided to deal with the situation by sending the prince몭s tutor, Dugu Xin, with an army to put the rebellious ex-governor in his place. As the army advanced, Yuwen Zhonghe holed up behind the walls of the city of Ying. Dugu Xin몭s strategy was to send his generals to the northeast corner of the city wall in the middle of the night with siege ladders, while he led a separate force to attack the southwest corner. By dawn, the city belonged to Dugu Xin, and Yuwen Zhonghe was his prisoner.

If your army is twice as numerous, divide the (enemy몭s) army into two.몯

If you only have twice the troop numbers of the enemy, you don몭t have a big enough advantage, and you need to come up with a way to make the enemy divide his army. In Du Mu몭s commentary, he clarified that Sun Tzu meant that it is the enemy몭s army that should be divided, and not your own. (As noted earlier, the original text in Chinese is so condensed that it could be interpreted either way). Du Mu advises that you should use your army to attack either the enemy몭s weakest point, or attack him where you know he will be unable to resist immediately coming to the rescue. In this way, you can decrease the number of troops available to him, and consolidate your initial two-to-one advantage. Then, it몭ll be much easier to defeat him.
Cao Cao몭s commentary is simpler: 몮If attacking one with two, then use one part as your mainstay, and the other part as the auxiliary force.몯 Cao Cao몭s interpretation of Sun Tzu is different; he reads it as an imperative to divide your own army.
Du Mu argues that the decision to split your army into a main force and an auxiliary force has nothing to do with the relative number of troops commanded by you and your enemy. He says that it몭s an essential part of all wars. As a case in point, when Xiang Yu fought his last battle by the Wu River, he only had 28 cavalry left, but he still split his men into a main force and an auxiliary force. During that battle, his two forces took turns trying to save each other. 
Du Mu was right 멪 the meaning of the original text is that you should divide the enemy몭s army. However, to achieve this, first you have to divide your own army. So, Cao Cao was right too. Cao Cao went into more detail as well, spelling out how many troops should be allocated for different functions. This topic actually constitutes a whole branch of the art of war, known as 몬the art of division.몭 A book by Ming dynasty strategist Liu Bowen, Extraordinary Strategies of a Hundred Battles, contains a chapter devoted to the art of division. Here몭s an excerpt:
몮When fighting your enemy, if my forces are numerous and the enemy몭s few, then I ought to select an open expanse as the site where I will defeat him. If my forces are five times more numerous than the enemy몭s, then I ought to allocate three fifths of my soldiers to be the main force, with the remaining two fifths as an auxiliary force. If my forces are three times more numerous than the enemy몭s, then I ought to allocate two thirds of my soldiers to be the main force, with the remaining one third as an auxiliary force. This can be called 몬blocking him in the front with one half of my forces, while attacking his rear with the other half.몭 The past master10 says: 몬if you do not divide when you ought to divide, you are tying your own hands.몭몯
Cao Cao몭s 몮If attacking one with two, then use one part as your main force, and the other part as the auxiliary force몯 could just as well be added to the text above.
In this chapter, the concept of 몬main forces and auxiliary forces몭 has repeatedly popped up. In fact, it comes from perhaps the most famous line (in China) of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몮Use the regular to engage the enemy, and the irregular to defeat him.몯 Here, 몬irregular몭 doesn몭t refer to anything strange or odd, despite the fact that the Chinese character used in the original text usually means 몬extraordinary,몭 or even 몬queer.몭 It simply means 몬forces kept in reserve.몭 While the main forces get the fight started, the commander watches from his command center, waiting for the crucial moment. Then, he orders his reserves to spring into action, sealing his victory.
This topic will be discussed in more detail in Chapter Five: Force. For now, we will put it to one side, closing with a quotation from Jiang Ziya: 몮It is no good talking about the use of auxiliary forces with a general who does not understand the art of dividing troops.몯

몮If twice as numerous, divide the army into two.몯

There are two famous examples of this: one reflecting how it should be done, and the other an instance of how it should not be done.
The example of how it should not be done comes to us courtesy of Emperor Fu Jian of the Former Qin Empire (not to be confused with the Qin Dynasty, which was the first to unify China in a single empire). It몭s the story of Fu Jian몭s catastrophic defeat in the Battle of Fei River, in 383 CE. His fatal mistake was that he didn몭t divide his troops when he should have. He had a ten-to-one advantage 멪  800,000 troops against the opposing Eastern Jin army of 80,000 멪 but he kept his whole army grouped together in a single mass. When the Eastern Jin forces attacked, his army fell into confusion and crumbled.
The example of how it should be done comes from a general of the Liang Dynasty, Wang Sengbian, who used the tactics of troop division to defeat rebel forces commanded by Hou Jing at a battle at Zhanggongzhou.
Wang Sengbian, along with another Liang general named Chen Baxian, lined up their forces opposite those of Hou Jing at Zhanggongzhou. The Liang army몭s battle banners flew high and proud, resplendent against a bright sky. Seeing the flags, Hou Jing felt disheartened. 몮Morale seems high in the Liang army. Let몭s blunt some of their enthusiasm and take away their edge,몯 he said. So, Hou Jing ordered his drummers to drum, and led 10,000 steel-clad cavalry in a direct charge. Chen Baxian turned to Wang Sengbian and quoted a passage from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몮Those who are skilled in war are like the snake of Mount Chang. Strike at its head, and you will be attacked by its tail. Strike at its tail, and you will be attacked by its head.몯 Then, he said: 몮The rebel scum is walking into his own death; he wants this fight. We are many and they are few, so we should divide his forces.몯 Wang Sengbian agreed. From the front, he held the enemy back using his crossbowmen, while attacking it from behind with his more mobile forces. Then, the bulk of his army separated into three groups, and charged straight at Hou Jing몭s forces from three different angles, causing them to collapse. Defeated, Hou Jing fled back behind his city walls. 



The wisdom of admitting defeat

Extract from the original text:
몮If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him. Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force.몯

Analysis:
몮If equally matched, we can offer battle.몯 If your forces are evenly matched with the enemy몭s, it몭s important that you have the ability to fight.
Cao Cao comments: 몮If the number of one몭s force are equivalent to the enemy몭s, then the skillful general lays an ambush with his irregular troops, and in this way secures victory.몯 So, once again it comes back to a division of duties between 몬regular and irregular troops.몭 The regular troops challenge the enemy head-on, while the irregular troops prepare an ambush. Though Cao Cao doesn몭t spell out here what proportion of troops should be allocated for 몬regular몭 and 몬irregular몭 roles, history tells us that in most cases when generals used this 몬lure and ambush몭 tactic, the main force was actually smaller than the auxiliary force.

몮If slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy.몯

If you have fewer troops than the enemy, don몭t leave your defensive position. Dig deep defensive trenches and put up high walls. Alternatively, conceal yourself so that the enemy doesn몭t know how weak you are, and when you get the chance, run away!

몮If quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him.몯

In Du Mu몭s commentary, he explains that if you are weaker than the enemy both in terms of your military strength and the level of support you receive from your allies, you need to escape without delay and flee as far away as possible. If the enemy gets too close to your weak point, it will be too late to run.
Sun Tzu was a conservative, deeply cautious man. He always wanted to win before fighting, and he refused to fight if victory did not seem almost certain. He certainly would never fight if he had fewer men than the enemy. On this point, Sun Tzu doesn몭t conform to certain mainstream values. We love to see an underdog beat a larger opponent, and history seems to be on our side on this, because the books are full of stories of famous underdog victories. So, why exactly shouldn몭t you fight just because the enemy has more men than you?
There몭s a concept from management studies called 몬proof is silent.몭 Cases where one side has held a truly absolute majority, where there has been an absolute probability, tend to happen in silence. Nobody talks about them, so nobody knows about them. On the other hand, people tend to make a lot of noise about low-probability events, where the underdog somehow defeats their more powerful foe. With such loud fanfare, these events are still remembered 1,000 years after they happen. So, as stories of these events have piled up over the course of 3,000 years of Chinese history, they appear much more common than they actually were. They have in fact become a mainstream cultural narrative.
 So, what is 몬silent evidence?몭 First of all, generals who run away because they didn몭t have as many men as their opponent tend to keep quiet about it. It몭s not something people like to publicize. Perhaps it shouldn몭t come as a surprise that none of the 11 great commentators on Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War offered a single historical example of these lines. In fact, they really wrote nothing about it; not even so much as a brief explanation! Zhang Yu did write a short addendum: 몮When the opponent is numerous and I am few, I ought to flee from him.몯  But 멪 and there is an important 몬but몭 멪 Zhang Yu also said: 몮If the enemy is in chaos and I am well ordered, if the enemy is lax and I am vigorous, then even though the enemy may be more numerous than my forces, I can still contend with him in battle.몯 Zhang Yu offered two historical examples: 몮Since Wu Qi destroyed a Qin army with 500 men against 500,000, and Xie Xuan defeated Fu Jian with 8,000 men against a million, what need was there for them to flee?몯
Zhang Yu몭s claim here is equivalent to listening to Sun Tzu tell you that you shouldn몭t try to break a stone with an egg (which he did actually say), and then responding with two examples of someone doing exactly that.
Zhang Yu is advocating a 몬yes, but멞몭 approach here. But, what about you? Could you replicate the things he talked about, defeating a force of 500,000 with only 500 men? A good number of people tend to think that they can be the exception to the rule. After all, every time someone has defied the rule, their story has literally gone down in history. But, propping up each of these success stories is an intricate structure of countless random circumstances. If you몭re missing just one piece, things won몭t go your way.
Today, we can add two more historical examples to illustrate the principles of, 몬If slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him.몭 One of them involves 몬silent evidence,몭 and the other is heavy on the fanfare. The one about silent evidence is the story of Shi Dakai, a general of the Taiping Rebellion during the Qing dynasty. His expeditionary force was hemmed in by the pursuing Qing imperial army, and within a year and a half he fought in three different provinces: Sichuan, Guizhou and Yunnan. After that, he returned to Sichuan and broke through the Qing defensive line at the Yangzi River. In the end, though, he couldn몭t quite get away. He died, and his story ceased to be told. This is the silent evidence: his story does not prove that Zhang Yu몭s words were correct.
The other story, the loud one, is common knowledge. The reason it remains known is that the army involved, once it started running, kept running for 8,000 miles. They got away from their enemies, and at the end of the war they emerged victorious. This is the story of the Red Army몭s Long March (1934-1935 CE). What would have happened if the Red Army didn몭t start running at that crucial juncture in Jiangxi Province?   

몮Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force.몯

A classic historical example of this is provided by the Han dynasty General Li Ling. General Li was ordered by Han Wudi to deliver a shipment of grain and fodder, but his pride wouldn몭t allow him to act as a lowly deliveryman. So, he asked permission to lead 5,000 infantry in a direct assault against the Xiongnu royal court. He ended up surrounded by 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry, and surrendered. Han Wudi punished Li몭s failure by executing his entire family, and even Li몭s main cheerleader, court historian Sima Qian, was punished with castration.
Wanting to win is part of being human, but reality reminds us that there몭s always a good chance of losing. So, it몭s important to be able to admit defeat. According to Stan Shih, the founder of Taiwan몭s tech giant Acer Inc, 몮You can only be a winner if you know how to concede defeat.몯 There몭s a lot to this idea. You could also say that only by losing can life keep on going. When we admit that we몭ve lost, we can keep hold of our wins and eventually expand upon them.
Even the renowned Ming dynasty thinker and statesman Wang Yangming 멪 who during his lifetime built a monumentally important body of scholarship and went down in history as one of the four great masters of Confucianism 멪 admitted defeat and stoically withstood the scheming of the palace secret police (몬the embroidered uniform guard몭) as they attempted to frame and provoke him with all kinds of outrageous ploys that also harmed the common folk. He understood that in the dark society of his times, anyone who attempted to extend justice, or even just a helping hand, to the common folk would immediately be pounced upon and destroyed. He acknowledged that this would not do anyone any good. He knew that all he could do was hold back until the secret police saw that they couldn몭t prevail.
So, Wang Yangming accepted defeat for the time being, and waited. He saw that if he waited until he was no longer in a losing position, then by default he would become a winner!



It몭s the emperor몭s prerogative to not understand military Issues, but it몭s imperative for generals to understand politics

Extract from the original text:
몮Now, the general is the bulwark of the State; if the bulwark is complete at all points, the State will be strong; if the bulwark is defective, the State will be weak. There are three ways in which a ruler can bring misfortune upon his army: (1) By commanding the army to advance or to retreat, being ignorant of the fact that it cannot obey. This is called hobbling the army. (2) By attempting to govern an army in the same way as he administers a kingdom, being ignorant of the conditions that obtain in an army. This causes restlessness in the soldier몭s minds. (3) By employing the officers of his army without discrimination, through ignorance of the military principle of adaptation to circumstances. This shakes the confidence of the soldiers. But when the army is restless and distrustful, trouble is sure to come from the other feudal princes. This is simply bringing anarchy into the army, and flinging victory away.몯

Analysis:
몮The general is the bulwark of the State; if the bulwark is complete at all points, the State will be strong; if the bulwark is defective, the State will be weak.몯 Here, the words 몬complete몭 and 몬defective몭 have three levels of meaning. On the first level, 몬complete몭 means 몬possessing both wisdom and talent, and having well-rounded abilities,몭 while 몬defective몭 means 몬having gaps in one몭s abilities.몭 On the second level, 몬complete몭 means that 몬the general몭s military arrangements are integrated and watertight, while 몬defective몭 means 몬the general몭s arrangements are full of holes.몭 On the third level, 몬complete몭 means 몬the general몭s plans are complete and carefully kept secret,몭 and safe from leaks, while 몬defective몭 means 몬the general몭s plans are transparent and obvious,몭 allowing the enemy to see and capitalize on your strengths and weaknesses.
We should follow the same principles in our daily activities: we should be fully equipped, keep our plans tight and allow no leaks in our calculations. If you leave any base uncovered 멪 if there몭s just one issue that you haven몭t given adequate consideration to 멪 what you have is a leak, and when it comes down to it, this leak will sink you. If this happens, there몭ll be no point crying out at the injustice: 몬Who knew this would happen?몭
There is an ancient Chinese phrase: 몬Not knowing is not a sin.몯 Totally incorrect! The phrase has it backward 멪 not knowing is the biggest sin of all! If you don몭t know about something, how can you deal with it responsibly?
From here, Sun Tzu outlines the 몬three not knowings몭 that every state leader must avoid. His message is: 몬Yes, you몭re the boss, but you몭re ignoring a few things, because you don몭t know about them.몭
The first 몬not knowing몭 is not knowing that your army is not in a position to advance, and as a result, you force the issue and order them to advance anyway. By the same token, you will be unaware of when your army isn몭t in a position to retreat, and so you force them to retreat when you shouldn몭t. Case in point: During the Tang dynasty몭s massive An Lushan Rebellion, General Geshu Han intended to hold Tongguan Pass against the rebel army. However, because Emperor Xuanzong didn몭t know that Geshu몭s army was in no position to fight a pitched battle, Xuanzong insisted that Geshu do exactly that. What happened? Geshu몭s army was overwhelmed and Tongguan Pass was lost. As a result, the capital city, Chang몭an, fell to the rebels and Emperor Xuanzong was forced to flee south to Sichuan.
Another example: During the Battle of Fei River in 383 CE, General Xie Xuan of Jin told his adversary, Fu Jian of Former Qin, 몮Move your army back a little bit; I몭ll cross the river, and then we can fight it out.몯 Fu Jian was apparently unaware that he absolutely should not retreat, and he did indeed move his troops back. Fu Jian몭s rear units didn몭t know why the forward units seemed to be retreating; all they knew was that they could hear the enemy troops shouting: 몮The Qin are defeated!몯 They thought that their own comrades at the front really had been defeated, so they turned and ran, and that몭s how a false defeat turned into a real one.
Situations like these are what happen when the leader doesn몭t know that life and death hang in the balance with every move his army makes, whether forward or backward. It is about knowing when to stop.
The second 몬not knowing몭 is not knowing anything about military issues, yet still wanting to have a role in the management of your army.
The Methods of the Sima says: 몮Military affairs cannot be allowed to permeate the state, and state affairs cannot be allowed to permeate the military.몯 Ruling a country and commanding an army are two very different games, with very different rules.
The military text Bing Jing says: 몮In state affairs, use words; in military affairs, use deception.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Benevolence and a principled approach can be used to rule a state, but not to command an army; an adaptable approach can be used to command an army, but not to rule a state.몯
Fu Jian, the losing Former Qin commander and Emperor, had bright prospects once upon a time. He was a brilliant and celebrated leader, and the military strength he commanded was unprecedented in his times. But, he was also the kind of person who indulges others, a personality trait that set the tone for the way he acted in his dealings with his enemy, General Xie Xuan. In their relationship, Fu Jian saw himself as the Emperor, and Xie Xuan as his subject. Perhaps he took inspiration from Zhuge Liang, who apparently captured, and then released, his enemy Meng Huo no less than seven times. Fu Jian let Xie Xuan take the initiative, and then, when he captured him, he tried to win him over with persuasion. During Fu Jian몭s erstwhile efforts, he forgot that 몮The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin; Hence, it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected.몯 Carelessness must not be tolerated. Because of one lapse of attention, Fu Jian몭s army crumbled, his country collapsed, and he lost his own life. 
In Du Mu몭s commentary, he expresses his opinion that armies have distinct systems of etiquette and command, and can only be handled using military methods and rules. If you try to command an army using the ordinary methods of administrating a state, the soldiers won몭t know what you want them to do. To illustrate his point, Du Mu cites the example set by Han dynasty general Zhou Yafu. When Zhou was stationed in Xiliu, the Emperor, Han Wendi, made an inspection tour of his forces, intending to show his appreciation to the soldiers. At every camp the Emperor visited, the gate guards let him pass as soon as they saw him, and the commanding officers rushed out to greet him. But Zhou Yafu몭s camp was different.
When Han Wendi arrived, he was stopped by the guards and told to wait while someone went to inform Zhou Yajun that he몭d arrived. The guards told the Emperor that they took orders from no one except their general, not even from the Son of Heaven. The Emperor waited for a good while before he was allowed in. Zhou Yafu didn몭t come out to greet him, but just gave a simple message for his men to relay to Han Wendi: 몮Please enter.몯 Zhou even told the emperor that his carriage was not permitted to move too quickly while inside the camp, per military rules. When the Emperor몭s carriage pulled up outside Zhou몭s tent, Zhou stood in the doorway and offered a simple salutation, clasping his hands in front of him and bowing. He told the Emperor that he couldn몭t kneel, because he was wearing armor.
Han Wendi leaned up against the railing of his carriage, and nodded his head admiringly toward Zhou Yafu. From then on, he marked out Zhou Yafu as a general he could rely upon, and on his deathbed, he told his successor, Han Jingdi, that Zhou Yafu should be made use of in the event of any military problems. Han Jingdi took his predecessor몭s advice, and Zhou Yafu went on to successfully put down the major Rebellion of the Seven States.
However, though the example Du Mu chose is a classic, it몭s not entirely apt. This is because, on that day at the Xiliu army camp, there were two important factors in play: Han Wendi몭s moral character, and Zhou Yafu몭s temperament. Zhou Yafu was very self-assured, cocky even, and he didn몭t only behave this way in his own camp. He didn몭t adopt a more deferential manner even when he was called to the imperial palace. Eventually, his behavior made Emperor Jingdi uncomfortable, and because of his lack of judgment he ended up accused of plotting treason. He was an old man by then, but he couldn몭t stand being accused of such a crime, so he chose to go on hunger strike in protest, a choice that proved to be fatal.
The third 몬not knowing몭 is not understanding that in the army, you need to adapt your leadership style to deal with changing circumstances, while still being involved in giving orders. There몭s no getting around the fact that, if the wrong person is in charge, you몭re going to lose. The most classic example of this is from the famous Battle of Changping (262-260 BCE), between the states of Qin and Zhao. The Zhao commander, Zhao Kuo, had no battlefield ability 멪 he was an armchair strategist at best. Zhao몭s fellow general, Lian Po, knew this, the Zhao statesman Ling Xiangru knew, and Zhao Kuo몭s mother knew. Even his dead father knew. Only two people didn몭t know: Zhao Kuo himself, and the King of Zhao. And, in brief, that is how 400,000 Zhao soldiers lost their lives.
Each of the 몬three not knowings몭 comes down this: 몮A general in the field is not subject to orders from his sovereign.몭 They are about the dangers of a ruler trying to directly control their armies. The Zhou dynasty strategist Jiang Ziya said: 몮The state cannot be governed from outside, and an army cannot be commanded from the palace.몯 If a ruler constantly tries to control his armies from afar, 몮The armies will be driven into a state of confusion and doubt, and the feudal lords will be subjected to great difficulties.몯 When this happens to a state, its enemies are able to exploit the confusion and slip in through the cracks. When you throw your own army into disorder, you몭re inviting the enemy in and giving victory away.

몮A general in the field is not subject to orders from his sovereign.몯

These words were meant for the ears of rulers, but an erstwhile advisor can never assume that the ruler will actually listen. The best they can do is try to open the ruler몭s eyes to the truth of these words. If he refuses to accept that truth, they still have to obey his orders. A general who doesn몭t obey his ruler doesn몭t tend to stay alive for long, and if he can몭t protect his own life, how can he protect his country? Then, what몭s the use in being considered a hero? A good example is the famous and highly celebrated Song dynasty martyr, General Yue Fei, who died because he refused to accept that the Emperor wouldn몭t listen to him. To this day, he is a Chinese national hero. People lionize him, and in the same breath they demonize Qin Hui, who is characterized as a treacherous courtier who betrayed Yue Fei. And yet, this doesn몭t change the fact that the Song dynasty was destroyed. Yue Fei몭s decisions compromised his duty to care for his country.
A counter-example would be the Qin General Wang Jian. The Qin king entrusted him with an enormous, 100,000멨strong army, which he used to eliminate six states in a row and unify all of China. He knew he had to reassure the King that he didn몭t have royal ambitions of his own, so he would frequently send messengers to the royal court asking for small favors. For example, one day he would ask for a few fields, and the next day he몭d ask for a simple house. In contrast, Yue Fei had a habit of doing and saying things that the Emperor found threatening, such as his ambition to rescue the two former Song Emperors who had been captured by their northern Jurchen enemies. How could he have expected Emperor Gaozong to tolerate this? What did he expect Gaozong to do if he came back with two other Emperors? How would Gaozong know that Yue Fei wouldn몭t pledge allegiance to one of them over him?
So, while it몭s acceptable for an Emperor to not understand military issues, it absolutely is not acceptable for a general to not understand politics.
The words 몬a general in the field is not subject to orders from his sovereign몭 are meant as advice for rulers, but it can never be assumed that an Emperor or King will understand the importance of this rule. The understanding has to come from the ruler; all an advisor can do is guide them to realize it.



Nothing is more difficult than getting judgment calls right

Extract from the original text:
몮Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (1) He will win who knows when to fight and when not to fight.몯

Analysis:
Here, Sun Tzu is talking about ways of knowing victory, not acquiring victory. This is another demonstration of the idea that you can know ahead of time who몭s going to win, but you can몭t just make victory happen. It몭s about not going to the battlefield in the hope that fortune will favor you and bring victory. It몭s about fighting a single, decisive battle when you already know that victory is assured. So, the first of these five factors is about knowing when you can fight and when you cannot 멪 before you make any moves, you need to know whether or not you can win.
This is a lot to ask of a general몭s ability to make sound judgment calls. How do you know when victory is a sure thing? If you always think you몭re going to win, and if you do indeed win time after time, wouldn몭t that make you a demigod? 
My own experience in the world of work is this: it몭s impossible to know whether you몭re definitely going to win, but it is possible to know when you몭re definitely going to lose.
For example, if you몭re tasked with drawing up a project plan, your most important skill is not creativity. Rather, it몭s an ability to make good judgment calls, as well as a clear grasp of where you are at any given point in the project, and knowing whether or not you몭re on track to successful completion. Being able to make good judgment calls is a prerequisite to creativity, and it몭s important to true creativity. Without this ability, creativity disengages from reality and floats off into an undefined, nebulous zone. How do you deal with this kind of creativity? The Han dynasty Grand Historian, Sima Qian, had this answer: 몮When a madman speaks, the sage seriously considers his words.몯 In other words, call in someone else to make a judgment for you.
There are some things that people believe only because they hope they몭re true 멪 wishful thinking is a human weakness. Let몭s suppose that wishful thinking accounts for 30% of any given judgment call. Having said that, whenever you feel a high degree of certainty about something, first subtract 30% of that certainty, and reevaluate. If you feel 100% sure of something, you get a revised certainty of 70% after subtracting the 몬wishful thinking몭 factor. Assuming that our judgment is accurate, there몭s a 50% probability of winning 멪 very good prospects indeed.
Success happens occasionally, but failure is always there, all but inevitable. It몭s important to understand this, and to not act rashly.
Knowing victory and defeat is just another way of saying evaluating the situation before 몬going to battle.몭 And the results will just automatically happen the way you몭ve called them, right? Actually, no. Wars end in victory or defeat, but that몭s not the case in business! Often, you don몭t know what the result is even after the 몬fight몭 has been 몬fought.몭 Sometimes, the results seem to show that you몭ve won, when in fact you몭ve just suffered a massive loss. Why?
The reason is that losses are often concealed; they can lie low for a long time, before finally reemerging and dealing you a crippling blow. It works like this: when someone starts a business, success and failure seem very obvious in the way they present themselves. Wins present as goals that have been achieved, while failures present as projects that end up costing you money. But, once a business is up and running, it몭s perfectly possible that you could make a crucial error, and yet your revenues keep on growing. By the time your market share starts to come down, you might not think that you몭ve done anything wrong, perhaps blaming it on your product having exhausted its life cycle.
Nothing is more difficult that making judgment calls and getting them right.



How many troops you can command depends on how strong your management skills are

Extract from the original text: 
몮Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (2) He will win who knows how to handle both superior and inferior forces.몯

Analysis:
Every line of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War is densely packed with information, and this one is no exception. The idea here, in the second of the 몬Five factors for knowing victory,몭 is that if you understand the different uses of both large and small numbers of troops, you have the ability to be a leader of men and armies. Broadly speaking, to unpack the meaning of this line we need to look at it from three different perspectives:
1) Do you know how many soldiers you need?

Example: King Zheng of Qin (the man who eventually became the First Emperor of all China) was intent on destroying the state of Chu, so he called a court meeting of all his ministers, and asked them how many men and horses would be needed to take Chu. One minister, Wang Jian, said: 몮Without 600,000 men, it cannot be done.몯 Li Xin disagreed: 몮A force of 200,000 is all that will be needed to defeat Chu.몯 King Zheng naturally preferred Li Xin몭s answer, and dismissed Wang Jian as an addled old man, no longer fit for use. The King named Li Xin and another general, Meng Tian, commanders of a 200,000-strong army, and sent them south to attack Chu. They lost, badly. Seven high-ranking Qin officers were killed, and the debacle stands out in history as one of the few major defeats suffered by Qin.

The first thing the Qin King did was apologize to Wang Jian, and then he invited him to lead a new army and fight Qin몭s enemies. Wang agreed, on the condition that he would be given 600,000 men.
	
Wang led his army into the state of Chu, set up camp and stayed put. He showed no interest in starting any fights, and instead spent his time running athletic competitions for his men. The Chu army was outnumbered, and they knew they were in position to attack, but after a year passed with no sign of action, the Chu forces became restless and began moving around much more often. Gaps soon opened in their defenses, and Wang Jian wasted no time 멪 he pounced, and in no time at all the state of Chu came undone.

When the Xiongnu leader, Modun, wrote that highly improper letter to Empress Lu, the first thought that came into the furious Empress몭 mind was to send out troops to punish the chieftain for his impertinence. In the imperial court, General Fan Kuai got quite carried away by the excitement of the occasion and, eager to answer the Empress몭 call, dramatically proclaimed: 몮Give me 100,000 men and horses, and I will wipe the Xiongnu from the maps!몯 He wasn몭t the only one; everyone seemed to be jumping on the war wagon. But then, Li Bu shouted over all the other voices: 몮Fan Kuai, you should be executed for such a suggestion! Do you forget that our late lord the Emperor once led a host of over 400,000 men against the Xiongnu, and yet he was surrounded at Baideng? It was only by the grace of Chen Ping몭s silver tongue that the enemy allowed Emperor Gaozu safe passage home. But you 멪 do you consider yourself superior to Gaozu?몯 

Empress Lu soon recovered her cool, and decided the best response was to write back to Modun instead of fighting him. Her letter, which we detailed earlier, was well balanced 멪 neither submissive nor overbearing 멪 which allowed her to maintain a friendly, peaceful relationship with her powerful Xiongnu neighbors.

2) How many soldiers are you capable of leading?

This is a skill that touches on management, organization and mobilization abilities. How many men can you lead? A squad? A company? A platoon? Perhaps an entire army? 

Liu Bang once gathered his most trusted followers and held a discussion about how many troops each of them was capable of leading. He asked Han Xin how many he thought that he, Liu Bang, could command. Han Xin replied that he thought Liu Bang몭s limit was 100,000 men 멪  any more than that and he wouldn몭t be able to get the job done. Then Liu Bang asked: 몮Han Xin, what about you? How many troops could you lead?몯 Han Xin replied: 몮Well, since it몭s me you몭re talking about, the more the merrier! I can take as many as you can give me.몯

Organizational and managerial skills are, as a topic of conversation, somewhat dull. They몭re not the kind of thing people relish talking about, unlike certain other personal attributes associated with war. For instance, everyone likes stories about leaders who had a knack for stratagems, or great courage. This is compelling stuff, and so, naturally, it is these stories that spread wide and far.
	
But which of these things made Han Xin so talented in the art of war? Why did he rise above his peers? Of course, he was certainly a very cunning strategist, but he was not courageous 멪 this is considered his weakness. He also had a superpower. Look no further than his words to Liu Bang: 몮The more the merrier!몯 What if you asked yourself, what몭s the biggest team I could lead? Managing a company of 20 people and managing a company of 200 are very different things. It몭s a different thing again to lead 2,000, 20,000 or 200,000. Some organizations might even manage a million people, like Foxconn. Unfortunately, the electronics manufacturer몭s management methods drove their employees mad, even to the point of suicide. On the other hand, we have the example of the Qin general Wang Jian, who managed to run a military camp of 600,000 men for a whole year with no battles to keep them busy, only daily athletic competitions. Yet, at the crucial moment, he was able to deliver a killing blow to the enemy. The fact that he was able to avoid any major disasters, while managing 600,000 young men living in close quarters without much to occupy them, is a testament to his incredible talent for management.

3)  How do you lead soldiers? How do you use them?

Here, we can borrow a principle from Chapter Five: 몮The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men.몯 This is what Han Xin was talking about: you could give him 100 men to lead, or a 100,000, and he would be equally at ease in both situations. He could do this is because he had a whole organizational framework and various management systems he could call upon. This is a topic that is discussed in later chapters (Chapter Four: Tactical Dispositions; Chapter Five: Energy; and Chapter Six: Weak Points and Strong).
	
Organizational framework is about designing different types of fighting units, from the smallest to the largest. As we몭ve noted, the smallest unit used in ancient Chinese warfare consisted of five men. By the Ming dynasty, General Qi Jiguang, who was famous for defeating the infamous wokou pirates, designed a 몬Mandarin Duck Unit몭 consisting of 20 men. In the 20th century, Communist Party General Lin Biao invented an organizational formula: 몬One point, two sides, three threes.몭 Lin Biao was a masterful commander, directing his men as if they were an extension of his own arm, from the smallest units of three men to huge armies of over a million soldiers.

This is what Sun Tzu meant when he wrote: 몮The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men.몯




Employees who can몭t see things from where their boss is standing have no future; a boss who doesn몭t think like an employee will never make it big

Extract from the original text: 
몮Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (3) He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks.몯

Analysis:
Now we move on to the third of the 몬five factors for knowing victory.몭
If you asked commanders if they understood what it means that 몬He will win whose army is animated by the same spirit throughout all its ranks,몭 they would all say 몬yes.몭 But, if you think about it in terms of Ming dynasty philosopher Wang Yangming몭s theory of the unity of knowledge and action, you can몭t really know what it means unless you몭ve actually done it. By these standards, almost nobody really knows what it means.
Unsurprisingly, when people try to put it into action, they start with their own desires and demand that other people conform. In general, you see people in higher positions trying to force their desires upon people in lower positions. Very rarely do people understand that the right thing to do conforms to the desires of others. 
The Neo-Confucianists spoke of 몬preserving the patterns of heaven, and destroying the desires of mankind,몭 while Wang Yangming said: 몮The patterns of heaven are the desires of mankind.몯 But these are two different types of desire. The former is personal desire, and 몬destroying몭 it simply means 몬controlling몭 it. The latter is communal desire, and Wang Yangming was saying that people should conform to this communal desire.
There is a passage from an ancient narrative history text, The Zuo Commentary, that reads: 몮It is admissible to follow men by using a desire, but if men are used to follow a desire, then success is a rare thing.몯 This means that you can achieve success by aligning your aspirations with those of a larger group of people, but if you make a group of people follow your own, personal desire, success will be hard to come by.
In fact, we might edit the original text, from 몮He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks,몯 to 몬He will win who aligns himself with the desires of others.몭

This takes us back to a truism: benefitting others is the same as benefitting yourself.
If you몭re an employee and you want to make quick progress, you should always analyze any problem you face from your boss몭s perspective.
In any business relationship, you should always try to put yourself in the shoes of the other party몭s boss. Sincerity works magic; it몭s the key to business stability.
If you몭re a boss, you need to be able to think like an employee. You need to see everything from their perspective, take an active interest in them, and put yourself at their service. If you can do that, you will find people willing to work with you.
If you몭re a business, you need to see things through the eyes of consumers.
