Rather than trying to make money by exploiting an imbalance in information access, focus on building a solid product and service structure on behalf of consumers. Do what others won몭t, and you몭ll have a brand that can last a hundred years.

몮He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks.몯

So, how is that done?
First, you need to admit that the upper and lower ranks do not share the same desires. Only when you몭ve done this will you be able to think of a way to unify them. If your starting point is a belief that everyone else should conform to you, and that there몭s nothing you need to do, it won몭t work. People will never truly conform to your way.
The Warring States period Legalist philosopher, Han Feizi, touched upon this in his writings, but he used a different wording from Sun Tzu: 몮Rulers and minsters cherishing divergent interests.몯
During the Three Kingdoms period, when Cao Cao attacked the state of Eastern Wu, the Eastern Wu King, Sun Quan, called a meeting with his minsters. He asked then: 몮Should we fight, or surrender?몯 The ministers몭 response was unanimous: 몮We cannot beat Cao Cao. Even General Liu Cong surrendered to him, and he was well prepared. But us? Forget about it. We should surrender, and then focus on negotiating terms.몯
But one Eastern Wu statesman, Lu Su, had other ideas. When Sun Quan left the courtroom for a moment to answer nature몭s call, Lu Su seized his chance to make a pitch to the King: 몮My lord, it does not matter for us ministers if we surrender, but you cannot.몯 Sun Quan asked him why, and he replied: 몮We몭re advisors 멪 even if there몭s a new lord, we몭ll still carry on as before, working in our official posts. If you surrender, then our assets and salaries will be safe, but what about you? What official post would you be eligible for?몯
Now, Sun Quan understood. He had to fight.
This is what it means for rulers and ministers to have different interests. So, what몭s the solution? And what몭s the solution for divided desires between 몬the upper and the lower ranks?몭
According to Han Feizi몭s logic, the answer is to develop a transactional relationship between a ruler and his ministers. In other words, build incentive mechanisms, which should be fair and transparent. Then, there몭s no need for rulers to be inherently benevolent, or for ministers to be loyal, because the incentives will automatically steer rulers toward benevolent kindness and ministers toward courageous loyalty.
In ruler-minister relations, there몭s no room for acting on emotion, whether love, respect, kindness or any of a long list of similar sentiments. What몭s crucial is that everyone must be loyal to the responsibility they hold within their individual role. They must be loyal to their job and to the rules of the game.
With well-designed incentives, even if everyone who works for you is essentially a bad person, it won몭t matter, because their impulse to follow their own interests will only cause them to do good. In terms of building your advisors몭 moral fiber, you just need to promote the idea that everyone should act the way good people act, and give credit to people who demonstrate especially good behavior. If you do this, you will be able to unite the desires of the upper and lower ranks as one, and you will win.



Properly understand the meaning of 몬Just in case멞몭

Extract from the original text:
몮Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (4) He will win who, prepared himself, waits to take the enemy unprepared.몯

Analysis:
Now let몭s take a look at the fourth of the 몬five factors for knowing victory.몭
The word in the original Chinese text corresponding to 몬prepare몭 is a rarely used, archaic character, which means 몬to make defensive preparations in advance.몭 It features in a modern Chinese four-character idiom, which means 몬two people deceive one another,몭 with the root meaning being: 몬two people make preparations against one another.몭
The ancient text, The Zuo Commentary, says: 몮He who makes no preparations in advance must not command soldiers.몯 Likewise, a passage from Chapter Eight of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War reads: 몮The art of war teaches us to rely not on the likelihood of the enemy몭s not coming, but on our own readiness to receive him; not on the chance of his not attacking, but rather on the fact that we have made our position unassailable.몯 
At one time during the Spring and Autumn period, the states of Wu and Chu were at war against one another. The two armies were positioned thirty li apart, but a rainstorm came that lasted ten days and ten nights. At night, there was total darkness, with no stars to light the sky. 
The Chu commander, Yi Xiang, held a meeting with Chu General Zi Qi.  몮With such terrible weather,몯 the commander said, 몮the Wu army no doubt believes that we have not made the proper defensive preparations. They will attempt a surprise attack, I am sure of it. The best course of action for us would be to prepare accordingly.몯
Sure enough, a Wu surprise attack didn몭t take long to materialize. But, when the Wu forces saw the Chu army arrayed in full defensive formation, they realized they held no advantage and quickly retreated. The Chu army didn몭t pursue them, because Yi Xiang knew that the Wu forces would have been prepared for that eventuality. Instead, he waited until the Wu army had retreated back to their camp, and then he made his move.
몮They have now marched a total of 60 li on their way here and back to their camp, so they will be tired and hungry. Their general will want to rest, and the soldiers will want to eat, so their defenses will be loose. If we quietly march our forces the 30 li to their camp, I am sure we can defeat them with a single, sharp blow,몯 Yi Xiang reasoned. And he was right 멪 his plan worked perfectly, and the Wu army suffered a massive defeat.
But theoretically, what would Yi Xiang have done if the Wu army didn몭t try their surprise attack? It was raining heavily, and his army was set up in a defensive formation. Wouldn몭t his effort have been wasted? It몭s normal to hear people say words to the effect of. 몬I wasted my time; all my preparation was for nothing.몭몯 This is exactly the kind of thinking that the idea of 몬the art of war몭 aims to dispel. The classic military text, One Hundred Sayings on the Art of War, puts it like this: 몮It is preferable to make preparations that are unused, rather than to not make preparations with the result that the enemy profits thereby.몯 
These advance preparations go 몬unused몭 in the vast majority of cases, because they are, by nature, made for 몬just in case몭 scenarios. They몭re a back-up, not the main plan. This means that for every example of such preparations working out with good effect, there are 9,999 cases of preparations going 몬unused.몭 The Chu commander, Yi Xiang, was by no means blessed with supernatural powers of foresight 멪 he had no way of knowing that the Wu army would come; he was just following standard operating procedure. That몭s why he prepared the way he did. If the Wu army hadn몭t showed up, the Chu soldiers would have grumbled for a while, and then things would have moved on. That day certainly wouldn몭t have found its way into the history books, and we wouldn몭t even know what happened. But the Wu army did attack, and that몭s why Yi Xiang몭s name has lived on for over 2,000 years. The very fact that this story has lasted so long goes to show how rarely things like this actually happen.
A friend of mine who works for the French petroleum company, Total, once told me that in any company meeting, there몭s always a safety officer present, and the meeting always starts with a half-hour safety presentation. It covers things like where the fire escapes are, emergency exits, the overall layout of whatever hotel the meeting is taking place in, locations of fire extinguishers, step-by-step instructions for evacuating the building, how to save yourself in different situations, how to help colleagues, first aid information, and so on.
From the perspective of pragmatic, mainstream values 멪 which put progress first, quality second, and safety third 멪 these tedious safety briefings are a colossal waste of time, especially because everyone there has likely heard it hundreds of times before!
But, this is where you need to really understand what 몬just in case몭 means. In Chinese, 몬just in case몭 is literally 몬one in ten thousand,몭 and that몭s what we몭re talking about here 멪 being prepared for a one-in-10,000 outcome! How many parents who drive cars don몭t bother with a child seat for their babies, because they don몭t think anything will go wrong? Clearly, they haven몭t considered the fact that if a one-in-10,000 event happens, their child will be gone. That몭s why whenever I travel with my child, I always take a child seat with me.
Another way to understand the idea of, 몬He will win who, prepared himself, waits to take the enemy unprepared,몭 is to put it like this: 몬Opportunity belongs to he who is prepared.몭 Life is constantly setting the scene for new situations. If you embrace the idea of this passage, you will be ready for opportunity when it arrives.
War is fleeting, and 99% of our work is preparation. There몭s deep meaning in this. Yet, it몭s so easy for people to see only the benefits or losses that war might bring them. That몭s why more time and resources are allocated to gathering the fruits of war than to preparing for war. But, you should be thinking about sowing seeds, not getting ahead of yourself and focusing on the harvest. I have observed certain entrepreneurs delegating 몬harvesting몭 work to their managerial staff, because today몭s harvest is the product of seeds that they sowed three years earlier. Meanwhile, the entrepreneur focuses all his attention and energy on the next round of sowing; he몭s preparing for the future.



The boss should let go of his judgments, where appropriate; employees should let the boss cross workplace boundaries

Extract from the original text:
몮Thus, we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (5) He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign. These five factors are the way to know who will win.몯 

Analysis:
We have now reached the last of the 몬five factors for knowing victory.몭 The Methods of the Sima says: 몮Advancing and retreating are decisions to be made according to the situation, not by dictate of the ruler.몯 
When the forces of Cao Cao몭s general, Sima Yi, were lined up against Zhuge Liang on the Wuzhang Plain, Sima Yi refused to fight. Day after day, Zhuge Liang launched tirades of insults against Sima Yi, including, as we몭ve noted, allegedly sending him a 몬gift몭 of women몭s clothing. Sima Yi몭s men were outraged by this humiliation, and began to suspect that Sima Yi was a coward. In one soldier after another, the desire to fight grew stronger. Sima Yi responded by telling them: 몮Alright, I will immediately request authorization from the Emperor to attack.몯 
Sima YI sent a letter to Cao Cao몭s court, but when they received it, they knew exactly what his real intentions were: he was just putting on a show, and he needed Cao Cao to play along. Cao Cao obliged, sending an imperial envoy named Xin Pi to Sima Yi몭s camp. Xin Pi stood at the camp몭s gate and announced an imperial decree to the soldiers: 몮Any man who presumes to inquire about attacking the enemy shall be executed!몯
When Zhuge Liang got wind of this, he said: 몮If Sima Yi was really capable of handling me, would he have written to his Emperor asking permission to fight? He몭s just pretending that the Emperor won몭t let him fight, because he몭s worthless as a leader!몯
By saying this, Zhuge Liang was referring directly to this chapter몭s passage from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몮He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign.몯 If Sima Yi wanted his ruler to interfere, that meant he didn몭t have any 몬military capacity.몭
However, Sima Yi몭s request for interference was a ploy 멪 he was play-acting. Zhuge Liang knew this, and he never did succeed in starting the fight he wanted so badly at Wuzhang Plain. Instead, he fell ill and died while still in camp. 
In ancient China, there was a ceremony by which the ruler would bestow his authority on his commander-in-chief. It centered on a ceremonial axe, which represented power over the lives and deaths of all subordinates, and the power to punish the ruler몭s enemies. The axe itself was not designed for battle, but for executions 멪 specifically, by beheading and by cutting people in half at the waist. In the ceremony, the ruler would hold the axe by the blade and, holding the handle out toward the general, say the following words: 몮Everything reaching from here up into the highest heavens shall be given into the general몭s power.몯 Then, the ruler would take the axe by the handle, hold out the blade toward the general, and decree: 몮Everything reaching from here down into the deepest recesses of the earth shall be given into the general몭s power.몯  This is how the Emperor passes his all-encompassing power over everything, from the heavens down to the earth, to the general.
몮He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign,몯 and the general shall not be dictated to from afar by the ruler. When people are lectured about the art of war, they naturally believe that this passage is correct. But in reality, it몭s describing an idealized state of affairs, which rarely crosses the boundary into objective reality. Things generally did not go well for generals who stubbornly insisted on this ideal 멪 many of them ended up dying horrific deaths.
From a general몭s position, they have to manage every detail of army life, and they also have to deal with the overwhelming minutiae and variables of battlefield situations as they develop in real-time. It몭s not surprising, then, that there몭s no way they could ask the ruler몭s permission for every move they make. But, it몭s not easier for the ruler either. Compared with his generals, the pressure a ruler has to deal with is significantly heavier. Rulers have to manage the ins and outs of politics, internal policy, diplomacy, hostile foreign states, armed rebels and other insider political foes. On top of that, the ruler has to hand over all his chips to his general. If a ruler can resist the temptation to send a supervisor to watch over his generals, he몭s already doing quite well, given the pressure he몭s under. If you want a ruler to not manage his generals in any way, and referain from asking them any questions, he몭d collapse into an anxiety-wracked mess.

몮The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin. Hence, it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected.몯

When a ruler is walking the line between life and death, you can몭t ask them not to speak their mind or interfere in military campaigns. This is because, with every passing moment, the ruler is constantly making judgment-calls.
Rulers should learn when it몭s appropriate to let go of their judgment; they should be able to exercise self-control. For example, during the Tang dynasty몭s An Lushan Rebellion, Tang general Geshu Han was holding a strong defensive position at Tongguan Pass, and his situation appeared to be improving after half a year of refusing to be drawn out of his fortress and into a pitched battle. Despite this, Emperor Xuanzong forced Geshu Han to go out and fight. Why did Xuanzong make this judgment call? Why did he think it was a good idea to fight out in the open? One reason was his pride. He could not accept the fact that An Lushan had rebelled against him, let alone the possibility that the rebel general could defeat him. That몭s why Xuanzong executed his two best generals, Feng Changqing and Gao Xianzhi, who had lost battles against the rebels. Xuanzong몭s behavior was an act of self-sabotage. Now that he could see the tide was turning in his favor at Tongguan Pass, Xuanzong was anxious to destroy An Lushan as soon as possible, like waving away an unpleasant smell. Another reason was that Emperor Xuanzong몭s advisor, Yang Guozhong, was fanning the flames. He was a sworn enemy of Geshu Han 멪 whatever Geshu Han wanted to do, Yang would tell the Emperor to do the exact opposite.
Emperor Xuanzong was not capable of making clear, critical judgment calls. He mostly acted on his emotions. He couldn몭t accept the idea of failure or being humiliated, so he felt an urgent need to remove the possibility of these outcomes every materializing, and to do so as quickly as possible.
Yang Guozhong slandered Geshu Han: 몮Since Geshu Han is taking such pains to convince us that he cannot fight, then even if we listen to him, what good will it do to wait for another half year? Would that really make a difference?몯 Yang whispered in the Emperor몭s ear, and his cajoling worked. Xuanzong became ever more assured that he was making the right decision.
Of course, the result of all this was that when Geshu Han obligingly led his troops out of the fortress, his entire army was decimated, the Tang capital was lost, and Xuanzong fled to Sichuan. Yang Guozhong was killed by outraged soldiers, along with his cousin Yang Guifei, an imperial courtesan with whom Xuanzong had been besotted.
Geshu Han몭s greatest 몬inability몭 in all of this was his failure to make Xuanzong trust him. Because of this, he had no claim to having 몬military capacity.몭 At the root of his failure was his vicious feud with Yang Guozhong. Yang may have been a contemptible kind of person, but sometimes 몬men of distinction몭 nonetheless have to put that aside and maintain friendly relations with such people. At the very least, you have to be aware of this idea, even if you can몭t bring yourself to actually be friends with people you despise. Many talented minsters and advisors achieved great things by relying on good relations with otherwise unpleasant palace eunuchs 멪 for example, Ming dynasty reformer Zhang Juzheng.
Rulers need to consider this chapter몭s passage carefully. Then, they will realize that being overly eager to kill or be killed could quickly lead to irreversible defeat, and that there몭s no harm in letting go of some of the executive decision-making and trusting the generals to take care of business themselves.
If you몭re a general, you should resist the temptation to swat away the ruler몭s hand whenever he tries to get involved. Instead, allow him access whenever he wants. Make sure he sees you as someone who is totally transparent, who would never try to keep him at a distance. If you do this, you몭ll be able to reason with the ruler more persuasively when that crucial moment comes and you absolutely have to take full control of the situation.



Know yourself and know your enemy. Problems usually arise from not knowing yourself, rather than not knowing your enemy

Extract from the original text:
몮Hence, the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. If you know yourself but not the enemy, for every victory gained you will also suffer a defeat. If you know neither the enemy nor yourself, you will succumb in every battle.몯

Analysis:
If you know yourself and your enemy, you can set yourself up in a position where failure is impossible. Knowing yourself and your enemy means that you clearly understand your own situation, and the enemy몭s, in terms of each of the 몬Five factors for knowing victory.몭 And, you will understand exactly how your situation compares with the enemy몭s. But, if you only understand yourself and not your enemy, your odds of victory immediately plummet to 50%. Worst of all, if you don몭t understand yourself or your enemy, your odds are zero. 
For an example of someone who knew themselves but not their enemy, look no further than Li Quan몭s commentary. He offers the case of the former Qin Emperor Fu Jian, and the Battle of Fei River.
When the former Qin statesman, Wang Meng, lay on his deathbed, he gave Fu Jian some advice: 몮Although the Jin court is located in the remote lands south of the Yangzi River, their bloodline is pure. The Jin generals Xian An and Huan Chong are powerful men, and we should not attack them. Our true enemies are here, in our midst 멪 the Xianbei and the Qiang, all wretched northern barbarians. They will ultimately be our undoing, unless we do what is good for the country and expel them from among us.몯
But Fu Jian didn몭t listen, and after Wang Meng died, he led an army to invade Jin. Even with the wheels already in motion, people tried to talk Fu Jian out of it: 몮We몭re not the only ones with talented generals,몯 his advisors argued. 몮They have Xie An and Huan Chong, both brilliant commanders. We mustn몭t underestimate them!몯
Fu Jian remained adamant: 몮I command the multitudes of eight provinces, and have in my possession a million men and horses. My armies are large enough to hold back the Yangzi River! What difficulty exists that I cannot overcome?몯
In fact, he was marching into a catastrophic defeat at the Battle of Fei River. Afterward, the Xianbei and Qiang people did indeed revolt, and Fu Jian was murdered by the Qiang chief, Yao Chang.
In retrospect, was Li Quan right? Was Fu Jian몭s fatal error knowing himself, but not knowing his enemy? Not at all. His problem wasn몭t that he didn몭t know the enemy, but that there were internal dynamics in his own camp that he didn몭t understand. He didn몭t realize that he was effectively bunking with his mortal enemies.
Some doubt remains about the accuracy of the historical records I quoted above about Wang Meng몭s advice to Fu Jian. It doesn몭t ring entirely true that Wang would have said that the reason the Jin shouldn몭t be attacked was that they had a 몬pure bloodline.몭 Fu Jian was himself not purely Han Chinese, and it몭s unlikely that people of ethnic minority background would believe it was dangerous to attack someone just because they were 몬pure몭 Han Chinese. Remember, though, that Chinese history is written by Han Chinese historians of 몬pure bloodlines,몭 and it몭s very likely this line is an editorial intervention.
Anyway, the important part was Wang Meng몭s second line, where he said that the non-Chinese Xianbei and Qiang peoples were the real enemies, and that they should be destroyed.
But Fu Jian had one, massive character flaw: he was too kind, and his kindness lacked principle. Anyone else, having conquered another state, would make sure they finished the job, pulling up the enemy by the roots. Not Fu Jian. As far as he was concerned, as long as the enemy surrenders, their former Emperor would be welcome to fight under his flag as a general. He was indiscriminately open-hearted.
This flaw explains why Fu Jian had already failed one of the 몬Five factors for knowing victory몭 멪 몮He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks.몯 His vast ranks comprised a million men, but they were divided in spirit. Vanquished Emperors and Generals of defeated states who served under Fu Jian still harbored dreams of restoring their fallen kingdoms, and they certainly had no intention of helping Fu Jian in his bid to conquer all of China and found a new empire. That몭s why, when Fu Jian몭s men heard the enemy shouting that their comrades were retreating, they all turned tail and fled.
Among the states conquered by Fu Jian was Former Yan. The Former Yan prince, a Xianbei boy named Murong Chong, was taken to Fu Jian몭s palace along with his older sister, who was fourteen at the time. His sister became a favorite concubine of Fu Jian, and Murong himself became a male concubine, so brother and sister both were moved into the imperial harem. Later in life, Murong Chong yearned to reestablish his old kingdom, but he ended up serving in Fu Jian몭s army. When Fu Jian saw him one day at the front, the old Emperor was overcome with emotion, and had a servant take a brocaded gown over to Murong Chong. This was just one more humiliation for a man who had once been a prince, who had lost his country and his family at the hands of this man, and who together with his sister had been bundled off into the enemy몭s harem. Yet, Fu Jian never thought there was anything but love between them! He was convinced that he was the undisputed lord of the whole world; that몭s what made him absurd. He had no idea that other people might also fancy themselves Emperor. 
Let몭s critique Fu Jian in terms of each of the 몬five factors for knowing victory.몭 
몮He will win who knows when to fight and when not to fight.몯 Wang Meng specifically warned Fu Jian that his real problems were internal, and that it would not be a good idea to start a war with the Jin rulers. Fu Jian didn몭t get it.
몮He will win who knows how to handle both superior and inferior forces.몯 On this point, Fu Jian was just sloppy. He didn몭t bother dividing his huge army into different units, but massed them together in one huge heap. That몭s why Fu Jian몭s order to retreat triggered his army몭s total collapse.
몮He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks.몯 We몭ve already addressed this point: many of the generals who supposedly served him were actually just waiting for a chance to restore their own nations and declare themselves Emperor.
몮He will win who, prepared himself, waits to take the enemy unprepared.몯 Xie Xuan carefully designed a trap for Fu Jian, who believed he didn몭t have anything to fear, regardless of what traps his enemies might have set. So, he didn몭t prepare. That몭s how he found himself on the back foot and getting punched in the mouth.
몮He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign.몯 In this case, Fu Jian was both the Emperor and the general in the field. He led a million men, but they could be more accurately described as a mob than an army, each with their own subversive motives.
Fu Jian didn몭t meet the standards of any of the five factors. So, he started out with a 100% chance of failure, rather than the 50% odds that he would have enjoyed if he knew himself but not the enemy.
We often focus on knowing our enemies, because we take it as a given that we know ourselves. But reality often says otherwise. Our problems generally come from the fact that we don몭t know ourselves. In practice, if you can몭t quite work out your enemies, how are you supposed to understand other peoples몭 situations?
The Tang Emperor Taizong specifically commented on this point with reference to Fu Jian: 몮Though the generals and advisors of today may not be capable of knowing their enemies, but what of Fu Jian? If he had been able to know himself, how could he have fallen into such an unfavourable position?몯
I believe that if you know yourself, but not the enemy, your odds of victory aren몭t just 50%, but 80%. You should definitely make sure you put in the hard yards when it comes to knowing yourself. My attitude is: 몬I don몭t care what your situation is, because that몭s out of my control. I only care about what my situation is, because then I몭ll be prepared for you regardless. More than that, I몭ll be able to twist you around my little finger.몭 In my readings of Zeng Guofan몭s Complete Works, I몭ve found very few journal entries containing specific details about his enemies. Instead, he mostly wrote technical reflections on his own work as he built up and managed his army. 
You only find out the truth about the enemy몭s situation after you몭ve already fought them.
There몭s another question you have to think about when you apply Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War to modern business management: Who is the 몬enemy몭 in 몬know yourself and know your enemy?몭 
It몭s not your competitors! In fact, your 몬enemy몭 is your clients. If you know yourself and you know your clients, you are guaranteed to win every battle you fight. Business management problems normally happen when you haven몭t properly done the work you need to on yourself, and on top of that you don몭t understand your clients. If what you take from the art of war is that you should spend every day studying your so-called enemy, you몭re just wasting your time and your effort.



Appendix: Complete text of Planning Assaults

Sun Tzu said: 몮In the practical art of war, the best thing of all is to take the enemy몭s country whole and intact; to shatter and destroy it is second best. So, too, it is better to recapture an army entirely than to destroy it, to capture a battalion, a company or a squad entire, than to destroy them. Hence, to fight and conquer in all your battles is not supreme excellence; supreme excellence consists in breaking the enemy몭s resistance without fighting. Thus, the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy몭s plans; the next best is to attack the enemy몭s alliances; the next in order is to attack the enemy몭s army in the field. Besieging walled cities is an option chosen only when nothing else is successful. The preparation of mantlets, armored wagons, and various implements of war, will take up three whole months; and the piling up of mounds over against the walls will take three months more. The general, unable to control his irritation, will launch his men to the assault like swarming ants, with the result that one-third of his men are slain while the city still remains untaken. Such are the disastrous effects of a siege. Therefore, the skillful leader subdues the enemy몭s troops without any fighting; he captures their cities without laying siege to them; he overthrows their kingdom without lengthy operations in the field. With his forces intact, he will dispute the mastery of the Empire, and thus, without losing a man, his triumph will be complete. This is the method of attacking by stratagem. It is the rule in war: if our forces are ten to the enemy몭s one, to surround him; if five to one, to attack him; if twice as numerous, to divide the army11 into two. If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him. Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force. If our forces are ten to the enemy몭s one, surround him; if five to one, attack him; if twice as numerous, divide the army into two. If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him. Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force. Now, the general is the bulwark of the State; if the bulwark is complete at all points; the State will be strong; if the bulwark is defective, the State will be weak. There are three ways in which a ruler can bring misfortune upon his army: (1) By commanding the army to advance or to retreat, being ignorant of the fact that it cannot obey. This is called hobbling the army. (2) By attempting to govern an army in the same way as he administers a kingdom, being ignorant of the conditions that obtain in an army. This causes restlessness in the soldiers몭 minds. (3) By employing the officers of his army without[bd12] discrimination, through ignorance of the military principle of adaptation to circumstances. This shakes the confidence of the soldiers. But when the army is restless and distrustful, trouble is sure to come from the other feudal princes. This is simply bringing anarchy into the army, and flinging victory away. Thus we may know that there are five factors for knowing victory: (1) He will win who knows when to fight and when not to fight. (2) He will win who knows how to handle both superior and inferior forces. (3) He will win whose army is animated by the same desire throughout both the upper and lower ranks. (4) He will win who, prepared himself, waits to take the enemy unprepared. (5) He will win who has military capacity and is not interfered with by the sovereign. These five factors are the way to know who will win. Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. If you know yourself but not the enemy, for every victory gained you will also suffer a defeat. If you know neither the enemy nor yourself, you will succumb in every battle.몯



Chapter Four
Formations

Win first, fight later

Extract from the original text:
몮The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy. To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself. Thus, the good fighter is able to secure himself against defeat, but cannot make certain of defeating the enemy. Hence the saying: One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it.몯

Analysis:
There is a connection between Chapter Four of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War (Formation) and Chapter Five (Force). These two words, 몬formation몭 멪 of which the root meaning in Chinese is simply 몬shape몭 멪 and 몬force몭 combine in modern Chinese to form a word with a range of meanings. They range from 몬terrain몭 to 몬power몭 to 몬situation.몭 It is a word that traces its origins directly to The Art of War. So, what is the meaning of 몬formation몭 here?
Cao Cao comments: 몮It is the shape of an army; I move, the enemy reacts. It is two enemies analyzing each other몭s situation.몯
Formation is something that can be observed. It몭s about making moves and watching how the enemy responds; it몭s about probing and observing one another. It몭s similar to a widely known concept in modern Chinese known as 몬reconnaissance by fire.몭 The idea is to take a couple of shots at the enemy, and see what shape or formation it exposes.
Zhang Yu also takes a shot at explaining the idea of 몬formation.몭 He said the following: 몮It is the shape of two armies, one attacking and the other defending. When it is hidden within, then the enemy cannot determine what it is; when it is visible from outside, then the enemy can infiltrate through the cracks.몯 
Both sides do all that they can to not allow the enemy to probe their formation. Once battle commences, one side becomes the attacker and the other the defender, and then the two armies몭 formations are exposed to each other.
So, 몬formation몭 is a stage before a battle starts, while 몬energy몭 is a topic for when battles have already gone live.
The Han dynasty scholar-official Xun Yue wrote about 몬formation몭 and 몬energy몭 in the same passage:
몮There are three essentials in the art of establishing policies and obtaining victory: 1) Formation; 2) Force; 3) Circumstances. In general, formation is about calculations of what may be gained and what may be lost. Force is about that which is appropriate in the moment-to-moment situation of a battle, and it is about opportunities for advancing and retreating. Circumstances are about whether or not, in truth, one몭s will is within the realm of possibility. Thus, the fact that results differ even when policies and events are the same is because of differences in the use of these three arts.몯
So, 몬formation몭 is about calculating gains and losses, and your odds of victory can be calculated. You should act only once you are clear about the calculations; if you몭re not clear, don몭t move.
Before you do anything, take a good look at the formations and work out if you몭re in a viable situation. Xun Yue also said that once the wheels are in motion, you need to rely on force. This isn몭t wrong, but Sun Tzu discusses the topic in much more detail in Chapter five. Finally, Xun Yue also mentioned 몬circumstances.몭 When he talks about 몬one몭s will,몭 he몭s referring to the commander-in-chief몭s willpower, but also to his men몭s morale, and whether or not it몭s 몬in the realm of possibility.몭 In The Art of War, 몬circumstances몭 are categorized as part of 몬force,몭 so Xun Yue몭s 몬three essentials몭 are actually only two: 몬formation몭 and 몬force.몭
Once you몭ve got your head around these two topics, the whole process of fighting and winning battles boils down to the two processes of 몬winning formation몭 and 몬winning force.몭 Now, let몭s start reading through Chapter Four: Formation, which is all about winning through the use of 몬formations.몭

몮The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy. To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself. Thus, the good fighter is able to secure himself against defeat, but cannot make certain of defeating the enemy. Hence the saying: One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it.몯

Ancient generals who were truly skilled in fighting wars would start with themselves, first making thorough plans so as to put themselves in a position where they can몭t be beaten. Then, they would wait for the right time and opportunity to defeat their enemy. Being unbeatable is down to you; being able to beat your enemy is down to whether or not the enemy gives you the opportunity to win. By this logic, generals skillful in the art of war had the ability to make themselves undefeatable, but not to guarantee certain victory over their enemy. Victory can be foreseen, but it can몭t be forced if the conditions aren몭t right.
There is a parallel between, 몮The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy,몯 and a passage from the previous chapter: 몮If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles.몯 Making your own plans such that your enemy can몭t defeat you is the same as 몬knowing yourself,몭 and waiting until the enemy can be defeated is the same as 몬knowing your enemy.몭

몮To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself. Thus, the good fighter is able to secure himself against defeat, but cannot make certain of defeating the enemy.몯

In short, you can control yourself, but not others. First, get your affairs in order, and then observe others. If the enemy has no weak point for us to attack, there몭s nothing we can do to secure victory.

몮One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it.몯

We can, through critical evaluation, determine that we are capable of winning, but if we don몭t have winning formation and force, we can몭t make it happen.
What are you supposed to do if you can몭t win, given that victory can몭t be forced?
The first thing to do is not do anything. So many people lose because they don몭t know that it몭s possible to leave situations unresolved. There몭s a Chinese saying that sums this up quite aptly: 몬If you go looking for ways to die, you몭re going to die.몭 If there몭s something you can몭t do, don몭t try to force it. That몭s because, as another Chinese saying reminds us, 몬As long as the green hills last, there몭ll always be wood for your stove.몭 In other words, if you insist on forcing a resolution, you몭ll end up losing all of your leverage.
If victory is beyond reach, don몭t fight. Reel it back, focus on yourself, and focus on training. Sun Tzu몭s philosophy is to secure victory first and go to battle later, and we haven몭t seen the last of this idea. It comes up again later in the text, where I rephrased it as, 몬Win first, fight later.몭 If you haven몭t won yet, don몭t fight.
Many people can몭t accept this idea. In their eyes, it means negligence; they have to always be doing something, because that몭s the only way they can feel at peace.  This mentality is a kind of 몬strategy-based anxiety,몭 and you see it when people forget that there몭s always another side to any action 멪  there몭s always a trade-off, there몭s always risk, and there몭s always something lost. In reality, not making a move doesn몭t mean that you몭re being negligent. Rather, it means that you몭re building yourself up and waiting for the opportune moment. In the War of the Three Kingdoms, Zhuge Liang was constantly doing things. It could fairly be said that he kept making moves even when the odds of victory were absolutely 몬zero,몭 and in the end he wore himself out so badly that he died of exhaustion. He should have waited for opportunities, and he should have worked out and kept his body healthy. There are two good reasons for doing this: 1) He would have lived longer; 2) He could have governed better, made his nation rich and powerful, and taught his son the lessons he needed to be well-prepared to carry on his legacy.
But, like so many others, Zhuge Liang thought he couldn몭t afford to wait. And what happens when you can몭t wait? Sima Yi lived longer than any of the other major players: he outlived Zhuge Liang, he outlived Cao Cao, and he even outlived Cao Cao몭s son and successor, Cao Pi. With no one left to stand in his way, Sima Yi몭s state of Jin took control of all three kingdoms.
That몭s why the second strategy is 몬waiting.몭 It몭s the best choice in many situations, and yet far too few people understand this. What you몭re waiting for is a change in circumstances 멪 specifically, for advantageous changes in formation and force.
A 몬winning formation몭 is something that gradually builds up while you wait. It몭s about making it impossible for the enemy to defeat you, and gradually growing stronger. 몬Winning force몭 is about seizing the opportunity for victory when it presents itself, and thoroughly defeating your enemy with a single blow.
No one was better at waiting than Japan몭s Tokugawa Ieyasu, who[bd13] emerged victorious from Japan몭s war-torn Sengoku period (1467-1615 CE). 
There몭s an amusing story about the three major heroes of the Sengoku period: The three 멪 Tokugawa Ieyasu, Oda Nobunaga and Toyotomi Hideyoshi 멪 were in a park with their pet bird, but the bird wouldn몭t sing. They tried to work out what to do about this.
Oda Nobunaga said: 몮If it keeps on not singing, we should just kill it and get another bird.몯
Toyotomi Hideyoshi said: 몮No need to kill it 멪 we should give it a reward if its sings, and punish it if it doesn몭t. It몭ll sing, one way or another.몯
Then the two men asked Tokugawa Ieyasu what he thought, and he said: 몮There몭s no need to do anything. Just wait! It몭s a bird, after all, and sooner or later it몭ll sing.몯
Tokugawa Ieyasu was the only one of the three who had the ability to wait, and he was also the longest-lived, so he ended up as Shogun of all Japan. His dynasty ruled Japan for the next 300 years.
Again, what are you supposed to wait for? 몬Winning formation,몭 meaning that you몭re waiting for yourself to built up to a certain point?  Or, 몬winning force,몭 meaning waiting for your enemy to make a mistake? As soon as the enemy slips up, an opportunity for victory presents itself. If the enemy doesn몭t slip up, there몭s either nothing we can do to win, or the tradeoff involved in winning would be unacceptably costly. In both cases, you몭re better off waiting and calculating.
And this is why we have the third strategy 멪 can we lure the enemy into making a mistake?
This is what the Tang Emperor Taizong was talking about in Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Duke Li of Wei, when he said: 몮Through my readings of military books, both ancient and new, I have discovered there is but one crucial teaching 멪 use a multitude of diverse methods to fool one몭s foe.몯

In a previous chapter I told the story of how the Qin General Wang Jian destroyed the state of Chu, in which he asked the King of Qin for a great army of 600,000 men, which he was duly given. He then crossed the border into Chu, and stopped. He didn몭t launch an offensive, but instead set up camp, built defensive walls around it, and then spent every day training his soldiers in athletics. All the while, he was waiting for Chu to make the first move. He had to wait for a year, but finally the Chu leaders couldn몭t bear it any longer, and began moving their forces around, trying to provoke Wang Jian. But in their movements, Wang Jian saw an opportunity. He struck a single, deadly blow, and the state of Chu ceased to exist.



To succeed, you need large-scale, long-term accumulation. If you do this, you can live in a way that transcends the limits of other people몭s imaginations

Extract from the original text:
몮Security against defeat implies defensive tactics; ability to defeat the enemy means taking the offensive. Standing on the defensive indicates insufficient strength; attacking displays a superabundance of strength. The general who is skilled in defense hides in the most secret recesses of the earth; he who is skilled in attack flashes forth from the topmost heights of heaven. Thus, on the one hand we have ability to protect ourselves; on the other, a victory that is complete.몯

Analysis:
몮Security against defeat implies defensive tactics.몯 The commentator He Shi explains it like this: 몮Having not seen any pattern or weakness within the enemy몭s formation and force that might lead to your victory, then defend your position staunchly.몯
Cao Cao limits his commentary to just five words in the original Chinese: 몮This means concealing your formation.몯 If, having surveyed the enemy몭s formation, I find no opportunity for victory, I need to conceal my own army몭s formation and establish a defensive position. It몭s important to not let the enemy find any weakness he could exploit.

몮Ability to defeat the enemy means taking the offensive.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮If the enemy몭s formation is such that he may be defeated, then you ought to march forth and attack.몯 An excellent example of the first two lines of this passage is one we have already discussed: the story of the Qin general Wang Jian destroying the state of Chu. He marched right up to Chu몭s front door, so to speak, with 600,000 men no less, but when he saw that the Chu armies were lined up waiting for him, he stopped and promptly took up a defensive position. He stayed on the defensive for a year, until the Chu army twitched, exposing a weakness in their defensive line (i.e., a beatable formation). Wang Jian attacked immediately, winning in a single move.
  
몮Standing on the defensive indicates insufficient strength; attacking, a superabundance of strength.몯

Sun Tzu몭s philosophy is nothing if not consistently cautious. 몮Standing on the defensive indicates insufficient strength몯 is about knowing when you몭re not strong enough, and adopting a defensive position. How much strength do you need if you want to attack? In a word, you need a 몬superabundance.몭 It몭s not enough to have just 몬sufficient몭 strength; you need to leave some leeway. Actually, you need a lot of leeway; you need to hold an overwhelming advantage, and only then should you attack.


몮The general who is skilled in defense hides in the most secret recesses of the earth; he who is skilled in attack flashes forth from the topmost heights of heaven.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Here, 몬recesses of the earth몭 means 몬deep beyond knowing,몭 and 몬the topmost heights of heaven몭 means 몬high beyond measure.몭몯
Du Mu comments: 몮When defending, cover up your words and erase your footprints, be as shadowy as a ghost. Underground, you cannot be seen. When attacking, move swiftly and in force, with terrible momentum. Be as fast as lightning, and attack as though dropping from the sky; then the enemy will have no way to prepare.몯
So, those who are skilled at defending conceal themselves 몬in the recesses of the earth,몭 so that their enemy is left knowing nothing. Those who are skilled at attacking know how to fill the sky with thunder and strike like lightning. Then, the enemy has neither the chance to react nor the strength to fight back.

몮Thus, on the one hand we have ability to protect ourselves; on the other, a victory that is complete.몯 

If you are capable of defending, you can protect the completeness of your forces. If you are capable of attacking, you can secure a completeness victory.
The 몬complete몭 in Sun Tzu몭s philosophy of complete victory isn몭t just about keeping your forces intact and whole. It몭s also about keeping your cities and resources intact and undamaged, and preserving your enemy몭s assets as well. 
First, take care of your own forces. Don몭t kill 1,000 of the enemy몭s troops if it means sacrificing 800 of your own. Second, try your best not to damage the enemy몭s forces and assets. Don몭t defeat the enemy only to watch him destroy bridges, roads, cities and other infrastructure, and burn his granaries and other resources as he retreats. You need to make sure none of these things get damaged, so that they can serve you later. Ideally, you also wouldn몭t kill any of the enemy몭s men. You can take away their will to fight if you몭re able to descend from the sky like lightning. They몭ll lay down their weapons and surrender, and they can join your army, making your forces all the more robust.
Please do not think that defending means being conservative or not trying to make progress.
Defending is, in essence, a way of accumulating the means to victory. In fact, it몭s a way of accelerating the process!
In terms of business management, a simple analogy for these principles would be specialization versus diversification. Every time you enter a new field, you몭re on the attack. Conversely, any time you do a deep dive into a certain field, you몭re in 몬protection mode.몭 Early in the career of Chinese businessman Wang Shi, he sold off all of his companies except for his real estate business, which he protected and ultimately nurtured into China몭s biggest real estate enterprise, China Vanke.
On a personal level, the ability to master anything you turn your hand to comes from concentration and persistence. Any person can become an expert in any field within five years, as long as they focus entirely on that one field. Within ten years, they can become a respected authority in the field, and within 15 they can be the best in the world.
In business, if you lock down on one thing and grow your operation into a world-class organization, you can live beyond the limits of other people몭s imaginations. So, 몬defending몭 is about moving from quantitative change to qualitative change. It몭s about concealing yourself deep 몬in the recesses of the earth,몭 so that nobody knows how deep your waters truly are, because they have never gone as deep into anything as you have. You몭ve become their highest competitive barrier, and nobody else can get around you.
So, what about the line: 몮He who is skilled in attack flashes forth from the topmost heights of heaven.몯 What does it mean? It means that when you think your enemy is attacking you, they actually aren몭t. The principle is similar to a concept invented by Chinese science-fiction phenomenon Liu Cixin, known as an 몬inter-dimensional strike.몭 It몭s a technology that can destroy your enemies without being directly connected to them in any way.
Being in the 몬topmost heights of heaven몭 means that you and your enemy are not on the same level; you몭re operating from a different platform. You몭re not even really fighting on the same battlefield.
In today몭s business world, every online company has to use mobile internet technology 멪 it몭s the price of admission. But there몭s no ticket office where you can buy admission; you have to create your own version of an entrance ticket. Every company몭s logic is different, and everyone is working from a different platform, on their own issues. This being so, is there any meaning in talking about 몬competition?몭  
So, what is competition? In essence, it몭s about making sure that your enemies can몭t compete with you. What it몭s not about is trying to compete against others. This is what Sun Tzu meant when he wrote: 몮Those who are skilled in war first make themselves undefeatable.몯 It몭s also what this passage from the Tao Te Ching means: 몮Nobody in the world can compete against one who does not engage in competition.몯 If you reach the point where you are considering competing against someone, you have already lost. Someone whose launch-point is in the 몬topmost heavens몭 doesn몭t even see themselves as competing against anyone. The way they would see it, wherever they move, they trail a strong wind in their wake, and 몬competitors몭 are just people who are blown over by that wind. Of course, the 몬competitors몭 do see it as competition, and are left believing that their possessions have been snatched away.
When you are deep in the 몬recesses of the earth,몭 you need to endure long, lonely periods of silence, and you have to be able to watch other people who attract more attention and seem better-off than you without losing your cool. Modern examples of this include technology company Huawei몭s decision early on to not enter the real estate sector, and online commerce giant Alibaba몭s decision to hone its core capabilities instead of jumping straight into gaming. If you bide your time and gradually build and grow, when you suddenly burst onto the scene, as far as everyone else is concerned, you몭ll be like Sun Tzu 몬flashing forth from the topmost heights of heaven.몭 People will want to learn from your success, and to do that they몭ll need to hop in a time machine and go back ten years, or even further back, to when you were in kindergarten. Basically, it몭ll be impossible for people to 몬learn몭 from you. When they look at you from outside, what they see won몭t be the reasons for your success, because you몭re already living beyond the limits of other people몭s imaginations.



What makes a general truly wise? Normally, only the general himself knows the answer 

Extract from the original text:
몮To see victory only when it is within the ken of the common herd is not the acme of excellence. Neither is it the acme of excellence if you fight and conquer and the whole Empire says, 몭Well done!몭 To lift an autumn hair is no sign of great strength; to see the sun and moon is no sign of sharp sight; to hear the noise of thunder is no sign of a quick ear. What the ancients called a clever fighter is one who not only wins, but excels in winning easy battles. Hence, his victories bring him neither reputation for wisdom nor credit for courage. He wins his battles by making no mistakes. Making no mistakes is what establishes the certainty of victory, for it means conquering an enemy that is already defeated.  Hence, the skillful fighter puts himself into a position which makes defeat impossible, and does not miss the moment for defeating the enemy. Thus it is that in war the victorious strategist only seeks battle after the victory has been won, whereas he who is destined to defeat first fights and afterwards looks for victory. The consummate leader cultivates the moral law, and strictly adheres to method and discipline; thus it is in his power to control success.몯

Analysis:
몮To see victory only when it is within the ken of the common herd is not the acme of excellence.몯 If everyone else can clearly see a victory in the making, the fact that you몭re also able to see it doesn몭t make you a talented commander.
Cao Cao contributes a very brief comment: 몮Better to see it before it sprouts.몯 Only if you have the insight to see something that isn몭t obvious can you be considered a talented commander.
몮You몭ve got to look at the results! Results give you the clearest picture!몯 This is a pretty common idea when it comes to critical evaluation. But, in reality, results aren몭t necessarily a good way to truly understand a problem. This is because today몭s results are a product of yesterday몭s policies. If you use a different policy, the results might end up better or worse, but nobody can go back in time and try again. Also, everyone has different ways of understanding and explaining results. What we need to be talking about is our judgments about the future. Of course, there몭s a massive gap between different people몭s views of what the future will bring.
Li Quan comments: 몮There is no skill in having knowledge that is no different from the knowledge of common people.몯
If what you can see is the same as what everyone else can see, that doesn몭t count as talent. You need to be able to see things that other people can몭t.
General Han Xin destroyed the state of Zhao at the famous Battle of Jingxing. At dawn, before the battle, Han Xin led his troops through Jingxing Pass. He announced to his army what time they would eat breakfast, and that by the time breakfast began, they would already have destroyed the Zhao forces. Han Xin몭s officers didn몭t believe him, but of course they pretended to, and all shouted: 몮Yes sir!몯 
Han Xin lined his army up with their backs to the Tao River.  When the Zhao general saw that his enemies had nowhere to run, he began laughing loudly. Han Xin had been right 멪 he defeated the Zhao forces in a single assault, and just as the battle was ending it was time for breakfast. 
This is a case of a general knowing something that the common people didn몭t.
What exactly did Han Xin know? First, he knew that by lining up his army with their backs to a river, they몭d be without an escape route, so they몭d fight with the conviction that comes from knowing defeat would mean certain death. Second, he knew how to shatter the morale of the Zhao troops and send them running for their lives, ragged and scared. As soon as the battle started, he sent 2,000 cavalry to attack the Zhao camp, tear down their banners, replace them with Han banners, and shout at the top of their voices: 몮The Zhao army is defeated!몯

몮Neither is it the acme of excellence if you fight and conquer and the whole Empire says, 몬Well done!몭몯

If the whole world collectively pats you on the back when you win, that means one thing: you haven몭t reached 몬the acme of excellence.몭
This means that by Sun Tzu몭s standards, Han Xin몭s famous 몬victory by the river몭 cannot be considered truly great. The reason is that an army winning a battle with its back to the river is not the kind of thing that happens very often, and this means that it몭s an inherently a dicey situation. By way of counter example, suppose you have an army of 10,000 men, and you defeat an enemy who has 200,000 men. Such a stunning victory is bound to become famous, and everyone everywhere is sure to tell you how amazing you are. Even 2,000 years later, historians will be citing your story as an example of some point they몭re trying to make. On the other hand, if you have a massive army of 200,000 men, and you squash a much smaller enemy force of 10,000, no one몭s going to bother writing down your story. A mere 10,000 men defeating 200,000 is a very low-probability event, so how do some generals actually achieve such unusual triumphs? Actually, it몭s more about trusting to luck and relying on your enemy몭s stupidity.
This is true of Han Xin몭s victory against Zhao. Considering the situation he started from, winning was always going to be a tall order. While Han Xin was still leading his army through the mountains toward Jingxing Pass, his enemy, Lord Guangwu of Zhao, tried to give some tactical advice to the Zhao commander, Chen Yu:
몮The mountain road to Jingxing is very narrow, allowing no more than two war chariots to proceed abreast. The path is too narrow for cavalry to ride in formation, and it extends over a distance of several hundred li, so the enemy supply wagons will have no choice but to fall far behind the rest of the army. Give me 30,000 men, and I will lead them along a small, hidden path through the mountains, and intercept the enemy몭s supplies. Then, you can build sturdy fortifications in the field, and refuse to come out to fight. Thus, the enemy will be stranded in the wilderness 멪 unable to move forward by fighting against you, and without a road of retreat. Without anything for them to eat or plunder, it will take less than ten days for Han Xin몭s head to be delivered to your tent.몯
But Chen Yu didn몭t listen. Han Xin몭s intel informed him of Lord Guangwu몭s plan, and he also learned that Chen Yu did not intend to put it into action. That몭s why he was willing to press ahead through the mountains. Before the battle, Han Xin ordered his men to capture Lord Guangwu and bring him to him, alive. He made it clear that Guangwu was not to be harmed. When Han Xin몭s men delivered Lord Guangwu to him, Han Xin personally untied the ropes that bound his hands, bowed to him, and respectfully addressed him as his 몬master.몭 Lord Guangwu replied deferentially, 몮A defeated general dares not praise himself.몯
Han Xin then said: 몮The ancient general Baili Xi once served the state of Yu, but Yu was destroyed. Then, Baili Xi travelled to Qin, and because of his talent, Qin grew ever more dominant. This does not mean that the Baili who served Yu was a fool who somehow became wise after moving to Qin. No, the truth is that his first master did not use him or listen to him, but his second master did. This is also the case with Chen Yu 멪 if he had used your plan, our current situation would be reversed, and I would be your prisoner. But, precisely because he did not use you, I now have the good fortune to be of service to you!몯 
Soon afterward, Han Xin used a plan devised by Lord Guangwu to force the state of Yan to surrender.
If we switch our perspective on the Battle of Jingxing and look at it from the Zhao point of view, Chen Yu wasn몭t actually beaten by Han Xin, but by himself. In the words of Lord Guangwu, Chen Yu had an 몬unassailable formula for victory,몭 and yet Chen Yu declined to use it. From the moment he made that decision, he had already lost. Just by giving Han Xin safe passage through Jingxing Pass, he guaranteed that nothing could stand in the way of the Han army. As for the bit about Han Xin announcing to his men what time breakfast would be served, this is exactly the kind of delectable detail that storytellers know is sure to delight audiences. When this sort of tidbit is repeated, it몭s equivalent to 몬the whole Empire saying, Well Done!몭 As far as the practical side of war goes, what time an army eats its meals isn몭t relevant.
We should be especially wary of stories like this 멪 tales of victories that have gained the public몭s unqualified seal of approval. You might think you can replicate these great feats, but you몭ll find that things start to go wrong as soon as you try. Han Xin won with his back to the water, but if you try to do the same, you might end up feeding the fishes instead.

몮To lift an autumn hair is no sign of great strength; to see the sun and moon is no sign of sharp sight; to hear the noise of thunder is no sign of a quick ear.몯

Being able to lift a single hair doesn몭t make you strong; being able to see the sun and the moon doesn몭t make you sharp-sighted; being able to hear thunder doesn몭t make you keen of hearing. 

몮What the ancients called a clever fighter is one who not only wins, but excels in winning easy battles. Hence, his victories bring him neither reputation for wisdom nor credit for courage. He wins his battles by making no mistakes. Making no mistakes is what establishes the certainty of victory, for it means conquering an enemy that is already defeated.몯

Those who are truly skilled in war win exclusively against enemies who are easy pickings, or even against enemies who are already beaten. Is there any argument that this isn몭t true of Han Xin몭s victory against Zhao at the Battle of Jingxing?
This line in particular bears repeating: 몮Conquer an enemy that is already defeated.몯 Truly skillful generals don몭t beat their enemies! They attack only once they can see when their enemy is already beaten.
That몭s why none of the truly skillful generals have a place in the ranks of history몭s most well regarded generals. What does a general have to do to become famous? One sure-fire way is to win an 몬unwinnable몭 battle to make your name really last down through the generations. Examples include Xiang Yu, and the Han dynasty general Li Guang, who was a scourge of the Xiongnu. Meanwhile, the truly capable generals were those who were always thoroughly prepared, who did things by the book, and who never made mistakes.
What about Sun Tzu himself? Does he count as a 몬famous general?몭 He몭s certainly famous, but his fame comes mainly from the book he wrote, and history hasn몭t preserved any accounts of the battles he fought. But his contemporary, Wu Zixu, who also served as a general for the state of Wu, is the very definition of a mega-famous general. During his life, he was acclaimed as a once-in-a-generation talent, and after he died, his memory remained a towering presence. Sun Zixu몭s whole life was an epic drama, full of feuding, vengeance and blood. Embroiled in an inter-generational bloodbath, he killed his enemies to avenge his father, and eventually he lost his own life in similar circumstances. Meanwhile, we have no detailed stories about Sun Tzu몭s life, or how he died, although presumably he passed away in the comfort of his own bed. That would certainly explain the lack of a theatrical death-story, ? la Wu Zixu. All we know is that Sun Tzu made important contributions as a general of the state of Wu.

몮Hence his victories bring him neither reputation for wisdom nor credit for courage.몯

This passage cuts to the essence. Skillful generals aren몭t famous for their wisdom, so they can몭t be accused of being too clever for their own good. Likewise, they몭re not famous for their bravery, and so they can몭t be said to be too brave for their own good. Why? Cao Cao comments: 몮If the enemy몭s formation is not fully-formed, defeating him brings no glory; it몭s not impressive.몯
The same principle is at play in a saying about Chinese medicine: 몬The supreme doctor cures patients who are not yet ill.몯 Doctors can become famous by bringing a patient back from the brink of death. We몭ve all heard it before: 몬He was knocking on death몭s door, but somehow the doctor brought him back to life!몭 This is what it means to have a reputation for wisdom and bravery. But, what if every terminal patient were handed over to this one doctor? Would he or she be able to save all of them?
That몭s why the highest level a doctor can reach isn몭t status as a 몬famous doctor,몭 but the distinction of being a 몬supreme doctor.몭 The very best doctors treat illnesses before they even happen. They can see the first signs of a developing sickness, and nip it in the bud by devising a course of preventative treatment, allowing you to sidestep the part where you actually get sick.
But there몭s a problem here: where몭s the proof that you were actually going to get sick? What if the doctor몭s tricking you? Was it really because of their treatment that you didn몭t get sick? The doctor can know the answers, but you never will. There are things that are only known to exceptional people, and to the heavens. Reporters can몭t write a story on these cases; they can몭t say that this person was going to get diabetes, but in the end they didn몭t, and it was entirely thanks to their doctor.
That몭s why a truly exceptional doctor will never become famous. This is also the story of the famous Warring States period doctor, Bian Que, and his two brothers.
Duke Wen of Wei summoned Bian Que, and asked him: 몮There are three brothers in your family. Which of you is most skilled in the arts of medicine?몯
Bian Que replied: 몮My eldest brother is the best, my second-eldest brother is slightly worse, and I am the worst of the three.몯
Duke Wen was confused by this answer, so Bian Que explained: 몮My eldest brother cures illnesses before they manifest any symptoms 멪 before even the patient knows that they are sick. He prescribes medicines to root out the causes of the illness, and so his medical skills have not been widely recognized. Even in our village, the people there do not think highly of him. That is why his name is not well known. Only our family members understand that he is the most talented of all of us.
몮As for my second-eldest brother, his skill lies in prescribing medicines to cure illnesses when they are still in the early stages, before the symptoms have made clear what the illness is. At this stage, the patient usually is not experiencing any pain or discomfort. The people of our village think he몭s capable of curing certain minor illnesses, and so he has a small degree of fame in the area where we live, but people in neighboring villages do not know who he is.
몮As for me, the way I work tends to make a bigger noise, so to speak. I am only able to treat illnesses once the symptoms have become very severe and the patient is in agony. In these conditions, the patient몭s family members naturally feel extremely anxious, and so they watch as I put needles in the patient몭s meridian points and let their blood, or apply poultices to wounds so as to attack the poison within their bodies. And they see how my gravely ill patients are cured, or at least gain some relief. And that is why I am famous around the world.몯
Famous generals are much like famous doctors, in that they win when it seems like nobody could possibly win. But truly skillful generals never fight hard battles, battles that merit dramatic retellings to teary-eyed audiences. Skillful generals stick to easy fights.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Great wisdom is not commended, and great merit is not widely talked about. What bravery or wisdom is there in the ability to see fine details and win easy victories?몯
He Shi says: 몮If you cure an illness before it has formed, who will call you wise? If you subdue the enemy without fighting, who will call you brave?몯
You don몭t get recognition if people don몭t know what you몭ve done.
This is why some unethical people wait and do nothing, even when they can clearly see a problem that needs to be solved. They know that if they wait until the problem has festered to the point that no one else can deal with it, they can jump in and be the hero who saves the day. The reason they don몭t act sooner is that they몭re only interested in doing things that people can see, and which will bring them praise.
This approach leads to unnecessary risk and loss. So, what do you do about it? Basically, nothing. You just have to rely on your boss몭s wisdom. A good boss has to have the ability to see things clearly, just like Liu Bang. When he finally unified all of China, and staged a grand ceremony to mark the beginning of the Han dynasty, he gave out noble titles to his various advisors and generals. But he heaped the highest accolades on his counselor, Xiao He, much to the chagrin of certain generals who proudly considered themselves brave warriors. They protested, saying that they had soaked themselves in blood on the battlefields and put their bodies on the line, while Xiao He stayed safely at home. They wanted to know how he could be honored more highly than them. Liu Bang responded by asking them if they몭d ever seen hunters at work. He explained that the way hunters work is by planning out routes ahead of time, and then releasing their dogs once they detect their prey몭s tracks. Liu Bang told them that they were his 몬esteemed dogs,몭 while Xiao He was his 몬esteemed hunter.몭 Then, he asked them who should be rewarded more highly.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Secret plans operate unseen, and victory is obtained by invisible means, so the people of the world do not hear about the wisdom which leads to the enemy몭s defeat, and they do not see the feats that lead to enemy flags and heads falling, and the minister who stays at home does not taste the glory of the battlefield.몯 
Here, the 몬minister who stays at home몭 refers to Liu Bang몭s other 몬esteemed hunter,몭 Zhang Liang.
Generally speaking, nobody knows about the achievements of generals who are truly wise, except the generals themselves. That is, unless they have a boss as clear-sighted as Liu Bang. So, to be a wise general, you have to get used to feeling left out. Anyway, who asked you to be so wise in the first place?



The innermost core of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: Win first, fight later

Extract from the original text:
몮Hence, the skillful fighter puts himself into a position which makes defeat impossible, and does not miss the moment for defeating the enemy. Thus it is that in war the victorious strategist only seeks battle after the victory has been won, whereas he who is destined to defeat first fights and afterwards looks for victory.몯

Analysis:
몮Hence, the skillful fighter puts himself into a position which makes defeat impossible, and does not miss the moment for defeating the enemy.몯
Two armies reach a standoff 멪 what next? First things first: get your own affairs in order. Set yourself up in a position where you can몭t be beaten. Of course, your opponent will also be familiar with the art of war, including the principle of establishing oneself in a 몬position which makes defeat impossible.몭 The difference will come down to who slips up first. If neither side makes a mistake, you몭ll have to wait out a long stalemate. In this scenario, the winner will be whoever has more food and fodder. In the meantime, you might still win a swift victory 멪 if the enemy ever reveals the slightest hint of a gap in their armor, strike instantly and mercilessly, and the day will be yours.
몮To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands.몯 Setting yourself up in a position where you can몭t be beaten is entirely up to you, and has nothing to do with anyone else.
몮The opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy.몯 Keep watching the enemy until he makes a mistake.
These are the principles behind a passage from Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Duke Li of Wei: 몮From ancient times until the present, all victories and defeats have been the product of nothing more than one mistake. One analogy would be the game of go 멪 in go, a single mistake cascades across the board, bringing utter defeat.
All it takes is one mistake. If your enemy seizes on your error, no amount of talent on your part will save you. On the other hand, if your enemy is an idiot, and doesn몭t notice your mistake, the game continues with one mistake triggering another, as both sides trade blows. This ensures heavy casualties, and plenty of tragic stories after the event.
In the real world of work, pretty much everyone is an idiot, and for the most part, the quality of play is fairly low all around. There몭s a saying: 몬The reason we몭ve made it this far isn몭t because we몭ve done a good job, but because we didn몭t do as badly as our competitors.몭 Every successful person had experiences like this, because they know that their performance hasn몭t always been particularly great. Yet, somehow, they몭ve become a 몬great master.몭
When your enemy makes a mistake, don몭t miss it. If it몭s clear they몭re not going to make a mistake, of course you shouldn몭t sit around waiting for nothing; you have to lure them into tripping over their own feet. This is why Emperor Taizong claimed that everything there is to know about the art of war comes down to one sentence: 몮Use a multitude of diverse methods to fool one몭s foe.몯 In war, there can never be too much deception. All possible variations on 몬deception in war몭 are available to browse in Chapter One:
몮All warfare is based on deception. Hence, when able to attack, we must seem unable; when using our forces, we must seem inactive; when we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away; when far away, we must make him believe we are near. Hold out baits to entice the enemy, spreading disorder. Then, crush him. If he is secure at all points, be prepared for him. If he is in superior strength, evade him. If your opponent is of choleric temper, seek to irritate him. Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant. If he is taking his ease, give him no rest. If his forces are united, separate them.몯
Everyone knows that military leaders don몭t shy away from deception, but this commonly accepted fact is also the source of a common misconception. Namely, that deception is at the heart of the art of war, to the point that war is deception, and deception is war. But this isn몭t true. In war, deception is exclusively used to manipulate the enemy and make them go where you want. It is by no means fundamental to managing your own business. If your enemy doesn몭t fall for your tricks, deception won몭t serve you. Likewise, if you don몭t fall for your enemy몭s tricks, his attempt at deception has been nothing more than a useless piece of theater. The real heart of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War isn몭t found in deception, but in this single line:
몮Thus it is that in war the victorious strategist only seeks battle after the victory has been won, whereas he who is destined to defeat first fights and afterwards looks for victory.몯
Winning armies always set themselves up to win. They secure the means of victory, and only then do they fight. On the other hand, losing armies invariably rush into fights, hoping they몭ll be lucky enough to stumble upon an opportunity to win in the heat of the battle.
Winning first and fighting later is about abiding by the rule of fighting only once you몭ve gained an overwhelming advantage, and it몭s about refusing to trust the idea of luck. This is Sun Tzu몭s philosophy.
Some people might object to this philosophy, on the grounds that this approach to war is only workable for the strong: if you몭re weak, how are you supposed to gain an overwhelming advantage? If you몭re starting a business, how are you supposed to set yourself up in a position where failure becomes impossible?
The problem with this objection is that it몭s based on a misunderstanding. Sun Tzu몭s philosophy isn몭t just for the strong; it몭s universal. If you몭re weak, you can still gain an overwhelming advantage 멪 the way to do it is to maneuver into a situation where you have a 몬local advantage.몭 It몭s the same concept as concentrating your strength in a position where it becomes superior to the enemy몭s, and then annihilating the enemy forces. And if you몭re starting a business, the way to set yourself up in a position where you can몭t lose is to gradually build up your trade knowledge and your resources before starting operations. If you rush into it without taking the time to understand even the basics, your only hope will be to get lucky, win big, and become another of history몭s 몬famous generals.몭 It몭s like trying to win the lottery.
Here몭s an example of the right way of doing it: You graduate from university, choose a field of work, and hunker down for the next fifteen years, applying yourself to both working and learning. After fifteen years, you몭ll be a senior figure in your field, an expert. If you make it to this point, you몭ve made good on Sun Tzu몭s fabled dictate to 몬establish oneself in a position where defeat is impossible.몭 As an expert, you also enjoy certain freedoms 멪 the freedom to confidently ask your boss for a raise, the freedom to move on to greener pastures in the knowledge that plenty of people will want you on their team, and the freedom to start your own business knowing that you have the resources you need. This is a real-life example of 몬looking for a fight when you몭ve already won.몭
But who wants to wait for fifteen years? Why not just go for it! When young people set out to start a business, they don몭t really understand or have any familiarity with a given industry, so they generally opt for projects that seem the most attractive. This is an example of 몬looking for victory once you몭re already in a fight.몭 When it doesn몭t work out, they try something else, and then something else, and so on.
