If you몭ve tried out more than a handful of trades, you end up not belonging to any of them, and you find yourself at the fringes of a society that you몭ve never had any strong connections to.
But, then again, what about the countless successful business 몬heroes몭 cheering you on in the news media? How did they make it?
First, they haven몭t necessarily made it. Some of them are just boasting without anything to back it up. 
Second, there aren몭t actually 몬countless몭 business success stories. They are very much countable, and you can be sure that the few people who actually make it will end up in the media. If everyone were successful, it wouldn몭t be worth reporting. There are 300 million young people in China, and the ones who can claim success in business have all been 몬discovered몭 by the press. And the fact is that at least half of these 몬successful몭 entrepreneurs are actually unsuccessful entrepreneurs who know how to talk themselves up.
One passage from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War comes to mind here: 몮The clever fighter몭s victories bring him neither reputation for wisdom nor credit for courage.몯 When someone settles into their line of work, and chips diligently away at it for the next decade or more, until their hard work bears fruit, it doesn몭t necessarily make for a captivating story. Headlines are reserved for stories like: 몬Female college grad opens sex shop.몭
There몭s a western saying that goes, 몬Successful people laugh in private, while failures occupy the pages of newspapers.몭 Don몭t be the main character of a great tragedy. Don몭t try to be like the people in the business press 멪 they몭re the preserve of low-probability events. Instead, learn from the people around you. You몭ll get a much better picture of what the world is really like.
What kinds of people are capable of being winners? Sun Tzu said: 몮The consummate leader cultivates the moral law, and strictly adheres to method and discipline; thus it is in his power to control success.몯
This is about politics and discipline. In terms of politics, the people must adore you, and in terms of discipline, you must refrain from causing the slightest bit of harm. There몭s nothing deceptive to be found here.



The eternal fundamental

To talk about 몬Winning first, fighting later,몭 we have to look at 몬winning몭 and 몬fighting몭 separately. They몭re two different stages. Winning comes first, and it represents the fundamentals, the essential groundwork. Only fight once you몭ve laid the foundation. Our problem is that we몭ve always paid much more attention to fighting than to winning. We몭re fascinated by shortcuts and workarounds, and so we want to get involved in fights before winning, which inevitably means the odds will not be in your favor.

Extract from the original text:
몮The consummate leader cultivates the moral law, and strictly adheres to method and discipline; thus it is in his power to control success. In respect of military method, we have firstly, Measurement; secondly, Estimation of quantity; thirdly, Numbers; fourthly, Balancing of chances; fifthly, Victory. Measurement owes its existence to Earth; Estimation of quantity to Measurement; Calculation to Estimation of quantity; Balancing of chances to Calculation; and Victory to Balancing of chances. A victorious army, as opposed to a routed one, is as a pound몭s weight placed in the scale against a single grain. The onrush of a conquering force is like the bursting of pent-up waters into a chasm a thousand fathoms deep. This is formation.몯

Analysis:
몮The consummate leader cultivates the moral law, and strictly adheres to method and discipline.몯
Li Quan interprets this passage like this: 몮Be smooth in the way that you deal with contrariness. Do not attack states that have committed no wrong. When your army arrives, do not plunder, do not cut down the people몭s trees or pollute their wells. When you pass through the enemy몭s territory, you must cleanse the land of local gods and shrines and root them out; do not become habituated to the things that remain of defeated states: this is what is referred to as 몬the moral law, method and discipline.몭 You must control your army strictly and solemnly, establish the death penalty but ensure that nobody commits crimes that would warrant it to be carried out; use rewards and punishments to establish trust and righteousness. If a general can establish himself in this way, he will be able to defeat his enemy몭s failing ways of governance.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮The moral law is righteousness; method and discipline are the system of laws. He who is skillful in war first concentrates on cultivating righteousness and upholding the system of laws, for this is a way of governance that makes one immune to defeat. Wait until the enemy shows some weakness that you can use to gain victory, and then attack. This will bring you victory.몯
So, the idea is that the 몬victorious way of governance몭 is to cultivate the moral law and uphold method and discipline. The 몬moral law몭 is about whether the reason for which you몭ve gone to war is a righteous one, and 몬method and discipline몭 are about keeping a strict and clear set of military laws, while not bringing any harm to the common people. A good example of these principles is the 1928 military doctrine, Three Rules for Discipline and Eights Points for Attention, published by Mao Zedong and written for the soldiers of the Red Army. The whole text is as follows:
몮Every member of the Revolutionary Army must commit to memory the following three rules for discipline and eight points for attention:

The Three Rules for Discipline are as follows:

(1) Obey orders in all your actions. We can only win if we coordinate every step we take.
(2) Don't take a single needle or piece of thread from the masses. Then, the masses will love and support us.
(3) Turn in everything captured. Strive to lighten the people몭s burden.

We must implement the three rules for discipline, and must not forget the eight points for attention.
@	The Eight Points for Attention are as follows: 
(1) Speak politely. Respect the masses; do not act arrogantly.
(2) Pay fairly for what you buy, and give fair prices for what you sell. It is forbidden to bully or use force in any transactions.
(3) Return everything you borrow. Make sure not to lose anything you borrow.
(4) Pay for anything you damage. You must pay the full price, and not a penny less.
(5) Don't hit or swear at people. Resolutely overcome the warlords몭 ways of behaving.
(6) Don't damage crops. While marching and fighting, always pay attention.
(7) Don't take liberties with women. Resolutely root out immoral habits.
(8) Don't ill-treat captives. It is forbidden to hit or swear at them, and to take their money.
Everyone must consciously uphold discipline and never violate it, and everyone must monitor one another.
You must clearly memorize each of the points of revolutionary discipline, and the people몭s warriors must love the people in every way.
Defend the motherland and move eternally forward, and the people of the whole country will love and support us.

몮In respect of military method, we have, firstly, Measurement; secondly, Estimation of quantity; thirdly, Numbers; fourthly, Comparison; fifthly, Victory. Measurement owes its existence to Earth; Estimation of quantity to Measurement; Calculation to Estimation of quantity; Balancing of chances to Calculation; and Victory to Balancing of chances.몯
The ideas of 몬measurement,몭 몬estimation of quantity,몭 몬number,몭 and 몬comparison몭 are all variables to be calculated when comparing your strength to your enemy몭s, as laid out in Chapter One, Calculations.
Du Mu comments: 몮몬Measurement몭 means 몬calculation.몭 It is about measuring the size of my state몭s territory, the number of households it contains, the amount of tax revenue collected, the number of war chariots, the ease or difficulty with which the terrain may be traversed, whether the roads are straight or winding. You must measure all of these as they apply to you, and then measure the enemy몭s situation. Only then should you raise an army.몯
So, 몬measurements몭 give us 몬estimation of quantities.몭 Once we몭ve made these estimations, we have the 몬numbers,몭 and in turn, once you몭ve measured the size of your state몭s territory, the number of households, and the amount of food produced, you calculate how many troops you can feed, how long you can support a war effort, and also how the enemy matches up to you on these points.
몬Numbers몭 give us 몬comparisons,몭 which means we have the information necessary to compare our situation to the enemy몭s.
몬Comparisons몭 give us 몬victory몭멪 once the comparisons have been made, you know who will win and who will lose. Better odds for victory go to whoever몭s numbers are bigger.

몮A victorious army, as opposed to a routed one, is as a pound몭s weight against a single grain.몯

In the original Chinese text, two ancient units of measurement were used in this passage: the yi and the zhu. One yi is equivalent to 480 zhu. Accordingly, 480:1 are not good odds. 

몮The onrush of a conquering force is like the bursting of pent-up waters into a chasm a thousand fathoms deep. This is formation.몯

In battle, a winner directs his forces as if unleashing a high mountain lake from behind a dam. Who could stand in his way? While 1,000 fathoms is unimaginably deep, he knows exactly how deep it is, though nobody else does. This is the way to approach military formations: hiding out of sight, 몬in the most secret recesses of the earth.몭
When the moment comes for him to unleash the floodwaters, he launches himself from 몬topmost heaven,몭 and his troops몭 formation becomes as water, going where the enemy least expects, avoiding where the enemy is strong and attacking where he is weak. Thus, he is unstoppable.
Sun Tzu chose to use the end of Formations to talk once again about the fundamentals: the strength of your nation, sound governance, and laws that are strict and clear.
At the start of this book, we talked about how Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War and The Thirty-Six Stratagems are two very different texts, representing two very different value systems. The Thirty-Six Stratagems is all about deception, ingenuity and sneaky shortcuts. Sun Tzu also talks about deception, but it isn몭t an important part of his work. From start to finish, he emphasizes these things above all else: the fundamentals, and actual strength.
Success always comes from long-term accumulation, not clever tricks, and successful people are always working on the most fundamental things. No matter what stage they몭re at, they몭re always focusing on the fundamentals. We몭ve talked about how 몬winning first, fighting later몭 is at the heart of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, and we몭ve discussed how winning and fighting need to be separated and understood as two different stages. Winning comes first, and winning is nothing other than working on the fundamentals. Fighting comes later, and this is the time for trying out a few sneaky ideas.
We generally run into problems when our focus is always on fighting, and not winning; when we want to use some clever idea to win quickly. Because we think like this, we get into fights without making sure to win first, which in turn leads to fighting against bad odds.



Appendix: Complete text of Chapter Four: Formations

Sun Tzu said: 몮The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy. To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself. Thus, the good fighter is able to secure himself against defeat, but cannot make certain of defeating the enemy. Hence the saying: One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it. Security against defeat implies defensive tactics; ability to defeat the enemy means taking the offensive. Standing on the defensive indicates insufficient strength; attacking displays a superabundance of strength. The general who is skilled in defense hides in the most secret recesses of the earth; he who is skilled in attack flashes forth from the topmost heights of heaven. Thus, on the one hand we have ability to protect ourselves; on the other, a victory that is complete. To see victory only when it is within the ken of the common herd is not the acme of excellence. Neither is it the acme of excellence if you fight and conquer and the whole Empire says, 몬Well done!몭 To lift an autumn hair is no sign of great strength; to see the sun and moon is no sign of sharp sight; to hear the noise of thunder is no sign of a quick ear. What the ancients called a clever fighter is one who not only wins, but excels in winning easy battles. Hence, his victories bring him neither reputation for wisdom nor credit for courage. He wins his battles by making no mistakes. Making no mistakes is what establishes the certainty of victory, for it means conquering an enemy that is already defeated.  Hence, the skillful fighter puts himself into a position that makes defeat impossible, and does not miss the moment for defeating the enemy. Thus it is that in war the victorious strategist only seeks battle after the victory has been won, whereas he who is destined to defeat first fights and afterwards looks for victory. The consummate leader cultivates the moral law, and strictly adheres to method and discipline; thus it is in his power to control success[bd14]. In respect of military method, we have, firstly, Measurement; secondly, Estimation of quantity; thirdly, Numbers; fourthly, Balancing of chances; fifthly, Victory. Measurement owes its existence to Earth; Estimation of quantity to Measurement; Calculation to Estimation of quantity; Balancing of chances to Calculation; and Victory to Balancing of chances. A victorious army, as opposed to a routed one, is as a pound몭s weight placed in the scale against a single grain. The onrush of a conquering force is like the bursting of pent-up waters into a chasm a thousand fathoms deep. This is formation.몯



Chapter Five: Use of energy

Organizational Structure and Command Systems: The Eternal Homework Assignment

This is a part of the art of war that nobody enjoys hearing about. And yet, these dull, nap-inducing topics contain the most important secrets, which can reveal whether or not your war is winnable. Don몭t go looking for these secrets in more exciting topics 멪 they몭re not there.

Extract from the original text:
몮The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers. Fighting with a large army under your command is no different from fighting with a small one: it is merely a question of instituting signs and signals.몯

Analysis:
Energy is powerful. Once it builds, it can몭t be stopped. The key is to create energy that will inevitably bring the results you want. Cao Cao puts it like this: 몮Using military force is about exploiting energy. If you want to use military force, you must rely on energy.
What relation is there between formation and energy? We mentioned this already 멪 before acting, you look at formations; once you몭ve taken action, you rely on energy.
몬Formation몭 is your material strength, and it몭s also your strategy. Energy is different; you can몭t give it a simple label like 몬battle tactics몭 or 몬execution.몭 One often-quoted explanation comes from the Han dynasty scholar-official, Xun Yue:
몮There are three essentials in the art of establishing policies and obtaining victory: 1) Formation; 2) Energy; 3) Circumstances. In general, formation is about calculations of what may be gained and what may be lost. Energy is about that which is appropriate in the moment-to-moment situation of a battle, and it is about opportunities for advancing and retreating. Circumstances are about whether or not, in truth, one몭s will is within the realm of possibility. Thus, the fact that results differ even when policies and events are the same is because of differences in the use of these three arts.몯
While this is an accurate analysis, Xun Yue is talking about a different kind of 몬energy몭 than that described in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. Xun Yue understands 몬energy몭 as being about responding to events as they develop, following whatever direction offers advantage. For Sun Tzu, 몬energy몭 is something artificial, something that people can create, like a kind of 몬momentum.몭
Once you몭ve built this momentum, you exploit it, using its artificial force to propel your team forward, or even to call upon the forces of nature to do your bidding. The main point that Sun Tzu emphasizes is building momentum as a way to influence people mentally, to exert force on their will. This is why, in The Art of War, the idea of 몬circumstances몭멪 which Xun Yue separates from 몬formation몭 and 몬force몭  멪 falls under the broader category of 몬energy.몭 So, if you build the right kind of momentum, it doesn몭t matter what the circumstances are. Even if the people you몭re trying to influence don몭t have the will to do what you want, once you apply force to them, one way or another they몭ll have to do what you want! An example of this is Han Xin몭s Battle of Jingxing, when he made his soldiers fight with their backs to a river, putting them in a position where they had only two choices: fight with everything they had, or die. They had to get a grip on themselves, and fight for their lives, and that몭s exactly what they did.
Using modern language to talk about 몬energy몭 as Sun Tzu thought of it, we몭d have to use two concepts: 1) Battle tactics; 2) Management.

몮The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers. Fighting with a large army under your command is no different from fighting with a small one: it is merely a question of instituting signs and signals.몯

Managing a lot of people is the same managing only a few, because of this idea of 몬dividing up their numbers,몭 also known as 몬staffing structure.몭 Here, 몬dividing몭 refers to squads, platoons, companies, divisions, armies, etc. The key question is: how exactly do you divide your men? Here, the idea of 몬numbers몭 is about how many men you allocate to each unit within your staffing structure. If you get your staffing and organizational structure right, it makes no difference whether you have a lot of people to manage, or a few 멪 using your human resources becomes as simple as using your own hand.
The entire discipline of modern management studies originally developed out of military management. There몭s an obscenely huge amount of scholarship and learning contained within these two small words: 몬dividing numbers.몭 A great number of companies put a huge amount of work every day into developing and better understanding their organizational structure, without ever really gaining the understanding they몭re working so hard for. Also, the faster a company몭s business develops or changes, the more reforms are needed to fine-tune its organizational structure.
So, the first passage in Energy is really about management problems 멪 specifically, organizational structure.
몬Dividing numbers몭 and 몬signs and signals몭 are fundamentally interlinked with the fifth of the 몬Five Factors몭 from Chapter One.  It says this: 몮By method and discipline are to be understood the marshaling of the army in its proper subdivisions, the graduations of rank among the officers, the maintenance of roads by which supplies may reach the army, and the control of military expenditure.몯 Cao Cao comments: 몮몬The marshaling of the army in its proper subdivisions몭 is the organizing of units, and it is also the organizing of flags and pennants, and of drums.몯 Here, 몬the organizing of units몭 corresponds with 몬dividing numbers,몭 and 몬flags, pennants and drums몭 corresponds with 몬signs and signals.몭
In ancient Chinese armies, the smallest fighting unit was called a wu, and contained five soldiers. The ancient word wu has become part of modern Chinese words, such as: duiwu, meaning 몬a squad,몭 and 몬ru dui,몭 meaning 몬to join the military.몭 Twenty wu 멪 100 soldiers 멪 makes a zu, which is more or less the same as a 몬company몭 in the modern military. Five zu 멪 500 soldiers 멪 makes a lu, and 25 lu 멪 12,500 soldiers 멪 makes a jun. 
In ancient China, all military staffing units were multiples of five. In the 20th century, Chinese Communist Party General Lin Biao invented his 몬three three몭s system,몭 making three the smallest military unit instead of five, and changing all the larger units into multiples of three. Lin Biao named the smallest unit a small battle group. Three small battle groups made up a battle squad, three battle squads made up a war platoon, three war platoons made up a company, three companies made up a battalion, three battalions made up a regiment, and three regiments made up a division. Lin Biao몭s 몬three three몭s system몭 was his own, unique invention, different from both the American regimental system and the former Soviet Union몭s division-based system.
What does it look like when an army based on multiples of three fights a battle? The officers choose experienced soldiers to lead each small battle group, and as they approach the enemy, the three members of the small battle group fan out in a triangular formation. This is to avoid clumping together and giving the enemy a chance to wipe out the entire small battle group in a single burst. So, how far apart do the three soldiers fan out? They had to stay within shouting distance of the group leader; otherwise the leader wouldn몭t be able to give his men commands.
Lin Biao would start his tactical planning at the level of the smallest, three-man unit, and extend this planning all the way up to the level of the entire Fourth Field Army. This is the meaning of 몬dividing their numbers,몭 and of the dictate that 몬Fighting with a large army under your command is no different from fighting with a small one.몭 Lin Biao was able to command the Fourth Field Army as easily and nimbly as a three-man small battle group.

몮Fighting with a large army under your command is no different from fighting with a small one: it is merely a question of instituting signs and signals.몯

What is the key to being able to command a large army on the battlefield in the same way as a much smaller force? It몭s all about 몬signs and signals.몭 And what are these? Cao Cao explains: 몮몬Signs몭 refers to flags; 몬signals몭 refers to drums.몯 The point is that 몬signs and signals몭 are about how commands are communicated. 몬Signs몭 are like road signs, in the sense that they몭re visual commands. In addition to flags, fire and smoke beacons (sometimes fueled with wolf dung, which created particularly dense smoke) were also used. Meanwhile, 몬signals몭 were audible commands. The Han dynasty dictionary, Shuowen Jiezi, explains that the word used for 몬signal몭 in the original Chinese text 멪 ming, which means 몬name몭멪 comes from a different character that is also pronounced ming, meaning 몬night.몭 At night, it몭s hard to see, and it몭s not easy to identify someone walking toward you. So, you shout out: 몬Who goes there?몭 In response, the other person would shout their name. The idea is that names are made to be shouted, not written down on paper. And so, the meaning stretches to cover the audible commands and code words used by armies at night.
There are command signals that are meant to be seen, such as fire and smoke signals, signal flags, etc. And there are also commands that are meant to be heard, such as verbal orders to charge, shouted directives to assemble, drums signaling to advance, gongs to signal retreat, and so on. We could talk about the informatization of modern militaries, but in reality, ever since armies existed they have relied on informatization to fight wars. Famous commanders from around the world have always been information experts 멪 for example, Napoleon was a master at using flag signals. During Japan몭s century-long Sengoku period of civil wars, Lord Takeda Shingen was hailed as a hero because he designed Japan몭s most advanced and most concentrated 몬smart beacon fire system.몭 His beacons radiated out from his base in Kai Province, and used several different colors of smoke to keep him informed with up-to-the-minute intelligence. If anything happened, he could mobilize his army within minutes. Takeda Shingen didn몭t just use 몬signs몭 on the battlefield; he built them into the infrastructure. 
Organizational structure and command systems are a never-ending homework assignment for any organization, because structures always need to keep up with the relentless forward march of time. Once a company develops to a new stage, its old structure no longer works. That몭s why it몭s important for organizations to be constantly reformed and tweaked, and to have cross-departmental coordination. On the biggest scale, the national scale, the reason China몭s government has set up so many 몬leading groups몭 is to deal with problems with organizational structure and command systems. Then there are counties that are directly managed by provincial governments, which has been a much talked-about topic for years now. This is about the problem of 몬dividing numbers.몭 On a much smaller scale, in private businesses, should staff be divided into different departments according to function, or would it be better to take a multi-divisional approach? Where should the boundaries be set for each level몭s scope of authority? Who should be in charge of whom? If you have a functional department set-up, should you use localized management or vertical management? These questions are all discussed in The Art of War, but nobody enjoys hearing about them. And yet, these dull, nap-inducing topics contain the most important secrets, which can tell you whether or not your war is winnable. Don몭t go looking for these secrets in more exciting topics; they몭re not there.




The most misunderstood passage in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몬The regular may be used for joining battle, but the irregular will be needed in order to secure victory몭

Extract from the original text:
몮To ensure that your whole host may withstand the brunt of the enemy몭s attack and remain unshaken 멪 this is effected by maneuvers regular and irregular. That the impact of your army may be like a grindstone dashed against an egg 멪 this is effected by the science of weak points and strong.
몮In all fighting, the regular may be used for joining battle, but the irregular will be needed in order to secure victory. Irregular tactics, efficiently applied, are inexhaustible as Heaven and Earth, unending as the flow of rivers and streams; like the sun and moon, they end but to begin anew; like the four seasons, they pass away to return once more. There are not more than five musical notes, yet the combinations of these five give rise to more melodies than can ever be heard. There are not more than five primary colors, yet in combination they produce more hues than can ever been seen. There are not more than five cardinal tastes, yet combinations of them yield more flavors than can ever be tasted. In battle, there are not more than two methods of attack: the regular and the irregular. Yet, these two in combination give rise to an endless series of maneuvers. The regular and the irregular lead on to each other in turn. It is like moving in a circle 멪 you never come to an end. Who can exhaust the possibilities of their combination?몯

Analysis:
몮The regular may be used for joining battle, but the irregular will be needed in order to secure victory.몯 This passage has the distinction of being the most misunderstood line in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War.
The biggest misunderstanding, at least for Chinese people, comes from the fact that the Chinese character for 몬indirect몭멯_[bd15]^has another, much more common meaning: 몬rare몭 or 몬remarkable.몭 The meaning that is used here, which is pronounced with a different tone, is 몬odd number,몭 as in, the opposite of an even number. In the ancient Chinese language, it also meant 몬Whatever is left over after some quantity has been counted.몭 This also applies to the arrangement of troops in an army: there몭s always a main force made up of regular troops, and whatever men are left over would be referred to as the 몬irregular troops.몭 The irregular troops would be kept back from the main battle, to be used only at the crucial moment. Put simply, they were the reserves of ancient Chinese armies. 
Cao Cao comments: 몮The 몬regular몭 refers to those who are ordered to join battle first, the 몬irregular몭 to those who are ordered to join later.몯 The relation between 몬regular몭 and 몬irregular몭 is simply their sequential timing: one comes after the other. The idea is to not play all your cards at once, but to keep some in your hand so you몭ll be able to make a play when the crucial moment arrives.
When two armies face off on the battlefield, the regular troops get the fight started, and the two opposing commanders watch from the back, waiting until they see a sign that the crucial moment is at hand. Then, they throw their reserves 멪 their irregular troops 멪 into the fray, in a bid to seal their win. Even though it몭s technically incorrect, there is a modern Chinese idiom that comes from this principle, meaning 몬to win by a surprise move몭 (벶_뻝`[bd16]). This is based on a misreading; it should be 몬irregular,몭 not 몬surprise,몭 but it몭s too late to correct that now!
Sun Tzu wasn몭t the first person to come up with the idea of fighting the main battle with regular troops and winning with irregular troops. Armies had been fighting in this way for 1,000 years before he was born. The earliest record we have of it is a text about the art of war, attributed to the legendary Yellow Emperor of early antiquity, titled, Writings on Grasping the Irregular or Grasping Contingency. This text is mentioned in Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Duke Li of Wei, with Emperor Taizong and Duke Li discussing what its correct title really is. Duke Li was of the opinion that it should be, Writings on Grasping the Irregular, because the pronunciation of 몬irregular몭 (ji) is exactly the same as 몬contingency.몭 Duke Li argued that there was a mix-up at some stage in the process of copying the text and passing it down, equivalent to a typo. Actually, it would be just as correct to call it Grasping Contingency, because an army몭s reserve forces are used as a contingency measure. 

몮Irregular tactics, efficiently applied, are inexhaustible as Heaven and Earth, unending as the flow of rivers and streams; like the sun and moon, they end but to begin anew; like the four seasons, they pass away to return once more.몯

In reality, there is only a piddling number of different moves to be made. There몭s only a handful of 몬the irregular몭 멪 they몭re really a fixed quantity, used in a fixed sequence of moves. And yet, once you actually put them into play, suddenly hundreds of variations and changes jump out, as if from thin air!
It몭s just like there are only five notes in the ancient Chinese pentatonic scale (gong, shang, jue, zhi and yu), and yet the musical combinations are infinite. It몭s a similar story with the tonal scale used in modern music, which only has seven notes (do, re, mi, fa, so, la and ti), and yet can be used to sing every song in the world. Similarly, there are only five primary colors in the Chinese system (blue, yellow, red, white and black), but the hues they can produce are endless. Today, we know that there are actually even fewer 멪 only three primary colors, (red, yellow and blue) 멪 but they can be used to create all the colors that have ever existed. 
There are no more than five basic tastes (sour, spicy, salt, sweet and bitter), and yet a lifetime wouldn몭t be enough to taste all of the delectable combinations that can be created with just these five flavors. The dizzying number of different world cuisines is testament to that!
So, even though in war there are only two different forces, or forms of energy 멪 regular and irregular 멪 the variations and combinations are inexhaustible. The regular and the irregular are able to transform each other, and their interactions are like a circle, without beginning and without end.
Li Quan comments: 몮The forces that directly engage the enemy are the 몬regulars,몭 while the forces who attack from the flanks are the 몬irregulars.몭 What Li Quan is describing here is how regular and irregular troops are arranged on the battlefield, but he몭s actually only talking about how a battle actually shapes up, and that things don몭t always go to plan. If the two armies몭 regular troops engage each other, and both sides keep their shape as the fight wears on, a general might order his irregular troops to attack the enemy몭s flank. If the flank attack successfully breaks up the enemy몭s lines, the regular troops can press forward. In this situation, the smaller force used to attack the enemy몭s flank is actually playing the role of regular troops, and the original 몬regulars몭 become the irregular troops. So, Cao Cao몭s comment is more accurate than Li Quan몭s. The simplest way of explaining it is that the difference between regular and irregular troops is just a difference of timing. If you take Li Quan몭s approach and lock yourself into a rigid binary, you can몭t have any of the transformations that happen when the regular and the irregular interact.

몮In battle, there are not more than two methods of attack: the regular and the irregular; yet these two in combination give rise to an endless series of maneuvers. The regular and the irregular lead on to each other in turn. It is like moving in a circle 멪 you never come to an end.몯

How exactly do the regular and irregular transform each other? It몭s actually very simple. In a battle, the forces you몭ve already committed to the fight are your regular troops, while the forces you keep in reserve are your irregular troops. And then, when you order your reserves to attack, they become your regular troops. When forces that are in the thick of the action pull back, they once again become your irregular troops.
So, irregular troops are just reserves that haven몭t yet joined the fight.
What historical examples are there of these principles? Some writers like to talk about the story of the Tang dynasty General Li Su몭s surprise attack against Cai Prefecture on one snowy night. In the middle of a snowstorm, Li Su led a 몬stealth force몭 in a direct attack on his enemy몭s base, capturing the renegade Tang General Wu Yuanji.
People love to hear stories like this, where the hero wins the day by perfectly executing a bold surprise attack. Nothing몭s more satisfying than when a cunning plan comes together! People expect to hear these stories, yet in real life, 3,000 years of history have only yielded a handful of examples where something like this actually happened. These stories run counter to Sun Tzu몭s value system, and they몭re based on a misunderstanding 멪 the mistaken notion that 몬using the irregular to seal victory몭 means that you몭re supposed to use surprise attacks. Impatient minds impulsively look for ingenious, fast solutions. If you몭re looking for a military theory that actually applies to Li Su몭s snowy surprise attack, a more suitable one would be the Russian Deep Battle and Operation Paralysis theories, where the aim is to attack deeply, moving past the enemy몭s defensive lines and directly striking their logistical hubs, thereby paralyzing them. 
There are three especially common misunderstandings of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. The first, which we몭ve already discussed in Chapter One, Calculations, is confusing the meaning of 몬calculation몭 with 몬cunning stratagems.몭 It몭s a mistake that comes from the fact that the original Chinese character contains both of these meanings. The Art of War is not about 몬The Way of Deception.몭 The second misunderstanding comes from the line, 몮If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles.몯 People always want to understand their opponent, and don몭t realize that their biggest problem is that they don몭t know themselves. The third misunderstanding is the one we몭ve just been discussing: people tend to be hungry for artful methods and fast results. Hence, the emphasis on surprise attacks.
But what Sun Tzu is really talking about when he says, 몮Use the irregular methods to obtain victory,몯 isn몭t surprise attacks, although there is an element of surprise to it. He몭s talking about types of troop deployment 멪 ways to effectively divide your forces.



How are battles fought? For many battles, the key to understanding is taking a look through the lens of 몬regular몭 and 몬irregular몭 forces

Extract from the original text:
몮In all fighting, the regular may be used for joining battle, but the irregular will be needed in order to secure victory. Irregular tactics, efficiently applied, are inexhaustible as Heaven and Earth, unending as the flow of rivers and streams; like the sun and moon, they end but to begin anew; like the four seasons, they pass away to return once more. There are not more than five musical notes, yet the combinations of these five give rise to more melodies than can ever be heard. There are not more than five primary colors, yet in combination they produce more hues than can ever been seen. There are not more than five cardinal tastes, yet combinations of them yield more flavors than can ever be tasted. In battle, there are not more than two methods of attack: the regular and the irregular; yet these two in combination give rise to an endless series of maneuvers. The regular and the irregular lead on to each other in turn. It is like moving in a circle 멪 you never come to an end. Who can exhaust the possibilities of their combination?몯

Analysis:
In war, there are only two kinds of forces: main forces and auxiliary forces. In the simplest terms, this is about troop division, and about coordinating regular and irregular troops on the battlefield. But, the concepts of 몬regular몭 and 몬irregular몭 are fluid 멪 they interact dynamically with each other, able to switch roles at any time. Don몭t lump all of your forces into a single group, and don몭t play all of your cards in one move. Before you go to war, assign your troops to regular and auxiliary units, and coordinate the different parts of your forces so that they work in tandem. When the day of battle arrives, don몭t order your entire army to advance right off the bat. It몭s essential to keep one card in your hand; to have a reserve force. The first to go into battle are the main forces, while the irregular troops are saved for later, when the opportunity to seal victory presents itself. This is the real meaning of the Chinese idiom 몬to win by a surprise (more correctly, irregular) move.몭
Now, we몭re going to take another look at the story of General Han Xin winning a battle with his back to the river, but this time from the perspective of 몬the regular and the irregular.몭
In this battle, Han Xin led a comparatively tiny force of 10,000 troops to victory at Jingxing against a Zhao army that boasted 200,000 men. Before the battle, and while Han Xin was still leading his army along a narrow mountain road to Jingxing Pass, the Zhao strategist Lord Guangwu advised his commander-in-chief, Chen Yu, to divide his army. Lord Guangwu reasoned that the mountain road to Jingxing pass was so narrow and long that if Chen Yu only gave him 30,000 troops, he몭d be able to set an ambush on the road. And then, when Han Xin reached Jingxing, Chen Yu could set up a defensive position and refuse to engage, so Han Xin would be trapped. With his road of retreat cut off, and unable to resupply his army with food, he몭d be starved into submission within ten days. Lord Guangwu promised that if Chen Yu took his advice, it would only be a matter of time until Han Xin몭s head was delivered to him on a platter.
Chen Yu refused to listen. 몮I have nothing to fear from Han Xin! I have righteousness on my side, and a host of 200,000 men! I have no use for these deceitful schemes. Let him come, and then we몭ll fight!몯
Han Xin몭s intelligence agents reported Chen Yu몭s plan, and once Han Xin found out that his opponent had no interest in using Lord Guangwu몭s guaranteed-to-work scheme, he knew it was safe for him to advance along the mountain road. After the battle, Han Xin met with Lord Guangwu, and said: 몮If your lord had the sense to use your scheme, I would now be your prisoner.몯 But Han Xin was just being polite; he never would have allowed himself to be taken prisoner, because if the Zhao army had decided to use Lord Guangwu몭s plan, he wouldn몭t have come. He either would have devised a different route to victory, or decided to wait and bide his time, in honor of the principle: 몬Win first, fight later.몭 If you몭re not going to win, you shouldn몭t start a fight. Yet, his intelligence told him that Guangwu몭s plan wouldn몭t be used, so he made his move.
We know that Chen Yu didn몭t divide his forces, but did Han Xin? In fact, he did. When he몭d marched within 30 li of Jingxing Pass under the cover of night, he put together an auxiliary unit of 2,000 men and divided up different tasks.
At first light the next morning, Han Xin몭s army emerged from Jingxing Pass and arranged a force of 10,000 soldiers with their backs to the river. When the Zhao troops saw this, they laughed loudly. They몭d never seen an army lined up like this before, and it seemed obvious that they몭d be able to force their enemy into the water with a single charge. The Han troops were also aware of this possibility, and knew that, with their backs to the river and no way out, their only option was to fight to the death. This story is actually the origin of another modern Chinese idiom: 몬To fight with one몭s back to the water.몭
Han Xin had already dispatched his auxiliary forces the night before. Once his 10,000-strong main force was in position by the river, he personally led his ceremonial guard of honor out of Jingxing Pass, and set up his battle flags, drums and ceremonial weapons with much pageantry and bravado. Then, he began his performance.
We can see now that Han Xin actually divided his army into three elements: the 2,000-strong auxiliary unit he몭d dispatched the previous night; the 10,000-strong main unit now lined up by the river; and a separate unit under his personal command (the history books don몭t tell us how many men were in this unit). Now, let몭s look at the historical reality of which unit was which, in terms of 몬the regular and the irregular,몭 how they switched roles and how the battle was fought.
The Zhao army watched as Han Xin performed his pageantry act. They saw red. Success was dangling temptingly in front of them, and they knew that the quickest way to get the job done was to capture the enemy leader. So, they opened their gates and surged forth, and Han Xin몭s personal unit met their challenge head-on. The battle had begun.
At this stage, Han Xin몭s army was divided into one main force (the first to fight) and two auxiliary forces. The first part of his army to start fighting was the unit under his command, so this was the main force. The two other units 멪 one with their backs to the river, and the other hiding in some undisclosed location, having set out the night before 멪 were the two auxiliary forces.
What about the Zhao army? Was it also split into different forces? No 멪 at least, not before the battle started. Chen Yu had opted not to send a force to block Jingxing Pass, and instead massed his whole army inside his camp. But if you ask the question again, once the battle몭s started, then yes, it absolutely was divided! The part of the army that charged out from the camp became the 몬main force,몭 while the reserves that stayed behind became the 몬auxiliary force.몭 For Han Xin, the next move would be to manipulate the Zhao army into committing all of its forces to the fight, emptying the Zhao camp.
Meanwhile, a great battle was being fought between Han Xin몭s main-force unit and the Zhao army, and as it dragged on, the Zhao army몭s numerical superiority was beginning to show. Han Xin몭s men could no longer hold them back, so they began to retreat. It was not a dignified retreat; the battle flags, drums and ceremonial weapons were left scattered on the ground. But, this was actually designed to draw the enemy into attacking. Han Xin retreated back to his 10,000-strong riverside unit, which he then led in a frenzied counter-attack, knowing full well that this was to be a fight to the death.
At this stage, Han Xin몭s army was no longer configured as two auxiliary forces and one regular, but had morphed into one main force and one irregular. His personal unit had merged with the force stationed by the river, becoming the new main force. The 2,000 men who몭d snuck out of camp the night before had yet to appear, and were now waiting for the crucial moment when victory would be theirs to secure.
Han Xin now had a good chance of winning. Why was that the case? The key was in the battle flags, drums and ceremonial weapons his men had dropped on the ground in the chaos of retreating. When the Zhao troops saw this happen, they reacted in two different ways. First, they thought that victory was already theirs; they concluded that Han Xin몭s army was crumbling before their eyes and had been forced back to the river. One more push, they thought, and their enemies would be fish food. Second, Han Xin몭s ceremonial props represented the spoils of war 멪 the men who captured these items would be lavished with praise and glory, and this whetted the Zhao troops몭 appetite to be part of this moment and be recognized as heroes. They thought that victory was at hand, and that now was the time to call upon their auxiliary forces and win the day. So, the Zhao forces that had been kept back in camp were sprung into action.
The Zhao army no longer had an auxiliary force; they몭d put all their cards on the table. But it was not so for Han Xin; he still had one card left to play! This was exactly the moment he몭d been waiting for. He now had a chance to win, so it was time to call on his 2,000 remaining men, who were laying in ambush nearby. As they charged toward the empty Zhao camp, each carried a red Han flag. They had one mission: to tear down the Zhao flag, and replace it with the Han flag.
In this final stage, what kind of interchange was there between Han Xin몭s regular and auxiliary forces? The 2,000 irregular troops became the main force, because they were now on the offensive, while the part of Han Xin몭s army that was not on the offensive became the auxiliary force. With his main force attacking the enemy camp, the Zhao began to fall back, defeated. Actually, they weren몭t defeated quite yet, but they were already mentally defeated, and so they began to pull back. Once this was happening, they really were defeated. Meanwhile, the main force now held the enemy camp, and their task was to not allow the retreating enemy troops back in.
At this point, Han Xin몭s troops by the river switched roles and became his auxiliary force. The Zhao army realized something was wrong at their camp: they saw that it was full of red, their opponent몭s color. It had been lost to the enemy, and now they had to take it back and get back to their general. Meanwhile, a deafening racket of drums assaulted their ears from behind. Han Xin몭s forces were in hot pursuit, and now the Zhao army became trapped between their pursuers and the closed gate of their own camp. They몭d lost the will to fight, and the whole army collapsed. In the end, Han Xin destroyed a 200,000-strong enemy force, killed Chen Yu and captured the Zhao king.
In this battle, we몭ve seen how the concepts of 몬the regular and the irregular몭 are used. Han Xin was able to maintain separate regular and auxiliary forces through the whole battle, while the Zhao army ended up without an auxiliary force. If the Zhao leaders had kept 2,000 men in camp as reserves, Han Xin몭s 2,000-strong auxiliary force wouldn몭t have been able to get past them. But the sight of Han Xin몭s ceremonial weapons strewn on the ground was the Zhao irregulars몭 undoing. They thought that the battle was already over, and if they didn몭t hurry up and get involved in the action, they wouldn몭t get a share of the glory.


몮In all fighting, the regular may be used for joining battle, but the irregular will be needed in order to secure victory. Irregular tactics, efficiently applied, are inexhaustible as Heaven and Earth, unending as the flow of rivers and streams멞 In battle, there are not more than two methods of attack: the regular and the irregular; yet these two in combination give rise to an endless series of maneuvers. The regular and the irregular lead on to each other in turn. It is like moving in a circle 멪 you never come to an end. Who can exhaust the possibilities of their combination?몯

So, Han Xin was one of those people with the ability to 몮efficiently apply 몬the irregular몭 in ways as inexhaustible as Heaven and Earth, and as unending as the flow of rivers and streams.몯 The principles of 몬the regular and the irregular몭 are infinite; they spawn each other, and shape-shift seamlessly into each other in an endless loop, bound by no beginning and no end!
Once you understand these principles, you can understand the mechanics behind a huge number of historical battles, and you can understand how they were actually fought. Of course, having this insight isn몭t the same as actually being able to put the principles into action. Still, it does enable you to at least crack the door open and get a little inside look at the game. 



Soccer as a metaphor for understanding how 몬the regular and the irregular몭 are used: the player with the ball is the main force; the player getting in position to receive the ball is the auxiliary force

When the ball is passed, there is a transformation; the player receiving the ball becomes the main force, while the player who passed it becomes the auxiliary force. The soccer field is a battlefield by another name. In fact, everywhere is a battlefield, and every minute, every second, there is constant transformation between the regular and the irregular. The changes between the regular and the irregular truly are endless.

Extract from the original text:
몮To ensure that your whole host may withstand the brunt of the enemy몭s attack and remain unshaken 멪 this is effected by maneuvers regular and irregular. That the impact of your army may be like a grindstone dashed against an egg 멪 this is effected by the science of weak points and strong.
몮In all fighting, the regular may be used for joining battle, but the irregular will be needed in order to secure victory. Irregular tactics, efficiently applied, are inexhaustible as Heaven and Earth, unending as the flow of rivers and streams; like the sun and moon, they end but to begin anew; like the four seasons, they pass away to return once more. There are not more than five musical notes, yet the combinations of these five give rise to more melodies than can ever be heard. There are not more than five primary colors, yet in combination they produce more hues than can ever be seen. There are not more than five cardinal tastes, yet combinations of them yield more flavors than can ever be tasted. In battle, there are not more than two methods of attack: the regular and the irregular; yet these two in combination give rise to an endless series of maneuvers. The regular and the irregular lead on to each other in turn. It is like moving in a circle 멪 you never come to an end. Who can exhaust the possibilities of their combination?몯

Analysis:
Let몭s go a bit deeper and break down the shifts between regular and irregular in Han Xin몭s victory against Zhao. Before the battle started, Han Xin had set up his army in one main force and two auxiliary forces. He personally commanded the main force, with one of the two auxiliary forces lined up with their backs to the river, and the other, consisting of 2,000 cavalry, laying in ambush.
As the battle unfolded, Han Xin몭s army switched three times between regular and irregular.
The first switch happened when the original main force feigned retreat, moving toward the auxiliary unit positioned by the river and merging with it. The newly combined Han force then engaged the enemy, making it the new main force.
The second switch was when the Zhao forces attacked with all the troops they had, emptying their camp in the process. Then, Han Xin몭s auxiliary force of 2,000 cavalry charged into the deserted enemy camp and switched the flags, effectively becoming the new main force. Shortly after, the enemy gave up the fight with the Han men by the river, turned back and tried to retake their camp. At this point, the large riverside force under Han Xin몭s personal command suddenly switched roles and became the auxiliary force. In other words, they were no longer part of the main battle. All of this constitutes one switch between main and auxiliary.
The third switch happened when the enemy troops were falling back in a panic, their chain of command having fallen apart. For Han Xin, the moment to seize victory had arrived. He mobilized what was now his auxiliary force and pounced on the retreating enemy, finally sealing his victory.
So, now we can see that the main and auxiliary forces aren몭t drawn up neatly and settled ahead of time. Instead, they몭re subject to change at any moment as they cycle through an infinite loop, always complementing one another.
Han Xin몭s great victory has served as an example of how an army is divided up into main and auxiliary forces, but these concepts don몭t only apply on the level of entire armies. There are also main and auxiliary forces at play on a much smaller level, like between individual squads and companies. In fact, every unit involved in a battle is wrapped up in 몬the regular and the irregular.몭 From a micro perspective, 몬the regular and the irregular몭 are the building blocks of battle tactics. They몭re why armies don몭t swarm forward like a hive of angry, disorganized bees, but instead work in regimented coordination, operating according to strict timing. This is the real reason why Sun Tzu said that the changes between 몬the regular and the irregular몭 are truly infinite: you could never run out of new combinations.
몬The regular and the irregular몭 are not only used by large armies. When Xiang Yu found himself making his last stand at the River Wu, with only 28 cavalry troops still by his side, he didn몭t charge the enemy in a single mass. He only had 28 men, but he still split them into two groups 멪 one main and one auxiliary 멪 that fought in tandem. In war, 몬the regular and the irregular몭 is truly a fundamental principle.
We can get a good understanding of how 몬the regular and the irregular몭 are used by looking at a soccer match as an example. Whichever player has possession of the ball is 몬the main force,몭 and any player who몭s making a run without the ball, in an effort to get in a good position, is an 몬auxiliary force.몭 Whenever the ball is passed, the roles switch. Whoever receives the ball becomes the main force, while the player who has just passed becomes an auxiliary force. If 몬the main force몭 attacks up the sideline and sees a gap in the opposition midfield, there몭s a chance to seize victory. The 몬main force몭 kicks the ball into the penalty box, passing the baton to their teammate, who receives the ball and, taking the opposition by surprise, attacks where they are unprotected. This unleashes the auxiliary in the same moment that they switch roles and become the 몬main force.몭 They shoot for victory, and the ball goes in the back of the net! 
The soccer pitch is no different than a battlefield. In fact, as we몭ve said, everywhere is a battlefield, and 몬the regular and the irregular몭 are everywhere, switching back and forth constantly, every second of the day. 

몮The regular and the irregular lead on to each other in turn. It is like moving in a circle 멪 you never come to an end. Who can exhaust the possibilities of their combination?몯

So, when we study battle tactics, it몭s as if we몭re studying soccer. In soccer, don몭t make the mistake of believing that 몬winning by surprise몭 means that if you make a fancy, surprise move, you몭re guaranteed to win. In reality, there몭s no such thing as a 몬surprise move.몭 There are only a handful of 몬moves몭 out there, and everyone already knows them. The problem is that nobody has the ability to actually use them. All soccer formations basically come under the umbrella of 5-3-2, 4-3-3, 4-4-2, the 몬bus몭 (9-0-1), and, if you몭re losing and angry about it, 1-0-9멞 and if you몭re losing and angry about it and only have 30 seconds left in the game, 0-0-10. In battles, tactics basically boil down to either a balance between attacking and defending, or deploying in a flank-center-flank formation. But these are not what몭s most important. What몭s really crucial is how strong the coach몭s leadership abilities are, his strategic thinking abilities and tactical acumen, and the players몭 physical conditioning, skills, experience, training and cleverness. If you don몭t get these basics right, how is a 몬surprise move몭 going to help you win?
There are only 11 players in a soccer team, but the 몬regular and irregular몭 remain infinitely variable. After all, Xiang Yu divided his troops into main and auxiliary forces even when he only had 28 men left. Small and big armies alike divide into main and auxiliary forces, unless they want to lose. Even an army of a million soldiers can lose if it몭s not divided properly.
Now, let몭s look at one more example from Chinese military history: The Battle of Fei River.
The Emperor of Former Qin, Fu Jian, marching at the head of a massive army of 800,000 to attack the state of Jin, lined his troops up in battle formation by Fei River. Meanwhile, his enemy, the Jin commander, Xie Xuan, had only 80,000 men. Xie Xuan sent a messenger to Fu Jian, to tell him to line his troops up by the river and make a little space by moving back, and that Xie Xuan would then cross the river with his army so they could get the fighting started. This way, they could get it over with as quickly as possible.
Fu Jian agreed to Xie Xuan몭s request, and ordered the front part of his army to move back. But the rear part of his army didn몭t know what was going on; they thought their comrades up front had been beaten, so they panicked and began to run away. Xie Xuan crossed the river, and delivered a crippling blow to the already limp Former Qin army.
Where did Fu Jian go wrong?
People generally attribute Fu Jian몭s error up to colossal stupidity on his part. What sane person would listen when their enemy tells them to retreat?
But in reality, of course, Fu Jian wasn몭t that stupid. He몭d made his own calculations, and he몭d talked things through with his brother and advisor, Fu Rong. His plan was to pretend to agree to Xie Xuan몭s request, back up a little, and let him cross the river. But, instead of waiting for Xie Xuan몭s men to safely cross, he was going to send in his armored horsemen to attack while only half of their forces had crossed. He wanted to wipe them out before they ever got a chance to reach the far shore.
On the face of it, this is a textbook strategy, completely watertight.
So, what went wrong? Fu Jian몭s mistake was that he didn몭t split up his army into main and auxiliary forces. Retreating wouldn몭t have been a problem if he had left an auxiliary force in the wings. Then, if anything went wrong with the main force, or if Xie Xuan somehow made it to the shore and went on the attack, the auxiliary force would be able to deal him a direct hit, and he wouldn몭t have had any advantage.
But Fu Jian was far too careless. He didn몭t really take Xie Xuan seriously. He thought that it몭d be enough to just back up a little, get Xie Xuan to cross the water as quickly as possible, trap him in the middle of the river and finish him. He didn몭t see any need to set up main and auxiliary forces.
On the other hand, Xie Xuan did have an auxiliary force, led by Zhu Xu, who had originally been an Eastern Jin general and had fought against the Former Qin. But he lost a battle, was captured, and formally surrendered to Fu Jian. Fu Jian then put him to work in his own army, making him a Former Qin general. This was the main reason behind Fu Jian몭s eventual doom. It was in his nature not to be suspicious of the people working for him, and even if he did have suspicions about a person, he몭d still put them to work for him. Half of those he몭d put in charge of his troops were like Zhu Xu: people with very different intentions than his own.
Before the Battle of Fei River, Fu Jian sent Zhu Xu to try to persuade the Eastern Jin leader Xie Shi to surrender. This was Zhu Xu몭s big chance. When he met with Xie Shi, he told him that although it was claimed that the Former Qin army numbered 800,000 men, not all of them had yet been assembled. If the Eastern Jin forces attacked quickly and routed the Former Qin vanguard, they몭d have a chance to defeat Fu Jian. It was because of this information from Zhu Xu that Xie Shi and Xie Xuan decided to make their move so quickly.
When Fu Jian waved the flag signaling for his men to retreat, the units in the rear didn몭t know what was happening. This was the result of the work done by Xie Xuan몭s 몬auxiliary force,몭 Zhu Xu. The clever Zhu Xu had loudly shouted: 몮The Qin army is defeated! We몭re finished!몯 At this point, the battle hadn몭t even started, but when the Qin soldiers saw the men in front of them falling back, and heard people behind them shouting that they몭d been beaten, they panicked and ran for their lives. The Jin army crossed the river. Fu Rong jumped on his horse and galloped over to the retreating Qin forces, trying to stop them, but luck wasn몭t on his side. His horse tripped, and he was flung to the ground and killed by Jin soldiers. Then, the Qin army really did collapse.
So it goes with the changes between the 몬regular and the irregular.몭
There몭s one more line in this passage that we haven몭t looked at yet: 몮That the impact of your army may be like a grindstone dashed against an egg this 멪 is effected by the science of weak points and strong.몯 The next chapter in Sun-Tzu몭s The Art of War is dedicated to 몬Weakness and Strength,몭 so we몭ll pick this thread up again later.



Simplify your movements before you act; action should be a rapid release

Extract from the original text:
몮The onset of troops is like the rush of a torrent which will even roll stones along in its course. The quality of decision is like the well-timed swoop of a falcon, which enables it to strike and destroy its victim. Therefore the good fighter will be terrible in his onset, and prompt in his decision. Energy may be likened to the bending of a crossbow; decision, to the releasing of a trigger.몯

Analysis:
Swiftly flowing rivers can wash away boulders, because they harness the energy of water. Birds of prey can fly and dive with incredible speed and ferocity, because they have mastered timing with relation to both the moment of action and distance. In the same way, when people who have mastered the use of armed force to win wars attack, they do so with speed and ferocity. When the time comes to act, their movements come in short, sudden bursts. An army at its most lethal is like a crossbow wound tight and quivering under enormous tension. A military force몭s quick, sudden action is like pulling the trigger.
The key part of this passage is: 몮The good fighter will be terrible in his onset, and prompt in his decision.몯 There are two concepts here, and the most important one to grasp is the latter: 몬being prompt in decision.몭 In this instance, 몬prompt몭 doesn몭t only mean being quick about doing something, but also minimizing the distance that has to be crossed when you act.
Another way of interpreting 몬being terrible in onset몭 is the idea of maximizing potential energy, and then rapidly releasing that energy over the shortest time and distance possible. This is how to deliver a high-precision strike on your target while also maximizing your attack몭s deadly force. 
More than any of the other commentaries on this passage, Li Quan몭s cuts straight to the essence: 몮When one fires an arrow, if your shot lacks force and speed, then the arrow will not travel far. If you shoot it over a great distance, you will not hit your target.몯
Despite the stories we may have heard as children, it몭s simply not true that the best bowmen reach mastery of their craft by splitting sticks in two from 100 paces! The principles of the art of war tell you not to set your sights on achieving such impressive feats. Instead, you몭re advised to shoot at a wicker basket from ten paces 멪 then, you몭re guaranteed to both hit your target and do so with enough force to pierce it. Another excellent analogy comes from the animal kingdom: When mother cheetahs teach their cubs how to hunt antelopes, the cubs learn that they can몭t start their chase from 100 paces. Instead, they learn to silently slink their way to within 50 paces of their target, before exploding into motion out of the cover of the high grass. The most important lesson is that they have to hit their prey immediately. If they don몭t, and the antelope starts running, there몭s no guarantee they몭ll be able to catch it.
Now is a good time to look back at a line from earlier on in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몮What the ancients called a clever fighter is one who not only wins, but excels in winning easy battles. Hence, his victories bring him neither reputation for wisdom nor credit for courage.몯 It몭s the same principle with bowmen: true masters aren몭t renowned for being able to skewer tiny targets from a great distance. Rather, the way they work is by sneaking up right under their targets몭 noses, and then shooting from point-blank range. People who aren몭t in the know might say that there몭s nothing difficult about that. These are the same people who say of a famous modern-day Chinese entrepreneur, 몬So what if Shi Yuzhu ran 300 million-yuan advertisements for his 몬brain platinum몭 product? That doesn몭t mean he몭s good at what he does! If you gave me 300 million-yuan ad spots, I몭d do a much better job!몭 The question they forget to ask is: 몬How did he get those 300 million-yuan ad spots?몭 Do people think they just fell from the sky, straight into his hands? Anyway, even if you were given those spots, would you actually know what to do with them?
몬Being terrible in onset몭 and 몬Being prompt in decisions몭 are fundamental principles, to be incorporated whenever we design any kind of work project. That몭s because, even if you plan ahead as though your life depends on it, and no matter how meticulous you몭ve been, when the time comes to act, things generally aren몭t that simple. Very rarely are ideas as effective in execution as you imagined during the planning stage. The worst-case scenario is, if you몭re working on a one-year plan, for example, sitting through a two-hour meeting, and at the end you still haven몭t gotten through everything you need to discuss. So, you decide to 몬leave it for now.몭 If you keep on 몬leaving it,몭 then just as an orchestra falls to pieces if a single musician doesn몭t show up, something is sure to go wrong later on, when you몭re trying to fit together different pieces of a complicated plan.
The right way to do it is to be like the bowman who winds his crossbow tight, sneaks up under his victim몭s nose and looses a single, deadly shot.
In war, you should win with a single battle; when firing a bow, you should hit your target with a single shot. Your preparation work is all about focusing on how to deliver that single blow, storing up the energy you몭ll need to strike, sharpening your single arrowhead, and choosing the time and place for your strike. It몭s not about shooting a lot of arrows; don몭t be sloppy. If you prepare properly 멪 and are 몬terrible in onset몭 and 몬prompt in decisions몭 멪 you몭re guaranteed to hit your target. On top of that, you몭ll only need one arrow. If you do decide to take the other, sloppier route 멪 assembling a whole bunch of bowmen to shoot a whole bunch of arrows 멪 not only will you not hit your target, but each of those men and each of those arrows will need to be paid for, both in money and energy.
This principle is a thread that weaves through the whole text of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War.



Courage and fear aren몭t about individual people; they몭re about energy

Extract from the original text:
몮Amid the turbulence and tumult of battle, there may be seeming disorder and yet no real disorder at all; amid confusion and chaos, your soldiers move in circles, yet they cannot be defeated. Disorder comes from order, fear comes from courage; weakness comes from strength. Order or disorder? This is a question of subdivision. Courage or fearfulness? This is a question of latent energy. Strength or weakness? This is a question of tactical dispositions. Thus one who is skillful at keeping the enemy on the move maintains deceitful appearances, according to which the enemy will act. He sacrifices something, that the enemy may snatch at it. By holding out baits, he moves him where he wills; then with a body of picked men he lies in wait for him.몯

Analysis:
몮Amid the turbulence and tumult of battle, there may be seeming disorder and yet no real disorder at all; amid confusion and chaos, your soldiers move in circles, yet they cannot be defeated.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮The banners swirl chaotically, but this is to give the appearance of disorder to the enemy; then, drums and gongs unify the army. The war chariots and cavalry move in circular formation, and their movements are patterned and ordered.몯 What Cao Cao is talking about here is manipulating the enemy, making them think that you몭re unorganized, weak and fearful. But, in reality, you몭re well ordered, strong and brave.
몬Turbulence몭 refers to a specific image 멪 battle flags flying around chaotically, never staying in place. 몬Tumult몭 refers to soldiers moving back and forth, apparently at random, while in reality they몭re bound together by tight discipline and a clear awareness of their duties, each with their own assigned role, able to be disruptive while being immune to disruption.
There몭s another layer of meaning beneath the surface of Cao Cao몭s words: 몮The banners swirl chaotically, but this is to give the appearance of disorder to the enemy; then, drums and gongs unify the army.몯 The banners swirling around in chaos are just a show put on for the benefit of the enemy commander standing far away. Meanwhile, drums and gongs quietly serve as the army몭s actual system for communicating commands, safely out of earshot of the enemy.
Wang Xi comments: 몮The commander desires inner clarity and outer darkness; inner control and outer chaos. So, he performs a show for the enemy, so that he might be underestimated.몯 In brief, the name of the game is tricking the enemy.
몮Amid confusion and chaos, your soldiers move in circles, yet they cannot be defeated.몯 Here, we몭re talking about troop deployment.
Du You explains in his commentary that the original word that몭s been translated as 몬confusion몭 actually refers to the turning of chariot wheels, while 몬chaos몭 refers to the pounding of galloping horses몭 hooves. 몮His troops move freely and unhindered, deployed in a circular pattern rather than a rectangular one, each troop with its own role.몯 
How can a circular formation make an army unbeatable? Du Mu cites an explanation offered by the ancient text, Writings on Grasping the Irregular, also known as The Yellow Emperor몭s Art of War. 몮Four parts constitute the main, four parts the auxiliary, and the surplus shall be the 몬fist.몭 First, send out a mobile battle unit to set the edges.몯
Expanding on this, Du Mu wrote: 몮The army consists of nine parts: the ninth part, the surplus, stays within the general몭s grasp and does not move. Thus, the general maintains all other units.몯 
This means that if an army has nine parts, four parts make up the main force that몭s used to launch the first attack; another four parts make up the auxiliary force that forms the army몭s reserves and is deployed at the vital moment in order to seal victory; and the left-over ninth part is known as the 몬fist.몭 This is the part that stays in a fixed position with the general, tightly within his grasp.
In a later part of The Art of War, Sun Tzu talks about being as 몬immovable as a mountain몭 멪 the commander-in-chief cannot move. If he moves forward, it몭s because the battle has already been won and the fighting is over. If he moves backward, it몭s because his army has suffered a total collapse. So, even if your enemy몭s troops cut their way through to your position, you can몭t move. That kind of situation is what the 몬fist몭 unit is for; it몭s there to keep enemy troops away from the commander. If the commander moves even slightly, or if his flag falls, his army몭s morale will evaporate and his men will run for their lives.
Of course, there are some situations where running away is necessary.
몮First, send out a mobile battle unit to set the edges.몯 This means that when organizing and deploying your battle units, you need to deploy one to clearly demarcate where each of the others is to be deployed. The mobile unit does this by taking each unit몭s unique flag and planting it in the right position. Then, the personnel of each unit assemble by their unit몭s flag.
몮Four parts constitute the main, four parts the auxiliary.몯 This line is a reference to the legendary 몬stone sentinel maze.몭 Contrary to popular belief, the stone sentinel maze wasn몭t invented by Zhuge Liang, but was in fact much earlier 멪 4,500 years ago, by the Yellow Emperor and his general, Feng Hou. It is also known as Feng Hou몭s Eight Formation Diagram. Similarly, Writings on Grasping the Irregular is also known as Feng Hou몭s Writings on Grasping the Irregular. Sun Tzu몭s philosophy and insights represent a continuation of Feng Hou몭s work, as do Zhuge Liang몭s version of the stone sentinel maze. Even the Tang dynasty Emperor Taizong몭s ambitious work of drama, Music of Prince Qin Breaking through the Enemy Array, was based on Feng Hou몭s Eight Formation Diagram.

몮Disorder comes from order, fear comes from courage; weakness comes from strength.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮These forms all convey destruction, but conceal the true situation.몯 So, disorder, fear and weakness are all just a pretense, a show put on for the enemy몭s benefit, and a way of hiding the real condition of your army.
Show the enemy disorder where in reality there is order; show fear where there is courage, and weakness where there is strength. The reason why 몬disorder comes from order몭 is that you must manage your army with both transparency and tight discipline if you몭re going to have any chance of effectively producing an illusion of chaos on the surface while still maintaining perfect order. The reason why 몬fear comes from courage몭 is that it takes extraordinary courage to act scared enough to suck the enemy in. Finally, the reason why 몬weakness comes from strength몭 is that you need your army to be exceptionally strong before you can feel confident enough to make a show of weakness and lure the enemy into launching an all-out attack on you.
The above forms the logic for the next passage: 몮Order or disorder? This is a question of subdivision. Courage or fearfulness? This is a question of latent energy. Strength or weakness? This is a question of tactical dispositions.몯
We몭ve already talked about the idea of 몬subdivision,몭 which appeared in the first line of Energy: 몮The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers.몯 The idea is that an organization몭s structure is built by properly dividing human resources into well-ordered units.
What determines whether your men feel scared or brave? Basically, the answer is energy. It몭s about knowing how to draw a group of people around you and inspire them to fight. But, if you take a group of people to war who haven몭t gone through military training, how do you make them brave? Bravery comes when you put them in a place of deadly peril 멪 a place where, if they don몭t fight, they몭ll die. When people are put in this situation, they instantly turn into death-defying berserkers. That몭s exactly what Han Xin did when he put his troops in a position where they had to fight with their backs to a river. So, bravery or lack of bravery really isn몭t about people몭s personalities; it몭s about the broader idea of 몬energy.몭
Strength and weakness are about how you present yourself. When Liu Bang sent an envoy to the Xiongnu Chieftain, the shrewd Modun made sure the envoy only saw the old and weak of his camp, the sick and disabled, men and horses both. Liu Bang fell for Modun몭s trick, and as a result his 300,000-strong expeditionary force was surrounded at Baideng, and Liu Bang very nearly didn몭t make it back home.
The passage몭s final couple of lines give a summary: 몮Thus one who is skillful at keeping the enemy on the move maintains deceitful appearances, according to which the enemy will act. He sacrifices something that the enemy may snatch at it. By holding out baits, he moves him where he wills; then with a body of picked men he lies in wait for him.몯
So, commanders who are skilled at manipulating their foes are able to move them exactly where they want them, no matter what impression of their own forces they engineer and present to the enemy. If they give the enemy a little incentive, the enemy is bound to come after it. Then, once the enemy has been lured in, they unleash their true military strength and meet the enemy with force.








To appoint the right people, use three energies: Qi (Air) energy, Earth energy and Adaptive energy

Extract from the original text:
몮The clever combatant looks to the effect of energy, and does not require too much from individuals. Hence his ability to pick out the right men and utilize energy. When he utilizes energy, his fighting men become as it were like unto rolling logs or stones. For it is the nature of a log or stone to remain motionless on level ground, and to move when on a slope; if four-cornered, to come to a standstill; but if round-shaped, to go rolling down. Thus the energy developed by good fighting men is as the momentum of a round stone rolled down a mountain thousands of feet in height. This is energy.몯

Analysis:
몮The clever combatant looks to the effect of combined energy, and does not require too much from individuals. Hence his ability to pick out the right men and utilize combined energy.몯
According to a common saying, the energy of a situation is a much stronger force than individual people. The balance between victory and defeat lies in how energy is created. This is a question for commanders-in-chief to ponder, not something that can be passed off to subordinates. If something isn몭t done right, you can몭t just blame the people below you, or claim that the problem is that they didn몭t carry out the plan as they were supposed to. You can몭t pressure subordinates to get things done by themselves, because the real problem is that you didn몭t do a good enough job laying the groundwork. Even if the people working for you aren몭t up to scratch, that몭s still your problem, because you didn몭t choose the right people.
This is why exceptional leaders focus on energy, and don몭t blame the people working for them. They have the ability to create the right energy, and to choose the right personnel.
