Du Mu comments: 몮Skilled commanders first weigh the energy of their army, then weigh the ability of their men and assign appointments according to their strengths and weaknesses. They do not flagellate subordinates by attacking their personal lack of worthiness.몯
It몭s essentially about using the right people in the right places. If the wrong people are used in the wrong places, the only person at fault is the leader.
A good example of these principles is the story of Cao Cao몭s 몬stratagem in a sealed envelope.몭
When Cao Cao led an army to Hanzhong to fight against Zhang Yu, he left three commanders 멪 Zhang Liao, Li Dian and Le Jin 멪 behind to guard the city of Hefei with a garrison force of a little over 7,000 men. Just before Cao Cao left, he gave a sealed letter to Military Protector Xue Ti, with instructions to open it in the event of an enemy attack.
Not long after Cao Cao몭s departure, the Eastern Wu Emperor, Sun Quan, marched toward Hefei at the head of a 100,000-strong invasion force. Cao Cao몭s four generals took out the letter and tore it open. It read: 몮If Sun Quan comes, Generals Zhang and Li are to lead men out into the field to fight him. General Le is to remain in Hefei and guard the city, and the Military Protector also must not go out to fight.몯 Three of the generals were perplexed, but Zhang Liao understood what Cao Cao meant, and explained: 몮Prime Minister Cao is away fighting. If we wait for him to come to our aid, our city will lie in ruins long before he arrives. Prime Minister Cao is telling us to take advantage of the fact that Sun Quan몭s military energy is not yet fully established. We must make a quick, brief strike so as to cut away his aura of power. Then, we shall be able to successfully defend the city. If we get this right, everything will go well. But if we don몭t, the only outcome for us will be defeat.몯
There was no delay. Li Dian and Zhang Liao, both of whom were ferocious warriors, attacked Sun Quan before his forces had a chance to get settled. Sure enough, they inflicted a shocking defeat on the Wu Emperor. The Wu army had been banking on its aura of power, but now that was gone. When Zhang and Li returned to the city, the garrison was in high spirits and feeling very secure in their position. Sun Quan had been slapped in the face, and although he re-gathered his forces and attacked the city, after ten days he still hadn몭t made any gains. So, he decided to withdraw.
The historian Sun Sheng commented: 몮War is 몬The Way of Deception.몭 Hefei was successfully defended by a stranded army, with no reinforcements coming to their aid. If the city had been left in the hands of lion-hearted warriors, their fondness for fighting would have led to disaster. On the other hand, if the defense had been left entirely to cowards, then their fear would have made it difficult to stand firm. But because the enemy몭s soldiers were far more numerous than the defenders몭, the enemy was bound to be vulnerable to apathy. So, fearless commanders were sent out to strike the ill-prepared enemy, and their powerful energy ensured that they would win. First winning a victory and then returning to the defensive is a sure way to stand strong against attack! Hence, the reason why Cao Cao chose commanders with diverse temperaments 멪 because this enabled his forces to respond to a changing situation, and ultimately everything proceeded as he had so presciently calculated.몯
During the reign of the Tang dynasty Emperor Taizong, his advisor and high-ranking general, Duke Li, stated that armies have three energies: qi (air) energy; earth energy; and adaptive[bd17] energy.
Qi energy is, above all, about personal inner power. When you have it, other people will believe that you are powerful.
Duke Li said: 몮The general pours scorn upon the enemy, the troops delight in fighting, one몭s aspirations tower up into the sky, and one몭s qi becomes as powerful as a whirlwind; this is what is meant by qi energy.몯 Duke Li is saying that you should strategically show contempt for your enemy, while still taking him very seriously in terms of planning the details of battle tactics. If you do this, he asserts, you will create a powerful aura, and this aura will turn into true power, as real as a raging mountain river.
We have all experienced, whether in our work or in negotiations, the crucial importance of qi energy. It is the essence of authority. If a person immediately backs away three yards when they first see you, you have a three-yard advantage before you몭ve even started. We sometimes see celebrities leveraging their star status to get away with acting in outrageous ways, and people let them get away with it because they feel they have to submit to celebrities몭 qi energy. Mark Twain몭s short story, The Million Pound Bank Note, is about how possessing a million-pound note enables you to eat, drink and live for free. This, too, is qi energy at work.
Qi energy isn몭t all empty air. It몭s very real, and that몭s because it몭s actually the product of accumulated strength. You can몭t effectively pretend to be strong when you몭re not. For example, the reason Twain몭s million-pound bank note had such power was because it was real. It could never have had the same effect if it was fake. Every successful figure has a sense of how their own qi energy changes as their success grows. It truly isn몭t an empty notion 멪 the more social recognition you get, the stronger your qi energy grows; everything starts to go your way, and you become virtually invincible.
Qi power requires a solid foundation of actual, real strength. This is vital. Next, it requires other people to be convinced that you have it; they have to be overwhelmed by your qi power. Otherwise, you몭ll have to fight them head-to-head.
Moving on, what is 몬earth energy?몭 Duke Li writes: 몮A small path through a narrow mountain pass, so narrow that a single soldier could hold it against a thousand, stopping them from passing. This is 몬earth energy.몭몯 Hence the Chinese saying used to describe the most ideal circumstances possible: 몬When the Heavenly timing is good, when the land is favourable, and when the people are in harmony.몭 In that way, 몬earth energy몭 is about controlling all of the best terrain 멪 having this advantage is like holding all the aces in a game of cards. No matter how talented your opponent is, they just won몭t be able to compete with you. So, how do you make sure the aces end up in your hand? You have to take them before anyone else realizes how valuable they are. The land, or 몬earth,몭 that you want has always been there, waiting, just like the aces have always been waiting in the deck of cards. They belong to whoever claims them. The key is to know which cards are the aces. A good example is when Zhuge Liang lost control of the Jieting region. Jieting was an ace card; it embodied 몬earth energy.몭 Whoever held Jieting also possessed earth energy. Without it, their earth energy dissipates.
Once Zhuge Liang lost his earth energy, no amount of fighting would do him any good. Retreat was his only option.
The third type of energy is 몬adaptive energy.몭 This is about adapting to the enemy몭s situation and energy, and taking advantage of the situation in front of you. Duke Li writes: 몮Adaptive energy is when the enemy is lax, when his soldiers are hungry and thirsty, his vanguard forces have not yet made camp, and when his rear forces are halfway through a river crossing.몯 We몭ve already talked about the story of Cao Cao몭s 몬stratagem in a sealed envelope.몭 This plan worked because he knew that Sun Quan commanded massive numerical superiority, and that there was a potential advantage for him in this. When a large army on the march reaches its destination, the natural thing for its commander to do is to wait until all of his troops are fully assembled and settled before launching an attack. This is exactly the situation Sun Quan was in: his 몬vanguard forces had not yet made camp몭 and 몬his rear forces were halfway through a river crossing.몭 Cao Cao knew how to take advantage of the situation. His forces delivered a stinging blow straight to Sun Quan몭s face, immediately puncturing his opponent몭s momentum, deflating his aura of power, and at the same time strengthening their own aura. So, adaptive energy is about being fluid and finding gaps to exploit; it몭s about opening and closing, manipulating the enemy, and being prepared to strike hard whenever the enemy몭s changing situation allows.

몮When he utilizes energy, his fighting men become as it were like unto rolling logs or stones. For it is the nature of a log or stone to remain motionless on level ground, and to move when on a slope; if four-cornered, to come to a standstill, but if round-shaped, to go rolling down.몯

Cao Cao comments that 몬utilizing energy몭 is about 몬utilizing natural energy몭 멪 moving with the natural flow. To do this, you first have to shape and design the 몭natural conditions.몭 This means putting the right people in the right places. If you can do that, everything will go your way, organically and naturally.
Think of people as logs and stones: heir shapes and natures are unchanging, so if you put them in a place of safety, they will be safe. If you put them in a place of danger, they will be in danger and unable to get out of danger몭s way, because they are inert and cannot move under their own power.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Logs and stones are heavy objects, but though it is difficult to shift them with force, it is easy to move them with energy.몯 If you try to move a tree trunk or a boulder just using brute force, you몭ll find you can몭t make them budge even an inch. However, if you place them on top of a mountain, then by using the mountain몭s energy rather than muscle-power, a light nudge can send them crashing down with incredible power.
What about armies? 몮No matter how large an army is, it can fight through the use of energy, but it cannot be maneuvered using brute force. This is The Way of Nature.몯
When Han Xin led his force of 10,000 against an enemy army numbering 200,000, every single one of his troops fought like untethered wild men. They did so because Han Xin exploited energy rather than putting responsibility on his men몭s shoulders. That energy came from the fact that the only way out of fighting was to jump into a watery grave at the bottom of a river. The troops몭 only option was to fight for their lives.
In the Battle of Fei River, Fu Jian commanded a truly colossal army against his enemy몭s 80,000. Yet, despite having a policy of executing runaways, he was powerless to stop his troops from fleeing the battlefield. This is because the circumstantial energy was different: his men had an escape route available to them, and they took it. As for the officers, who were supposed to be executing the runaways, they had their hands full dealing with the onslaught of enemy troops.
There몭s a reason why when generals surround a city in a siege, they often leave one side open so that the enemy troops have somewhere to run. It몭s about managing the energy, and making sure that you don몭t put the enemy in a position where they have to fight for their lives. It몭s much easier to annihilate an enemy army if you can force them to run for their lives and attack them as they flee. This way, you can also avoid fighting a costly battle in which you might lose 800 of your own men for every 1,000 enemy soldiers you kill. To really put the cherry on the cake, you can position an irregular force somewhere along the enemy몭s escape route, ready to ambush them as they flee.

몮Thus the energy developed by good fighting men is as the momentum of a round stone rolled down a mountain thousands of feet in height. This is energy.몯

Sun Tzu finishes off his fifth chapter, Energy, with a short conclusion. He summarizes the meaning of energy: when a round stone is rolled down a mountain thousands of feet in height, who can stand in its way?
몬Potential energy몭 is a term we몭ve all come across in physics class. It몭s expressed in the formula mgh (mass x acceleration due to gravity x height).
The potential energy of a round stone on top of a mountain is equivalent to its weight multiplied by the height of the mountain. When the stone begins to roll down the mountainside, its potential energy is converted into kinetic energy, which is calculated with the formula 1/2mv2  (the square of mass x speed/2).
The higher the mountain, the faster the speed of the stone. Nobody can stop it once it몭s rolling.
Du Mu comments: 몮A stone rolling down a high mountain cannot be stopped; this is not because of the stone, but because of the mountain. When soldiers have the courage to win a hundred battles, the question of whether they are strong or weak is not decided by themselves, but by energy.몯  Basically, it몭s all about where you position things. 
In Wang Xi몭s commentary, he writes that stones are incapable of rolling by themselves; what makes them unstoppable is the energy of the mountain. Similarly, in war you can몭t force victory, because military energy is not something that can be strong-armed into existence.
So, what makes a skillful leader is their ability to exploit energy, not people. Once they몭ve exploited energy, then they appoint the right people to the right positions.


Appendix: Complete text of Energy

Su Tzu said: 몮The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers. Fighting with a large army under your command is no different from fighting with a small one: it is merely a question of instituting signs and signals. To ensure that your whole host may withstand the brunt of the enemy몭s attack and remain unshaken 멪 this is affected by maneuvers regular and irregular. That the impact of your army may be like a grindstone dashed against an egg 멪 this is effected by the science of weak points and strong. In all fighting, the regular may be used for joining battle, but the irregular will be needed in order to secure victory. Irregular tactics, efficiently applied, are inexhaustible as Heaven and Earth, unending as the flow of rivers and streams; like the sun and moon, they end but to begin anew; like the four seasons, they pass away to return once more. There are not more than five musical notes, yet the combinations of these five give rise to more melodies than can ever be heard. There are not more than five primary colors, yet in combination they produce more hues than can ever been seen. There are not more than five cardinal tastes, yet combinations of them yield more flavors than can ever be tasted. In battle, there are not more than two methods of attack: the regular and the irregular; yet these two in combination give rise to an endless series of maneuvers. The regular and the irregular lead on to each other in turn. It is like moving in a circle 멪 you never come to an end. Who can exhaust the possibilities of their combination? The onset of troops is like the rush of a torrent, which will even roll stones along in its course. The quality of decision is like the well-timed swoop of a falcon, which enables it to strike and destroy its victim. Therefore the good fighter will be terrible in his onset, and prompt in his decision. Energy may be likened to the bending of a crossbow; decision, to the releasing of a trigger. Amid the turbulence and tumult of battle, there may be seeming disorder and yet no real disorder at all; amid confusion and chaos, your soldiers move in circles, yet they cannot be defeated. Disorder comes from order, fear comes from courage; weakness comes from strength. Order or disorder? This is a question of subdivision; Courage or fearfulness? This is a question of latent energy; Strength or weakness? This is a question of tactical dispositions. Thus one who is skillful at keeping the enemy on the move maintains deceitful appearances, according to which the enemy will act. He sacrifices something that the enemy may snatch at it. By holding out baits, he moves him where he wills; then with a body of picked men he lies in wait for him. The clever combatant looks to the effect of energy, and does not require too much from individuals. Hence his ability to pick out the right men and utilize energy. When he utilizes energy, his fighting men become as it were like unto rolling logs or stones. For it is the nature of a log or stone to remain motionless on level ground, and to move when on a slope; if four-cornered, to come to a standstill, but if round-shaped, to go rolling down. Thus the energy developed by good fighting men is as the momentum of a round stone rolled down a mountain thousands of feet in height. This is energy.몯


Chapter Six: Weak points and strong

The enemy has weak and strong points, and so do you

Don몭t try to 몬fix몭 your weak points. Instead, learn how to fight as you are 멪 weaknesses, strengths and all. Learn to not try to fix all of your problems, but to keep moving forward, even in the midst of those problems. When you learn how to do this, you will have mastered the essence of 몬weak points and strong.몭

Extract from the original text:
몮Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will be exhausted.몯

Analysis:
Let몭s start by talking about what 몬weak points and strong몭 are. Du Mu comments: 몮In war, generals invariably seek to avoid the enemy몭s strong points and strike his weak points. The first thing a general must do is to decipher the weak and strong points, both of the enemy and of their own forces.몯
No matter how thoroughly you prepare your defenses, there will always be a weakness somewhere, and it will be exposed. But, this also means that the enemy has weak points, and you can find ways to expose them as well. You can even find ways to engineer new weaknesses in the enemy forces. Then, you can attack the enemy몭s weak points while steering clear of their strong points.
The last two chapters, and this one, are all about how wars are fought, and they follow a logical progression: In Formation, Sun Tzu talks about winning first and fighting later; in Energy, he talks about how armies are to be deployed and split into main and auxiliary forces, with the main force used to start battles and the auxiliary force used to win them. Now, in Weak Points and Strong, he talks about avoiding the enemy몭s strong points and striking where they몭re weak.
The point to keep in mind in this chapter is that both you and your enemy have weak and strong points. Is it possible to make yourself strong in every area; to cover all your bases and have not a single weakness?  No, that would be impossible. If you try to make yourself as strong as possible in every area, then inevitably every part of your defenses will be flawed, because there are limits to resources, and similarly there are limits to people몭s energy and concentration.
There몭s a line later on in Weak Points and Strong that reads: 몮Should the enemy strengthen his van, he will weaken his rear; should he strengthen his rear, he will weaken his van; should he strengthen his left, he will weaken his right; should he strengthen his right, he will weaken his left. If he sends reinforcements everywhere, he will everywhere be weak.몯 It몭s impossible to have all the good things fall into your lap, and yet people are willing to believe that that they can indeed have all the good things, because this is a highly appealing idea. 
So, we often entertain wishful thinking. A useful anecdote on this point is the Wooden Bucket Theory: the amount of water a wooden bucket can hold is determined by the length of the bucket몭s shortest stave. If we want our bucket to hold more water, we have to lengthen the shortest stave. It would be completely useless to try to lengthen the longest stave, because no matter how long it may be, the water will only go as high as the shortest stave before spilling on the ground.
To put it in Sun Tzu몭s language, your longest stave is your 몬strong point,몭 and your shortest stave is your 몬weak point.몭 Where does success come from 멪 lengthening your longest stave? No. To be successful, you have to lengthen your shortest stave. There몭s no getting around your weak points; you have to acknowledge them, and you have to acknowledge that you are not a god, but human, and that you are prone to all the traits that come as part of being human.
Then there몭s all the nonsense that we learn from a young age, ideas that would have us deny that we are actually human. In Chinese, there몭s a phrase that몭s a good example of this: 몬Have what other몭s don몭t; when others can do something, do it better than them; when others are better than you at something, do it faster than them; when others are faster than you, then transform.몭 How is this supposed to be possible? This whole idea assumes that you몭re not human but a god, while the 몬others몭 are mere mortals. And if it were actually possible to put this idea into practice, then the art of war would be irrelevant. You wouldn몭t need to learn about 몬avoiding the enemy몭s strong points and striking him where he몭s weak.몭 You could just attack whichever part of the enemy몭s몭 forces you feel like, using whichever part of your own forces you feel like, because whatever you chose to do, it would be like hitting an egg with a rock. The enemy would shatter on impact.
The idea that you can just be better than everyone else by sheer force of will is madness. In the real world of actual military strategy, there is a fundamental principle: 몬I have what the enemy doesn몭t, and what the enemy has, I don몭t.몭
When we were looking at the idea of 몬If you know the enemy and you know yourself, then you can fight a hundred battles without fear of losing,몭 we talked about how the main problem we have is that we don몭t know ourselves, and not that we don몭t know the enemy. It몭s quite easy to focus more on other people while forgetting to be mindful of ourselves. We think, 몬Of course I know myself,몭 but in fact the person we know least tends to be ourselves. Similarly with 몬weak points and strong,몭 we can몭t just focus on other people몭s weaknesses and strengths while assuming that we몭ve effectively strengthened ourselves on every front. We몭d be wrong to think that; no matter what you do, you will always have both strengths and weaknesses, and it몭s impossible to patch up all your weaknesses. If you think you몭ve patched up all your weaknesses, every one of those patches is in fact a weakness.
Don몭t try to 몬fix몭 your weak points. Instead, learn how to fight as you are멞 weaknesses, strengths and all. Learn not to try to fix all of your problems, but to keep moving forward, even while surrounded by difficulties. When you learn how to do this, you will have mastered the essence of 몬weak points and strong.몭
Sun Tzu said: 몮Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will arrive exhausted.몯
When you arrive at the battlefield before the enemy, your troops and horses will be well rested and full of energy. Not only that, you몭ll also have the pick of the best terrain, meaning that you can wait for the enemy to arrive knowing that you몭ve already secured advantageous 몬earth energy.몭 
But when you arrive after the enemy, the best terrain will already be occupied by your foe. And, you몭ll likely get no rest after your long, tiring journey, but be forced to fight immediately. You몭re making your job much harder for yourself when you arrive after the enemy.
To rephrase this idea in a more relatable context, it몭s like going on a business trip to meet a client, and then having to sit through a two-hour meeting. For the client sitting in their office waiting for you to arrive, all they need to do is set aside two hours from their day. Meanwhile, you have to catch a flight to the client몭s city, and check in and out of a hotel, and by the time you get back home, the whole process has taken two full days of your time.
Our historical example for this passage comes from the war between the Later Zhou dynasty and the Northern Qi. The Later Zhou army moved to attack, but the Northern Qi commander, Duan Shao, held a defensive position inside his city walls. There had been heavy snowfall that day, and snow lay deep on the ground. The Later Zhou commander had sent a vanguard infantry force toward the city, moving in from the west. 
Northern Qi scouts informed their commander and his generals that the enemy army was now within two li of the city. All of the generals were eager to march out and fight in the open, but Commander Duan Shao reasoned against this: 몮Infantry troops have limited energy reserves, and it몭s extremely tiring to trudge through snow as deep as there is today. If we charge out now, the snow will make it hard for us, too. The better option is to deploy our soldiers in battle formation and wait for the enemy; thus, the enemy will be exhausted but we will be fresh. Victory will surely be ours.몯 Sure enough, the Northern Qi forces crushed the Later Zhou army that day, wiping out their vanguard infantry forces and routing their rear forces.


Creating a home field advantage

Extract from the original text:
몮Therefore the clever combatant imposes his will on the enemy, but does not allow the enemy몭s will to be imposed on him.몯

Analysis:
몬Imposing one몭s will on the enemy몭 is about making the enemy come to you. 몬Allowing the enemy몭s will to be imposed몭 on oneself means that the enemy has caused you to come to them. 몬The clever combatant몭 has the ability to manipulate the enemy, while not allowing the enemy to manipulate them.
During the Eastern Han dynasty, a general named Fei Yi, who was in the service of the rebel commander Zhang Bu, sent his younger brother, Fei Gan, to hold a defensive position in the city of Juli. A commander of the Han imperial army, Geng Yan, moved in close to Juli and made ready to attack the city. He cut down a large number of trees, and let it be known that he planned to use them to fill in the city몭s moat, after which he would attack. Several days later, Geng Yan몭s forces captured a rebel soldier, who informed them that Fei Yi had heard Geng Yan was planning to attack Juli, and was preparing to come to his younger brother몭s rescue. When Geng Yan heard this, he loudly ordered his troops to ready their weapons and prepare for battle in three days몭 time. Then, he had his guards 몬accidentally몭 let the enemy prisoner escape. The prisoner made his way to Fei Yi몭s camp, and told him about Geng Yan몭s plans. Sure enough, Fei Yi ordered his forces to move out; he was coming to rescue his brother. But Geng Yan was ready; he left 3,000 troops to keep Juli surrounded, while with the bulk of his forces he personally orchestrated an ambush against Fei Yi. Geng Yan won a crushing victory that day, and executed Fei Yi.
This is a classic strategy: besieging a city in order to manipulate the enemy into sending a relief force, and then ambushing that relief force while it몭s still on the road. 
Zhang Yu comments: 몮When I manipulate my enemy and cause him to come to me and fight, then he will always be in a position of weakness; if I do not travel to attack the enemy, then I will always be in position of strength. This is the art of using the strength and weakness of the enemy and of myself.몯 It몭s about putting yourself in a position of strength, and the enemy in a position of weakness.
Du You comments: 몮When two armies are far away from one another, they are equal in weak points and strong. The enemy may come to me and thus imperil himself, but I may not imperil myself by going to him.몯
Zeng Guofan also wrote his own, brief explanation of the idea of 몬imposing one몭s will on the enemy and not allowing the enemy몭s will to be imposed몭 on oneself. 몮It is delightful to be the host, but not at all delightful to be the visitor.몯 This is the concept of the home field advantage, exactly the same as in soccer matches. The visitors start with a 30% handicap. So, it몭s important to come up with a way to position yourself in a 몬home field몭 position, and make sure your enemy is forced to play the role of the 몬visiting team.몭


Don몭t get carried away by your emotions; the art of war can be used to do all kinds of things, but the moment you get carried away, it all goes out the window

Don몭t be greedy. Greediness in a person makes them easy to trick. Don몭t believe that some things are too important to ever let go of, because this makes you liable to being baited by your enemy. Except for your own life, everything is expendable. 

Extract from the original text:
몮By holding out advantages to him, he can cause the enemy to approach of his own accord; or, by inflicting damage, he can make it impossible for the enemy to draw near. If the enemy is taking his ease, he can harass him; if well supplied with food, he can starve him out; if quietly encamped, he can force him to move.몯

Analysis:
What is this chapter, Weak Points and Strong, about? According to Cao Cao, it몭s about 몮the ability to navigate the strengths and weaknesses of both yourself and your enemy.몯 In other words, it tells us that both sides in a conflict have strengths and weaknesses, and that it몭s important in war to use your strong points to strike the enemy몭s weak points. To do this, you need to manipulate the enemy into moving where you want him, turning his strong points into weak points.

몮The clever combatant imposes his will on the enemy, but does not allow the enemy몭s will to be imposed on him.몯

Make the enemy come to you. Make them play the role of the 몬visiting team,몭 while you enjoy the advantage of playing in your 몬home field.몭 How do you go about doing this? You do it by 몬holding out advantages to him몭 멪 in other words, by finding a way to tempt him.
When General Li Mu of the state of Zhao took up his border garrison command, the first thing he did was build up his fortifications and evacuate the surrounding countryside. He closed his gates and refused to come out and fight for ten years, forcing the Xiongnu chieftain to hold his breath and wait. Finally, Li Mu chose a day to emerge from behind his walls and lay out bait for the enemy, in the form of several thousand troops sent out to 몬fight a battle몭 against the Xiongnu. When Li Mu몭s suicide force was defeated, their oxen and sheep were scattered across the countryside, and this temptation proved too much for the Xiongnu chieftain, who had been starved of plunder for ten years. Swept up in uncontrollable excitement, he forgot all about the art of war, and led his entire army out to pluck up Li Mu몭s lost livestock. Meanwhile, Li Mu had set an ambush. On that day, Li Mu wiped out 100,000 Xiongnu cavalry. The Xiongnu were so badly beaten that they didn몭t dare show their faces again for years afterward.
This is an example of 몬holding out advantages.몭 But why did the Xiongnu chieftain fall for such a simple trick? He must have just been too excited. After all, he몭d been waiting for a chance like this for ten whole years! Ten years without stealing so much as a single sheep, and without fighting a single battle! After all that time, the chieftain would have been on the verge of losing his mind. We know that people are prepared to die for a chance to get rich, just as birds are prepared to die in pursuit of their next meal. He couldn몭t help himself; he saw a prize waiting for him to grab, and he lost control of himself.

몮By inflicting damage, he can make it impossible for the enemy to draw near.몯

If you don몭t want to make your enemy come to you, or if you want to move him away from the battlefield, you몭ll need to attack something that he is bound to want to protect, and inflict damage where it몭s bound to make him anxious. If you do this, the enemy몭s anxiety will cause him to lose all concern for himself, and focus entirely on protecting whatever it is he considers so precious.
A classic example of this principle from Chinese military history is a Warring States period story of how the Zhao city of Handan, under siege by a Wei army, was saved by an allied Qi army. When the Wei commander Pang Juan attacked the state of Zhao, the state of Qi sent Commander Sun Bin with an army to the rescue. But, instead of rushing to join the fray at the besieged Zhao city, Sun Bin headed directly toward the Wei capital city, Daliang, and put the city under seige. With Daliang under attack, the Wei army couldn몭t hang around at Handan; they had to pull back and relieve their capital city. And so, suddenly, the siege of Handan was broken. Sun Bin몭s next move was a textbook example of the strategy of 몬setting up a siege to destroy the relief force.몭 He devised an ambush for the returning Wei army, positioning himself in a home field advantage and forcing the Wei army into the role of the 몬visiting team.몭 He successfully made himself strong and the enemy weak, himself fresh and the enemy exhausted, and in the battle that followed the Wei army was battered. Commander Pang Juan died in the fight. 

몮If the enemy is taking his ease, he can harass him.몯

The point is to be in a situation where you몭re fresh and well rested, but the enemy is exhausted. If, at the starting point, both you and your enemy are well rested, you need to come up with a way to exhaust him; you need to keep him so busy that he doesn몭t have time to think. 
During the Spring and Autumn period conflict between the states of Wu and Chu, the Wu general Wu Zixu put together three separate forces, with the express intention of using them for 몬harassment missions.몭 With much fanfare, he marched out to attack Chu at the head of one of those forces, but once the entire Chu army had been mobilized to fend him off, he retreated back home to Wu. Then, he waited until the Chu army had been disbanded and sent home, and immediately moved again to attack Chu, this time at the head of the second of his forces. He kept using this tactic to harass Chu, to the point that their leaders were unable to think straight, and he managed to do this without fighting a single battle. Then, with deadly speed, he mobilized all three of his forces, and this time he attacked for real, sacking the Chu capital city. This was the first time in the Spring and Autumn period that a state had successfully attacked the capital city of another state.
This same tactic was used by the Sui dynasty to defeat the rival state of Chen. Every time that the crops were just ready for harvest in the Chen territory, the Sui dynasty leaders deployed their armies and pretended they were about to attack. Then, they waited until the state of Chen had finished frantically mobilizing its forces to face the Sui threat, before standing down. They repeated this over and over, until the people of Chen were physically and mentally spent.

몮If well supplied with food, he can starve him out.몯

This is about finding a way to use hunger against your enemy. We just spoke about how the Sui dynasty harassed its rival, the state of Chen, and in fact, hunger was also a part of the Sui strategy. The state of Chen was located south of the Yangzi River, where the climate is warm and damp, and where most of the houses are made of thatch. Food was hung up inside these houses for storage, rather than kept in the relative safety of underground cellars. So, the Sui leaders dispatched several raiding squads to roam the Chen territories and set fire to settlements, using the prevailing winds to their advantage. The people of Chen would build new houses, but then their Sui tormenters would come again and burn them down once more. This left the people with nothing 멪 starving and utterly destitute.
Years later, in the final days of the Sui dynasty, General Yuwen Huaji, who had just engineered a coup, led his army to attack another Sui general named Li Mi. But, Li Mi knew that Yuwen Huaji didn몭t have much grain, so he pretended to sue for peace, claiming that he was no match for his adversary. Yuwen Huaji was delighted, and was content to wait while preparations were made for a peace treaty to be signed. In reality, Li Mi was just playing for time, waiting for Yuwen Huaji몭s army to run out of food. Yuwen Huaji didn몭t bother rationing his supplies, because he believed he몭d soon be able to feed his men from Li Mi몭s granaries. Once his food was gone, though, he found that Li Mi suddenly wasn몭t quite as peaceful as he몭d seemed. Soldiers need to eat, and Yuwen Huaji몭s men soon went over to Li Mi몭s side, and so he lost. 

몮If quietly encamped, he can force him to move.몯

Cao Cao says: 몮Attack whatever the enemy will be compelled to protect, appear where he will compelled to meet you; this is how to force the enemy to launch a relief action.몯
When one of Cao Cao몭s generals, Sima Yi, led an expedition to Liaodong to attack a rebellious general named Gong Sunxiao, Gong Sunxiao deployed his forces along the Liao River, blocking Sima몭s way forward. Sima Yi had no intention of fighting Gong by the river, and he told his generals in a meeting: 몮Our foe몭s encampment is strong and well fortified, and it is his intention to tire us out. If we attack him here, we will be doing just as he has planned. We must attack him elsewhere, somewhere that he will be compelled to protect, so that we can force his men to leave their camp.몯
Sima Yi made a big show of strength close to the enemy, while secretly sending part of his army around the enemy몭s defenses and behind their lines to besiege Gong Sunxiao몭s base, the city of Xiangping. Gong Sunxiao was left with no choice but to leave his front-line camp and fight out in the open. Sima Yi crushed his army, executed him and restored stability to the Liaodong region.
But, if you look at this situation in terms of the results 멪 Gong Sunxiao was executed 멪 there wasn몭t actually any need for him to rescue Pingxiang. Liaodong is a land of brutally cold winters. If Gong Sunxiao had hunkered down in his fortified camp, and pulled grain and people from the surrounding countryside inside his gate, it wouldn몭t have mattered if all his cities had been burned to the ground. He could have stayed safe, far away from the cities, wait for winter to come and for Sima Yi to run out of food and pull his forces back. And then, Gong Sunxiao could have attacked him as he retreated. If he몭d done this, he would have had a chance of holding on to power in Liaodong. In fact, this is exactly how the people of Korea were able to survive for thousands of years as an independent nation without being annexed, even though it sits right at the edge of China.
So, in conclusion, don몭t get carried away. The art of war can be used to do all kinds of things, but the moment you get carried away, it all goes out of the window. Don몭t be greedy. Greediness in a person makes them easy to trick. Don몭t believe that some things are too important to ever let go of, because this makes you liable to being baited by your enemy. Except for your own life, everything is expendable.


Don몭t do things your own way without caring what people think; Do things your own way, but do it in a way that people don몭t expect; Don몭t let people know what you몭re doing

Extract from the original text:
몮Appear at points which the enemy will not be quick enough to defend; march swiftly to places where you are not expected. An army may march great distances without distress, if it marches through country where the enemy is not. You can be sure of succeeding in your attacks if you only attack places which are undefended. You can ensure the safety of your defense if you only hold positions that cannot be attacked.몯

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: 몮Compel the enemy to mount a relief effort.몯
We often talk about how people should walk their own paths, and not worry about what other people say. But, from the perspective of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, this is not best way to do things. Instead, he suggests, walk your own path in a way that other people would never expect, and don몭t let others know what you몭re doing.

몮An army may march great distances without distress, if it marches through country where the enemy is not.몯

There are two classic examples from Chinese military history that shed light on this passage, and both come from armies that conquered the kingdom of Shu, in modern-day Sichuan Province.
One of these examples is well known in China, because a fictionalized version of it forms part of the classic novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms. It comes from the story of how Zhong Hui and Deng Ai conquered Shu. Deng Ai, taking advantage of the fact that the Shu commander Jiang Wei was boxed in at Sword Gate Pass by Zhong Hui, led a force east from Yinping along the Jinggu Path. He cut south through the mountains and emerging in Shu territory, over 200 li away from Sword Gate Pass. He몭d led his troops on a perilous journey through difficult terrain, building bridges and walkways along sheer cliffs as he went. For over 700 li, his forces moved in single file through uninhabited wilderness, a dangerous land of soaring peaks and deep canyons. Throughout Deng몭s journey, he had no access to food resupplies, and he often found himself in seriously dangerous situations. At one point, having arrived at a place called Horse Pavilion Mountain, he discovered that the way ahead was impassable. For a moment, it seemed he was stuck, unable to move forward or backward, but he eventually came up with a solution. He wrapped himself in felt and rolled down the mountain slope, ahead of his men. 
Finally, Deng Ai led his troops out into the Sichuan Basin, taking the enemy by surprise and making straight for the city of Jiangyou. Once there, he forced the garrison commander, Ma Miao, to surrender. Then, Deng Ai cut a bloody path all the way to the Shu capital city of Chengdu, at which point the Shu Emperor, Liu Chan, surrendered.
Our second example comes from the Northern and Southern Dynasties period (420-589 CE). The Prince of Wuling, Xiao Ji, had gained control of Sichuan (Shu), installed himself in the city of Chengdu, and declared himself Emperor. The ambitious Xiao Ji had designs to attack Emperor Yuan of Liang and seize control of the Liang territories. Meanwhile, the Northern Wei dynasty leaders saw an opportunity. The head of the Northern Wei military, Yu Wentai, thought that the time was ripe to gain control of both Shu and Liang. But, the other Northern Wei generals couldn몭t come to an agreement. So, Yu Wentai entrusted one of them, Yuchi Jiong, to take control of the mission. When Yu asked Yuchi what his plan was, he replied: 몮The lands of Shu have been isolated from the central Chinese territories for over a hundred  years. They are surrounded by dangerous mountains and rivers, so the Shu leaders will not expect me to attack. The best plan is to attack with an elite armored cavalry force, moving quickly and at night. We will travel at double speed in places where the road is easy, and when we encounter dangerous roads, we will slow our pace and advance more gradually. Thus, we will take the enemy by surprise and strike straight to his heart. He will surely be unable to defend against us if we attack in this way.몯
And that is exactly what happened. Yuchi Qiong entered Shu through Sanguan Pass, besieged Chengdu, and took the city within 50 days, enabling him to take full control of the Shu territories.

몮You can be sure of succeeding in your attacks if you only attack places which are undefended.몯

There몭s a mantra that people often repeat: 몬Fight when there is no possible outcome other than victory; attack where there is no possible outcome other than overwhelming the enemy몭s defenses.몭 But this is impossible, because it몭s not just your slogan; your enemy will have it posted all over his walls, too. The only situation in which these words can become a reality is if the enemy hasn몭t made defensive preparations. Using soccer as an example again, it몭s no easy thing to score a goal when there are defenders in front of you, even if you몭re as talented as Argentine superstar Diego Maradona. To score, you first have to maneuver back and forth, wait until your opponent takes the foot off the gas, and then shoot.
Our next military example comes once again from Geng Yan몭s campaign to put down Zhang Bu몭s rebellion during the Eastern Han dynasty. Zhang Bu had ordered his younger brother, Zhang Lan, to hold a defensive position in the city of Xi몭an, and he sent another of his generals to defend the city of Linzi. Meanwhile, Geng Yan marched his army towards Xi몭an, and set up camp 40 li outside of the city. Studying the city몭s defenses, Geng saw that although Xi몭an몭s walls were small, they were sturdy, and manned by experienced troops under the command of Zhang Lan. Linzi, on the other hand, though protected by high city walls, would be a much easier target to attack. So, Geng Yan made up his mind to attack Linzi instead. To do this, he had to convince the enemy that he was planning to attack Xi몭an, so he used the same trick he몭d used to such good effect before. He ordered his men to build siege weapons, and let it be widely known that he was planning to attack Xi몭an. Then, he 몬accidentally몭 let some captive enemy soldiers escape, so that they would go back to their commanders with news of his fake plans. When Zhang Lan heard, he began intensive preparations to ward off Geng Yan몭s coming attack.
At midnight the day before Geng Yan had said he would attack Xi몭an, he called his officers from their beds to eat with him, and announced that they would be marching straight for Linzi. The officers didn몭t come around immediately, and argued that they should attack Xi몭an instead. But Geng Yan reasoned with them that Xi몭an had strong walls, elite soldiers and watertight defenses, whereas Linzi was undefended. Geng Yan told them that the enemy would never expect them to suddenly show up at Linzi몭s city walls; with their enemies shell-shocked, they could take the city within a single day. Then, once Linzi had fallen, Xi몭an would be within their reach. So, they몭d be killing two birds with one stone.
Geng Yan put his plan in motion, and the events that followed happened exactly as he몭d said they would. 

몮You can ensure the safety of your defense if you only hold positions that cannot be attacked.몯

If you want to guarantee that you몭ll be able to hold your ground against enemy attacks, you need to prepare solid defenses even in places where the enemy is not attacking. When the enemy attacks you in the east, it몭s possible that he몭s just bluffing, and that his real attack will come from the west. So, what happens if you haven몭t set up proper defenses in your western positions? Well, something like what happened in the example above. Geng Yan wanted to capture Xi몭an, so Zhang Bu didn몭t bother properly defending Linzi, which led to Linzi falling into Geng Yan몭s hands.
Earlier on, during the Western Han dynasty (206 BCE-9 CE), there was a major uprising called the Rebellion of the Seven States. The commander of the Han imperial forces, Zhou Yafu, was holding a defensive position in the city of Changyi. The rebel army attacked swiftly, heading straight for the southeastern section of the city walls, but Zhou Yafu made sure to position a large part of his troops near the northwestern section of the walls. Before long, the rebel army did indeed send its best troops to attack from the northwest. However, because Zhou Yafu had set up strong defenses, the rebels couldn몭t break through. With the rebels forced to abandon their attack, Zhou Yafu pursued them as they retreated and inflicted a massive defeat on them.


At its most refined, 몬Weak points and strong몭 is about appearing and disappearing like a ghost, Holding your destiny and your enemy몭s destiny in the palm of your hand

Extract from the original text:
몮Hence that general is skillful in attack whose opponent does not know what to defend; and he is skillful in defense whose opponent does not know what to attack. Oh divine art of subtlety and secrecy! Through you we learn to be invisible, through you inaudible; and hence we can hold the enemy몭s fate in our hands.몯

Analysis:
몮Hence that general is skillful in attack whose opponent does not know what to defend; and he is skillful in defense whose opponent does not know what to attack.몯
Being good at attacking means making your enemy unsure where to defend, and being good at defending means making your enemy unsure where to attack.
Cao Cao gives us a very simple comment on this point: 몮It is about not leaking intelligence.몯 In other words, don몭t let the enemy know what your army is doing.
When attacking, if the enemy has no idea where you몭re going to attack, he won몭t know how to defend. He몭ll expend a lot of effort working out what you몭re doing, and then he몭ll set up defenses, only for you to feint left and strike right. In Chinese, this stratagem is known as 몬luring the tiger out of its mountain lair.몭
When defending, if the enemy can몭t work out where your weak and strong points are positioned, he will be unable to come up with an effective attack plan. He몭ll put a lot of effort into working out where the gaps in your armor are, only to fall into your ambush when he tries to attack.
This is the principle (the Dao) of 몬weak points and strong.몭 If you want to win, you need to avoid the enemy몭s strong points and strike his weak points. You need to make sure the enemy can몭t find your weak points, so that each time he thinks he몭s figured you out, and attacks, he runs straight into your strongest point, like hitting a brick wall. Meanwhile, when you attack, you need to always manipulate the enemy into exposing the gaps in his fortifications. Once you몭ve done this, burst through as quickly as possible and liquefy his entire position.
If you can do all this, you will have almost supernatural abilities.

몮Oh divine art of subtlety and secrecy! Through you we learn to be invisible, through you inaudible; and hence we can hold the enemy몭s fate in our hands.몯


The Dao of 몬weak points and strong몭 truly is extraordinary. It empowers you to attack like a lightning bolt from a cloudless sky, and to defend like a mole hiding deep underground. With 몬weak points and strong,몭 you can appear and disappear at will, wrap your enemy around your finger, and put him entirely at your mercy. This is how to take control of your enemy몭s fate.
In the original Chinese text, in the sentence translated as 몮And hence we can hold the enemy몭s fate in our hands,몯 Sun Tzu says that you will be like the underworld god in charge of people몭s fates. In Waging War, the second chapter of The Art of War, he also says: 몮Thus it may be known that the leader of armies is the arbiter (god in charge) of the people몭s fate, the man on whom it depends whether the nation shall be in peace or in peril.몯 The general who knows his men is like a god to the people of his country, and he holds their fates in his hand; what he does will decide whether they live or die. Here, in Chapter Six, Sun Tzu takes it a step further by talking about how to become the arbiter of your enemy몭s fate, and taking control of whether your enemy lives or dies.
He Shi comments: 몮Sun Tzu is here discussing the art of weak points and strong. It is divine in its subtlety, and it has the ultimate efficacy in achieving success. With it, I can make my strong points seem weak to my enemy, and my weak points seem strong. Where the enemy is strong, I can manipulate and move him, so that he becomes weak. Where the enemy is weak, I can perceive his lack of strength. In summary, my enemy cannot see my weak and strong points, but I can see everything about his weak and strong points in a single glance.
몮When I am preparing to attack the enemy, I know where his defenses are strong and where they are inadequate and weak, so I can avoid his strong points and attack him where he is fragile. When the enemy wants to attack me, I know that when he makes a great deal of noise and fuss about attacking a certain position, that position will certainly not be his main focus; rather, the place I actually should fortify with additional troops is wherever he has not yet attacked.
몮I show the enemy my weak points, but attack him with my strong points. If he makes a show of attacking from the east, then I should prepare to defend against him in the west. So, when I want to attack him, he doesn몭t know where to defend; when I want to defend against him, he cannot find a good opening to attack.
몮The variables involved in attacking and defending stem from the art of using weak points and strong. I am either defending, in which case I am like a mole hiding deep underground, or I am attacking, in which case I am like a lightning bolt striking from a cloudless sky. I erase my tracks and thus I cannot be seen; I muffle my voice, and thus I cannot be heard. I delve into the ground and spring forth from thin air; I emerge suddenly and disappear into the space between things; I shine like the stars and move like a ghost; I enter into realms of nothingness and circle the void in the underworld. This is the subtlety of all subtleties, the divine of all divinity; the sharpest eyes in the universe cannot perceive the nuance of its forms, and the most acute ear in the universe cannot hear its divine sound. It has form yet it is as though without form; it makes sound yet it is as though soundless. It is not that it has no form, but that the enemy cannot see it; it is not that it makes no sound, but that the enemy cannot hear it. This is the immaculate intricacy of the variations in between weak points and strong.몯
This lengthy bit of commentary by He Shi basically covers all there is to say about the wondrous essence of 몬weak points and strong.몭 But is it really so 몬divine?몭 Actually, it really is! So, how is that you can avoid falling for the enemy몭s bluffs, while making the enemy fall for yours and take control of his movements into your hands? This is basically a question of experience and intuition. To put it in a philosophical frame, it몭s a question of uniting your knowledge and your actions as one, which was a major theme in the School of Mind, a movement identified with the major Neo-Confucian philosopher Wang Yangming.
In ancient Chinese military circles, everyone was very familiar with Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War and Thirty-Six Stratagems, and even a six-year-old can understand the concept of the bluff. But, once you몭re on the battlefield and your enemy is charging from the east like a thunderstorm, with dead bodies piling up before him, how do you know if he몭s actually planning to attack from the west? And what if he knows you know that he몭s bluffing? Won몭t he then just follow through on his bluff and continue his main point of attack in the east, or even change direction entirely and attack from the north and south?
Here몭s another example question: do you know that sugar is sweet? Of course, everyone knows that. But, if someone has never eaten sugar, how do you describe to them what sweetness is?
So, though every commander in ancient China would have read The Art of War, and may even have it memorized word-for-word, how much actual knowledge you have of it is a different matter entirely. When people read books, they can only learn from those books to a certain extent, determined by their own limitations. If you can몭t map the knowledge from the books onto your own life, you don몭t really know what you몭ve read. Not only that, you don몭t know that you don몭t know what you몭ve read, and you have the illusion that you know everything about it. General Zhao Kuo is a classic example. He was an armchair strategist, and not only did he not know what he was doing, he also didn몭t know that he didn몭t know. Worse than that, he thought he knew everything, and this is exactly how he brought ruin on his country.
So, can we know if our enemy is bluffing 멪 feinting to the east, only to strike from the west?
No! That몭s because knowing about the concept of the bluff doesn몭t count as having real knowledge of it. Actual understanding only happens on real battlefields. Whether he몭s bluffing in the east or in the west, it doesn몭t really matter; it몭s about being able to instantly see where the enemy몭s weak and strong points are, and understanding where you need to position yourself.
This is the meaning of unifying knowledge and action as one. If you want to learn how to unify knowledge and action, you first have to know that you don몭t know.
There몭s a Confucian saying that sages know things precisely because they don몭t know them, whereas small-minded people don몭t know things precisely because they know them. Sages know that they don몭t know things, which makes them cautious, alert and wary. They are good at observing, studying and asking questions, and so they are able to gain knowledge about things. But small-minded people don몭t know that they don몭t know, and because they think they know things, they have no ability to observe, study and ask questions. This is why they don몭t know things.
Just because we몭ve studied the art of war doesn몭t mean we몭ll be able to win real-life battles. The act of reading books and studying is a kind of self-reflection; we mould the way we study around our real-life work, and then continue to refine this knowledge and gain more understanding of it as we apply it to our real lives and seek to improve ourselves.
For the last part of our discussion on this passage, I몭m going to talk about a story from my own personal experiences.
Once, over dinner, I introduced a work partner to a good friend of mine. After we finished our dinner, my friend told me, very bluntly, that this person I몭d been working with wasn몭t up to scratch. He told me, 몮I can tell you exactly how much firepower this guy몭s working with 멪 I can literally put a number on it.몯 
I was taken aback, and asked: 몮How can you tell?몯 
몮Whenever someone has less money than me, I can tell how much money they have the moment I meet them, because I know how people act in each of the different levels of wealth. I can몭t tell when a person has more money than me, but I can always tell when someone has less.몯
This happened many years ago, but it had such an impact on me that I몭ve always remembered it. As I reflected on what my friend had said, and on my own experiences, I realized that I had a similar knack. Whenever I talk business with someone who has less money than me, I always have a clear idea of how much they have, and I can actually tell quite easily when they몭re telling the truth and when they몭re faking it. This is because whatever they몭re talking about, I have a memory-bank of similar experiences from my own life to compare it with, and I know whether what the other person몭s talking about is the real thing. Similarly, if the person I몭m talking with has more experience than me, and has seen more of the world, there몭s no way for me to know.
This is the meaning of unifying knowledge and action. It really is a mysterious thing. That몭s why Sun Tzu called it a 몬divine art of subtlety and secrecy몭 멪 this is one thing that he couldn몭t use words to communicate to us.


Retreating and pursuing are both important parts of military tactics

Extract from the original text:
몮You may advance and be absolutely irresistible, if you make for the enemy몭s weak points; you may retire and be safe from pursuit if your movements are more rapid than those of the enemy.몯

Analysis:
If you want to attack the enemy and leave him powerless to stand in your way, you have to look for a chink in his armor during the heat of battle, and immediately burst through it. If you pull it off smoothly, you need to pull back rapidly as soon as you몭ve met your objective, circle the wagons and defend your position, so the enemy has no way to hurt you while you몭re exiting the battlefield.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Order your troops to charge the enemy where he is weak and lax. Then, retreat with speed.몯
In Cao Cao몭s own military career, he became a real-life example of his own words. In fact, he kindly left us with an example and a counter-example, both from the same battle, during his campaign against Zhang Xiu.
Cao Cao had surrounded Zhang Xiu몭s stronghold, the city of Rangcheng, when he received a message from the rear. It informed him that another of Cao Cao몭s enemies, Yuan Shao, was taking advantage of Cao Cao몭s absence to attack the city of Xudu. Cao Cao had no choice but to withdraw.
When retreating, the first thing you have to do is make your enemy confused and disoriented, and then pull your troops back as quickly as possible. When Cao Cao retreated, he split his army into a main force and an auxiliary force, and then waited for Zhang Xiu to come chase him. When Zhang Xiu saw that Cao Cao was pulling back, he coordinated with the army of his ally, Liu Biao, and attacked Cao Cao from either side, in a pincer movement. Under Cao Cao몭s expert direction, his forces delivered a crushing defeat to Liu Biao몭s and Zhang Xiu몭s two armies, and then rapidly withdrew.
Everything went exactly as Cao Cao had planned, except for one thing: he hadn몭t accounted for a certain, extremely talented adviser who was working for Zhang Xiu, a man named Jia Xu.
As the victorious Cao Cao ordered his men to retreat, an enemy force under the personal command of Zhang Xiu got ready to chase after him. But, Jia Xu had something else in mind.
몮Don몭t pursue them! If you chase after them now, you are sure to lose,몯 Jia Xu said.
But Zhang Xiu was eager for revenge, and there was no way he was going to listen to Jia Xu in that moment. He went straight after Cao Cao, who then cut him off from his reinforcements and demolished his pursuit force.
When Zhang Xiu returned home with the remnants of his defeated army, he told Jia Xu: 몮Since you seem to know when I몭m doomed to lose, do you also know when I몭m certain to win? If you only know when I몭m going to lose, then I몭ll never win. But if you do know how I can win certain victory, then tell me! That몭s the only way I몭ll be able to win!몯
Jia Xu said: 몮You need to take these troops you몭ve just come back with and go after Cao Cao. If you do this, you are sure to win!몯
This time, Zhang Xiu listened. Without even asking Jia Xu to explain his logic, he turned on his heel and went out after Cao Cao. Sure enough, he managed to break the back of Cao Cao몭s rear reserve force.
When Zhang Xiu returned, he declared Jia Xu a genius, and asked him to explain what had just happened.
Jia Xu replied: 몮Actually, it몭s a very simple concept. Cao Cao attacked us, but he didn몭t beat us. He took the decision to withdraw on his own initiative, which could only mean he had some kind of problem to deal with back in the rear that was forcing him to retreat. Since he had to retreat, he was always going to prepare properly 멪 he would lead a group of elite soldiers to cut off any enemy pursuers. My lord, you are a capable commander, but you are still somewhat behind Cao Cao. I knew that there was no way you could beat him, so I knew you were sure to lose.
몮He몭d won a big victory against us, and then he beat our pursuit force. So, in his head, everything was going as well as it could be, and he naturally would have thought that we wouldn몭t come after him again. He was preparing to concentrate all his efforts on retreating, and he was planning to go back ahead of his main army accompanied by his best generals and advisors to take care of whatever problem he had to deal with back home, while leaving the job of covering his army몭s retreat to his other generals. These generals, and the troops they led, weren몭t a match for our men, so I knew that the second time we went after him, we몭d be bound to win.몯
Retreating from a battle is an important part of military tactics. In terms of organizing a retreat, the heavy supply wagons have to go at the front, while the army몭s best fighters go at the back.
However, a certain Song dynasty commander named Bi Zaiyu came up with an extremely innovative way of retreating during a fight against Jin dynasty몭s army. His innovation is known as 몬Hanging up a goat and beating the drums.몭 He strung up a goat in his camp, and placed its two front hooves on the surface of a war drum. The goat, which was quite upset, struggled to get free, and stamped repeatedly on the drum, making a huge amount of noise. This went on day after day, and the Jin army listened as the sound of the drums from the Song camp grew gradually fainter, weaker and less frequent. This seemed odd to them, so they sent scouts over to see what was happening. Only then did they realize that the camp was deserted 멪 the Song forces had retreated several days earlier.
Pursuing a retreating enemy is also an important part of military tactics. It formed the core of Communist Party General Lin Biao몭s approach to war. His military principles included 몬One point, two sides,몭 몬Three three몭s,몭 몬Four swifts and one slow,몭 and 몬Three ferocities,몭 among others.
Earlier in the book, when we were looking at 몬dividing numbers,몭 we took a first look at Lin Biao몭s 몬Three three몭s몭 organizational system.
In his 몬One point, two sides몭 principle, 몬one point몭 is about shattering the enemy by concentrating your firepower on a single point, and attacking that point with maximum ferocity. The 몬two sides몭 are about surrounding the enemy on two sides, or more, so as to not allow him to escape. Then, you can wipe out his forces, or leave one open direction for him to run, and wipe him out while he retreats.
To understand the 몬Four swifts and one slow,몭 we should first look at the 몬one slow.몭 It is about moving slowly as you launch your general offensive, and not making any moves unless you몭re fully ready. If you believe you몭re not ready, but you몭ve received orders from above to hurry up the attack, you can disobey those orders. Now let몭s look at the 몬Four swifts몭: 1) When advancing on the enemy position, move swiftly; 2) Once the enemy is between your teeth, swiftly carry out necessary preparation work 멪 surveying the terrain, building and engineering works, packing gunpowder, distributing your firepower, etc.; 3) Once you몭ve made a breakthrough, swiftly expand your battle advantage; 4) Once you몭ve broken the enemy and his forces are retreating, pursue them swiftly.
The 몬Three ferocities몭 are: fighting with ferocity, charging with ferocity, and pursuing with ferocity. Concentrate on a single point, gather your strengths and attack the enemy where he is weak, and then charge and fight with ferocity. As soon as the enemy breaks and retreats, pursue him with ferocity. Lin Biao put particular emphasis on pursuing the enemy with ferocity; it몭s a principle he built into the grassroots of his operations. Whenever he saw his enemy retreating, he would pursue ferociously.
At this stage of battle, don몭t wait for orders, and don몭t bother making any other preparations. In this situation, not preparing is the tactically sound thing to do, and trying to make preparations would actually be a tactical error. Just go after the enemy 멪 don몭t worry about whether you have too few men, whether you might be missing something about the overall situation, or whether your enemy has set an ambush for you. Don몭t even wait to report to your commanding officers. Just chase after the enemy, and once you몭re already moving, send someone back to report to the commanding officers. This philosophy that Lin Biao developed is about preparing properly before going into battle, and then not giving the enemy a second to think or reorganize once the battle has started. Keep them under constant pressure, and charge, fight and pursue with ferocity. Chase him to the ends of the earth, and never stop.


Randomness is always a factor in any single victory or failure; Success that lasts a lifetime is achieved by using successes to neutralize failures

Extract from the original text:
몮If we wish to fight, the enemy can be forced to an engagement even though he be sheltered behind a high rampart and a deep ditch. All we need do is attack some other place that he will be obliged to relieve. If we do not wish to fight, we can prevent the enemy from engaging us even though the lines of our encampment be merely traced out on the ground. All we need do is to throw something odd and unaccountable in his way.몯

Analysis:
If I몭m looking for a fight, there몭s a way I can force him to come out and face me in the open, no matter how high his walls are or how deep his moat. All I have to do is strike in a position that he has no choice but to protect. He may well know what I몭m doing 멪 luring the tiger out of its lair, and setting up a siege in order to destroy the relief force 멪 but he몭ll be forced to go where I want him to anyway, because I몭m attacking in a place that he cannot leave unprotected.
We몭ve already looked at a good few examples of this strategy: besieging the Wei capital to save Zhao from a Wei attack, Sima Yi몭s campaign in Liaodong, etc. I just want to give one more example in this subchapter, this time from the Ming dynasty, when Wang Yangming was tasked with putting down the Prince of Ning Rebellion in Nanchang. As soon as the Prince of Ning launched his insurrection, he attacked the city of Anqing with an army of 60,000 troops. The situation was extremely dangerous 멪 if he succeeded in taking Anqing, the city of Nanjing would virtually be in the bag for him. And, because of Nanjing몭s status as a capital city, as soon as he entered it he몭d have the political capital to proclaim himself Emperor. So, what did Wang Yangming do? He didn몭t try to save Anqing, but instead headed straight for the Prince of Ning몭s powerbase: the city of Nanchang. This left the Prince of Ning with only one option 멪 to abandon Nanchang, occupy Anqing, and then move downriver to Nanjing, where he몭d declare himself Emperor.
So, even though the Prince of Ning had lost Nanchang, he still had an opportunity open to him. The Emperor at the time, Zhu Houzhao (known as the Zhengde Emperor), was a deeply evil man, practically a devil incarnate, widely loathed by common folk and court officials alike. If the Prince of Ning managed to make it into Nanjing and crown himself Emperor, he wouldn몭t have to worry about gaining the support of the people. And yet, he couldn몭t bring himself to abandon his old base, Nanchang, so he forgot the age-old lesson: there몭s no reward without risk. He pulled his troops back to Nanchang, and collided with Wang Yangming몭s army at Poyang Lake. He lost the ensuing battle and was taken prisoner. His whole uprising, the cause he몭d staked his life to, was finished within just 35 days of starting.


몮If we do not wish to fight, we can prevent the enemy from engaging us even though the lines of our encampment be merely traced out on the ground.몯

If I don몭t want to fight, I just draw a line on the ground. My opponent won몭t dare cross it, because I몭ll make it my job to fill him with uncertainty and doubt about my side of the line 멪 exactly the place he wants to attack. 
In the original Chinese text, the wording for 몬prevent the enemy from coming몭 is unique to the classical Chinese language. The key word (translated here as 몬prevent몭), guai, means 몬well-behaved몭 or 몬clever몭 in modern Chinese. However, its ancient meaning is the opposite: 몬(to make something) counter-intuitive and difficult.몭 So, 몬making it counter-intuitive for the enemy to engage us몭 is about confusing them with trickery and smokescreens. Then, even though the enemy actually is capable of crossing the line we have drawn, he몭ll lack the conviction to actually do so. Cao Cao comments: 몮The meaning of 몬to make counter-intuitive몭 is to make the enemy몭s way forward awkward and difficult. It is a way of presenting gains and risks to the enemy in such a way that he becomes filled with doubt.몯
The most popular and well-known example of this strategy would be Zhuge Liang몭s Empty Fort gambit. As the story goes, Sima Yi was launching an attack on Zhuge Liang몭s fort at the head of a large army. Zhuge Liang only had 10,000 troops, so he didn몭t have the power to stop Sima Yi. If Sima Yi attacked, he몭d be able to take the city virtually without resistance, almost instantly. So, Zhuge Liang, ever cool and collected, opened the gates wide and sent men out with brooms to sweep in the gateway, as if everything was normal. When Sima Yi saw this, he immediately suspected that something was off. Without a doubt, he would have been thinking that Zhuge Liang was trying to make things 몬counter-intuitive,몭 just as The Art of War says. But, what if Zhuge Liang was actually playing some kind of double bluff? Sima Yi knew that he could never determine what Zhuge Liang was up to with any certainty. On top of that, considering Zhuge Liang몭s long-held reputation for caution and aversion to risk, it seemed very likely that there was an ambush force somewhere nearby waiting for him to fall into their trap. So, Sima Yi gave the order to retreat. 
Zeng Guofan also had experience defending cities against attack, and he몭s noted for saying that the absolute best way to defend cities is to use 몬uncanny silence.몭 This just means that when the enemy advances in a rush of noise, with war drums beating at the foot of the city walls, you shouldn몭t respond in any way. Just remain completely silent, and make sure that your soldiers stay hidden out of sight, away from the ramparts. If you do this, even relatively hotheaded attackers won몭t dare try to scale your walls with ladders. And anyway, your typical bandit army doesn몭t have much in the way of siege equipment. They generally like to watch what the defenders are doing, and use that information to decide what their next move should be. So, as a defender, the key is to not do anything at all. Don몭t show them so much as a silhouette; don몭t let them hear so much a single voice. If you do this, the enemy won몭t be able to drum up the energy and excitement they need to fight 멪  they might try a few more rounds of drumming, but eventually they몭ll get bored and leave. 
Let몭s talk a little more about Cao Cao. As far as official Chinese historical records go, there몭s actually no mention of Zhuge Liang몭s Empty City stratagem. So, now let몭s look at how Cao Cao was tricked by Zhao Yun몭s Empty Camp stratagem. During Cao Cao몭s struggle with Liu Bei for control of the strategically important city of Hanzhong, Zhao Yun was in charge of defending Bietun. One day, he몭d left his camp with a few dozen cavalry troops to inspect the local terrain, and he suddenly ran into Cao Cao몭s army. Zhao Yun beat a hasty retreat, fighting as he went, while Cao Cao몭s army chased after in swift pursuit. When Zhao Yun made it back inside his camp, he left the main gate open, and ordered complete silence and stillness. Cao Cao, surveying the scene, seemed to be facing one of two possibilities. Which principle from The Art of War was Zhao Yun using?
A) 몬Making it counter-intuitive for the enemy to engage us몭 멪 trying to scare the enemy off with trickery and smokescreens?
B)   몬Draw the enemy in with the prospect of benefits, then trap him in an ambush몭 멪 had Zhao Yun sent a small force to attack his army and pretend to be beaten, only to lure his pursuit force into the jaws of an ambush?
As Cao Cao pondered the situation, drawing on the lessons of The Art of War, he determined that since he hadn몭t intended to fight a battle that day 멪 and if he hadn몭t run into Zhao Yun, he would never have gone to his camp 멪 it was possible that this was a plan made by Zhao Yun. Zhao Yun was on his home field, while Cao Cao was the visitor. Therefore, Zhao Yun was in a strong position, and he was in a weak position. So, Cao Cao decided that the answer to his question should be 몬B.몭 And that was Cao Cao몭s final answer. He handed in his figurative exam script and pulled his troops back.
The lesson here is that real-life situations are often random.
But we can몭t say that Cao Cao몭s analysis was wrong. Actually, his evaluation was absolutely right, as was his decision-making. Why? After all, it몭s pretty clear that Zhao Yun got the better end of the bargain in that interaction. You just can몭t evaluate decision-making on the basis of a single gain or loss. Leaders have to make countless decisions each and every day, many of them about matters of life and death. Many of these choices create ripple effects that can have profound and long-lasting impacts. It would be impossible to get every decision right. The question is, how do you effectively use pragmatism? And the answer is: use successes to offset defeats, and correct decisions to offset wrong decisions.
In the end, if we몭re going to grade Cao Cao몭s 몬exam script몭 from that day, we have to give him full credit.


The idea of striking where you have a numerical advantage isn몭t about the balance of troop numbers, but weak and strong points

Extract from the original text:
몮By discovering the enemy몭s forms and remaining invisible ourselves, we can keep our forces concentrated, while the enemy몭s must be divided. We can form a single united body, while the enemy must split up into fractions. Hence there will be a whole pitted against separate parts of a whole, which means that we shall be many to the enemy몭s few. And if we are able thus to attack an inferior force with a superior one, then I will be fighting against a limited force. The spot where we intend to fight must not be made known; for then the enemy will have to prepare against a possible attack at several different points; and his forces being thus distributed in many directions, the numbers we shall have to face at any given point will be proportionately few. For should the enemy strengthen his van, he will weaken his rear; should he strengthen his rear, he will weaken his van; should he strengthen his left, he will weaken his right; should he strengthen his right, he will weaken his left. If he sends reinforcements everywhere, he will everywhere be weak. Numerical weakness comes from having to prepare against possible attacks; numerical strength, from compelling our adversary to make these preparations against us.몯

Analysis:
몮By discovering the enemy몭s forms and remaining invisible ourselves, we can keep our forces concentrated, while the enemy몭s must be divided.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Other people몭s forms are visible, but my forms are invisible. Thus, the enemy must divide his troops to be prepared for me.몯 It몭s about using all kinds of reconnaissance methods to bring the enemy몭s form under a spotlight, or to move the enemy where you want him, exposing the true facts of his situation, so that you can read him like a book. For example, you could use the Chinese concept of 몬reconnaissance by fire몭 멪 take a few shots at him, and watch to see which locations the enemy fires back from.
Reconnaissance isn몭t about probing blindly. You need to approach it with purpose; it should be an exercise in confirming what you basically already know. Napoleon had the habit of mentally rehearsing all kinds of possible situations before fighting a battle. He did this over and over again, often for months beforehand. What will the enemy do if I do such-and-such? Where will the enemy camp? Where will he set up an ambush? Which route will his army take?
When Napoleon arrived at the battlefield, he definitely didn몭t send out scouts with vague instructions to 몬go find out what몭s going on with the enemy.몭 Instead, he would give clear, specific instructions to each reconnaissance team, instructing them exactly where to go to check for any signs of an enemy presence.
