In other words, Napoleon몭s approach to reconnaissance wasn몭t to cast a wide net, but to send people to very specific locations, along very specific routes, to either confirm or rule out his earlier assessments.
Meanwhile, be invisible. Hide your intentions and your actions, so that the enemy cannot see what the shape of your army is, or where your weak and strong points are. Then, he몭ll have to divide his troops between many different places, just to be ready for anything you might do. Meanwhile, you몭re free to concentrate your troops wherever his weak points are. So, you몭re concentrated, while your enemy몭s divided.

몮We can form a single united body, while the enemy must split up into fractions. Hence there will be a whole pitted against separate parts of a whole, which means that we shall be many to the enemy몭s few.몯

Du You comments: 몮I can form a single united body, which means that I have more soldiers, while the enemy must split up into fractions, meaning he has fewer soldiers.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮I am able to see where the enemy몭s weak and strong points are, so I need not make excessive preparations, but can concentrate my forces into a single, united body. The enemy, however, cannot do this. He cannot see the form of my army, so he must split up his army into fractions and distribute them between many places, in order to be adequately prepared for me. This means that I can fight with a ten-to-one numerical advantage, so no matter how I choose to fight, the numerical advantage will be mine, and no matter how the enemy fights, he will be outnumbered.몯

몮And if we are able thus to attack an inferior force with a superior one, then I will be fighting against a limited force.몯

Seeing the enemy몭s weak and strong points in a single glance, you can concentrate your troops on a single point, and the enemy won몭t know where you몭re going to attack from. So, he몭ll have to cover all his bases in terms of where he deploys his troops, meaning there will be fewer of his soldiers available to fight you. This is what it means to be able to 몬attack an inferior force with a superior force.몭몯

몮The spot where we intend to fight must not be made known; for then the enemy will have to prepare against a possible attack at several different points; and his forces being thus distributed in many directions, the numbers we shall have to face at any given point will be proportionately few. For should the enemy strengthen his van, he will weaken his rear; should he strengthen his rear, he will weaken his van; should he strengthen his left, he will weaken his right; should he strengthen his right, he will weaken his left. If he sends reinforcements everywhere, he will everywhere be weak.몯


The enemy doesn몭t know where I몭m going to come at him from. He doesn몭t know where the point of engagement will be, so he몭ll need to be prepared to defend against me in more places. The more places he needs to defend, the fewer military assets he몭ll be able to commit to engage my troops. If he beefs up his forward units, he몭ll be weakening his rear units, and vice versa. The same goes for his two flanks. And if he tries to strengthen all of his positions 멪 forward, rear, right and left 멪 he몭ll be weakening himself across the board.

몮Numerical weakness comes from having to prepare against possible attacks; numerical strength, from compelling our adversary to make these preparations against us.몯

When troop numbers are stretched thin and their battle capability weakened, it몭s because they몭re put in a passive position, forced to plan and account for their enemies. 
When troop numbers are kept high and battle capability strong, it몭s because the commander has been able to force the enemy to plan and account for them.
Du Mu comments: 몮You must not allow the enemy to know where you will engage him. I do not leak any information about my situation, and so the enemy knows nothing about my left and right flanks, my forward and rear positions, how far or close I may be, and what dangers or openings there may be, and nor will he know from which direction I will attack or where our forces will meet. Therefore, he will divide his soldiers so as to guard all possible points of attack. He who keeps his situation concealed will possess numerical superiority; he who divides his troops across most positions will be at a numerical disadvantage. Therefore, victory will surely belong to he who has numerical superiority, while defeat will be the sure fate of he who is disadvantaged numerically.몯

몮For should the enemy strengthen his van, he will weaken his rear; should he strengthen his rear, he will weaken his van; should he strengthen his left, he will weaken his right; should he strengthen his right, he will weaken his left. If he sends reinforcements everywhere, he will everywhere be weak.몯 

This is the most fundamental principle, and it also applies to everything we do in our own lives. You have to choose one option; you can몭t just have all the options for yourself. If you try to hold on to all the options, then you몭ll end up losing all of them. And yet, humans are greedy 멪 when they get hold of one thing, they immediately start thinking about getting the next thing, and so they ultimately lose both.


When and where should the fighting start? Let the enemy choose

Extract from the original text:
몮Knowing the place and the time of the coming battle, we may march from the greatest distances in order to fight. But if neither time nor place be known, then the left wing will be impotent to succor the right, the right equally impotent to succor the left, the van unable to relieve the rear, or the rear to support the van. How much more so if the furthest portions of the army are anything under a hundred li apart, and even the nearest are separated by several li! Though according to my estimate the soldiers of Yue exceed our own in number, that shall advantage them nothing in the matter of victory. I say then that victory can be achieved. Though the enemy be stronger in numbers, we may prevent him from fighting.몯

Analysis:
몮Knowing the place and the time of the coming battle, we may march from the greatest distances in order to fight.몯
If you are capable of predicting where and when a fight몭s going to happen, you몭ll be able to take the fight to the enemy, even if you몭ve just marched 1,000 li.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Use measurements and knowledge of space to find out on what day battle will take place.몯
Meng Shi comments: 몮Using measurements and knowledge of space, you can know the terrain of the battle location, as well as the time when you will encounter your enemy there. Then, you can plan your battle from 1000 li away, and once you arrive, you can set an ambush and wait for your enemy. If, on the other hand, the enemy arrives before you, and takes control of the best terrain, you can choose not to go, leaving the enemy with nothing to show for their efforts. 
Earlier on, we looked at how Wang Yangming destroyed the Prince of Ning. When the prince launched his uprising, he몭d surrounded the city of Anqing with a large army. The reality on the ground was that, if he took Anqing, he몭d be able to move unobstructed down the Yangzi River, and Nanjing would be his for the taking. As soon as he entered Nanjing, he몭d have the political clout to rally more people behind him.
From Wang Yangming몭s position, in order to put down the rebellion, he몭d first have to work out where and on what day his forces would engage the Prince of Ning몭s army. He only had a small, hastily thrown-together army to achieve his aims, so where should the fight take place? Well, since the prince  was at that moment carrying out a ferocious assault on the city of Anqing, of course, he should save Anqing. However, if he did choose to go to Anqing, there was no guarantee that he몭d be able to save the city. The Prince of Ning might actually be preparing for him to march to Anqing 멪 it might even be his plan to use the siege as a way to lure Wang Yangming, and beat him on the road.
 Wang Yangming decided to gamble, but on what? His gamble was to attack the Prince of Ning몭s base, Nanchang, betting that the prince would abandon Anqing and rush back to save Nanchang. If Wang몭s gamble was right and the Prince of Ning did rush back, he몭d have the chance to plan the battle location from afar. So, where should it be? Not at Nanchang. Wang planned to catch the prince near Poyang Lake, while he was still traveling, and fight a decisive battle there. 
This is what it means to 몬know the place and time of the coming battle.몭
Was this a stroke of brilliance by Wang Yangming? Actually, he was just gambling, and it was the only thing he could do. There was also a potentially fatal problem with his plan: what was Wang supposed to do if the Prince of Ning didn몭t come back to Nanchang? If he did decide to give up Nanchang, and just continued his siege of Anqing, the city would be at serious risk of falling. If Anqing fell, Nanjing would be as good as lost, too, and the rebellious prince could march into Nanjing and proclaim himself Emperor.
But, Wang Yangming bet that the Prince of Ning didn몭t have the wisdom or the boldness to pursue this course of action. As it happened, Wang won that bet. As soon as Wang entered Nanchang, the prince immediately called off his siege of Anqing, even though he had the place on the brink of collapse, and pulled his armies back to Nanchang. His bet paid off 멪 after a fierce battle at Poyang Lake, the Prince of Ning became his prisoner.
In our second historical example, Zhou Yafu, a Han dynasty Imperial general, put down a rebellion led by the Liu Pi, Prince of Wu. The prince was looking to attack the capital city, Luoyang, from the east. On the road west, he would have to move through the state of Liang, which had been given to Emperor Jing몭s younger brother, Liu Wu, the Prince of Liang. The rebel armies, from Wu and Chu, inflicted a heavy defeat on the Liang army at Jibi, in the south of Liang. The Liang authorities sounded the alarm bells and requested imperial backup. However, Zhou Yafu was firmly ensconced in his camp, safe behind high walls and a deep moat. Every day, messengers from the Prince of Liang arrived in Zhou Yafu몭s camp, but Zhou Yafu obstinately refused to come to Liang몭s rescue. So, the Prince of Liang wrote a petition to Emperor Jing, who then sent an envoy to Zhou Yafu몭s camp, with orders to come to Liang몭s aid. But Zhou Yafu still didn몭t move. He took the prerogative of the general in the field who does not always listen to his sovereign몭s commands.
While Zhou Yafu let the Prince of Liang and the Wu armies fight a bitter war between themselves, he quietly sent a unit of light cavalry to cut the Wu and Chu supply lines. The Wu army soon was short on grain, and facing the reality of starvation. Liu Pi knew that Zhou Yafu was behind this, so he moved to attack Zhou몭s camp. But Zhou stayed put behind his fortifications; he still had no intention of getting involved in a fight.
As the Wu soldiers struggled to stave off starvation, their fighting capability began to weaken, and so Liu Pi decided to withdraw. Bearing in mind the tenet of 몬knowing the place and the time of the coming battle,몭 Zhou Yafu몭s time had now come, and he몭d chosen the location: an area of level ground in Huaibei. Because the bulk of the Wu army was infantry, fighting on level ground limited the danger for Zhou Yafu몭s imperial Han army, which had a higher proportion of cavalry, while also giving them an advantage 멪 level ground is the absolute best terrain for fighting running battles. With Zhou Yafu in command, the Han army ran the rebel troops off the field and crushed the Wu forces.
It took no longer than three months to put down the Wu and Chu uprisings, which is incredibly fast. Zhou Yafu gained widespread respect and admiration for his vision and his impeccable planning, from the Emperor to the court ministers and imperial generals. But, there was one person who felt nothing but a deep hatred for Zhou Yafu: the Prince of Liang, Liu Wu. The prince was outraged that Zhou Yafu had essentially served him to the enemy on a plate, and left him to fight the entire war on his own, almost losing his fiefdom and his life in the process. From his perspective, all that Zhou Yafu did was to wait until the enemy was almost dead from starvation, and then gave them a little shove. The enemy collapsed, and the victory was chalked up entirely to Zhou Yafu몭s 몬impeccable planning.몭

몮But if neither time nor place be known, then the left wing will be impotent to succor the right, the right equally impotent to succor the left, the van unable to relieve the rear, or the rear to support the van. How much more so if the furthest portions of the army are anything under a hundred li apart, and even the nearest are separated by several li!몯

Zhang Yu comments that, if you don몭t know where the enemy has gathered his troops, or when the battle will happen, your preparations won몭t be focused and your defensive position will not be sturdy. If you몭re suddenly faced with a powerful enemy thrust, you몭ll be forced to take hasty action, and the different parts of your army won몭t be able to help one another, especially if they are separated over distances of dozens of li.
In both of the two historical examples we몭ve just looked at, the antagonists 멪 The Prince of Ning, Zhu Chenhao (Ming dynasty); and the Prince of Wu, Liu Pi (Han dynasty) 멪 both had the location and timing of their battles dictated by their opponent. How could they not lose?

몮Though according to my estimate the soldiers of Yue exceed our own in number, that shall advantage them nothing in the matter of victory. I say then that victory can be achieved.몯

Sun Tzu몭s wrote The Art of War for Helu, King of Wu. The states of Wu and Yue had long been enemies, which is why Sun Tzu used Yue as the antagonist in this passage. The story of the war between Goujian of Yue and Fuchai of Wu is a well-known cultural reference point for Chinese people 멪 Fuchai was Helu몭s son.

몮Though the enemy be stronger in numbers, we may prevent him from fighting.몯

So, victory can be engineered even if the enemy has more troops, because it몭s possible to put the enemy in a position where he can몭t fight.
In Chapter Four, Formations, Sun Tzu says: 몮One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it,몯 which can also be interpreted as 몬victory may be known, but not engineered.몭 And yet, here he몭s saying that 몬victory can be achieved (engineered).몭 Is he contradicting himself? Actually, no, because the context is different.
He몭s talking about different situations in these two cases. For example, in the case of Wang Yangming몭s conflict with the Prince of Ning, if Wang had had enough resources, or enough time, it would have been a situation where 몬victory can be known, but not engineered,몭 and Wang몭s best choice would be to fight slow and steady. But when the Prince of Ning rebelled, the imperial government was caught unprepared, and Wang was left without the backup of the imperial army. He had to deal with the rebellious prince immediately, with only the resources already at his disposal. Wang couldn몭t let the prince get to Nanjing. In this situation, the only option is to make victory happen 멪 몮Though the enemy be stronger in numbers, we may prevent him from fighting.몯 In the end, Wang Yangming몭s gamble paid off. Though the Prince of Ning commanded a powerful force, Wang was able to stop him from attacking Anqing and gaining entry to Nanjing, and managed to summon him to Poyang Lake. In effect, the prince willingly carted himself off to the executioner.


The key tactical elements of knowing yourself and knowing your enemy

Extract from the original text:
몮Scheme so as to discover his plans and the likelihood of their success. Rouse him, and learn the principle of his activity or inactivity. Force him to reveal himself, so as to find out the ground of life and death. Carefully compare the opposing army with your own, so that you may know where strength is superabundant and where it is deficient.몯

Analysis:
몮If you know yourself and you know your enemy, you can fight a hundred battles unscathed.몯 The idea of 몬knowing몭 before fighting a battle is about the 몬Five Factors and Seven Considerations몭 referred to in Chapter One, Calculations. The five factors are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and Discipline. 몬The seven considerations몭 are: (1) Which of the two kings is imbued with the Moral Law? (2) Which of the two generals has the most ability? (3) With whom lie the advantages derived from Heaven and Earth? (4) On which side is discipline most rigorously enforced? (5) Which army is stronger? (6) On which side are officers and men more highly trained? (7) In which army is there the greater consistency both in reward and punishment?
The five factors and seven considerations deal in terms of politics, resources, strength and strategy. But how do you go about knowing the enemy in terms of tactics, once you몭re already on the battlefield? That몭s exactly what we몭re going to talk about next.

몮Scheme so as to discover his plans and the likelihood of their success.몯

Meng Shi comments: 몮Scheme and measure the enemy몭s situation, and observe his work; thus, you will know the likelihood of success.몯
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮I already know, through my calculation and scheming, the likelihood of the enemy either succeeding or failing.몯
In sum, it몭s basically about analyzing the plans of both yourself and your enemy, and deducing who will win and who will lose.

몮Rouse him, and learn the principle of his activity or inactivity.몯

몬Rousing몭 the enemy is about prodding him, irritating him so that he does something unnecessary, and then watching where he moves and where he stays still. Then, you will know where his weak and strong points are. This is also similar to 몬reconnaissance by fire,몭 which we have mentioned before.
Duke Wu of Wei once asked his advisor, Wu Qi: 몮What is to be done if, when my army meets with that of the enemy, I do not know how great or how limited my opponent몭s leadership skills are?몯
Wu Qi replied: 몮Send a small detachment of brave soldiers to launch a stinging attack on him, but order them to feign defeat and retreat as soon as they engage, and then observe how the enemy acts. If his forces pursue your men, but pretend to be unable to keep up, and pretend not to see the weapons, flags and other valuable objects discarded by your fleeing troops, then he is a general of great wisdom. But if they pursue with their entire army in a confused mass of motion and flags, and if they are greedy for spoils and loot, then your opponent몭s leadership skills are second-rate, and you may prepare to launch a general offensive against him directly.

몮Force him to reveal himself, so as to find out the ground of life and death.몯

One way of forcing the enemy to reveal himself is to 몬rouse him, and learn the principle of his activity or inactivity.몭
Du Mu comments: 몮몬The ground of life and death몭 refers to strong and weak points on the battlefield. I must use a multitude of methods to deceive the enemy, observe how he reacts, and then bring him under my control. Thus, I know the 몬ground of life and death.몭몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮If I use weakness to reveal my enemy, I lure him to advance towards me. If I use strength to reveal my enemy, I force him to retreat. When he is advancing or retreating, I know the 몬ground of life and death몭 as concerns the ground he is occupying.몯

몮Carefully compare the opposing army with your own, so that you may know where strength is superabundant and where it is deficient.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Here, 몬comparing몭 refers to measuring.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮Here, 몬comparing몭 refers to making measurements. I use my areas of abundance to measure the enemy몭s areas of abundance; I use my areas of inadequacy to measure the enemy몭s areas of inadequacy.몯
In the ancient philosophical text, The Guanzi, it is written: 몮Thus, those who are skilled at attacking learn the enemy몭s numbers by attacking them, learn the enemy몭s food stores by attacking his food stores, and learn the enemy몭s level of preparation by attacking his preparations. If the enemy possesses numerical superiority, do not attack; if he possesses superiority in food stores, do not attack; if he is well prepared, do not attack. Stay away from areas of strength, and attack weak points; stay away from places where the enemy is sturdy, and attack where he is weak; stay away from areas of difficulty, and attack where it is easy.몯
For our historical example for this passage, let몭s look back once more at Sima Yi몭s campaign to put down the rebellion in Liaodong. We몭ve already talked about this example twice, and the principle of appraising the enemy몭s plans is yet another point that relates to Sima Yi몭s experience. During that campaign in Liaodong, Sima Yi had 40,000 troops compared to Gong Sunxiao몭s 200,000. As mentioned earlier, Gong Sunxiao sent a vanguard force of a few tens of thousands of troops to guard the River Liao. He personally commanded the main force, which was to act as a relief force for the vanguard, thus blocking Sima Yi몭s forward progress from a distance of several dozen li. Sima Yi used part of his army to pin down the enemy, and then quietly led an elite force around the enemy lines, across the River Liao, and directly to Gong Sunxiao몭s powerbase, the city of Rangping, which he then besieged. This is the stratagem of 몬Forcing him to move by attacking a place where he is bound to come to the rescue; to leave him with no option but to fight, despite having strong defensive fortifications.몭 Gong Sunxiao was forced to move, to protect Rangping, and while on the road, he was defeated three times by Sima Yi몭s forces. He eventually retreated behind Rangping몭s city walls, where he took up a defensive position. This is what it means to 몬surround an enemy position in order to destroy his relief force; know on what day and in what location the battle will be fought.몭
When Sima Yi arrived in Liaodong, it was the seventh month of the year 멪 the beginning of the wet season. Once the rains started, they didn몭t stop for a whole month, so Sima Yi hunkered down with his army and didn몭t move. He was in no rush. One of his officers, Chen Gui, asked him: 몮Back when Meng Da rebelled, we marched against him with eight armies, day and night for eight days. We moved 1,200 li, took Meng Da몭s fortress, and executed him. Today, we have come a great distance to Liaodong, yet we are sitting here, taking our ease, and drawing up plans at a leisurely pace. It must be because of my stupidity, but to tell the truth, I cannot understand this.몯
Sima Yi replied: 몮What we are doing is measuring the enemy몭s numbers and the amount of his food stores. Meng Da did not have many men, and his food stores were enough to feed his army for a year. Our army had four times the numbers of Meng Da몭s, and our food stores were only enough to last for a month. When you have a month몭s store of food, and your enemy has a year몭s, you naturally need to act quickly. That몭s why we had to beat Meng Da, without worrying too much about our own casualties. In truth, it was not Meng Da whom we were fighting against; we were racing against time to finish the war before our food stores ran out. If we failed to do that, our men would have starved to death. As for this campaign, though it is true we have travelled a great distance, we have brought ample food stores, whereas our enemy will soon run out of food. The enemy has more troops than us, so while he starves, we will be well fed. So, the situation now is precisely the opposite of when we fought against Meng Da. This rain does not make for good fighting weather, which is perfect for us 멪 we are all using up our food supplies, so what need is there to hurry?몯
After thirty days, the rain stopped and Sima Yi finally began his attack. In Pingrang, the food shortage was so severe that people had taken to cannibalism. Many enemy officers surrendered, Sima Yi successfully took Pingrang. He executed Gong Sunxiao and restored stability to Liaodong.


If you learn from me, you몭ll survive; If you imitate me, you몭re dead

Surface-level things 멪 the things that people see and talk about 멪 are never the things that are truly important. There are essentially two threads that contain what is really crucial. The first is the current situation, conditions and pre-planning, and the second is the skill that you, as an individual, have accumulated over many years. Typically, people who learn from other people don몭t have any grasp on the second of these threads, and don몭t even know about the first thread. Their way of studying is to follow the crowd, so naturally their studies amount to nothing.

Extract from the original text:
몮In making tactical dispositions, the highest excellence you can attain is to make them without form; when your dispositions are without form, then you will be safe from the prying of the subtlest spies, from the machinations of the wisest brains. With varying formation, victory is achieved, yet although it is placed before the people, they do not know how it came to be. All men can see the tactics whereby I conquer, but what none can see is the strategy out of which victory is evolved. Do not repeat the tactics which have gained you one victory, but let your methods be regulated by the infinite variety of circumstances.몯

Analysis:
몮In making tactical dispositions, the highest excellence you can attain is to make them without form.몯
몬Making tactical dispositions몭 actually means showing the enemy a certain shape or form in the way your army is deployed. It몭s also about making false movements, which are meant as feints, but might also turn into a real move at any moment. This uncertainty is intentional 멪 it몭s about selling the enemy a deceptive impression, just like Emperor Taizong meant when he said: 몮Use a multitude of diverse methods to fool one몭s foe.몯 The point is to come up with a way, any way, to trick the enemy into slipping up and making an error of judgment. So, 몬In making tactical dispositions, the highest excellence you can attain,몭 and the absolute best way to show the enemy your form is to make your form infinitely variable, to the point that your army becomes 몬without form.몭 Then, the enemy is either completely unable to evaluate your situation, or he accepts a pre-made 몬evaluation몭 that you give to him.

몮When your dispositions are without form, then you will be safe from the prying of the subtlest spies, from the machinations of the wisest brains.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮Here, Sun Tzu says that there is no more perfect way to use armed force than to employ formlessness. When you are formless, then though agents may come deep within my ranks to spy on me, they will be unable to perceive my weak and strong points. Because there is no leaked information about my strengths and weaknesses, even wise and capable men will be unable to devise schemes against me.몯

몮With varying formation, victory is achieved, yet although it is placed before the people, they do not know how it came to be.몯

몬Showing one몭s form몭 is a way of misleading the enemy; 몬formlessness몭 is about the dimensions within which you use your army.  몬Varying formation몭 is about changing your formation and choosing the right approach in response to the enemy몭s situation and unfolding events.
In the original Chinese text, it몭s not entirely clear how readers should interpret 몬although it is placed before the people, they do not understand how it came to be.몭 Li Quan provides a clear explanation in his commentary. In the story of Sima Yi몭s expedition to Liaodong, in the previous subchapter, none of Sima Yi몭s subordinates understood what exactly his plan was, right up until he crushed Gong Sunxiao몭s army and executed the rebel leader. That몭s why we saw Chen Gui asking Sima Yi to explain what was going on.

몮All men can see the tactics whereby I conquer, but what none can see is the strategy out of which victory is evolved. Do not repeat the tactics which have gained you one victory, but let your methods be regulated by the infinite variety of circumstances.몯

It몭s clear for anyone to see what formation I use, and how I deploy my troops, yet nobody can tell how I responded to the enemy몭s formation so effectively that I won the battle. In the next battle I fight, the enemy몭s situation will be different. And so, because it몭s about responding to the situation in front of me, I won몭t use the same approach, and indeed I never use the same approach twice. There몭s an infinite number of possible variations, which are all based on the situation at hand.
Let몭s look at the meaning of this subchapter몭s heading: 몬If you learn from me, you몭ll survive; if you imitate me, you몭re dead.몭 If you watch how someone else wins a battle, and then try to copy them exactly, you몭ll end up in a terrible mess. Why? Because you haven몭t understood how the person you몭re trying to learn from actually won. He did things a certain way based on the current situation and circumstances. When you try to copy their approach, the situation and circumstances that you몭re facing are completely different. Also, when you saw the general you몭re trying to copy using a certain approach, that approach was not something that just happened in isolation. There was also a wider context of conditions and factors at play before the battle happened, all of which the successful general has to take into account. But you didn몭t do any of this. You just made a crude copy of what you saw, with the mindset that if it worked for other people, then it should work for you, too. And that몭s why it몭s all going to go pear-shaped for you.
Let몭s take another quick look at Han Xin몭s battle by the river, where he put his army of 10,000 men in a place of mortal danger, with their backs to the deep river, and yet he survived. It worked because his men had no escape route 멪 they had to fight and win, or else die. That몭s how they defeated 200,000 enemy troops that day.
But is that really what happened?
If the fighting had lasted a little longer, Han Xin몭s 10,000 troops would have been wiped out. Or, if the enemy commander had ordered his troops to lower their weapons and stand down, some of Han Xin몭s men would have surrendered there and then. But, Han Xin also had a force of 2,000 cavalry, which he used to attack the Zhao camp, tear down the Zhao banners, and replace them with their own Han banners. When the Zhao troops saw that they몭d lost their base camp, they panicked and began to run. That was the moment when the tide turned for Han Xin, when the conditions were right for him to pounce on his enemy.
The crucial factor in that battle was the unit of 2,000 cavalry. We몭re now all familiar with how Han Xin won the battle, even with his back to the river, and the idea of winning with your back to the river has become an idiom in the modern Chinese language. But would you have the courage to intentionally fight a battle with your back to a river? Han Xin himself only did this once 멪 he changed his approach in the very next battle he fought[bd18].
Another important point is that, to study the art of war, you need to also look at it through the lens of a devil몭s advocate. You should spend a lot of time thinking about worst-case scenarios, instead of assuming that things will go well. The first aspect of this is to not study how to make calculations about other people, but how to make other people unable to make calculations about you. Also, don몭t think that you can win by using the formula: 몬I am formless, I show the enemy a form, I deceive the enemy, and then I attain victory.몭 As pleasing as this approach might seem, don몭t allow yourself to be too delighted by it, or when you몭re actually on a battlefield you몭ll find that the fun won몭t last for long. You need to play devil몭s advocate 멪 turn the formula upside down, and as you read each line, imagine yourself as the person who is being 몬shown forms몭 by the enemy. Don몭t allow yourself to be misled, don몭t act without thinking things through, prioritize protecting yourself, and only then allow your thoughts to turn to working out the enemy. This is the true way of the art of war.
We read books and study as a way of projecting what we learn onto ourselves. We take it for granted that we should put ourselves in the role of the winner, and we internalize the emotions and mindset of the winner, because it몭s human nature to do so. But, it몭s important to remember to look at the reverse side of things: to imagine yourself in the role of the loser, and to spend time thinking about how to avoid defeat. This is what you have to do if you want to learn more. 
When studying the art of war, first study how not to lose, and only then move on to how to win. Indeed, the starting point of the whole of the art of war is the question of not losing. The art of war does not begin with victory.


Victory and defeat are not equal; Victory brings nothing more than a few spoils, but defeat means you might lose your life

Extract from the original text:
몮Military forms are like unto water; for water in its natural course runs away from high places and hastens downwards. So in war, the way is to avoid what is strong and to strike at what is weak. Water shapes its course according to the nature of the ground over which it flows; the soldier works out his victory in relation to the foe whom he is facing. Therefore, just as water retains no constant shape, so in warfare there are no constant conditions. He who can modify his tactics in relation to his opponent, and thereby succeed in winning, may be called a heaven-born captain. The five elements (water, fire, wood, metal, earth) are not always equally predominant; the four seasons make way for each other in turn. There are short days and long; the moon has its periods of waning and waxing.몯

Analysis:
This is the final subchapter of Chapter Six, and it shall be used as a summary of Weak Points and Strong.

몮Military forms are like unto water; for water in its natural course runs away from high places and hastens downwards. So in war, the way is to avoid what is strong and to strike at what is weak.몯

The way wars are fought is like water. When water moves, it always follows the same pattern: flowing from high places to low places. Similarly, the pattern to follow in war is to stay away from places where the enemy is strong, and strike him where he is weak. Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Water flows smoothly when it is moving downhill, and battles unfold advantageously when striking the enemy몭s weak points.몯

몮Water shapes its course according to the nature of the ground over which it flows; the soldier works out his victory in relation to the foe whom he is facing.몯

The above passage is quite self-explanatory.


몮Therefore, just as water retains no constant shape, so in warfare there are no constant conditions. He who can modify his tactics in relation to his opponent, and thereby succeed in winning, may be called a heaven-born captain.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Energy comes from responding to the enemy.몯 As the enemy changes, I change in response. That몭s why 몬in warfare there are no constant conditions,몭 just as water never stays in any one form. When water comes upon a square-shaped space, it becomes a square, and when it enters a circular space, it becomes a circle. If you can find a way to victory based on how the enemy몭s situation changes, you have practically become a god of war.

몮The five elements (water, fire, wood, metal, earth) are not always equally predominant; the four seasons make way for each other in turn. There are short days and long; the moon has its periods of waning and waxing.몯

Each of the five elements 멪 metal, wood, water, fire and earth 멪 subdues one of the other elements, but none of them is able to permanently overpower all of the others. The four seasons 멪 spring, summer, fall and winter 멪 constantly replace one another, and none of them can last for a whole year. The days grow long and then short, and the moon waxes and then wanes. In this passage, Sun Tzu uses all of these natural phenomena as an analogy. He몭s telling us that since all of these things experience periods of growth and decline, how could anyone ever set in stone the constantly fluctuating forms of war? 
We have now reached the end of Chapter Six, Weak Points and Strong. To sum up the chapter몭s essential message, we can look at a comment by Cao Cao: 몮It is about being able to use weak points and strong, both your own and the enemy몭s.몯 As you move your forces this way and that, the objective is to put yourself in a position of strength, and the enemy in a position of weakness 멪 this is how you can become like a god of war.
However, as we learn to fight like a god of war, the most important thing to understand is that you are not a god. It몭s therefore impossible for your troop movements to always put you in a position of strength and the enemy in a position of weakness. More likely, you몭ll find yourself in a position of weakness and your enemy in a position of strength. So, if you can double down on being cautious, you could at least say that your studies of the art of war have not been for nothing. 
Victory and defeat are a question of wisdom, of strength, and also of probability. But, in terms of results, victory and defeat are usually not of equal value. All that you get from victory is some spoils of war, but if you몭re defeated, you몭re liable to lose your life. 
In Questions and Replies between Emperor Taizong of Tang and Duke Li of Wei, there몭s a whole chapter dedicated to weak and strong points, in which Emperor Taizong says: 몮I have read all of the military treatises, and none surpasses Sun Tzu몭s. Within Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, the best of the best is the chapter on Weak Points and Strong. If, as a commander of soldiers, one can distinguish between weak points and strong, then one will sweep to victory wherever one goes. Every general is prone to say that they avoid their enemies몭 strong points while attacking their weak points, yet once they are upon the battlefield, they cannot perceive their enemy몭s weak and strong points. As a result, it is not they who move the enemy where they will, but the enemy who moves them. What do you make of this problem?몯
Duke Li of Wei replied: 몮To perceive weak points and strong, one must first understand 몬the main and the auxiliary.몭 Most military leaders do not know how to use a main force as an auxiliary force and vice versa, so how could they properly identify when a strong point is a weak point, and a weak point is a strong point? The main and the auxiliary are used to manipulate the enemy몭s weak and strong points 멪 where the enemy is strong, I must use my main force; where the enemy is weak, I must use my auxiliary force. Without an understanding of the usages of the main and the auxiliary, then even if one is able to perceive the enemy몭s weak and strong points, one will still be unable to attack them.몯
Then, Emperor Taizong said: 몮When I use my auxiliary force as my main force, my enemy thinks that I am using my auxiliary force, when in fact it is my main force with which I am striking him. Or, the enemy thinks I am using my main force, when in fact it is my auxiliary force with which I am striking him. Thus, the enemy is in a constant position of weakness, while I am in a constant position of strength.몯
This passage ends with a summary by Duke Li of Wei: 몮Countless words have been written on this subject, but essentially, the message never ventures beyond this idea: 몬Manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated.몭몯
The duke몭s summary forms a pair with the principle of winning by responding to your enemy몭s situation. When the idea of manipulating your foe while avoiding being manipulated yourself is taken to an extreme, it becomes: 몬I don몭t care what your deal is; I only care what my deal is.몭 Above all else, it몭s about not being manipulated by your enemy, not giving him any opportunities and forcing him to endure a long wait. In fact, it몭s totally viable to not even fight at all, because the one thing that you absolutely must do is to win first and fight later.
Winning by responding to the enemy몭s situation is about basing decisions about where you should deploy your troops based on the enemy몭s troop movements. But, when you use this approach, it몭s easy to end up being manipulated and having your movements dictated by the enemy. This is because it몭s possible that the changes you can see in your enemy몭s situation and formation have been intentionally designed to trick you. Perhaps where you see a weak point, the reality is that it몭s the enemy몭s strong point. There몭s a great deal of danger in this strategy, and it몭s not something that just anyone is capable of pulling off.
So, to truly be an all-conquering general, you must be able to 몬manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated,몭 have a high tolerance for isolation, and be extremely patient. To reach an even higher level 멪 to fight like a god 멪 you need to be able to pluck victory from the changes in your enemy몭s situation.
In all honesty, Emperor Taizong was practically a god. When we try to learn from him, the most important thing is to remember that, unlike him, we are not gods.
Appendix: Complete text of Weak Points and Strong

Sun Tzu said: 몮Whoever is first in the field, and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will be exhausted. Therefore the clever combatant imposes his will on the enemy, but does not allow the enemy몭s will to be imposed on him. By holding out advantages to him, he can cause the enemy to approach of his own accord; or, by inflicting damage, he can make it impossible for the enemy to draw near. If the enemy is taking his ease, he can harass him; if well supplied with food, he can starve him out; if quietly encamped, he can force him to move. Appear at points which the enemy will not be quick enough to defend; march swiftly to places where you are not expected. An army may march great distances without distress, if it marches through country where the enemy is not. You can be sure of succeeding in your attacks if you only attack places which are undefended. You can ensure the safety of your defense if you only hold positions that cannot be attacked. Hence that general is skillful in attack whose opponent does not know what to defend; and he is skillful in defense whose opponent does not know what to attack. Oh divine art of subtlety and secrecy! Through you we learn to be invisible, through you inaudible; and hence we can hold the enemy몭s fate in our hands. You may advance and be absolutely irresistible, if you make for the enemy몭s weak points; you may retire and be safe from pursuit if your movements are more rapid than those of the enemy. If we wish to fight, the enemy can be forced to an engagement even though he be sheltered behind a high rampart and a deep ditch. All we need do is attack some other place that he will be obliged to relieve. If we do not wish to fight, we can prevent the enemy from engaging us even though the lines of our encampment be merely traced out on the ground. All we need do is to throw something odd and unaccountable in his way. Knowing the place and the time of the coming battle, we may march from the greatest distances in order to fight. But if neither time nor place be known, then the left wing will be impotent to succor the right, the right equally impotent to succor the left, the van unable to relieve the rear, or the rear to support the van. How much more so if the furthest portions of the army are anything under a hundred li apart, and even the nearest are separated by several li! Though according to my estimate the soldiers of Yue exceed our own in number, that shall advantage them nothing in the matter of victory. I say then that victory can be achieved. Though the enemy be stronger in numbers, we may prevent him from fighting. Scheme so as to discover his plans and the likelihood of their success. Rouse him, and learn the principle of his activity or inactivity. Force him to reveal himself, so as to find out the ground of life and death. Carefully compare the opposing army with your own, so that you may know where strength is superabundant and where it is deficient. In making tactical dispositions, the highest excellence you can attain is to make them without form; when your dispositions are without form, then you will be safe from the prying of the subtlest spies, from the machinations of the wisest brains. With varying formation, victory is achieved, yet although it is placed before the people, they do not know how it came to be. All men can see the tactics whereby I conquer, but what none can see is the strategy out of which victory is evolved. Do not repeat the tactics which have gained you one victory, but let your methods be regulated by the infinite variety of circumstances. Military forms are like unto water; for water in its natural course runs away from high places and hastens downwards. So in war, the way is to avoid what is strong and to strike at what is weak. Water shapes its course according to the nature of the ground over which it flows; the soldier works out his victory in relation to the foe whom he is facing. Therefore, just as water retains no constant shape, so in warfare there are no constant conditions. He who can modify his tactics in relation to his opponent and thereby succeed in winning, may be called a heaven-born captain. The five elements (water, fire, wood, metal, earth) are not always equally predominant; the four seasons make way for each other in turn. There are short days and long; the moon has its periods of waning and waxing.몯


Chapter Seven
Armed struggle

When you make projections based on the art of war, it all seems so perfect, yet once you몭re on the battlefield, you forget all about the art of war

Extract from the original text:
몮In war, the general receives his commands from the sovereign. Having collected an army and concentrated his forces, he must blend and harmonize the different elements thereof before pitching his camp. After that, comes tactical maneuvering, than which there is nothing more difficult.몯

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: 몮Armed struggle is about two armies vying for victory.몯 Once the weak and strong points have been established, then you can maneuver yourself into a tactical advantage.몯 This is why this chapter is positioned immediately after Weak Points and Strong.

몮Having collected an army and concentrated his forces멞몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Assembling the people of the country, forming fighting units, selecting officers, establishing camps 멪 hence battle formations are drawn.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Assembling people from across the country is how armies are built; gathering the soldiers together is how battle formations are drawn.몯
So, what we몭re talking about here is a nationwide mobilization: recruiting soldiers, and then forming armies and sending your forces into the field. 

몮He must blend and harmonize the different elements thereof before pitching his camp.몯


When you come face to face with the enemy, set up camp.
Cao Cao comments: 몮The gate of an army camp is called the 몬gate of harmony.몭 Gates to the left and the right are called the 몬banner gates.몭 The gate of a camp made of chariots bound together is called the 몬axel gate.몭 The gate of a camp made by men is called the 몬human gate.몭 When the two armies face one another, the different elements of the army are blended and harmonized.몯
There몭s a famous story in China about a warrior named Lu Bu, who managed to avert a battle with a wager that he could shoot a very difficult target 멪 the blade of a halberd, a battle-axe topped with a spike 멪  with an arrow. In the story, Lu Bu is standing by the axel gate. From Cao Cao몭s comment, we know that the name 몬axel gate몭 was used specifically for a gate made of chariot axel rods, while the main gate in an army camp was known as the 몬gate of harmony.몭 He Shi comments: 몮Facing the enemy at the gate of harmony, the general assembles his forces for battle and prepares to vie with the enemy for tactical advantage. This is a difficult task which military commanders face.몯

몮After that, comes tactical maneuvering, than which there is nothing more difficult.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮From the time when the general is first appointed, to the moment battle is joined, struggling for advantage is constantly difficult.몯 
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Nothing is more difficult, from being appointed as general, all the way to this juncture.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Standing opposite the enemy and vying with him for advantage is among the most difficult things in the world.몯
To put it simply, this is incredibly hard!
Earlier on, in Calculations, it was all about generals making their plans in the safety of their tents, far away from any real danger.
Later on, in Waging War and Planning Assaults, we talked about scenarios where food supplies are plentiful and armies even got the chance to eat the enemy몭s food, and where generals were free to fight if they thought they could win, or to run away, which they몭d definitely do if they weren몭t sure of winning.
Then, in Formations and Energy, we talked about various situations involving formations and energy, and about organizing armies, deploying troops, and how to come to decisions.
In Weak Points and Strong, we talked about probing the enemy to find out his weak and strong points, how to manipulate him and move him wherever you want, and how to stay clear of his strong points while hitting him where he몭s weak.
It몭s really quite joyful when you talk about it like that 멪  you get to beat your enemy without fighting him. He just surrenders without you having to make a single move. And, even if you do fight, you get to set yourself up in a position where you can몭t be beaten, and you still get to win before you fight. You can cycle your troop organization between main and auxiliary formations, keeping the enemy constantly guessing and never able to work you out. Then, exploiting the space in between weak and strong points, you manipulate your enemy until he몭s more obedient than your own kids. And finally, once you몭ve put him a weak position and yourself in a strong one, you crack him like an egg.
However, you have to remember that if you understand all this, other people understand it, too. If you can do it, others can as well. If you몭re actually doing it, other people are also doing it. Not only that, other people might be doing it better than you. That몭s why you have to 몬struggle,몭 and pit your courage and your wisdom against the enemy몭s. You have to fight to stay one step ahead. And so, the most difficult thing in the world is to find yourself on the battlefield, facing the enemy몭s army, knowing that the fighting몭s about to start.
Mao Zedong once said: 몮As soon as you몭re on the battlefield, you forget all about the art of war.몯
So, how are you supposed to fight? What are the principles? What do you need to remember? These questions are what Armed Struggle is all about.


Sometimes it takes longer than you think it should to do something, but that몭s just life; In the same way, spending money on things you don몭t want to spend money on is part and parcel of spending money

When the right thing to do is admit defeat, admit defeat; when the right thing to do is swallow your objections, swallow your objections. Don몭t fight just for the sake of being right, and don몭t try to right the boat when it몭s already sunk, especially if it means throwing away your capital in the effort.

Extract from the original text:
몮The difficulty of tactical maneuvering consists in turning the circuitous into the direct, and misfortune into gain. Thus, to take a long and circuitous route, after enticing the enemy out of the way, and though starting after him, to contrive to reach the goal before him, shows knowledge of the artifice of the circuitous and of the direct.몯

Analysis:
몮Turn the circuitous into the direct.몯
The quickest way of getting between point A and point B isn몭t to move in a straight line. A route that, on the surface, seems full of twists and turns is actually the easiest, most direct path. There are two reasons for this: terrain, and the enemy몭s formations. Because of these two factors, if you try to move in a straight line, you몭ll find your way forward blocked.
So, when faced with complex terrain and an enemy who is constantly shifting formation, which route is fastest? This is where you 몬turn the circuitous into the direct.몭 The quickest road is actually the one full of twists and turns. In soccer, it would be impossible to attack in a straight line from deep in your own half all the way to the opposition몭s goal posts. So, every time a player runs with the ball or passes it, they are 몬turning the circuitous into the direct.몭 Even for the 몬King of Soccer,몭 Pele, dribbling the ball in a straight line, right into the opposition goal, meant 몭turning the circuitous into the direct몭 every time his foot touched the ball. It몭s about turning adversity into advantage. 

몮Thus, take a long and circuitous route, after enticing the enemy out of the way, and though starting after him, contrive to reach the goal before him.몯

This is about intentionally choosing a long, winding route so as to give the enemy the impression that you몭re not actually planning to go to your destination. Then, you make some false moves and hold out some small enticement to gain control over your enemy, before making a sudden move straight to your destination. This is how you arrive before your enemy, even if you set out after him.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Taking a long and circuitous route is about showing the enemy that you are far away. To arrive before the enemy, even though you depart after him, you must have a clear grasp of measurements, numbers and distances.몯
If you make your enemy think that you몭re far away, they몭ll let down their guard. To arrive before the enemy, you need to work out the terrain ahead of time, including the distances of various routes and where you can cut quickly and suddenly to your destination.
Our historical example for this subchapter comes from Warring States period: how Zhao She defeated a Qin army.
The name Zhao She might sound familiar. That몭s because he was the father of Zhao Kuo, the armchair strategist we talked about earlier. However, unlike his son, Zhao She was a true and renowned general.
When Qin attacked Han, they sent an army to besiege Yuyu. The Zhao king, Huiwen, decided to go to Yuyu몭s aid, so he asked his general, Lian Po, for advice. Lian Po told him that it would be a difficult mission, because the road to Yuyu was long and narrow, and crossed through dangerous, rugged terrain. King Huiwen asked Le Cheng what he thought, and Le Cheng gave the same answer as Lian Po. Then, King Huiwen asked Zhao She, who said: 몮When enemies meet on a narrow road, victory goes to he who is bravest. Leave it to me.몯
When the Qin government found out that Zhao had dispatched an army, they sent a unit to set up a camp to the west of the city of Wu몭an. This, together with their position at Yuyu, put them in a strong position to attack any enemy force from two sides at once.
Zhao She몭s war had just gotten harder.
Zhao She, freshly appointed, gathered an army, marched out of the Handan city gate, and proceeded to set up camp after walking only 30 li. He apparently had no intention of moving any further. He let it be known around the camp, by way of a formal decree: 몮Anyone who speaks out of turn about military arrangements shall be decapitated!몯
Meanwhile, the Qin army was riding a powerful wave of energy and momentum. From their camp outside the city walls of Wu몭an, they beat the war drums to energize the troops, and the noise was so loud that it made the roof tiles inside the city shake.
But, one officer in the Zhao army camp had concerns about the commander-in-chief몭s orders not to move 멪 concerns that were too strong not to express. So, he approached Zhao She, knowing that he was risking his life, and begged him to go to war to save Wu몭an. Zhao She knew that this officer was a good man, but this was exactly what he몭d been waiting for: a good man to come to him and offer his head on a platter. This was part of his plan to 몬turn the circuitous into the direct.몭 So, he immediately ordered that the officer be taken outside and beheaded.
Zhao She kept his army in that camp for 28 days, kept on building up the camp몭s fortifications, and showed no intention whatsoever of moving out to fight. The Qin army sent a spy, and Zhao She put on a show for the agent. He convinced the spy that there was absolutely no chance that the Zhao army would move out, come hell or high water.
When the spy brought this news back to the Qin commander, he was delighted. It seemed to him that the Zhao army didn몭t have the will or the courage to fight him. It was likely that the only reason the force had been sent out in the first place was to make a show of honoring the state of Han몭s plea for help. 
Meanwhile, the moment Zhao She had seen off the Qin spy, he ordered his army to pack up their armor, along with a few, light pieces of equipment and supplies, and he set off. Moving quickly, they arrived safely at Yuyu after two days and one night몭s march, without running into a single ambush or even the slightest whiff of resistance.
Zhao She didn몭t head straight for Yuyu, but stopped about 50 li shy of the city, and set up camp in a location he몭d selected specially for its good terrain. At this point, another of his officers, a man named Xu Li, stepped forward and put his neck on the line by suggesting to Zhao She: 몮Victory will surely belong to whoever holds the northern mountains.몯 Zhao She immediately agreed with the man, and sent 10,000 troops to set up a position at the highest point in the northern mountains. 
Xu Li, who몭d suggested the mountain defense, said: 몮I have said my piece, and I am prepared to accept my death.몯
몮And why should you be put to death?몯 Zhao She asked.
몮Because멞 your decree! 몬Anyone who speaks out of turn about military arrangements shall be decapitated,몭몯 Xu Li replied.
몮We shall discuss this matter further upon our return to Handan,몯 Zhao She said, ending the discussion. (When the army eventually returned to Handan, Xu Li was promoted and given an official title: Defender in Chief.)
The Qin commander, hearing that the Zhao army had reached Yuyu, broke out in a cold sweat. He immediately pulled his army back from Wu몭an and rushed to protect the Qin position at Yuyu. But Zhao She already held the best terrain, so he won a major victory over the Qin army, resulting in the end of the Qin siege of Yuyu.
The story of this battle is a particularly gripping one.
Traveling unarmored, and with only light supplies, is a very dangerous move. After a forced march lasting two days and a night, without any supply wagons, the Zhao army had moved far away from its rear support system, and the soldiers would have been exhausted. If Zhao She had rushed straight into a confrontation with the Qin army under Yuyu몭s city walls, without pausing for a rest, he likely would have ended up as a Qin prisoner. Zhao She몭s stroke of genius lay in the fact that he camped 50 li outside of Yuyu, set up a proper defensive line and fortifications, and dug in, waiting for the Qin army to come to him. In doing this, he was putting into practice a key lesson from Weak Points and Strong: 몮Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will be exhausted.몯 If one of the two sides was exhausted, it was definitely the Zhao troops 멪 they would have been utterly spent after their forced march. But instead of heading straight for Yuyu, they pulled up 50 li short, meaning that the Qin soldiers basically had to run a marathon to get to them, wearing themselves out in the process. This turned the tables 멪 the Zhao troops rested up while they waited for their enemies to tire themselves out on the road to the battlefield.
Also in the chapter on Weak Points and Strong, we read how Duke Li of Wei said that in all the thousands of pages written about the art of war, there is nothing that isn몭t essentially saying: 몬Manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated.몭 At first, the Qin army had everything planned out. They thought they were manipulating Zhao She, because they몭d set up strong, mutually reinforcing positions at Wu몭an and Yuyu, and planned to use the stratagem of besieging a city with the main purpose of drawing in an enemy relief force, under Zhao She몭s command, and destroying it on the road. But as it turned out, the Qin forces weren몭t able to catch Zhao She, because he successfully 몬turned the circuitous into the direct,몭 materializing as if by magic outside Yuyu with his army. Once Zhao She had put the finishing touches to the location he몭d chosen for a battlefield, the roles had reversed: Zhao She was to be the gracious host, and the Qin army was to be his guests. They had to go exactly where Zhao She wanted them. 
Another passage from Weak Points and Strong says: 몮Knowing the place and the time of the coming battle, we may march from the greatest distances in order to fight.몯 Again, Zhao She did it by the book, choosing both the time and the location of the battle.
However, there몭s one question that must be asked: What it the Qin army didn몭t show up?
This was actually an option for the Qin commander 멪 once he found out that Zhao She had used the stratagem of 몬turning the circuitous into the direct,몭 and made his way to Yuyu, he could have thought things through more thoroughly. He might have realized that, since it was now a fact that the Zhao army was here, he could just work out how many days the isolated enemy force could realistically last without grain and supply wagons. He could have waited and watched, and postponed making any firm decisions. But he didn몭t. He panicked, because something had happened that he wasn몭t expecting, and because he didn몭t know what other moves Zhao She might have up his sleeve. So, he allowed himself to be swept up in his panic, and hurried off to fight. He returned from the battle that followed as a badly beaten general.
A different commander might not have fallen into Zhao She몭s trap. That would have been a real problem. In the story we looked at earlier of Wang Yangming putting down the Prince of Ning몭s rebellion, Wang Yangming really only had one card in his hand: attacking the city of Nanchang and waiting for the Prince of Ning to come to its rescue. This strategy was also an example of 몬turning the circuitous into the direct.몭  But what if the Prince of Ning didn몭t come to save Nanchang? His advisors all tried to tell him that losing Nanchang wasn몭t a big deal, because if he only managed to take Nanjing he몭d become the Emperor of all China, and he몭d be able to take back control of Nanchang by just sending a letter! But the prince panicked. He went back to Nanchang, not knowing that he was marching to his death.
In both cases, the panicked commander was like a rabbit in the headlights, choosing an escape route on blind impulse.
It몭s important to not panic, and to be able to admit defeat. Once you admit defeat, and acknowledge that the circumstances have changed, you can work out what to do about it. What you mustn몭t do is keep thinking about how to turn back time and re-create the old situation. Also, don몭t throw your capital away in an attempt to claw back your advantage. If you do that, you몭ll lose everything.
Finally 멪 and this is a bit of a tangent 멪 when you use the stratagem of 몬turning the circuitous into the direct,몭 you몭re still going after 몬the direct.몭 However, in life and personal growth, the road is inherently full of twists and turns, of forward movement and backward steps. Nothing ever goes entirely smoothly, and you can never move in a perfectly straight line. So, you have to understand this at a basic level. A winding road is a road, too, and money you don몭t want to spend is just the same as any other money. If you refuse to take the winding road, you몭ll find yourself without any road at all, and if you refuse to spend money that you don몭t want to spend, you won몭t spend money when it몭s the right thing to do.


Marching is part of war, and so is camping

If you take this logic a step further, you몭ll find that training troops is also a part of war. In fact, it몭s an even more important element of war than fighting battles. Actually, fighting is the least important part; all the variables solidify and take their final form well before the battle happens. Yet, when people talk about war, they always talk about battle stories. It몭s very rare to hear stories about camping, and you almost never hear stories about training, because 몬training몭 and 몬stories몭 don몭t go together. So, the real work of wars all happens away from the limelight of storytelling. That몭s exactly what Sun Tzu meant when he said: 몮Good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage.몯 True heroes don몭t make it into the storybooks.

Extract from the original text:
몮Armed struggle can be advantageous, and it can be dangerous. If you set a fully equipped army in march in order to snatch an advantage, you will be too late. On the other hand, abandoning the army for the purpose involves the sacrifice of its baggage and stores. Thus, if you order your men to roll up their armor, and make forced marches without halting day or night, covering double the usual distance at a stretch, doing a hundred li in order to wrest an advantage, the leaders of all your three divisions will fall into the hands of the enemy. The stronger men will be in front, the jaded ones will fall behind, and on this plan only one-tenth of your army will reach its destination. If you march fifty li in order to outmaneuver the enemy, you will lose the leader of your first division, and only half your force will reach the goal. If you march thirty li with the same objective, two thirds of your army will arrive. We may take it then that an army without its baggage-train is lost; without provisions it is lost; without bases of supply it is lost.몯

Analysis:
몮Armed struggle can be advantageous, and it can be dangerous.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮For a skilled general, it is advantageous; for an unskilled general, it is dangerous.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮When a wise general engages in armed struggle, he does so to his advantage; when a mediocre general engages in armed struggle, he endangers himself. The wise general understands the circuitous and the direct; the foolish general is ignorant of the workings of the circuitous and the direct.몯
To put it plainly, nothing몭s difficult if you know how to do it. If you know how to snatch an advantage from your enemy몭s hands, you몭ll do well; if you don몭t, you몭ll end up putting yourself in danger. For example, in the previous subchapter, Zhao She was able to successfully gain the advantage by marching light and fast for two days and a night, because he understood the stratagem of 몬turning the circuitous into the direct.몭 So, he was able to manipulate his enemy while avoiding being manipulated himself, and he was able to foretell the time and location of the battle. Zhao She put into practice the principle that 몬armed struggle can be advantageous몭 by marching 100 li to fight. But, if he몭d done exactly the same thing without first committing to do all the groundwork and showmanship that went into fooling the Qin general, he would have played straight into his enemy몭s plan, which was to besiege the cities of Wu몭an and Yuyu with a primary objective of luring in and destroying a relief force. If Zhao She had been lured in and crushed, he would have been proving the other side of the equation: 몬armed struggle can be dangerous.몭
This is why, so often when we see someone else smartly pulling off a certain strategy, we fail spectacularly when we try to do the same thing. This is because people aren몭t the same, and there are different levels of preparation that go into making these things either work or backfire.

몮If you set a fully equipped army in march in order to snatch an advantage, you will be too late. On the other hand, abandoning the army for the purpose involves the sacrifice of its baggage and stores.몯

A 몬fully equipped army몭 means that, along with the soldiers and horses, you몭re marching with full armor, weapons and other equipment, grain and heavy supply wagons. This makes for slow travel, hence the phrase, 몬you will be too late.몭 So, when the crucial moment arrives, you have to leave your heavy supply wagons behind and move quickly, with just a light cavalry force. This is the meaning of 몬abandoning the army to snatch the advantage.몭 Similarly, 몬the sacrifice of its baggage and stores몭 means giving your supplies to someone else. Who exactly you give them to is impossible to know, but you몭re essentially throwing them away.

몮Thus, if you order your men to roll up their armor, and make forced marches without halting day or night, covering double the usual distance at a stretch, doing a hundred li in order to wrest an advantage, the leaders of all your three divisions will fall into the hands of the enemy. The stronger men will be in front, the jaded ones will fall behind, and on this plan only one-tenth of your army will reach its destination.몯

몬Rolling up the armor몭 is about packing just the essential armor and riding light. In this situation, your unit marches all through the day and all through the night, without rest. If you make a forced march with three separate units over a distance of 100 li in a bid to seize the advantage, your three commanders will all be taken prisoner by the enemy. Why? The men who are in the best physical condition will be able to make it to the destination without any rest, but the weaker ones will straggle behind. So, only one tenth of the units몭 troops will arrive on schedule, and your unit will have drastically shrunk in size, to the point that it doesn몭t matter much where they are, because the enemy will be able to swallow them up. Also, the enemy will be fresh and well rested, while your men wear themselves out on their journey. All the enemy has to do is wait for your men to walk, in scattered groups, right into their open jaws.
In the Battle of Fei River, which we looked at earlier in the book, I wrote that Xie Xuan had an army of 80,000 men, and that he defeated Fu Jian몭s much larger army of 800,000. But actually, although Fu Jian몭s army did indeed number 800,000 troops in total, not all of them arrived in time. Many of his soldiers were still on the road when the battle started, and it몭s unclear in the historical records exactly how many made it to the battlefield on time. Xie Xuan had inside information, thanks to his secret ally, Zhu Xu, so he knew that Fu Jian hadn몭t yet assembled his whole army. That몭s the only reason Xie Xuan decided to launch a lightning-speed attack.
In ancient Chinese warfare, armies would normally march 30 li, on average, per day. On forced marches, this speed would double, to 60 li per day. If marching 몬without halting day or night,몭 another 40 li could be covered, adding up to a total of 100 li over the course of a whole day and a whole night. So, since we know Zhao She marched for two days and one night, he probably covered a distance of 160 li. According to The Art of War, he should have been captured by his enemy. What was his solution? To camp and set up defensive lines a full 50 li before reaching the enemy, partly to give the stragglers time to catch up, as well as to eat and rest. And, he did so to force the enemy to march the remaining 50 li, tiring out the enemy troops while he waited at his leisure.

몮If you march fifty li in order to outmaneuver the enemy, you will lose the leader of your first division, and only half your force will reach the goal.몯

Zhao She implemented this passage to the letter: 50 li was the distance he left for the Qin army to march on their way to meet him. The Qin forces underwent a forced march to cover those 50 li as quickly as possible, with the result that only half of their force initially arrived, while the other half, including high-ranking officers, was still on the road. This would have made life quite difficult for the soldiers that arrived first.

몮If you march thirty li with the same objective, two thirds of your army will arrive.몯

Even marching at a normal speed 멪 30 li per day 멪 the army will still become separated, with two thirds of the troops reaching the destination before the remaining third.  

몮We may take it then that an army without its baggage-train is lost; without provisions it is lost; without bases of supply it is lost.몯

Here, the 몬baggage-train몭 includes battle equipment, grain, clothing and other consumable supplies. 몬Bases of supply몭 means roughly the same thing: goods, valuables and other commodities. 
So, an army that marches quickly like this is, in reality, extremely vulnerable. Without their baggage-train, they몭re dead; without supplies and equipment, they몭re dead. Think about conditions during the Korean War 멪 soldiers without winter clothing and blankets were doomed. Whole regiments and whole army camps froze to death on the front lines.
This passage from The Art of War contains three truths.
The first truth is that accomplishing something isn몭t difficult if you have the right abilities, but it몭s impossible if you don몭t. Challenges can bring huge benefits for wise leaders, but death and disaster for foolish leaders. If you see someone doing something, but don몭t understand how they do it, don몭t make the mistake of thinking that if someone else can do it, you can too.
The second truth is that marching is a part of war, and is in fact an even more important element than fighting in battles. The Art of War also states that camping is a part of war. Questions like where and when to set up camp can be even more pivotal in determining who will win or lose a conflict than the actual process of fighting. By the time the fighting starts, who will win and who will lose is a foregone conclusion; what makes the difference is the commanders몭 decisions about marching and camping. These factors are exactly what decided Zhao She몭s victory over the Qin forces.
There몭s a famous quotation from Napoleon: 몮Marching is war, and war is marching. Ability in conducting wars is one and the same as the ability to move effectively.몯 Napoleon specifically researched different marching speeds. Traditionally, an army was supposed to be able to march 70 paces per minute, but Napoleon upped this speed to 120 paces per minute. So, Napoleon몭s main battle weapon wasn몭t his soldiers몭 guns, but their legs. Another leader who was especially skilled at marching was General Su Yu, of China몭s People몭s Liberation Army. He understood the stratagem of 몬turning the circuitous into the direct몭 better than anyone, and he was able to memorize maps of entire war zones in full detail. This talent enabled him to cut across the terrain with incredible speed, and to appear out of nowhere, where his enemies least expected.
If we take the logic of marching and camping being integral parts of warfare to the next step, we realize that training is also an integral part of warfare, and that it too is even more important than actual fighting. A bit of extra work and sweat in peacetime saves a lot of blood in times of war.
If you take this logic yet an additional step further, you몭ll find that training troops is also a part of war, and in fact, it몭s an even more important part of war than fighting battles. Actually, fighting is the least important part; all the variables solidify and take their final form well before the battle happens. Still, when people talk about war, they always recount battle stories. As we몭ve said, it몭s rare to hear stories about camping, and you almost never hear stories about training, because 몬training몭 and 몬stories몭 don몭t go together. The real work of wars all happens away from the limelight[bd19] of storytelling. That몭s exactly what Sun Tzu meant when he said: 몮Good fighters have neither a reputation for wisdom nor merit for courage.몯 True heroes don몭t make it into the storybooks.
The third truth is that armies are extremely vulnerable and fragile. If you stop paying attention for even a moment, you몭re dead. The strongest thing in the world is also the weakest and most delicate. In the times when we feel strong and powerful, we need to be even more careful than usual. Observe yourself 멪 are you really so powerful, or are you actually very weak?
Behind the simple words, 몬Know the terrain,몭 there are countless details, and countless people몭s sweat, wisdom and lives

Extract from the original text:
몮We cannot enter into alliances until we are acquainted with the designs of neighboring lords. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country 멪 its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and obstructions, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantage to account unless we make use of local guides.몯

Analysis:
몮We cannot enter into alliances until we are acquainted with the designs of neighboring lords.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮Without knowing the enemy몭s situation and details of their plans, one cannot form alliances with them.몯 If you don몭t know the politics and motives of neighboring powers, you don몭t have the ability to decide your own diplomatic policy, and you can몭t count on other people helping you.
A passage from earlier in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War tells us: 몮Thus the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy몭s plans; the next best is to attack the enemy몭s alliances.몯 If you want to engage in diplomacy and get it right, you need a clear idea of what the various parties몭 interests and motives are. This is an idea from game theory, the study of mathematical models of strategic interaction between decision-makers. So, The Art of War isn몭t just a work of military strategy, it몭s also hailed by game theory scholars as the earliest game theory text.
Any behavior that contains elements of competition or antagonism can be called 몬game theory behavior.몭 Within this category of behavior, every side involved, or every competitor, has different goals or interests. The different sides, in order to achieve their various goals, have to contemplate all of their adversaries몭 possible moves or action plans, and also do whatever it takes to choose the right action plan for themselves. They need to pursue a course of action that몭s as rational as possible, or maximizes benefits for them.
In game theory strategy, one very important principle is that you mustn몭t look at the game just from your own perspective and your opponent몭s perspective, or just in terms of your and your opponent몭s interests, and the demands under which you and your opponent are operating. Instead, you need to expand your understanding of the number of participants in the game, or even to completely remodel the game, adding in more people and interests which might at first glance seem irrelevant to the game, while also increasing the number of chips you have in the game.
