War, too, isn몭t just a game between two sides. By expanding your understanding of the number of participants in the game of war, by bringing more states and various other factors into the picture, you stand to gain support from unlikely or hidden sources, and increase your chances of winning. For example, if you connect the dots between the 몬Crimea Issue몭 between Russia and Ukraine, on the one hand, and the Diaoyu (Senkaku in Japanese) Islands issue between China and Japan, a regional game becomes a global one.

몮We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country 멪  its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and obstructions, its marshes and swamps.몯

Cao Cao breaks down this passage in his commentary: 몬mountains몭 refers to places of commanding height; 몬forests몭 refers to places containing many trees; 몬pitfalls몭 refers to moats and other deep holes in the earth; and 몬obstructions몭 refers to vertically uneven terrain. 몬Marshes몭 refers to damp, boggy places, full of water and grasses; and 몬swamps몭 refers to places where water from many sources converges and becomes stagnant (i.e., lakes and ponds).
In short, you need to be extremely clear about the terrain before leading an army out on the march.

몮We shall be unable to turn natural advantage to account unless we make use of local guides.몯

If you don몭t take seriously the need to use local guides, you won몭t be able to gain control of the best terrain.
Studying and researching terrain from a strategic perspective is extremely intensive and detail-heavy work. It몭s common knowledge that before the Normandy landings in World War II, the Allies took their reconnaissance of the terrain they몭d be navigating in France to an extremely high level of detail. They sent spies during the night to dive in Normandy몭s coastal waters, where they took samples of beach sand and mud. They then evaluated all sorts of metrics, such as the thickness of the sand layer, the amount of mud, its relative hardness or softness, whether or not tanks could be driven onto the beaches, and so on. In the end, the Ally researchers concluded that the sand was too soft, and that tanks would get stuck. What was their solution? The plan was to send a single tank ahead of the rest, the front part of which would be loaded with a 몬carpet몭 made of canvas and wooden boards, which it would lay down on the beach so that the rest of the tanks would have a good surface to drive on.
And how did the Allies deal with anti-tank obstacles? Again, they sent a single tank ahead of the rest, which welded a bomb onto the anti-tank obstacle and blew it up. At that point, soldiers jumped out of the tank, wrapped cables around the obstacle 멪 now reduced to a heap of scrap iron 멪 and dragged it out of the way.
Moving further up the beach, the next barrier to overcome would be rows of landmines. For this, the Allies designed a special mine-clearing tank, a great monstrous machine mounted with a horizontal bar on two arms at the front.  From these arms hung a cluster of steel wrecking balls. As it drove forward, the wrecking balls hit the ground in front of the tank, detonating any landmines and clearing a way for troops behind to move forward.
If it weren몭t for this extremely intensive and detailed reconnaissance work, as well as the subsequent, highly-targeted design and engineering work, many, many more people would have died on those Norman beaches.
So, when we talk about 몬knowing the terrain,몭 it seems simple 멪 it몭s just three words. Yet, behind these words there are countless details, as well as the sweat, wisdom and lives of countless people.


The idea that 몬War is built on deception몭 plays the same role as feints in soccer; It몭s not actually a fundamental part of The Art of War, and it certainly is not representative of its value system

Extract from the original text:
몮In war, make deception the foundation upon which to stand, move with advantage, and change by dividing and consolidating.몯

Analysis:
The first part 멪 몮In war, make deception the foundation upon which to stand몯 멪 is a little misleading. Some readers consider these words the philosophical heart of The Art of War. To them, it seems perfectly clear: Sun Tzu is telling us to 몬make deception the foundation,몭 so it seems only natural that deception should also serve as a broader theoretical foundation. However, in the context of The Art of War as a whole, 몬The Five Factors and Seven Considerations몭 don몭t come from deceit, and neither does 몬Win first, fight later.몭 
So, it몭s important, when you몭re reading a book or listening to someone speak, to make links between the different parts of the book or speech. Experts in the field of linguistics tell us that any given text can only communicate a small fraction of the writer몭s thoughts. To get a complete picture of what the person behind the text is thinking, you need to integrate the language of the text with the wider context. We can몭t just lift a single sentence that someone몭s said out of its context, thinking we can explain what it means in isolation. Likewise, we can몭t presume to magnify it by inserting it into a completely different context. If you do that, we몭ll veer way off course from the author몭s original idea.
When Sun Tzu wrote the line, 몮Make deception the foundation upon which to stand,몯 he was writing in the context of this chapter, Armed Struggle. Here, he몭s beginning to talk about deception now that we몭ve reached the stage where the two sides몭 armies fight it out for victory. That comes only after going through the steps of making calculations in the temple, planning your assault, and thinking about formation and energy.
What is deception? The simplest way to explain it is with a concept from soccer: false movement, also known as the 몬feint.몭 You could say that every time your foot is about to touch the ball, there몭s always the potential for a feint 멪 a deceptively faked move. Deceit is a way of concealing your intentions; of fooling your enemy and making them go where you want them to go. Like Emperor Taizong said, it몭s about finding some way to lure your enemy into making a mistake.
In the context of football, 몬deceit몭 takes the form of feints. But, when you몭re training a soccer team, you can몭t just practice feints. In war, you make deceit your foundation, but if you also turn deceit into your entire value system, and believe that only deceitful people can get things done, you몭ll end up tricking not just your enemy, but also yourself. You몭ll start to believe your own lies.

 
몮Move with advantage.몯

This bit of text also has multiple possible meanings. What몭s your understanding of the word 몬advantage?몭 Does it just mean 몬Anything that might benefit you?몭 But if you몭re prepared to move at the first sight of benefit, aren몭t you liable to be tricked into moving if your enemy uses the illusion of benefit to fool you? So, 몬advantage몭 means 몬Something that is actually beneficial to you.몭 You should only move when doing so benefits you along the road to victory.
You might think, 몬Well, that몭s pretty obvious! Of course you should only move when it몭s of benefit to you. It goes without saying, doesn몭t it?몭
Actually, it does need to be said. That몭s because our failure to put into practice the principle of only moving when it gives you an advantage is our biggest weakness. So often, we move not because we stand to gain any real advantage, but because we feel anxious or under pressure, or because of greed or anger. 
The 몬advantage principle몭 is the most important tenet to put into practice whenever we몭re trying to get something done. Don몭t preoccupy yourself with the past 멪 no matter what might have happened before, the only thing you need to get a firm grip on is how to take your next step in a way that gives you an advantage.
몬Moving with advantage몭 doesn몭t mean moving at the first sight of an advantage. It몭s about only moving if doing so actually gives you an advantage.
It몭s just a few words, and yet the vast majority of people will never, in their whole life, successfully put them into practice. Otherwise, what business would these words have being part of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War?

몮Change by dividing and consolidating.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Each act of division and each consolidation is a change undertaken in light of the enemy몭s situation.몯
Changing an army by 몬division and consolidation몭 is exactly the same thing as allocating main and auxiliary forces. In the vocabulary of The Art of War, this is also known as 몬the art of division,몭 and the overarching term for this strategy is 몬dividing and consolidating the main and auxiliary.몭 Duke Li of Wei said: 몮If your troops are scattered, consolidate them into an auxiliary force; if your troops are consolidated, divide them into an auxiliary force. Thus, repeatedly ordering your forces to consolidate and divide, you return into the main.몯
몮In war, make deception the foundation upon which to stand.몯 This plays a role similar to the feint in soccer. It몭s not actually the foundation of the art of war, and it몭s definitely not part of the art of war몭s core value system. 몬Moving with advantage몭 doesn몭t mean moving at the first sight of a possible benefit; it몭s about only moving when doing so brings you some kind of advantage.


Wind, Forest, Fire, Mountain 멨 Takeda Shingen몭s version of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War

Extract from the original text:
몮Let your rapidity be that of the wind, your compactness that of the forest. In attacking and ravaging the enemy, be like fire; in immovability, like a mountain.몯

Analysis:
These four lines have had a bigger impact in Japan than any other part of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. I say this because, during Japan몭s Sengoku period of prolonged war between feudal states (1467-1615 CE), a feudal lord named Takeda Shingen had these lines written in gold lettering upon a piece of cyan cloth, and he made this his battle flag. It was known as the 몬Flag of Sun Tzu.몭
Let몭s start by looking at what these lines mean.

몮Let your rapidity be that of the wind.몯

Li Quan comments: 몮This is about advancing and retreating. When you advance, leave no trace of yourself; when you retreat, move with the utmost speed.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮It is about striking at emptiness.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Advance with explosive speed, and you will sweep away all in your path.몯
So, 몬let your rapidity be that of the wind몭 has two parts: attacking and retreating. When you attack, be as fast as the wind, and when you retreat, leave no trace. Cao Cao adds on an extra meaning, which is that you should 몬strike at emptiness.몭 This means that you need to be able to judge the enemy몭s weak and strong points, to do what they least expect 멪 to attack them where they몭re unprepared, and to avoid their strong points while striking their weak points. If you do all this, you will sweep away all in your path, and you will be as fast as the wind.

몮Let your compactness be that of the forest.몯

This line is talking about battle lines drawn up as neatly and tidily as the trees in a forest. If you move slowly and deliberately, there will be no gaps in your lines for your enemy to exploit.
Li Quan comments: 몮Making your battle lines orderly, and then moving.몯 You can imagine it like this: an entire army in battle formation, moving as a single unit, like a forest full of trees swaying. The army advances slowly and quietly, embodying a powerful sense of constriction, like being inside a huge forest.
Du Mu comments: 몮몬Compactness몭 is about being slow and steady. When ordering the army to move slowly and steadily, the ranks and columns must be like trees in a forest, in case the enemy may attempt a surprise attack.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮This is for times when there is no advantage to see.몯 This echoes the line from the previous passage about 몬moving with advantage.몭 If you haven몭t yet been able to identify the enemy몭s weak and strong points, and if you haven몭t seen any opportunity to attack that would give you the advantage, you should move slowly and cautiously.
Du You comments: 몮Do not move forward if you see no advantage. Be like a forest when the wind blows through it, making some small movements, but no big ones.몯

몮In attacking and ravaging the enemy, be like fire.몯

When moving in for the attack, be like a raging fire. Li Quan comments: 몮Be like a blazing inferno burning across a prairie; leave not a single blade of grass unburned.몯 His addition of 몬leave not a single blade of grass몭 is telling us that the enemy should be left with nowhere to run and no way to resist. Not a single enemy soldier should be allowed to escape. Lin Biao몭s 몬three ferocities몭  멪 fight ferociously, charge ferociously and pursue ferociously 멪 are a modern equivalent to this line from Sun Tzu.
Cao Cao몭s comment repeats what he said earlier: 몮It is about being fast.몯

몮In immovability, be like a mountain.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about holding a defensive position.몯 When your army is not in motion, it should be like a mountain: unshakeable.
A text by the ancient philosopher Xunzi, entitled A Debate about Warfare, says this: 몮When holding a position, form strong lines on all sides, and you will become like a massive boulder; whatever beast may charge you, its horns shall shatter upon impact.몯
The metaphor of 몬wind, forest, fire and mountain몭 is about using speed, as well as caution. The ancient military text, the Wei Liaozi, says: 몮In heaviness, be like the mountains and the forests; in lightness, be like fire and cannon smoke.몯 So, when attacking and withdrawing, be like wind and fire, and when you몭re not moving, be like the mountains and forests.
How should we understand 몬wind, forest, fire and mountain몭 from the perspective of Takeda Shingen?
For him, there were two levels to being as swift as the wind. The first level was about how he used cavalry. He had the best cavalry in all of Japan, and he typically began his battles with a cavalry charge. The second level was about strategy and infrastructure, which had two main parts. The first part was beacon towers used for communicating signals. Takeda Shingen built a dense network of signal towers radiating out in all directions from his base in Kai Province. If anything unusual happened in his border territories, smoke of various colors would be used to report to Takeda Shingen, enabling him to react, and possibly mobilize troops, at the fastest possible speed. The second part was his famous road system, known as the Shingen Bomichi roads. Kai Province is located in mountainous terrain, so Shingen Takeda built nine extremely straight roads that allowed his armies could move more effectively. All nine roads led directly to major war zones. So, with the support of information and transport infrastructure, Shingen Takeda몭s armies were able to move as swiftly as the wind.
What about the second part, 몬Letting your compactness be that of the forest?몭 Again, there were two levels. First, this relates to Takeda Shingens몭 rifle units. Each soldier in these units carried a long gun, between four and six meters in length. When these rifles were held upright, the unit would have looked just like a forest. These units would move slowly, and they were a potent weapon against enemy cavalry forces. The second level is about the army as a whole 멪 when ordering his men to move out, they did so in perfect order, moving fluidly and serenely, as a single unit.
Moving on to the next line 멪 몬In attacking and ravaging the enemy, be like fire몭 멪  for Takeda Shingen, this was first about charging the enemy with irresistible force, like a blazing wildfire surging over grasslands. Secondly, it was about his system for organizing his army and communicating commands. The idea was to be able to command his forces so seamlessly that it was as if they were an extension of his own arm, moving wherever he pointed his finger.
Next, we have 몬In immovability, be like a mountain.몭 First of all, for Takeda Shingen, this was about how he conducted himself as an individual. No matter how intense the situation around him might be, he would be able to rise above the flames of battle and continue directing his army. It was about being untouched by the commotion around him. Even if enemy soldiers advanced right up to where he sat, he wouldn몭t so much as stand up 멪 he would let his bodyguards kill the attackers. This is about the commander being immoveable and the army몭s battle flag remaining untouched. This is the way to keep your soldiers몭 hearts steady, and to fill them with the courage to kill the enemy.
The next part of 몬immovability몭 is about the discipline of Takeda Shingen몭s army, and the way he managed his battle lines. Every member of his army would be positioned according to his own, specific role, and if anyone showed the slightest sign of non-compliance, they were dealt with by martial law. This meant that no matter what kind of attack Takeda Shingen몭s enemies might try, his troops never wavered, never left their position in the army몭s battle lines, and never allowed the enemy to affect them. So, from Takeda Shingen himself, down the hierarchy to every single member of his army, the whole organization was as immovable as a mountain.
Next, it몭s time to look at how this passage relates to Takeda Shingen몭s strategy. He never acted without thinking through the possible consequences, and he never allowed the enemy몭s attempts to probe him provoke him into action. He moved in step with his own rhythm 멪 slowly and steadily, like the trees in a forest, and immovable like a mountain. Yet, as soon as an opportunity presented itself, he would strike with the speed of the wind and the raging intensity of fire.
Wind, forest, fire and mountain 멪 through these elements, Takeda Shingen brought Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War into the real word in a very big way.
Takeda Shingen practically worshipped Sun Tzu. In a television drama series filmed by Japanese public broadcaster NHK, entitled Takeda Shingen, there is an episode in which a Chinese Buddhist monk visits Kai Province, Takeda Shingen몭s stronghold. Takeda Shingen invites the monk into his home, and recites these passages of The Art of War to him, in Japanese:
몮sono?haya kikoto?kaze nokotoku,?
sono?shizu kanarukoto?hayashinokotoku,?
shingyaku surukoto?hi nokotoku,?
ugo kazarukotono yamano.몯
Then, Takeda Shingen made a request of the Chinese monk:
몮Would you recite for me the words in Chinese, so that I may know how they sound?몯 
The monk courteously accepted, and began to recite the words in a soft voice:
몮qi ji ru feng,
qi xu ru lin,
qinlue ru huo,
bu dong ru shan.몯
Takeda Shingen closed his eyes, immersed deeply in his enjoyment of these heaven-sent sounds.


The military practice of looting: An army몭s 몬unofficial welfare benefit몭

Any organization is always going to need some kind of benefits. But, the problem with official benefits is that people feel that they몭re entitled to them. And then, as soon as they begin taking them for granted, the benefits몭 incentive mechanism breaks down or even goes into reverse, encouraging laziness. So, you몭re always going to need a few unofficial sources of benefits 멪 an occasional, pleasant surprise to incentivize your people and crank up their enthusiasm.

Extract from the original text:
몮Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt. When you plunder a countryside, let the spoil be divided amongst your men; when you capture new territory, cut it up into allotments for the benefit of your men. Ponder and deliberate before you make a move. He will conquer who has learnt the artifice of turning the circuitous into the direct. Such is the art of armed struggle.몯

Analysis:
몮Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night.몯 Be like dark clouds covering up the sky, so that the sun, moon and stars become invisible, and their movements impossible to measure.

몮When you move, fall like a thunderbolt.몯

Lord Jiang Ziya said: 몮Be like thunder that comes so quickly that there is no time to cover your ears; be like the lightning that strikes before you can blink your eyes.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮This is about attacking as if striking from the empty sky above, so that the enemy does not know how to evade you.몯

몮Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt.몯 

When the sky is filled with dark clouds, nobody can see the sun, moon or stars, and your enemy cannot tell which cloud harbors thunder and lightning behind it. Behind the cloud layer, the hunter몭s eyes look down from on high, unseen yet seeing all. When a lightning bolt suddenly cleaves the sky, there is nowhere to hide, and no time to react.

몮When you plunder a countryside, let the spoil be divided amongst your men.몯


To put this line simply, it몭s about sharing the wealth, so that everyone gets a piece of the pie.
몬Plundering a countryside몭 means robbing local landowners, but also the common people of your enemy몭s country. Once your army arrives in the enemy몭s lands, you move through the villages, plundering as you go. What kinds of things do you take? You might take grain and other food, other useful items or tools, livestock such as chickens, ducks, pigs, sheep, cows and horses, and you might also take children, women, silk and gold.
Food and other resources are things that every army needs, and indeed, Sun Tzu writes about this specifically in Waging War: 몮Hence a wise general makes a point of obtaining food from the enemy. One zhong of the enemy몭s provisions is equivalent to twenty of one몭s own, and likewise a single picul of his fodder is equivalent to twenty from one몭s own store.몯 As for captured children, women, gold and silk, these are to be divided among the officers and troops, with everyone getting a share of the wealth, slaves and women.

몮Let the spoil be divided amongst your men.몯

This just means that everything should be shared, so that every man in the army has the chance to get his hands on something. There몭s no risk involved in plundering villages, and it can bring in lucrative profits. This cushy job shouldn몭t be given to just one unit; it몭s important that every man in your army gets the chance to join in. Everyone can get rich together!
Plundering was an unwritten convention of ancient warfare. It몭s certainly one of the uglier parts of army life, but it was an important incentive mechanism.
Whenever you hear about disciplined, well-behaved armies that leave the common people alone, this is because there몭s some higher political ambition driving them. They already consider the common folk of the enemy몭s country to be their own compatriots; they need to be looked after, and made ready to become future subjects of their new lord. But when a war is a simple conflict between two states, with the only aim being to extract some benefit from the enemy, there몭s no need to treat the enemy몭s people nicely, and they become just another part of the spoils of war, to be divided up between the officers and common soldiers. It몭s similar to the Chinese Communist Party몭s early 몬mass struggle movements몭 against landlords in the 1950s. If you were a landlord, you essentially had a big label on your face saying 몬class enemy,몭 and that meant you몭d be swept away as if you were dust, with absolutely no mercy. Then, all the villagers, having just overthrown the local landlords, would take part in claiming the 몬spoils of war.몭 Every family got to take home part of the wealth. One effect of this was that, even if you only took an old iron cooking pot, you몭d become a part of the Communist revolution.
For over 2,000 years, China and the Xiongnu people from the north fought each other. When the northerners ventured down into China for a new round of war, plundering was their only goal. From the perspective of a Xiongnu leader, the warriors riding with you are following you because they want plunder, and you need to make sure that opportunities to plunder, as well as the actual spoils of war, are distributed in fair and rational way. Otherwise, your band of warriors will start fighting one another, and your army will collapse in on itself. Generation after generation of successful generals who lived through times of war had one thing in common: they were all extremely fair in the way they divided up the spoils of war.
But, how do you actually put fairness into practice? It몭s not at all easy, because people are prone to believe that they haven몭t been treated fairly, even if it몭s not true. If everyone thinks they몭re getting shortchanged, then, essentially, 몬fairness몭 doesn몭t even exist. One general had a solution 멪 he would not take a single bit of the spoils of war for himself. He decided he would only take what the Emperor saw fit to give him, and leave everything that came from the battlefield to be divided up among the soldiers. That way, nobody could complain to him.
War can be divided into two different types. The first can be called 몬invasions,몭 which are characterized by plundering. The second can be called 몬campaigns,몭 examples of which include the Chinese Nationalists몭 Northern Expedition (1926-1928 CE), and Zhuge Liang몭s nine campaigns into China몭s Central Plain region.
The goal behind 몬invasions몭 is to gain some kind of benefit, like plunder and territory. Invasions aren몭t meant to bring down and replace the enemy state; they몭re simply about plundering and seizing some advantage, or perhaps beating the enemy into submission so that they have to sue for peace. That naturally involves them paying you, in the form of ritualized tribute offerings.
몬Campaigns몭 are quite different. They몭re built around political objectives. In Chinese, the word for 몬campaign몭 멪 which can also be a verb meaning 몬to campaign against somebody몭 멪 has a root meaning of 몬to chop down trees.몭 During a military campaign, you chop down the trees outside the enemy몭s temples, ancestral shrines and graveyards. Once all the trees are down, you level the buildings, overthrow the enemy state and take your place as ruler of all the land. So, 몬campaigns몭 are about cutting down the enemy몭s power, their culture and their symbols. Then, you build up your own power system, and your own symbols. During China몭s Cultural Revolution (1966-1976 CE), the Confucian temples were destroyed. Even if you몭ve already gained power, you still have to keep on cutting down the old powers.
As the cycle of warfare and chaos came full circle, time and again throughout history, bandits and thieves roamed the land, and feudal lords fought each other for supremacy. The way to identify a leader who has grander ambitions 멪 for instance, someone who dreams of ruling the entire known world 멪 is to watch out for armies that don몭t plunder, and that leave the common people undisturbed. One example would be Li Zicheng, a rebel leader who launched his bid for supremacy during the final years of the Ming dynasty, and who called himself 몬The Roaming King.몭 He was known for his slogan: 몬The Roaming King isn몭t here to take your grain!몭 He successfully captured Beijing, but then he fell back into his old ways 멪 he forgot that he was in Beijing on a military campaign, and not as an invader. He took the local children, women and valuables, and shared them with his soldiers. This paved the way for Wu Sangui, the general who helped establish the Qing dynasty, to lead Manchu soldiers through the mountains and toward Beijing from the northeast.
Let몭s talk some more about 몬plundering the countryside, and dividing the spoils amongst the men.몭 Cao Cao wrote a comment on this line, but it몭s quite vague: 몮Find a way to victory based on the enemy몭s situation.몯 Cao Cao isn몭t really saying anything here. Bearing in mind that he was a leader of soldiers and also a prime minister, it몭s likely that he didn몭t want people to hear him talking about these things.
By contrast, Du You몭s comment is very specific: 몮If the enemy몭s villages and towns are undefended and their livestock and wealth easily available to plunder, then this plunder must be divided in an orderly manner, so that every member of your forces obtains some part of it. You must not allocate everything to one recipient. Thus, everyone, from the young to the old, the weak to the strong, will want to participate in war and gain some advantage for themselves.몯 It몭s important to make sure that everyone gets opportunities, and that no single army unit keeps all of the loot. If you can do this, everyone will be enthusiastic.
When Zeng Guofan spoke about the art of being a good general, he emphasized that it몭s important for generals to be incorruptible. Ordinary soldiers might not understand the finer points of military strategy, but they can all understand where the money is. If the general is greedy for money, or if he몭s cutting his men out of the spoils and keeping them all for himself, his soldiers will never willingly give up their lives for him. But, if you몭re uncorrupt and clean, and make sure you have something nice to give your troops every now and then, every one of your men will gladly follow you and kill your enemies.
We몭re now getting to the part about 몬unofficial welfare benefits.몭 Any organization is always going to need some kind of benefits. The problem with official benefits is that people feel they몭re entitled to them, and as soon as they begin taking them for granted, the benefits몭 incentive mechanism breaks down or even goes into reverse, encouraging laziness. So, you몭re always going to need a few unofficial sources of benefits 멪 an occasional, pleasant surprise to incentivize your people and crank up their enthusiasm, as well as to keep things interesting for them.

몮When you capture new territory, cut it up into allotments for the benefit of your men.몯

The meaning of this line is basically the same as: 몮When you plunder a countryside, let the spoils be divided amongst your men.몯 The difference is that the 몬spoils of war몭 are for sharing with the common soldiers, while new territory is to be divided up among the senior generals, especially those who몭ve made a big contribution to the war effort. It몭s essentially about giving out land and noble titles. Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about sharing benefits gained from the enemy.몯

몮Ponder and deliberate before you make a move.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about gauging the enemy몭s situation before engaging in plunder.몯
The Wei Liaozi said this: 몮Ponder the enemy and evaluate your generals before taking action.몯
In the original Chinese text, the idea of 몬ponder몭 is expressed with the image of hanging up a steelyard weight, part of an ancient scale used for weighing objects. Zhang Yu comments: 몮Weigh the enemy so that you know how light or heavy he is, evaluate your generals몭 ability or lack thereof, and then determine to take action.몯

몮He will conquer who has learnt the artifice of turning the circuitous into the direct. Such is the art of armed struggle.몯

After you몭ve worked out whether the enemy is a heavyweight or a lightweight, and where his weak and strong points are, consider the terrain and then plan out how to apply the stratagem of 몬turning the circuitous into the direct.몭 Within this is another principle: in armed struggle, strive to position yourself ahead of your enemy.


The command system makes the army

It doesn몭t matter how many soldiers you have in your army 멪 if you don몭t have a command system, it몭s not an army. It몭s just a swirling mass of blind men. That몭s why the saying goes, 몬A general in the field might not hear all of his king몭s orders,몭 and not 몬A general in the field might not obey all of his commander몭s battle orders.몭 Any army officer who defied orders from his superiors would soon find his body separated from his head.

Extract from the original text:
몮The Book of Army Management says: On the field of battle, the spoken word does not carry far enough: hence the institution of gongs and drums. Nor can ordinary objects be seen clearly enough: hence the institution of banners and flags. Gongs and drums, banners and flags, are means whereby the ears and eyes of the gathered army may be focused on one particular point. The army thus forming a single united body, is it impossible either for the brave to advance alone, or for the cowardly to retreat alone. This is the art of handling large masses of men. In night-fighting, then, make much use of signal fires and drums, and in fighting by day, of flags and banners, as a means of influencing the ears and eyes of your army.몯

Analysis:
The Book of Army Management was an ancient Chinese military text, but it is now lost to history.
Part of what is known about it today, from instances where it was quoted in other writings, is a passage that reads: 몮At times it is not possible to hear one another몭s voices. That is why we have drums and gongs. At times it is not possible to see one another; that is why we have flags and banners.몯 
Gongs and drums serve as an alternative command system. Ancient gongs were made of bronze, which produced a resonant, percussive sound like 몬DANG,몭 powerful enough to send vibrations through people몭s bodies. Ancient war drums were made from cowhide, and emitted an energizing, blood-pumping 몬DONG몭 sound. In their simplest usage, drumbeats were the signal to attack, while the gong was used to signal retreat. But, there were also many other signals, and many other instruments, such as bugles and horns, each used to send different kinds of information.
In situations where soldiers and officers couldn몭t see one another, flags were used to relay commands. Many different colors and patterns were used, each with a different role in communicating. There was also a whole system of 몬flag language,몭 with different movements and gestures used to convey various kinds of information about battle commands or the enemy몭s situation. Flags were a visual communication tool; a way of using signals to give commands.


몮Gongs and drums, banners and flags, are means whereby the ears and eyes of the gathered army may be focused on one particular point. The army thus forming a single united body, is it impossible either for the brave to advance alone, or for the cowardly to retreat alone. This is the art of handling large masses of men.몯

If you have gongs, drums and signal flags, you can make your entire army see and hear the same thing at the same time, and move as a single, coordinated unit. The bravest among your warriors can몭t charge the enemy on their own if you haven몭t ordered them to, and the less brave among your men can몭t retreat unless you give the order. This is how to command a large army in battle.
Under strict military discipline, 몬Any man who, upon being ordered to advance, does not advance, or who, upon being ordered to retreat, does not retreat, shall be executed.몭 There is a story relating to this from the ancient commander Wuzi몭s war against the state of Qin. As the two armies stood facing one another, before the fighting had begun, one soldier couldn몭t contain his fighting spirit, and charged the enemy on his own. He killed two enemy soldiers, cut off their heads, and took them back to his comrades. Wuzi executed that man. One of Wuzi몭s officers had his own opinion about this, which he expressed to the commander: 몮That man clearly is a person of considerable ability! Why not give him a chance to make up for his crime?몯 But Wuzi replied: 몮Military discipline is not concerned with distinctions between men of ability and men without ability.몯
A general in the field might not hear all of his king몭s orders, but it is absolutely unacceptable for anyone to ignore commands given on the battlefield. That is how serious battle commands are. So, suppose you몭re an officer leading a battle unit in a pursuit movement. Judging from the situation in front of you, you몭re only moments away from catching the enemy, but then you hear the sound of gongs from behind. In this moment, you absolutely have to retreat, even if it means letting the enemy get away. This is because it몭s not your job to give commands 멪 you don몭t know what the overall situation is across all parts of the battlefield.

몮In night-fighting, then, make much use of signal fires and drums, and in fighting by day, of flags and banners, as a means of influencing the ears and eyes of your army.몯

There몭s a story from the Spring and Autumn period that몭s well known by Chinese readers. It involves Cao Gui, a general from the state of Lu who is famous for his theoretical approach during the battle of Changshao, a conflict between the neighboring states of Lu and Qi. After a round of fighting between the two armies, the Qi army was second best, and began to retreat. Duke Zhuang of Lu wanted to pursue the fleeing enemy, but Cao Gui urged him to wait. Cao clambered up onto a chariot and spent some time surveying the scene. Eventually, he said that now was a good time to pursue, and so that몭s exactly what the Lu troops did. They chased the enemy for 30 li, killing as they went. After it was all over, Duke Zhuang asked Cao Gui what his reasoning had been. Cao Gui said that although the enemy seemed to be defeated and retreating, he was concerned that they might have laid an ambush. But, then he saw that the enemy chariots were moving chaotically, and that the enemy flags had fallen on the ground. That was how he knew it was safe to start chasing them.
What does it mean if the enemy battle flags have fallen? It means that they no longer have a command system, and that their soldiers are all fleeing for their lives. It몭s become an 몬every man for himself몭 scenario. At this point, you could say that the enemy army is no longer an army; it몭s turned into a torrent of blind men. So, it몭s safe to give chase.
Of course, it몭s also possible to be tricked even when the enemy몭s flags are in a mess. You might think that their command system has broken down, but it몭s possible that they몭re using gongs and drums to send secret signals, and that abandoning their flags was all part of their plan to trick you.
In Du Mu몭s comment on this passage, he talks about how fires and drums were used in army camps during nighttime: 몮When the army has halted, they are used to set camp; when the army is marching, they are used to set formation.몯 The logic behind setting up camp in the evening is more or less the same as that behind marching during the day. When marching, within the formation of the army as a whole, you need to organize men in smaller units of ranks and columns. Likewise, a large army camp is made up of many smaller 몬sub-camps.몭 The different parts of the army 멪 forward, rear, left and right 멪 set their tents in concentric circles. The commander-in-chief몭s encampment is located in the dead center of the camp, encircled by the other camps, which together formed an interlocking and symmetrical pattern, a bit like star constellations in the night sky. Each of the small camps would be positioned between 50 and 100 paces apart, with pathways connecting them. The space between these camps would be large enough for the army to easily exit the camp and form up in battle formation. The camps were also close enough to each other that if one camp was attacked, soldiers in the neighboring camp could help their comrades by shooting at the enemy from behind their camp몭s fortifications. In each place where two pathways intersect, a raised earthwork would be built 멪 with firewood laid on top and trenches dug underneath 멪 where soldiers would be stationed to keep watch.
If the enemy tried to raid the camp during the night, the watchmen would wait for them to enter the camp, and then sound the drums. Soldiers from each of the camps would respond at the same time, lighting all the prepared firewood and turning the night as light as day. Soldiers were not allowed to run about on their own, but had to line up in battle formation, forming walls blocking the enemy몭s exit. That way, it would be clear that any men left running around in a disorderly fashion were enemy soldiers. Then, archers would climb up to high positions and shoot the enemy soldiers until there were none left standing. Any invader venturing inside the camp would never leave alive.
This is exactly how Zhuge Liang planned his camps: they were like nets set out to trap the enemy. When he finally retreated, abandoning his camp, Sima Yi went to see what he could learn from his enemy몭s camp design, and apparently sighed: 몮Genius! This truly is a wonder of the world.몯


Energy and momentum determine victory; You should have the awareness to guard your energy, and you should have strategies for cultivating energy

Extract from the original text:
몮A whole army may be robbed of its spirit; a commander-in-chief may be robbed of his presence of mind.몯

Analysis:
몮A whole army may be robbed of its spirit.몯 This is about attacking the morale of the enemy troops, so that all their energy and momentum turns into sluggish dejection. When an army loses morale, it also loses its strength, and so its battle capability goes out the window, too.
The American psychologist David Myers put forward a 몬fatigue motivation theory몭 that can be used to explain issues about the connection between troop morale and battle capability. According to his theory, the human body몭s energy store is a constant, but people allocate themselves different amounts of energy each day, based on their needs and their level of motivation. If their motivation is strong, they allocate more energy. Conversely, if they have a low level of motivation, they allocate a smaller amount of energy.
The most famous historical example of an army being robbed of its 몬spirit몭 is one we just mentioned, in which Cao Gui explained his methods to his lord at the battle of Changshao, fought between the states of Lu and Qi. As the two armies faced off, the Qi drums began beating, and Duke Zhuang of Lu immediately became eager to get the fighting started. But Cao Gui raised his voice: 몮Not yet!몯 He held the army몭s battle lines in an iron grip, and let it be known that anyone who broke formation would be executed. The Qi army charged the Lu battle lines, but when they were unable to break through, they retreated, re-gathered their flags and drums, and then came again. But still, the Lu army wouldn몭t charge. After three rounds of drumming by the Qi drummers, the Lu army finally began beating their own drums, and charged the enemy, thoroughly beating them. Later, when Duke Lu asked Cao Gui to explain his reasoning, Cao Gui said: 몮Any kind of fighting always involves courage. The first round of drumming builds up soldiers몭 energy; in the second round, the enemy begins to deflate; and in the third round, the soldiers enter a state of rest. I make sure that when the enemy is resting, my energy is in full flow; that is why I can defeat my enemy.몯 
After one round of drumming, the Qi soldiers were pumped up and ready to go, but the Lu army ignored them and refused to engage. After three rounds of drumming, the Qi soldiers couldn몭t keep their excitement going 멪 they lost their energy. Meanwhile, the Lu soldiers had conserved their energy, and now they were ready to unleash it. This is how you engineer a situation where the enemy is resting, while you몭re overflowing with energy.
There몭s another, similar historical example, from the final years of the Three Kingdoms period, involving Sima Yi몭s son, Sima Shi.
A Wei general named Wen Xin had rebelled against the state, so Sima Shi took an army to deal with him. Wen Xin put his son, Wen Yang, in charge of his whole army, even though Wen Yang was just 18 years old. Wen Yang told his father: 몮The enemy army has to travel a very long way to come here. I몭m going to hit them as soon as they arrive, before they have the chance to get settled. That몭s how we can beat them.몯 The boy몭s father didn몭t say anything, so when the two armies were lined up facing one another, Wen Yang got the drums beating. Amid deafening noise, the men shouted, 몮Let몭s kill the enemy!몯 But three rounds of drumming went by, and still Wen Xin didn몭t give the order. Wen Yang was forced to retreat east, along with his father.
When Sima Shi saw the enemy retreating, he said: 몮Wen Xin몭s going to run! Quick, chase him!몯 But his officers replied: 몮Wen Yang몭s a fierce commander 멪 if he몭s running away before the fight몭s even begun, it might mean he몭s laid an ambush for us.몯 But Sima Shi had the last say: 몮After the first round of drumming, the energy peaks, after the second round it begins to diminish, and after the third round it is depleted. Wen Yang beat his drum three times, but Wen Xin didn몭t respond. Wen Yang몭s men will now have no energy left, so what are we waiting for?몯
The Wei army gave chase, and dealt a major defeat to Wen Xin.


When a leader has inner power, their team몭s energy and momentum are unstoppable

Extract from the original text:
몮A commander-in-chief may be robbed of his presence of mind.몯

Analysis:
Du Mu comments: 몮The heart 멪 it is upon the general몭s heart that the entire army relies.몯 It might not matter much if one soldier in an army is a coward, but a general몭s cowardice can infect the whole army. 몬Robbing a general몭s presence of mind몭 means probing at and undermining the enemy general몭s resolve, because if he loses his resolve his army will fall apart.
Our historical example for this subchapter is one we discussed in Chapter Three, about attacking and sabotaging the enemy몭s plans. It몭s the story of Kou Xun몭s campaign against Kui Xiao, during the time of the Eastern Han dynasty. One of Kui Xiao몭s senior generals, Gao Jun, who was in charge of holding a certain city, sent one of his officers, Huang Puwen, to visit Kou Xun as an emissary. However, when Huang Puwen refused to submit to Kou Xun or to pay his respects, Kou Xun immediately had him executed, and then sent Huang Puwen몭s deputy back to Gao Jun to tell him to surrender. The next day, Gao Jun opened the gates of his city and surrendered.
Kou Xun몭s officers asked him to explain how this had happened. Kou Xun replied: 몮Huang Puwen was the brains of Gao Jun몭s whole operation; it was he who did Gao Jun몭s planning and strategizing. When he came here, he was unyielding and defiant 멪 it was clear that he could not be convinced to surrender. If I had let him go back to Gao Jun, his planning abilities would have been put to work for Gao Jun. But, by killing him, I could rob Gao Jun of his courage and make him surrender.몯
So, by executing a single man, Huang Puwen, Kou Xun was attacking Gao Jun몭s planning capabilities. A commander can be robbed of his presence of mind 멪 in this case, killing the one man Gao Jun relied on was enough to rob him of his presence of mind.
For our second historical example, we turn to the Uprising of the Five Barbarian Peoples during the Sixteen Kingdoms period (304-439 CE). Specifically, let몭s look at the war between Tuoba Gui of Northern Wei and Murong Bao of the Later Yan. As their two armies faced one another across a river, Tuoba Gui received intelligence that Murong Bao몭s father, Emperor Murong Chui, had fallen ill at around the time that Murong Bao had deployed his forces. So, Tuoba Gui cut off the Later Yan army몭s communication lines, so they would be unable to receive news from home. Later, Tuoba Gui몭s forces captured a Former Yan messenger, and forced him to shout across the river to Murong Bao: 몮Your father is dead. You need to go home, now!몯 When Murong Bao heard this, he was overcome with worry and snuck out with his forces under the cover of night, heading homeward. Tuoba Gui chased him, and defeated the Later Yan army at the Battle of Canhe Slope.
Sima Fa wrote: 몮The mind is set in an original state, but it can be defeated after an influx of new energy.몯
Duke Li of Wei wrote: 몮In attack, one must not only attack the enemy몭s fortifications and battle lines; it is essential to possess the skill to attack his mind.몯
If you want to rob someone of his presence of mind, there몭s a precondition몯 you need to have inner mental power. For a leader to be able to build up his team몭s energy, he must have the ability to strengthen his own mind. When the leader몭s mind is strong, his team becomes truly powerful, like a force of nature.


Force makes for a long war; Energy brings victory

Force can몭t last for long, which is why it몭s impossible to have a constantly overflowing supply of energy. It몭s important to be constantly aware of your energy and how to tend to it, and to know how to tend to your team몭s energy. As for whether it몭s possible to influence other people몭s energy멞 since we몭re not in a war, it몭s best to focus on ourselves. There몭s no point to occupying your thoughts with other people when you haven몭t yet taken care of yourself.

Extract from the original text:
몮Now a soldier몭s spirit is keenest in the morning; by noonday it has begun to flag; and in the evening, his mind is bent only on returning to camp. A clever general, therefore, avoids an army when its spirit is keen, but attacks it when it is sluggish and inclined to return. This is the art of studying moods.몯

Analysis:
몮Now a soldier몭s spirit is keenest in the morning; by noonday it has begun to flag; and in the evening, his mind is bent only on returning to camp.몯
In simple terms, morning is the best time to get things done. Morning is the time when mental energy is at its fullest; by noon, it begins to decline, and by evening all you몭re thinking about is heading home for the day.
There몭s a passage in The Methods of Sima that reads: 몮New energy defeats old energy.몯
Chen Hao comments: 몮When new energy first arrives, it is full and sharp; do not fight someone in this state.몯 When the enemy is flush with new energy, stay out of his way, and don몭t try to fight him. Let him stew for a while.
Meng Shi comments: 몮Morning energy is the energy of beginnings; noon energy is the energy of continuing work; evening energy is the energy of decline.몯 The meaning is the same as 몮The first round of drumming builds up the energy, with the second round of drumming the energy begins to deflate, and with the third round, the energy is depleted.몯
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Morning 멪 here he speaks of beginnings; noon 멪 here he speaks of the midpoint; evening 멪 here he speaks of endings. He says that one몭s energy is sharp in the beginning, but after a while one몭s energy declines and one몭s thoughts turn to returning home. This is the time when one may attack.몯 The reason why it몭s important to pursue the enemy when they are withdrawing is because the enemy soldiers are all thinking about going home. This means that they don몭t have the will to fight, and the time is ripe to wipe them out.
So, in fact, the ideas of 몬morning, noon and evening몭 used here don몭t correspond directly with the specific times of day that they seem to refer to, but represent a progression of three stages.

몮A clever general, therefore, avoids an army when its spirit is keen, but attacks it when it is sluggish and inclined to return. This is the art of studying moods.몯

Skilled generals stay well out of the enemy몭s way while they몭re still in the first flush of sharp, hard-edged energy, and wait for them to lose their edge, and for their thoughts to turn to home. That몭s when the skilled general attacks. This is the way to manipulate energy.
In the aftermath of the collapse of the Sui dynasty (581-618 CE), among three main contenders vying for the throne, it was Li Shimin who would eventually triumph and become the first Emperor of the Tang dynasty, Emperor Taizong. During his struggle for supremacy, he went on the warpath against another contender, Wang Shichong. This was a worrying development for the other contender, a general named Dou Jiande, because if Wang Shichong fell, the delicate equilibrium between the three of them would break down. So, Dou Jiande moved out with a large army to help Wang Shichong fight Li Shimin. He lined his soldiers up along the eastern bank of the Si River, and his army was so large that it stretched for miles. A powerful energy hummed through the ranks. From a nearby mountainside, Li Shimin looked down at the enemy. Turning to his officers, he said: 몮The traitor army is poised and dangerous, but they have no government giving them instructions. We will keep our lines close to the city walls 멪 this will put my heart at ease. We will hold our position, and we will not go out to meet the enemy, but wait for enough time to pass that their soldiers grow tired and hungry. Then, they are sure to withdraw. As soon as they withdraw, we will move out and pursue them, and then we shall be able to defeat them in a single battle.몯
Dou Jiande kept his troops in formation from six o몭clock in the morning until noon. They became tired and hungry, and some of them sat down on the ground, while others took breaks to drink water. Li Shimin saw this, and shouted: 몮Now is the time to strike!몯 The two sides fought a battle, and by the end, Dou Jiande was Li Shimin몭s prisoner.
In chains, Dou Jiande was brought before Li Shimin. The victorious Li asked his prisoner: 몮Originally, I set out to fight Wang Shichong. There was no need for you to be involved 멪 it had nothing to do with you 멪 so why did you travel so far to be here today?몯
몮I thought I몭d deliver myself right to your door, and save you the trouble of making a long trip just to come get me.몯 As soon as these words came out of Dou Jiande몭s mouth, any residual angry energy disappeared.
몮Force makes for a long war; energy brings victory.몯 Force can몭t be kept up for long, which means it몭s impossible for your energy stores to always be full. Properly managing your energy 멪 maintaining the sharp, powerful energy of the morning 멪 is the key, for both individual people and for teams.
We need to keep observing our teammates and ourselves. When we first set out on a new endeavor, we don몭t let our standards slip, and each of us puts our full energy into our work. This is the meaning of 몬morning energy몭 or 몬sharp energy.몭
After working like this for 10-20 years, we have no more financial pressure to deal with, or at least, much less. We have a family, and now it몭s time to enjoy life. Once you reach this point, it몭s possible that you might not have the awareness or the ability to take the next step upward. If you can몭t find new value for yourself, and a new way of expressing that value, you won몭t be able to transition upward to the next stage, and you몭ll find yourself confronted with sluggish, lazy energy.
If this lazy energy keeps growing, it will turn into 몬evening energy,몭 and you break down as a person until you effectively become waste for the trash heap.
We need to keep reflecting on ourselves, keep our energy sharp at all times, hold on to our true, individual nature and fulfill our life duties. Once we reach the point where we have less energy than we did in our youth, we have to focus our 몬sharp energy,몭 stay committed to our position on the front line, and stay connected to the earth몭s energy. We must also begin to transition upward to the next stage, moving from working on our own self-realization to helping other people become who they are meant to be.
It몭s necessary to have a constant awareness of managing energy 멪 not only your own, personal energy, but also the energy of your team. As for whether it몭s possible to influence other people몭s energy, since we몭re not in a war, it몭s best to focus on ourselves. There몭s no point occupying your thoughts with other people when you haven몭t yet taken care of yourself.	


Managing your own mind 멪 The root of everything

Extract from the original text:
몮Disciplined and calm, to await the appearance of disorder and hubbub amongst the enemy: this is the art of retaining self-possession. To be near the goal while the enemy is still far from it, to wait at ease while the enemy is toiling and struggling, to be well fed while the enemy is famished: this is the art of husbanding one몭s strength. To refrain from intercepting an enemy whose banners are in perfect order, to refrain from attacking an army drawn up in calm and confident array: this is the art of managing changes.몯

Analysis:
몮Disciplined and calm, to await the appearance of disorder and hubbub amongst the enemy: this is the art of retaining self-possession.몯
Use your discipline and orderliness to wait for the enemy to fall into chaos. Use your calm to wait for the enemy to become agitated and loud. This is how to manage your mind.
Du Mu comments: 몮Sima Fa Said, 몬The mind is set in an original state.몭 Understanding the enemy is the way to win. Although your mind may be already set in a certain state, you can make adjustments and manage it, making yourself calm, sturdy and immune to annoyances and temptations. Wait for the enemy to descend into disorder and confusion, and then send out troops to strike him.몯
What exactly does Du Mu mean by the words 몬disorder몭 and 몬confusion?몭 Chen Hao comments: 몮Disorder is when the government gives contradictory commands and there is no clarity in the system of rewards and punishments. Confusion is when the flags are jumbled and troops make much noise and act recklessly while on the march. If you detect these things in your enemy, then it is time to move your forces and strike.몯
He Shi comments: 몮Every general stands alone, in body and in mind, and alone, must take a great, confused array of things deep into his mind: uniting hundreds of thousands of troops, standing against ferocious, pitiless enemies; making sense of a tangle of dangers and potential advantages, untying victory from defeat, keeping track of the many, minute variations in power and knowledge. He must take these things inside himself without becoming lost within their vast spaces; he must allow no trace of disorder into his heart. How can he make himself endlessly adaptable to changing situations? How can he not get lost in details while dealing with all manner of things? How can he maintain composure when suddenly faced with a great disaster? How can he maintain a clear mind while dealing with everything? Self-management is all that is needed to deal with confusion. Even if a million enemy soldiers are arrayed before you, if you see them properly, then it will be no different to facing a small raiding force. When Yafu encountered a raiding party, he obstinately refused to get up from bed; When Luan Cuan was about to go to battle, he used orderliness and leisure to good effect. If we are to evaluate these two cases, what stratagems did they use? They are refined in the way that they conceal their wisdom, and they nurture their minds with the result that they have an abundance of wisdom.몯
This is brilliant commentary by He Shi. As a general, every move you make has an impact on huge amounts of wealth, human lives, perceptions of truth, ethics and the moral fiber of many people. A leader몭s emotions have an impact on the morale of the entire organization, and they can interfere with the leader몭s decision-making and execution of plans. So many decisions are made because of pressure and anxiety. This kind of decision, which often is rash and ill advised, is an attempt to find some relief from the pressure and anxiety. Either that, or it몭s a result of the leader몭s inability to 몬maintain composure when suddenly faced with a great disaster.몭 When confronted with challenging and dangerous circumstances, they panic and lose all sense of the right way forward, and instead gallop off in the worst possible direction, towards certain doom.
몮When Yafu encountered a raiding party, he obstinately refused to get up from bed.몯 One night, while Zhou Yafu was dealing with the Rebellion of the Seven States, there was a sudden commotion in his camp, and he could hear chaos outside his tent 멪 soldiers shouting and screaming. So, what did he do about it? He stayed in bed, and went back to sleep. Eventually, the soldiers calmed down.
There are four key points to grasp if you want to keep your team몭s battle capability at a high level: managing energy, managing minds, managing strength and managing changes. And, at the root of all of this is managing your own mind.

몮To be near the goal while the enemy is still far from it, to wait at ease while the enemy is toiling and struggling, to be well-fed while the enemy is famished: this is the art of husbanding one몭s strength.몯

Be the first to arrive at the battlefield, and wait while the enemy makes a long slog from afar to reach your location. While you relax and wait, taking your ease, the enemy wears himself out marching at speed towards you.  And, keep your belly full while the enemy goes hungry. These are all ways to 몬manage strength몭 and to maintain battle capability.
The reason Li Shimin held his troops in position and waited all morning, while Dou Jiande몭s troops stood in formation, ready for battle, was to force the enemy to lose its orderliness, freshness and calm, and fall into chaos, noise and exhaustion. At the beginning of the morning their bellies were full and they were not thirsty, but by the end of the morning their bellies were hungry and their throats were parched, and they몭d used up the strength that they needed to be properly prepared for battle.
Duke Li of Wei stated that all of the thousands of pages written about The Art of War boil down to a single idea: 몬Manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated.몭 In other words, seize the initiative and keep it firmly in your grasp. 

몮To refrain from intercepting an enemy whose banners are in perfect order, to refrain from attacking an army drawn up in calm and confident array: this is the art of managing changes.몯


Cao Cao comments: 몮The meaning of 몬in calm and confident array몭 is that the enemy몭s army is very large.몯
Here, 몬intercepting몭 means 몬attacking.몭
If the enemy몭s flags are neat and well ordered, and if their battle lines are powerful and imposing, then don몭t attack. Do some evasive maneuvering, and let the enemy use up some of their energy. Wait until their 몬sharp morning energy몭 has run out; wait until they몭re hungry, thirsty and have lost their excitement, and become full of 몬lazy midday energy몭 and 몬time-to-go-home evening energy.몭  Then it is time for you to attack.
Once, while Cao Cao was besieging the city of Yecheng, a general named Yuan Shang made an attempt to break the siege from outside. Cao Cao said: 몮If he comes here along the main road, we should evade him. But if he comes from around the mountains to the west, he will soon be our prisoner.몯 What was Cao Cao몭s reasoning? Basically, if Yuan Shang advanced along the main road, his army would be able to move 몬in perfect order몭 and in 몬calm and confident array.몭 They would be fearless, and it would not be possible for Cao Cao to beat them. There would have to be some significant change in circumstances in order for Cao Cao to prevail. But, if Yuan Shang chose the difficult path along the base of the mountains, his men would have to walk carefully, with eyes glued to the ground. They몭d have a feeling of being unsure, and they wouldn몭t have much physical strength to call upon. They would be easy targets.
As it turned out, Yuan Shang did choose to advance around the western mountains, so Cao Cao wheeled his forces around, attacked him on the road and heavily defeated him.
몬Managing changes몭 is a skill that몭s used to respond flexibly and effectively to developments in the enemy몭s circumstances. Even though Cao Cao was an extremely formidable general, he didn몭t take the threat posed by Yuan Shang lightly. If Yuan Shang had arrived in 몬perfect order,몭 Cao Cao was prepared to run and stay well clear of his enemy몭s claws[bd20]. The Book of Army Management contains a passage that reads: 몮Advance when you see that it is possible to do so, retreat when you become aware of difficulty, and avoid the enemy when he is strong.몯


You need policies, strategies, tactics and a toolbox of elementary battle tactics

Extract from the original text:
몮It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare.몯

Analysis:
In my opinion, the most accurate way to break down the topic of military strategy is to use the six-level approach created by 19th century Swiss military strategist Antoine-Henri Jomini. His framework can be neatly applied to any strategic endeavor, no matter what it might be, and used to bring a high degree of clarity into your planning.
The first thing to think about is policy. Jomini put policy ahead of strategy, and he believed he was the first military strategist to propose that policy should be put above strategy. What this means in a military context is that the first thing you need to get busy with is foreign policy and diplomacy. Only after this step do you move on to decisions about whether or not to fight, who to build alliances with, and who to fight against.
In a business operations context, the first thing to do is formulate policies governing how we interact with society and with consumers. Only when this is taken care of should we move on to thinking about what we need to do in terms of strategy. What the word 몬policy몭 means is: 1) Who am I? 2) Whose interests do I represent? 3) What basic policy direction do I have to inform my actions?
Sun Tzu talks about policy, too. What he calls 몬The Way몭 (one of the 몬Five Factors and Seven Considerations몭) is just another way of saying 몬policy.몭
What exactly is the difference between 몬policy몭 and 몬strategy?몭 Strategy is about yourself; it몭s your personal scheme. Policy is about other people; it comprises the practices[bd21] you use with other people. Putting policy before strategy means that you think about other people, and then you think about yourself. First, think about the interests of all interested parties, and the systems and setups of the various players in the game.
After policy, we move on to item two: strategy.
Strategy is about: 1) Where you are now; 2) Where you want to go: 2) How you get there. Strategy is your roadmap to victory. Sun Tzu몭s approach to strategy is to win first and fight later, or to force the enemy몭s army into submission without fighting. This is what strategy is made of.
The third level in Jomini몭s framework is 몬overarching tactics.몭 This is about using one trademark move, something that only you can do, and capitalizing on it in any kind of situation. This is a common trait of every successful person 멪 they all have their own, personal, special skill. This is what 몬overarching tactics몭 is all about.
In Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, the primary battle tactic is to use your main force to start a battle, and an auxiliary force to win it. This is applied to any and every battle situation; no matter how you fight, it몭s always some variation of the art of division. Main and auxiliary forces repeatedly switch roles, with infinite variability.
The fourth of Jomini몭s six levels is 몬military logistics.몭 This is a key topic in Chapter Two of The Art of War 멪 Waging War 멪 and it includes all kinds of details. They include things like how to 몬field a thousand swift chariots, as many heavy chariots, and a hundred thousand sets of armor, with provisions enough to carry them a thousand li.몭 No matter how strong or massive an army may be, without guaranteed logistical support it will be extremely vulnerable, fragile and likely to shatter upon first impact.
The fifth of Jomini몭s six levels is the art of engineering, which is about how to attack and defend fortified strongholds.
Finally, the sixth level is basic tactics, which is all about how to fight in various situations. In other words, it몭s a tactical toolbox, a term commonly used in Chinese and one that몭s often cited in employee training programs. 
In this chapter of The Art of War 멪 Armed Struggle 멪 Sun Tzu writes: 몮It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard.몯
Here, we are entering the realm of basic tactical principles.


The art of war can몭t account for all possible situations 멪 That몭s what makes it so deadly!

Extract from the original text:
몮It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare.몯

Analysis:
몮멞 not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill.몯
When the enemy holds the high ground, you can몭t attack. If the enemy is coming down from a mountain or a hill, you can몭t counterattack.
If you do choose to attack an enemy who is uphill from you, the terrain is against you. It will be hard for you to leverage your strength, and it몭ll be easy for the enemy to launch missiles, such as logs and boulders, down at you.
If the enemy holds the high ground and charges downhill at you, the terrain is working to his advantage. He doesn몭t have to worry about covering his rear, and it몭s so easy for him to build momentum as he moves from high ground to low that his strength is effectively doubled. Don몭t try to counterattack. Instead, try to draw him onto level ground, and fight him there.
Our historical example for this subchapter is another one that we looked at earlier in the book: Zhao She몭s war against the Qin forces. Zhao She set up camp fifty li short of the city he was aiming to save. One of his men, Xu Li, advised him to take up a position on the mountains to the north, because, as he said: 몮Victory will belong to whoever holds the northern mountains.몯 So, that몭s what the Zhao army did: they turned the terrain to their advantage. When the Qin forces arrived, they struggled to scale the mountain but were unable to reach the top. Then, the Zhao army hit the Qin soldiers with their full force, inflicting a heavy defeat on them.
Zhuge Liang once said: 몮When fighting in steep country, do not attack a position that is higher than your own. If the enemy comes towards you from a higher position, do not try to fight them, for the momentum will be against you. Instead, draw the enemy onto level ground, and only then engage.몯
However, there몭s always another side to things. Zhuge Liang famously had to execute his disgraced ally, Ma Su, after the Battle of Jieting. Ma Su had occupied the high ground and set up camp on top of a mountain, where he could await the enemy Wei army. He positioned himself 몮looking down at the enemy,몯 the story goes, 몮with the intention to cut through the enemy like an axe through bamboo, to put himself in death몭s way and yet prevail.몯

It must be noted that while the semi-fictional classic novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms, holds that Zhuge Liang executed Ma Su, official historical records say Ma Su died in prison. There몭s also a theory that Ma Su never reported back after his defeat, and escaped into obscurity with his life.
Ma Su몭s deputy general, Wang Ping, had tried to persuade Ma Su not to set up camp on the mountain, reasoning that there was no water source up there and no resupply route. If the enemy surrounded the mountain, he몭d be stuck up there and unable to get out alive.
Why was Ma Su unable to understand the logic of what Wang Ping was trying to tell him? The truth is that he did understand, but his whole plan was to put himself in a dangerous position and yet find a way to survive. He wanted to occupy the high ground and slam down into the Wei army with overwhelming force. He몭d never planned to stay on the mountain for any length of time, so as far as he was concerned, issues like water sources and resupply routes were completely irrelevant.
However, Ma Su forgot one thing. Back when Han Xin had put himself in a similarly dangerous situation, with his back to a river, and yet found a way to survive, he didn몭t put all of his men by the river. He kept 2,000 cavalry aside, and it was this cavalry force that captured the Zhao camp and activated the 몬main force/auxiliary force몭 synergy. If Han Xin hadn몭t used the art of division and separated his army into main and auxiliary forces, and instead positioned his entire army by the river, things would have been very different. He and his men would have ended up in a watery grave.
But, Ma Su didn몭t use the art of division. Instead, he placed all of his soldiers and horses in death몭s doorway.
Wang Ping was unable to talk Ma Su around. All he got for his efforts was a tongue-lashing from Ma Su, who called him an 몬unlettered general몭 who had 몬no understanding of the art of war.몭 Wang Ping was in fact illiterate 멪 he knew no more than ten Chinese characters 멪 while Ma Su was a talented literary man. So, naturally, Ma Su had nothing but contempt for his deputy. Wang Ping decided to try a different approach. He suggested that Ma Su set up camp on the mountaintop, but give some of his men to him, so he could set up another camp on level ground and divide their forces into two prongs. And then, if either of them got into trouble, the other could come to the rescue. Ma Su agreed to this.
So, in the end, the army did use the art of division: Ma Su led the main force, and Wang Ping led the auxiliary force.
When the Wei commander, Zhang He, arrived, he saw that Ma Su was encamped on the mountaintop, so the first thing that he did was surround the mountain. The second thing he did was cut off the water source and resupply routes. Ma Su had expected this to happen 멪 he wasn몭t Zhuge Liang몭s favorite student for nothing. But, he didn몭t expect the third thing that Zhang He did, because it몭s not written about in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. Zhang He set fire to the mountain.
What makes The Art of War so dangerous is that it can몭t cover every base; it can몭t account for every possible real-world situation.
As soon as the fire started to climb up the mountain, the words 몬Do not advance uphill against the enemy몭 no longer applied. Ma Su몭s men, already unbearably hungry and thirsty, fell into chaos as the smoke and heat of the fire began to torment them. In that state, there was no way they could charge down toward the enemy below them. Zhang He launched an attack, and Ma Su was badly beaten. After losing Jieting, Zhuge Liang몭s whole war plan was completely derailed.
But what about Wang Ping몭s auxiliary force? Wang Ping just stood and watched. There몭s a biography of Wang Ping, in the historical text Records of the Three Kingdoms, that contains the following passage: 몮Ma Su turned away from the water source and went up the mountain, a disastrous decision. Wang Ping repeatedly tried to reason with Ma Su, but Ma Su did not take his advice, and suffered a heavy defeat at Jieting. Ma Su몭s soldiers scattered, but Wang Ping, at the head of a thousand men, sounded his drums, and Zhang He did not press him, for he suspected an ambush.몯 
Wang Ping몭s fortunes began to improve after the Battle of Jieting, and he went on to become a highly respected general in the Shu army.


Use yourself as bait; this is the only way to snare your enemy

Extract from the original text:
몮It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare.몯

Analysis:
몮Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight.몯 Another line 멪 몮Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy몯 멪 also has this meaning: when the enemy uses bait, don몭t bite on his hook. 
Send a small force uphill to attack the enemy, and then have them pretend to retreat. The idea is to draw the enemy몭s entire army toward you, and then hit him with your auxiliary force, crushing him in one fell swoop. This is a standard tactic 멪 it몭s nothing new for anyone who wasn몭t born yesterday.
And yet, once you몭re actually on a battlefield and the enemy몭s retreating, it몭s impossible to judge with any certainty whether it몭s a real retreat or a fake. You see the bait, but you can몭t tell if there몭s a hook hidden within. It몭s precisely because of this kind of conundrum that we have the expression 몬armchair strategist몭 to describe someone who seem to know everything, and yet never manages to make the right judgment calls. The truth is, these people don몭t really know what they몭re talking about.
So, does the fact that we몭ve read Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War mean that we know the concepts of 몬Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight몭 and 몬Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy?몭 The answer is: no, we don몭t know. But, if we know that we don몭t know, reading The Art of War hasn몭t been totally in vain. 
These two tactics 멪 simulating flight and offering bait 멪 were the key to Han Xin몭s defeat of the Zhao army at that famous battle in which he began with his back to the river.
Han Xin몭s first move was to deploy 10,000 troops in a battle line by the riverbank, and then he sent out a detachment of soldiers as bait, to get the fight started. And who played the role of the bait? Han Xin himself. That몭s why the Zhao army couldn몭t help but bite! How could they not, when they saw Han Xin dangling right in front of them, there for the taking? They certainly weren몭t going to go for any other target.
Because it몭s nearly impossible to turn down such tempting bait, there are many more examples throughout history of using commanders-in-chief, and even Emperors, as bait. When the prize is so great, the enemy is sure to bite, even if he knows you몭re baiting him. And, once the enemy gets excited, it몭s even more of a done deal 멪 he몭s definitely not going to hold back and think about whether or not he몭s being baited. However, this is the kind of tactic that only gets put on the planning table if the commander himself puts it forward as an idea. Advisors would never normally dare to suggest that their boss should use himself as bait.
When Han Xin marched forth at the head of his unit of bait soldiers with drums pounding and his personal banner streaming in the wind, excitement crackled through the Zhao ranks. They all knew that a big battle was coming, and that whichever one of them cut off Han Xin몭s head would instantly become a great hero. Today was going to be their day!
Han Xin몭s men and the Zhao troops smashed together in combat, and after a while, Han Xin started his 몬simulated flight.몭 But, in fact, it wasn몭t an entirely false retreat. He didn몭t have much choice but to withdraw, because the Zhao forces had a huge numbers advantage over him, and he could never have beaten them if the fight kept on going the way it had started. So, the genius of his mock retreat was the fact that it was actually very real. He couldn몭t win, and that made his fake withdrawal all the more convincing.
