As Han Xin retreated, he started to lay out his baited hooks: his personal banner, his ceremonial weapons, his war drums, and so on. All of these items would be highly valuable to the Zhao troops; whoever got hold of Han Xin몭s personal banner would be sure to receive rich rewards. And so, the entire Zhao army poured out of the gates of their camp, falling over themselves in their rush to grab the treasure and bite on Han Xin몭s hook.
The Zhao army broke two of Sun Tzu몭s rules: 몬Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight몭 and 몬Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy.몭 Meanwhile, in front of the massed Zhao soldiers, Han Xin몭s unit retreated to the riverbank, joined forces with the 10,000 men he몭d stationed there earlier, and then charged back towards the Zhao army. From behind the Zhao lines, Han Xin몭s 2,000-strong auxiliary cavalry force rode into the Zhao camp and captured it, leaving the Zhao army facing a powerful enemy to their front, and suddenly without a base to retreat to. That was the moment when they crumbled.
There몭s a common Chinese saying: 몬You can몭t expect to catch the wolf if you몭re not prepared to risk the life of your child.몭 From Han Xin몭s story, we learn that if you really want to catch the wolf, you also have to be prepared to use yourself as bait.


Analysis of the battle of Changping: In our own lives, we often play the roles of Zhao Kuo and the King of Zhao

Extract from the original text:
몮It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare.몯

Analysis:
In the most horrific conflict of the entire Warring States period, the Battle of Changping, 400,000 Zhao soldiers were buried alive. Why? Because the famous armchair strategist Zhao Kuo broke two important rules: 몮Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight몯 and 몮Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy.몯 Two other rules also played a part: 몮Do not advance uphill against the enemy and do not oppose him when he comes downhill.몯
As for the Qin commander, Bai Qi, he also broke three rules: 몮Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard.몯 If the enemy is forced into a corner, he몭s likely to fight with everything he has, so don몭t press too close. But, Bai Qi didn몭t pay any mind to these principles. He completely surrounded the Zhao forces and annihilated them.
Let몭s look at how the battle unfolded. The Qin army sent out a detachment of troops to act as bait, and then pretended to withdraw in defeat. Zhao Kuo immediately chased after them with his entire army. The Qin men drew Zhao Kuo to the main Qin force몭s position at a place called Changbi, where they Qin army was waiting for them.  The Qin commander was using principles from The Art of War: 몮Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will be exhausted,몯 as well as 몮Knowing the time and place of the battle몯 and 몮By holding out advantages to him, he can cause the enemy to approach of his own accord.몯 The Qin generals knew that the outcome of the battle would be decided at Changbi, so that몭s where they set themselves up to lure Zhao Kuo to them. Zhao Kuo was completely in the dark about this.

몮The Regular May Be Used for Joining Battle, but The irregular Will Be Needed in Order to Secure Victory.몯


The Qin army started the battle by using its 몬bait troops몭 as their main (regular) force, while the main army stationed at Changbi served as the auxiliary (irregular) force.
When Zhao Kuo arrived at Changbi, the Qin bait troops merged with the bulk of the Qin army, forming a new main force. Now it was time for the Qin general to dispatch his second auxiliary force.
Zhao Kuo found his way forward blocked at Changbi, and the fighting wasn몭t going his way. He was getting ready to retreat when 25,000 Qin auxiliary troops struck out of nowhere. They had been waiting in ambush on each flank of the Zhao army, and now they cut their way behind the Zhao troops and took up a strong position on a raised barrier to the west. From there, they blocked the Zhao army몭s escape route and cut off Zhao Kuo몭s communications with his main camp. The Zhao army had now been split in two.
Next, General Bai Qi sent 5,000 elite cavalry soldiers to the Zhao camp, to pin down the small Zhao force that had been left behind to guard it. Now, all of the Zhao food resupply routes were cut off, and the Zhao army was completely immobilized.
Surrounded, Zhao Kuo몭s only option was to build defensive fortifications and wait to be rescued. Bai Qi didn몭t give him a moment몭s rest, sending out a constant stream of light cavalry to attack and harass him. Bai Qi was putting one of Sun Tzu몭s principles into action: 몮If the enemy is taking his ease, he can harass him; if well supplied with food, he can starve him out.몯
When King Zhaoxiang of Qin received reports that Bai Qi had control of the situation, he immediately set out to the front lines, where he enlisted all local boys and men over the age of 15 into the Qin army. He then poured the new recruits onto the battlefield, completely surrounding the Zhao army and cutting it off from its resupply routes and from any would-be rescuers.
After 46 days without food supplies, the Zhao troops had become so desperate that they몭d started murdering and eating each other. All that Zhao Kuo could do was make one, desperate roll of the dice: he tried to break out of the Qin encirclement. He was killed in the attempt. His army surrendered, and then the Qin forces buried them alive 멪 all 400,000 of them.
The first question is: Why did Zhao Kuo make such a basic error? After all, he was quite familiar with all of the writings about the art of war. The answer is that he was too self-confident.
Newborn calves aren몭t scared of tigers, but that doesn몭t mean a tiger won몭t eat them.
Zhao Kuo몭s thinking would have gone something like this: 몬Lian Po (the previous Zhao commander-in-chief) is an old man, and now it몭s my turn to be my country몭s star general. Lian Po spent three whole years right next to the Qin army at Changping, and all he did was twiddle his thumbs and waste the country몭s resources. He몭s nearly bankrupted the state of Zhao, and now it몭s up to me to solve the problems he몭s created.몭
Since Zhao Kuo was so self-confident, it was inevitable that he would underestimate the enemy. In his first taste of battle with the Qin, his self-confidence was immediately validated when the enemy turned and fled. This proved to him that he was right, and that he was strong, so he immediately gave chase. While we might say the enemy was 몬simulating flight,몭 he would have argued that he was pressing his advantage and 몬attacking the enemy when they are sluggish and inclined to return home.몭 But, once he was committed to the chase, there was no turning back.
The second question is: How did Zhao Kuo몭s father, Zhao She, know that his son wasn몭t up to the task, and yet was unable to trip him up or stump him in debates about the art of war?
Zhao She once said to Zhao Kuo몭s mother: 몮War is a matter of life and death, and yet Kuo speaks of it so easily and lightly. If the king does not make Kuo a general, nothing will come of it, but if he is made a general, he is sure to be the ruin of the Zhao army.몯몯
Some say that Zhao Kuo was an example of someone who was deeply familiar with the scholarship on the art of war, but was unable to bring his knowledge into the real world. However, this misses the point. The essence of Zhao Kuo몭s problem was that just because someone has read all of the books on the art of war and is deeply familiar with them, that isn몭t the same as actually understanding the art of war.  
There몭s a saying in Chinese: 몬Even if you몭ve never eaten pork, you몭ve seen a pig running, haven몭t you?몭 This means that even if you몭ve never tasted their flesh, you still have some observational knowledge of pigs. But this is completely untrue! Seeing a pig running isn몭t the same as knowing about pigs. To really know what pigs are like, you have to have personally experienced eating pork. This is even truer in the case of Zhao Kuo. He몭d only ever seen pigs running through the pages of a book, and had never seen a real-life pig running in the real world!
So, when we read about principles, we only can say we know the principles; we can몭t say we can actually use them. To gain true knowledge, it몭s essential to actually use principles, and to practice using them.  As for how well you can know something, that몭s a different matter. There몭s no end to knowledge.
Confucius wrote: 몮Is it not a delight to learn something and have the time to practice it?몯 When we 몬learn몭 something, we haven몭t actually gained true knowledge of it. For that, we have to use this knowledge, practice it, and learn from experience. This is the only way to gain true knowledge, and it truly is a delightful thing!
Have you ever been taught something, yet failed to really learn it? Maybe you understood what your teacher was telling you, but when you actually tried to put it into practice, you found that you were unable to. That means you never really understood in the first place. You can only say you몭ve made some small steps in learning something once you몭re able to act on what you have learned.
Zhao Kuo몭s mother also knew that her son wasn몭t fit for the task he몭d been given. We know this partly because her husband, Zhao She, had told her as much, and partly because she tried to talk the King of Zhao out of appointing Zhao Kuo as commander. She said to the King: 몮You once appointed Kuo몭s father, She, as general. From the day that She received his orders, he never gave any attention to our personal family problems, and whatever gold or silks he acquired, he shared all of it between his officers and soldiers. Now, you have appointed Kuo as commander. You have given him rewards and noble titles, and he has kept all of this wealth in our family; he is storing it away, and he has told all of our family members to hurry and buy up the best land and houses. He does not behave in the way a leader should.몯
The third question is: Why didn몭t the King of Zhao listen? Why was he so hell-bent on replacing Commander Lian Po, and why did he want Zhao Kuo to take over? Did he really fall for the Qin trick 멪 몬the stratagem of sowing discord?몭 Qin spies had spread a rumor that the reason Lian Po wasn몭t attacking the Qin was because he planned to surrender, and that the Qin generals were much more afraid of Zhao Kuo than of Lian Po. So, did the King of Zhao fall for it?
Not in the slightest!
The reason why the King of Zhao made such a bad decision was because of anxiety and pressure. He was anxious and despondent, and he felt under such great pressure that he simply had to change something. Even if he was going to die, he had to at least go out fighting!
But why?
Let몭s take a look at how this war started.
It began when the state of Qin attacked the state of Han. The Qin army was too strong for the Han forces to deal with, so they sued for peace, and offered some land to the Qin if they would call off their attack. That land was the Commandery of Shangdang. But the Han official in command of Shangdang Commandery, Feng Ting, wasn몭t willing to take orders from the Qin authorities, so he decided to make his own offer. He announced that he was bequeathing Shangdang Commandery to the King of Zhao. The King of Zhao, being greedy by nature, was delighted, and immediately sent soldiers to occupy Shangdang. You could describe this move as 몬stealing food from the tiger몭s mouth.몭
There was no way the King of Qin would sit idly by after the King of Zhao had stolen his new land from under his nose, and he turned the Qin war machine toward Shangdang. Of course, the small detachment of Zhao soldiers sent to take possession of Shangdang was no match for the Qin army. They retreated to Changping. The King of Zhao then sent a large army to Changping, with Lian Po in command. The two armies faced each other from across the River Dan. Lian Po knew that he couldn몭t beat the Qin army, so he established a defensive position in favourable terrain, and dug in. He had no intention to get into a fight, and this situation lasted for three years.
Over the course of those three years, more than a million Qin and Zhao soldiers twiddled their thumbs at Changping, using up their countries몭 resources until both states were on their knees, their economies close to collapse. What started with the King of Zhao salivating over the prospect of getting his hands on some new territory ended up with his whole kingdom sliding towards collapse, before he몭d even had the chance to so much as sit down in Shangdang Commandery. There was absolutely no way he could leave his kingdom in this downward spiral. In Chinese there몭s a saying: 몬Trying to steal a chicken only to lose the rice you were using as bait.몭 But in this case, the state of Zhao was losing the entire contents of all of its granaries!
But would things work out if the King of Zhao tried to put an end to this descent into ruin?
In the end, he wasn몭t equal to the task.
The King of Zhao몭s frustration with Lian Po had reached boiling point 멪 he absolutely had to change something, anything! What he didn몭t realize was that making changes isn몭t the same thing as solving a problem, or that making the wrong change can even make the situation worse. As far as the King of Zhao was concerned, if Lian Po couldn몭t fight, it went without saying that none of the other old generals would be able to, either. The only option was to choose a younger commander. He realized that many believed Zhao Kuo wasn몭t the right man for the job, but also that nobody else could do what had to be done. Zhao Kuo hadn몭t yet been tested in battle, so why not take a chance and bet on him?
In our own lives, we go about most of our decision-making in more or less the same way that the King of Zhao did. We always feel a strong desire to solve problems, but we don몭t have the insight or attention span to realize that the action we choose to solve the problem is actually creating new problems, and might even bring a catastrophe down on our heads.
Imagine if we were sent back in time 2,000 years 멪 if we were in the King of Zhao몭s position, what would be the right thing to do?


A 몬fierce general몭 is one who hides when the enemy is fierce. They wait until the enemy has used up their strength, and then they unleash their ferocity

Extract from the original text:
몮It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare.몯

Analysis:
몮Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen.몯
The word 몬keen몭 means the same thing as 몬sharp,몭 as in 몬sharp morning energy.몭 You need to stay out of the way of the enemy when their energy is keen, and strike when their energy is lazy, and they몭re preoccupied with thoughts of returning home. When the enemy is full of energy and at the height of his powers, stay well out of his way. Let him stew for a while, and wait until his energy and excitement pass and he becomes hungry, thirsty and tired. Then, it몭s time to strike.
Once again, it몭s all about managing energy.
The management of energy was a strong suit of Li Shimin, who became Taizong, second Emperor of the Tang dynasty. We몭ve already learned about how Li Shimin beat Dou Jiande: during that war, he used the principles of 몬Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen몭 and 몬Attack when the enemy is sluggish and inclined to return.몭 Now, we몭re going to look at two more historical examples in which Li Shimin plays the leading role.
In the first example 멪 Li Shimin몭s fight against Liu Wuzhou 멪 he used the same two principles.
Originally, Liu Wuzhou was a general in the imperial army of the Sui dynasty. When the Sui dynasty collapsed and the country descended into chaos, he raised his own army in rebellion against the Sui court, declared himself Emperor and went on the warpath. After securing support from non-Chinese Turkic forces, he seemed unstoppable. He fought several battles against the Tang forces, winning each time. He shredded Tang Prince Li Yuanji몭s forces, which fled in tatters, abandoning the city of Jinyang (Taiyuan) to the enemy. At this point, Li Xiao (first Emperor of Tang) and his group of allies lost their base to enemy forces; all the land east of the Yellow River was now under the control of Liu Wuzhou.
Li Xiao was running scared. He told his advisors: 몮It is impossible to contend with these bandits when their energy is like this. We should abandon the lands east of the Yellow River to him, and concentrate on guarding the lands west of the pass.몯 Li Shimin replied: 몮Taiyuan is the foundation of the King몭s entire cause; it is the very route of the country. The lands to the east of the Yellow River are rich, and it is from these lands that the capital derives its resources. Your humble advisor would hate for us to abandon these lands.몯 Then, Li Shimin asked for permission to personally lead 30,000 elite troops to deal with Liu Wuzhou and regain control of Taiyuan.
These were the events that led to the Battle of Baibi.
Li Shimin, taking advantage of thick ice on the Yellow River, crossed the river at the head of an army and arrived at Baibi. There, he confronted a detachment of Liu Wuzhou몭s army, under the command of General Song Jingang. Li Shimin and Li Daozong climbed up to a vantage point and looked down at the two armies. Li Shimin asked Li Daozong: 몮The enemy has so many soldiers 멪 what do you think will happen if they accept our challenge and come at us in force?몯
Li Daozong replied: 몮The bandits command an unstoppable force. It will be easy to make them submit using calculated strategy, but impossible to best them in a contest of strength.몯
몮My thoughts exactly,몯 Li Shimin said. 몮Song Jingang몭s army is seriously isolated; he has elite troops and ferocious generals under his command, and they are all gathered here. Liu Wuzhou is relying upon Song Jingang to hold us back so that he can retain control of Taiyuan, but Song몭s army lacks provisions. They rely on plundering to obtain the supplies they need, which means that it is to their advantage to finish this war quickly. I will close the gates of our camp and build up our energy until it is sharp enough to force back the enemy. Then, I will divide our army and send one part to strike the enemy in their belly. By that time, they will have used up their food supplies and exhausted their planning capabilities, and so they will naturally flee from our assault. This is the opportunity we should wait for; it would not be to our advantage to fight this war quickly.몯
몮Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen.몯 At that moment, Song Jingang몭s energy had reached its pinnacle 멪 it was as sharp as it would ever be. So, Li Shimin left him to stew. He waited for five long months, never venturing outside the walls of his camp, except to send small detachments to harass the enemy and disrupt their resupply routes. Eventually, Song Jingang ran out of food and lost the sharp energy that had made him so dangerous before. All he could do was withdraw.
As soon as Song Jingang withdrew, Li Shimin sprung into action, 몬attacking when the enemy is sluggish and inclined to return.몭 In ferocious pursuit, he and his army covered 200 li in a single day and night, fighting eight separate running battles as they went. After three days in which the Tang troops never once ate or took off their armor, the Tang generals finally called off the pursuit, announcing, 몮That will do.몯 They let their troops rest for a while, and once everyone had been fed and re-gathered, they set off once more in pursuit. Li Shimin said: 몮I planned this all out long ago: we will keep chasing and keep fighting, and by the time it몭s over, we몭ll have crippled the enemy for good!몯 The Tang forces kept up their pursuit, eventually pinning down Song Jingang몭s main force and annihilating them in a single fight. 
Liu Wuzhou, seeing that the tide had turned against him, abandoned Taiyuan and fled toward the lands of his Turkic allies. Before long, the Turks murdered him. And that is how Liu Zhouwu lost his power.
It was the same story when Li Shimin led a campaign against another rebellious warlord, Xue Rengao.
Xue Rengao had over 100,000 troops in his service, and they were full of energy, sharp and dangerous. Li Shimin used the same move he몭d used before, once again following the principle of 몬Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen.몭 After Li몭s generals begged him to allow them to attack the enemy, Li gave them a formal order: 몮Any man who dares speak of attacking shall be executed!몯 The two armies faced off for over 60 days, at which point Xue Rengao ran out of food. With no food, some of his men surrendered. It was clear to them that the other side몭s men got three square meals a day, while their own side had nothing left to eat.
When Li Shimin saw that the enemy had lost its sharp energy, and had come adrift from its purpose, he announced: 몮Now is the time to attack.몯
First, he sent out a small detachment to act as bait. Having lured out the few remaining enemy soldiers who still had the will to fight, his next move was to pour cold water over what was left of their sharp energy.
Li Shimin allocated part of his army to travel to Qianshuiyuan and set up camp there, under the command of General Liang Shi. Two months passed in which, try as they might, Xue Rengao몭s forces could not pull Li Shimin into a battle. One of Xue Rengao몭s generals, Zong Luohou, who was known to be a ferocious warrior, arrogant and always spoiling for a fight, couldn몭t take it anymore. He몭d reached breaking point. Zong moved out with his toughest soldiers and launched a blistering attack on Liang Shi. But, Liang Shi stayed safely behind his walls, content to let Zong wear himself out. Zong몭s response to Liang몭s refusal to engage was to redouble the intensity of his attack.
Li Shimin waited until Zong Luohou몭s energy was dulled and his stamina exhausted, and then personally led the bulk of his army onto the battlefield, delivering a crushing defeat to Zong. As Zong Luohou began to retreat, Li Shimin pursued him mercilessly, all the way to the foot of Xue Rengao몭s walls. Once there, he re-gathered his forces and surrounded Xue몭s position. Xue Rengaao, his nerves badly rattled, opened his gates and surrendered. Li Shimin took him prisoner and had him sent under armed guard to the capital city, Chang몭an, where he was executed.
The final years of the Sui dynasty were marked by the appearance of many heroic warriors, such as Li Mi, Dou Jiande and Liu Wuzhou. Each of them was a giant among men, but they were unfortunately up against a truly once-in-a-millennium fighter, a general so powerful that he was considered almost superhuman. That general was Li Shimin, and he wiped the floor with them.
What made Li Shimin such a great fighter was chiefly his ability to know when it was the wrong time to fight. His greatest power was knowing when to stay out of the way and hide. Then, once the enemy was drained of energy, he would unleash his power. He never had to fight more than one battle in a campaign 멪 he sealed the deal in the first round, and he always did a clean job. Everyone who fought against him was out-calculated, and wiped out.


Why do so many people gain nothing from their education? It몭s because what they몭re doing isn몭t studying, it몭s 몬correcting mistakes몭

Where people go wrong in their studies is by focusing on winning. If you want to make real gains from your studies, the key is to have a correct understanding of what studying actually is.

Extract from the original text:
몮It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare.몯

Analysis:
몮Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy.몯
When the enemy lays out bait for you, don몭t bite.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Fish die when they are greedy for bait; armies are defeated when they are hungry for bait. If the enemy uses soldiers to hook me, I must not follow them.몯
Our historical example for this subchapter is the story of how Cao Cao baited Liu Bei and Wen Chou.
Cao Cao was fighting a war against Yuan Shao. After executing Yan Liang and breaking the Siege of Baima, he and several hundred cavalry troops were escorting heavy grain wagons as they withdrew from the front line. He was still on the road when he ran into several thousand enemy soldiers led by Liu Bei and Wen Chou, who had been chasing him. Cao Cao몭s generals were shaken and scared. The way they saw it, the enemy had too many soldiers for them to fight, and their best option was to run back to the safety of their camp. Cao Cao몭s advisor, Xun You, said: 몮This is a situation in which we should bait the enemy. What should we do to drive them away?몯 They decided to abandon the heavy grain carts, while also unsaddling the horses and setting them free. This was a trick; a way of tempting Yuan Shao몭s troops. The plan worked 멪 Liu Bei and Wen Chou both went straight for the grain carts, and Yuan Shao몭s troops busied themselves stealing whatever they could. Fighting was the last thing on their minds. Then, Cao Cao and his men mounted their war horses, charged their distracted enemies and killed Wen Chou.
Du Mu provides a completely different commentary. According to him, the words 몬Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy몭 should be understood literally. In his interpretation, it means that you shouldn몭t eat any food that the enemy leaves behind because it might be poisoned. 몮If the enemy, being in a rush, leaves food behind after leaving a place, the food must first be tested and not eaten directly, for concern that it may have been poisoned.몯
Du Mu follows these words with a historical example.
During the reign of Emperor Wen of the Later Wei period (Cao Cao몭s second son), the imperial lands were raided frequently by the nomadic Kumo Xi people from the north. Emperor Wen ordered the King of Jiyin, Tuoba Xincheng, to take an army and deal with the Kumo Xi raiders. Tuoba Xincheng had his men collect a large number of wine jugs, which he filled with poisoned wine and deposited around his camp. When the enemy attacked, he pretended to think he was no match for them, and fled from his camp. When the enemy troops entered Tuoba Xincheng몭s deserted camp, they were delighted to find so much wine, and drank without restraint, happy for the chance to let their hair down. As the poison started to take effect, Tuoba Xincheng appeared out of nowhere, and this time it was he who was on the offensive. With no effort at all, he defeated the enemy, taking thousands of prisoners.
Was Du Mu몭s assertion about poisoning correct? Of course not. There몭s no way that Sun Tzu몭s original intention for this line was to remind us not to eat candy from strangers. But, it doesn몭t really matter that Du Mu몭s comment is incorrect relative to Sun Tzu몭s original intent, because there is still some value to it. From him, we have learned that there are real historical cases of poisoned wine being used to win a war.
There몭s one exceedingly common mistake we make when we몭re studying or talking through problems: we몭re focused exclusively on winning. Instead of concentrating on what we can learn, or on new experiences we can have, we think only about beating other people. When you몭re debating with someone, they might have made a very eloquent and strong point, and yet you rack your brains to come up with a counterpoint, because you want to beat them. Or, approaching from a different angle, you might be looking for a way to put your fellow debater off balance 멪 that way, you can show off your own skill, or at least show other people that you know more.
In classroom situations, when we ask the teacher a question, it몭s not always because we really have a question.  Sometimes it몭s just a way of displaying our 몬wisdom.몭 When class is dismissed, or when we finish reading some famous book, we exchange our ideas about what we몭ve learned with other people, but this isn몭t necessarily about having an intellectual exchange. Perhaps it몭s really about saying things like, 몬Well, I think what they said there is obviously wrong.몭
Wanting only to win is a very serious problem that can derail a person몭s studies. It makes you aggressive towards your fellow students in discussions, it makes you want to challenge your teachers, and when you read ancient texts, it even makes you want to 몬beat몭 the ancient writers themselves! As soon as you become obsessed with winning, you can no longer study with any sincerity. Instead, you hold on tight to the pleasure you gain from correcting mistakes. What you몭re doing isn몭t studying at all; it몭s correcting mistakes.
I felt and saw this very clearly while I was reading Eleven Commentaries on Sun Tzu몭s Art of War, because this text is the product of 11 different people writing in different historical time periods, Each one built on the foundation left by those came before him. The first commentator was Cao Cao, so he became a target for the others. Mainly, it was Du Mu who attacked him 멪 he shot so many arrows at Cao Cao몭s commentary that it ended up like a porcupine. Many of Du Mu몭s comments begin with the line. 몮What Cao Cao wrote is mistaken.몯 Cao Cao was long dead by the time Du Mu was writing, and he couldn몭t rise from his grave to argue back, so these textual 몬debates몭 were, naturally, entirely one-sided. Du Mu always won. But why was Du Mu always saying that Cao Cao was wrong? It몭s because it gave him a huge amount of pleasure to feel he had beaten Cao Cao.
Du Mu was a literary man 멪 a poet 멪 meaning that he took special joy in being original and unconventional. It seems to me that Du Mu probably wasn몭t thinking much about what practical use The Art of War might have in his own life when he was writing his commentary. Instead, he was likely  much more preoccupied with his own writings. If his commentary was too similar to those written by previous commentators, he may have felt, it would be meaningless.
Confucius once said: 몮He who is respectful to others will not be treated with insolence.몯 The other side of this is: If you are disrespectful to others, you will be treated with insolence. Du Mu had a habit of claiming that other people were wrong, and so, naturally, other people came after him and said he was the one who was wrong. That몭s why, each time the line, 몮What Cao Cao wrote is mistaken,몯 appears in Eleven Commentaries on Sun Tzu몭s Art of War, it몭s immediately followed by 몮What Du Mu wrote is wrong.몯 Mei Yaochen, in particular, made it his business to set the record straight. Mei Yaochen lived during the Song dynasty, and like Du Mu, he was also a poet. Du Mu had been dead for 200 years by the time Mei Yaochen was writing, so he obviously couldn몭t argue back.
In the final analysis, who do we think is right?
First of all, we몭re not really concerned with who was right. Our main interest is what we can learn, and what use the text has in our own lives. Reading and studying is about projecting what we learn onto ourselves and our own experiences. It몭s about applying what we learn to real-life situations and using it to figure things out. That몭s what real studying is about. It몭s a terrible mistake to chase after being 몬original,몭 and doing things just so that you can push your own theories.
Second, just because something몭s wrong does not mean it has no value. We몭re able to learn a great deal of unusual things from Du Mu몭s commentary. Isn몭t that a good thing? Also, he put a huge amount of work into writing his observations, and that몭s why he became the greatest and most influential of the 11 commentators. There몭s no need for us to correct his mistakes; it몭s enough to take what we can from his work.
The Prussian military theorist, Carl von Clausewitz, once said: 몮No matter how absurd a mistaken opinion may be, it at the very least enables us to learn other people몭s way of seeing things.몯 There is value in this. Sometimes, when someone tries to explain their theory to you, it seems so ridiculous that you can몭t even deal with it. At times like this, you should try to find something positive 멪 this person is teaching you that there are people out there who see things in this way!
Third, who몭s really right? This question is, quite naturally, something we pay a lot of attention to. After all, there is such a thing as right and wrong. So, who몭s right? I pretty much always assume that Cao Cao몭s comments set the standard. Why? Because Cao Cao몭s the only one who몭s actually 몬eaten the pork!몭 The others haven몭t so much as seen a pig running.
Apart from Cao Cao몭s commentary, there몭s one other book that has been an authoritative mainstay for me: A Translation and Commentary of Sun Tzu몭s Art of War, by Guo Huaruo. Guo Huaruo was a Lieutenant General in the People몭s Liberation Army of China, a graduate of the Whampoa Military Academy, and he taught for many years in the Counter-Japanese Military and Political University. His commentary is fit to be used as a standard go-to for any questions readers might have about The Art of War.
I often find myself in discussions with other people about Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, and  two questions often come up.
The first is whether Sun Tzu and Sun Bin were the same person. Nothing much can be said about this, other than that it몭s a boring question. There몭s no way they could have been the same person, because Sun Tzu worked with the King of Wu during the Spring and Autumn period, and much of the contents of The Art of War specifically talk about the state of Yue. Sun Bin lived in the state of Qi during the Warring States period, and by the time he was born, the state of Wu had long since fallen into history몭s dustbin. More than 100 years passed between Sun Tzu몭s death and Sun Bin몭s birth. The only reason there몭s debate about this is that some people want something to talk about, to show that they몭re cultured and knowledgeable. These people몭s theories aren몭t worth taking seriously 멪 they몭re only interested in empty talk, not in real learning.
The second point that몭s regularly questioned in discussions is the line: 몮Though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force.몯 When you look at this line in the context of the text that comes before and after, its meaning is as clear as day. 몮It is the rule in war, if our forces are ten to the enemy몭s one, to surround him; if five to one, to attack him; if twice as numerous, to divide the army12 into[bd22] two. If equally matched, we can offer battle; if slightly inferior in numbers, we can avoid the enemy; if quite unequal in every way, we can flee from him. Hence, though an obstinate fight may be made by a small force, in the end it must be captured by the larger force.몯
If you can win, go ahead and fight. If you can몭t win, then run. If you only have a 몬small force,몭 but you insist on being 몬obstinate몭멪 meaning that you refuse to run away 멪 you몭re going to be captured by the enemy. Or, at least, that몭s what everyone thinks it means. One prominent Chinese expert[bd23][TT24] who studies Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War who has a different interpretation of the original text. According to him, the real meaning of this line is: 몬If the weaker side is able to hold out obstinately, they몭re guaranteed to be able to capture their more powerful opponent, without killing him.몭 If that몭s really what Sun Tzu meant, there was no point in him saying the lines that came immediately before.
There is another interpretation, also from a highly regarded expert[bd25], that really takes the cake. So vast is his learning that he came up with a unique way of expressing his ideas. After all, if his writing were no different from other people몭s, his breathtaking scholarship would have no chance to shine. According to him, the word translated as 몬obstinate몭 actually means 몬the enemy몭s financial assets and equipment.몭 He argues that the line means: if you can beat the enemy, all his treasure and gear goes straight to you, regardless of how carefully he몭s locked it up and hidden it away! He then quotes a passage from the classic Daoist text, Zhuangzi, to prove his point: 몮Zhuangzi said: 몬If one would like to ensure that thieves come groping into your bags and rifling through your cupboards, and you want to make the right preparations, then you must lock up your things as tightly and securely as you can.몭몯
As soon as the distinguished professor몭s audience hears the Zhuangzi quotation, they몭re blown away: 몬Wow! You know everything!몭
As we contemplate the ills of education and academic pursuit, we might listen to what Wang Yangming wrote about it: 몮When there is already a fully adequate explanation for something, do not persist in constructing alternative theories to defeat the original one.몯 This isn몭t real learning. It몭s empty, and it몭s motivated only by a vain desire for victory.
When learning, just ask yourself what you몭re getting from it, and if it몭s useful to you. Don몭t pedantically quibble over words and manufacture farfetched connections, all in the belief that what you몭re doing is 몬scholarship.몭
This is why, during my studies of The Art of War, I try to understand it on another level 멪 I insert myself into what I read, and imagine what I would do if it was me. When we study, just like when we watch films, we naturally imagine ourselves on the winning side. We need to turn it around and imagine ourselves as the losing side, and think: 몬If it were me, what would I do about this situation?몭
Put yourself into the books you read, and then put the books you read into your own life and work. 
What has been revealed to me in my actual work, and what real-life situations have I been in that mirror scenarios and echo principles from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War?
True learning comes when you diligently hone and polish what you have learned.


Managing energy is about weighing one몭s willpower and matching it against your opponent몭s

Extract from the original text:
몮Do not hem in an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare.몯

Analysis:
The three instructions in the passages are about managing energy, and they all boil down to the principle of 몬not attacking soldiers whose temper is keen.몭

몮Do not hem in an army that is returning home.몯

When soldiers are on the homeward road, their minds are focused sharply on the fact that they몭re going home. If you get in their way, they몭ll fight you with everything they have.
But, weren몭t we just talking about how you should attack the enemy when their energy is sluggish? So, why aren몭t we supposed to 몬interfere with an army that is returning home?몭 This is a question of directions. If the enemy troops want to go home, and you몭re chasing them from behind 멪 and if they want nothing more than to get home as quickly as possible, and have no desire to fight you 멪 you몭re in a strong position to take advantage, in terms of energy.
However, if you몭re in front of the enemy, blocking their way home, they몭ll fight with everything they have. In that situation, their energy is stronger than yours.
Our historical example for this subchapter comes from Cao Cao몭s campaign against Zhang Xiu. The campaign wasn몭t going well for Cao Cao, and he decided to retreat. But Zhang Xiu몭s ally, Liu Biao, sent reinforcements and blocked Cao Cao몭s way home. Pressed in by enemies, in front and behind, Cao Cao set a trap. During the night, he stealthily moved out his heavy supply wagons and deployed troops in an ambush formation. Then, he waited for Zhang Xiu to come after him. The next day, Zhang Xiu came in hot pursuit and got caught in Cao Cao몭s ambush. With infantry and cavalry soldiers clamping him in a pincer from either side, Zhang Xiu suffered a major defeat. When the battle was over, Cao Cao said to an advisor, Xun Yu: 몮The bandits hemmed us in while we were returning home and gave me a situation of life and death; that is when I knew that victory was ours.몯
Du You comments: 몮If the enemy is wavering and is marching a great distance towards home, because of the perilous circumstances in which they march, each enemy soldier thinks only of returning home, and so the enemy army has the ability and the courage to fight even unto death. Be slow and watch for opportunities presented by the enemy; do not move great distances in order to intercept him.몯

몮When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.몯

When you surround an enemy, you have to leave a gap for him, so that he has a way out if he wants to run for his life.
There is a passage in The Methods of Sima that reads: 몮Surround him on three sides, leaving one side as an outlet. This is to show him a path to survival.몯
The intention here is to not corner the enemy in a deathtrap, which he has to fight his way out of alive, because in this scenario everyone dies fighting. The intention is to make him run away, and once he몭s running, to hit him with ambushes. Ideally, you would have troops lying in ambush at different points along the route that he몭ll take as he runs homeward. You let him run for a while, and take a bite out of him as he runs into the first ambush. Then, he runs some more, and runs straight into the next ambush 멪 and you take another bite. A few more bites like this, and you will have eaten and thoroughly digested every last part of him.
Turning back to Cao Cao몭s fight against Zhang Xiu, what is it that Zhang Xiu and Liu Biao should have done with their armies?
First of all, they shouldn몭t have completely surrounded Cao Cao, because they didn몭t have the ability to eat him. With no way out, and staring down death, every man in Cao Cao몭s armies fought for their lives 멪 they were unstoppable. Zhang and Liu should have let Cao Cao go, with Zhang Xiu chasing after him from behind, and Liu Biao waiting in ambush further down the road. But what Liu Biao actually did was attempt to hold a very dangerous position and block Cao Cao몭s way home. Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War tells us that we should surround our enemies if we have ten times his numbers. Liu Biao never had anything close to that kind of superiority.
If we recall, we몭ve already looked at this historical example, but from a different viewpoint. Just as Zhang Xiu was moving out to chase Cao Cao, one of his advisors, Jia Xu, told him that he mustn몭t chase Cao Cao unless he wanted certain defeat, because Cao Cao was bound to have set an ambush. Zhang Xiu didn몭t listen, ran straight into an ambush, and lost the battle. Upon his return, he asked Jia Xu: 몮Well, clearly you somehow know when I몭m bound to lose a battle, but can your abilities tell you when I몭m bound to win? It몭s not much use to me if you only know about losing. If I몭m going to win my battles, I need to know the results beforehand!몯 Jia Xu replied: 몮The time is now! Quick, go and give chase 멪 you are sure to win!몯 Zhang Xiu turned straight around, jumped on his horse and chased after Cao Cao once more. Just as Jia Xu had said, the next time he came back, he몭d just won a battle.
But why was that the case?
The first time that Zhang Xiu gave chase, he was 몬hemming in an army that is returning home.몭
But, the second time, he was 몬attacking when the enemy is sluggish and inclined to return.몭
The types of energy involved in these two scenarios are very different. The two sides몭 levels of determination had changed, and this in turn resulted in a major change to the fighting capacities of each side. 
Managing energy is about weighing up both sides몭 level of determination, and matching yours against theirs.

몮Do not press a desperate foe too hard.몯

Nothing fights harder than a cornered animal. If your enemy is already in a desperate situation, don몭t be too eager to get close to him. Don몭t press him so hard that he has nowhere left to run, because then he몭ll turn and fight to the death.
Somehow, at some point, the words 몬do not press a desperate foe too hard몭 morphed into 몬do not pursue a desperate foe.몭 But Sun Tzu never said that. 몬Do not press몭 and 몬do not chase몭 are two completely different things.
Of course you should chase them. Why wouldn몭t you?
Mao Zedong once said: 몮The general should ride the momentum of his courage and pursue the enemy when they are under pressure; the general should not vainly flatter himself and take after the example of past tyrants.몯


Appendix: Complete text of Armed Struggle

Sun Tzu said: 몮In war, the general receives his commands from the sovereign. Having collected an army and concentrated his forces, he must blend and harmonize the different elements thereof before pitching his camp. After that, comes tactical maneuvering, than which there is nothing more difficult. The difficulty of tactical maneuvering consists in turning the circuitous into the direct, and misfortune into gain. Thus, to take a long and circuitous route, after enticing the enemy out of the way, and though starting after him, to contrive to reach the goal before him, shows knowledge of the artifice of the circuitous and of the direct. Armed struggle can be advantageous, and it can be dangerous. If you set a fully equipped army in march in order to snatch an advantage, you will be too late. On the other hand, abandoning the army for the purpose involves the sacrifice of its baggage and stores. Thus, if you order your men to roll up their armor, and make forced marches without halting day or night, covering double the usual distance at a stretch, doing a hundred li in order to wrest an advantage, the leaders of all your three divisions will fall into the hands of the enemy. The stronger men will be in front, the jaded ones will fall behind, and on this plan only one-tenth of your army will reach its destination. If you march fifty li in order to outmaneuver the enemy, you will lose the leader of your first division, and only half your force will reach the goal. If you march thirty li with the same object, two thirds of your army will arrive. We may take it then that an army without its baggage-train is lost; without provisions it is lost; without bases of supply it is lost. We cannot enter into alliances until we are acquainted with the designs of neighboring lords. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country 멪 its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and obstructions, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantage to account unless we make use of local guides. In war, make deception the foundation upon which to stand, move with advantage, and change by dividing and consolidating. Let your rapidity be that of the wind, your compactness that of the forest. In attacking and ravaging the enemy be like fire, in immovability like a mountain. Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt. When you plunder a countryside, let the spoil be divided amongst your men; when you capture new territory, cut it up into allotments for the benefit of your men. Ponder and deliberate before you make a move. He will conquer who has learnt the artifice of turning the circuitous into the direct. Such is the art of armed struggle. The Book of Army Management says: On the field of battle, the spoken word does not carry far enough: hence the institution of gongs and drums. Nor can ordinary objects be seen clearly enough: hence the institution of banners and flags. Gongs and drums, banners and flags, are means whereby the ears and eyes of the gathered army may be focused on one particular point. The army thus forming a single united body, is it impossible either for the brave to advance alone, or for the cowardly to retreat alone. This is the art of handling large masses of men. In night fighting, then, make much use of signal fires and drums, and in fighting by day, of flags and banners, as a means of influencing the ears and eyes of your army. A whole army may be robbed of its spirit; a commander-in-chief may be robbed of his presence of mind. Now a soldier몭s spirit is keenest in the morning; by noonday it has begun to flag; and in the evening, his mind is bent only on returning to camp. A clever general, therefore, avoids an army when its spirit is keen, but attacks it when it is sluggish and inclined to return. This is the art of studying moods. Disciplined and calm, to await the appearance of disorder and hubbub amongst the enemy 멪 this is the art of retaining self-possession. To be near the goal while the enemy is still far from it, to wait at ease while the enemy is toiling and struggling, to be well fed while the enemy is famished 멪 this is the art of husbanding one몭s strength. To refrain from intercepting an enemy whose banners are in perfect order, to refrain from attacking an army drawn up in calm and confident array 멪 this is the art of managing changes. It is a military axiom not to advance uphill against the enemy, nor to oppose him when he comes downhill. Do not pursue an enemy who simulates flight; do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen. Do not swallow bait offered by the enemy. Do not interfere with an army that is returning home. When you surround an army, leave an outlet free. Do not press a desperate foe too hard. Such is the art of warfare.몯


Chapter Eight
Variation in Tactics

Making progress means constantly discovering what you can몭t do

What does it mean to know how to do something? It몭s impossible to say. Only people who know how to do the thing in question know what it means to 몬know how to do it.몭 Not only that, as time passes they find again and again that they can몭t do it anymore. They have to progress some more, and they have to keep growing their skill.

Extract from the original text:
몮In war, the general receives his commands from the sovereign, collects his army and concentrates his forces. When in difficult country, do not encamp. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies. Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem. In a desperate position, you must fight. There are roads which must not be followed, armies which must be not attacked, towns which must not be besieged, positions which must not be contested, commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed. The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops. The general who does not understand these may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account.몯

Analysis:
Variation in Tactics is the shortest chapter in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, at only just over 200 Chinese characters in the original text. However, the subject matter is complex 멪 it overlaps with content from other chapters, and the ordering and layout is a little chaotic. In particular, there몭s a part where Sun Tzu says, as a kind of summary, that if you don몭t know about the variations of tactics, no amount of knowledge about the terrain will enable you to actually take advantage of favourable terrain. This has prompted some researchers to say that this section should have been put at the end of Chapter Ten (Terrain). The suggestion is that once the reader is finished learning about terrain, they can be reminded that they have to know how to adapt to the situation at hand. There are also some related technical terms that only appear, with accompanying definitions, in Chapter Ten.
Anyway, while noting that some people might have something to say about this, let몭s stick to the order of the original text.
몬Variation몭 refers here to being able to adapt to changing circumstances, and being able to deal with a situation without relying on conventional principles. In the original text, the title of this chapter is actually Nine Variations. The Chinese tend to use numbers in a more general sense, so here, 몬nine몭 just means 몬many.몭 As such, Nine Variations could be translated as Several Types of Situations in which to Be Mindful of Adaptability.
However, Cao Cao clearly states that there are nine relevant situations in his commentary: 몮By considering the main variations, we derive nine principles to be used.몯 
This is awkward. We are presented with a circle to be squared. No matter which way you count it, there just aren몭t nine principles:
1. When in difficult country, do not encamp.
2. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies.
3. Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions.
4. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem.
5. In a desperate position, you must fight.
6. There are roads that must not be followed.
7. There are armies that must be not attacked.
8. There are towns that must not be besieged.
9. There are positions that must not be contested.
10. There are commands of the sovereign that must not be obeyed.
And the grand total is멞 ten principles!
Which brings us to an explanation offered by certain scholars, which is that there are 몬nine variations and one summary.몭 According to them, the tenth and final principle is actually just a summary of what has come before.
There몭s a vast number of studies and research about The Art of War, full of stuff like this. I generally don몭t use, or even discuss, this kind of material. It몭s not particularly relevant for our study of Sun Tzu몭s thinking whether there are nine principles or ten, and once you start getting into this kind of highly detail-oriented research, it can easily consume your whole academic career. This kind of work is the specialty of scholars and experts, and it몭s outside the scope of our studies. Even if we studied it, it wouldn몭t improve our critical thinking.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮몬Variation몭 refers to being unconfined to ordinary methods; it is about adapting to situations as they arise. It is about resourcing our actions from that which must be done. Whenever one is competing for advantage with another person, one must know the nine variations. That is why this chapter follows after Armed Struggle.몯
If you don몭t understand the art of war, you can몭t fight battles. If you go about your tasks using the principles of the art of war, but you still lose, that몭s because you don몭t understand Variations in Tactics.
This is why it몭s impossible to say what it means to know how to do something. As we said, only[bd26] people who know how to do the thing in question know what it means to 몬know how to do it.몭 And as time goes by, they can몭t do it anymore. They have to exercise and advance their skill.
Making progress means constantly discovering what you can몭t do.


It몭s better to go looking for death than to wait for It to come to you; when you find yourself facing death, fight with steely determination

Extract from the original text:
몮When in difficult country, do not encamp. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies. Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem. In a desperate position, you must fight.몯

Analysis:
Cao Cao, in his commentary, defines 몬difficult country몭 as 몬places in which nothing can be relied upon; places of water and ruin.몭 What he몭s talking about is places dominated by water: wetlands, lakes, marshes and any other locale where the sodden terrain makes travel difficult. Don몭t camp in places like this. When there몭s water everywhere, not only is it difficult to actually set up camp, but if the enemy shows up, you몭ll have a hard time building defenses and you won몭t have much ability to quickly move around the camp.

몮In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies.몯

몬Country where high roads intersect몭 refers to wide-open terrain, where it몭s possible to move in any direction. The original word used in the Chinese text 멪 qu, a rarely used term meaning 몬thoroughfare몭 멪  appears in the name of a city in Zhejiang Province. The city is called Quzhou, and it was given this name because it몭s easy to travel from Quzhou to four different provinces: Zhejiang, Fujian, Anhui and Jiangxi. This is the kind of place that military strategists fight over.
In ancient China, places where there is open country made it easy to travel between different feudal states. In these places, you need to 몬join hands with your allies.몭 In other words, make sure you get your foreign relations right. If you get that right, you몭ll get help from your allies. At the very least, make sure your neighbors don몭t see you as an enemy, and make sure they don몭t fall into enemy hands.

몮Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions.몯

Li Quan gives his definition of 몬dangerously isolated positions몭 in his commentary: 몮Dangerously isolated places are those in which there are no wells or natural water sources, no animals or livestock, and no firewood. One must not linger in such places.몯 
Jia Lin comments: 몮River canyons with dangerous waters and no through road 멪 this is what is called a dangerously isolated place; one should leave with haste, and must not linger.몯 If you find yourself in a dead end with dangerous terrain, get out of there quickly. Don몭t get boxed in by the enemy.

몮In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem.몯

We can find a definition of 몬hemmed-in situations몭 in Jia Lin몭s commentary: 몮When surrounded by danger on four sides, this is called a 몬hemmed-in situation.몭 The enemy is free to come and go, but I am unable to leave as I will. In this kind of situation, you may plan cunning stratagems to make the enemy unable to harm you; then, you can find salvation.몯
You face danger on all four sides, and the road ahead is narrow, while the road behind is tortuous and winding. It is easy for the enemy to travel here if he wants to, but it is difficult for me to come and go. Terrain like this is a 몬hemmed-in situation.몭 It몭s important to come up with a clever plan that makes it impossible for the enemy to hurt you. That몭s the only way to escape.
A good example of this is when Han Xin was about to deliver the final blow in the war against the state of Zhao. Before that, he had to get past Jingxing, a place with dangerous terrain, where it몭s easy to be hemmed in. With Jingxing, the clue is in the name. Jing means 몬well몭멪 as in 몬stuck at the bottom of a well몭 멪 and xing means 몬an area deep within a mountain range.몭 Han Xin took an extremely cautious approach, not daring to move his troops into Jingxing. Instead, he sent out spies, which gave him a clear picture of the situation. Only once he was sure there was no ambush did he swagger his way through the area, cross through the mountain pass and begin staging his famous show 멪 몬Han Xin fights with his back to the river.몭

 몮In a desperate position, you must fight.몯

After passing through terrain where he could easily have been hemmed in, Han Xin deployed his troops by the river 멪 a deathtrap 멪 and yet he came out alive.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮When obstacles impede you in front and behind, the time has come to settle the battle in a death struggle.몯
He Shi comments: 몮He who quickly seeks battle will survive; he who dallies and does not fight will exhaust his energy, and meanwhile his grain supply lines are severed. Why wait for death?몯
When you몭re in a deathtrap, it really is true that it몭s better to go looking for death than to wait for it to come to you. When faced with death, greet it with a steely resolve, and fight.


The psychology of strategic decision-making: The decision-maker몭s 몬personal needs몭 are always in the background

These 몬needs몭 might be someone몭s personal ambitions, their financial interests or those of their company. They might be emotional 멪 some kind of unresolved complex or anxiety, or some sort of shadow cast by their psyche. These are all possibilities. To analyze a person몭s decision-making, it몭s important to consider one몭s own, personal viewpoint. When it몭s time for you to make decisions, you need to have awareness of 몬no self.몭 This means stripping away emotional and other personal factors from your decision-making. This is how you make the right choices.

Extract from the original text:
몮There are roads which must not be followed.몯

Analysis:
There are some roads that, though possible to travel along, should not be taken. The opposite is also true: some roads are impossible to use, and yet there몭s a chance you might take them. This is where 몬variation몭 comes in to play.
Li Quan comments: 몮Some roads are narrow and dangerous, and may not be travelled lest one walk into an ambush.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮One should not follow roads which pass through dangerously narrow places; if there is no choice but to follow this road, then this is the result of variation.몯
We have already looked at the case study of Han Xin defeating the state of Zhao several times now. The story involves a road that should not have been used as a military route: Jingxing Pass. Han Xin only made the decision to pass through this place after he몭d received intelligence from his spies that the Zhao commander, Chen Yu, had opted not to use Li Zuoche몭s idea of sending part of the Zhao army to set an ambush at Jingxing Pass. If there had been an ambush, as Han Xin said to Li Zuoche after capturing him, 몮If Chen Yu had employed your stratagem, our respective situations would be reversed 멪 it is I who would be your prisoner.몯
몬The General who Calms the Waves,몭 Ma Yuan of the Han dynasty, lost the final battle in his campaign to put down a rebellion of five non-Chinese ethnic groups precisely because he took the wrong road.
When Ma Yuan and his vice general, Geng Shu, first mobilized their troops, they won some early victories that forced the barbarian armies to hide in the mountain forests. Ma Yuan was ready to close in on the enemies몭 base, but first he had to choose which of two roads to take. The route through Chong County had good roads, but was very long, while the route from Hutou was short, but also dangerous, because it would involve water travel.
Ma Yuan decided that it would waste too much grain to take the long, land route through Chong County, and that the better option was to take the water route. Anyway, he thought, if he could take the enemy base directly, Chong County would be his, too, and without any extra fighting.
However, Geng Shu strongly disagreed. He said that the land road might be long, but it was safer. Even if they were unable to break into the enemy Miao territory, they몭d have an easy route to retreat. He argued that the water route was too dangerous, unless they could somehow reach the enemy base undetected. Otherwise, the enemy could easily take up positions above them, on the high ground to either side of the water. Unless by some miracle they could grow wings, they몭d be stuck in deep water and wedged between high hills, doomed to a watery grave.
But Ma Yuan wouldn몭t change his mind. He argued that the land route wasn몭t so safe, anyway 멪 there could be an ambush anywhere. Neither man could convince the other, so they sent a message detailing their positions to the imperial court. In the end, Emperor Guangwu supported Ma Yuan몭s opinion. 
So, the Han army embarked on boats and travelled upriver into Hutou. It went exactly as Geng Shu predicted: the Miao fighters quickly found out what the Han army was up to, and took up a strong position on high ground above the narrow river. This was the Yuan River, whose  fast-flowing waters made it difficult for boats to move against the current, and their slow progress, combined with the sticky summer heat, caused sickness among the troops. Whole chunks of the army died, including Ma Yuan himself.
Why did Ma Yuan make this mistake?
First of all, the land route wasn몭t necessarily the right choice, either. We judge choices as being 몬right몭 or 몬wrong몭 in hindsight, by looking at the result. But, in reality, what we call 몬right몭 isn몭t necessarily right, and what we call 몬wrong몭 isn몭t necessarily wrong.
Having said that, there몭s no doubt that the water route was dangerous, and the more risky choice overall. By choosing it, Ma Yuan was gambling with his life. Why did he do that? If you look at Ma Yuan몭s psychology and his emotional landscape before the campaign, you can see that the writing was already on the wall.
When the campaign started, Ma Yuan was already sixty-two years old.
When the 몬barbarian몭 forces raided Jun County, Emperor Guangwu sent 몬the General of Martial Power,몭 Liu Shang, to deal with them. Liu was defeated and his army destroyed at a battle by the Yuan River. The next year, a respected senior general, Li Song, and Ma Cheng, governor of Zhongshan, were sent out into the field, but still the Han army couldn몭t make positive gains. Ma Yuan then asked for permission to lead an army out, but Emperor Guangwu refused, out of concern that Ma Yuan was too old. But Ma Yuan protested: 몮Your servant is still capable of donning armor and mounting a horse.몯 So, Emperor Guangwu ordered him to do a test ride on a horse. Ma Yuan jumped into the saddle, and turned to look at the Emperor, eager to show he still had what it takes. The Emperor laughed, and said: 몮I declare this fellow hearty and hale!몯 He ordered Ma Yuan to lead Geng Shu, Commander of the Palace Guard Ma Wu, Liu Kuang, Sun Yong and various other generals 멪 along with a force of over 40,000 soldiers 멪 to put down the barbarian rebellion.
As they set out, Ma Yuan bade a nighttime farewell to various people who had come to see him off on his expedition. To his friend Du Yin, he said: 몮I am an old man now. I have often worried that I would not have the opportunity to die for my country, but today, my wish has been granted. Now I can die at peace.몯
Ma Yuan was determined to be a martyr. In fact, he몭s the original source for a well-known idiom in Chinese that refers to dying on the battlefield: 몬corpse wrapped in horse hide.몭 He apparently said: 몮A man ought to die in the wilderness, his body wrapped in horse hide to be carried home for burial. How could I just lay in bed and let myself be possessed by evil spirits, in the hands of my children?몯 All he wanted was to die on the battlefield, and not at home in bed.
Ma Yuan was an old man when he set out to put down the Miao rebellion, and he no longer cared whether he died. For him, this was the last chance to win glory in service of his country. Of course he knew the dangers of the water route 멪 how could he not, after spending his whole life fighting? But this particular war against the Miao had already dragged on for two years, and three Han commanders-in-chief had already been recalled and replaced. The only thing to be said for the land road was that it made for an easy retreat. It was good for self-preservation, but not necessarily good for winning.
몮This will be my last war 멪 if I don몭t establish my legacy now, there will be no more chances.몯 Ma Yuan had decided to gamble with his life.
But why were the young people in his army willing to follow this old man and gamble on their own lives?
Stranded in a river valley, unable to move forward or backward, disease was spreading rampantly through the ranks of the Han army, and men were dying in droves every day. Geng Shu was beside himself with anxiety. But he was a young man, and a young man몭s words carry no weight. The Emperor would never listen to him, so there was nothing he could do. He wrote a letter to his elder brother, Geng Yan, telling of the situation and asking him to go and talk with the Emperor.
Geng Yan could tell the situation was serious, and he immediately requested an audience with the Emperor. His words carried more weight than his younger brother몭s, and the military situation really was dire, so Emperor Guangwu sent Liang Song to ask Ma Yuan some hard questions, and to supervise the army몭s operations. By the time Liang Song arrived at the army몭s locations, Ma Yuan was already dead.
In the end, the Han forces didn몭t win their war. Instead, they came up with a plan that resulted in the Miao forces murdering their leader and surrendering. The rebellion was over.
Ma Yuan gambled with his life, and in return his name became immortal thanks to the idiom 몬corpse wrapped in horse hide.몭 But he wasn몭t the only one. Because of him, many thousands of Han soldiers and officers also went home wrapped in horsehide.
It몭s possible that this psychological analysis of Ma Yuan몭s decision-making is just my own, subjective judgment. But멞
Whenever a strategic decision is being made, the decision-maker몭s 몬personal needs몭 are always lurking in the background.
몬No self몭 is an objective rock to stand on. Make a decision with 몬no self,몭 and it몭s guaranteed.


Not fighting: An important element of war

Extract from the original text:
몮There are armies which must not be attacked.몯

Analysis:
Sometimes, though it may be possible to attack the enemy army, you don몭t do it.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Though an army may be attacked, if the terrain be adverse and difficult to travel, then lingering there will cause you to lose formerly held advantages, and taking it will give you only a meager advantage. If the enemy army is small and beleaguered, it will certainly fight unto death.몯
If you find a small, down-on-its-luck enemy force holed up in the kind of terrain that can easily turn into a deathtrap, there몭s not much to gain by wiping them out. In fact, doing so would mean paying a big price, possibly even holding up your entire war plan. If that몭s the case, don몭t fight.
Du Mu, in his commentary, writes that this line refers back to earlier lines: 몮Do not attack soldiers whose temper is keen; do not interfere with an army that is returning home; do not press a desperate foe too hard; do not attack terrain where death abounds.몯 These all refer to armies that shouldn몭t be attacked. Du Mu also raises one other situation where an army shouldn몭t be attacked. Namely, if your army is stronger than the enemy몭s, and the enemy vanguard arrives before the rest of their forces, don몭t attack them straight away and cause them to run. Wait until the rest of the enemy troops show up, and then take down their whole army in one fell swoop. 
Jia Lin comments: 몮Causing your enemy to submit without fighting him is supreme excellence.몯 If you can cause your enemy to surrender, there is no need to attack. He also saw that if the enemy forces, though hard-pressed, are holding a position in dangerous terrain, such that attacking them will result in 몮a fight unto death,몯 don몭t attack. Wait patiently for the enemy몭s situation to change, and wait for them to become sloppy, and then take them.
Zhang Yu adds: 몮There is no harm in indulging the enemy, and nothing to gain by defeating them.몯 This is another kind of situation where you shouldn몭t attack.
Don몭t be greedy for small gains. When all that몭s on offer is a few tasteless scraps, you don몭t lose anything by not eating. On the contrary, if you see some small gain dangling in front of you, and immediately want to take it, you몭re delaying your real business and potentially sabotaging your grand plan.
We몭ve already talked about how marching is a part of war, one that might even be more important than actually fighting. We몭ve also talked about how camping is a part of war. Now, we몭re beginning to see that not fighting is also an element of war. This is about weighing pros and cons, and it몭s about being able to see the overall picture. If you weigh up the pros and cons, it몭s not worth killing 1,000 enemy troops if it means losing 800 of your own. In terms of the bigger picture, a low-level gain might end up having a negative effect on your overall position, perhaps because it delays the day of the battle that몭s going to win you the war.
It seems like quite a simple sentence 멪 몬There are armies which must not be attacked몭 멪 that you몭d think you could understand it the moment you hear it. Yet, we need to remember that when we read books and study, the aim is to bring what we learn into our own lives. If we apply this notion to our own lives, we find that there isn몭t a single day when we actually live up to these words. We몭re unable to actually not do certain things: not get sucked in to certain social engagements, or not drink alcohol in certain situations.
Don몭t let yourself think that you몭re a hardworking, honorable caricature of a person, or that you몭re some brave, mythical warrior. And don몭t let yourself feel guilty whenever you stop working for a moment to rest. If you keep yourself busy to the point of organ failure on a daily basis, if you몭re constantly grasping after every opportunity you get a sniff of, you몭ll end up losing what you already have because you몭re distracted by going after things you don몭t have. This mentality doesn몭t work; you몭ll never be able to really build anything.
It몭s better to just stop, do some proper planning, and work out what exactly it is that you want.


The art of war for rebels: The name of the game is speed

Extract from the original text:
몮There are towns which must not be besieged.몯

Analysis:
Some cities, though it may be possible to take them by force, should not be attacked.
Cao Cao comments: 몮If the city walls are small but solid, and if the grain supplies are ample, then one must not attack it. This is why I laid aside thoughts of capturing the cities of Hua and Fei, and instead plunged deep into Xu Province, by which action I gained territory of forty counties.몯
Du Mu, in his commentary, says that if your enemy is positioned at a strategic point, and has dug deep moats and stored up vast amounts of grain, their intention is to hole up and delay your forces. If you attack him and manage pull him out by the roots, there몭s not much benefit for you. Even worse is if you attack him but can몭t beat him 멪 that몭ll really scupper your war plans. In this situation, don몭t attack.
This line, 몬There are towns which must not be besieged,몭 is more important for rebels than for anyone else. This is 몬The Art of War for Rebels.몭 Or, at least, you could call it that.
If you몭re ever thinking of starting a rebellion, the best plan you could choose is to take the capital city as quickly as physically possible, and get rid of the Emperor. Then, you get to be Emperor. But if, for whatever reason, your progress gets held up, the whole country will mobilize to come to their Emperor몭s rescue, and before you know it you몭ll be faced with a massive army standing in your way. At that point, your rebellion몭s a lost cause.
We몭ve already looked at how the Ming dynasty statesman Wang Yangming defeated the Prince of Ning몭s rebellion. If the Prince of Ning had focused all his strength on taking the city of Anqing, the capital, Nanjing, would be within his grasp. Once he entered Nanjing, he몭d have the political capital to declare himself Emperor, and once he몭d done that, all the government officials and court politicians would be forced to choose a side. The Zhengde Emperor, who was in power at the time, was laughably unsuited to be the 몬Son of Heaven,몭 so the Prince of Ning wasn몭t lacking for opportunity.
Wang Yangming, taking advantage of the fact that the Prince of Ning몭s stronghold city, Nanchang, was undefended, marched in and took it, gambling that the Prince of Ning would withdraw his army and attempt to take back Nanchang. The Prince몭s advisors tried to reason with him until they were red in the face: 몮There are towns which must not be besieged! We don몭t need Nanchang! Once we have Nanjing, the whole world will be ours 멪 including Nanchang! If we get bogged down in Nanchang, we몭ll lose our chance. We몭ll be finished!몮
But the Prince of Ning couldn몭t stand the thought of his home city being captured, so he abandoned his siege of Anqing, which had been about to fall, and pulled his armies back toward Nanchang. He never made it there 멪 he was captured by Wang Yangming when he was only half-way back, at Poyang Lake.
The Prince of Ning was inspired to launch his rebellion partly by the earlier success of Zhu Kang, who became Emperor Chengzu of the Ming dynasty. But Zhu Kang몭s strategy was precisely that 몬there are towns which must not be besieged.몭 At the start of Zhu Kang몭s uprising, he spent a lot of time stuck in stalemate. He was mostly fighting in Hebei and Shandong Provinces, and although his army (the Yan army) won slightly more than they lost, he suffered heavy casualties, while the imperial army had a massive pool of manpower to call upon. If the imperial commanders could drag the conflict out, Zhu Kang would be unable to get the better of them.
Later in the war, Zhu Kang got word from an imperial court eunuch in his service that Nanjing was poorly defended. So, he changed his whole strategy, drew up a large army, and personally led it directly to Nanjing. He fought his way to Yangzhou, at which point an imperial naval commander named Chen Xuan surrendered to Zhu Kang, handing him a fleet. He crossed the Yangzi River, made his way down to Zhenjiang, and then straight to Nanjing, where Zhu Hui, Prince of Gu, and Li Jinglong opened the Jinchuan gate and surrendered. Zhu Kang몭s rebellion had succeeded.
During the reign of Empress Wu Zetian of the Tang dynasty (665-690 CE), Xu Jingye attempted a rebellion. His advisors urged him to move directly on the city of Luoyang, which Empress Wu had turned into the new capital city. If he did that, they몭d suggested, he몭d be cutting straight to the heart of the Empress몭 power, and he could neutralize the fact that she had far more followers than him. It might also bring more people to his cause, which was the only hope for his rebellion bid to succeed. But Xu Jingye chose not to move north toward Luoyang, and instead marched south with ambitions to capture the cities of Changzhou, Zhenjiang and the old imperial capital Nanjing, where he planned to finally achieve his dream of becoming an Emperor. But, this move sent a clear message to everyone: his ambition only went as far as separatism. He was just interested in carving out a kingdom independent from the Tang dynasty, without actually replacing it. So, nobody followed him.
Du Mu also wrote about another rebellion, that of a man named Shen Youzhi, who held de facto control of Jing Province. He몭d attempted a rebellion against Emperor Shun (477-479 CE) of the Liu Song dynasty. He was well funded: according to historical documents, he몭d built up a force of 100,000 men and 2,000 armored horses, and had significant stockpiles of grain. When he made his move, the first target for his rebel army was the city of Ying.
