A minister named Cang Yin of the Bureau of Merit once said that it is easy for shifts to occur in the balance of energy between attackers and defenders. In the case of the city of Ying, it was easy to defend and difficult to attack. It certainly couldn몭t be taken unless you committed 10-15 days to besieging it. And, if you weren몭t able to capture it smoothly, your aura of strength would dissipate, along with the initial sharpness of your energy. The soldiers in rebel armies never have much say; they become rebels whether they like it or not. So, at the first inkling that things aren몭t going well, the rebel army몭s entire mentality changes. What Shen Youzhi should have done was steer clear of Ying and instead move down the river and take the city of Jiankang (an older name for Nanjing). If he몭d done that, he could have torn the Liu Song dynasty up by the roots, and Ying would have fallen into his hands by Shen Youzhi몭s imperial decree.
Shen Youzhi didn몭t listen to his advisors, and even though he committed all of his best troops to attacking the city of Ying, he was denied victory by the Commandery Governor, Liu Shilong. The soldiers who had followed Shen could now see that even this, the very first battle, was far from an easy task. They saw that their rebellion몭s chances of success were extremely slim, and so, unwilling to be convicted for a crime that would see them and their entire families executed, they deserted. Shen몭s rebel army fell apart. He realized that he몭d lost control of the situation, and walked alone into a forest and hanged himself. And that was the end of his life몭s work, his rebellion. It had been pure foolishness.
In another, later era, military strategists in a certain western country developed a strategy that has been summarized as 몬deep battle몭 or 몬strategic paralysis.몭 It몭s about driving deep into the enemy country몭s heart and paralyzing their central nervous system. When you do this, the whole country surrenders. Don몭t fuss around with setting up new camps and new defensive lines with every forward step you take; in fact, don몭t even wait for your supply line to catch up with you. The key is to be quick. This is none other than Hitler몭s and Guderian몭s blitzkrieg (몬flash war몭) method of warfare.


There몭s a price to pay for everything

In Chinese society, we have a culture of 몬talking big.몭 For example, people love to talk about doing things 몬no matter what the cost.몭 In reality, there몭s nothing in this world that is beyond calculations of 몬cost.몭 There몭s a price to pay for everything.

Extract from the original text:
몮There are positions which must not be contested.몯

Analysis:
There are some places that, although it might be possible to take them by force, you shouldn몭t fight over.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Positions which can bring only small benefit are liable to cause loss as soon as they have been won; therefore, do not contest them.몯 
Du Mu comments: 몮It is said that there is no harm in losing a position which, once gained, is difficult to defend. Wu Zixu once advised Fuchai thus: 몬If today we attack Qi and take their land, that land will be alike to a field full of stones; it would be better to make haste and take action in Yue.몭몯
Wu Zixu wanted Fuchai, King of Wu, to try to seize the land of the state of Yue, and not of the state of Qi. His reasoning was this: both Wu and Yue were southerly kingdoms, so the land of Yue would be easy both to defend and to farm for the people of Wu. But, the state of Qi was in the north, and its land wouldn몭t be much use to the Wu invaders; it would also be difficult to defend against invaders.
However, Fuchai was already very happy with life at that time. He was enjoying the pampering being showered on him by the King of Yue, Goujian. He spent his days in the arms of the renowned beauty, Xi Shi, who had been gifted to him by Goujian. He fundamentally didn몭t believe there was any need to wipe out the state of Yue. Instead, his interests were much more focused on the Central Plain region to the north. He wanted to fight with the states of Qi and Jin in a bid to establish himself as undisputed ruler of the known world. 
So, Fuchai fell into Goujian몭s trap 멪 the stratagem of sowing discord 멪 and ordered Wu Zixu to be killed. Then, just as Fuchai had moved north at the head of an army, Goujian seized his chance. While the lands of Wu were unguarded, he launched a sudden attack, during which he killed the crown prince. Several years later, the state of Wu was obliterated by Yue, and Fuchai killed himself.
As students of history, it몭s hard not to give a wistful sigh every now and then. Wu Zixu did such good work for his country, and he was so important to Wu 멪 how could Fuchai kill him? How could he be so self-destructive? The reason we might think this way is because of our position. We몭re observers. From Fuchai몭s point of view, the power and success of Wu was his own work, and he certainly would never give the credit to Wu Zixu.
Du Mu also writes about another historical example. It몭s the story of a general named Tao Kan. 
During the Eastern Jin dynasty (317-420 CE), Tao Kan was stationed in the Wuchang garrison. Across the Yangzi River, on the north bank, there was a city called Zhucheng. The officers around Tao Kan were all trying to talk him into sending an army to take Zhucheng, but Tao Kan ignored them. The officers kept pushing the idea, so Tao Kan took them across the river on a hunting trip.
During the trip, he went near Zhucheng, and told them: 몮The reason why I foresee danger here and opt for a defensive posture is because of the danger presented by the Yangzi River. Zhucheng is on the north bank; it has no hinterland upon which to rely, and it is menaced by barbarians from outside. Lusting after the profit to be gained from Zhucheng will not only lead us into a place that is impossible to defend, but it will also incite barbarians to come. So, gaining Zhucheng will bring no benefit to our lands south of the river; on the contrary, it would invite disaster.몯
Years later, the Jin general Yu Liang attempted to hold Zhucheng, and sure enough, he suffered a crushing defeat.
To gain territory, the highest price must be paid, and the people must suffer the greatest misery. The so-called 몬Emperor Wu the Great몭 of the Han dynasty once said: 몮Any who dare use force against Han will surely be brought to the executioner, no matter how far away they may be.몯 Because of these words, many people today think of Emperor Wu as a great hero, and he몭s hailed in history books as a great ruler and military leader. And yet, if you actually lived during the time of his reign, your fate would have been one of misery, and no escape. You could go to the front lines and lose your life on a blood-soaked battlefield, or you could stay at home and suffer all kinds of hardships, because Emperor Wu bankrupted the entire country.
In his later years, as the country tottered on the brink of collapse, and under enormous political pressure, he published his famous self-criticism, in which he called himself 몮arrogant and unreasonable.몯 On that count, he was right.
Some 800 years later, the Tang dynasty poet Du Fu left behind one of the most famous Chinese poems of all, A Song of War Chariots, which speaks of the time when Emperor Wu was fighting his wars of expansion:
몮Frontiers on which enough blood has flowed to make a sea,
Yet our Emperor still would expand his authority!
Have you not heard how east of Huashan two hundred counties are nothing but weed-choked villages, desolate with thorns?
Strong women till the fields, yet crops come not as well as before; 
Lads from around here are well known for their bravery, but hate to be driven like dogs or chickens;
Only because you kindly ask me do I dare give vent to grievances;
Now the year is ending, yet the men from the western frontier still have not returned; the government demands immediate payment of taxes, but how can we pay when so little has been produced? 
Now, we peasants have learnt one thing: To have a son is not so good as having a daughter
A daughter can marry a neighbor and still be near us, while a son will be taken away to die in the grass in some wild place몯


The words 몬Sometimes, the lord몭s orders may not be received몭 are meant for the ears of kings and lords, not for battle commanders

If a commander on the front lines wants to be able to 몬not receive몭 his lord몭s commands, first he must be committed to sacrificing himself.

Extract from the original text:
몮There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed. The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops. The general who does not understand these, may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account. So, the student of war who is unversed in the art of war of varying his plans, even though he be acquainted with the Five Advantages, will fail to make the best use of his men.몯

Analysis:
Sometimes, orders from the leader of the country should not be obeyed. For example, if a command doesn몭t take into account the actual situation on the front line, it should be rejected.
This line 멪 몮There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed몯 멪 is one of the most famous passages in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. Cao Cao comments: 몮Providing that it be expedient to handling affairs, one should not be constrained by the sovereign몭s commands.몯 If it몭s good for your battle position, there몭s no need to stick to the letter of the sovereign몭s orders.
There몭s a passage in the Wei Liaozi that reads: 몮War is a matter of deadly weapons; to fight in a war is to defy morality, and to be a general is to be a dead man. For him, there is no heaven above, no earth below, no enemy in front, and no lord behind.몯
This passage means that battle commanders work in the space between life and death, and nothing is off the table for them if it means surviving 멪 there are no moral standards, no law and no heaven above. The 몬king몭 ceases to exist.
But is that really true?
If it were true, it would be impossible to command an army.
Because generals sometimes don몭t obey commands from their rulers, so too there are junior officers who sometimes don몭t obey commands from the general. If everyone몭s making their own judgment calls, and ignoring the judgment of their senior commanders, how are you supposed to control an army?
This brings us to two concepts that are crucial to understanding this passage.
First, this line is mainly intended to be read by kings and lords. Its message to them is that they should let the people who are actually within earshot of the cannons to do the decision-making, and rein in, as much as they can, their impulse to 몬remote control몭 the army.
Secondly, this is about one of the 몬nine variations몭 멪 it몭s about staying open to change. What this means is that this isn몭t a normal situation; this is for special circumstances. This line is saying that, although it몭s a crime to disobey the sovereign몭s commands, a crime that carries the death penalty, if you find yourself in exceptional circumstances, in which obeying orders would mean certain death, while disobeying them would be good for the country, you can 몬adapt몭 and disobey. 
But, if you몭re a general, you absolutely shouldn몭t take the concept of 몬There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed몭 at face value. When this line was first written, the man who held the pen was a battle commander, and he was writing specifically for the eyes of kings and Emperors. His idea in writing this line was definitely not that it would be taken seriously only by generals and not by their kings. He wasn몭t trying to give generals the idea that nobody was above them on the decision-making ladder, and that they had the unique right to call the shots.
Let몭s take a look at the historical record, shall we? Was it actually true that sometimes the sovereign몭s orders could be ignored? The answer to that would be멞 no.
During the chaos of the Tang dynasty몭s An Lushan Rebellion, Imperial Commander Geshu Han was committed to holding a defensive position at his fortress in Tongguan Pass, and to keeping his army safe behind its thick walls. However, Emperor Xuanzong was piling pressure on him to come out and engage the enemy in the open. Geshu Han knew that fighting in the open would mean certain defeat. So, did the thought occur to him that 몬There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed?몭 Yes, it did. But there were consequences for those who disobeyed the sovereign몭s orders 멪  most notably, the death sentence. Geshu Han had already seen two prominent imperial generals meet this very fate at the hands of Emperor Xuanzong: Gao Xianzhi and Feng Changqing, both staunch pillars of the state. And so, Geshu Han came shaking and sobbing out of his fortress, leading the Tang army into battle. He lost, badly. Tongguan Pass fell to the enemy, Geshu Han was captured, and Emperor Xuanzong abandoned the capital city of Chang몭an and fled toward Sichuan.
Then there몭s the case of another toweringly famous Chinese general, Yue Fei. He nearly pulled off a stunning success during his northern expedition, but fell at the final hurdle. As he mulled his defeat, he received a summons from Emperor Gaozong, calling him back from the front line. Was it an option for him to disobey the Emperor몭s orders? If he몭d chosen that path, he몭d be dead 멪 the Emperor would send a Military Supervisor armed with an Imperial edict, and he몭d be executed it in his own camp. 
We can take another look here at a historical example from earlier on, to answer the question of whether or not a lower-ranking officer can disobey his general몭s orders.  It was covered in detail in an earlier chapter, but bears repeating.
There was an episode during the war between the states of Qin and Zhao in which a massive Qin army surrounded the city of Yuyu. The Zhao commander, Zhao She, marched his army to the city in a bid to break the Qin encirclement. But, he halted his army with thirty li of road left before reaching the city of Handan, set up camp and fortified his position. Pretending he had no intention of moving any closer to the enemy, he circulated an order through his army: 몮Any man who offers unsolicited suggestions regarding military matters shall be executed!몯
Meanwhile, as the Qin army carried on its siege of Yuyu, a secondary force was formed to hold off the Zhao army and prevent it from reaching the city. This secondary force moved directly to Wu몭an, splitting the Qin forces into two parts and positioning them in a pincer shape. In the Zhao camp, a junior officer, distraught with worry, went to Zhao She with urgent counsel. The gist of the officer몭s advice was that the army should hurry over to Wu몭an, otherwise this would happen and that would happen. As promised, Zhao She executed him on the spot.
Zhao She waited just long enough for the Qin forces to let down their guard and start believing he몭d only come to make it look like he was doing something to 몬relieve the besieged city,몭 but didn몭t actually want to fight. Then, all of a sudden, Zhao She made his move. With a light force, he marched non-stop, day and night, straight towards Yuyu. When he몭d reached within fifty li몭s distance of the city walls, he halted and set up camp. One of his soldiers, a man named Xu Li, looked at the terrain around the camp and came to Zhao She with a suggestion: 몮Victory will belong to whomever holds the mountain to the north. My lord, I hereby request that we set our camp atop the northern mountain, and that we draw defensive lines there.몯 Zhao She agreed with the idea. Then, Xu Li said: 몮I have said what I came to say. My lord, please execute me now in accordance with your decree!몯 Zhao She only said: 몮We will delay this matter until our return home.몯
Later, when the battle had been won and the Zhao army had returned home, Xu Li was promoted to the office of Defender in Chief.
What can we see from this case study? The first man, the one who was executed, could see part of what was going on, but not the full picture; he could see the outermost layer, but not the essence. So, his judgment fell short of his commanding officer몭s, yet he still tried to disobey his commander몭s orders, which led him straight to the executioner. His head was separated from his shoulders, and became a component in Zhao She몭s strategy.
The second man who disobeyed his commander몭s orders, Xu Li, had the sense that he was walking into certain death. According to his logic, his life belonged to the country, so if his words might be of use to the country, he would speak them and die with no regrets.
The lesson is that if you want to actually disobey certain orders from your superiors, you need to be committed to sacrificing yourself.

몮The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops. The general who does not understand these, may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account. So, the student of war who is unversed in the art of war of varying his plans, even though he be acquainted with the 몬Five Advantages,몭 will fail to make the best use of his men.몯
 

This passage is a summary of the first part of this chapter of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. If a general has complete understanding of how to vary his tactics to adapt to the changes mentioned above, he understands how to use military force. If he doesn몭t, even if he understands the terrain he몭s situated in, he won몭t be able to gain any advantage from it. If you try to command an army without understanding how to adapt your tactics, then even if you know about the 몬Five Advantages,몭 you still won몭t be able to unleash the full potential of your army몭s battle capability.
There몭s a concept that pops up here 멪 몬The Five Advantages몭 멪 which actually means the same thing as 몬The Nine Variations.몭 It refers to five different kinds of situations within the framework of the nine variations. What are they?
According to one interpretation, they are: 몬There are roads which must not be followed, armies which must be not attacked, towns which must be besieged, positions which must not be contested, commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed.몭  According to a different interpretation: 몬When in difficult country, do not encamp. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies. Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem. In a desperate position, you must fight.몭
To conclude, all it means is that you need to understand how to adapt to change.


The philosophy of risk and gain: You need to see risks within gains, and gains within risks

As you rush to make gains, don몭t forget to dodge risks. Human psychology is wired for wishful thinking and trusting in luck. Even when people see a risk hiding inside a potential gain, they believe that there몭s only a low chance of the risk actually happening. So, no need to worry! As for seeing gains within risks, people can see potential gains even when they몭re not really there, and they firmly believe that such gains will definitely pan out.

Extract from the original text:
몮Hence in the wise leader몭s plans, considerations of advantage and of disadvantage will be blended together. If our expectation of advantage be tempered in this way, we may have confidence in accomplishing our tasks. If, on the other hand, in the midst of difficulties we are always ready to seize an advantage, we may extricate ourselves from misfortune.몯

Analysis:
몮Hence in the wise leader몭s plans, considerations of advantage and of disadvantage will be blended together.몯
A wise leader has the ability to take into account gains and risks at the same time, and also has the ability to see when conditions are favourable, and when they몭re not.
There is some similarity here to the modern SWOT analytical framework (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats). 몬Gains몭 are the same as 몬opportunities,몭 and 몬risks몭 are the same as 몬threats.몭 It몭s essential that you pay attention to both sides, and not focus entirely on either one of them.
Cao Cao comments: 몮When amidst advantage, consider the risks; when amidst risk, consider the advantages; when encountering difficulties, exercise authority.몯
When you see a potential gain, pause to think a moment longer about what hidden risks and dangers might be lurking under the surface. When you see a potential risk, think for a moment about whether there몭s a positive side to it, and whether or not it can be turned into a gain. When you find yourself in a difficult or unexpected situation, it몭s important to understand how to adapt.
This comment by Cao Cao is a deep one. What about ourselves? It몭s easy to think about what gains might be hidden inside a risk, but difficult to think about what risks might be hidden inside a potential gain.
As we몭ve said, this is because human psychology is wired for wishful thinking. People are always greedy for gains and reluctant to get close to risks, and we몭re prone to trust in our own luck.
When we몭re greedy for gains, that몭s real greed. When we try to stay away from risks, it몭s more of a psychological response, recoiling from the idea of risk. Instead of actually trying to avoid risk, we trust luck and don몭t bother taking actual steps to prevent risk. When we see a potential gain, we know in our hearts that it involves some risk, but we believe that the danger won몭t actually happen. When we see a potential risk, we firmly believe there몭s something good hiding in the background, and we also believe that this good thing is definitely going to happen!
We can see this from the way that people explain and deconstruct the Chinese word for 몬crisis몭 멪 weiji. Wei means 몬danger,몭 and ji can mean 몬opportunity.몭 So: crisis = danger + opportunity. Therefore, the thinking goes, when there몭s a crisis, we need to turn danger into opportunity.
But this is incorrect. The ji in the Chinese word for 몬crisis몭 actually has a different root meaning 멪 몬trigger.몭 Don몭t pull the trigger. When your bills are due, pay them, and don몭t make a fuss about it.  Just accept that you몭re going to lose some money. This is the most positive way of dealing with the situation. Is there anyone alive who doesn몭t run up against at least some bad things in life? Don몭t always think about how to turn bad things into good things, and don몭t always look for a way to profit from them.
You can only win if you몭re also able to admit defeat. If you refuse to admit defeat 멪 to pay your dues 멪 and just keep plowing onward, not only will the dangers not turn into gains, they몭ll just keeping growing bigger. This is not the message that Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War is trying to teach us. 
Jia Lin comments: 몮Dangers and benefits are mixed together; the wise leader is about to ponder both and deal cautiously with both, and thus derive the benefit.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮The wise leader몭s way of contemplating things is thus: though he be situated in a favourable position, he absolutely considers the risks inherent in this position. Likewise, though he be situated in a dangerous position, he absolutely considers the benefits inherent in this position. This too is what we call 몬adapting to change.몭몯

몮If our expectation of advantage be tempered in this way, we may have confidence in accomplishing our tasks.몯

The words 몬tempered in this way몭 mean that the advantages are considered along with the risks intertwined within. The non-beneficial side of the situation, as well as the potential for danger, are both part of the leader몭s calculations. If you can address both sides of the situation, then we can have confidence in what we need to do, and we can make them into a reality.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Having calculated that the enemy is unable to harm me, and indeed lacks the position to do, I may have confidence in my tasks.몯
If you몭ve taken into account all the areas where the enemy might be able to hurt you, and if you몭ve found that, no matter how you add up the numbers, there몭s no way he can actually hurt you, your plan is workable.
Du Mu comments: 몮몬Confidence몭 refers to 몬reaching forth.몭 Sun Tzu몭s meaning is that if one desires to extract advantage from one몭s foe, it is not sufficient merely to perceive the advantage to be gained from the enemy; one must first add to one몭s calculations the ways in which the enemy may inflict harm. This being done, one can reach forth and execute one몭s tasks.몯
If you want to gain an advantage from someone, you can몭t only have eyes for the advantages. You need to take into consideration the ways in which the enemy might be able to hurt you. This is a step you must take for the things you want to accomplish to actually succeed.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Add that which presents danger to that which presents advantages. By doing this, one may reach forth and achieve one몭s objectives.몯
Zhang Yu also provides a case study. The ancient state of Zheng sent an army to attack the state of Cai. The Zheng army was victorious, and all the people of Zheng were happy, except for Zi Chan, who was deeply worried. 몮There is no greater catastrophe than a small country which is bereft of moral civilization, and yet experiences military triumph,몯 Zi Chan declared. He was proved right: not longer afterward, the state of Chu raised an army and moved to attack Zheng. Chu had always seen the state of Cai as part of its sphere of influence, and so, for Chu, it was a case of: 몬If you pick on my little brother, I몭m going to beat you up!몭

몮If, on the other hand, in the midst of difficulties we are always ready to seize an advantage, we may extricate ourselves from misfortune.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮If I wish to extricate myself from misfortunes caused by my foe, I must not only see the things that my enemy can do to harm me, I must also include in my calculations the advantages that I can extract from him. Having done this, I can then successfully extricate myself from misfortune. For instance, supposing I have been surrounded by enemy forces: If I know only to attempt to break through the encirclement, my men몭s force of will is sure to be feeble, and we shall surely be harried and struck down. But if I rouse the soldiers몭 spirits and vigorously carry the fight to the enemy, then the prospect of victory and the advantages it brings shall enable us to break the encirclement.몯
Jia Lin comments: 몮When in a position of danger, turn your mind to the advantages, and thereby you shall evade the danger. Thus, being confronted with death, one survives, and facing ruin, one persists. This is what is meant by 몬extricating ourselves from misfortune.몭몯
Zhang Yu gives another case study for this line of thinking: The Rebellion of the Eight Princes during the time of the Western Jin dynasty (266-317 CE). There was a general named Zhang Fang who, after taking the capital city, Luoyang, suffered a string of defeats. He was advised by some to flee, but he said: 몮It is entirely normal in armies for shifts to occur between potency and dullness, and the most precious victory comes from defeat.몯 That night, his army sneaked right up under the enemy몭s noses and defeated them in combat.
The second part of what Zhang Fang said gives readers much to chew on: that the most valuable victory comes straight out of failure. In other words, you can fail over and over again, and still end up achieving your goal. This is exactly how it works with scientific inventions and experiments, and with entrepreneurs building new businesses. In the final analysis, all success is a result of failure. If you keep moving with the flow, even as you rack up one failure after another, as long as you constantly review those failures, learn from them and apply what you몭ve learned, you will ultimately succeed.


몬The art of harm몭 teaches us not to let people harm us

This part of The Art of War teaches us how to hurt people. Take a quick look at this passage 멪 that몭s all that몭s necessary. The message is simple enough: Don몭t let anyone hurt you, and even more importantly, don몭t hurt other people.

Extract from the original text:
몮Subdue hostile barons by inflicting damage on them; encumber them with constant engagements; hold out specious allurements, and make them rush to any given point.몯

Analysis:
몮Subdue hostile barons by inflicting damage on them.몯
Come up with a way of making them do things that aren몭t in their own interests, so that they몭re unable to unfurl their strength to its full extent.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Damage him in ways that he would consider pernicious.몯 
Li Quan comments: 몮Damage him politically.몯
Jia Lin comments: 몮Use harmful strategems 멪 each one is different: perhaps one may entice the wise men and ministers in his court, so that he is deprived of advisors; or avail yourself of underhanded men, and through them sabotage his decrees and commands; or employ underhanded tricks to sow discord between the king and his advisors; or send ingenious craftsmen to him, and thus exhaust his people and empty his coffers; or use gifts of debauchery and pleasure to corrupt the social currents of his realm; or give him beautiful women to ensnare his mind. Each of these stratagems, if conducted in total secrecy, is capable of harming people and causing them to submit.몯
All of this is about how to hurt people. As I몭ve said, for us it몭s enough just to take a look and move on.
몮Entice the wise men and ministers in his court, so that he is deprived of advisors.몯 If you can draw capable people away from your enemy, he won몭t have anyone he can depend on. Lift up the unscrupulous men in his court, and his administration will rot from the inside; use trickery to create divisions between the enemy and his advisors.
There are many historical examples of this, including ones we몭ve already examined in previous chapters. In the Battle of Changping, between the states of Qin and Zhao, Qin sent a spy to the Zhao city of Handan to spread rumors that the Zhao commander-in-chief, Lian Po, wasn몭t going to fight, and that he actually was planning to surrender to Qin. There was also another rumor 멪 that the Qin generals weren몭t worried about the idea of facing Lian Po, but were scared stiff of a different Zhao general, Zhao Kuo. The goal of these rumors was to make the Zhao authorities call Lian Po back from the front lines and send out Zhao Kuo instead. Zhao Kuo would march to his death.
몮Send ingenious craftsmen to him, and thus exhaust his people and empty his coffers.몯 The idea here is to make the enemy spend money on big projects, such as building grand summer palaces. Then, he won몭t have any money left to spend on his army.
During Japan몭s Warring States period, after the death of Tiyetomi Hideyoshi, Tokugawa Ieyasu[bd28] used precisely this trick to destroy the rest of the Tiyetomi family. He contrived to cause Hideyoshi몭s wife, Yodo Dono, and his son, Hideyori, to launch a huge project building Buddhist temples, with the aim of making them use up all of their gold and leaving them unable to recruit new soldiers.

몮Encumber them with constant engagements.몯

This is about finding things that will cause the enemy headaches, keep him busy and wear him out.
Cao Cao comments: 몮몬Engagements몭 refers to 몬problems.몭 Cause him to become weary and irritated. When he advances, I retreat; when he retreats, I advance. That is what this is about.몯
Cause headaches for your enemy. For example, if he turns back, you should move out into the field. If he moves out, you should retreat. We have a good historical example of this from earlier in the book: the Spring and Autumn period state of Wu몭s campaign of harassment against the state of Chu. Recall that Wu Zixu split the Wu army into three forces, and then made as if to attack, taking only one of the three forces. The state of Chu mobilized its full army in response, only for the Wu force to suddenly head back home. Once the Chu army had disbanded, the second Wu force would suddenly show up in Chu and start causing problems, causing the Chu authorities to once again mobilize their entire army. And, once again, the Wu army promptly turned around and went home. Then, the third Wu force did the same thing. After several rounds of this, the state of Chu was exhausted and on the brink of a nervous breakdown. It was at this moment that Wu mobilized all three of its armies at once, captured the Chu capital, the city of Ying, and became the first Spring and Autumn period state to capture another state몭s capital city.
During the Warring States period, the state of Han had a plan to exhaust its rival, the state of Qin. It successfully enticed the Qin leaders into spending vast human and material resources on a huge irrigation project. They initiated this by sending a hydro engineer named Zheng Guo to the Qin court, where he pushed the massive, resource-intensive project forward.  This left Qin without the energy to carry on its invasions against other states to the east. Zheng Guo designed a huge irrigation project for Qin, which would divert the Jing River a distance of over 300 li and into the city of Luoyang. But while the project was under construction, the Han king몭s plot was exposed. The Qin king wanted to kill Zheng Guo, but the engineer protested: 몮It몭s true that, at first, the Han King wanted me to work as his agent, but this irrigation project won몭t do anything for Han apart from giving it a few years of grace. Meanwhile, this project is a great achievement of the state of Qin, one that will endure for generations.몯 The Qin king몭s officials could see the sense in Zheng Guo몭s words, so he was allowed to continue overseeing the irrigation project.
Once Zheng Guo몭s irrigation project was completed, it radically changed the agricultural productivity of the entire Guanzhong region. Guanzhong had very little rainfall and poor soil quality, and yet it became one of the richest farming regions in all of China. So, the Han plan to 몬encumber몭 and exhaust the state of Qin actually had the opposite effect: it helped Qin to accomplish an era-defining achievement.

몮Hold out specious allurements, and make them rush to any given point.몯

Use the power of temptation to make the enemy go exactly where you want them.
Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about making him come of his own accord.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Use the prospect of some small advantage to move him; make it inevitable that he will rush where you want him.몯
This part of The Art of War teaches us how to hurt people. As I몭ve suggested, take a quick look 멪  that몭s all that몭s necessary. Don몭t let anyone hurt you, and even more importantly, don몭t hurt other people.


Stay safe but always be mindful of danger; Practice good governance but be mindful of potential chaos; This is the way to keep danger and chaos from becoming reality

Stay safe but always be mindful of danger; Practice good governance but be mindful of potential chaos; This is the way to keep danger and chaos from becoming reality. Solve problems every day, and be ready for things to go wrong at any moment, because things inevitably do go wrong. It would be impossible for nothing to ever go wrong. This is exactly what being a leader is about: solving problems and smoothing things out.

Extract from the original text:
몮The art of war teaches us to rely not on the likelihood of the enemy몭s not coming, but on our own readiness to receive him; not on the chance of his not attacking, but rather on the fact that we have made our position unassailable.몯

Analysis:
Military principles tell us not to pin our hopes on the possibility that the enemy just won몭t turn up. Rather, we몭re supposed to depend on having made ample preparations and being ready to deal with them when they come. Don몭t hold false hope that your enemy won몭t attack you; make sure you have the strength and the solutions that will stop the enemy from defeating you when they do attack.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Never be idle; let this be what you rely upon.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮When safe, do not forget danger. This is about constantly making preparations.몯 Always be on your guard.
In the ancient strategist Wu Qi몭s writings about the art of being a general, he says: 몮Whenever you go out of your house, act as though you had just seen your enemy before you.몯 In other words, keep yourself in a state of heightened alertness.
Then there몭s this line, from the ancient historical text, The Zuo Commentary: 몮He who does not prepare or make predictions is not fit to serve as a general.몯
Wang Xi comments: 몮In general, that which leads to victory in war can be called 몬striking where the enemy is weak and attacking where they are sluggish.몭 The moment you show weakness or a lack of energy, you are immediately placing yourself in grave danger, because this is precisely what your enemy, lined up in neat battle formation, is waiting for. So, if you can consistently keep your battle lines in good order, the enemy will never come.몯
People often say that there몭s no point to making preparations if the enemy doesn몭t come; that it몭s a waste of time. But, in reality, the enemy didn몭t come precisely because you made those preparations. If you hadn몭t done so, the enemy would be breathing down your neck in an instant.
So, when something happens, you need to solve the problem. If nothing몭s happened yet, you need to be prepared for something to happen at any moment. An anxiety-free life is just not possible for leaders 멪 for them, each and every day is a journey through anxiety and highly-strung nerves.
Wang Xi gives us several examples to think about:
몮In ancient days, the people of Jin dug deep moats and erected high walls to defend against the military threat posed by Qin. The people of Jin waited for the Qin armies to come, and the Qin commanders could not remain long in the lands of Jin. The Chu armies lined up in battle formations, so that when the Wu forces arrived to fight, they retreated upon seeing that their foe was well prepared. Cheng Bushi was inflexible and rigid as a general. He instilled exacting order upon the ranks of his army, and he also instilled order while marching and setting camps; his men used their mess bowls as drums; he kept military documents in tight order; and no man violated his rules. When Zhu Ran became a general, he ordered his troops to beat the drums every day at dawn and dusk, even when all seemed at peace in the world. When in camp, everybody stayed equipped and ready to march in formation at all times, which rendered enemies unable to calculate how to prepare. Thus, whenever he moved, he recorded new successes.몯
The parts about the conflicts between Jin and Qin, and Wu and Chu are self-explanatory. The next part, about Cheng Bushi, is especially interesting. Cheng Bushi was a renowned general of the Han dynasty, and a contemporary of another famous general, Li Guang. These two men were both extreme in their own ways, and since they represent opposite ends of the spectrum, they몭re often compared against each other.
But today, while stories of 몬the flying general,몭 Li Guang, are family favorites across China, few know about Cheng Bushi. This is because of the sheer number of stories about Li Guang, and the total lack of stories about Cheng Bushi; it몭s possible that Cheng barely fought any battles at all. But, why is that? It몭s because his enemies were too scared to attack him. He might not be able to score a victory against you, but one thing몭s for certain: he would never be defeated.
Why is it that Cheng Bushi couldn몭t be beaten? It was all down to his extreme strictness and caution. First, 몮He instilled exacting order upon the ranks of his army,몯 meaning that his chain of command was enforced with extremely tight discipline at every level. Next, 몮He instilled order while marching and setting camps.몯 He constructed his camps methodically and with a high level of detail, and when it was time for his army to move, it moved as a single unit. Whenever he몭d made camp, his enemies would never be able to dislodge him, no matter how hard they charged his lines. As for the mess bowls, these were the copper vessels used by soldiers at meal times, and they were also used as drums by sentries during their patrol rounds. There are some lines relating to this from a poem by the Tang poet Du Fu: 몮Thoughts turning to men shouldering spears, who pass years guarding borders; Suddenly, at dusk someone beats their copper bowl, its noise jarring in all directions.몯
When Cheng Bushi was on the march, he sent scouts ahead of the main force, and a rear guard behind, and he stayed so alert that his camps were practically airtight. He was supremely well prepared, never leaving a base uncovered.
몮He kept military documents in tight order.몯 He did paperwork every evening, which kept him busy all through the night, until dawn the next day. This is how he never let the Xiongnu get the better of him. Yet, he never won any impressive victories, and the soldiers who served under him never had a moment몭s rest. Life in his army was extremely tense, and extremely hard work.
On the opposite end of the spectrum, we have General Li Guang. He never had anything even slightly resembling a well-ordered chain of command. Instead, he formed close personal bonds with his junior officers; his army was a band of brothers. He didn몭t keep any particular order or structure when marching, and he was quite happy to set up camp any old place, as long as there was a water source. Troops were allowed to make their own arrangements, and generally do things in whatever way suited them, and Li Guang never used the mess-bowl sentry drum system. So, soldiers loved serving under Li Guang, and dreaded having to go with Cheng Bushi. The Xiongnu felt the same way about the two Chinese generals 멪 they loved fighting against Li Guang, and they knew that picking a fight with Cheng Bushi would only bring them bad luck. That몭s why Cheng Bushi was never defeated. He was so well prepared that even his enemies didn몭t want anything to do with him; the mere thought of him was depressing to them.
With Li Guang, it was always either a massive victory or a massive defeat. He was once taken captive by his enemies, only to pull off a brilliant escape plan involving a fake illness and stealing horses. He was later sentenced to death, bought a pardon and was reduced to the status of a commoner, but was eventually reinstated to the rank of general. In the end, after losing his way on the battlefield and finding himself powerless to achieve his objective, the shame was too much for him to bear, and he killed himself.
The way Li Guang did things was not how armies are supposed to be run. In fact, he didn몭t even manage his forces in any formal sense. This made him incapable of leading large armies, although he had the ability to lead a small band of brothers-at-arms. This is why the Emperor never trusted him with command of the main Imperial army, and instead tasked him with assistant roles, such as small-scale flanking strikes. He won glory on the battlefield with great consistency, and became extremely famous, and yet he was never rewarded with any noble title. This even became a joke, immortalized in the lines of a Tang poem: 몮How easy it is for Feng Lao to grow old, and how hard for Li Guang to win a noble title.몯
So, who should be our role model: Li Guang or Cheng Bushi? The most accurate assessment comes courtesy of Han dynasty general Ma Yuan, known as 몬The general who calms the waves.몭 He said this:  몮It is not possible to imitate Cheng Bushi, because trying to make oneself a careful, self-controlled person may end in the same way that attempting to carve a swan may produce something that looks much more like a duck. It is not possible to imitate Li Guang, because one will lower oneself to the station of a frivolous man 멪 this is what is known as trying to draw a tiger and inadvertently drawing something that looks more like a dog.몯
Sima Guang also commented: 몮If one imitates Bushi, one may not achieve great merit, yet one will not suffer defeat. If one imitates Li Guang, there are few who would not bring the whole empire crashing down as a result.몯 
The last person who Wang Xi uses as an example is General Zhu Ran, who served as a senior general under Sun Quan during the Three Kingdoms period. Zhu Ran may not have been as famous as General Zhou Yu, but he was a man of high position. He ultimately reached the ranks of Left Grand Marshal and Right Military Advisor, which made him one of the highest-ranking decision-makers in the Eastern Wu military. Over his lifetime, he built a glittering military record, and enjoyed what could be called a good death (at least by the standards of the chaotic era in which he lived), at the age of sixty-eight. Even when he wasn몭t at war, he still beat the drums and drilled his troops every day at dawn and dusk, and he was in the habit of wearing full armor at all times whenever he was in camp, so he몭d be ready to move out at a moment몭s notice. His enemies never knew what he was planning, so every move he made brought positive results.
Stay safe but always be mindful of danger; Practice good governance but be mindful of potential chaos; This is the way to keep danger and chaos from becoming reality. Solve problems every day, and be ready for things to go wrong at any moment, because things inevitably do go wrong; It would be impossible for nothing to ever go wrong. This is exactly what being a leader is about: solving problems and smoothing things out.


The five most dangerous character flaws for leaders

Leadership ability is, to a large extent, a personality type. But, this works both ways 멪 the worst leadership failures generally happen because of some kind of character flaw. As we몭ll cover below, there are five character flaws that are especially dangerous.

Extract from the original text:
몮There are five dangerous faults which may affect a general: (1) Recklessness, which leads to destruction; (2) Cowardice, which leads to capture; (3) A hasty temper, which can be provoked by insults; (4) A delicacy of honor, which is sensitive to shame; (5) Over-solicitude for his men, which exposes him to worry and trouble. These are the five besetting sins of a general, ruinous to the conduct of war. When an army is overthrown and its leader slain, the cause will surely be found among these five dangerous faults. Let them be a subject of meditation.몯

Analysis:
There are five character flaws that, for those in leadership positions, are especially dangerous:
1) Having no fear of death. If you blindly put yourself in situations where you have to fight to the death, you몭re going to die at the hands of your enemies.
2) Loving life too much, and being overly fearful of death. If you don몭t accept the fact of death, you몭ll end up an enemy prisoner-of-war.
3) Being prone to extreme anger. If you can몭t handle being provoked, your enemies will use plots to make you angry, so that you come out to fight when you shouldn몭t, and die in the process.
4) Being too precious, and too fond of your reputation. If you can몭t tolerate being bad-mouthed, you몭ll ignore serious risks if you think you몭re doing something to uphold your reputation and clean your name of the filth that your enemies have smeared it with. Because of this, you몭ll fall for your enemy몭s몭 tricks.
5) Being too protective of the common people. This is something your enemies will exploit, either by making you overwork yourself for the sake of protecting people, or by using ordinary people as human shields, so that you can몭t bring yourself to attack.
For someone whose job it is to lead an army, all five of these character flaws are catastrophic. It is important to be alert to them 멪 any time an army is destroyed or a general is killed, it몭s virtually always because of one of these five factors! 


A person몭s character is also their fate

Extract from the original text:
몮There are five dangerous faults which may affect a general: (1) Recklessness, which leads to destruction; (2) Cowardice, which leads to capture; (3) A hasty temper, which can be provoked by insults; (4) A delicacy of honor, which is sensitive to shame; (5) Over-solicitude for the people, which exposes him to worry and trouble. These are the five besetting sins of a general, ruinous to the conduct of war. When an army is overthrown and its leader slain, the cause will surely be found among these five dangerous faults. Let them be a subject of meditation.몯

Analysis:
몮(1) Recklessness, which leads to destruction멞몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮Men possessed of courage but who lack contemplativeness are inevitably prone to desire fighting unto death; they cannot be made to bend or yield, but one traps them in ambushes.몯
If you ever come up against an enemy who몭s hell-bent on fighting a death match with you, don몭t face him head-on. Lure him toward you, set an ambush, and eat him for breakfast.
In The Methods of Sima, there is a line that reads: 몮He who launches himself toward death cannot be victorious.몯 In other words, a general is never going to win if he substitutes a willingness to lead the charge and duel with death for strategic thinking.
Lord Huang Shi, the immortal who according to legend presented the Han dynasty몭s General Zhang Lang with a copy of Jiang Ziya몭s Art of War, once said: 몮Brave men love to exercise their will, and foolish men care not if they die.몯 Brave men like to do things their own way, and are typically unwilling to abandon their plans just because there might be some danger involved. If a man is both brave and foolish, he won몭t care about dying, which makes him blind to any danger that might threaten his life.
Wu Qi once said that when ordinary people discuss what makes a general, they all agree that bravery comes before all else. But, in reality, bravery should only constitute a small part of a general몭s personality make-up. This is because brave men can go to battle without giving it too much thought. Anyone who sends their troops into battle without first having a clear idea of what they need to do to advance their own interests doesn몭t have what it takes to be a general.
When Sun Tzu writes about 몬The Way of the General,몭 he lists the necessary personal qualities in the following order: wisdom, sincerity, benevolence, courage and strictness. But in the writings of the Prussian military theorist, Carl von Clausewitz, he emphasizes courage above everything else. Meanwhile, Wu Qi bluntly said that bravery shouldn몭t represent more than one small part of a general몭s personality make-up.


몮(2) Cowardice, which leads to capture멞몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮One can see a potential gain, yet fails to advance because one is scared.몯
In the same passage of The Methods of Sima that contains the words, 몮He who launches himself toward death cannot be victorious,몯 there is also the line: 몮He who clings to life is filled with many doubts.몯 If you몭re scared of death, you몭re paranoid, you exaggerate dangers and you fear losing what you have. Lacking the will to fight is a disaster for any military commander.
During the time of the Eastern Jin dynasty (317-420 CE), General Huan Xuan usurped the Jin throne and declared himself Emperor. Another Jin general, Liu Yu, raised an army to put down Huan Xuan몭s uprising. Moving up the Yangzi River toward Huan Xuan몭s position, the two sides met at Zhengrong Island, in the middle of the river, and fought a battle there. Liu Yu only had a few thousand troops, while Huan Xuan commanded a much larger force of infantry and cavalry. And yet, Huan Xuan was scared 멪 scared of losing, and scared of dying. He kept a small rowboat tied to his warship so that he몭d be ready to make his escape at any moment. His troops weren몭t blind; they could see he was frightened, and this completely deflated their willingness to fight. When the battle started, the wind was blowing in Liu Yu몭s favor, and he used it to set fire to the enemy fleet. Attacking fast and hard, he crushed Huan Xuan.
Meng Shi comments: 몮Cowardice in a general inevitably gives rise to a desire to return home, and to an unwillingness to personally take part in fighting. This renders soldiers dull of spirit, and causes hesitation at all levels of the army. When your army is in such a state, the enemy can attack swiftly and subdue your forces.몯
There몭s a lot of depth in these words. First, if you몭re cowardly, you몭ll be preoccupied with thoughts of going home, and in the back of your mind you몭ll always be thinking about how you absolutely must make it back alive. There몭s no way you can fight a battle in this state of mind, because there몭s no such thing as a battle where you몭re guaranteed to come out alive. If you want to be certain that you몭ll survive, the only things you can do are run away or surrender.
Nor can you just let your subordinates go to their deaths on the front lines without being prepared to do the same yourself. This is because, as the leader, it was your idea to go to war in the first place. Everyone else in your army is just following your lead; they몭re there to lend you a hand, to help you solve your problems. You can몭t send other people to do something for you if you몭re not prepared to do it yourself, because that means you몭re not needed.
The same principle applies in the modern world: whatever project you몭re working on, you mustn몭t go absent from the front line. If you do, you become disconnected from the situation on the ground, which effects your ability to apply yourself mentally to the project. Once you no longer have your nose to the ground, your ability to lead suffers and grows weaker. In terms of the dynamics of your organization, if you몭re not there by your soldiers몭 side, if you몭re not personally leading them, 몮this renders soldiers dull of spirit, and causes hesitation at all levels of the army.몯 When that happens, 몮the enemy can attack swiftly and subdue your forces.몯


몮(3) A hasty temper, which can be provoked by insults멞몯
Du Mu comments: 몮A 몬hasty temper몭 refers to one who is unyielding and prone to anger; it refers to one who is often hurried, and whose character is not steadfast.몯
Wang Xi comments: 몮In generals, the most precious characteristic is consistency and an even keel; with a hasty temper, one is susceptible to provocation.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮Men who are of hasty temper can be provoked and angered, and in this way, they may be defeated.몯
To be a general, it is important to be naturally calm, steady and stable. If you몭re hotheaded, with a short temper, and blinkered in the way you think, these are character flaws that your enemies will exploit. They몭ll poke you, press your buttons and insult you until you bite down hard on their baited hook.
During the Uprising of the Five Barbarians, which took place during the Sixteen Kingdoms (304-439 CE) period, Yao Xiang of the Qiang ethnic group attacked Huangluo. Fu Sheng of the Former Qin dynasty sent Fu Huangmei and Deng Qiang to deal with the invasion. Meanwhile, Yao Xiang had already built a solid defensive position, where he몭d holed up and was refusing to come out and fight. Deng Qiang said to Huangmei: 몮Yao Xiang is a hard man by nature, and fierce. It will be easy to make him angry. If we make a lot of noise and fanfare, and press straight towards his ramparts, I am sure that he will not tolerate our noise. He몭ll be compelled to come out and show that he몭s stronger than us, and then, after just one battle, he몭ll be our prisoner.몯 Huangmei went along with this plan, and sure enough, Yao Xiang couldn몭t take the provocation. He came storming out to fight in a fury, and ended up getting executed by Huangmei.
Another example would be the case of Li Shimin, who before he became the first Emperor of the Tang dynasty (Emperor Taizong) beheaded the Sui dynasty general Song Laosheng. Song Laosheng headed a force of 20,000 elite troops defending the city of Huoyicheng, and Li Yuan prepared to attack Song몭s position. Li Shimin told Li Yuan that Song Laosheng was brave, but simple-minded 멪 he could definitely be lured out to fight. So, Li Yuan set up an ambush outside the city walls, while Li Jiancheng and Li Shimin led a few dozen cavalry troops to the foot of the city walls, where they began hurling insults at Song Laosheng. As expected, Song Laosheng couldn몭t stand the verbal abuse, and came charging out of the gates at the head of his army. He ran straight into Li Yuan몭s ambush, by which point Li Shimin had already taken control of the city gates, leaving Song with nowhere to run. He was cut down on the battlefield.

몮(4) A delicacy of honor which is sensitive to shame멞몯
Here, 몬a delicacy of honor몭 doesn몭t mean the kind of honor that몭s the opposite of corruption. Instead, it몭s the kind of honor that makes people believe in their own purity and perfection. This is about people who have an extreme love for their own image and reputation, and who can몭t tolerate the slightest stain on their good name. This is the kind of person who, if you destroy his reputation, will jump in the Yellow River and still not feel clean. This means two things: 1) He몭ll fight you to the death; 2) He몭s willing to die to prove his purity. He몭ll walk right into your trap, do exactly what you want him to, and he몭ll do this even if he knows perfectly well that you몭re tricking him.
It몭s a massive character flaw to not be able to deal with being bad-mouthed. At the same time, if you몭re always fishing for compliments and praise, and if you몭re motivated by shaping a glowing reputation for yourself, you have a serious problem. That몭s because the more your reputation sparkles and shines, the more you trigger a compulsive reflex in the people around you to throw dirt on your name. Let몭s face it: it hurts the eyes to look at someone so impossibly pure and spotless. That몭s why, in ancient China, there was the concept of 몬a gentleman belittles himself.몭 This essentially meant that by carefully applying some dirt to your image, you take the shine off and make it less painful for others to look at you. It몭s self-effacement as a self-defense mechanism.

몮(5) Over-solicitude for the people, which exposes him to worry and trouble멞몯
The same principle works here as in kidnapping. In movies, when a hero몭s girlfriend is captured, no danger, no matter how deadly, can stop him from coming to her rescue. If a general has great love for the people, the people can be used against him, as hostages. There몭s a well-known story that relates to this, in the classic novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms. Before the Battle of Red Cliffs, Cao Cao was on the attack against Liu Bei. Liu Bei retreated, but he could only move very slowly because he몭d taken civilians with him, and his focus and attention were drawn to protecting them. So, Cao Cao caught up with him.
However, this trick doesn몭t work on certain people. For example, during the Rebellion of the Seven States (154 BCE), when the rebel army attacked the kingdom of Liang, Liang was placed under enormous strain. The situation was perilous. The King of Liang begged for imperial reinforcements, but Imperial Commander Zhou Yafu completely ignored him, and left him to struggle alone on the brink of the abyss. In fact, Zhou Yafu wanted to wear down the rebel army몭s morale and let them use up their grain rations, and in the end he swept in to the save the day, just when it appeared all was lost. Things had gone exactly according to his plan 멪 the kingdom of Liang survived, the rebel army ran out of grain and retreated, and Zhou Yafu struck just as the enemy had become sluggish and had begun thinking of going home. In one fell swoop, the rebellion was over. But the King of Liang was left with nothing but a deep hatred for Zhou Yafu. In the end, the Commander got all the credit for putting down the rebellion, but it was he who had weathered the ravages of war!
Zhou Yafu didn몭t look out for the King of Liang, but Liu Bang was even more heartless 멪 he didn몭t even take care of his own family. His father, wife and children were all left out in the cold. Xiang Yu captured Liu Bang몭s wife, Lu Hi, as well as his father, who was stripped naked and trussed up on a giant wooden chopping board. Next to the chopping board, Xiang Yu installed a huge cooking pot, and told Liu Bang that if he refused to come out and fight, his father would be boiled alive and his wife would be slaughtered. Liu Bang, standing on his city walls, shouted his reply to Xiang Yu at full volume: 몮You and I are sworn brothers 멪 we made our oaths with King Huai as a witness 멪 so my father is your father. If you intend to make our father into soup, then save a bowl for me. As for my wife 멪 kill her if you wish, it makes no difference to me.몯 Xiang Yu, confronted with such appalling shamelessness, turned purple with fury. And yet, he never did harm Liu Bang몭s family members.
Another time, after being soundly defeated by Xiang Yu, Liu Bang was in a chariot fleeing the scene. Xiahou Ying was at the reigns, and also in the chariot were Liu Bang몭s young son and daughter, the future Emperor Hui and Princess Lu Yuan. With enemy troops closing in from behind, Liu Bang decided that the chariot was moving too slowly because it was overloaded with too many people. So, using his feet, he shunted his son and daughter off the vehicle, planning to continue his getaway as the lone passenger. But, Xiahou Ying immediately stopped the chariot, scooped up the children, and carried on. This happened three more times. Each time that Xiahou Ying plucked the terrified children from the ground, they clung tight to his neck. And Xiahou Ying took his time 멪 he didn몭t lash the horses back up to high speed, but soothed the children until they몭d calmed down a little, before finally speeding the horses on their way. Liu Bang was so furious that he wanted to kill Xiahou Ying there and then, but if he did that, there would be no one to drive the chariot. In the end, everyone on board made it to safety.
People like Liu Bang 멪 who feel no compulsion either to cling to life or veer towards death, never rush things, don몭t have a sparkling reputation to keep shiny, and don몭t love the common people 멪 may well be the most contemptible kind of people to walk the earth. Yet, because of this, they are also unstoppable as war leaders.


Appendix: Complete text of Variation in Tactics

Sun Tzu said: 몮In war, the general receives his commands from the sovereign, collects his army and concentrates his forces. When in difficult country, do not encamp. In country where high roads intersect, join hands with your allies. Do not linger in dangerously isolated positions. In hemmed-in situations, you must resort to stratagem. In a desperate position, you must fight. There are roads which must not be followed, armies which must be not attacked, towns which must not be besieged, positions which must not be contested, commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed. The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops. The general who does not understand these may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account. There are commands of the sovereign which must not be obeyed. The general who thoroughly understands the advantages that accompany variation of tactics knows how to handle his troops. The general who does not understand these may be well acquainted with the configuration of the country, yet he will not be able to turn his knowledge to practical account. So, the student of war who is unversed in the art of war of varying his plans, even though he be acquainted with the Five Advantages, will fail to make the best use of his men. Hence in the wise leader몭s plans, considerations of advantage and of disadvantage will be blended together. If our expectation of advantage be tempered in this way, we may have confidence in accomplishing our tasks. If, on the other hand, in the midst of difficulties we are always ready to seize an advantage, we may extricate ourselves from misfortune. Subdue hostile barons by inflicting damage on them; Encumber them with constant engagements; hold out specious allurements, and make them rush to any given point. The art of war teaches us to rely not on the likelihood of the enemy몭s not coming, but on our own readiness to receive him; not on the chance of his not attacking, but rather on the fact that we have made our position unassailable. There are five dangerous faults which may affect a general: (1) Recklessness, which leads to destruction; (2) Cowardice, which leads to capture; (3) A hasty temper, which can be provoked by insults; (4) A delicacy of honor which is sensitive to shame; (5) Over-solicitude for the people, which exposes him to worry and trouble. These are the five besetting sins of a general, ruinous to the conduct of war. When an army is overthrown and its leader slain, the cause will surely be found among these five dangerous faults. Let them be a subject of meditation.몯


					Chapter Nine
The Army on the March

Trusting to luck is the worst possible mindset for a decision-maker

Understanding the art of war doesn몭t necessarily mean that you know how to use it, because when the time comes, your state of mind might be different.

Extract from the original text:
몮We come now to the question of encamping the army, and observing signs of the enemy. Pass quickly over mountains, and keep in the neighborhood of valleys. Camp in high places, facing the sun. Do not climb heights in order to fight. So much for mountain warfare. After crossing a river, you should get far away from it. When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross. Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun. Do not move upstream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare.몯

Analysis:
Commenting on The Army on the March, Wang Xi writes: 몮Armies on the move should occupy favourable terrain, and observe the enemy몭s situation.몯 Here, 몬armies on the move몭 includes the various stages of marching, camping and strategically arranging battle lines. Generals on the march should do two things: make good use of favourable terrain, and pay close attention to the enemy몭s situation. So, The Army on the March is about what to take note of in different types of terrain, and the secrets to accurately judging the enemy situation.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Choose that which brings advantage, and then march.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Understand the variations in the nine types of terrain; then, you can select for advantages and march. Hence, this chapter proceeds from Variations in Tactics.몯

몮We come now to the question of encamping the army, and observing signs of the enemy.몯


The meaning of 몬encamping the army몭 is self-explanatory. 몬Observing signs of the enemy몭 is about watching for clues and signs from the enemy, and using these to shed light on certain questions.
Wang Xi comments: 몮Regarding encamping the enemy, there are four points to consider; regarding observing signs of the enemy, there are thirty-one points to consider.몯 Wang Xi is talking about different methods for camping in four different types of terrain, and how to assess thirty-one different kinds of signals gleaned from observing the enemy.

몮Pass quickly over mountains, and keep in the neighborhood of valleys. Camp in high places, facing the sun. Do not climb heights in order to fight. So much for mountain warfare.몯

Here we have the most important things to know about the first terrain type: mountains.
What is there in mountain valleys that몭s useful for an army? Cao Cao comments: 몮It is advantageous to be close to water and grass.몯 In mountain valleys, you can find water sources and grass for feeding livestock. Armies have horses, and horses need grass to eat. Then there are the animals brought along by the army cooks 멪 pigs and sheep.
Li Quan comments: 몮Whenever an army makes camp, it is essential to immediately assign soldiers to guard duty, set livestock out to graze, collect firewood and gather wild vegetables. Then, all will be calm in the camp.몯
During the Later Han dynasty (25-220 CE), there was an uprising of ethnic Qiang people in the Wudu Commandery. General Ma Yuan was sent to deal with the rebels. When he arrived, the Qiang warriors were high up in the mountains, so he occupied a valley, setting up a strong defensive that gave him exclusive access to the area몭s water and grass. And then, he refused to come out to fight. The Qiang warriors were in a dire situation 멪 their water supply was cut off and their food stores dwindling 멪 and so, they surrendered.

몮Camp in high places, facing the sun.몯

몬Facing the sun몭 also means 몬facing south몭 in this context.
So, to 몬Pass quickly over mountains, and keep in the neighborhood of valleys몭 means that, although you should stay close to the valleys, you mustn몭t camp in valley bottoms. Instead, camp somewhere high up, facing the sun. In high places, your field of vision opens up, which makes it easier to defend your camp. If you camp in a valley, it몭s easy for the enemy to surround you, and to attack you from above.
The reason we몭re told to specifically select campsites facing the sun is because they몭re drier, warmer and more comfortable. And, in these places, it몭s not so easy for disease to spread. In shady, damp locations, it몭s easy for soldiers to catch colds, and due to the lack of medicine in ancient times, a rampant flu might lead to a large number of deaths. Napoleon once said that no war, no matter how brutal, has as negative an effect on an army몭s morale as an unhygienic camp. It몭s a much grimmer scenario to lose soldiers to an epidemic, away from the battlefield, than it is to lose them in combat. That몭s because in a battle, at least the enemy is losing soldiers at the same time you are. But disease can decimate your army while completely ignoring the enemy.
We just talked about how Ma Yuan몭s occupation of favourable terrain caused serious problems for the Qiang rebels, which ultimately led to their downfall. But earlier in the book, we also learned about the final battle of Ma Yuan몭s career. He was leading a campaign in Hunan to put down a rebellion of the Miao people, and his risky decision to lead his army forward via a river led to him being stranded in a deep valley, hemmed in by high mountains and dense vegetation. His camp on the riverbank was damp and far removed from the sun. Pinned down by enemy attacks from high above, and facing a disease outbreak, his own life came to an end when he fell prey to the contagion. Was Ma Yuan aware of the dangers when he made that fateful decision? Of course he was 멪 crystal clear. But he was also old, and he knew that this campaign would be his last chance to earn a glorious place in the history books. He didn몭t care about danger or whether he몭d come out alive; he intended to take his chances. This is a different kind of mentality, and it represents the first of the 몬five dangerous faults which may effect a general몭 from the previous chapter. Namely, 몮Recklessness, which leads to destruction.몯 There몭s no doubt that he would have been able to recite this line from memory. The reason he disobeyed it was that he몭d given himself over to the worst of all mindsets that a decision-maker can have: trusting to luck. 
Trusting to luck is a mentality that effects all of us, and often. That몭s why it몭s important to check our state of mind before making decisions. Ask yourself, 몬By making this decision, is there any part of me that몭s taking a chance?몭

몮Do not climb heights in order to fight.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮If I occupy a lower position, then I may not move uphill to attack, and neither may I face an enemy attack if they come from above.몯
You몭ll always come off second best if you try to attack uphill. Don몭t even try it.

몮So much for mountain warfare.몯

The lines above contain all the information needed to properly handle moving armies, camping and fighting in mountainous terrain.

The art of war in marine combat is the same as fighting on land

Extract from the original text:
몮After crossing a river, you should get far away from it. When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river that he has to cross. Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun. Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare.몯

Analysis:
몮When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river that he has to cross.몯
When an enemy army crosses a river on its way to attack you, before anything else, you need to choose a place far away from the river to set up your battle lines. Don몭t hover near the river, and don몭t stand in the river waiting for the enemy to come. Instead, wait until only half of their forces have crossed, and then strike.
So, Sun Tzu몭s methods for fighting marine battles are the same as his methods for fighting on dry land. The only difference is that if you fight all your battle on the water, you몭re leading a navy, and not an army.
The reason you shouldn몭t deploy in battle formation directly on a riverbank is that although this enables you to stop the enemy from crossing the river, if they don몭t actually cross, you won몭t have a chance to beat them.
So, abandon your position on the riverbank and draw the enemy across the river. Once they몭ve begun crossing, don몭t wait in the middle of the river for them to attack 멪 wait until half of their forces have crossed, and then strike. This way, the enemy army will only be able to commit half of its troops to the fight, and you also benefit from the fact that they몭re on low ground (the river bank), while you can charge down from higher ground.
This is all quite different from how we normally imagine launching and defending against amphibious attacks. For example, if during the Normandy landing on D-Day, the German army hadn몭t tried to hold a defensive position on the coast, but had instead waited for the Allied forces to be 몬halfway landed몭 멪 and then launched an offensive 멪 that day in history would have taken an unimaginably different course. That몭s why there몭s a pre-condition for this approach to fighting: it only applies 몬If you are anxious to fight.몭 This is only for generals whose goal is annihilate their enemy in battle, and not for generals whose main objective is to defend.


Duke Xiang of Song몭s attempt to model himself after Duke Huan was absurd, not 몬Benevolent몭

Extract from the original text:
몮When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross. Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun. Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare.몯

Analysis:
In Du Mu몭s commentary on these lines, he writes about a historical episode from the Three Kingdoms period (220-280 CE).
While General Guo Huai of the kingdom of Wei held a position in the city of Hanzhong, Liu Bei and his army were on the other side of the Han River, planning to cross and attack Guo Huai. Guo Huai몭s junior officers all considered Liu Bei a formidable warrior, and on top of that, he also had superior numbers. Therefore, they advised Guo Huai to set up battle lines along the riverbank, stopping Liu Bei from crossing. But Guo Huai disagreed: 몮You are all wrong. By clinging to the riverbank we would be showing weakness, and Liu Bei would know immediately that we were scared to fight him. Knowing this, he would be emboldened to cross the river regardless. It is better to deploy our forces at a distance from the river, thus enticing him to cross. Then, while only half of his forces have crossed, we will strike.몯 And so, Guo Huai deployed his forces far from the river. On the far bank, Liu Bei saw what was happening, and knew exactly what trick Guo Huai was planning. He knew better than to try to cross, and instead he withdrew his army.
After the death of Duke Huan of Qi in 643 BCE, during the Spring and Autumn period, the lands of China no longer had a single, undisputed ruler. Duke Xiang of Song had ambitions to take up the late Duke Huan몭s mantle, but he lacked the power to do so. So, he tried to fashion himself as a new Duke Huan, trumpeting his 몬benevolence몭 in the hope that this would be enough to convince all the people of China to bend the knee to him. In the attempt, Duke Xiang left us with a big, historical joke 멪 the battle of the River Hong.
With his ambition to become undisputed ruler of the known world, Duke Xiang decided to start with the easiest target: he went on the warpath against the feeble kingdom of Zheng. Zheng requested help from the kingdom of Chu, which immediately sent out an army to attack the kingdom of Song. Duke Xiang, seeing that he had a serious situation on his hands, called his armies back and dug in at a defensive position by the River Hong, where the Chu and Song armies eventually clashed.
The Chu forces had yet to cross the river, but meanwhile, on the far side, the Song army was already deployed in battle formation. The Song Minister of War, Gong Sungu, tried to give Duke Xiang some advice: 몮The enemy몭s men are many, while we are few; we should strike when they are in the midst of crossing.몯 But Duke Xiang didn몭t agree. Claiming that he was a 몬benevolent몭 commander, he said: 몮I shall not impel the enemy to a perilous position, and I shall not force them into distress.몯
So, the Chu army crossed the river safely and began to deploy in battle formation. Again, Gong Sungu pled with Duke Xiang to take advantage of the enemy몭s temporary disorderliness and attack, but Duke Xiang wouldn몭t allow it. 몮They are not yet beating their drums, and they have not yet formed up in their ranks,몯 he said. Only after the Chu soldiers had finished lining up did he finally give the order to attack. His whole army was annihilated, and he himself sustained a fatal injury. And that was the end of Duke Xiang of Song몭s dreams of ruling the entire world.
People often laugh at what they call 몬Duke Xiang몭s pig-headed benevolence.몭 At the same time, they lament the loss of the 몬traditional chivalry of war몭 that came after the time of the first three of China몭s dynasties, the Xia, Shang and Zhou. 몬Benevolence is dead and buried,몭 people sigh, 몬and skullduggery stands in its place.몭
But, in reality, Duke Xiang wasn몭t the slightest bit 몬benevolent.몭 He was just a classic nobleman, full of dreams of restoring his ancestors몭 glory. The rulers of Song were descended from the former royal house of Shang, confined to the land of Song after the new Zhou dynasty destroyed the final Shang ruler.
