When Duke Huan of Qi died, Duke Xiang thought it should be his turn to rule the world. But he had lived his whole life deep inside palace chambers, in the hands of women. He몭d never left the palace, and he had no idea what the world was like, let alone the intricacies of politics and war. He knew that he didn몭t have military power, but the way he saw it, 몬benevolence몭 was what enabled Duke Huan of Qi to rule the world. And so, he felt, all he had to do was possess 몬benevolence몭 and the world would raise him up and name him Undisputed Sovereign.
Nobody else was buying it, especially not the leaders of Chu, who kidnapped Duke Xiang during a meeting he몭d called in the hope of launching a new alliance. It was only after the rulers of Lu spoke on his behalf that Chu let him go home. He몭d been humiliated by Chu, yet he was too scared to take his revenge. And so, instead, he tried to vent his anger on Chu몭s 몬little brother,몭 the state of Zheng. Chu then attacked him, and the whole absurd farce that was the Battle of the River Hong unfolded.
There was nothing at all 몬benevolent몭 about Duke Xiang of Song. Even describing him as an idiot would be over-selling him 멪 he was nothing less than absurd.


The problem with studying The Art of War is that the enemy understands it, too; The problem with studying game theory is that the enemy doesn몭t understand it

The art of war is about winning. But, if the enemy also understands the art of war, that makes it difficult to win. In game theory, everyone can win. This means that if you calculate the optimum outcome for both sides, but your enemy doesn몭t understand how it works, they몭ll end up dragging you down with them and you몭ll both suffer damage.

Extract from the original text:
몮After crossing a river, you should get far away from it. When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross. Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun. Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare.몯

Analysis:
When Liu Bei saw that Guo Huai had lined up his army far away from the river, he didn몭t dare try to cross. A similar scenario played out in the early years of the Tang dynasty (618-907 CE), but there was an opposite outcome.
Generals Xue Wanjun and Luo Yi were defending Youyan when Dou Jiande attacked the area of Fanyang, at the head of an army of several hundred thousand men. Xue Wanjun said to Luo Yi: 몮We are outnumbered 멪 if we go out to fight, even if we fought a hundred different battles, we would be defeated each time. Our only option is to subdue the enemy by trickery. We should send a detachment of our weakest soldiers to the river in front of the city to block Dou몭s passage. Thus, Dou will be enticed into crossing the river. Meanwhile, you will lay in ambush on the enemy몭s flank with several hundred elite warriors, and once half of the enemy forces have crossed, that is when you will strike.몯
Luo Yi went along with the plan, and sure enough, Dou Jiande crossed. Luo Yi attacked precisely when half of the enemy troops had crossed, and inflicted a massive defeat. 
Zhang Yu comments: 몮If rebel soldiers move their forces across a waterway in order to join battle on the far side, you must not meet them at the water몭s edge. Wait until half of the enemy forces have crossed, and then move while their ranks are not yet settled and their head and tail detached; if you strike then, you are sure to be victorious.몯


몮If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross.몯

If you몭re looking to engage the enemy in combat, don몭t deploy your forces at the water몭s edge and think they몭ll come to you; they won몭t. 
Zhang Yu comments: 몮If I wish to be certain that battle will be joined, then I must not await the enemy near to the water, for fear that he will not cross. Conversely, if I do not wish to fight, then I must obstruct his passage across the water, so that it is impossible for him to cross.몯
However, given that both sides understand this principle, it몭s actually used in reverse, as in the historical examples above. Guo Huai didn몭t want a fight with Liu Bei, and he knew exactly what to do: according to the art of war, if you don몭t want to fight, you should deploy at the river몭s edge so as to block the enemy from crossing. But Guo Huai knew that Liu Bei was familiar with this tactic, meaning that if he followed the art of war and lined up by the river, Liu Bei would recognize this as a sign that Guo Huai was weak, reluctant to fight, and would then do the exact opposite of what Guo Huai wanted, crossing the river and attacking. Then, there would be no guarantee that Guo Huai몭s limited battle capabilities would be able to hold off the enemy. But, if Guo Huai chose to form up at a distance from the river, then according to the art of war, Liu Bei should take this as a sign that Guo Huai had a powerful enough army to feel confident, that he wanted to fight, and that if Liu Bei tried to cross, Guo Huai would attack before all his forces reached the far side. So, Liu Bei decided he couldn몭t take the risk of attacking.
In the end, Guo Huai몭s gamble paid off 멪 he forced an error of judgment from Liu Bei.
Zhang Yu also wrote about another interesting episode from Chinese military history, from the Spring and Autumn period. During a war between the states of Jin and Chu, the forces of Jin commander Yang Chufu and Chu commander Zi Shang came head-to-head at the River Zhi. Yang Chufu wanted to make the Chu army cross the river, so he could attack while only half their army had crossed. He pulled his army back some way from the river and set up camp. Meanwhile, Zi Shang had the same idea: wanting to lure the Jin army across the river, he also pulled his army back and set up camp away from the river. Both generals were thinking in exactly the same way, so neither was fooled by the other몭s plan. Both sides kept retreating, further and further away, until it became clear that nothing was going to happen. At that point, both sides packed up and headed home.
This is why the problem with studying the art of war is that the enemy understands it, too. By contrast, with game theory, problems happen when the enemy doesn몭t understand it. The art of war is about winning, but if the enemy also understands the art of war, that makes it difficult to win. In game theory, everyone can win. This means that if your enemy doesn몭t understand game theory,  even if you calculate the optimum outcome for both sides, if your enemy doesn몭t understand how it works, they몭ll end up dragging you down with them, and you몭ll both take damage.
It몭s a common saying in Chinese that 몬Circumstances are more powerful than mortal men.몭 So, if you몭re faced with circumstances where both you and your enemy are taking damage, why not team up instead? And yet, your opponent likely has a different assessment of the circumstances than you do. If he thinks he can win, all you can do is walk with him down the road of defeat.

몮Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun.몯

Earlier, we talked about how, in mountainous terrain, it몭s important to 몬camp in high places, facing the sun,몭 and the same principle applies when you몭re near bodies of water. 
Cao Cao comments: 몮On water also, one should position oneself up high; face the water, and keep your backs to the high terrain.몯
We몭ve already talked about why you should choose a position facing the sun 멪 these places are drier, more hygienic and less prone to outbreaks of disease.
There are three good reasons to position yourself in high places. First, you have a broader field of vision, which helps you monitor the enemy몭s situation. Second, the enemy won몭t be able to flood you out, and you몭ll be safe from flash floods if there몭s an overnight rainstorm. Third, if the enemy tries a surprise attack, starting from a higher position will tilt the balance of power and energy in your favor.

몮Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮For fear of being flooded.몯 Here, Cao Cao is referring to being flooded out of one몭s camp by the enemy. The same meaning applies as in 몬moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun.몭
Jia Lin comments: 몮In areas with flowing water, the enemy may flood my army, or he may release poisonous substances in the water.몯 Poison is another potential danger.
Zhuge Liang once said: 몮In waterborne combat, one must not try to move counter to the current.몯 Whichever side is moving with the current holds an advantage 멪 a big advantage. If you try to move upstream to attack an enemy, you몭re fighting against the current as well as against your enemies, leaving you with very poor odds of victory. This is why the cities of Xiangyang and Anqing were key strategic locations throughout history; any general who takes Xiangyang or Anqing would have free movement downriver, making it effectively impossible to stop them from taking Nanjing.

몮So much for river warfare.몯

This concludes the section about applying the art of war to marine warfare.
The art of using military force in salt marshes and on open plains

Extract from the original text:
몮In crossing salt marshes and swamps, your sole concern should be to get over them quickly, without any delay. If forced to fight in a salt marsh or a swamp, you should have water and grass near you, and get your back to a clump of trees. So much for operations in salt marshes. In dry, level country, take up an easily accessible position with rising ground to your right and on your rear, so that the danger may be in front, and safety lie behind. So much for campaigning in flat country. These are the four useful branches of military knowledge that enabled the Yellow Emperor to vanquish four sovereigns. All armies prefer high ground to low, and sunny places to dark. If you are careful of your men, and camp on hard ground, the army will be free from disease of every kind, and this will spell victory. When you come to a hill or a bank, occupy the sunny side, with the slope on your right rear. Thus you will at once act for the benefit of your soldiers and utilize the natural advantages of the ground.몯

Analysis:
Chen Hao comments: 몮Salt marshes are areas of alkaline land, where both water and grass are of coarse quality, and they are so imbued with damp that they are not suitable places to position an army. In The Xin Xun, it is written that 몬in areas of salt marshes and swamps, the five grains cannot grow.몭 This is true.몯
Wang Xi comments: 몮Salt marshes are alkaline places, characterized by open, sunken land, and by a lack of secure places.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮On account of damp and humid vapor possessed by the earth in such places, and of the sparse and coarse water and grasses, one should make haste to pass through.몯
In these comments, we have four major threats posed by salt marshes:
1) 몬The five grains몭 cannot grow, meaning there is no food and no opportunity to re-supply.
2) Water and local grass species are sparse and of poor quality, meaning these are challenging places in which to encamp.
3) The terrain is open and low, meaning there are no easily defendable places, and making it difficult to build defensive structures.
4) The air is damp and humid, making it easy for disease to spread.
Hence, 몬Your sole concern should be to get over them quickly, without any delay.몭 In these lines, we can find the source of the difficulties faced by the Communist Red Army while crossing grassy areas during the Long March.


몮If forced to fight in a salt marsh or a swamp, you should have water and grass near you, and get your back to a clump of trees.몯

If you몭re going to be in a damp, marshy area, it몭s essential that you find somewhere with a fresh water source. Without access to fresh drinking water, an army won몭t last long in a salt marsh.
There are two benefits to positioning yourself up against trees: 1) Nobody will be able to come at you from behind, so at least it will be impossible for an enemy force to surround you on all four sides; 2) In marshland, it몭s impossible to know how shallow or deep the bog in front of you might be. With each step you take, you face the possibility that you몭ll sink irretrievably into a deep swamp, like hapless Red Army soldiers in war movies, swallowed whole as they walk across the marshlands. The same thing can happen in deserts 멪 in certain spots there are deep pits of loose sand that are impossible to climb out of once you fall in. All you can do is wait as you slowly sink deeper, and are eventually buried by the sand. If you fall in, you몭re not the only person in danger; anyone who tries to pull you out risks being sucked in with you. Wherever there are trees, you know the ground is relatively solid, so you don몭t have to face this danger.
Li Quan mentions this danger in his commentary: 몮If it is impossible to cross quickly, and if one must fight, it is essential to find a position with water, and with trees with which to shield one몭s back. In any place with water and trees, there is no danger of becoming trapped and drowning.몯 If it몭s not possible to quickly cross a marsh 멪 for example, because it몭s too big to cross in a single day 멪 it몭s necessary to find a place with water and trees to camp and prepare for the eventuality of engaging in battle.

몮So much for operations in salt marshes.몯

This concludes the part about strategies for leading armies in salt marshes.

몮In dry, level country, take up an easily accessible position.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮Flat land 멪 one must choose a place that is flat, level and provides easy access, and position one몭s army there. Thus, one몭s chariots and cavalry are able to move at speed.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮It is beneficial for chariots and cavalry.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Level, open wildernesses are places for chariots and cavalry; one must choose a position that is level, easily accessible, and devoid of pits and holes, and station one몭s army there. This is beneficial to moving at high speed.몯
In ancient times, the Chinese didn몭t rely only on the Great Wall to stop the northern nomadic people from launching raids to the south. They also planted massive numbers of trees on the open plains, because the armies of the northern Xiongnu were built around cavalry, while Chinese armies mainly used infantry forces. The idea behind planting trees was to slow down the speed at which the Xiongnu could travel; otherwise, the pounding hooves of the northern cavalry would have been able to carry invading armies deep into China.

몮멞 with rising ground to your right and on your rear, so that the danger may be in front, and safety lie behind.몯

While you should choose a flat place with easy access, that doesn몭t mean your base should be surrounded by flat ground on all sides. If all around you there몭s nothing but flat land, you would be exposed to the enemy on all sides. In the ideal scenario, you would have high land to your right and to your rear, and flat land to your left. This gives you a protective barrier to shield your back, and flat terrain in front so that you can take the fight to the enemy. The meaning of 몬danger in front, and safety behind몭 is that the battlefield, the place of death, should be out in front, and behind you there should be mountains 멪 a place without danger, a place of life. This puts you in a good position to fight.
So, whichever side reaches the battlefield first, and claims the best terrain, gets a major boost to their odds of victory.
Cao Cao comments: 몮This is beneficial for fighting.몯 In other words, setting yourself up like this makes things more convenient.
But why should the high land be on the right, and not on the left?
Li Quan comments: 몮In all things which a man might make use of, it is most convenient to use the right; hence, one should face away from the right.몯 An estimated 90% of people worldwide are right-handed; they do everything with their right hand. For example, when holding a long gun, most use their left hand to hold the front and their right hand to hold the back. Hence, the right side is, for the vast majority of people, the side of convenience.
Jia Lin comments: 몮Hillocks and mounds are here called 몬life,몭 and battlefields are here called 몬death.몭 With hillocks or mounds to your rear, your army occupies a stable position; with the battlefield positioned in front, one is conveniently positioned to deploy one몭s army; with high land to the right, it is expedient to turn around.몯
For example, if you shout an order, 몬Turn to the right,몭 everyone will turn in the clockwise direction, but some might mistakenly turn to the left. If that happens, everyone will laugh and make fun of them.
Jiang Ziya once said: 몮One몭s army must be positioned with rivers or swamps to the left, and hills to the right.몯 This is the best of all possible worlds 멪 you have everything you need, and the enemy only has one approach route, which makes the task of defending your position much easier.


몮So much for campaigning in flat country.몯

This concludes the section on leading armies in flat terrain.

몮These are the four useful branches of military knowledge which enabled the Yellow Emperor to vanquish the four sovereigns.몯

We몭ve now reached the conclusion of this part on terrain, where Sun Tzu wraps up the sections on how to use military force in mountainous, watery, swampy and flat terrain.
Zhuge Liang once said: 몮When fighting in mountainous country, do not climb to fight the enemy at a higher elevation; when fighting upon water, do not move counter to the current; when fighting in marshland, do not wade into the depths; when fighting in flat country, do not leave yourself exposed at the rear.몯
These are the four principles the Yellow Emperor used to defeat the four feudal lords of China.
Who were these 몬sovereigns? In the records of the most ancient reaches of Chinese history, there is mention of 몬the Three Emperors and the Five Sovereigns,몭 but there몭s nothing written about 몬the four sovereigns.몭 Cao Cao comments: 몮When the Yellow Emperor first established himself, the sovereigns of the four regions all claimed the title of sovereign.몯 So, 몬sovereign몭 was just a generic word used for feudal lords at the time.
Where did Sun Tzu learn the art of war? Did it just fall from the sky? Did he come up with it entirely by himself? In fact, it was none of the above. He worked in the same way as Confucius, who said: 몮I expound, rather than create.몯 Sun Tzu just offered explanations of what he몭d learned from the ancient thinkers who came before him; he didn몭t create anything new.
Every version of The Art of War that exists traces its origins to the Yellow Emperor. The Yellow Emperor몭s treatise was written about his top general, Feng Hou. We몭ve already discussed the principle of 몬Using the regular to engage the enemy, and the irregular to defeat him.몭 This idea originally came from Writings on Grasping the Irregular, part of Feng Hou몭s writings on the art of war. It then passed from the Yellow Emperor down to Jiang Ziya, and from Jiang Ziya to Sun Tzu, who finally compiled the entirety of China몭s military wisdom in his book, The Art of War. This book has, from ancient times until today, always kept its place at the cutting edge of each historical era몭s military strategy and thinking.
The famous British strategist, BH Liddell Hart, once commented: 몮There are only two books of military strategy in this world, which surpass all the strategies contained in all other books of military lore. Those two books are Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War and Clausewitz몭s On War, and the latter is outdated when compared with Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War.몯
On War came into the world more than 2,000 years after Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, yet here Liddell Hart claims that On War is outdated, while The Art of War represents the forefront of military thinking. If you want to know the true value of Sun Tzu몭s masterwork, look no further.

몮All armies prefer high ground to low and yang (sunny) places to yin (dark). If you take care of your men, and place yourself in a position of strength, the army will be free from disease of every kind, and this will spell victory. When you come to a hill or a bank, occupy the yang side, with the slope on your right rear. Thus you will at once act for the benefit of your soldiers and utilize the natural advantages of the ground.몯

And with that, let몭s do one last summary.
Whenever it comes time to find a campsite for your army, always choose high, dry terrain, and stay well clear of damp, low-lying ground. Orient yourself towards yang, and don몭t back yourself up against yin.
몬Taking care of your men몭 means staying close to fresh water and grass. This makes it easy to graze the army몭s war horses, cattle and sheep, to find food for the pigs, to fetch water and firewood, and to maintain open supply lines.
몬Placing yourself in a position of strength몭 means occupying the high ground, with mountains covering your back 멪  this is a strong position. If you back up against empty space, leaving your rear unprotected, your position is weak.
If you 몬take care of your men and place yourself in a position of strength몭 you are safeguarding your army몭s vital necessities. You have the security of a natural barrier protecting your rear, so you don몭t have to worry about being attacked from behind, and you keep one side open so that you can press the enemy.  If you camp high up, facing the sun, taking care of your men and putting yourself in a strong position, disease won몭t spread easily through your army. This is the only way to keep your army몭s battle capabilities sharp; this is how to guarantee victory.

몮When you come to a hill or a bank, occupy the sunny side, with the slope on your right rear.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮Whenever encountering hills or banks, one should occupy the southeastern side.몯
So, selecting a military campsite is more or less the same as buying a house 멪 if you want to be safe and comfortable, you have to carefully choose a place with the right orientation.
Wang Xi comments: 몮Positioned in yang, people are able to live in comfort and harmony; this is beneficial to nurturing health and talent[bd29][TT30].몯


Sun Tzu teaches a life-saving lesson to backpackers from The Art of War

Extract from the original text:
몮When, in consequence of heavy rains up-country, a river which you wish to ford is swollen and flecked with foam, you must wait until it subsides.몯

Analysis:
If you몭re trying to cross a river and you see that the water is brown with mud and has bubbles on the surface, this means there몭s been a lot of rain upriver, and it몭s possible that the water level is about to surge upwards. If you see these signs and still try to cross, it몭s possible that the river will swell while you몭re still crossing. If that happens, you might drown. Don몭t cross; wait for a while. When the river surface shows signs of calming down and the flow stabilizes, then you can cross.
I regularly see news reports about water released from an upstream reservoir, resulting in death by drowning at points downstream. The only effect of these reports is to rouse public fury, but nobody comes out with a technical solution for the problem. Why isn몭t it possible to release signals into the river before releasing reservoir water? For example, you could start by releasing only a small amount of water, and at the same time put red floating balls into the stream to warn people downstream. These balls could be released in batches, every ten minutes, and after an hour the full water release would officially commence. Wouldn몭t this give people downstream time to prepare? Otherwise, if you just continue the old policy of sending out notifications in downstream villages, there will always be people who don몭t get the news in time. Then, when the deluge comes barreling down the river, lives are lost.
For those of us who enjoy outdoor pursuits, this part of The Art of War is very useful. It몭s not unheard of for hikers to camp next to rivers, only for flash floods to come down from the mountains and drown them in the night. This kind of tragic event has happened at the foot of Ali Mountain in Taiwan 멪 tourists were fishing on a riverbank when a flash flood came down from upstream, causing the water level to surge. Search and rescue personnel made it to the scene, as well as television broadcasting trucks, but they were unable to save the stranded tourists, who ended up drowning on live television.
Make sure you remember this line from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: if you see river water turning muddy and starting to bubble, that means it몭s raining upstream, and the water level is liable to shoot up suddenly. At least there몭s one difference between flood surges caused by rain and those caused by reservoirs dumping water into rivers 멪 with natural floods, there몭s generally time to escape.


Six dangerous types of terrain

Extract from the original text:
몮Country in which there are precipitous cliffs with torrents running between, deep natural hollows, confined places, tangled thickets, quagmires and crevasses should be left with all possible speed and not approached. While we keep away from such places, we should get the enemy to approach them; while we face them, we should let the enemy have them on his rear.몯

Analysis:
These are the six dangerous types of terrain, which we should never get too close to.
Mei Yaochen comments about 몬precipitous cliffs with torrents running between몭 that are 몬dangerously steep all around, with water rushing about.몭
Cao Cao comments: 몮몬Precipitous cliffs with torrents running between몭 refers to places of deep mountains and large waterways.몯
Basically, it몭s about places with deep ravines with large waterways flowing through, which are impassable.
About 몬deep natural hollows,몭 Mei Yaochen says that these are 몮dangerously steep on four sides; places to which ravines and canyons lead.몯
Cao Cao identifies these places as having 몮high walls in all directions, with a hollow below in the center.몯
Du Mu quotes from another ancient text, the Jun Shi: 몮Terrain characterized by cavities, where large waterways flow; such places are called 몬heavenly wells.몭몯
These places are deep holes with water at the bottom. Basically, they몭re massive, natural wells.
About 몬confined places,몭 Mei Yaochen states that they are 몮blocked on three sides; easy to enter, but difficult to exit.몯몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮Places which are passed through in deep mountain terrain; for those who are not diligent, they become 몬natural prisons.몭몯
Du Mu comments: 몮Oppressively narrow mountain ravines, which can stop people몭s forward progress; such places are called 몬natural prisons.몭몯
Here, we have different explanations from three commentators. In Eleven Commentaries on Sun Tzu몭s Art of War, Mei Yaochen몭s explanation is considered the correct one. In a 몬confined place,몭 the way forward is blocked off on three sides, and although it몭s possible to enter on one side, once you몭re inside it몭s impossible to get back out.
About 몬tangled thickets,몭 Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Places where grasses and trees grow dense, such that neither spear nor arrow may be deployed.몯
This is about places where the vegetation is so thick and movement so difficult that there몭s no space to wave a sword or a spear, or even to fire an arrow. It몭s just like in golf, when you몭re in a stand of trees and you don몭t have space to swing your club.
About 몬quagmires,몭 Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Muddy, low-lying terrain, impassable for chariots, carts and cavalry.몯
These places are 몬natural traps.몭
About 몬crevasses,몭 Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Two mountains facing one another, forming a cave-like passage; narrow and loathsome.몯
This is the same geographical feature that is found in so many scenic sites in China, beloved by tourists and known in modern Chinese as 몬a crack of sky.몭 But although these places make for fun tourist destinations, they몭re much less fun for armies on the march in wartime. It몭s bad luck to have to take an army through such places.

몮멞 (such places) should be left with all possible speed and not approached.몯

If you encounter any of these six types of terrain, it몭s important to leave as quickly as possible. Better yet, don몭t even get close in the first place.

몮While we keep away from such places, we should get the enemy to approach them; while we face them, we should let the enemy have them on his rear.몯

As we stay far away from these places, we can draw our enemies to them. If we engage our enemy near these types of terrain, the arrangement most favourable for us is for our army to be facing the dangerous terrain, while the enemy fights with their back to it.
Cao Cao comments: 몮In war, we always stay far away from the six dangers, while causing the enemy to draw close to them and to face away from them; thus, I benefit and the enemy is in danger.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮This passage tells us that, when encountering these six dangerous types of terrain, I should stay far away while facing the dangerous terrain, allowing me the freedom to advance and to halt as I will; the enemy should be made to draw near to the dangerous terrain and to face away from it, thus creating a barrier to his movements. Thus, this is beneficial to me and dangerous to my enemy.몯
So, in war, the key is to seize control of the best terrain. And, if you encounter any of the six dangerous types of terrain, keep your distance while still facing it, wait for the enemy to arrive, and then force him into the dangerous terrain.


Thirty-two methods for monitoring the enemy몭s condition (part one)

Extract from the original text:
몮If an army on the march should encounter any steep and obstructed terrain, ponds surrounded by aquatic grass, hollow basins filled with reeds, or woods with thick undergrowth, they must be carefully routed out and searched; for these are places where men in ambush or insidious spies are likely to be lurking. When the enemy is close at hand and remains quiet, he is relying on the natural strength of his position. When he keeps aloof and tries to provoke a battle, he is anxious for the other side to advance. If his place of encampment is easy of access, he holds an advantage. Movement amongst the trees of a forest shows that the enemy is advancing. The appearance of a number of screens in the midst of thick grass means that the enemy wants to make us suspicious. The rising of birds in their flight is the sign of an ambuscade. Startled beasts indicate that the enemy is surging forth. When there is dust rising in a high column, it is the sign of chariots advancing; when the dust is low, but spread over a wide area, it betokens the approach of infantry. When it branches out in different directions, it shows that parties have been sent to collect firewood. A few clouds of dust moving to and fro signify that the army is encamping.몯

Analysis:
몮If an army on the march should encounter any steep and obstructed terrain, ponds surrounded by aquatic grass, hollow basins filled with reeds, or woods with thick undergrowth, they must be carefully routed out and searched; for these are places where men in ambush or insidious spies are likely to be lurking.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮What is meant by 몬steep몭 is terrain with abrupt transitions between high and low land; what is meant by 몬obstructed몭 is terrain with large amounts of water; thick undergrowth can be used as a natural screen.몯
Next, we몭ll go through the various ways you can observe the enemy. The Art of War discusses a total of 32 such observational techniques:

1) 몮When the enemy is close at hand and remains quiet, he is relying on the natural strength of his position.몯

This is when the enemy is in close proximity to your army, but shows no signs of moving. They have control of the best terrain, terrain that is dangerous for you to approach. So, they feel secure, without fear. Here, 몬quiet몭 is used in the sense of 몬motionless.몭 It doesn몭t necessarily mean that the enemy isn몭t making any noise. In a historical example from a previous chapter 멪 the one about General Ma Yuan몭s expedition in Hunan against the rebellious Miao people 멪 Ma Yuan became stranded on a riverbank. The Miao fighters stood on the high cliffs above the river ravine and subjected Ma Yuan to a deafening racket, because they knew there was no way he could climb up to where they were. He was completely helpless.


2. 몮When he keeps aloof and tries to provoke a battle, he is anxious for the other side to advance.몯

This is when the enemy stays far away from your army and sends a small force to lure you into a fight. Their aim is to tempt you into moving forward, towards them.

This is the exact opposite of the previous line. Rather than staying put, secure in the knowledge that their position is strong, here the enemy forces move over a great distance to pick a fight with you, as an attempt to provoke you into moving towards their main force.
In the Wei Liaozi, there몭s a passage that reads: 몮When the enemy has the distribution of dangerous terrain, do not commit your heart to battle. When the enemy challenges you to fight, do not commit your full energy to fighting.몯 If the enemy takes control of dangerous terrain before you do, don몭t try to make a fight happen. If the enemy is deployed far away from you, and sends soldiers to pick a fight, don몭t hit him with your full force. Leave some units in reserve, and watch how the battle unfolds.

3. 몮If his place of encampment is easy of access, he holds an advantage.몯

If the enemy has taken up a position in open country, he definitely has a terrain advantage, and he몭ll want to lure you towards him and finish you.

Zhang Yu comments: 몮When the enemy spurns dangerous terrain and positions himself in easy terrain, it is certain that he has derived some advantage.몯 This means the enemy isn몭t even slightly scared of you; he몭s just waiting for you to come to him so he can put you to the sword. In this situation, you need to play it cautiously. The principle here is roughly the same as the passage, 몬refrain from intercepting an enemy whose banners are in perfect order; refrain from attacking an army drawn up in calm and confident array,몭 which appears in Chapter Seven, Armed Struggle.

4. 몮Movement amongst the trees of a forest shows that the enemy is advancing.몯

If you see tree branches moving, that means the enemy is on their way towards you.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮It is vital, in an army, to send a man skilled in observation to climb high points and monitor the enemy. If he sees movement among trees, this means the enemy is cutting down trees to clear a path; he is coming. It is also possible that they are not just clearing a path, but also preparing to craft weapons.몯

When a large army is on the move, it needs to cut down trees as it goes to clear its path forward, and it몭s also possible that they are using the wood of these trees to make weapons and build structures for their camp. To sum up, if you see trees swaying about, this is a sign that the enemy is coming.

5. 몮The appearance of a number of screens in the midst of thick grass means that the enemy wants to make us suspicious.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮If the enemy makes bundles of grass to use as screens, he wishes to sow doubt in my mind.몯

If the enemy is setting up barriers in dense areas of grass, what he몭s doing is setting up a diversion. In fact, he might already have fled the area.

Du Mu comments: 몮This passage tells us: either the enemy has not yet completed construction of defensive fortifications at his camp, or he has removed his army from the areas and has secretly departed, and, fearing that we may pursue him, he has deployed bundles of grass about the place as if there were people concealed behind, in order that we would feel misgivings and not dare to approach.몯

6. 몮The rising of birds in their flight is the sign of an ambuscade.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Where you see birds rising upwards, there are troops hiding in ambush below.몯

Zhang Yu몭s commentary gives a more vivid image: 몮When you see birds flying horizontal to the ground, and then, having arrived at an enemy position, suddenly fly upwards, this shows there are enemy soldiers lying in ambush below.몯

7. 몮Startled beasts indicate that the enemy is surging forth.몯

Chen Hao comments: 몮What is meant by 몬surging forth몭 is that the enemy is hidden in the woods, and will drive forth to attack you.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮The enemy battle lines are vast and widely spread, and they are surging forth to attack.몯

몬Surging forth몭 has two meanings. First, it means the enemy is hiding in the woods and is about to launch a surprise attack. Second, it means that 몬the enemy battle lines are vast and widely spread몭 멪 they have a lot of troops, and they will attack over a wide area. So, when you see wild animals running from the woods because they have nowhere left to hide among the trees, then you have a serious problem on your hands!

8.  몮When there is dust rising in a high column, it is the sign of chariots advancing멞몯

When you see dust rising high in the sky in a narrow column, that means enemy chariots are on their way.

Zhang Yu comments: 몮Chariots and horses moving at high speed and in large numbers, when they move in formation and follow precisely in the tracks of those before them, then dust rises high and straight.몯

9. 몮When the dust is low, but spread over a wide area, it betokens the approach of infantry.몯

War chariots move in tight lines, each line following precisely the one in front, which is why the dust they produce forms narrow columns. Infantry soldiers, however, move in relatively broad lines, so they kick up wider dust clouds. Also, dust from infantry units doesn몭t rise as high in the sky as dust produced by chariots.

In ancient Chinese warfare, there were people who had the specific duty of observing dust clouds created by enemy armies. At one point during the Three Kingdoms period, Cao Cao was chasing Liu Bei, so Liu Bei몭s ally Zhang Fei sent a cavalry unit out to trick Cao Cao. Each of the unit몭s horses had a tree branch tied to its tail, which they dragged back and forth in an effort to send a huge amount of dust up into the sky. The question is, would Cao Cao have been able to tell that the dust was fake?

10. 몮When it branches out in different directions, it shows that parties have been sent to collect firewood.몯

When dust is spread out and forms long, narrow columns, this means the enemy soldiers are cutting firewood.

Why does the dust do this? First of all, the reason it몭s spread out is that soldiers on firewood-cutting duty fan out in all directions. Then, when they몭re finished chopping, they drag the wood along the ground back to camp, which is why the dust forms long columns.

Li Quan comments: 몮When the commanders of Jin set out to invade Qi, they ordered men to drag firewood behind their army. From the mountaintops, the men of Qi saw this and were terrified that this signified vast Jin armies. They fled at night.몯


11.  몮A few clouds of dust moving to and fro signify that the army is encamping.몯

Zhang Yu comments: 몮Whenever encamping, it is vital to dispatch light cavalry to travel out in the four directions and inspect the nearby terrain. This is in order to know where the terrain is dangerous or easy, and where it is open or narrow. Hence, there is a small quantity of dust, and it moves here and there.몯


Thirty-two methods for monitoring the enemy몭s condition (part two)

Extract from the original text:
몮Humble words and increased preparations are signs that the enemy is about to advance. Violent language and driving forward as if to attack are signs that he will retreat. When the light chariots come out first and take up a position on the wings, it is a sign that the enemy is forming for battle. Peace proposals unaccompanied by a sworn covenant indicate a plot. When there is much running about and the soldiers and chariots fall into rank, it means that the critical moment has come. When some are seen advancing and some retreating, it is a lure. When the soldiers stand leaning on their spears, they are faint from want of food. If those who are sent to draw water begin by drinking themselves, the army is suffering from thirst. If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are in chaos. If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are exhausted. If birds gather on any spot, it is unoccupied. Clamor by night betokens nervousness. If there is disturbance in the camp, the general몭s authority is weak. If the banners and flags are shifted about, sedition is afoot. If the officers are angry, it means that the men are weary.몯

We will now move on to the next 14 ways outlined in The Art of War for observing the enemy, and interpreting what you see:

 12. 몮Humble words and increased preparations are signs that the enemy is about to advance.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮The enemy몭s messengers use humble rhetoric; when I send spies to observe the enemy, I learn the enemy is increasing his preparations.몯

The enemy is attempting to make us apathetic and arrogant; while we let down our guard, he몭s preparing to launch his offensive.

In Du Mu몭s comment on this line, he writes about a historical case study we몭ve already seen in previous chapters: Zhao She몭s war to save the city of Yuyu. Zhao She set out with his army from the city of Handan, but after marching only thirty li, he set up camp and halted his troops몭 advance. When the enemy Qin forces sent a messenger to his camp, the man was treated well and given plenty of good food and drink. The Qin commander, it seems, believed that Zhao She didn몭t have the courage to attack. As soon as the Qin messenger left the Zhao camp, Zhao She moved out, marching double time until his forces reached the Qin army. He took the enemy unawares and unprepared, and utterly trounced them in battle.

Zhang Yu also writes about a historical case study, in which General Tian Dan defended the city of Jimo while being besieged by General Qi Jie of the state of Yan. As Tian Dan enlisted soldiers for his forces, he even enlisted his wives and concubines, and he personally joined the rank-and-file soldiers in readiness to fight for their city. Once he몭d finished his preparations, he sent a woman up onto the city walls to offer surrender to the enemy outside. Qi Jie received the news with delight.

Tian Dan took 1,000 yi of gold from the people of the city and ordered Jimo몭s richest citizens to take the gold and present it to Qi Jie, and to deliver a message for him: 몮The city is surrendering. I hope that your soldiers will not plunder the city or harm my wives and concubines.몯 Hearing this, the Yan troops relaxed even more.

The next moment, Tian Dan was charging out of the gates with his army. He hit the Yan army hard, routing them in one fell swoop.

Tricks and scams 멪 the truth is that there are really only a handful of variations, and they몭re all well documented in books. Yet, people still fall for them. All you can do is shake your head and sigh: 몬There are too many idiots in this world. Frankly, there aren몭t enough scammers to go around!몭

So, why do people fall for these scams? There몭s a proverb from the west: 몮There are some things that people believe for the sole reason that they want so badly for it to be true.몯

When someone creates an illusion, if that illusion symbolizes a hope or desire you have,  you몭ll believe in it totally. You몭ll go all in, and you몭ll delightedly tell yourself: 몬It몭s happening just the way I thought it would. I몭m not surprised!몭

In the case of the Qin general, he was thinking: 몮Zhao She몭s just a boy; he몭d never dare cross swords with the great Qin army! I always knew there was never any chance he몭d come, and lo and behold, he몭s not coming!몯

And, in the case of the Yan general, Qi Jie, he was thinking: 몮How could Tian Dan ever be a match for me? And I was right 멪 he몭s no match for me! At least you can say this about him: he knows the score. Look, the local magnates are coming out to give me protection money.몯

13. 몮Violent language and driving forward as if to attack are signs that he will retreat.몯

This is the opposite of 몬humble words몭 signaling an imminent attack. If the enemy몭s messengers deliver fiery, aggressive speeches and give the impression that their forces are on the attack, this actually means they몭re about to run away. The belligerent messengers are just sheep in wolves몭 clothing.

Du Mu writes about a historical example of this principle: King Fuchai of Wu몭s northern expedition to tussle for supremacy with Duke Ding of Jin. The two armies몭 paths collided at Huangchi, but before the fighting had even started, King Goujian of Yue invaded Wu, taking advantage of the Wu army몭s absence. Fuchai was spooked. He wanted to withdraw his armies and hurry back home to protect his kingdom, but he felt held back by two concerns. First, considering that his army was lined up opposite the Jin army, he was worried that retreating without a fight would cripple his troops몭 morale. Second, he was worried the Jin forces would chase after him. He called a meeting with his advisors, and asked: 몮Which course of action offers greater advantage 멪 withdrawing without a fight, or fighting in a bid to secure supremacy?몯

Advisor Wang Sunluo said: 몮We must challenge the enemy to fight today, so as to invigorate the men몭s hearts. Only then can we withdraw.몯

So, the King of Wu took 30,000 armored troops and advanced to within one li of the Jin army, lined up in battle formation, and started up a deafening noise. Duke Ding of Jin sent his advisor Dong He to ask King Fuchai, 몮What is the meaning of this?몯 Fuchai granted the messenger a personal audience, and answered his question with hard words: 몮The time has come. If you want to orphan your children or if you want to save yourself trouble, either way, today is the day!몯

Dong He went back to Duke Ding, and told him: 몮When I was observing the King of Wu몭s complexion, it appeared that something of great magnitude is gnawing at his mind. If we engage in battle today, he will hold nothing back in the fight. We cannot fight him.몯 So, Duke Ding of Jin backed off, and agreed to make peace. 

Now Fuchai was on the front foot. He몭d secured a peace agreement and he몭d kept his dignity. He immediately moved his forces back to the home front.

14. 몮When the light chariots come out first and take up a position on the wings, it is a sign that the enemy is forming for battle.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Forming up battle lines means that the enemy desires battle.몯

The first to come out are the light chariots. This means the enemy is about to form up battle lines and engage. The chariots are sent out to either flank to act as boundary markers for the army. Once they몭re in place, battle flags are planted in specific locations, and each unit assembles behind their flag. This is what happens when the enemy is setting up their battle lines and getting ready to fight.

15.  몮Peace proposals unaccompanied by a sworn covenant indicate a plot.몯

If the enemy says he wants peace but doesn몭t make any solid proposals, don몭t be fooled 멪 he has a trick up his sleeve.

We just talked about how Tian Dan 몬sued for peace몭 with Qi Jie. First, he sent a woman up on the city walls to make himself look weak and to ask for peace. Then, the richest residents of the city went out to offer protection money, and they did so as private citizens. At no point did Tian Dan himself offer specific surrender terms. This proves beyond doubt that he was up to something. If he really wanted to surrender, wouldn몭t he have put some effort into negotiating a price for peace?

The same thing happened when Ji Xin fooled Xiang Yu.

It happened like this: Liu Bang had been surrounded by Xiang Yu몭s forces at Xingyang, and his anxiety was at the boiling point. But his advisor Ji Xin had a clever plan. Since he looked very similar to Liu Bei, he could disguise himself as his lord and come out of the eastern gate to surrender, while the real Liu Bei could escape through the western gate. Liu Bei agreed to give the plan a try. He sent a document of surrender to Xiang Yu, in which he wrote: 몮The King of Han shall this evening come to offer his surrender.몯 Xiang Yu was delighted.

At midnight, a large number of women poured out from the eastern gate, with multiple groups coming out in bursts. The Chu army came forward to encircle the women, to watch and wait for Liu Bang to come out. By the time the last of the women had emerged, the sky was already growing light. Finally, a figure who appeared to be Ji Xin made his way slowly out of the gates, lying down in an imperial chariot. When the Chu troops saw that Liu Bang had come to surrender, they began to shout: 몮Long Live King Xiang,몯 the assembled troops cried. By the time Xiang Yu realized that this 몬Liu Bang몭 was a fake, the real Liu Bang had already fled through the western gate. He was long gone.

Xiang Yu never stopped to wonder why Liu Bang would send a letter announcing he was going to surrender on the same day, without mentioning a single term or condition? It made no sense! But Xiang Yu was a very arrogant man 멪 the way he saw it, it was right and proper that Liu Bang should surrender to him unconditionally.

There was another famous example of this from the reign of Emperor Dezong of the Tang dynasty: the treaty ambush at Pingliang. A leader of the Tibetan Empire, Shang Gyaltsen, was invading Hequ when his army fell prey to a disease outbreak. Half of his men and horses died, and he became worried that he wouldn몭t be able to make it back home. So, he sent a messenger to the camp of the Tang commander, Ma Sui, humbly and politely requesting a meeting to discuss not only signing a peace treaty, but forming an alliance. Ma Sui granted the request.

The governor of Hezhong Prefecture sent his advisor, Hun Jian, to the imperial court with a message: 몮If our nation몭s armies were pressing on the Tibetan border and we were planning to invade, then perhaps it might be believable that the Tibetans would request an alliance. But, in the current situation, the Tibetans need nothing from our nation, and yet they have made this bizarre request for an alliance. Without doubt, they are plotting something.몯
But Emperor Dezong didn몭t listen.
Hun Jian and Shang Gyaltsen arranged a meeting at Pingliang, and when Hun Jian arrived, he had 3,000 men at his back. Shang Gyaltsen had positioned cavalry troops in ambush formation at a location to the west of the Alliance Hall. When the time came, tens of thousands of Tibetan cavalry troops poured forth and captured the outlying Tang troops. Hun Jian acted quickly; he leapt onto a nearby horse and fled across the Pingliang River. So, except for Hun Jian, who had been in charge of the alliance negotiations, all 60 or more Tang court officials sent to the meeting were captured by the Tibetans, including Vice Commissioner Cui Hanheng and a high-ranking court official, the eunuch Ju Wenzhen. In what went down in history as 몬The treaty ambush at Pingliang,몭 500 or more Tang soldiers were killed, and another 1,000 or more were captured.

In Chen Hao몭s commentary, he writes that when commanders from two states go on the attack, if neither side is showing any weakness, and yet one of them requests a peace treaty for no apparent reason, that means one of two things: (1) The enemy leaders are worried about some internal problem at home and, out of carelessness, have decided on a policy of peace for the time being; (2) They knew that it might be possible to try something, and they몭re trying to make you believe in yourself beyond doubt, and asking for peace now, while planning to launch a surprise attack later.

Zhang Yu comments: 몮If the enemy requests peace for no reason, there is certainly some cunning plot in play.몯 Once Liu Bang had already become Emperor Gaozu of the Han dynasty, he sent Li Yiji with a large cargo of treasures to visit with the Qin general Jia Shu and ask him to agree to peace terms. But they weren몭t even at war yet, so why would Gaozu send gifts and ask for peace? And yet, Jia Shu believed the Han Emperor. Liu Bang then took advantage of his enemy몭s lack of preparedness and alertness, and destroyed the Qin army with a single strike.

16. 몮When there is much running about and the soldiers and chariots fall into rank, it means the enemy is in a state of anticipation.몯

In Du Mu몭s commentary, he writes that this line goes together with the previous one: 몮When the light chariots come out first and take up a position on the wings, it is a sign that the enemy is forming for battle.몯 Once the light chariots have staked out the flanks, then 몮there is much running about and the soldiers fall into rank.몯

In an ancient text called The Rites of Zhou, it몭s written that: 몮As chariots fly forth, foot soldiers follow, halting when they reach their mark.몯 The 몬marks몭 are flags set out by the chariot personnel, signs showing the infantry units where to take up positions as they run hectically after the fast chariots.

As for the meaning of 몬anticipation,몭 it몭s possible to interpret it as being directed at the enemy몭s own foot soldiers.

Zhang Yu comments: 몮Marks are given where flags are planted, and as the general anticipates the people going forth, thus they run toward their marks.몯

17. 몮When he is halfway in advance and halfway in retreat, it is a lure.몯

This means that there몭s a lack of coordination; some soldiers move forward while others fall back, advancing and retreating at different times. The army seems like a chaotic mess, but this is engineered precisely to lure you into advancing. From the enemy몭s standpoint, he worries that if he advances, you몭ll run away, and if he retreats, you won몭t chase him. So, he does both 멪 advancing and retreating at the same time. 

18. 몮When the soldiers stand leaning on their spears, they are faint from want of food.몯

Send spies to watch the enemy. If you can see enemy troops far in the distance hanging onto their spears to keep themselves upright, this proves that they몭re exhausted and famished.  They몭ve run out of food.몯

19. 몮If those who are sent to draw water begin by drinking themselves, the army is suffering from thirst.몯

If you see the men on water-fetching duty glugging it down as quickly as they can, this proves that there몭s no water left in the enemy camp, and that the whole army is suffering badly from thirst.

20. 몮If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are exhausted.몯

If the enemy can see you have a weakness they could exploit, and yet they don몭t do anything about it, this shows that their troops몭 energy and battle capabilities are badly depleted.

21. 몮If birds gather on any spot, it is unoccupied.몯

In Zhang Yu몭s commentary, he writes that in a situation where the enemy army has stealthily retreated and left their tents behind to make it seem like they몭re still there, there몭s one sign you should look out for. If birds realize that nobody몭s at home in the camp, they몭ll congregate in the sky above. So, if you see birds gathering above the enemy camp, you know that it몭s empty.
When the state of Chu invaded Zheng, the Zheng army couldn몭t hold the Chu army back, so they made ready to flee. But then a scout report came in 멪 birds had been sighted in the Chu camp. It turned out that the Chu army had reached breaking point, too, and had already turned tail and run.

When the state of Jin invaded Qi, Shu Xiang said: 몮There are birds over the city walls 멪 the Qi commanders have fled.몯 There were birds perched on the city walls, so it was a sure bet that there was nobody guarding the city; they몭d all run away. During the late years of the Zhou dynasty (1046-256 BCE), King Xian of Qi invaded Northern Qi. The Northern Qi general, Ban Shi, built fake tents using cypress branches, and then he created smoke by starting fires with ox and horse manure. The Qi army watched for two days before they realized the camp was empty. By then, it was too late to catch up with the Northern Qi forces.

22. 몮Clamor by night betokens nervousness.몯

몬Clamor몭 refers to any disturbance in the enemy camp. Any display of panic during the night means that the enemy army몭s mindset is shaky.

Cao Cao comments: 몮If the soldiers cry out at night, this means the general lacks courage.몯 

The general isn몭t brave, so he can몭t stay on top of his troops. The army has no backbone to keep it stable, making the men so jittery that every bush and tree looks like an enemy soldier.

Zhang Yu comments: 몮The general is the mainstay of any military force; if the general lacks bravery and cannot bring peace to the soldiers몭 minds, then they will become terrified and cry out during the night. For example, a Jin army once kept up their clamor throughout an entire night.몯

Chen Hao comments: 몮In ten men, if only one has courage, then though the remaining nine may be cowards, one brave man is enough to bring peace to their hearts. If tonight clamor breaks out among the soldiers, it is because the general has no courage.몯

Panic in a camp doesn몭t stop at shouting and yelling. It몭s hard to see at night, so in the madness it몭s possible that the men of the same army will start attacking and even killing one another, thinking that they몭re fighting the enemy. This is why previous sections of the book, about the rules for setting up a camp 멪 like, how closely spaced each unit should be and where fires should be lit 멪 went into such a high level of detail. If the enemy launches a surprise attack, or if panic breaks out in the camp, each subsection of the camp is to come out and form up in their sub-camp. They몭re not allowed to move, and all the fires are to be lit at once, to light the camp up as brightly as if it was daytime, making it easy to tell who몭s a friend and who몭s a foe. Also, archers and crossbowmen are to be installed at high vantage points, so they can shoot and kill any enemy soldiers who have infiltrated the camp.
While Zhou Yafu was combatting the Rebellion of the Seven States, he also had to deal with panic in his camp. The situation was so bad that his soldiers were attacking one another, and the chaos even threatened to spread to his command tent. As we몭ve discussed, his solution was to stay tucked in bed and keep sleeping. His army calmed down, naturally, on their own.

23. 몮If there is disturbance in the camp, the general몭s authority is weak.몯

The general is unable to bring stability to his army. Du Mu comments: 몮This passage says that when the general orders his army to advance and retreat without proper consideration, and generally behaves in a frivolous manner, then he has no prestige and the soldiers will cause disturbances.몯

During the Three Kingdoms period, General Zhang Liao was in command of an army stationed at Changshe. One night, a disturbance flared up among his men, and the chaos engulfed his whole army. Zhang Liao said he was certain this was the work of an enemy agent, and he ordered everybody to stay where they were and not move. Having ordered his men to sit down and stay still, he stood tall and authoritative in the middle of the army. After a while, silence and calm was restored to the camp.

24. 몮If the banners and flags are shifted about, sedition is afoot.몯

Zhang Yu comments: 몮Banners and flags are the instruments by which an army is brought into order; if they waver and come untethered, this is a sign that there is confusion among the ranks.몯

As discussed earlier, banners and flags are the tools a general uses to give orders. If they are flailing around any which way, that shows that the command system has fallen apart, and confusion has infected the ranks. During the Battle of Changshao (684 BCE), between the states of Qi and Lu, there was a moment when the Qi army seemed defeated and began to flee. Duke Zhuang of Lu wanted to give chase, but Cao Gui shouted: 몮Wait a moment!몯 Cao Gui climbed onto a chariot and gazed into the distance. 몮Now! Now, give chase!몯

몮What do you see?몯 Duke Zhuang asked him.

몮I was looking to see whether their flags are in disorder. No disorder means someone is still charge and it몭s possible they몭re not really beaten, and there might be an ambush. If there몭s disorder, that means they몭re really running away and nobody몭s in command 멪 then we can go after them!몯

The Lu army pursued the fleeing Qi troops and, as expected, they won the day.

25. 몮If the officers are angry, it means that the men are weary.몯

Jia Lin comments: 몮When people are tired, they become angrier.몯 If officers become angry for no apparent reason, this proves that they몭re already exhausted.

Zhang Yu comments: 몮When the generals몭 commands contradict one another, people become exhausted and thus the officers grow increasingly angry.몯 Either the commander doesn몭t have a grip on the situation, and is giving commands that don몭t make sense, or he몭s inconsistent in handing out rewards and punishments. This makes people angry. Then, the officers start taking out their anger on the regular troops, and they fly into a rage for no evident reason. When this happens in an army, the men lose their fighting spirit and even start hoping that their side will lose, as revenge against their commander.

The classic historical example of this principle comes from the battle of the city of Bi, during the war between Jin and Chu, when the two states were vying for supremacy in China. At the beginning of the conflict, neither side wanted to fight; they were on the verge of starting negotiations for a peace treaty. The Jin commander-in-chief, Xun Linfu, had set his heart on building an alliance with Chu, and he wasn몭t putting much energy into preparing for war. Two generals under his command, Wei Qi and Zhao Zhan, had once asked Xun Linfu for promotion to higher ranks, but had been refused. They몭d borne a grudge ever since, and now they wanted to sabotage Xun Linfu몭s career. So, they both in turn approached Xun Linfu and asked him to let them go to the Chu camp and provoke the enemy into fighting. Xun Linfu refused their request. So, they asked instead for permission to go to the Chu camp and propose an alliance. This time, Xun Linfu gave his permission. The two scoundrels made their way to the enemy camp, and instead of trying to build an alliance, they challenged the Chu leaders to fight.

After the two men set out, another Jin general, Xi Ke, said: 몮Those two are angry about the past. If we do not make ready, certain defeat is what awaits us.몯 Nothing good would come of two disgruntled young men going to the enemy. Without proper preparations, the Jin army was bound to lose. But, Xun Linfu didn몭t take the situation seriously.

In the Chu army, there were two opposing factions: one wanted peace, the other wanted war. But when the King of Chu learned about the divisions among the Jin officers, he made up his mind 멪 there was going to be war. The Chu commanders launched a major offensive, and what happened next will come as no surprise: the Jin forces were badly beaten. When the battle was over, the state of Chu was the new superpower in China몭s Central Plain region.


Thirty-two methods for monitoring the enemy몭s condition (part three)

Extract from the original text: 
몮When an army feeds its horses with grain and kills its cattle for food, and when the men do not hang their cooking-pots over the camp-fires, showing that they will not return to their tents, you may know that they are determined to fight to the death. The sight of men whispering earnestly without ceasing, or speaking in subdued tones, points to disaffection amongst the rank and file. Too frequent rewards signify that the enemy is at the end of his resources; too many punishments betray a condition of dire distress. To begin by bluster, but afterwards to take fright at the enemy몭s numbers, shows a supreme lack of intelligence. When envoys are sent with compliments in their mouths, it is a sign that the enemy desires repose. If the enemy몭s troops march up angrily and remain facing ours for a long time without either joining battle or taking themselves off again, the situation is one that demands great vigilance and circumspection.몯

We now come to the final seven ways outlined in The Art of War for observing the enemy, and interpreting what you see:

 26. 몮When an army feeds its horses with grain and kills its cattle for food, and when the men do not hang their cooking-pots over the camp-fires, showing that they will not return to their tents, you may know that they are determined to fight to the death.몯

Grain meant for human consumption is fed to horses, the cart-oxen are cooked and eaten, the cooking pots disappear from the tree branches where they used to hang and are smashed into pieces, abandoned 멪 the enemy isn몭t planning to cook any time soon. They won몭t return to their tents; they몭re abandoning their camp. In other words, they몭re burning all their bridges, cutting off all their means of retreat and getting ready for a life-and-death struggle.

In Chapter Seven of the ancient text, Records of the Grand Historian, which is a record of Xiang Yu, there is the following passage: 몮Xiang Yu then brought all the soldiers of his army across the river; he sunk all his boats, destroyed all his cauldrons and pots, burned his shelters, and set out with rations sufficient only for three days. This was to show that each one of his men was determined to die, and not one of them intended to return.몯

What should you do in this situation? What should you do if the enemy sinks their boats and destroys their cooking pots to show they plan to fight to the death? Zhang Yu comments: 몮If the enemy behaves in this way, you should resolutely hold your position and wait for afflictions to accost him.몯 If you try to fight, you몭ll be dealing with an enemy pumped up with extremely intense energy. But, if you hold your position and don몭t come out to fight, you can make them wait until they run out of food. Let starvation do your work for you 멪 hunger can kill the enemy for you.

27. 몮The sight of men whispering earnestly, without ceasing, or speaking in subdued tones points to disaffection amongst the rank and file.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Here, 몬earnestly몭 refers to the way they speak; the constant movement of their mouths indicates the appearance of men who have lost their force of will.몯

The word used in the original text, xi, has a root meaning of 몬mouths opening and closing몭 멪 the passage conveys an image of men chattering on and on, endlessly.

These 몬whispering men몭 might be officers talking with their subordinates, or it might be rank-and-file soldiers talking amongst themselves. Either way, if your scouts spy soldiers standing around, engrossed in deep conversation, in the enemy camp, this means the enemy general has already lost the hearts and minds of his men. If the enemy general is walking around talking with various people, that shows that his army몭s mindset is unstable, and he몭s working to deal with that situation. If the enemy몭s몭 rank-and-file troops are talking amongst themselves, they몭re likely bad-mouthing their commander.

28. 몮Too-frequent rewards signify that the enemy is at the end of his resources멞몯

Li Quan comments: 몮The enemy is in a state of distress, so he distributes rewards in order to spur his men forward.몯

If a general is handing out rewards to his troops as if his life depended on it, it몭s because he몭s in an extremely precarious situation: his men don몭t want to work for him and they몭ve lost all respect and fear for their commander. Nothing he says can make them do what he wants, so all he can do is take out his family silver and share, it in the hope that he can buy his men몭s courage with extravagant gifts.

29. 몮Too many punishments betray a condition of dire distress.몯

Just like with rewards, dishing out too many punishments will cause problems. Du Mu comments: 몮When the men are tired and the army몭s power is wilting, such that soldiers do not fear punishment, the general issues many punishments so as to instill fear in them.몯

30. 몮To begin by bluster, but afterwards to take fright at the enemy몭s numbers, shows a supreme lack of intelligence.몯
Jia Lin comments: 몮Orders and commands are not clearly distinguishable and the soldiers are not trained or drilled. He launches campaigns of which the premise is his own powerful desire, but when his soldiers defy him he grows fearful; this is the height of cowardice.몯

Jia Lin몭s comment cuts deep; the leadership defect he몭s describing here can be seen in a very significant number of leaders indeed! First of all, he doesn몭t stand up and take responsibility as a leader 멪 he gives confusing, contradictory orders and his troops don몭t get enough training. This creates ineptitude throughout the whole army, from rank-and-file troops to senior officers. So, what does the general do about this situation? Rather than focusing on coming up with a detailed plan, and lacking the ability to direct his troops and lead problem-solving efforts, his attitude turns inflexible and uncompromising, and he makes demands of his subordinates. He probably sounds something like this: 몮All I want from you is results! Get out there, and get it done!몯 When his subordinates fail to do what he wants, he punishes them.

Naturally, his men were not happy with their commander. They know they몭re powerless to satisfy him, but at the same time they몭re unsatisfied with his leadership. They start thinking: 몮Why don몭t you do it yourself and see how it goes? All you몭re doing is sitting there and telling us to lay down our lives for you!몯 The men can see that beneath his hard exterior; he몭s weak and cowardly inside. So, they stop doing what he tells them, and start resisting. As soon as he sees that his men aren몭t listening to him, and he can몭t keep them under control, he gets scared.

According to Jia Lin, this kind of general represents the height of cowardice.

31. 몮When envoys are sent with compliments in their mouths, it is a sign that the enemy desires repose.몯

Jia Lin comments: 몮When their energy is soft and their language apologetic, they desire to seek reconciliation between the two sides.몯

But what about this line from earlier: 몮Humble words and increased preparations are signs that the enemy is about to advance.몯 Isn몭t the basic meaning of 몬humble words몭 the same as 몬compliments in their mouths?몭 So, how can one of them mean that the enemy wants to fight, while the other one means they want peace? The key is that in the earlier line: 몬humble words몭 come together with 몬increased preparations.몭 The enemy is actually cranking up their preparations for war. How do we know the enemy isn몭t secretly making 몬increased preparations몭 when their envoys come with 몬compliments in their mouths?몭

This is why there몭s an alternative interpretation of this line: 몮When hostages are sent with compliments.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮The reason why 몬hostages are sent with compliments몭 is that the enemy is compelled to rest, either because their energy is exhausted or because of some other reason.몯

Zhang Yu comments: 몮If the enemy uses his intimate family members as hostages and sends them to you, this means their energy and strength are severely exhausted, and so they desire a repose from war, and to let their soldiers rest.몯 When the enemy is even sending their loved ones off as hostages, this means they have no other choice 멪 they몭re utterly spent.

32. 몮If the enemy몭s troops march up angrily and remain facing ours for a long time without either joining battle or taking themselves off again, the situation is one that demands great vigilance and circumspection.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Prepare to face an ambush.몯

Zhang Yu comments: 몮When the enemy comes with fury and bluster, and yet neither initiate battle nor withdraw, then you should keep close formation and wait; inevitably, he will have prepared an ambush.몯


 Don몭t rely on the younger generation to fight your wars for you, and don몭t pin your hopes to your allies

Many people keep busy every day going to all kinds of events in the hope of 몬meeting people.몭 But, if you몭re a somewhat capable person and you have your own business to take care of, you don몭t have the time or the motivation to run around trying to 몬meet people.몭 You몭re better off staying at home and looking after your children. Not investing enough of your own time in your children is a common problem, one that afflicts all too many professionals, and it몭s a serious blunder in terms of a person몭s investment strategy.

Extract from the original text:
몮Greater numbers of soldiers do not equate to advantage; do not advance relying solely upon military might. Proper personnel selections are sufficient to concentrate all our available strength and anticipate the enemy몭s movements. He who exercises no forethought but makes light of his opponents is sure to be captured by them. If soldiers are punished before they have grown attached to you, they will not prove submissive; and, unless submissive, then will be practically useless. If, when the soldiers have become attached to you, punishments are not enforced, they will still be useless.몯

Analysis:
몮If our troops are no more in number than the enemy, that is amply sufficient; it only means that no direct attack can be made. What we can do is simply to concentrate all our available strength, anticipate the enemy몭s movements, and obtain reinforcements.몯
What makes an army strong isn몭t filling it with as many troops as possible, but the ability to refrain from charging forward blindly, to bring its power to bear in specific places, and to accurately assess the enemy몭s situation. This is all that몭s needed to make a strong army. And the key to being able to 몬concentrate all our available strength, and anticipate the enemy몭s movements몭 is to pick the right people to work for you.

몮Greater numbers of soldiers do not equate to advantage.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Attain balance between the power of your army and the extent of your authority.몯
Wang Xi comments: 몮It will suffice to attain an even balance between the power of your army and the extent of your authority. Do not believe that it is always good to have more.몯
What do they mean by 몬an even balance between the power of your army and the extent of your authority?몭 It몭s about being able to dominate your army. If your army reaches a size beyond your ability to control and dominate it, adding more troops isn몭t going to do you any good.
Han Xin once claimed that, as far his own leadership ability was concerned, there was no such thing as too many troops. Whether 100,000 or a million, he could dominate any army. He also claimed that Liu Bang didn몭t have the skill to lead more than 100,000 men at a time; that was supposedly the upper limit of his leadership abilities. But, Han Xin did say that although Liu Bang wasn몭t a good leader of soldiers, he was a very good leader of generals 멪 that was why he was able to handle Han Xin.

몮Do not advance relying solely upon military might.몯

Wang Xi comments: 몮One cannot rely solely on martial might; one should proceed using wisdom and planning to predict the enemy몭s movements.몯

몮Proper personnel selections are sufficient to concentrate all our available strength and anticipate the enemy몭s movements.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Personally cultivating them will suffice.몯
Being able to 몬concentrate all our available strength and anticipate the enemy몭s movements몭 is all about choosing the right people to work for you. And where should you look for these talented individuals? Cao Cao has the answer: 몬personally cultivate몭 them. Don몭t bother with outside hiring 멪 the people you need are already in your army. They몭re the next generation; you trained them yourself. So, how are you supposed to 몬cultivate몭 your soldiers? In the next part, we몭ll dive into how it몭s done.
This is a major strategic and organizational concept. It몭s about relying on the internal strength of your organization, and picking talented people from inside, instead of relying on outside help. With armies, the important thing isn몭t to have as many troops as possible. On top of that, your leadership ability needs to match the number of men under your command. You need to be able to unify your army 멪 to hold the reins and stay in charge. That몭s why you shouldn몭t rely on people from outside.
This is a relevant passage from the Wei Liaozi: 몮Any time that reinforcements are called upon in war, if it is claimed that 100,000 men will come, then in reality only a fraction of that number will materialize. Moreover, among those that come, every one of them remonstrates with their general: 몬Let us not fight first on their behalf.몭몯
This is exactly what happened when the six remaining states at the end of the Warring States period were finally wiped from the map by the state of Qin. The Qin armies fought for their own kingdom, so when they won, the victory belonged to Qin. The same was true when they lost. But, the other six states joined their armies together, meaning that nobody wanted to be the first to fight. That몭s because if they lost, they몭d have to own it, and even if they won they might still come out the other end as a loser.
It몭s the same with development strategy for businesses. To develop, you need to rely on your own strength. If you want to get into a coalition with other businesses, so you can 몬complement each other몭s competitive advantages,몭 it몭s because you몭re hoping the other companies will help you out with developing your business. You몭d be better off letting go of such hopes!
The same principle applies on the level of individual people. People often say that 몬Each friend you make opens up a new opportunity.몭 But, while it몭s true that friends can help you, you can몭t expect your friends to make things happen for you. As we몭ve said, many people keep busy every day going to all kinds of events in the hope of 몬meeting people.몭 Don몭t waste your time; you won몭t derive real benefit from all the running around.

몮He who exercises no forethought but makes light of his opponents is sure to be captured by them.몯

A passage in the Zuo Commentary reads: 몮Lords must not refer to Zhu as a small state. Even bees and chai have venom within; how much more venom is there within a state?몯
Chai are a kind of venomous insect, similar to scorpions.
Armies aren몭t just about large numbers, and disaster doesn몭t just happen when lots of things go wrong 멪 a single, small problem could be your undoing. If you have courage but not wisdom, and if you underestimate your enemy, you몭ll definitely end up getting captured.
There was war between the states of Song and Chu in the Spring and Autumn period, during which the Song commander-in-chief, Hua Yuan, once cooked a big pot of mutton soup. He shared the soup with his men, and they happily ate it. Unfortunately, he forgot about his chariot driver. That whole night, the driver drooled, and all the while his resentment grew. The next day on the battlefield, before any orders had been given, the chariot driver suddenly spurred the horses forward and, without saying a word, charged straight into the Chu lines.
