His startled passenger 멪 the commander Hua Yuan 멪 was captured.
And that몭s how even a little bee sting can be fatal.

몮If soldiers are punished before they have grown attached to you, they will not prove submissive.몯

This line is where we move on to talk about how to cultivate your personnel.


The deepest essence of human relationships 멨 People taming people

Extract from the original text:
몮If soldiers are punished before they have grown attached to you, they will not prove submissive; and, unless submissive, then will be practically useless. If, when the soldiers have become attached to you, punishments are not enforced, they will still be useless. Therefore, soldiers must be treated in the first instance with civil values, but kept under control by military values. This is a certain road to victory. If, in training soldiers, commands are habitually enforced, the army will be well disciplined; if not, its discipline will be poor. If a general shows confidence in his men but always insists on his orders being obeyed, the gain will be mutual.몯

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: 몮Personally cultivating them will suffice.몯 Use soldiers who you몭ve raised yourself. This one word, 몬cultivating,몭 is pregnant with meaning.
In the original text, the word translated here as 몬cultivating몭 contains two characters. The first one, si, has a basic meaning of 몬sticking close together.몭
The words used to express the idea of 몬cultivating personnel몭 in the original text could be interpreted as insulting, as if describing a dog someone was taming. But if the people being cultivated are like dogs, at least you know they몭ll be unfailingly loyal to their master.
If you turn things around and look at this potentially insulting language (몬taming몭) from the master몭s perspective, then if you train your soldiers to be like your dogs (몬unfailingly loyal몭), isn몭t that a good thing, in terms of military command and control in times of war?
So, it would seem that 몬taming몭 people like this works out pretty well.
But, do we understand how to tame people? Have we ourselves at some point been tamed by someone?
Turning the question around again, would we want to be tamed by someone else? Would we know how to be tamed?
There몭s an expression in Chinese: 몬A person who you look after, but who never really becomes part of the family.몭 No matter how well you treat this person, they don몭t understand you and never take after your way of thinking. So, you end up leaving this person.
If we turn this back on ourselves, could it be possible that there are people who would use this expression to describe us? I몭m afraid that the answer is yes. There have been those who think this way about us, who몭ve treated us so well that we took it for granted and thought it was normal. We lower the standards we hold ourselves to and end up hurting the very person who was looking after us.
This line of thought is profound. Under its surface, there lies a vast body of learning.
몬Keeping and training몭 is the subject matter of a certain, highly influential work of world literature, one that몭s been called 몬a fairytale for adults몭 멪 The Little Prince.
The Little Prince, a short story by the poet and journalist Antoine de Saint-Exup?ry, is a famous work of French children몭s literature published in in 1943. The main character is a little prince who comes from another planet, and the story몭s narrator is a pilot. He tells of how the prince set out on a journey from his planet towards earth, and about all the adventures he experienced on the way.
In one part of the story, the little prince meets a fox who demands that the prince take him in and look after him. The fox explains the essential qualities of the relationship between the person in charge and the creature who몭s being looked after: love and responsibility. The way a leader should keep, look after and train the people in their charge is all about love and responsibility.
Let몭s read a bit of the story. It몭s a long passage, but it몭s one that몭s absolutely worth reading, re-reading, and thinking about in detail

"Come and play with me," proposed the little prince. "I am so unhappy." "I cannot play with you," the fox said. "I am not tamed." "Ah! Please excuse me," said the little prince. But, after some thought, he added: "What does that mean 멪 'tame?몭" "You do not live here," said the fox. "What is it that you are looking for?" "I am looking for men," said the little prince. "What does that mean 멪 'tame?몭" "Men," said the fox. "They have guns, and they hunt. It is very disturbing. They also raise chickens. These are their only interests. Are you looking for chickens?" "No," said the little prince. "I am looking for friends. What does that mean 멪 'tame?몭" "It is an act too often neglected," said the fox. 몮It means to establish ties." "'To establish ties'?" "Just that," said the fox. "To me, you are still nothing more than a little boy who is just like a hundred thousand other little boys. And I have no need of you. And you, on your part, have no need of me. To you, I am nothing more than a fox like a hundred thousand other foxes. But if you tame me, then we shall need each other. To me, you will be unique in all the world. To you, I shall be unique in all the world..." "I am beginning to understand," said the little prince. "There is a flower... I think that she has tamed me..." "It is possible," said the fox. "On the Earth one sees all sorts of things." "Oh, but this is not on the Earth!" said the little prince. The fox seemed perplexed, and very curious. "On another planet?" "Yes." "Are there hunters on this planet?" "No." "Ah, that is interesting! Are there chickens?" "No." "Nothing is perfect," sighed the fox. But he came back to his idea. "My life is very monotonous," the fox said. "I hunt chickens; men hunt me. All the chickens are just alike, and all the men are just alike. And, in consequence, I am a little bored. But if you tame me, it will be as if the sun came to shine on my life. I shall know the sound of a step that will be different from all the others. Other steps send me hurrying back underneath the ground. Yours will call me, like music, out of my burrow. And then look: you see the grain?fields down yonder? I do not eat bread. Wheat is of no use to me. The wheat fields have nothing to say to me. And that is sad. But you have hair that is the color of gold. Think how wonderful that will be when you have tamed me! The grain, which is also golden, will bring me back the thought of you. And I shall love to listen to the wind in the wheat..." The fox gazed at the little prince, for a long time. "Please 멪 tame me!" he said. "I want to, very much," the little prince replied. "But I have not much time. I have friends to discover, and a great many things to understand." "One only understands the things that one tames," said the fox. "Men have no more time to understand anything. They buy things all ready made at the shops. But there is no shop anywhere where one can buy friendship, and so men have no friends anymore. If you want a friend, tame me..." "What must I do, to tame you?" asked the little prince. "You must be very patient," replied the fox. "First you will sit down at a little distance from me 멪 like that 멪 in the grass. I shall look at you out of the corner of my eye, and you will say nothing. Words are the source of misunderstandings. But you will sit a little closer to me, every day..." The next day the little prince came back. "It would have been better to come back at the same hour," said the fox. "If, for example, you come at four o'clock in the afternoon, then at three o'clock I shall begin to be happy. I shall feel happier and happier as the hour advances. At four o'clock, I shall already be worrying and jumping about. I shall show you how happy I am! But if you come at just any time, I shall never know at what hour my heart is to be ready to greet you... One must observe the proper rites..." "What is a rite?" asked the little prince. "Those also are actions too often neglected," said the fox. "They are what make one day different from other days, one hour from other hours. There is a rite, for example, among my hunters. Every Thursday they dance with the village girls. So Thursday is a wonderful day for me! I can take a walk as far as the vineyards. But if the hunters danced at just any time, every day would be like every other day, and I should never have any vacation at all." So the little prince tamed the fox. And when the hour of his departure drew near 멪 "Ah," said the fox, "I shall cry." "It is your own fault," said the little prince. "I never wished you any sort of harm; but you wanted me to tame you..." "Yes, that is so," said the fox. "But now you are going to cry!" said the little prince. "Yes, that is so," said the fox. "Then it has done you no good at all!" "It has done me good," said the fox, "because of the color of the wheat fields." And then he added: "Go and look again at the roses. You will understand now that yours is unique in all the world. Then come back to say goodbye to me, and I will make you a present of a secret." The little prince went away, to look again at the roses. "You are not at all like my rose," he said. "As yet you are nothing. No one has tamed you, and you have tamed no one. You are like my fox when I first knew him. He was only a fox like a hundred thousand other foxes. But I have made him my friend, and now he is unique in all the world." And the roses were very much embarrassed. "You are beautiful, but you are empty," he went on. "One could not die for you. To be sure, an ordinary passerby would think that my rose looked just like you 멪 the rose that belongs to me. But in herself alone she is more important than all the hundreds of you other roses: because it is she that I have watered; because it is she that I have put under the glass globe; because it is she that I have sheltered behind the screen; because it is for her that I have killed the caterpillars (except the two or three that we saved to become butterflies); because it is she that I have listened to, when she grumbled, or boasted, or even sometimes when she said nothing. Because she is my rose.

The reason why The Little Prince has been described as a fairytale for adults is because it lays bare the deepest essence of how humans relate to one another. That essence is, in a phrase, 몬taming몭 one another.
Bosses and their underlings tame one another; husbands and wives tame one another; businesses and consumers tame one another; governments and ordinary people tame one another. To tame someone is to establish a bond with them. Once there몭s a bond between us, I know how you몭ll treat me, and how you몭ll behave at different times and in different circumstances. Also, I know how I should treat you.
Taming someone is about love and responsibility, expectations and dependence.
The relationships built by the act of taming are deep, and yet they also become increasingly fragile as they gain more depth 멪 they cannot survive even the slightest betrayal.
In taming, there are no surprises; everything runs its course, steadily and dependably. For example, look at how circus troupes tame their animals. When they train a dolphin to bounce a ball on its head, it is absolutely certain that each time it bounces the ball, it will be fed a fish. There몭s no way the one-fish-for-one-bounce mechanism can fail. If it does, even once, it will not be possible for the show to go on.
Now, let몭s get back to The Art of War. 
몮Bear in your mind the interests of those under your command and be able to make them aware of it.몯
This is one of the regulations at The United States Military Academy.
In relationships based on taming, it몭s important to be mindful of the other person; you can몭t just think about your own goals. It몭s also essential that the other person knows you몭re being mindful of them, and that they trust you to think on their behalf. If you feel that the other person in this relationship is keeping distant from you, then, unfortunately, that몭s probably because you haven몭t factored them into your thinking enough. Or, perhaps, you haven몭t been able to make them aware that you몭re thinking about them.
Teams must understand the need for members to tame each other, and each of them must also enter into the spirit and ritual of taming one another.
You could spend a lifetime practicing this skill, and still have more to learn. 
That said, let몭s read another piece from Sun Tzu:

몮If soldiers are punished before they have grown attached to you, they will not prove submissive; and, unless submissive, then will be practically useless.몯

If you try to use punishment as a method for managing your soldiers before they몭ve become personally attached to you, they won몭t accept that you몭re right. If they don몭t accept that you몭re right, it will be very difficult to put them to use.
Du Mu comments: 몮Without trust and kindness having first been established, it will not do to use punishment to bring your soldiers into line.몯
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Use morality to make yourself supreme over them; use kindness to bring them close to you. Without applying morality and kindness, they will not accept your punishments but rather will grow resentful. It will be difficult to use them.몯
First, you have to make your people respect and love you. Only then can they respect and fear you at the same time. If you want everyone to be scared of you from the very start, you won몭t make it as a leader.

몮If, when the soldiers have become attached to you, punishments are not enforced, they will still be useless.몯

This situation is the opposite 멪 if everyone몭s already attached to you, but you몭re unable to enforce strict discipline, your army won몭t be any use in a battle.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Kindness and trust having been established, if you do not employ punishments, then the soldiers become arrogant, slothful, and useless.몯
If you have kindness but no authority, love but no punishments, your troops and officers will grow lazy and arrogant. They몭ll be of no use to you.
All of this is the territory of what could be called 몬The Way of Taming.몭


몮Therefore, soldiers must be treated in the first instance with civil values, but kept under control by military values. This is a certain road to victory.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮몬Civil values몭 means 몬benevolence.몭 몬Military values몭 means 몬law.몭몯
몬Civil values몭 are about soothing and pacifying people 멪 they몭re the carrot to the stick of 몬military values,몭 which consist of martial discipline and law. You need both the carrot and the stick if you want to create an army that몭s guaranteed to win.
몮A man capable of using civil values to build intimacy with the people, and military values to extend authority over his enemies.몯 This is a recommendation for Sima Rangju, written by the ancient statesman Yan Ying.
Wu Qi wrote: 몮He who combines civil and military values may take command of an army; he who can be both hard and soft has the ability to fight wars.몯

몮If, in training soldiers, commands are habitually enforced, the army will be well-disciplined; if not, its discipline will be poor. If a general shows confidence in his men but always insists on his orders being obeyed, the gain will be mutual.몯

Note the use of the word 몬habitually몭멪 it몭s important. You don몭t wait until you몭re on the battlefield to start enforcing commands. Just imagine: 몬Alright! The battle몭s about to start, so it몭s time to start enforcing some commands! We normally like to keep it nice and casual, but this time is different!몭 It몭s precisely during the 몬normal몭 times that you need to strictly enforce your commands. This way, your troops will get in the habit of obeying them.
If your normal way of doing things is very relaxed, and you don몭t instill good habits in your men, they won몭t obey you on the battlefield when you finally do start to insist on strict compliance with your commands. They simply won몭t be in the habit of doing so.
The only way to build well-oiled coordination between the ranks of an army is to train your troops to jump when you tell them to.
Du Mu comments: 몮When staying in a fixed position, on days when there is no other business to attend to, one must, as a priority, instill in one몭s men trust and fear towards you, an awareness of your kindness, and compliance with commands. Then, when the time comes to face the enemy and you issue commands and call upon the laws, every one of your men will obey멞 Commands must be clearly stated in advance, so that people are not confused when they hear them; laws must be enforced, so that people abide by them and do not look upon them lightly. The 몬three commands and five orders몭 must be demonstrated to people so as to avert confusion. Laws and commands should be simple and adequate, and any law that is introduced must be enforced. Then, it will be possible for the general and his men to understand one another.몯
There are two crucial elements when it comes to commands and rules: make clear what they are as early as possible, so that everyone knows exactly what they mean; and any law that you establish absolutely must be enforced, with no exceptions.
몬The three commands and five orders몭 refers to the ancient Chinese system of military laws and rules. 
The first 몬command몭 is: 몬Keep watch over the enemy몭s plots, observe the state of the roads and other transport routes as regards ease of use, and be informed about where the places of life and the places of death are located.몭
The second 몬command몭 is: 몬Keep your ears alert to the sound of gongs and drums and your eyes alert to flags and banners, so that your eyes and ears work in unison.몭
The third 몬command몭 is: 몬Raise the axe high, to make known what are the punishments and what are the rewards.몭
Now, for the 몬five orders.몭
The first 몬order몭 is: 몬Use rewards and punishments to make their hearts and minds as one.몭
The second 몬order몭 is: 몬Observe the way they divide and come together, so as to make their movements as one.몭
The third 몬order몭 is: 몬Draw battle lines using flags and banners.몭
The fourth 몬order몭 is: 몬When fighting at night, listen for fire and drums.몭
Finally, the fifth 몬order몭 is: 몬To any who does not reverently obey orders, look upon him with the axe.몭
To make everyone in your organization feel secure and rooted, you need to make the 몬three commands and five orders몭 totally clear. Make your rules and orders simple and appropriate, enforce all of your rules, and don몭t make any exceptions. If you do this, your people몭s minds will be clear and unclouded.
However, if the 몬three commands and five orders몭 become nothing more than empty words 멪 if you enforce the rules selectively, even though all of your men are guilty of violations 멪 they몭ll get in the habit of trusting to their luck. At the same time, this situation makes men feel anxious and insecure.
There몭s a passage from the Wei Liaozi that reads: 몮If, in the rules which you employ to give orders, there are found some small errors, do not change the rules; if you find some minor issues involving lack of clarity, do not reformulate them. The reason for acting this way is that the senior officers will not doubt the commands they give, and the soldiers will not conjure up two interpretations of each command. If you can act without hesitation or doubt, then the soldiers will not have second thoughts about their will to act. Thus, you will not face a situation where you cannot command confidence and trust in their minds, but will be able to harness their strength; having averted the possibility of not being able to harness their strength, you will be able to make them fight unto death.몯
This is about how to make rules. If you realize, after the fact, that there are some minor issues with your rules, as long as they몭re not serious, don몭t change them. Just keep on enforcing them the way they are. If there are some minor parts of your rules that aren몭t easy to understand, don몭t try to re-write them. Rules are rules 멪 once you몭ve made them, just keep enforcing them.
It몭s important that rules be strict, authoritative and stable, more so than how practical they are. For example, when Zhuge Liang was enmeshed in fighting the Wei army, he started off outnumbered. Despite this, when the prescribed time came for a portion of his soldiers몭 military service to end, he was bound by his own rules to send them home. 몮Trust cannot be lost,몯 he said. He didn몭t keep them until the fighting was over and then send them home; he let them go on exactly the predetermined date. This in fact inspired them to stay with Zhuge Liang, and fight at least one more battle. This trust between the general and his soldiers was like rocket fuel for his army몭s morale. Zhuge Liang ended that campaign by inflicting a massive defeat on the Wei army.
This is how Zhuge Liang and his men 몬tamed몭 one another.


Appendix: Complete text of The Army on the March

Sun Tzu said: 몮We come now to the question of encamping the army, and observing signs of the enemy. Pass quickly over mountains, and keep in the neighborhood of valleys. Camp in high places, facing the sun. Do not climb heights in order to fight. So much for mountain warfare. After crossing a river, you should get far away from it. When an invading force crosses a river in its onward march, do not advance to meet it in mid-stream. It will be best to let half the army get across, and then deliver your attack. If you are anxious to fight, you should not go to meet the invader near a river he has to cross. Moor your craft higher up than the enemy, and facing the sun. Do not move up-stream to meet the enemy. So much for river warfare. In crossing salt marshes and swamps, your sole concern should be to get over them quickly, without any delay. If forced to fight in a salt marsh or a swamp, you should have water and grass near you, and get your back to a clump of trees. So much for operations in salt marshes. In dry, level country, take up an easily accessible position with rising ground to your right and on your rear, so that the danger may be in front, and safety lie behind. So much for campaigning in flat country. These are the four useful branches of military knowledge that enabled the Yellow Emperor to vanquish four sovereigns. All armies prefer high ground to low and sunny places to dark. If you are careful of your men, and camp on hard ground, the army will be free from disease of every kind, and this will spell victory. When you come to a hill or a bank, occupy the sunny side, with the slope on your right rear. Thus you will at once act for the benefit of your soldiers and utilize the natural advantages of the ground. When, in consequence of heavy rains up-country, a river that you wish to ford is swollen and flecked with foam, you must wait until it subsides. Country in which there are precipitous cliffs with torrents running between, deep natural hollows, confined places, tangled thickets, quagmires and crevasses, should be left with all possible speed and not approached. While we keep away from such places, we should get the enemy to approach them; while we face them, we should let the enemy have them on his rear. If an army on the march should encounter any steep and obstructed terrain, ponds surrounded by aquatic grass, hollow basins filled with reeds, or woods with thick undergrowth, they must be carefully routed out and searched; for these are places where men in ambush or insidious spies are likely to be lurking. When the enemy is close at hand and remains quiet, he is relying on the natural strength of his position. When he keeps aloof and tries to provoke a battle, he is anxious for the other side to advance. If his place of encampment is easy of access, he holds an advantage. Movement amongst the trees of a forest shows that the enemy is advancing. The appearance of a number of screens in the midst of thick grass means that the enemy wants to make us suspicious. The rising of birds in their flight is the sign of an ambuscade. Startled beasts indicate that the enemy is surging forth. When there is dust rising in a high column, it is the sign of chariots advancing; when the dust is low, but spread over a wide area, it betokens the approach of infantry. When it branches out in different directions, it shows that parties have been sent to collect firewood. A few clouds of dust moving to and fro signify that the army is encamping. Humble words and increased preparations are signs that the enemy is about to advance. Violent language and driving forward as if to attack are signs that he will retreat. When the light chariots come out first and take up a position on the wings, it is a sign that the enemy is forming for battle. Peace proposals unaccompanied by a sworn covenant indicate a plot. When there is much running about and the soldiers and chariots fall into rank, it means that the critical moment has come. When some are seen advancing and some retreating, it is a lure. When the soldiers stand leaning on their spears, they are faint from want of food. If those who are sent to draw water begin by drinking themselves, the army is suffering from thirst. 
몮If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are in chaos. If the enemy sees an advantage to be gained and makes no effort to secure it, the soldiers are exhausted. If birds gather on any spot, it is unoccupied. Clamor by night betokens nervousness. If there is disturbance in the camp, the general몭s authority is weak. If the banners and flags are shifted about, sedition is afoot. If the officers are angry, it means that the men are weary. When an army feeds its horses with grain and kills its cattle for food, and when the men do not hang their cooking pots over the camp fires, showing that they will not return to their tents, you may know that they are determined to fight to the death. The sight of men whispering earnestly without ceasing or speaking in subdued tones points to disaffection amongst the rank and file. Too frequent rewards signify that the enemy is at the end of his resources; too many punishments betray a condition of dire distress. To begin by bluster, but afterwards to take fright at the enemy몭s numbers, shows a supreme lack of intelligence. When envoys are sent with compliments in their mouths, it is a sign that the enemy desires repose. If the enemy몭s troops march up angrily and remain facing ours for a long time without either joining battle or taking themselves off again, the situation is one that demands great vigilance and circumspection. Greater numbers of soldiers do not equate to advantage; do not advance relying solely upon military might. Proper personnel selections are sufficient to concentrate all our available strength and anticipate the enemy몭s movements. He who exercises no forethought but makes light of his opponents is sure to be captured by them. If soldiers are punished before they have grown attached to you, they will not prove submissive; and, unless submissive, then will be practically useless. If, when the soldiers have become attached to you, punishments are not enforced, they will still be useless. Therefore, soldiers must be treated in the first instance with civil values, but kept under control by military values. This is a certain road to victory. If, in training soldiers, commands are habitually enforced, the army will be well disciplined; if not, its discipline will be poor. If a general shows confidence in his men but always insists on his orders being obeyed, the gain will be mutual.몯


Chapter Ten: Terrain

Six terrain types and how to fight in them (part one): First, occupy the most favourable terrain

Extract from the original text:
몮We may distinguish six kinds of terrain: (1) Accessible ground; (2) Entangling ground; (3) Temporizing ground; (4) Narrow passes; (5) Precipitous heights; (6) Positions at a great distance from the enemy. Ground which can be freely traversed by both sides is called accessible. With regard to ground of this nature, be before the enemy in occupying the raised and sunny spots, benefiting your line of supplies. Then you will be able to fight with advantage. Ground which can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling. From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him. But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue.몯

Analysis:
Here is Cao Cao몭s commentary to begin the chapter on Terrain: 몮If you wish to fight, assess the terrain. Use it as the foundation upon which to construct your victory.몯
Terrain is crucial to fighting battles. That몭s why you must assess and familiarize yourself with the terrain before the fighting begins. This is the only way to 몬construct victory.몭
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Whenever an army goes on the march, first send out an advance party to search for enemy ambushes; order them to sweep all the land, mountains and rivers within a distance of fifty li. Then, the general shall personally inspect the terrain, and by his inspections, shall map the land so that he may know where it presents danger and where it may be easily traversed. In this way, when an army marches into foreign territory, victory is constructed upon an assessment of the terrain. When this has been done, then soldiers may be dispatched.몯
Having this information allows you to choose a good location to engage in the fight.
Every time Li Shimin went to war, he unfailingly inspected the terrain in person. He even scouted out enemy camps, putting himself in danger many times in the process. He never palmed off this work to other people 멪 it had to be him. The reason behind this principle is that, whatever question you might have, the answer will be found at the spot where the battle will take place. These places are almost 몬alive.몭 They talk to you. Once you arrive, you몭ll know where and how to send your troops into action; you몭ll be able to sketch out a mental outline for every step you take, so by the time the battle begins you몭ll already have a few cards up your sleeve.
During the Three Kingdoms period, there was a high-ranking Wei general named Deng Ai, who was sent with an army to attack and attempt to destroy the kingdom of Shu Han. Deng Ai came from a poor family and had once worked as a junior official in charge of a few rice fields under Cao Cao몭s Tuntian system of state-organized farming. He was a very intelligent, educated man, and he deeply enjoyed military life. Whenever he was on the move, every time his journey took him to a high mountain or a big river, he would scout the surrounding area and hold elaborate discussions about where would be a good spot to camp, where to set up an ambush, and what route the enemy would take if they were to attack. The people around him made fun of him for this diligent intelligence gathering, analysis and planning, but he didn몭t care in the slightest.
Just like landscape painters who liked to search out strangely shaped mountains and sketch every one they could find, Deng Ai was constantly formulating projections based on everything he saw, constantly practicing and mentally rehearsing battles in whatever type of terrain he came across. Twenty years passed without anything of much significance happening, until finally he was promoted and given a position as a 몬Commandant of Agriculture.몭 He몭d been put in charge of managing a few farms, which gave him the opportunity to travel to the capital city, Luoyang, where he was to deliver a report. He was able to meet with General Sima Yi, and the conversation that ensued changed his life. He was brought into the palace, and he finally had his chance to do something great for his country.
At this point, let몭s talk about 몬the six types of terrain.몭

몮(1) Accessible ground; (2) Entangling ground; (3) Temporizing ground; (4) Narrow passes; (5) Precipitous heights; (6) Positions at a great distance from the enemy.몯

1) Accessible ground:

몮Ground which can be freely traversed by both sides is called accessible.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Places where transport routes intersect and expedite travel.몯

Du You comments: 몮All such places are in level expanses, expeditious for coming and going.몯 These places are accessible to your forces and the enemy몭s alike; neither side can obstruct the other.


몮With regard to ground of this nature, be before the enemy in occupying the raised and sunny spots, benefiting your line of supplies. Then you will be able to fight with advantage.몯


What몭s the right way to fight on terrain where neither side is able to block their opponent몭s access? The first thing to do is to occupy the high ground, from where you몭ll have a clear view of the surrounding area. Make sure your position faces the sun and that your grain re-supply carts can get in and out easily. This is how to create a more beneficial situation.
Cao Cao comments: 몮It is better to maneuver the enemy to come to you than to be maneuvered by the enemy.몯

Du Mu writes that 몬accessible land몭 consists of places where a battle could happen anywhere 멪 the enemy could come from any direction. He also emphasizes that you should occupy the high ground, facing into the sun, and not allow the enemy to get there first. That몭s because it몭s not easy when you몭re in a flat landscape to find a piece of elevated ground big enough for a large army to camp.

How are you supposed to 몬benefit your line of supplies?몭 Build defensive structures or walls either side of the road in key 몬crossroad몭 locations. This is how to protect your supply lines, and building walled-in roads between key grain depots is exactly what Liu Bang did during his war against Xiang Yu. He relied on these structures to secure his food supply.

Zhang Yu writes that you should position yourself at the battlefield and wait for the enemy to come to you 멪 this is how to maneuver the enemy while avoiding being maneuvered. But what if you do this, and even though you hold the best terrain, the enemy never comes? Meanwhile, you몭re burning through food supplies every day. That몭s why it몭s essential to secure your food supply and make sure your supply lines don몭t get cut.

Reading Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, we realize that much of the time, the best strategy is to wait for the enemy to come to you. It몭s essential to know how to wait, and to be able to put that ability into practice. Some people can몭t wait; to them, waiting is the same as doing nothing. That몭s why such people are likely to act without thinking and are bound to make mistakes.

Before we move on, I몭ll add a few words about how Liu Bang몭s war against Xiang Yu wrapped up.

Liu Bang held the granaries, so he and his men had plenty to eat every day. Meanwhile, Xiang Yu몭s supply lines were cut by the Han armies, and his troops suffered unspeakable hunger. Ultimately, this led Xiang Yu to accept peace terms, which fixed the borders between the kingdoms of Chu and Han. But, the moment that Xiang Yu had signed the peace treaty and pulled his troops back, Liu Bang immediately tore up the treaty and attacked while the enemy몭s spirit was 몬sluggish and inclined to return.몭 Soon after, he fought the final battle of the war at Gaixia, where Xiang Yu slit his own throat on the bank of the River Wu.


Six terrain types and how to fight in them (part two): True heroes understand the waiting game

Extract from the original text:
몮Ground which can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling. From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him. But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue. When the position is such that neither side will gain by making the first move, it is called temporizing ground. In a position of this sort, even though the enemy should offer us an attractive bait, it will be advisable not to stir forth, but rather to retreat, thus enticing the enemy in his turn; then, when part of his army has come out, we may deliver our attack with advantage.몯

Analysis:
2) Entangling ground:
몮Ground which can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling.몯
When you몭re able to travel to a place, but unable to get out again, you몭ve become entangled. Du Mu comments: 몮That which is called 몬entangling몭 is when one is drawn in and hung up.몯

몮From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him. But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue.몯

When you come across 몬entangling ground,몭 you need to observe whether the enemy is prepared to hold off an attack. If they몭re unprepared, you can send out your troops and beat him using a surprise attack. But, if they몭re prepared, you won몭t be able to get the upper hand in an attack, and you몭ll find yourself unable to move forward or backward without serious difficulty.
Du Mu comments: 몮Entangling ground is a place of danger and obstruction, both for oneself and for one몭s enemy. Presented with a jagged, uneven line between the two sides, any move might cause one to become entangled and obstructed. Moving to attack the enemy, if the enemy be unprepared, then one몭s attack is certain to bring victory. Thus, although one is situated amidst danger and obstructions, the enemy is already defeated and will be unable to intercept my route of retreat. If, having moved to attack the enemy, the enemy is prepared, then victory will be impossible. Then, with the enemy holding a defensive position in a dangerous and obstructed location, they will block one몭s road of retreat, rendering it difficult to return.몯
If the enemy is unprepared and you launch a surprise attack, the enemy is already beaten. At that point, you don몭t care about the terrain. But, if the enemy is prepared, you won몭t be able to dislodge them, and they몭ll cut off your escape route. Unfortunately for you, you몭re likely to get hung up to dry.
What are you supposed to do if you find yourself in this unpleasant situation? 몮If, despite one몭s efforts, one is trapped there, one must adopt a stratagem of holding one몭s own for a long duration; plunder grain from the enemy so that you may wait for an advantageous situation, upon which you must seize and strike the enemy.몯 This advice comes from Chen Hao몭s commentary.
Dear old Mister Chen is just trying to make you feel better. In reality, he몭s putting you in even more danger! If you몭re all tangled up in treacherous terrain, with an enemy in front of you that you can몭t beat, and your way back cut off, what makes you think you몭ll be able to steal the enemy몭s food and hold out over the long haul? In this situation, you only have three choices: (1)  Wait for reinforcements to come and save the day, in which case everything몭s coming up roses; (2) Stand and fight 멪 go all out and hope you can beat the practically insurmountable odds. However, the result is likely to be the death of your entire army. Otherwise, you몭re not really in 몬entangling ground; (3) Admit defeat and surrender.
The Art of War doesn몭t teach anything about surrendering, which is a serious problem. If you don몭t admit defeat when it몭s the right thing to do, all that몭s left for you is to give up your life.
Why do I say that Chen Hao is putting people in danger? Here, Sun Tzu hasn몭t taught us what to do in this dire situation, because he doesn몭t have a solution. And yet, here we have a 몬solution,몭 because Chen Hao has made one up.
You mustn몭t go into 몬entangling ground몭 멪 if you do, there몭s no coming back 99% of the time. The moment your escape route is cut off, you몭re totally trapped. But, Chen Hao tells us that 몬where there몭s a will, there몭 a way.몭 He tells us he has a solution, and when we hear this our ears perk up. Hope stirs in us that, with a bit of luck, we might just pull it off. This na?ve hope, combined with a compulsion to do something, is what got you in this mess in the first place. Admittedly, it몭s true that this has sometimes worked. You can find the proof if you flick through the history books, and knowing this, your confidence swells some more. But the reality is that this kind of situation has played out 1,000 times through history, and 999 times, it몭s ended in death. There몭s no point writing something down that몭s happened so many times, but the one time when it worked and the protagonists came out alive 멪 that몭s enough to convince you it몭ll work out the same way for you, or even better.
And so, you venture into the 몬entangling ground몭 anyway, and what happens? You get hung up to dry.

       3) Temporizing ground[bd32]:
      몮When the position is such that neither side will gain by making the first move, it is called temporizing ground.몯
If you and the enemy are on either side of a narrow strip of crossable land, meaning that whoever moves first will be at a disadvantage, this is called 몬temporizing ground.몭
For example, suppose there몭s a narrow canyon separating two armies. Whoever attacks first will have to pass through the canyon, and while they몭re inside, they몭ll be vulnerable to ambush. Or, suppose there몭s a river separating the two armies. If one side wants to attack, they몭ll have to cross the river, which gives their opponents the chance to attack before they몭ve finished crossing. The upshot is that neither side is keen to make the first move.
In this situation, even though the enemy may offer us attractive bait, it will be advisable not to stir forth, but rather to retreat, thus enticing the enemy in his turn. Then, when part of his army has come out, we may deliver our attack with advantage.
Chen Hao writes in his commentary that if both sides send out troops in difficult terrain, it몭s vital that you not chase after the enemy if they try to bait you. You should pull your army back, and if the enemy doesn몭t chase after you, forget about it. If they do chase after you, wait until they몭re halfway through the 몬temporizing ground,몭 and then strike as quickly as possible.
In an earlier case study, we learned about a standoff between Commander Yang Chufu of the state of Jin and Commander Zi Shang of the state of Chu. The two armies stood on either side of the River Zhi, and Commander Yang Chufu decided he wanted to make the enemy come across the river so he could attack before they몭d finished crossing. He pulled his men back from the riverbank and set up camp. Meanwhile, Commander Zi Shang had the same idea, and he also pulled his men back and set up camp some distance away from the river. Both men were thinking alike, and, each unable to fool the other, they both retreated further and further away from the river, until it became obvious that nothing was going to happen. At that point, they both quit while they were ahead and marched back home.
This is an example of 몬temporizing ground.몭 All that means is that whoever moves first will be at a disadvantage. So, both sides try to lure the enemy into attacking first. When they fail to bait each other, they give up the idea of fighting and just go home.
Some might ask, 몬What has this got to do with the art of war, if there몭s no fighting and nobody wins?몭
As we몭ve said again and again, the most important part of the art of war isn몭t fighting, but not fighting. Why do we lose? Why do our troops die and why do our commanders몭 heads get separated from their bodies? It몭s because we decided to fight.
If we don몭t fight, we can몭t lose.
If we don몭t fight, there몭ll always be a chance to fight in the future. If we fight, lose and end up dead, we몭ll never have another chance.
This is why Sun Tzu talks about winning first and fighting later. If you haven몭t already won, don몭t fight. Obviously, this means there aren몭t many situations where you actually fight; most of the time, you should choose to not fight. If you do fight, finish the job with one battle. If you look closely at the major historical case studies 멪 such as when Zhou Yafu put down the Rebellion of the Seven States 멪 they can all be summed up as 몬waiting instead of fighting, then settling the score in a single battle.몭
A true hero is someone who몭s mastered the waiting game, and who understands how to hold off from fighting. Heroes who spend their whole time fighting belong in the movies; their only job is to put on a show. True heroes understand one, simple truth: if you don몭t go looking for death, you won몭t get yourself killed.


Six terrain types and how to fight in them (part three): Ability to judge when you몭re doomed to lose is more important than confidence that victory is yours

Extract from the original text:
몮With regard to narrow passes, if you can occupy them first, fill them up and await the advent of the enemy. Should the enemy forestall you in occupying a pass, do not go after him if the pass is fully garrisoned, but only if it is weakly garrisoned. With regard to precipitous heights, if you are beforehand with your adversary, you should occupy the raised and sunny spots, and there wait for him to come up. If the enemy has occupied them before you, do not follow him, but retreat and try to entice him away. If you are situated at a great distance from the enemy, and the strength of the two armies is equal, it is not easy to provoke a battle, and fighting will be to your disadvantage. These six are the principles connected with Earth. The general who has attained a responsible post must be careful to study them.몯

Analysis:
3) Narrow passes:

몮With regard to narrow passes, if you can occupy them first, fill them up and await the advent of the enemy.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Narrow passes are canyons giving passage between two mountains. Here, the enemy몭s force is powerless to harm me.몯

High mountains on either side, and a canyon in between 멪 if I seize this position, there몭s only one road the enemy can take to get to me. If I hold the entrance to the canyon, he몭s powerless to attack me.

If you come across this kind of terrain, 몬fill it up and await the advent of the enemy.몭 The notion of 몬filling it up몭 is the same idea as filling a sink with water: deploy your men in a formation that uses up all the space in the pass. How do you do this? Deploy troops on either side of the pass. Cao Cao writes: 몮Square your forces with the entrance of the defile,몯 meaning that your battle lines should precisely cover the entrance to the pass. Each pass has two entrances 멪 one in the front, and one in the back 멪 so you need to deploy troops on both sides. This is how to make sure nobody can get in.


몮Should the enemy forestall you in occupying a pass, do not go after him if the pass is fully garrisoned, but only if it is weakly garrisoned.몯


If the enemy seizes the pass before you and fills it up with his men, stay away. If he only deploys troops on one side of the pass, or if he doesn몭t secure it at all, you should attack, because without securing both sides of the pass, the terrain isn몭t giving him any advantage. Who will win then comes down to the people in both armies, rather than the terrain.

We몭ve already learned about how General Han Xin defeated the state of Zhao. In that war, the Zhao army failed to secure Jingxing Pass, allowing Han Xin to saunter unopposed through the dangerous terrain.

4) Precipitous heights:

몮With regard to precipitous heights, if you are beforehand with your adversary, you should occupy the raised and sunny spots, and there wait for him to come up.몯

Places described as 몬precipitous heights몭 are strategic locations, easy to defend and difficult to attack. If you get there first, you can set up in high, sunny ground, and wait for the enemy to come to you. This is about the importance of seizing the high ground before your enemy can.


몮If the enemy has occupied them before you, do not follow him, but retreat and try to entice him away.몯


Du Mu comments: 몮Precipitous heights are places of steep mountains and deep ravines, against which human strength is impotent. It is essential to occupy the high, sunny ground, and there await the enemy. If the enemy seizes the position first, then you must not contend with him, but should entice him to leave his position. Sunny ground is that which faces south. It is likely that the enemy will hold his position for a long time; if you position yourself on shady ground, then disease will spread through your ranks. Should you encounter the enemy in mountainous or watery terrain, then first move to occupy a position in the mountains to the north; thus, you will be facing into the sun and away from the shade. Facing the sun, or holding a high position 멪 between these two, one may sacrifice a sunny position for the sake of gaining a high position, but not the other way round. Sun Tzu wrote about this in general terms.몯

If the enemy occupies a strategic location, you can몭t beat him through force of arms alone. If it몭s obvious that you can몭t win, don몭t fight. Pull your troops back and retreat. If the enemy chases after you, he몭s left his strategic location and lost his terrain advantage and you can set an ambush. If he doesn몭t chase after you, let him stay on his mountain. Time to go home.

Cao Cao comments: 몮In dangerous and constricted terrain, it is particularly important not to be maneuvered by the enemy.몯 It몭s essential not to attack in this kind of terrain. 

Duke Li of Wei wrote that the entirety of The Art of War boils down to just one sentence: 몮Manipulate your foe, and do not allow yourself to be manipulated.몯 In practice, this means that you have to set up the battlefield and wait for the enemy to bring the fight to you. Accordingly, it also means refusing to go to a battlefield if it was chosen by the enemy.

5) Great distances:

몮If you are situated at a great distance from the enemy, and the strength of the two armies is equal, it is not easy to provoke a battle, and fighting will be to your disadvantage.몯

In terrain characterized by 몬great distances,몭 your army and the enemy army are positioned far apart. If you몭re in this situation, and if your capabilities are evenly matched with the enemy, you shouldn몭t try to start a fight. In Du Mu몭s commentary, he gives an example: If your army is 30 li distant from your enemy, and you march out to attack the enemy camp, your men will be exhausted by the time you get there, while the enemy is still fresh. But if you wait for them to come to you looking for a fight, you can stay fresh and just wait while they tire themselves out.

What if you absolutely have to fight? 몮Those who are determined in their desire to fight should move closer to the enemy,몯 Du Mu writes. Move your camp closer to the enemy.
This solution comes straight from Du Mu몭s imagination, not from anything Sun Tzu wrote. Sun Tzu only wrote about the characteristics of 몬great distances몭 in terms of general principles. The only place to get a detailed, specific solution is the battlefield. No two places are the same, and no two battles are the same.


몮These six are the principles connected with Earth. The general who has attained a responsible post must be careful to study them.몯


These six terrain types, and the 몬art of terrain,몭 are crucial considerations. For any general or leader, it몭s simply not an option to be ignorant about such an important subject. It몭s a big responsibility.

When we몭re at war, we몭re all more than willing to drum up confidence within ourselves that victory is the only outcome. But, for generals, it몭s more important to be a good judge of when you몭re 몬doomed to fail몭 than to be confident of victory. If you know that you몭ve lost the initiative and the terrain advantage, don몭t engage. The biggest disaster is when you don몭t know that you몭re going to lose and walk blindly into a fight.

Zhuge Liang had a Chinese Dream 멪 to unify all of China. This is why, even though it was obvious that his kingdom was no match for the state of Wei, he kept hammering, launching one campaign after another into the Central Plain. However, whenever he saw that victory was beyond his grasp, he would immediately pull his army back and head home.
There몭s no such thing as a sure victory. Instead, we should aim to not lose. 


Six ways to lose (part one): You always lose to yourself; All responsibility belongs to the commander-in-chief

Extract from the original text:
몮Now an army is exposed to six calamities, not arising from natural causes, but from faults for which the general is responsible. These are: (1) Flight; (2) Looseness; (3) Collapse; (4) Ruin; (5) Disorganization; (6) Rout. Other conditions being equal, if one force is hurled against another ten times its size, the result will be the flight of the former. When the common soldiers are too strong and their officers too weak, the result is looseness. When the officers are too strong and the common soldiers too weak, the result is collapse. When the higher officers are angry and loose, and on meeting the enemy give battle on their own account from a feeling of resentment, before the commander-in-chief can tell whether or not he is in a position to fight, the result is ruin. When the general is weak and without authority; when his orders are not clear and distinct; when there are no fixed duties assigned to officers and men, and the ranks are formed in a slovenly haphazard manner, the result is utter disorganization. When a general, unable to estimate the enemy몭s strength, allows an inferior force to engage a larger one, or hurls a weak detachment against a powerful one, and neglects to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout. These are six ways of courting defeat, which must be carefully noted by the general who has attained a responsible post.몯

Analysis:
몮Now an army is exposed to six several calamities, not arising from natural causes, but from faults for which the general is responsible. These are: (1) Flight; (2) Looseness; (3) Collapse; (4) Ruin; (5) Disorganization; (6) Rout.몯
This section is about the six 몬calamities,몭 or the six failures:
1) Flight:

몮Other conditions being equal, if one force is hurled against another ten times its size, the result will be the flight of the former.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮The force has not been measured.몯

Li Quan comments: 몮This is about not measuring force. One may use the stratagem of ambush by an auxiliary force, provided that you have obtained advantageous terrain.몯

If you try to fight a force ten times the size of your own, you haven몭t accurately assessed the balance of power. Then, the only way you몭ll be in a position to fight is if you have a terrain advantage that allows a single one of your soldiers to hold back thousands of the enemy.

2) Looseness[bd34][TT35]:

몮When the common soldiers are too strong and their officers too weak, the result is looseness.몯

If the soldiers are tough but their officers are soft, to the point that officers몭 commands don몭t move them and discipline is limp, this is called 몬looseness.몭

During the Battle of Jifu, between the ancient states of Wu and Chu, the Chu forces teamed up with a few, small vassal states to form a seven-state allied army, which included in its ranks several minor lords. During the war, the Chu commander-in-chief, Yang Gai, fell ill and died. 몮The Chu army has been spoiled, and there is no consistency in commands and decrees; the commanders are debased and incapable of organizing the army. Lacking authority sufficient to give orders, Chu is likely to lose.몯 Thus spoke the Duke of Wu, Zi Guang. And he was right 멪 the conflict ended with a major defeat for Chu.

During the reign of Tang dynasty Emperor Muzong (795-825 CE) there was a military uprising in Zhen Prefecture. The Imperial House appointed Tian Bu as Governor of Weibo, and ordered him to deal with the rebels. Tian Bu had spent his childhood in Weibo, and the local people looked down on him and didn몭t listen to him. In his camp, many thousands of troops milled around aimlessly, and Tian Bu was unable to rein them in. After several months, it seemed like fighting was about to break out, but none of his soldiers were willing to go to battle. Helpless, Tian Bu sent a note to the Emperor, telling him about the army몭s situation and that he was powerless to do anything about it. The only thing Tian Bu had to offer was his life, and so he killed himself.

The lesson here is that if you want to put a person to work for you, not only must that person have the proper skills, he also must have authority and the ability to twist people몭s arms and make them do his bidding. If the person you choose has the skill but not the authority, he몭s only fit to work as an assistant.

3)  Collapse:

몮When the officers are too strong and the common soldiers too weak, the result is collapse.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Strong officers want to advance, but if the common soldiers are weak, collapse will ensue.몯 This applies when soldiers don몭t follow behind their brave and strong commander. 몮With me!몯 the general shouts, as he charges. Behind him, though, his troops haven몭t followed. He plunges forward, alone, and into collapse.

Zhang Yu comments: 몮The general and officers are brave and desire to fight, but the common soldiery lack quality and training, rendering them unable to match their leaders몭 bravery or to fight zealously alongside them. If you use such men, you are certain to meet with collapse, death and defeat.몯

It몭s important to 몬match bravery몭 between troops and officers, and for everyone to fight alongside each other with the same, elevated energy. The general몭s duty is to train and lead soldiers, not to fight single-handed. If he can몭t properly train his men during peacetime, all his personal bravery and strength won몭t do any good on the battlefield. He몭ll find himself trapped, and collapse will inevitably follow.

4) Ruin:

몮When the higher officers are angry and loose, and on meeting the enemy give battle on their own account from a feeling of resentment, before the commander-in-chief can tell whether or not he is in a position to fight, the result is ruin.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮몬Higher officers몭 are assistant generals. The senior general vents rage upon them, and so in their hearts they do not respect him. Being already angry, when the time comes to attack the enemy, they do not measure the balance of power. Then, ruin is inevitable.몯 After meeting the enemy, the senior officers don몭t wait for command, and lead their men into battle under their own authority. In an army where the commander can몭t control his officers, ruin is what happens. 

Chen Hao comments: 몮This is when the commanding general behaves unreasonably and thus enrages the assistant generals. They harbor disrespect in their hearts, and because they bear grudges, they commence battle as soon as the enemy is at hand, without considering whether they can win. Therefore, they are heavily defeated.몯 When officers are disgruntled, they want to fight as soon as they catch sight of the enemy. They don몭t care whether they live or die, and they care even less about overall strategy. Feeling bitter and having lost control of their emotions, they want to fight to vent their feelings. But, it might be even more serious 멪 they might hope that their own side will lose just to humiliate their commander. 몬I remember when it was you abusing me. Well, let몭s see how things go for you now!몭 they think to themselves.몯

We몭ve already learned about the Battle for the City of Bi, which took place during the war between Jin and Chu, as both states vied to dominate China. The Jin and Chu armies were standing on opposite sides of the Yellow River. It was clear that the next battle would be decisive, and within the Jin army everyone had different opinions about whether to fight or sue for peace. The commander-in-chief, Xun Linfu, wanted to hold their position, while the Military Adjutant, Xian Gu, wanted to take the fight to the enemy. There was a fierce debate, but no conclusion. So, Xian Gu did exactly what Sun Tzu wrote about: he got angry, lost respect for his commanding officer, and because of his feelings, he started a fight on his own initiative, leading his household soldiers across the Yellow River. Xun Linfu was shocked when he heard the news. Sima Hanjue suggested mobilizing the rest of the army to prevent Xian Gu몭s force from being wiped out. And that몭s how the entire Jin army was forced to start a fight.

But, there were two other men in the Jin army who proved to be even worse than Xian Gu: Wei Qi and Zhao Zhan. At least Xian Gu thought he was trying to help his country, but these two wanted the Jin army to lose. It was, as we discussed earlier, all because Xun Linfu had refused them when they몭d asked for promotions. Now, they wanted to see Xun suffer. The two managed to get authorization from Lin to go to the Chu camp and negotiate a peace accord. But when they got there, they did the exact opposite. Instead of negotiating for peace, they picked a fight. They intentionally left Xun Linfu unprepared for the Chu surprise attack that they몭d provoked, which naturally inflicted a heavy defeat on the Jin army. That was the moment when Jin was no longer a contender in the contest to dominate China.

Xun Linfu몭s grandson, Xun Yan, also served as commander-in-chief of the Jin army, and while he was at the helm, he led a campaign against the state of Qin. When it was time to march out from Jin, he announced: 몮We ride when the cock crows; you will follow me, and me alone.몯 But this infuriated the man next to him, Lian Shu, who announced: 몮There is no man of Jin living who can give me orders like this!몯 He was in effect saying, 몬I몭m pulling my men out, and I don몭t want to have anything more to do with you.몭

Lian Shu was a powerful politician in Jin, and he was old enough to be Xun Yan몭s father.
If this is how things were done in Jin, it몭s no wonder that the state eventually fractured, resulting in new states 멪 Han, Zhao, and Wei, three of the seven major states during the Warring States period. If Jin had stayed unified, there only would have been five states, and Qin might not have been able to ultimately unify all of China.

Let몭s talk about another arrogant Jin general, Zhao Chuan. He was a through-and-through rich kid, completely reliant on his uncle Zhao Cui and his older brother, Zhao Dun. Zhao Dun was the Jin commander-in-chief when Qin invaded. His trusted advisor, Military Adjutant Yu Pian, came up with a plan. He said that the Qin army lacked staying power, and proposed taking advantage of that. 몮If we hold our position and don몭t come out to fight, they won몭t be able to last. Eventually, they몭ll pull back, and then we can hit them when they몭re 몬sluggish and inclined to return.몭 It몭ll be a complete victory.몯 Zhao Dun was completely sold on the plan, so he gave orders that nobody was allowed to go out and fight.

When it became clear that the Jin forces weren몭t going to engage, Duke Kang of Qin grew anxious. He turned to a Jin exile, Shi Hui, who had moved to Qin. The duke asked Shi Hui, 몮What몭s going on?몯 

몮This is Yu Pian몭s idea, no doubt,몯 Shi Hui replied. 몮The Jin commander-in-chief몭s younger brother, Zhao Chuan, is extremely upset that his brother promoted Yu Pian. If we pick a fight with Zhao Chuan몭s men, he몭s bound to come out and fight.몯

The Qin commander did as Shu Hui said. A force was dispatched to harass Zhao Chuan, and sure enough, Zhao Chuan came out to fight. At the time, Zhao Dun was holding a meeting. When he heard that Zhao Chuan was fighting, his only option was to mobilize the whole army and join the fray.  After all, his little brother몭s safety was at stake. 


Six ways to lose (part two): The art of choosing your vanguard

5) Disorganization:

몮When the general is weak and without authority; when his orders are not clear and distinct; when there are no fixes duties assigned to officers and men, and the ranks are formed in a slovenly haphazard manner, the result is utter disorganization.몯

When a general is timid, doesn몭t manage his men strictly enough, and doesn몭t give clear instructions, his soldiers are left without a consistent framework. When it몭s time to line up for battle, the battle lines will be ragged and the troops will get in each other몭s way. This is what Sun Tzu means by 몬disorganization.몭

Zhang Yu comments: 몮The general is weak and not strict; this is what it means to speak of 몬a commander who lacks authority and moral force.몭 His instructions and communications are unclear; this is what it means to speak of 몬a commander whose commands are not informed by the methods of old.몭 There is no consistency among the officers and the soldiers; this is what it means to speak of 몬a commander who has no long-standing advisors.몭 When he lines up his soldiers, the lines are slovenly and uneven; this is what it means to speak of 몬the soldiery lacking control.몭 When a general is like this, disorganization follows.몯

A general who 몬is weak and not strict몭 has no authority or moral force.

In a company where no one has been in the job for long 멪 where everyone몭s new 멪  frankly it would be strange if disorganization and chaos weren몭t the order of the day.

6) Rout:

몮When a general, unable to estimate the enemy몭s strength, allows an inferior force to engage a larger one, or hurls a weak detachment against a powerful one, and neglects to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout.몯

The key here is: 몬place picked soldiers in the front rank.몭 This is imperative. Form a vanguard from a handpicked group of your best fighters. They will be your spearhead; they몭ll be like a dagger to plunge into the enemy. You could say that without a spearhead, all you몭re left with is a bunch of soldiers with no sharp edges.

King Wei of the state of Qi asked the strategist Sun Bin about battle theory: 몮If the ground is level and the two armies몭 personnel are evenly matched when they come together, what causes one side to be routed?몯

몮Because they had battle lines but no spearhead,몯 came Sun Bin몭s reply. Any army that makes this mistake is doomed to be defeated.

Also on this point, there몭s a passage from a chapter of the Wei Liaozi, entitled Authority in War, which reads: 몮If one fails to hand-pick warriors, one몭s entire army will be weak.몯
This line is a reminder: where is your spearhead? As a military leader, it몭s absolutely essential to have one.

Du Mu mentions in his commentary that Duke Li of Wei wrote about having a vanguard unit as part of his writings on the art of war.

We also have a detailed comment from He Shi: 몮It is always unacceptable to treat soldiers as a single entity, when they comprise soldiers who are weak and soldiers who are full of courage. Because the brave soldiers will receive no encouragement, and the weak soldiers will be able to hide themselves and thus will go into battle but not fight. Hence, defeat awaits. This is why it is written in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몬Neglecting to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout.몭 

몮In times of old, the state of Qi derived strength from their 몬strike specialists,몭 Wei derived vigor from their 몬martial men,몭 and Qin built victory upon their 몬sharp swords.몭 There were many alternative names for 몬handpicked vanguard.몭 The Han military men had their 몬three rivers, valiant swordsmen and prodigies,몭 the Wu generals called them 몬problem-solvers,몭 the Qi generals called them 몬fate-fixers,몭 and the Tang generals called them 몬leapers and shakers.몭 Nothing comes before this in the use of military tactics. As for the talents the chosen men must possess, the senior general would order each camp to select its best fighting men, who must be unusually strong and fit in addition to being surpassingly skilled in the use of weapons. These men should be 몬organized into a separate unit몭 consisting of roughly one tenth of the army. The chosen men have few tasks; the crucial point is that they must be ready. They are the heart of the general몭s command system; they are the general몭s personal fighting force, and they also serve such tasks as fighting at the front line, setting ambushes, and so forth. Each of them must be deployed in accordance with an accurate assessment of their qualities."

If you treat all of your men as if they were the same, the best fighters won몭t get any recognition; if they think there몭s no honor to be gained, their will to fight will fade. As for the weaker men, they몭ll be able to hide their mediocrity by blending into the background and letting more capable men do the heavy lifting. They몭ll be physically present on the battlefield, but they won몭t be fighting; they몭ll be hiding behind the stronger men. That몭s why The Art of War tells us that if you don몭t have an advance unit, you몭re going to lose.

You can call this unit 몬the big guns,몭 몬the death-defiers,몭 or simply 몬the vanguard.몭 Whatever you call it, they몭ll be your cutting edge.

All the dynasties throughout Chinese history have made it a priority to build up vanguard forces, and each dynasty had a different name for these special units. During the Spring and Autumn period, they were called 몬forward marchers몭 by Jin tacticians, and 몬sharp swords몭 or 몬line-breakers몭 by Qin generals. They were known as 몬strike specialists몭 or 몬fate-fixers몭 by Qi commanders, during the Warring States period. The leaders of the state of Wei referred to them as 몬martial men,몭 while Tang strategists called them 몬fighting blades몭 and 몬leapers and shakers.몭

Judging by all these names, it몭s clear how much importance was attached to building these vanguard units. Above all else, using military force is about using these units. They account for one in ten soldiers in an army 멪 chosen from among the best men in every camp 멪 and tasked with fighting at the front line, carrying out ambushes, serving as the general몭s personal guard, and other critically important duties. They are absolutely crucial; they are the elite force that brings victory.

The Ming dynasty writer Yu Qian observed: 몮Of all the methods to prevent disgrace, none is better than training the soldiers, and the crucial part of training soldiers is to separate the strong from the weak. Thus it is written in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몬Neglecting to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout,몭 and 몬proper governance is what brings victory in war.몭 A million men who do not obey orders are worth less than ten thousand with the will to fight; ten thousand men who do not obey orders are worth less than a hundred imbued with powerful energy. That is, the most treasured resource in war is not numbers, but spirit; much better to have a handful of spirited men than many lackluster men.몯

During the time of the Eastern Jin dynasty (316-420 CE), the Eastern Jin commander Xie Xuan faced heavy military pressure from the Former Qin dynasty. Xie Xuan picked out the most fearless warriors from among the northern nomads and put a man named Liu Laozhi in command. He proved to be an excellent leader, and he led the vanguard unit in dozens of battles, winning each and every one. His unit became known as the Northern Palace Detachment. They made their name at the Battle of Feishui after defeating Fu Jian몭s million-man army, and they were consistently the most powerful weapon in the Eastern Jin arsenal. It was from their ranks that the man who founded the Liu Song Empire, Liu Yu, first rose to power. After taking the throne, the Northern Palace Detachment became the core of the Liu Song military apparatus. 


Sun Tzu몭s professional ethics: Don몭t seek fame when you advance; don몭t avoid blame when you retreat

Guo Ziyi represents the Chinese people몭s ultimate dream, a dream thousands of years old: honor, wealth and status; good health and long life; and many, many children and grandchildren.

Extract from the original text:
몮The natural formation of the country is the soldier몭s best ally; but a power of estimating the adversary, of controlling the forces of victory, and of shrewdly calculating difficulties, dangers and distances, constitutes the test of a great general. He who knows these things, and in fighting puts his knowledge into practice, will win his battles. He who knows them not, nor practices them, will surely be defeated. If fighting is sure to result in victory, then you must fight, even though the ruler forbid it; if fighting will not result in victory, then you must not fight even at the ruler몭s bidding. The general who advances without coveting fame and retreats without fearing disgrace, whose only thought is to protect his country and do good service for his sovereign, is the jewel of the kingdom.몯

Analysis:
몮The natural formation of the country is the soldier몭s best ally; but a power of estimating the adversary, of controlling the forces of victory, and of shrewdly calculating difficulties, dangers and distances, constitutes the test of a great general. He who knows these things, and in fighting puts his knowledge into practice, will win his battles. He who knows them not, nor practices them, will surely be defeated.몯
In war, terrain is your natural helper. The best generals accurately judge their enemy몭s plans, study the terrain and identify where it presents danger and easy travel, calculate the distances to be travelled, and draw up a battle plan. If you go into battle as a commander having understood these principles, victory is within your grasp. If you don몭t, you몭re going to lose.
Terrain is of crucial importance. In Chinese, there몭s a saying that good terrain trumps timing. However, it몭s still just a helper; having the right personnel is better than having a terrain advantage. Your human resources are your foundation. This doesn몭t mean that good terrain is worth less than having more people; it means that having people who understand the art of war is the only way you can evaluate the terrain, assess the enemy몭s situation and ultimately win the decisive battle.

몮If fighting is sure to result in victory, then you must fight, even though the ruler forbid it; if fighting will not result in victory, then you must not fight even at the ruler몭s bidding.몯


Depending on the situation on the ground, if victory is already certain, you can fight even if the ruler orders you not to. If it몭s clear that you몭re going to lose, you can choose not to fight even if the ruler orders you to fight. This is the same principal as before: 몬The general in the field does not always obey the sovereign몭s orders.몭

몮The general who advances without coveting fame and retreats without fearing disgrace, whose only thought is to protect his country and do good service for his sovereign, is the jewel of the kingdom.몯

What makes this kind of person a national treasure? Zhang Yu comments: 몮A loyal servant of the state is a man who advances or retreats without regard for his own life, who never acts out of personal interests, and who does everything to protect the people and bring benefit to the sovereign; such a man is the jewel of the kingdom.몯 
He Shi comments: 몮How could it be acceptable to seek fame by advancing? Look always for what is beneficial to the state and the people, and only advance when you have seen it. How could it be acceptable to avoid blame by retreating? Upon seeing a danger that might bring disaster to the state and the people, do not advance even if the sovereign commands you. Have no regrets, even if you are tainted by disgrace.몯
As He Shi has pointed out, Sun Tzu doesn몭t just suggest that everything you do should be for the people: 몮Protect the people in everything you do; seek outcomes that align with the sovereign몭s interests.몯
Protecting your officers, soldiers and the common people is about staying alive. Don몭t throw lives away for no good reason, and remember that you need to bring home whatever helps your ruler몭s interests. There몭s a difference between the interests of the people and the interests of the ruler.
A 몬jewel of the country몭 could be described as 몬of superlative quality, honest and upright, kind, devoted and proud.몭
Being of 몬superlative quality몭 means having the ability to see the essence of things, to know whether the outcome of a conflict will be victory or defeat, and to know when to advance and when to retreat.
Being 몬honest and upright몭 means integrity is in your very bones; you몭re not just truthful and principled in certain things, but in everything you do. No matter what decision you몭re faced with, nobody in your organization, from the lowest rank to the highest, questions your motives. This is the only kind of person who has the qualifications and the space to make unilateral decisions and to act alone.
This kind person is someone who truly loves their people, their country and their subordinates, as well as their ruler. Their love is sincere and without pretense; it is a love that every person can feel emanating from them.
A 몬devoted몭 person is someone who is truly loyal to their country, and to the interests of their people and their ruler. It is not someone who is loyal only to instructions given by any one person. Because the ruler몭s instructions don몭t necessarily align with his interests, the ruler몭s judgment might be incorrect.
A 몬proud몭 person is someone who cares nothing about the fame that comes with being a 몬winner.몭 That몭s worthless to them. They have no use for yet another victory to prove their worth. When other people measure them by their victories, they just laugh.
So, who lives up to these standards? Who can rightly be called a 몬jewel of the country?몭
How about Yue Fei? Actually, no. The way Yue Fei moved his armies might have aligned with the interests of the state and the people, but not with those of the ruler, Emperor Zhao Gou. Yue Fei몭s actions could have resulted in two men both claiming to be Emperor 멪 what was Zhao Gou supposed to do about that? In the fallout after the destruction of the Northern Song dynasty, Zhao Gou had the biggest stake in the game, because he몭d become Emperor even though he wasn몭t technically 몬qualified.몭 If there were a war, the enemy Khitan state wouldn몭t even need Yue Fei to fight. They might have just released Zhao Gou몭s older brother and sent him home, which would have plunged the Emperor into a deep political crisis. There몭s not much use you can get out of a captive enemy ruler; the enemy will just choose a new ruler, and your prisoner will become worthless.
During the Ming dynasty몭s Crisis of Tumu Fortress, the Mongolian commander Esen Taishi captured Emperor Yingzong. Immediately, the Ming court installed Yingzong몭s younger brother, Chengwang, as the new ruler, known as the Jingtai Emperor. Esen Taishi no longer had any use for the Emperor he몭d captured, so for lack of better options, he sent him home, where he was put under house arrest in the Southern Palace by the Jingtai Emperor. He stayed locked up for seven years, until the Jingtai Emperor fell ill. Then, Shi Heng and his co-conspirators launched the 몬Duomen Coup몭 and restored Yingzong to the throne.
So, when Yue Fei championed the idea of bringing back 몬the second Emperor,몭 he was completely ignoring Emperor Gaozong몭s (Zhao Gou몭s) interests. Ultimately, Emperor Gaozong negotiated peace with the Khitans, who kept his older brother Qinzong in captivity but released his mother, Empress Xianren. Emperor Gaozong became the architect of the Southern Song restoration, and eventually died peacefully at the ripe old age of 81.
