In the long run, the man who acted in his ruler몭s interests wasn몭t the folk hero Yue Fei, but the 몬villain,몭 Qin Hui. They were two halves of a whole: Yue Fei embodied the principle of 몬protecting the people in everything you do,몭 while Qin Hui embodied the idea of 몬seeking outcomes that align with the sovereign몭s interests.몭
There was one man who meets both requirements: protecting the people while bringing benefits to the ruler. That man was Guo Ziyi.
During the Tang dynasty몭s cataclysmic An Lushan Rebellion, Guo Ziyi was the governor of Shuofang Province. On the battlefield, he defeated Shi Siming in Hebei, and later joined forces with an ethnic Huihe army, retaking the two capital cities of Luoyang and Chang몭an. With a glowing record of service for his contribution to quelling the rebellion, he was promoted to Grand Councilor and granted the noble title of King of Fenyang. During the reign of Emperor Daizong, the traitorous general Pugu Huai몭en convinced Tibetan and Huihe forces to invade the Guanzhong plain region. Guo Ziyi made the correct strategic decision: he allied with the Huihe troops and fought against the Tibetans, and successfully upheld the peace and protected his country.
Guo Ziyi spent his whole life working as a military man, only leaving the arena for the final time at the age of 84. He racked up many amazing achievements during his career, and because of him China enjoyed peace for over 20 consecutive years. He had all the power in the world, but didn몭t provoke the imperial court몭s hostility. He was the most celebrated man of his generation, but he was never doubted by the Emperor. He enjoyed the highest esteem and prestige, throughout the land.
Holding posts at the pinnacle of the governmental hierarchy, Guo Ziyi had immense power. And yet, he always had an easy way about him, and never put up any barriers between himself and the Emperor. Certain court ministers, the type naturally given to treachery, were jealous of him and told tales that he was plotting a rebellion. They insisted to the Emperor that he summon Guo Ziyi to see whether he would obey the summons. If he didn몭t come, that would prove he would soon rebel; if he did come, they figured, they몭d have their chance to take him down. 
Guo Ziyi didn몭t delay for a second. He went immediately before the Emperor, and he went alone, with no guards. He told the Emperor that his head had always been Imperial property, and it was the Emperor몭s to take if he wished.
Guo Ziyi몭s son, Guo Ai, was given an Imperial princess as his wife, but the two used to quarrel.
몮My father is the Emperor, how dare you treat me so rudely!몯 the Princess said.
몮Who cares about the Emperor? My father doesn몭t want to be Emperor. Otherwise, the throne would be his already! Do you really think your father would have a chance?몯 Guo Ai shot back.
The princess went to the Emperor in tears and told him what Guo Ai had said. Under the rule of any of China몭s historical dynasties, his actions would have been enough to have him sentenced to death. Guo Ziyi heard about his son몭s ridiculous actions, and hurried to the palace to apologize for the young man몭s crime.
몮The boy has been quarreling and saying all manner of nonsense. What are we to do with him?몯 the Emperor said.
In the end, Guo Ziyi personally gave his son a beating. And with that, it was done.
Guo Ziyi had seven sons and eight sons-in-law, and all of them made it into high-ranking government posts. On his sixtieth birthday, all his sons and sons-in-law came to celebrate, and each carried from the Imperial court the tablets that government ministers used to record the Emperor몭s commands or comments. These they placed on their father몭s bed. The bed was covered in the tablets, and the phrase 몬a bed full of courtier몭s tablets몭 has entered the Chinese language as a reference to classical culture, meaning 몬a family that has achieved extraordinary success.몭
If you visit ancient Chinese villages, you will see tile sculptures above the doorways of old manor houses, and the story of Guo Ziyi is the most common theme of these sculptures. Guo Ziyi represents the Chinese people몭s ultimate, age-old dream: honor, wealth and status; good health and long life; and an abundance of children and grandchildren.
Love your troops like your own children; True love isn몭t easy; Not for generals, and even less so for the troops!

Extract from the original text:
몮Regard your soldiers as your children, and they will follow you into the deepest valleys; look upon them as your own beloved sons, and they will stand by you even unto death.몯

Analysis:
Treat your soldiers the same way you몭d treat a baby you are raising. If you do that, you can command them to go with you into dangerous places, and they몭ll follow. You can go face-to-face with death, and know that they will be with you at your side.
During the Warring States period, the strategist Wu Qi served as a general. He shared food and clothing with even the lowest of the low among his troops. He slept on the ground without a mat to pad his body, walked rather than ride a horse, and carried his own food on his back; he shared all the physical work and all the hardship that his men experienced. In a story we recounted earlier, one of his men had an ulcer on his leg, so Wu Zi put his mouth to the wound and sucked out the puss. When the man몭s mother heard of this, she began weeping bitterly, as if in grief. 
몮The general has been so kind to your son, what are you crying for?몯 her neighbors asked her.
몮Years ago, my son몭s father also had an ulcer on his leg, and general Wu sucked his wound clean. Very soon after that, my husband died in battle. Now, General Wu has done the same thing for my son, and he too will fight and die for him,몯 the woman replied.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Give them nurture and comfort, and they will stay close to you and never stray. Love and help them, and they will trust you and never doubt. Thus, though they may die, they will offer you their death; though they may come into peril, they will do this for you.몯
That몭s why it몭s important to sincerely care for your troops. Don몭t think that Wu Qi몭s sucking of the ulcers was just a cheap trick. If you do think that, why don몭t you try sucking on someone몭s ulcer! Without sincere, honest love for your men, and without leading them as though they were your own sons, you can never become an outstanding leader.
In He Shi몭s commentary, he writes that a benevolent approach to directing an army is what enabled General Duan Jiong to defeat the Qiang people. He personally attended to the wounded in his army, wrapping their bandages himself. Over the dozen or more years he spent living on the frontiers of the Empire, he never gave himself the luxury of a bed or even proper bedding. Whatever hardship his troops went through, so did he. That몭s what made every one of his troops glad to fight and die for him.
What about the idea that leaders should 몬lead from the front?몭
몮Soldiers toil and labor; the general must go before them. In summer he should not protect himself from the sun with awnings, and in winter he should not wear heavy clothing. When danger comes, he must take the first step. He must only drink after the soldiers몭 well is ready, he must only eat after the soldiers몭 meal is cooked, and he must only take shelter after the soldiers몭 quarters are built.몯 This is a teaching from the art of war.
This isn몭t about going through the motions a couple of times, or just for a day or two; you have to do this day after day, perhaps for decades. It isn몭t something that can be faked, and if you do manage to 몬fake it몭 for decades, you몭re not actually faking; you몭re really doing it.
Can it be done? Few indeed really and truly have the ability. 
Also in He Shi몭s commentary, he tells the story of Wang Rui, a governor of Ba Commandery under the Western Jin dynasty. Wang Rui took up the post in Ba, part of modern Sichuan Province, after Liu Bei몭s Shu Han Kingdom was wiped out by Western Jin forces. Ba Commandery bordered the kingdom of Wu, so Wang Rui was tasked with preparing for war. Soldiers and commoners were conscripted for forced labor, and the work was so grueling that many families killed or abandoned their newborn sons rather than raise them to join the workforce.
Abandoning boys is a phenomenon that happened again and again throughout Chinese history. This was because the poll tax was calculated by the number of males in each household, as was conscription for forced labor. During the reign of Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty (141-87 BCE), the Emperor몭s constant wars bankrupted the country:
A passage from the ancient text, History of the Former Han Dynasty, reads: 몮Emperor Wu, to finance his campaigns against the various barbarians, imposed heavy taxation upon the people. When a family produced a son, taxation was due upon the boy몭s third birthday. So burdensome was this that some killed their sons upon their birth. What tragedy!몯
Readers know[bd36][TT37] that the modern 몬one-child policy몭 led to people killing or abandoning female babies, but many might not know that the same thing happened to male babies throughout China몭s historic succession of dynasties, all because of military conscription and taxes.
There몭s a passage from a poem by the Tang dynasty poet Du Fu that reads: 
몮We know now having boys is bad,
While having girls is for the best;
Our girls can still be married to the neighbors,
Our sons are merely buried amid the grass.몯
The true horror was even worse than the poem suggests. 
What did Wang Rui do about it when he found out this was going on? First, he gave out harsh punishments to people who abandoned or killed babies. Next, he granted maternity and paternity leave to all new parents, along with exemptions from forced labor and tax breaks. That was all it took to save thousands of baby boys! Nearly two decades passed like this, until Wang Rui raised an army and gave orders to invade the kingdom of Wu, by which point the baby boys had reached fighting age. The young men몭s mothers told them:
몮It wasn몭t us, your mother and father, who brought you into this world; it was the lord up in the palace. You must do all you can to help him, and do not hold back from giving your life!몯
So, Wang Rui, by then over 70 years old, completed his great task of destroying the kingdom of Wu and uniting the Three Kingdoms under the rule of the Western Jin dynasty.


There몭s more to fear from your high-ranking officers than from the enemy

Extract from the original text:
몮If, however, you are indulgent, but unable to make your authority felt; kind-hearted, but unable to enforce your commands; and incapable, moreover, of quelling disorder: then your soldiers must be likened to spoiled children; they are useless for any practical purpose.몯

Analysis:
If you only know how to be soft with your men, and can몭t make them do what you want 멪 if you constantly spoil them, and can몭t make them obey your orders 멪 you won몭t be able to reel them in if they break the rules or if their discipline lapses. Then, your men will become proud and unusable.
In Du Mu몭s commentary, he quotes from Huang Shigong: 몮One may go down to one몭s men, but one may not foster arrogance.몯 You can make yourself approachable and get close to your men, and you can treat them politely. What you cannot do is give them free rein. 몬Going down to one몭s men몭 is about using kindness to cultivate your troops and behaving modestly with them; 몬Not fostering arrogance몭 is about using rules and law to control them.
There몭s a passage in a classical text, the Yinfujing, which reads: 몮Danger is born of kindness.몯 When we treat a person too well, we generally end up hurting them as well as ourselves. Why? Because you몭re always nothing but kind, nothing but loving, and you have no boundaries or rules. People get used to this, and they start to act spoiled and let themselves go. Once that happens, there몭s no way back, no matter how you try to adjust. All you can do is give up on them. Then, they lose their chance to be a part of what you몭re doing, and you몭ve wasted your time trying to make something of them.
As soon as the kindness that these people have come to expect from you is gone, they become your enemy. On what grounds do they make an enemy of you? It몭s not that you몭ve hurt them, just that you몭ve withheld your kindness. As far as you몭re concerned, all you몭ve done is stop giving them something, but they feel that you몭re taking something of theirs, something precious, away from them.
Kindness and resentment, debts of gratitude and desire for revenge; they all go together, and they are proportionate to each other. Without kindness, and without a debt of gratitude, there몭s no drive for revenge.
Wu Qi writes: 몮Drums, both on horseback and on the ground, cymbals and bells all establish authority over the ears that behold them; flags, banners and insignias establish authority over the eyes that behold them; prohibitions, commands and punishments establish authority over the minds that behold them. Sounds are used to build authority via the ears, so they must not be unclear; images are used to build authority via the eyes, so they must not be dull; punishments are used to build authority via the minds, so they must not be lax. If you do not establish these three, you inevitably shall suffer defeat at the hands of your enemy. Therefore, it is said that 몬when a general gives signals with flags, all of his soldiers without exception follow the direction indicated; when a general points, all of his soldiers without exception advance towards death.몭몯
Regular training, drills and ceremonies are all important; they strengthen the authority of your command system and get your men used to obeying commands and not doing forbidden things. This is the only way to train troops who aren몭t scared to sacrifice themselves, and who will fight wherever you point them. As soon as you point your signal flags and beat your drums, they몭ll charge without a second thought, because they know that not charging will bring dire consequences.
Duke Li of Wei wrote: 몮Those who fear me will not fear my enemies; those who fear my enemy will not fear me.몯 As a general, it몭s essential to be scarier than your enemy. You want your men to realize that they won몭t necessarily die if they charge the enemy battle lines, but there몭s no escape from the executioner if they don몭t charge when the bugle sounds.
If that doesn몭t horrify you, a passage from later on in Duke Li몭s writings might: 몮In ancient times, it was a requirement for generals to be able to kill three of every ten of their own soldiers; second-rate generals would kill one of every ten. Killing three of every ten, your authority will shake the enemy몭s country; killing one of every ten, you could effectively command an army.몯
In early antiquity, Chinese generals would kill some of their own men, not enemy hostages, before marching to war. Killing hostages 멪 like the Kangxi Emperor몭s killing of rebel general Wu Sangui몭s son 멪 isn몭t a way to establish authority, but to burn bridges. If you want to build military authority, establish military law and make sure your army obeys you, the only people you should kill are men under your command who don몭t listen to orders. As for exactly what kind of people you should select for the executioner, the best targets are those who have some favor with the Emperor. They think that nobody would dare hurt them, and this makes them careless. By killing people like this, you show your men that anyone can be killed. Execute first, tell the Emperor afterward. When you report to the Emperor when the deed몭s already done, he몭ll feel that you몭ve acted appropriately.
There are countless stories along these lines. When Sun Tzu was discussing the art of war with the King of Wu, the king handed his concubines over to Sun Tzu and instructed him to train them as soldiers. If he could turn them into a squad of battle-ready warriors, the King of Wu said, Sun Tzu would win his trust. At first, the concubines giggled and ignored Sun Tzu몭s orders, so he immediately executed the leaders, two of the king몭s most beloved concubines. After that, Sun Tzu was able to complete the women몭s training without delay.
Another classic example of this principle is Tian Rangju몭s execution of Zhuang Jia.
The states of Jin and Yan had both attacked the state of Qi, and Qi crumbled under their assault. Duke Jing of Qi then appointed Tian Rangju as a senior general, on the recommendation of his advisor, Yan Ying. The new general had an idea, and went to tell Duke Jing: 몮I am of humble birth, and now you have elevated me from a commoner to a great general. Nobody knows me, so nobody will obey me, and I shall be unable to hold together the battle lines. I ask you, my lord, please appoint one of your must trusted and senior advisors to serve as my overseer.몯 Duke Jing chose to appoint a man named Zhuang Jia.
Tian Rangju made arrangements with Zhuang Jia, and they agreed to set out at noon the next day. At the hour of departure, the army was assembled and ready, but Zhuang Jia was still drinking with his fellow senior officials, who were giving him a send-off. It was sunset by the time he arrived at the place where the army was gathered. Tian Rangju summoned a military legal official, who confirmed the punishment for reporting late to an army preparing to march 멪 execution by decapitation! The death sentence was served immediately. When Duke Jing received a report that Zhuang Jia was about to be beheaded, he dispatched an official to rush to the scene and save the condemned man. When the official arrived, Tian Rangju found him guilty of driving horses at excessive speed in a military camp, and sentenced him to death as well. However, he granted the man a reprieve on account of his status as a messenger for the Duke, and instead executed the charioteer and the left-side horse.
These executions sent shockwaves through the enemy lands, and when the Jin leaders heard about this savage man in charge of the Qi armies, they didn몭t wait to see what it would be like to fight him. They were so scared that they immediately pulled back their forces.
With the Yan armies in flight, Tian Rangju pressed his advantage and gave chase, recovering all the territory that Qi had lost.
When the Qi army returned in triumph, Duke Jing came out to greet them at the head of an escort of 100 officials. He몭d forgotten all about his advisor, Zhuang Jia! Tian Rangju was granted the title of Minister of War (몬sima몭), and that몭s how he became the famous General Sima Rangju.
Sima Rangju몭s gambit has been imitated again and again throughout history, but many times by ignorant men who neglected to study, and who ended up losing their own heads as a result.
In the final years of the Qin dynasty (221-207 BCE), Chen Sheng and Wu Guang launched an insurrection, as did Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu. Both rebellions managed to seize a few commanderies, and left chaos in their wake. Every wild, ambitious young man in the realm was itching to get involved, and a few 멪 hangers-on of  General Peng Yue 멪 went to Peng. They told him they몭d follow him if he rose up against the Emperor 몮If Chen Sheng, Wu Guang, Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu can do it, we definitely can!몯 they said. But Peng Yue refused: 몮Currently, there are two tigers in battle against each other, and it is completely unclear how the situation might develop. I don몭t want anything to do with it.몯
But, the young, would-be rebels wouldn몭t let the matter drop. They gathered together 100 or so men, determined to conquer the world with their big brother Peng Yue leading the way. Peng Yue couldn몭t get them out of his hair, and finally he gave way: 몮Alright, alright 멪 since you all are insisting on doing this, we몭ll hold our first military meeting tomorrow at dawn. Since we몭re making an army, we몭ll need a code of military laws; anyone who is late to the meeting will be decapitated!몯
The next day at noon, Peng Yue was still waiting. Finally, the last few young men began to trickle into the meeting place. Over a dozen of them were late.
몮According to military law, anyone who is late is to be decapitated, but since so many of you are late, I can몭t execute you all. So, I몭ll just execute whoever arrived last!몯
The men laughed, and asked: 몮Is that really necessary? Now, we know it won몭t happen again.몯
Peng Yue said nothing. He stepped forward, drew his sword, and beheaded the man who몭d arrived last. Everyone else was so scared they began shaking; they didn몭t dare look Peng in the eye. Then, Peng built a simple, earthen altar and offered up the man몭s severed head as a sacrifice.
Peng Yue became a powerful figure in the region, and after throwing his weight behind Liu Bang he was eventually made a senior official in the new Western Han regime.
Today, when we talk of official corruption, there몭s this idea in China that 몬unless we fight corruption, the country will fall; if we do fight corruption, the party will fall.몭 This is a talking point used by people who don몭t want to do anything to stop corruption. Actually, not fighting corruption is what will bring down the party. It몭s not true that the party won몭t have any officials left to do its work if all the corrupt officials are rounded up. In fact, this will only bring the party more strength and vitality.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Neither kindness nor punishments may be used exclusively. If you show only kindness, then the soldiers will become arrogant and useless. If you show only punishments, then the soldiers will not be close to you, which will also render them useless. The kingly way to manage soldiers is to use both kindness and punishments, thus establishing grace and authority simultaneously.몯
There몭s also a passage from the Wei Liaozi that reads: 몮If you do not use love to make their hearts willing, then they are useless to you. If you do not use authority to make their hearts fearful, then they cannot be commanded by you.몯 
For generals, the art of commanding men consists of love and fear 멪 it몭s a matter of rewards and punishments.
What is the essence of fear? 몮Those who fear me shall not fear my enemy; those who fear my enemy shall not fear me.몯 If men are scared of their commanding officers, they won몭t be scared of their enemies, they won몭t be scared of death, and vice versa. So, we have clear criteria for what constitutes 몬fear몭멪 as a general, you have to be scarier than your enemies.


몬Knowing yourself and your enemy몭 according to Emperor Taizong: If you don몭t have the skill to understand others, make sure you know yourself

As long as you know yourself, you can몭t lose. Where people go wrong isn몭t that they don몭t understand other people; it몭s that they don몭t know themselves.

Extract from the original text:
몮If we know that our own men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the enemy is not open to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half. If we know that the enemy is open to attack, but are unaware that our own men are not in a condition to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half. If we know that the enemy is open to attack, and also know that our men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the nature of the ground makes fighting impracticable, prospects for victory still stand only at one half. Hence the experienced soldier, once in motion, is never bewildered; at his disposal is an endless array of possible actions. Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, your victory will not stand in doubt; if you know Heaven and know Earth, you may make your victory complete.

Analysis:
몮If we know that our own men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the enemy is not open to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half.몯
In this scenario, you understand yourself, but not your enemy. You know your army is ready to fight, but you don몭t know that the enemy is also very strong, and you won몭t necessarily be able to get the best of them. So, your odds of victory are fifty-fifty.

몮If we know that the enemy is open to attack, but are unaware that our own men are not in a condition to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half.몯

If you몭ve identified a vulnerability in the enemy that you can strike, but you don몭t realize your men aren몭t up to the task, you won몭t necessarily be able to win. In this scenario, you understand your enemy, but not yourself. Your odds of victory are still fifty-fifty.
In both scenarios, there몭s no certainty of victory.
Emperor Taizong wrote: 몮Whenever I stand with serried ranks facing my enemy, I first evaluate the enemy몭s thoroughness and prudence, and mine also, and so I am able to know my enemy in this way. I observe the degree to which my enemy몭s energy has been cultivated, and mine also, and so I am able to understand myself. This is how I come to know both my enemy and myself; this is indispensable for any military leader. If the officials and advisors of today only know themselves, even without knowing the enemy this is still enough that they will not easily be defeated.몯
Emperor Taizong was able to see through his enemies, and he also had a clear understanding of himself. Even in midst of a dynamic, developing situation, he was able to grasp and manipulate both his army and his enemy몭s forces, including shifts in both armies몭 morale and mood. By doing this, he could create opportunities for certain victory. But, he also says that if you don몭t have the ability to do all this, you don몭t have to completely understand your enemy. In other words, as long as you have a clear understanding of yourself, you can몭t lose. 
This is Emperor Taizong몭s view on 몬knowing yourself and your enemy몭 멪 if you don몭t have the skill to understand other people, make sure you know yourself. I feel very much the same way. Generally, when we try to learn about 몬knowing yourself and your enemy,몭 we focus entirely on how to understand other people, thinking that of course we have a good understanding of ourselves. But, in reality, people usually go wrong because they don몭t correctly understand themselves, and not because they can몭t understand other people. The same is true in business. Don몭t focus exclusively on learning about the so-called 몬competition,몭 because it몭s not particularly useful to know what other people are doing. You need to know what your customers need and what you몭re capable of doing.

몮If we know that the enemy is open to attack, and also know that our men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the nature of the ground makes fighting impracticable, prospects for victory still stand only at one half.몯

It몭s not enough to know yourself and your enemy; you also have to know the terrain.

몮Hence the experienced soldier, once in motion, is never bewildered; at his disposal is an endless array of possible actions.몯

You몭ve already seen and thoroughly considered all the factors in play before you take action, so you can몭t become confused. You know yourself and your enemy, and you know where the advantage of terrain and timing are, so you can take any change in your stride and adapt without breaking step. You몭ll never find yourself without a plan.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮He does not move recklessly, and thus when he does move, he makes no mistake. He does not take action lightly, and thus when he does take action, he does not find himself in difficulties. He learns the weaknesses and strengths of himself and the enemy, and he gains the advantage of expeditious terrain. Only then does he fight.몯


몮Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, your victory will not stand in doubt; if you know Heaven and know Earth, you may make your victory complete.몯

So, if you know yourself and your enemy, you can win without danger; if you understand the advantages of terrain and timing, victory is completely guaranteed.


Appendix: Complete text of Terrain

Sun Tzu said: 몮We may distinguish six kinds of terrain: (1) Accessible ground; (2) Entangling ground; (3) Temporizing ground; (4) Narrow passes; (5) Precipitous heights; (6) Positions at a great distance from the enemy. Ground that can be freely traversed by both sides is called accessible. With regard to ground of this nature, be before the enemy in occupying the raised and sunny spots, benefiting your line of supplies. Then you will be able to fight with advantage. Ground that can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling. From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him. But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue. Ground that can be abandoned but is hard to reoccupy is called entangling. From a position of this sort, if the enemy is unprepared, you may sally forth and defeat him. But if the enemy is prepared for your coming, and you fail to defeat him, then, return being impossible, disaster will ensue. When the position is such that neither side will gain by making the first move, it is called temporizing ground. In a position of this sort, even though the enemy should offer us an attractive bait, it will be advisable not to stir forth, but rather to retreat, thus enticing the enemy in his turn; then, when part of his army has come out, we may deliver our attack with advantage. With regard to narrow passes, if you can occupy them first, fill them up and await the advent of the enemy. Should the enemy forestall you in occupying a pass, do not go after him if the pass is fully garrisoned, but only if it is weakly garrisoned. With regard to precipitous heights, if you are beforehand with your adversary, you should occupy the raised and sunny spots, and there wait for him to come up. If the enemy has occupied them before you, do not follow him, but retreat and try to entice him away. If you are situated at a great distance from the enemy, and the strength of the two armies is equal, it is not easy to provoke a battle, and fighting will be to your disadvantage. These six are the principles connected with Earth. The general who has attained a responsible post must be careful to study them. Now an army is exposed to six calamities, not arising from natural causes, but from faults for which the general is responsible. These are: (1) Flight; (2) Looseness; (3) Collapse; (4) Ruin; (5) Disorganization; (6) Rout. Other conditions being equal, if one force is hurled against another ten times its size, the result will be the flight of the former. When the common soldiers are too strong and their officers too weak, the result is looseness. When the officers are too strong and the common soldiers too weak, the result is collapse. When the higher officers are angry and loose, and on meeting the enemy give battle on their own account from a feeling of resentment, before the commander-in-chief can tell whether or not he is in a position to fight, the result is ruin. When the general is weak and without authority; when his orders are not clear and distinct; when there are no fixed duties assigned to officers and men, and the ranks are formed in a slovenly haphazard manner, the result is utter disorganization. When a general, unable to estimate the enemy몭s strength, allows an inferior force to engage a larger one, or hurls a weak detachment against a powerful one, and neglects to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be a rout. These are six ways of courting defeat, which must be carefully noted by the general who has attained a responsible post. The natural formation of the country is the soldier몭s best ally; but a power of estimating the adversary, of controlling the forces of victory, and of shrewdly calculating difficulties, dangers and distances, constitutes the test of a great general. He who knows these things, and in fighting puts his knowledge into practice, will win his battles. He who knows them not, nor practices them, will surely be defeated. If fighting is sure to result in victory, then you must fight, even though the ruler forbid it; if fighting will not result in victory, then you must not fight even at the ruler몭s bidding. The general who advances without coveting fame and retreats without fearing disgrace, whose only thought is to protect his country and do good service for his sovereign, is the jewel of the kingdom. Regard your soldiers as your children, and they will follow you into the deepest valleys; look upon them as your own beloved sons, and they will stand by you even unto death. If, however, you are indulgent, but unable to make your authority felt; kind-hearted, but unable to enforce your commands; and incapable, moreover, of quelling disorder: then your soldiers must be likened to spoiled children; they are useless for any practical purpose. If we know that our own men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the enemy is not open to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half. If we know that the enemy is open to attack, but are unaware that our own men are not in a condition to attack, prospects for victory stand at one half. If we know that the enemy is open to attack, and also know that our men are in a condition to attack, but are unaware that the nature of the ground makes fighting impracticable, prospects for victory still stand only at one half. Hence the experienced soldier, once in motion, is never bewildered; at his disposal is an endless array of possible actions. Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, your victory will not stand in doubt; if you know Heaven and know Earth, you may make your victory complete.몯


Chapter Eleven: The Nine Situations

How to wage war in the 몬Nine terrain types몭 (part one): Managing energy, selecting men for your vanguard, and the art of dividing your forces

Extract from the original text:
몮The art of war recognizes nine varieties of ground: (1) Dispersive ground; (2) Facile ground; (3) Contentious ground; (4) Open ground; (5) Ground of intersecting highways; (6) Serious ground; (7) Difficult ground; (8) Hemmed-in ground; (9) Desperate ground. When a chieftain is fighting in his own territory, it is dispersive ground. When he has penetrated into hostile territory, but to no great distance, it is facile ground. Ground the possession of which imparts great advantage to either side is contentious ground. Ground on which each side has liberty of movement is open ground. Ground that forms the key to three contiguous states, so that he who occupies it first has the world at his command, is a ground of intersecting highways. When an army has penetrated into the heart of a hostile country, leaving a number of fortified cities in its rear, it is serious ground. Mountain forests, rugged steeps, marshes and fens 멪 all country that is hard to traverse: this is difficult ground. Ground which is reached through narrow gorges, and from which we can only retire by tortuous paths so that a small number of the enemy would suffice to crush a large body of our men: this is hemmed-in ground. Ground on which we can only be saved from destruction by fighting without delay is desperate ground. On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not. On facile ground, halt not. On contentious ground, attack not. On open ground, do not try to block the enemy몭s way. On the ground of intersecting highways, join hands with your allies. On serious ground, gather in plunder. In difficult ground, keep steadily on the march. On hemmed-in ground, resort to stratagem. On desperate ground, fight.

Analysis:
Cao Cao comments: 몮There are nine types of terrain where battle may be desirable.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Among all the terrain types where war may be waged, there are nine attendant energies. Here, the subject matter is the energy pertaining to terrain; hence, this chapter follows after the chapter entitled Terrain.몯
This chapter is about the 몬energy pertaining to terrain몭 멪 the various features of a battlefield. It mainly revolves around how deep one몭s army has entered into enemy territory; the state of relations with neighbors; your psychological condition and that of the enemy; the disparity in overall support available to yourself and your enemy; and what strategic action plans are used under different 몬terrain energies.몭


몮The art of war recognizes nine varieties of ground: (1) Dispersive ground; (2) Facile ground; (3) Contentious ground; (4) Open ground; (5) Ground of intersecting highways; (6) Serious ground; (7) Difficult ground; (8) Hemmed-in ground; (9) Desperate ground.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮These are the names of the nine types of terrains.몯
According to the laws of warfare, there are nine terrain types that strongly impact on the strategy of the fighters:
1) Dispersive ground:

몮When a chieftain is fighting in his own territory, it is dispersive ground멞 On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not.몯

Where does this term, 몬dispersive ground몭 come from? Why is it used to describe a situation where a leader is fighting on his own territory? Cao Cao comments: 몮One몭s soldiers are attached to this ground; the roads are short and it is easy for one몭s army to disperse.몯 When you fight close to home, your men will slip through your hands and go home if you don몭t keep control of them. It몭s easy for your men to lose focus, and if that happens your army can easily collapse.

Li Quan comments: 몮Soldiers long for their home ground and they miss their wives and children; if they become anxious then they will disperse. This is 몬dispersive ground.몭몯

Du Mu comments: 몮The soldiers being close to their homes, they will not be committed to death in their minds as they advance, and they will be mindful that a place of refuge awaits if they only retreat.몯

What are the principles for waging war on dispersive ground? Sun Tzu writes: 몮On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not.몯 Don몭t get into a fight lightly.

Jia Lin comments: 몮One must not fight too many times.몯 If you must fight, finish the job in a single move.

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮Since it is inadvisable to fight on dispersive ground, one is compelled to hold fast in a defensive position, and to not come out. But what ought I do if my enemy attacks the small towns of my kingdom, if he plunders my fields and forests, if he prevents me from gathering firewood, if he blocks my roads, and if he waits for me to be weakened before launching a rapid strike?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮If the enemy enters deep into your territory, his fighting spirit is concentrated and he will easily engage in combat. Your soldiers are close to their homes, so your battle lines will lack solidity and you will not prevail in battle. Instead, you should assemble your people and gather up your grain, protect your fortified cities and prepare to hold strategic locations with dangerous terrain; then, dispatch light forces to sever the enemy몭s supply lines. The enemy will be unable to provoke you into fighting, his supplies will not reach him, he will be unable to plunder the countryside, and his forces will suffer deprivations. Thus, you may lure him after observing his condition, and you will have a chance to succeed. If you desire to fight in open country, you must base your designs upon the energy of terrain and set ambushes in locations with dangerous terrain. If there is no dangerous terrain, conceal yourself in the shadows and emerge when the enemy does not expect you and strike when he is sluggish.몯

Raiding parties manned by the peoples of the north repeatedly invaded China throughout the ages, and pretty much any time the marauders breached the Great Wall, the Chinese defenders used the strategy outlined above. The Chinese forces would shrink back and stay inside Beijing몭s city walls. The invaders would plunder and loot the surrounding countryside for a while, without much to show for their efforts, until soldiers loyal to the Emperor would coalesce from around China and march towards Beijing.  At that point, the invaders would retreat north. Alternatively, if the Emperor couldn몭t stand his honor being tarnished, he would inevitably send an army out to fight. This approach typically ended in disaster.

During the Ming dynasty몭s Crisis of Tumu Fortress, Emperor Yingzong personally led an enormous army of 200,000 troops into battle against the Mongol leader, Essen. His army was annihilated at Tumu Fortress, and he was captured alive. An official named Yu Qian rose to face the crisis, and was given the authority to lead the imperial response. First, he ordered all government officials in Tongzhou to withdraw their salaries and empty all of the grain stores, so they wouldn몭t fall into Essen몭s hands. Meanwhile, Essen was scything a path towards Beijing, right up to the base of the city walls. Defending the city was a force of 220,00 men under the personal command of Yu Qian, who had taken up sword and shield to protect Beijing. He inflicted heavy defeats on Essen, first at Desheng Gate and then at Xizhi Gate, and Essen몭s younger brother was killed in the fighting.

Unable to breach Beijing몭s walls and with no loot within his reach, the Mongols몭 morale was low after successive defeats. At the same time, soldiers from all over China were now on their way to save Beijing. Essen couldn몭t stay where he was 멪 he was standing on hot coals. So, he broke camp and beat a retreat. Yu Qian came out and pursued him while he was 몬sluggish and inclined to return,몭 hitting him with cannon fire. He roundly beat Essen two more times, once at Gu몭an (famous now for the slogan 몬Gu몭an, 50 km due south from Tiananmen 멪 I love Beijing!몭), and once at Bazhou (the 몬Hot Spring Town몭), and captured eighteen high-ranking Mongol generals.

2) Facile ground:

몮When he has penetrated into hostile territory, but to no great distance, it is facile ground멞 On facile ground, halt not.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮It is easy for the soldiers to return home.몯

Li Quan comments: 몮This is terrain which facilitates retreat.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Having entered no great distance into enemy territory, the road home is short and it is easy to return.몯

There몭s not much difference between dispersive ground and facile ground. On dispersive ground, you몭re practically standing in the doorway of your home; as soon as your men몭s fighting spirit slips, home is where they몭ll go. Meanwhile, on facile ground you몭re standing in your enemy몭s doorway, but you몭re still not far from your own home. Here, the idea of pressing forward is scary; you don몭t know what dangers lie ahead. But, you know that pulling back is an easy option, and that you몭ll be safe once you몭re back in your own country.

So, facile ground is also a terrain type where your men몭s fighting spirit will be weak. What is there to do about it? 몮On facile ground, halt not.몯 Don몭t linger.

Du Mu comments: 몮That which is called 몬facile ground몭 in The Art of War is terrain where one has entered not far past the enemy frontier, before the point where dangerous terrain may be pressing against you from behind; it is terrain where the soldiers몭 minds are preoccupied with thoughts of returning home, where it is difficult to advance and easy to retreat; it is a place where the most difficult thing is to move deeper in. One must select the best cavalry soldiers at one몭s disposal and dispatch them in secret to lay an ambush; when enemy soldiers arrive, strike without hesitation; if the enemy soldiers do not come, then quickly depart.몯

If enemy troops come to you, for them it is dispersive ground, and their fighting spirit will be even weaker than your own! So, strike immediately. If they don몭t come, move through quickly 멪 don몭t linger, and make sure your men drop their anxiety about leaving home as quickly as possible. Make them let go of any wishful thinking they might have about a quick return. 

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮What is to be done if the soldiers are preoccupied with thoughts of returning home, if it is difficult to advance but easy to retreat, if one does not yet have one몭s back up against dangerous terrain, and if the minds of one몭s men are filled with dread?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮When the army is situated on facile ground, the soldiers몭 minds are not concentrated. Your task is to advance; do not seek battle. To this end, do not move close to major enemy cities; do not travel by their major transportation routes. Establish decoy units and feign confusion, and give the impression that you are on the verge of departing. Then select an elite group of cavalry soldiers, attack them where they are weak and seize their livestock; when the rest of your forces see this, they will no longer fear moving forward. Split off some good soldiers from your army and secretly install them in an ambush position; if the enemy comes, strike without hesitation. If the enemy does not come, abandon the ambush position and move onward.몯

When you몭ve only just crossed the enemy몭s border, your men haven몭t yet had a chance to get into a war mentality. This is an extremely frightening situation. It몭s best not to fight if you can help it; don몭t bite off more than you can chew, don몭t attack any cities, and don몭t travel along major roads, because they will be guarded by enemy troops. Send out decoy troops to confuse the enemy, and then plunge ahead with elite vanguard units, find easy targets for them, and go looting around the countryside. When the rest of your men see this, they몭ll think that you몭re winning the war! Their spirits will rise, and they won몭t be frightened anymore. At the same time, split off some of your men and use them to set ambushes. If the enemy comes, move at once and hit them where it hurts. If they don몭t come, move onward as quickly as possible; don몭t wait around. 

When making plans and coming up with tactics for fighting on facile ground, put into practice three art of war philosophies that we몭ve already learned about: 1) Manage energy; pay attention to your men몭s psychological state, and engineer a small victory to put some wind in their sails and lend them some courage. 2) Select troops to form a vanguard unit; rank-and-file troops will be scared, so choose some who aren몭t afraid to be your spearhead. Give them the task of winning some victories, seizing some loot and drumming up your army몭s morale. 3) Use the art of division 멪 몬Use the regular to engage the enemy, and the irregular to defeat him.몭 While your main force rapidly makes its way forward, your vanguard wins some cheap victories by picking easy targets, while another auxiliary force sets an ambush in coordination with your other movements as defense against an enemy attack.


How to fight battles in the 몬Nine terrain types몭 (part two): The crucial thing about strength is willpower

What we see when we look at how the art of war applies to dispersive ground, facile ground and contentious ground is that everything revolves around the element of psychology. It몭s all about the two sides몭 relative mental strength, and how each side manages energy.
The crucial thing about strength is willpower.

Extract from the original text:
몮Ground the possession of which imports great advantage to either side, is contentious ground멞 On contentious ground, attack not.몯

Analysis:
3) Contentious ground:

몬Contentious ground몭 is the kind of terrain that military strategists fight to control and which offers an advantage to whoever seizes possession of it first. As to why, Cao Cao has the answer: 몮Here the few can defeat the many, and the weak can strike the strong.몯 So, if your enemy gets hold of 몬contentious ground,몭 don몭t insist on fighting him there.

Li Quan comments: 몮This is about holding dangerous terrain such as narrow passes and defiles; victory belongs to whoever holds it first; such is 몬contentious ground.몭몯 

Du Mu includes a historical case study in his comment. Before the Battle of Feishui, Fu Jian sent Lu Guang, one of his high-ranking generals, to invade the western regions. Lu Guang subdued the armed opposition he met there, and returned east with a huge consignment of treasure and other goods. However, by that point Fu Jian had already suffered a catastrophic defeat at the Battle of Feishui. After Fu Jian몭s fall, the regional generals of the Former Qin dynasty held total military power, and each one of them had his own ideas about what to do with it. When Lu Guang arrived at Yizhu (present-day Anxinan, in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region), the Former Qin governor of Liang Province, Liang Xi, wanted to seal off his region몭s roads, and refused to let Lu Guang in.

The governor of Gaochang, a man named Yang Han, said to Liang Xi: 몮Lu Guang is newly returned from his conquest of the western regions; his army is strong and he bears an acutely sharp energy. Now that he has heard of the chaos reigning in the Central Plain, he is sure to have his own designs. He holds a vast expanse of land west of the river, and his army boasts 100,000 armored warriors; he is well placed to defend himself. And if he chooses to come out from the land of sands, his momentum will be hard to oppose. There is a location at the entrance to the Gaowu River Valley, a place of narrow and dangerous terrain. We should hold it and thus deprive him of a water source, and thus he will become tired and thirsty, and we will be able to best him even without moving. If you consider the Gaowu Valley to be too far away, then we can also hold him off at Yiwu Pass. This is a location that must be contended for, because it would offer Guang a great opportunity. If he passes through these two places, even though we have Zifang몭s stratagem, we will be unable to use it.몯 

But, Liang Xi refused to take Yang Han몭s advice.

This is precisely the essence of 몬contentious ground몭 멪 the mouth of the Gaowu River Valley and Yiwu Pass were the two places containing terrain where Lu Guang could have been stopped. When Lu Guang received reports from his spies telling of Yang Han몭s plan, he was deeply concerned. But then, his advisor Du Jin told him: 몮Liang Xi has talent in spades when it comes to the gentle arts, but he lacks pragmatism. He will not listen to Yang Han. For us, the advantage lies in advancing rapidly; we must not delay. I assure you, if Liang Xi does go along with Yang Han몭s plan, I will cut off my own head and present it to you as a gift.몯

Just as Du Jin predicted, Liang Xi decided that the Gaowu River Valley and Yiwu Pass were too far away. So, he sent 50,000 men to block the road at Jiuquan. Meanwhile, Lu Guang몭s army was rapidly covering the great distance toward the eastern regions. Yang Han was the first regional leader to surrender, followed by the governors of Dunhuang and Jinchang. In the end, Lu Guang captured and beheaded Liang Xi and then established the Empire of Later Liang.

We몭ve seen that no army camp is short of wise advisors, but if the lord can몭t understand what they몭re telling him, there몭s nothing to be done. For example, in Han Xin몭s Battle of Jingxing, his opponent, Chu Yu, refused to listen when his advisor Lord Guangwu suggested blocking off Jingxing Pass. So, Han Xin defeated the Zhao army, beheaded Chu Yu and took Lord Guangwu prisoner. Han Xin treated Lord Guangwu courteously and told him that if Chu Yu had used his plan, there was no way things would have worked out the way they did. So, Lord Guangwu switched sides and began to work for Han Xin. The same thing happened with Yang Han 멪 when he saw that his superior wasn몭t going to listen to him or use his plan, he knew that it was over. He was the first to surrender when Lu Guang몭s army arrived.

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮What should be done if the enemy arrives first, occupies the advantageous terrain, drills his soldiers there, and is able to either come out or hold his position in order to prevent me from effectively using auxiliary forces?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮As regards the methods to be used in contentious ground, the advantage belongs to whoever seizes it first. If the enemy holds contentious ground, be cautious and do not attack. Draw him out and feign retreat; plant flags and sound your drums, attract his attention using things that are precious to him, drag firewood about to raise up dust clouds, confuse his ears and eyes, and select your best soldiers and secretly set an ambush. The enemy is bound to come out; go to the places towards which he harbors desire and take that which he discards. This is the art of contentious ground. If you arrive first and the enemy seeks to use this strategy against you, then select your best soldiers and form a light unit to pursue him; meanwhile, hold your original position and establish ambushes in locations with dangerous terrain. Then, if the enemy returns to fight, your ambush unit will leap forth from the flanks. This is the way to total victory.몯

Here, Sun Tzu clearly explains how to deal with this situation, from the position of both the attacker and the defender. 

His principles of fighting on contentious ground were put into practice by Li Shimin 멪 who eventually became Emperor Taizong of Tang 멪 when he defeated Dou Jiande at the Battle of Hulao Pass.

Amidst the pandemonium of the final years of the Sui dynasty, strongmen all over China were running around chasing power. Wang Shichong had occupied the ancient capital of Luoyang and proclaimed himself Emperor of the state of Zheng. Meanwhile, north of the Yellow River, Dou Jiande had proclaimed himself Emperor of the state of Xia. Li Shimin, at the head of over 30,000 Tang troops, surrounded Wang Shichong몭s Luoyang, and the two sides engaged in vicious combat for eight months. Wang Shichong was relentless, and the conflict left both sides utterly exhausted. It was then that Dou Jiande began to march with a massive army of 100,000 men to rescue Wang Shichong. Dou Jiande was a capable and battle-hardened warrior 멪 even if Li Shimin pulled back and tried to re-gather his forces for another attempt, nobody could blame him. On the other hand, if he left he몭d be wasting all the hard work that had so nearly brought Luoyang within his grasp. Also, if Zheng and Xia joined forces, they몭d be able to take the fight deep inside his own territory.  And yet, Li Shimin saw a chance to wipe out his two formidable opponents in one fell swoop. It would rely on using an area he몭d identified as contentious ground: Hulao Pass.

So, Li Shimin left Li Yuanji in command of the siege of Luoyang, while he led a tiny force of 3,500 cavalry on an all-day and all-night journey straight to Hulao Pass. He made it there just before Dou Jiande. By the time he finished setting up his position, Dou Jiande몭s forces were only 30 li away.

The next day, Li Shimin sprang a small-scale ambush on the Xia army and succeeded in blunting his enemy몭s momentum. He led 500 cavalry soldiers out of the pass and ordered two officers, Qin Shubao and Cheng Yaojin, to lay an ambush. Meanwhile, he and another officer, Yuchi Jingde, went with only four soldiers to the Xia camp to provoke them. They lured several thousand enemy cavalry straight into an ambush, crushing the Xia force and capturing two of its senior generals.

As we몭ve already mentioned in the sections on 몬dispersive몭 and 몬facile몭 ground, even though on the face of it we몭re talking about terrain, it몭s actually all about psychological warfare, or 몬managing energy.몭 You need to manage your own army몭s energy, but you also need to manage the enemy army몭s energy. Dou Jiande몭s army was massive 멪 100,000 men 멪 and it was bearing down with the momentum of an avalanche. By comparison, Li Shimin몭s 30,000-strong Tang army was tiny; it would be difficult for his men not to be deeply nervous about their chances of victory. But, Li Shimin didn몭t delay for a second. Before the enemy could establish themselves, he swiftly went to the front lines in person, and scored a victory. This boosted his men몭s morale while shaking that of his enemies.

And that몭s how Li Shimin held Dou Jiande off. Hulao Pass is a place that can be held by a single warrior against 10,000, and Li Shimin stalled his enemies there for over a month. Occasionally, he would send out a fast-moving force to pick off some of the enemy, and the Xia army was powerless to breach the pass.

Li Shimin몭s spies fanned out over the land, enabling him to seize opportunities. He also sent a 1,000-strong cavalry force to disrupt the Xia supply route, and in the process they stole all of the Xia grain wagons. Once that happened, the Xia army몭s situation took a sharp turn for the worse and their morale sank ever lower.

After tormenting his enemy for over a month, Li Shimin decided that he몭d done his job. As a smokescreen, he let it be known that the Tang army was going to put its horses out to graze, meaning that his cavalry would be without the use of their mounts. Dou Jiande mobilized his entire army, hoping to use this opportunity to deal with Li Shimin once and for all. At dawn, the Xia army was lined up, but noon came and went and still there was no sign of a battle starting. The soldiers were hungry and tired. Meanwhile, Li Shimin had re-gathered his war horses and launched a sudden, all-out strike. His 3,500 cavalry troops shattered the 100,000-strong Xia army몭s lines, and on that day he captured Dou Jiande himself. He put Dou Jiande in a cage on wheels and took him to the foot of the Luoyang city walls, where he shouted for Wang Shichong to come and look: 몮Your reinforcements are here!몯 When Wang Shichong saw this, he suffered a total breakdown. He came out from behind his city walls and offered his surrender.

Li Shimin asked Dou Jiande: 몮What business was it of yours that I was fighting with Wang Shichong? What made you come running from so far away just to skewer yourself on my sword?몯

Dou Jiande tried to ingratiate himself: 몮I just didn몭t want you to go to the bother of coming all the way to get me, so I delivered myself to you instead.몯 Clearly, his energy was utterly depleted 멪 how could a war hero, a man who called himself Emperor, speak in such a way?

So, what we see when we look at how the art of war applies to dispersive ground, facile ground and contentious ground is that everything revolves around the element of psychology. It몭s all about the two sides몭 relative mental strength, and how each side manages energy.

The crucial thing about strength is willpower.

How to wage war in the 몬Nine terrain types몭 (part three): Ally with 몬third parties몭

Extract from the original text:
몮Ground on which each side has liberty of movement is open ground. (멞 on open ground, do not allow severance.) Ground that forms the key to three contiguous states, so that he who occupies it first has the world at his command, is a ground of intersecting highways. (멞 on the ground of intersecting highways, join hands with your allies.) When an army has penetrated into the heart of a hostile country, leaving a number of fortified cities in its rear, it is serious ground. (멞 on serious ground, gather in plunder.)몯

Analysis:
4) Open ground:

몮Ground on which each side has liberty of movement is open ground.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮This is where roads intersect.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮Rivers are wide and the ground is level, such that one may come or go at will; it provides adequate conditions to fight a battle.몯

Du You comments: 몮Open ground is a place transected by multiple roads; it is impossible to block movement here.몯

He Shi comments: 몮Open ground is a flat, navigable plain; one may travel great distances in all four cardinal directions, and it is impossible for movement to be blocked.몯

Open ground is an area of open space, with no dangerous terrain features and roads that stretch out in all directions. Even without roads, it몭s possible to travel freely and meet no resistance. If this is a terrain type you can travel through easily, the same is true for your enemy; nobody can stand in anybody몭s way here.

So, what is the principle of waging war on open ground? Sun Tzu tells us: 몮On open ground, do not try to allow obstacles to movement.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮One몭s component parts must be joined to one another.몯 Every part of your forces needs to stay joined up, with no gaps in between. If there are gaps, it몭s easy for the enemy to split up your forces and either cut off the head of your army or surround you and prevent you from reattaching your head to your body, as it were. 

Du Mu comments: 몮Rivers are wide and the ground is level; battle may be joined from any direction, and so one must combine chariots, cavalry and infantry into a single, connected unit so as to prevent the enemy from severing the parts of your forces and for fear that the enemy will take advantage.몯

Wang Xi comments: 몮It is beneficial for grain supply routes. Ground which is expeditious for coming and going can also be referred to as 몬easily navigable ground.몭 Occupy an elevated, sunny location, and await the enemy there. You should ensure that your grain supply routes are not severed.몯

It is not a set-in-stone requirement that your army must not be separated. When Sun Tzu says 몬on open ground, do not allow severance,몭 he means that you shouldn몭t allow your forces to be cut off. He몭s not saying that you absolutely must keep all parts of your army together, with no separation at all. For example, to secure your grain supply routes, you will need to send some of your troops out to guard the roads. In order to occupy high, sunny ground, it might also be necessary to split off part of your army and set it up somewhere else, where the terrain enables you to coordinate the different parts of your army into a pincer formation. Taking the initiative to divide your army is not 몬severance.몭  Rather, it requires you to pay attention and not allow gaps to open up between your various units while on the march. You need to be able to use the different parts of your army as a coordinated whole, keep communication open, and don몭t give the enemy any openings to exploit.

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮If I desire to sever the enemy몭s forces on open ground and render him unable to move, I must order my frontier cities to prepare their defenses, I must fully sever transportation routes, and I must fortify areas of narrow terrain. But what is to be done if my planning is not timely and the enemy is already prepared, and being prepared, he is able to come to me and I am unable to move, and if our forces are evenly matched in number?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮Since you are unable to move, and since the enemy is able to come, you can take a part of your army and conceal it. Meanwhile, remain behind your defenses and take your ease, showing yourself to be incapable. When the enemy arrives, set a hidden ambush and spring it such that he is taken by surprise.몯

5) Ground of intersecting highways:

몮Ground which forms the key to three contiguous states, so that he who occupies it first has the world at his command, is a ground of intersecting highways.몯

This terrain type is quite simple to understand. 몬Ground which forms the key to three contiguous states몭 just means a place where the borders of three countries meet. It몭s a place where, as a Chinese saying puts it, 몬Roosters can be heard in three provinces.몭 The city of Quzhou, in Zhejiang Province, takes it one step further 멪  four provinces share borders there: Fujian, Zhejiang, Jiangxi and Anhui. The city of Quzhou is a transportation and distribution hub for all four provinces, making it a 몬super-intersection.몭 This is also the source of the city몭s name: the 몬Qu몭 (쾦) in[bd38] Quzhou means 몬intersection.몭 It has been dubbed 몬the four-province intersection and the source of the five roads.몭

What is the reasoning behind the next part: 몮He who occupies it first has the world at his command?몯 Here, 몬the world몭 stands for the feudal states of ancient China. The parties involved aren몭t just limited to your country and your enemy몭s; there몭s also a third country. Whoever arrives first can form an alliance with that third country and gain their assistance. Then, the war turns into two against one, increasing your odds of victory. This is why Sun Tzu writes: 몮He who occupies it first has the world at his command.몯 The strategy to use in this terrain type is to get your diplomacy right; build alliances with other countries.

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Your forces being evenly matched with the enemy몭s, and being situated where neighboring countries converge on three sides, whoever arrives first will acquire the aid of the other country.몯

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮It being vital to arrive first at ground of intersecting highways, what is to be done if I am unable to arrive first due to the distance to be travelled, and despite driving my chariots and horses forward at high speed?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮States adjoin one another, and they are connected to one another in all directions. Your forces and those of your enemy being equivalent, and if there is another neighboring country, then he who is referred to as 몬arriving first몭 must be he who first sends messengers with a heavy load of treasures to negotiate an accord with that neighboring country. Having established close ties and favor, then the peoples of the two countries are already linked, even though your army shall arrive later. Thus, you have the support of many people, while the enemy has lost the chance for an alliance; two countries poised either side of the enemy, you then attack amidst a thundering of drums, reducing the enemy to shock and terror and utterly without recourse.몯

Arriving first doesn몭t always mean that your army reaches a certain location before the enemy; it몭s about making sure your envoys get there first. With a generous haul of gifts and all the proper courtesies, you can secure an alliance before your enemy has a chance. Then, it doesn몭t matter if your army arrives after the enemy. You attack alongside your new ally, and your enemy is powerless to stop you. This is the true meaning of that line from Chapter Three, Planning Assaults: 몮Thus the highest form of generalship is to attack the enemy몭s plans; the next best is to attack the enemy몭s alliances멞몯

6) Serious ground:

Extract from the original text:

몮When an army has penetrated into the heart of a hostile country, leaving a number of fortified cities in its rear, it is serious ground멞 On serious ground, gather in plunder.몯


Analysis:

Cao Cao comments: 몮This is terrain from which it is difficult to return.몯 Serious ground is the opposite of facile ground; once you몭re deep inside serious ground, meaning deep within enemy territory, with a good number of enemy cities already behind you, it becomes very difficult to go back to your home country.

Li Quan comments: 몮These are places of firm resolve.몯 When it몭s difficult to go back the way you came, you give up on the idea of going home and stop thinking about it altogether. Your mind becomes focused, and your willpower grows steady and strong. Two examples of 몬entering deep into serious ground몭 are Bai Qi몭s invasion of the state of Chu and Yue Yi몭s invasion of the state of Qi.

What should you do if you find yourself in serious ground? 몮Gather in plunder.몯 Steal what you can; seize grain and other supplies, because you몭re already beyond the reach of resupply missions from your own country.

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮Suppose I have drawn my army deep into serious terrain and I have travelled through much enemy territory, and my grain supply routes have been severed. I desire to return to my country, but I am constrained by circumstances; what should I do that I may eat my enemy몭s food and maintain my army without suffering loss?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮Whenever you are situated in serious terrain, your soldiers are easily emboldened. If your transportation routes are impeded, then you can secure food supplies by plundering. Soldiers who acquire grain and fine goods must deliver their plunder in its entirety to their superiors; those who render the largest quantity shall be rewarded, and thus your soldiers will have no thoughts of returning home. If you truly desire to return to your country, then make defensive preparations; dig deep trenches and erect high walls to show the enemy that you intend to stay for a long time. Thus, the enemy will suspect that some other transportation route remains open to you, and so he will secretly remove his soldiers from the main roads. Then, order your light chariots to move swiftly and silently. Use your oxen and horses as bait, and if the enemy comes, sound your drums and pursue him. Having concealed your soldiers in ambush, when the enemy triggers the ambush, attack from two sides at once. If you do this, the enemy몭s defeat is certain.몯

When you몭re deep inside 몬serious몭 enemy terrain, the most important thing is that you take supplies from your enemy. However, your enemy will also be aware of this principle and might burn everything rather than leave anything for you. When Napoleon fought his way into Moscow, if the city had been full of supplies and comfortable living quarters, he could have stayed there and waited for the Tsar to surrender. But, the Russians burned Moscow down with a single torch. The French army tried to put out the fire, but they found that all of the city몭s fire-fighting equipment had been sabotaged. In the trajectory of Napoleon몭s fall, the Great Fire of Moscow was a major turning point.


How to wage war in the 몬Nine terrain types몭 (part four): Move rapidly through dangerous terrain

Extract from the original text:
몮Mountain forests, rugged steeps, marshes and fens 멪 all country that is hard to traverse: this is difficult ground. (... in difficult ground, keep steadily on the march.)몯

Analysis:
7) Difficult ground:

Jia Lin comments: 몮Passing through terrain ravaged by water 멪 this is called 몬difficult ground.몭몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about places with few solid features.몯

He Shi comments: 몮몬Difficult ground몭 refers to places with few solid features, where it is not possible to build fortified walls or dig deep moats; one should make haste to leave such places behind.몯

What몭s the right thing to do in difficult ground? 몮In difficult ground, keep steadily on the march.몯 With nothing but water-logged ground beneath you, these are places where it몭s impossible to secure yourself, and impossible to build fortifications or any other construction works. You can몭t camp there either; all you can do is make your way through this terrain as quickly as possible. Don몭t stop.

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮Suppose I have entered difficult ground, where I am faced with mountains, rivers, and all manner of dangerous and obstructive terrain, such that the road is hard to follow, my soldiers are exhausted by long days of marching, the enemy is at once ahead of me, lying in ambush behind me, encamped to my left, holding another defensive position to my right, and blocking my narrow way forward with strong horses and fast chariots. What am I to do?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮First, move your light chariots ten li ahead of your army and order them to await the enemy there, and engage the enemy in battle in a place of dangerous and obstructive terrain. At the rear, spread out your soldiers and move now to the left, now to the right; the general must keep watch in all directions and identify a weakness in the enemy position, following which all parts of the army must converge in a suitable location. Once your soldiers become exhausted, then stop.몯

Once your men are exhausted, stop attacking, secure your position and re-gather your army. This is important, because moving over difficult ground is a painstaking task and it consumes a lot of energy. It몭s necessary to conserve your men몭s strength.


How to wage war in the 몬Nine terrain types몭 (part five): To break out of an encirclement, rely on cunning

Extract from the original text:
몮Ground which is reached through narrow gorges, and from which we can only retire by tortuous paths so that a small number of the enemy would suffice to crush a large body of our men: this is hemmed-in ground. (멞 on-hemmed in ground, resort to stratagem.)몯

Analysis:
8) Hemmed-in ground:

Here, we몭re talking about being 몬hemmed in,몭 or surrounded, not by enemy forces but by terrain 멪 narrow roadways and places where the only way back is to travel long, twisting routes. If you get stuck in this kind of terrain, the enemy can beat you even with a small number of troops. This is what we mean when we talk about 몬hemmed-in ground.몭

Li Quan comments: 몮Here it is difficult to move.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮It is difficult both to enter such places and to exit them.몯

It몭s not just that these places are hard to get into; once you몭re in you can몭t get out, nor can you spread out your forces to fight.

So, what are you supposed to do? Sun Tzu몭s advice is this: 몮On hemmed-in ground, resort to stratagem.몯 In other words, you have to work it out yourself!

Clearly, there really isn몭t much you can do. Unless you come up with some clever plan, you몭ll never be able to get out.

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮Suppose I have entered into hemmed-in ground; before me the enemy awaits in strength and behind me I am backed against dangerous terrain; the enemy has severed my grain supply routes, is enticing me to retreat, and is sounding war drums, yet without advancing, to watch what my response will be. What should I do?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮This is what should be done in hemmed-in ground: you must obstruct access to your location and make it seem as though you plan to stay there; then you ought to treat your army like your family, and make the hearts of your men of one accord. Then, cook food enough for several days; in the following days, the enemy will believe we are weak and in tumult, because they will see no smoke where are cooking fires should be. Believing this, the enemy is sure to slacken their preparedness; then, fan the flames of your soldier몭s passions, rouse their fury, send forward a unit of your strongest men, and making use of the treacherous terrain to left and right, charge at the enemy to the beat of war drums. If the enemy tries to stop you, attack with rapid fury and you will be sure to break through the encirclement. Then, while your forward troops give battle, their gains shall be expanded upon by your rear troops, with left and right units working in unison, pinching the enemy between them.몯

First, make sure the enemy can몭t attack your position, and make it look like you have no intention of trying to smash your way out. Show everyone, your enemy and your own men, that you몭re determined and that you won몭t back down. This will make your troops 몬feel at home,몭 as it were. It will encourage them to think of the army as their family, and to think with one mind. Then, you can guard against the enemy with peace of mind. Cook all the food you몭ll need for several days in one go, and then don몭t cook for the next few days 멪 this will make the enemy think you have nothing to eat.

Make it look like you몭re in bad shape. As a reference point, look at this passage from Chapter Nine, in The Army on the March: 몮When the soldiers stand leaning on their spears, they are faint from want of food. If those who are sent to draw water begin by drinking themselves, the army is suffering from thirst멞 If the banners and flags are shifted about, sedition is afoot. If the officers are angry, it means that the men are weary. The sight of men whispering earnestly without ceasing or speaking in subdued tones points to disaffection amongst the rank and file멞몯 You can act out all of these  diversionary tactics and put on a nice show for the enemy scouts.

The enemy will believe you몭re on your last legs, and that the fruits of victory will soon be theirs. They몭ll relax and let down their guard. This is the moment for you to call your whole army before you and prepare them to fight a decisive battle. Whip them up into a state of excitement and fury, and send out your best soldiers to charge the enemy in a sudden burst, all the while making use of the tricky terrain. If the enemy puts up a fight, move in hard and attack 멪 they won몭t be able to stop you from breaking through. While your vanguard fights at the front lines, your rear units will capitalize on the vanguard몭s gains. With your entire army mobilized and working in close coordination, you can quickly take down the enemy.

The King of Wu had another question for Sun Tzu: 몮If I have hemmed in my enemy and he conceals himself so as to plot and scheme; if he entices me and orders his flag bearers to wave them here and there in imitation of chaos, such that it is impossible to know in which direction he will move, what should I do?몯

This is just the opposite of the first situation the king asked about.

Sun Tzu said: 몮Send forth a thousand men waving flags. Meanwhile, block off the main transport route using a separate detachment of soldiers, and send a mobile unit towards the enemy to provoke him. Reserve the bulk of your army and maintain formation; do not engage them in fighting and keep them steady. Do not retreat. This is the way to thwart the enemy몭s plans.몯

Keep your main force in position and steady. Don몭t charge after the enemy, and don몭t retreat. Keep doing this, and watch what the enemy is trying to do; then you can work out what his plan is.


Staying alive in 몬desperate ground몭 멨 Nine times in ten, you몭re dead

What you need to learn is how to stay away from 몬desperate ground.몭 Once you몭re in such a place, you can몭t chase after life; you have to chase after certain death. But, you might be able to stay alive if you go just far enough into the jaws of death, and manage to find a few sacrificial lambs to offer up to annihilation.
High stakes risk-taking is not something to draw lessons from. If you몭re forced into it, you몭ll find out how strong your life force really is. That몭s all. 

Extract from the original text:
몮Ground on which we can only be saved from destruction by fighting without delay, is desperate ground. (멞 on desperate ground, fight.)몯

Analysis:
9) Desperate ground:

What몭s the difference between 몬difficult ground몭 and 몬desperate ground?몭 On 몬difficult ground,몭 you can wait, but there몭s no waiting on 몬desperate ground.몭 So, what can you do? 몮On desperate ground, fight.몯 Fight immediately, because if you fight quickly you may live, but if you몭re not quick you몭re going to die.몯

This is a vitally important point to make because, in most situations, waiting is in fact a viable option. But, if the leader thinks  they can몭t wait, and that fighting at speed might save them 멪 and not doing so will lead to death 멪 they end up walking into their own death for no good reason.

In[bd39][TT40] reality, it몭s not guaranteed that fighting quickly when you몭re on desperate ground is a foolproof way to survive. If it was, it wouldn몭t be called 몬desperate ground몭 in the first place; it몭d be called 몬be-quick-and-you몭ll-live ground.몭 In 몬desperate ground몭 the outcome is practically guaranteed to be death. There몭s no hope of survival. That몭s why you shouldn몭t chase after life. However, you might be able to stay alive if you go just far enough into death, and if you manage to find a few sacrificial lambs to offer up their lives! In other words, it몭s time to fight as though you몭re already dead. When an army does this, they become possessed of a power terrible to behold.
And what do our commentators have to say about 몬desperate ground?몭
