Cao Cao comments: 몮High mountains ahead, great bodies of water behind; the road ahead is fruitless, the road behind is obstructed.몯

Li Quan comments: 몮Blocked by mountains, backing onto water, food has run out. In this situation, speed is beneficial, slowness is not.몯

Duke Li of Wei offers a more complete commentary: 몮Perhaps one has advanced with one몭s forces and, lacking a guide, plunges into danger and defeat and becomes constrained by the enemy. With a chasm to the left and cliffs to the right, one travels a road where horses must be led by hand and cart wheels hang into the void on one side; the way is blocked ahead and behind, rocks and cliffs over which one passes like a column of wild geese or fish on a line. One몭s battle lines are disorganized; if the enemy comes at speed and in strength, there is no solid ground for one to advance or retreat upon. One cannot fight even if one desires to, and there is no safety in guarding one몭s position. The days will be long if one stays still, and if one moves, then the enemy will be waiting in any direction one may choose. In this wilderness there is no drinking water or grass, the army lacks grain and supplies, the horses are weary and the men exhausted, one몭s resourcefulness is depleted and one몭s strength has reached its limits. When one man guards a narrow defile, ten thousand men cannot pass through. If the enemy has occupied such a location, then he possesses so great an advantage that one has already lost. Though one may have talented soldiers and sharp weapons, how can they be put to use? In 몬desperate ground몭 such as this, one may survive by fighting quickly; if one fails to fight quickly, death awaits. One must unify the hearts and minds of the various ranks within one몭s army so that they become a single force, pull out one몭s intestines and splash one몭s blood, charge forward toward death, glory in defeat, and transform disaster into a great good fortune.몯

Duke Li몭s discourse on 몬desperate ground몭 can be divided into commentaries about seven distinct situations:

1) 몮Perhaps one has advanced with one몭s forces and, lacking a guide, plunges into danger and defeat and becomes constrained by the enemy.몯

You didn몭t bother finding a local person to guide you as you moved your army forward. You plunged blindly ahead, got lost, and found yourself in a deep hole, in danger and at the mercy of the enemy. 
 
So, the main point to learn when studying 몬desperate ground몭 isn몭t how to fight in this kind of terrain, but how to avoid being forced into such a desperate situation in the first place. The first point Duke Li makes is the vital importance of studying the maps and being totally clear about the lay of the land. Also, you absolutely must use a guide while on the march, because this is the only way to avoid trapping yourself in 몬desperate ground.몭 Throughout Chinese history, renowned generals have always memorized maps inside out, and made a point of studying maps whenever they had a spare moment. When Liu Bang came through the mountain pass as a conqueror into the land of Qin, he didn몭t steal the beautiful women or the riches of Qin. Instead, his strategist Xiao He headed straight for the Qin archive library and gathered up all the maps he found there. The People몭s Liberation Army commanders Lin Biao and Su Yu used to sit in daylong trances before tables-full of maps, whether or not they were at war at the time. In their minds, great armies were constantly maneuvering back and forth across those maps.

2) 몮With a chasm to the left and cliffs to the right, one travels a road where horses must be led by hand and cart wheels hang into the void on one side.몯

The enemy doesn몭t even need to attack at this point. All they have to do is crowd you, and your whole army will plunge into the void.

3) 몮The way is blocked ahead and behind, rocks and cliffs over which one passes like a column of wild geese or fish on a line.몯

There몭s no road open to you either ahead or behind. All you can do is move single-file along the edge of steep cliffs.

4) 몮One몭s battle lines are disorganized; if the enemy comes at speed and in strength, there is no solid ground for one to advance or retreat upon.몯

You몭ve only just arrived at the battlefield, you haven몭t had a chance to organize your battle lines, you haven몭t built any defensive structures, you haven몭t had time to form up your soldiers, and already the enemy is charging towards you. If you advance to meet them, your army will be uncoordinated and unable to muster any kind of striking force; if you retreat, there몭s nowhere for you to shelter, and your army will disintegrate.

What to do in this situation? This has already been covered in an earlier section of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: victory belongs to whoever arrives first. The key is to be there waiting for the enemy. In this situation, your enemy is well prepared, while you몭ve showed up in total disarray and are completely unable to organize yourself. So, the battle is basically lost already, and there몭s nothing you can do except get ready for a messy scrap 멪 find out what your men are made of, and see whether their training has equipped them to fight, kill, and somehow carve out the slenderest hope of survival from the chaos.

If you get out alive, remember the next time to get to the battlefield first and be properly prepared. If the enemy gets there before you, don몭t go. Set up camp 30-50 li away, form up your battle lines and coax the enemy to you. Then, the enemy will be the one whose 몬battle lines are disorganized,몭 and they몭ll have 몬no solid ground for one to advance or retreat upon if the enemy comes at speed and in strength.몭 This is exactly how General Zhao She defeated the Qin army: he set up a defensive position 50 li away from the enemy camp and lured the enemy to him, compelling them to march the extra 50 li and tire themselves out.

5) 몮One cannot fight even if one desires to, and there is no safety in guarding one몭s position. The days will be long if one stays still, and if one moves then the enemy will be waiting in any direction one may choose.몯

Even if you try to make a fight happen, you won몭t be able to reach the enemy. And, if you try to stay put and defend, you몭ll find no terrain features to secure your position. If you hunker down, the days will drag past slowly and your situation won몭t get any better. If you try to take action, you몭ll be hemmed in by the enemy in both directions, and you몭ll be completely unable to move.

6) 몮In this wilderness there is no drinking water or grass, the army lacks grain and supplies, the horses are weary and the men exhausted, one몭s resourcefulness is depleted and one몭s strength has reached its limits.몯

Suppose you몭re in the Gobi Desert, and there몭s no water for your men and no grass for your horses. Your army has no food and everyone몭s exhausted, men and horses both. Your men몭s strength is being pushed to its limits, there몭s no way out, and no actionable plan.

7) 몮When one man guards a narrow defile, ten thousand men cannot pass through. If the enemy has occupied such a location, then he possesses so great an advantage that one has already lost. Though one may have talented soldiers and sharp weapons, how can they be put to use?몯

If your enemy holds a position where one man could hold off 10,000, the rope is already around your neck. No matter how strong your men are or how sharp your weapons, you won몭t be able to put them to use.

In any of these seven situations, if you attack quickly, survival is a possibility. If you don몭t, you몭ll die. You need to make everyone in your army, officers and rank-and-file soldiers alike, into a single mind. They need to be ready and willing to spill their own blood and march to their death; they need to find glory in their predicament and find something good in a hopeless situation.

The King of Wu once asked Sun Tzu: 몮Suppose my army has departed the borders of my country and travelled into enemy lands. The enemy has arrived in force and encircled me in many rings around. I wish to break through the encirclement, but I face an impregnable barrier in all directions. I desire to encourage my soldiers and rouse their spirits so that they are willing to forfeit their lives and break the enemy encirclement. How can I do this?몯

Sun Tzu replied: 몮Dig deep trenches and build high walls, creating the impression that you intend to take a defensive bearing. Remain calmly in place and do not move, thus concealing your capabilities. Inform your soldiers that the situation is desperate, that there is but one option before you. Slaughter your oxen and burn your carts, so as to provide a feast for your men. Burn your grain, fill in your wells, level your cooking ranges, cut your hair and cast aside your hats, thus severing yourself from care about whether you live. The men will see that their general has no other plan, and so they will steel themselves to death. Then, don armor and take up your swords and mould your army into a single force. Attack both of the enemy flanks amid the clamor and thunder of war drums; the enemy will be scared and will not know what they should do. Divide your best soldiers among the ranks and launch a fierce attack to the enemy몭s rear. This is how to abandon morality and seek life. Thus, it is said, 몬He who is in a desperate plight and yet does not make a plan is lost; he who is lost and yet does not fight is dead.몭몯

There are many rituals described here, all designed to unleash your men몭s inner fury and savagery. Once you몭ve whipped your men up and mentally prepared them for certain death, then is the time to charge the enemy.

If you find yourself in 몬desperate ground,몭 you몭re going to die nine times out of ten. When the odds of survival are so low, there몭s nothing to be learned from this situation. What you need to learn is how to stay away from 몬desperate ground.몭 Once you몭re in 몬desperate ground,몭 you can몭t chase after life; you have to chase after certain death. But, you might be able to stay alive if you go just far enough into death몭s door and if you manage to find a few sacrificial lambs to offer up. In the South Korean film, The Battle of Myeongyang, the Korean troops and officers were terrified by the power of the invading Japanese army, and one after another they came before the commander-in-chief, Yi Sun-sin, and asked him what they were going to do. Li Sun-sin몭s reply was brief: 몮Are you telling me you still want to live? Tomorrow we shall all go to our deaths!몯 Surviving when you몭re in desperate ground isn몭t about learning how to survive; it몭s about learning how to accept death!
High stakes risk-taking is not something to draw lessons from 멪 if you몭re forced into it, you몭ll find out how strong your life force really is. That몭s all. Don몭t, whatever you do, try to copy what Han Xin did, leading his men to the edge of a river and forming up for battle with their backs to the deep water. As you몭ll recall, that was only part of the story; he also had 2,000 men waiting behind, ready to help out. He was never really in 몬desperate ground,몭 he only made it look like he was. It was a fake. If those 10,000 men backed up against the river really had been his whole army 멪 if he had no other forces to call upon, and yet those 10,000 somehow managed to survive 멪 only then could you say that he had gone into desperate ground and come out on the other side alive!
People are fond of exaggerating and adding flavor to details. That몭s what gives stories their dramatic tension, and everyone likes a bit of drama, including those who write the official histories, which also contain a good amount of seasoning. But facts are as cold as ice. So, when we read history, we mustn몭t fall into the traps that our innate fondness for drama sets out for us; we must not think that you can reenact the battles we read about, move for move. You몭ll find that if you try this, the script that reality plays from isn몭t what you imagined.
This is the real script: everyone who goes into 몬desperate ground몭 dies. That몭s why it몭s called 몬desperate ground.몭

The King of Wu asked Sun Tzu: 몮If I have surrounded the enemy, what should I do?몯
Sun Tzu replied: 몮Where the cliffs are steep and the ravine is perilous, such that the terrain is impassible, then it may be said that the enemy is cornered. This is how to strike: conceal soldiers in ambush, open a way for the enemy to exit his confinement; show him a way out. As he flees for his life, he will have no appetite for battle, and thus you can attack. Even if his soldiers are numerous, your victory is certain.몯
According to The Art of War: 몮If the enemy is in desperate ground, his soldiers will be filled with courage. The way to attack such an enemy is to use smoothness, and not to pit strength against strength. You may gain advantage by secretly establishing a secure position. Then, you must open a path for the enemy while blocking the road in various places with elite cavalry soldiers in various positions. Send fast soldiers to draw him out, form up as if to fight, but do not engage. This is the way to scheme the enemy몭s defeat.몯
Don몭t keep the enemy totally surrounded. It몭s necessary to give him an escape route; you have to make him run. If the enemy몭s men think they might live, they won몭t want to die and their will to fight will weaken. Their minds will be filled with thoughts of escaping death. Set up ambushes along the road, manned by your best troops, and each time the enemy triggers an ambush, you can eat away at his forces. Then, chase down the remainder. This is not only a way to guarantee total victory, it also guarantees that your army won몭t suffer any losses.
Suppose you have surrounded 1,000 enemy soldiers. If you keep up a watertight encirclement, you can be sure of killing every single enemy soldier, but at a cost of perhaps 800 of your own men, because the enemy will be fighting like cornered animals. But, if you give them an escape route and stage your attacks at various points along the road, although 20 enemy soldiers might get away, you can limit your own casualties to ten soldiers or less.


The artistry of commanding an army as battle breaks Out 멨 First and foremost, harass the enemy

Extract from the original text:
몮Those who were called skillful leaders of old knew how to drive a wedge between the enemy몭s front and rear; to prevent cooperation between his large and small divisions; to hinder the good troops from rescuing the bad, the officers from rallying their men. When the enemy troops were scattered, they prevented them from assembling, and when the enemy몭s men were pressed together, they prevented them from uniting. When it was to their advantage, they made a forward move; when otherwise, they stopped still. If asked how to cope with a great host of the enemy in orderly array and on the point of marching to the attack, I should say: Begin by seizing something which your opponent holds dear; then he will be amenable to your will.몯

Analysis:
The most effective battle commanders of ancient China all kept these skills in their arsenal. They knew how to 몮Drive a wedge between the enemy몭s front and rear멞몯
The best generals had the ability to separate the front and rear parts of the enemy army and stop them from helping each other or coordinating.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Establish an ambush, then charge and slaughter.몯 Set up an auxiliary force in an ambush position and use them to charge the enemy, scattering their troops and breaking up the links between different parts of their army.

몮Prevent cooperation between his large and small divisions멞몯
Prevent the enemy몭s main force and their smaller forces from backing each other up. Mei Yaochen comments: 몮This is about harassing the enemy.몯

몮Hinder the good troops from rescuing the bad, the officers from rallying their men.몯
This is about stopping the enemy몭s officers and rank-and-file from helping each other; it몭s a way of sowing confusion in the ranks, spreading panic and breaking down the enemy몭s organizational structures.

몮When the enemy troops were scattered, they prevented them from assembling, and when the enemy몭s men were pressed together, they prevented them from uniting.몯

Keep the enemy soldiers scattered. If they are already gathered together, make it impossible for them to form up in an orderly formation.

Du Mu comments: 몮Employ varied and numerous deceits to harass the enemy; you may charge his front lines and slaughter his rear units, or launch a surprise attack in the east before striking from the west, or array your soldiers in a false formation, or unveil an irregular formation. If I join battle with my soldiers in shapeless formation, the enemy must make preparations to counter all possibilities, and so the great host of his army becomes divided. I fill his thoughts with fear and disperse his forces; his officers and soldiers are panicked and harassed so that they are unable to unite in an orderly fashion. This is the way skillful generals conduct battles.몯
An army is only an army if it몭s organized. Without organizational structures, even if you have a million men, your army might as well be a massive flock of lambs awaiting slaughter. The artistry of directing the flow of a battle is all about disrupting the enemy몭s organization. Any time in history when a small army has defeated a large one, it몭s always been because the leaders of the larger army either lacked the ability to organize their men, or their chain of command broke down.

몮When it was to their advantage, they made a forward move; when otherwise, they stopped still.몯

If you can manufacture a situation that favors your army, take action; if you can몭t, don몭t move.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Use violence to scatter them, use chaos to make them unable to organize themselves, then mobilize and engage.몯
Li Quan comments: 몮Harass them until an opportunity becomes apparent, then take action. If they do not move, then be still.몯

몮If asked how to cope with a great host of the enemy in orderly array and on the point of marching to the attack, I should say: Begin by seizing something which your opponent holds dear; then he will be amenable to your will.몯

The first item on the agenda when you몭re trying to control the course of a battle is to harass and disrupt the enemy. But, if they keep their shape, and if they have more soldiers than you and begin advancing toward you in neat formation, what should you do?
Seize something the enemy holds dear. Cao Cao comments: 몮First, seize an advantage upon which he relies. If I arrive first upon favourable ground and occupy it, then I am sure to gain what I desire.몯

Cao Cao is saying that 몬what the enemy holds dear몭 is the favourable conditions he몭s counting on to win. If you hold the best ground, you몭ve seized the initiative.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮That which the enemy holds dear is territory and food; if I seize these things first, then circumstances will in no way proceed counter to my plans.몯
If you hold the territory and the food supplies, the enemy will dissolve in panic and chaos; they몭ll be completely unable to muster the courage and energy to take the fight to you.
In the case of Li Shimin defeating Dou Jiande, which we learned about earlier, 3,500 men under Li Shimin took possession of Hulao Pass and successfully kept out Dou Jiande몭s 100,000-strong army. Then, Li found a way to wipe out Dou Jiande몭s grain supply units and steal all his food. Once that had happened, it was only natural that Dou Jiande lost.


It takes years to raise an army, but only a moment to use it

Extract from the original text:
몮Rapidity is the essence of war: take advantage of the enemy몭s unreadiness, make your way by unexpected routes, and attack unguarded spots. The following are the principles to be observed by an invading force: The further you penetrate into a country, the greater will be the solidarity of your troops, and thus the defenders will not prevail against you. Make forays in fertile country in order to supply your army with food. Carefully study the well-being of your men, and do not overtax them. Concentrate your energy and hoard your strength. Keep your army continually on the move, and devise unfathomable plans. Throw your soldiers into positions whence there is no escape, and they will prefer death to flight. If they will face death, there is nothing they may not achieve. Officers and men alike will put forth their utmost strength. Soldiers when in desperate straits lose the sense of fear. If there is no place of refuge, they will stand firm. If they are in hostile country, they will show a stubborn front. If there is no help for it, they will fight hard. Thus, without waiting to be marshaled, the soldiers will be constantly on the alert; without waiting to be asked, they will do your will; without restrictions, they will be faithful; without giving orders, they can be trusted. Prohibit the taking of omens, and do away with superstitious doubts. Then, until death itself comes, no calamity need be feared. If our soldiers are not overburdened with money, it is not because they have a distaste for riches; if their lives are not unduly long, it is not because they are disinclined to longevity. On the day they are ordered out to battle, your soldiers may weep, those sitting up bedewing their garments, and those lying down letting the tears run down their cheeks. But let them once be brought to bay, and they will display the courage of a Chu or a Gui.몯

Analysis:
몮The following are the principles to be observed by an invading force: The further you penetrate into a country, the greater will be the solidarity of your troops, and thus the defenders will not prevail against you.몯

Having penetrated into enemy territory, you are already deep in 몬serious ground.몭 At this point, your soldiers won몭t even think about running away. Their minds will be focused, and they will fight with everything they have.
The reason why the enemy can몭t beat you is that while you몭re in 몬serious ground,몭 and the enemy is in 몬dispersive ground.몭 As we몭ve already said, dispersive ground is no place to fight. So, the enemy몭s will to fight won몭t be as strong as yours.
Du Mu comments: 몮This passage comments on the art of attacking in general. If you have entered deep within enemy lands, your soldiers will have the conviction to die and their minds will be focused. The defending enemy will be unable to defeat you.몯

몮Make forays in fertile country in order to supply your army with food.몯

This aligns with passages from earlier in the text: 몮On serious ground, gather in plunder멞 procure your food from the enemy.몯 If you do this, all your men and horses will stay well fed.

몮Carefully study the well-being of your men, and do not overtax them. Concentrate your energy and hoard your strength. Keep your army continually on the move, and devise unfathomable plans.몯

Make sure to keep your soldiers well rested and fit. Keep their energy sharp and their strength focused. Use deception and schemes whenever you move your army, so that the enemy can몭t work out what you몭re doing.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Nurture your soldiers and keep your army몭s energy unified. When you move your army, plan it in such a way as to be inscrutable to the enemy.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮This is about what to do when one plunges deep into enemy territory. One must plunder the countryside to keep one몭s army sufficiently supplied with food. Then, enclose oneself behind walls and nurture one몭s army. Do not exhaust them with labor, but maintain their full strength and energy so that one may obtain victory immediately upon taking action. When one moves, use variety so that the enemy is unable to take one몭s measure.몯
When Wang Jian destroyed the state of Chu, he did it by using this exact approach.
He set out with 600,000 Qin soldiers on a mission to annihilate Chu. When he arrived, he set up camp, built fortifications and dug moats, and then concentrated on looking after his men and keeping them sharp. Day after day, all he did was organize athletic competitions, getting his troops to compete at games such as rock throwing. When the Chu forces tried to provoke Wang into fighting, he just stayed secure behind his defenses and refused to come out. The massive size of the Qin army scared the Chu leaders out of trying to attack them in their camp. Time went by, and eventually a year passed without any change in the situation. The Chu soldiers were tired and stiff after a year of waiting and being constantly on alert. So, they began to roam the area to get some exercise, and as soon as they moved from their position, Wang Jian pounced, ending the war in a single, bloody battle. Afterwards, the state of Chu ceased to exist.

몮Nurture your soldiers and keep your army몭s energy unified.몯 There몭s actually a huge amount of information contained in this brief line of commentary by Cao Cao. When people look at wars, they always concentrate on the actual fighting. And yet, the fighting is only one part of war, and as we몭ve said again ad again, it몭s not the most important part. Sun Tzu said: 몮Win first, fight later.몯 By the time fighting starts, it몭s only happening because victory has already been sealed. It몭s a case of 몬beating them and then fighting,몭 not 몬beating them by fighting them.몭 The secret of warfare lies in what conditions you need to meet, and what conditions you need to identify in the enemy, that give you the signal to launch your attack.
When Zeng Guofan was in charge of the Hunan army, he didn몭t have many clever stratagems or tricks. What he did have was a steady, grounded attitude. This gave him staying power. He always consolidated his advantages. In his diary, the things he paid attention to during drawn-out stays in camp while besieging enemy towns were details like whether there was enough meat and whether there were any vegetables. Eventually, he decreed that every time his army set up a new camp, they must plant crops and breed pigs. This way, he몭d have fresh vegetables and meat; he몭d be living right, and his men would have some physical work to keep them fit and their energy sharp.
There몭s a saying: 몬It takes years to raise an army, but only a moment to use it.몭 Normally, this phrase is used to remind soldiers that the state is looking after them, so when the time comes to take to the battlefield, they몭d better repay their debt to the motherland. But, this isn몭t what the phrase originally meant. It comes from the ancient text, The History of the Southern Dynasties, in a chapter entitled, A Biography of Chen Xuan: 몮One may keep an army for a thousand days without using it, but one may not keep an army for a single day without being properly prepared.몯
There are three layers of meaning in these words. First, it몭s possible to keep an army for years. If you carefully look after your men and don몭t work them too hard, you can build up their strength and mould their energy into a single force, and you can maintain it without ever using it. But, the moment you do use it, it evaporates.
Second, you use an army for only a very short period of time. So, it몭s important to wait until the crucial moment, when the enemy is unprepared, caught off-guard, and not expecting you. Then, fling your army from your hand and strike like lightning; only if you do this can you guarantee victory. It몭s like when two people are in a knife fight 멪 before you lunge, while the knife is in your hand and ready for use, you still have all your energy at your disposal. If you lunge, but your knife doesn몭t find your opponent몭s body, in the moment before you pull your knife back you몭ve left the door wide open for your opponent. You have no energy to call upon and you몭re in a state of almost total defenselessness. If your opponent seizes his chance, you몭re finished.
The power of a knife comes from the moment before you lunge with it. If you do lunge, it몭s imperative that you get a result. If you don몭t, your enemy will, and in all likelihood you몭ll be dead.
The third layer of meaning has already been discussed in the previous section: you have to be constantly ready to defend. You can몭t let your guard down for a single second. If you do, the enemy will serve you up on a plate.

몮Throw your soldiers into positions whence there is no escape, and they will prefer death to flight.몯

If you bring your men into a place where there몭s no way out, they몭ll naturally be mentally prepared to die in battle, and they won몭t run away. After all, there몭s nowhere to run anyway.

몮If they will face death, there is nothing they may not achieve. Officers and men alike will put forth their utmost strength.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮The soldiers being willing to die, how could they fail to be victorious?몯

몮Officers and men alike will put forth their utmost strength.몯 

Facing death, they don몭t have any choice but to fight with all their strength. Cao Cao comments: 몮In challenging terrain, their hearts are united.몯 It몭s critically important for your men to pool their strength and make their thinking as one.
There몭s a passage in the Wei Liaozi that reads: 몮When a single brigand takes up a sword and takes to hacking all around him in a market, though there are ten thousand people there, every one of them will shrink away from him, and not a single one will have the courage to fight him alone, because all ten thousand people are unworthy. One who has committed himself to death can never be compared to one who has committed himself to life.몯
The man with the sword is ready to die, but everyone else wants to live. He is a true terrorist, in the sense that everyone else is terrified of him.

몮Soldiers when in desperate straits lose the sense of fear.몯

When people find themselves in desperate peril, they accept that death is inevitable, and so they no longer fear the enemy. They are already dead, so what is there to be scared of? There몭s nothing scarier than death, is there?

몮If there is no place of refuge, they will stand firm. If they are in hostile country, they will show a stubborn front. If there is no help for it, they will fight hard.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮They are bound and trussed.몯 They몭re trapped. There몭s a Chinese saying: 몬Grasshoppers tied together on a length of string.몭 When an army comes to a dead end deep in enemy territory, it몭s as if they몭re bound together with rope 멪 they must fight like cornered animals, and they must fight as a single unit.
Du Mu comments: 몮If there is no help, then the men will all suspect that they have already entered the land of death and that survival is impossible. They will resolve to fight death with death. There being utterly no help available, each and every man will fight with all their strength.몯
몬Fight death with death몭 멪 these four words are crucial. It몭s not about fighting desperately against death in the hope of living. The moment the idea of survival occurs, it becomes much more difficult to fight against death, because you might surrender or try to run away. But, if survival isn몭t even a possibility in your mind, your mindset will be: 몬I might as well take some enemy soldiers with me, since I몭m going to die anyway.몭 This is the only way to truly keep the possibility of survival alive.

몮Thus, without waiting to be marshaled, the soldiers will be constantly on the alert; without waiting to be asked, they will do your will; without restrictions, they will be faithful; without giving orders, they can be trusted.몯

When you have an army like this, you don몭t need to keep them in line or order them around. The men will know without you telling them to stay vigilant. Without the officers making any demands of them, they몭ll be able to fight with all their strength. Without any boundaries being set or any encouragement given, they몭ll be so intimate with each other that they몭ll form the most united of fronts. When you have an army like this, you won몭t need to repeat your orders again and again, because they몭ll keep their discipline anyway.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Everyone is crammed together on the same boat.몯
This passage forms the root of a saying that has entered the Chinese language as a 몬four-character idiom몭 멪 몬Wu and Yue on the same boat.몭 During the Spring and Autumn period, the states of Wu and Yue were bitter rivals; they had been fighting for generations. One day, a group of common folk from both countries were crossing a river on the same boat. They sat there, shooting hostile looks at each other, when suddenly the weather turned bad just as the boat reached the middle of the river. Strong wind and heavy rain sprang up from nowhere, and it seemed as though the boat was about to capsize. The only thing to do was to climb the mast and unfurl the sails. Suddenly, everyone on the boat, Wu and Yue alike, moved as quickly as they could. Working together, they managed to unfurl the sail, and the day was saved. 
On stormy waters, everyone몭s in the same boat; enemies can turn into family. You don몭t need to preach the message that 몬unity is strength,몭 because circumstances force people to put it into action.

몮Prohibit the taking of omens, and do away with superstitious doubts. Then, until death itself comes, no calamity need be feared.몯

Forbid all superstitious activities and clear up your men몭s deluded doubts. Do this, and they will fight to the death and never run away.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Forbidding all talk of omens and sorcery is the stratagem for dispelling doubt.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮Lord Huang Shi said: 몬Forbid fortune-telling and wish-making in order that your officers and soldiers do not divine the fortunes, good or ill, of your army. Fear disturbs the mentality of soldiers.몭 Lord Huang meant that if one dispels doubt, then one몭s soldiers will fight unto death without being distracted by other thoughts.몯 
Of course, there are examples in which the opposite happened 멪 when generals cast themselves in the role of gods or wizards and prophesied that the army would enjoy great good fortune, all in an effort to spur on their men to fight bravely. That몭s exactly what General Tian Dan did while defending the city of Jimo. He had one of his men dress up as an immortal and then brought him out and treated him like a deity, with all the respect and ceremony that몭s proper when dealing with divine beings. He waited hand and foot upon the man, and every time he gave an order, he would always say that it was the will of the immortal.

몮If our soldiers are not overburdened with money, it is not because they have a distaste for riches; if their lives are not unduly long, it is not because they are disinclined to longevity.몯

The reason 몬our soldiers are not overburdened with money몭 is because they have to choose between money and their lives. They don몭t fear death, either, but that몭s not because they don몭t want to live to 몬a good old age.몭 Rather, it몭s because if they don몭t fight without fear of dying, they have no chance of surviving the war.
Cao Cao comments: 몮If they all burn their riches, it is not that they loathe being overburdened with them; they abandon their riches and draw close to death because there is no other choice.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮If they have wealth, then sadly the soldiers will feel attached to it and the idea will occur to them that they ought to cling to life. They might not have the conviction to meet with death.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Wealth and long life are things that people hold dear. So, when people burn and discard riches and cut themselves free from the prospect of long life, it is not because these things are loathsome to them, but that they have no choice.몯

몮On the day they are ordered out to battle, your soldiers may weep, those sitting up bedewing their garments, and those lying down letting the tears run down their cheeks. But let them once be brought to bay, and they will display the courage of a Zhu or a Gui.몯

In war, it몭s generally true that when you give marching orders, there are men who will weep. But, if you put them in a place where there몭s nowhere to go except forward, each and every one of them will become as brave as the legendary heroes Zhu Zhuan and Cao Gui.
Just how brave was Zhu Zhuan? When Duke Guang of Wu (who later became King Helu of Wu) ordered him to assassinate King Liao of Wu, he accepted the mission. Duke Guang invited King Liao to his house to eat with him. Zhu Zhuan brought dishes to the table, among which was a whole cooked fish with a dagger concealed in its belly. When Zhu Zhuan pulled out the dagger and leapt toward King Liao, he was immediately impaled from behind by a spear wielded by the king몭s bodyguard. And yet, with his last breath he managed to stab the king, and the blow was fatal.
What about Cao Gui? What made him brave? He was a senior official in the state of Lu, and in a previous chapter we discussed his role in the Battle of Changshao. It was he who came up with 몬The strategy of three rounds of drumming.몭 Recall that the first round of drumming builds up soldiers몭 energy; in the second round, the enemy몭s energy begins to deflate; and in the third round, the enemy soldiers enter a state of rest. He was there with Duke Zhuang of Lu during his conference with Duke Huan of Qi at Dong몭e, and it was he who pulled out a dagger and seized Duke Huan, putting him in a position to secure an alliance treaty that restored Lu몭s lost lands.


If you tie everyone to a war chariot, nobody can get off

Extract from the original text:
몮The skillful tactician may be likened to the shuairan. Now, the shuairan is a snake that is found in the Chang Mountains. Strike at its head, and you will be attacked by its tail; strike at its tail, and you will be attacked by its head; strike at its middle, and you will be attacked by head and tail both. Asked if an army can be made to imitate the shuairan, I should answer, 몬Yes.몭 For the men of Wu and the men of Yue are enemies; yet if they are crossing a river in the same boat and are caught by a storm, they will come to each other몭s assistance just as the left hand helps the right. Hence it is not enough to put one몭s trust in the squaring of horses, and the burying of chariot wheels in the ground. The principle on which to manage an army is to set up one standard of courage which all must reach. How to make the best of both strong and weak? That is a question involving the proper use of ground. Thus, the skillful general conducts his army just as though he were leading a single man, whether he likes it or not, by the hand.몯

Analysis:
몮Hence it is not enough to put one몭s trust in the squaring of horses, and the burying of chariot wheels in the ground.몯
몬Squaring of horses몭 means tethering them. Even if you tie up the horses and bury the chariot wheels in an attempt to stop your soldiers from running away, you can몭t trust them not to run anyway.
Cao Cao comments: 몮몬Squaring horses몭 means to tether them. Chariot wheels are buried to show your men that they are not to move. This passage tells that it is better to adapt intelligently than to rely exclusively on creating difficulties for the soldiers.몯 It is more effective to be flexible with your troops than to force them into anything. This way, you can create a situation where they have no choice but to fight to the death.
Why does 몬squaring몭 mean the same thing as 몬tethering?몭 Du Mu comments: 몮Horses are tethered in order to form battle lines that are even and square.몯 So, the horses aren몭t tethered to posts. Rather, they몭re tied up in their respective battle units 멪  forward, rear, left and right 멪  so they can몭t run away.

몮The principle on which to manage an army is to set up one standard of courage which all must reach.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮Being unified and possessed of courage, the soldiers of an army become as one; this is a principle to be used by all in positions of governance.몯
Chen Hao comments: 몮The style of governance and orders both being strict and clear, brave soldiers will not advance alone, and neither will cowards retreat alone; all the soldiers of the army will be as one.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Positioning them in a place of peril and causing them to keep each other alive, the masses of soldiers within the army will pool their strength and unify their courage as though they were one man. This is the proper way to govern armies.몯

몮How to make the best of both strong and weak 멪 that is a question involving the proper use of ground.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮The strong and weak shall be of a single energy.몯 The key to unlocking the potential of strong and weak soldiers alike is to use the terrain appropriately and set your army up in the best possible position.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Gaining the advantage of favourable terrain, even weak soldiers can defeat the enemy in battle, let alone the strongest among your soldiers. It is the energy provided by terrain that enables one to make full and simultaneous use of both weak and strong soldiers.몯
Your army is made up of both strong and weak soldiers, and you need to make full use of all of them. A good example of this is how Li Shimin used 3,500 soldiers to defeat Dou Jiande몭s army of 100,000. How do you properly use 3,500 people? He kept 3,000 of them to guard Hulao Pass, a transport corridor so narrow that a single man could guard it against 10,000. There was no way the enemy would be able to fight their way in. Meanwhile, Li Shimin led the remaining 500 men out of the pass to pick a fight, luring Cheng Yaojin and Qin Shubao to chase after him with their troops, while he set an ambush at the side of the road. Later in that conflict, Li Shimin selected the six strongest men from the 500, who themselves were the strongest of his entire 3,500-strong force. They included two ubermensch warriors 멪  Yuchi Jingde and himself 멪 and went out again to pick another fight. Li Shimin said to Yuchi Jingde: 몮With my bow, and your spear, not even a thousand armed men could touch us!몯 The two of them, along with their four handpicked cavalrymen, headed straight for Dou Jiande몭s main camp and lured several thousand enemy troops into the pre-assigned ambush location, where Li몭s forces won a great victory. Winning the first couple rounds of this conflict provided a huge morale boost to the 3,000 soldiers left guarding Hulao Pass. This is how to use both the strong and weak soldiers in your army.

몮Thus, the skillful general conducts his army just as though he were leading a single man, whether he likes it or not, by the hand.몯

So, the best strategists have the ability to make their army work as a single unit, almost as a single body, because they are able to engineer circumstances in which their men have no choice but to go along with him. If each and every one of their men has no way out and no other choice but to do what they say, the commander has effectively tied them to his war chariot.
Li Quan comments: 몮The patterns by which to govern a great multitude are the same as those used to govern a small number of men.몯 This is the same principle that we몭ve already seen in a passage from Chapter Five, Energy: 몮The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men멞 Fighting with a large army under your command is no different from fighting with a small one.몯 People who have a firm grasp on the art of managing an army are just as unconstrained and at ease commanding any number of men as if they were only in charge of a single man. They are able to advance and withdraw as one and unify their men몭s bodies and minds.


As a leader, don몭t be frantically busy, be calm and collected; Your movements should be neither slow nor rushed

We think that becoming successful and catching hold of success always comes from motion 멪 몬We have to move, because by moving we take hold of success.몭 And yet, so often we flail and grab at success but come up empty-handed. Can we calm down, do some serious thinking and steadily build success? Can we let it come to us from a place of calmness, instead of spinning around in constant motion, grabbing at it? This is the thinking behind strategy, behind Buddhism, and behind managing military issues. It몭s also a kind of wisdom that can be applied to life in general.

Extract from the original text:
몮It is the business of a general to be quiet and thus ensure secrecy; upright and just, and thus maintain order. He must be able to mystify his officers and men by false reports and appearances, and thus keep them in total ignorance. By altering his arrangements and changing his plans, he keeps the enemy without definite knowledge. By shifting his camp and taking circuitous routes, he prevents the enemy from anticipating his purpose. At the critical moment, the leader of an army acts like one who has climbed up a height and then kicks away the ladder behind him. He carries his men deep into hostile territory before he shows his hand. He burns his boats and breaks his cooking-pots; like a shepherd driving a flock of sheep, he drives his men this way and that, and nobody knows whither he is going. To muster his host and bring it into danger: this may be termed the business of the general.몯

Analysis:
몮It is the business of a general to be quiet and thus ensure secrecy; upright and just, and thus maintain order.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮This is what is called 몬quiet몭 멪 serene, obscure and orderly.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮몬Quiet몭 is a simple and easy thing; obscurity is difficult to gauge; orderliness does not err. By using these, one is able to govern with total effectiveness.몯
As a leader, you don몭t want to be manic or overly busy. It몭s best to stay calm and level-headed. Don몭t do things too slowly, but don몭t be too quick either. Take plenty of time to think things over, act in a systematic way, behave with moderation, and keep as a tight a grip on events as you can[bd41].
We want to control other people, and we make up many rules and demands that we place on them, but we don몭t consider that if we want to straighten out other people we first have to straighten out ourselves. Then, we have to use our own 몬straightness몭 as a mould, and reproduce it throughout the ranks of our army.
The Confucians have something to say about the idea that 몬to straighten out other people we first have to straighten out ourselves.몭 They put it like this: 몬Rectify your heart, make your thoughts honest, cultivate your moral self, bring order to your house, bring good governance to your country, and bring peace to the world.몭 The principle also applies to military leaders: cultivate your own moral fiber in order to bring order to your army.
In Zeng Guofan몭s approach to the art of military leadership, he put special emphasis on the concept of 몬incorruptibility.몭 Zeng said that ordinary soldiers don몭t understand the art of war, and they have no idea which generals are more talented than others. Yet, when it comes to gold and silver, they have a very clear idea of what몭s happening. If a general is greedy and corrupt, there몭s no way his soldiers will truly submit to him. But, if a general is clean and honest in matters of money, his soldiers will accept him as their leader. If, on top of that, the general has the ability to clearly lay out information about rewards and punishments, and also make sure all of his men get a share of whatever profit the army might come by, each and every one of his men will be ready and willing to fight alongside him.

몮He must be able to mystify his officers and men by false reports and appearances, and thus keep them in total ignorance.몯

This isn몭t about fooling people; it몭s about keeping secrets. You can몭t let your men know what your battle plans are. Just make sure everyone knows what their individual task is, while remaining in the dark about the planning and intent of the war effort. It is what must be done to protect military secrets.
Cao Cao comments: 몮It is permissible for the people to come together with you in joy, but not to start out from worry.몯 A leader몭s responsibility is to fill everyone with confidence and get them to work side by side; what a leader mustn몭t do is spread worry through his ranks about what on earth should be done. Confucius said something along the same lines: 몮The people may be made to follow a path of action, but they may not be made to understand it.몯 The soldiers should only know what their individual tasks are, while the general keeps a grip on the overall situation.

몮By altering his arrangements and changing his plans, he keeps the enemy without definite knowledge.몯

By making frequent use of variation in the way you carry out operations, and by constantly tweaking your stratagems, other parties won몭t be able to decode what you몭re up to.
Du Mu comments: 몮In all that you do and in all that you plan, do not show the original thoughts that bring these things into being and do not make known the source from which they flow.몯 Make sure people know what you몭re doing, but not how. Then, nobody will be able to work out what your next step will be.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮All your former acts and all your old plans were varied and changed so that people could not know them.몯 If you몭re constantly bringing variety and change into what you do, nobody can know what you몭ll do next. This is because the people who make up your army aren몭t just your brothers-at-arms; your ranks will always contain a certain number of enemy spies and even your own people who, without knowing it, leak secrets. That몭s why you mustn몭t let anyone work out what your next move will be, and you have to make nonsense of any information that might enable people to identify a pattern.
On the other hand, if you몭re in a constant state of instability, how can you make sure your men listen to you? This calls for some more tricks. Zhang Yu wrote about the story of a famous Tang dynasty general named Pei Xingjian, who waited until just after his men had set up camp and then suddenly gave the order that the camp was to be moved up a nearby mountain. The men would have to break everything down and set up again. The soldiers weren몭t happy. In fact, they felt extremely frustrated. But, when evening came, a heavy rainstorm appeared from nowhere and flooded the original campsite, where the water rose over ten feet deep. The soldiers were shocked, and asked Pei Xingjian, 몮How did you know it was going to rain?몯 Pei replied: 몮In the future, when I tell you to do something, you do it. Don몭t ask me what I know, and don몭t ask me how I know.몯
Pei Xingjian managed the situation expertly. If he몭d told his men there was a possibility of rain, but then the rain failed to show up, they몭d stop believing everything he said. He didn몭t say anything, so if it hadn몭t rained that night, nobody would have made the connection between the weather and his command to move camp. And so, his authority wouldn몭t have been compromised. In fact, it did rain 멪 to an extent that everyone would have perished 멪 and he gained a reputation for supernatural foresight. This boosted his authority even higher.

몮By shifting his camp and taking circuitous routes, he prevents the enemy from anticipating his purpose.몯

If you want your men to keep a secret, the best approach is to keep them from knowing the secret in the first place. If you do that, the enemy can send as many spies as they want; it still won몭t do them any good.

몮At the critical moment, the leader of an army acts like one who has climbed up a height and then kicks away the ladder behind him.몯

When a commander assigns tasks to his men, it몭s like he sends them up a ladder to the floor above, and then pulls the ladder away so they have no choice to retreat.


몮He carries his men deep into hostile territory before he shows his hand. He burns his boats and breaks his cooking pots; like a shepherd driving a flock of sheep, he drives his men this way and that, and nobody knows whither he is going.몯

When a commander-in-chief leads his men deep into enemy territory, it몭s like firing an arrow 멪  once you몭re there, there몭s no coming back. He burns his boats and smashes his cooking pots, because today will be the day of the battle that seals the war. The commander drives his troops before him like a herd of sheep, turning this way and that, nobody knowing where they몭re going, only that they are to follow their leader.
Li Quan comments: 몮The general, having burned all the ships, hardens the resolve of his men, who neither know what their commander몭s plan may be, nor harbor any thought of returning home. In this way, they are like herded sheep.몯 The soldiers have no idea what their commander is thinking; all they can do is stake their lives on following him. In this respect, they몭re no different from a herd of cattle or a flock of sheep being driven by their herder.

몮To muster his host and bring it into danger 멪 this may be termed the business of the general.몯

It is a general몭s duty to lead his men into peril and somehow find a way to victory.
I몭m suddenly reminded of the America general George Patton몭s famous words at the height of World War II: 몮I want you to remember that no bastard ever won a war by dying for his country. He won it by making the other poor, dumb bastard die for his country.몯
Although it몭s a generals몭 business to take his men into danger, it몭s also your responsibility to bring them home alive. As Zeng Guofan put it, the young men you lead to war should, after the war is won and they return home to their parents and brothers and sisters, remain simple and honest young men, if perhaps more mature than when they left. You mustn몭t lead them astray and teach them the vices of gluttony, drinking, whoring, gambling and smoking.
This is the way of the benevolent, Confucian general.


Success depends on making just a little bit of effort every day

Extract from the original text:
몮The different measures suited to the nine varieties of ground; the expediency of aggressive or defensive tactics; and the fundamental laws of human nature: these are things that must most certainly be studied.몯

Analysis:
The ability to respond flexibly to each of the nine situations and to a developing situation, as well as mastery over the psychology and emotions of the many kinds of people in your army, are essential capabilities that every general should possess. This passage is a summary of the nine situations, and it also lays the ground for what comes next.
The reason there is special mention of 몬the fundamental laws of human nature,몭 or just 몬emotions,몭 is to highlight the role of managing energy. The only way to gain control over your army몭s morale is to master human psychology and emotions. If you can do that, you be able to both boost your men몭s morale and take control of the enemy몭s.
Confucian scholars talk about 몬the Laws of Heaven,몭 몬the Laws of the Realm,몭 and, as with the art of war, they also talk about 몬the laws of human nature.몭 We몭ve already seen examples of how the art of war is applied to human nature or emotions 멪 when we talk about managing energy, that basically means paying attention to your soldiers몭 psychological state. Psychology determines morale, and morale determines an army몭s fighting ability.
Zeng Guofan had two things to say about studying. First, stay committed and study every day, even if you only read one page or even one line in a day. Stay dedicated and you몭ll progress quickly enough 멪 this is the idea of moving at speed without hurrying. The worst scenario is to whip yourself into a frenzy and go all out for one, huge session, only to abandon your efforts as soon as you lose steam. If that몭s the way you do things, you몭ll have a hard time finishing anything.
The key to finishing a job and achieving a goal is to keep moving forward, one step every day. If the road to success were a chess game, becoming successful would depend on using pawns, not rooks, because you don몭t have as many rooks as pawns. And yet, lots of people only want to use their rooks. If you try to talk to them about pawns, they simply don몭t listen.
The second thing Zeng Guofan said about studying and reading is that you should finish reading the book in your hands before starting the next. That몭s so you don몭t end up with a hulking pile of books, all of which you gave up on halfway through.
I suppose this could be called 몬the art of war for reading books.몭



Once inside enemy territory, unite your army as one

Extract from the original text:
몮When invading hostile territory, the general principle is that penetrating deeply brings cohesion; penetrating but a short way means dispersion. When you leave your own country behind, and take your army across neighborhood territory, you find yourself on critical ground. When there are means of communication on all four sides, the ground is one of intersecting highways. When you penetrate deeply into a country, it is serious ground. When you penetrate but a little way, it is facile ground. When you have the enemy몭s strongholds on your rear, and narrow passes in front, it is hemmed-in ground. When there is no place of refuge at all, it is desperate ground. Therefore, on dispersive ground, I would inspire my men with unity of purpose. On facile ground, I would see that there is close connection between all parts of my army. On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear. On open ground, I would keep a vigilant eye on my defenses. On ground of intersecting highways, I would consolidate my alliances. On serious ground, I would try to ensure a continuous stream of supplies. On difficult ground, I would keep pushing on along the road. On hemmed-in ground, I would block any way of retreat. On desperate ground, I would proclaim to my soldiers the hopelessness of keeping their lives.몯

Analysis:
몮When invading hostile territory, the general principle is that penetrating deeply brings cohesion; penetrating but a short way means dispersion.몯
When fighting as a 몬visitor몭 in foreign lands, your soldiers몭 minds will become focused and their resolve will harden once you몭re deep in enemy territory. But, if you don몭t plunge deep into enemy territory, your men몭s fighting spirit will easily become diluted and weak.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Entering deeply brings focus and solidity; entering shallowly brings dispersion and a desire to return home.몯 This is the difference between serious ground and facile ground on the one hand, which we몭ve already talked about, and shallow ground.

몮When you leave your own country behind, and take your army across neighborhood territory, you find yourself on critical ground. When there are means of communication on all four sides, the ground is one of intersecting highways. When you penetrate deeply into a country, it is serious ground. When you penetrate but a little way, it is facile ground. When you have the enemy몭s strongholds on your rear, and narrow passes in front, it is hemmed-in ground. When there is no place of refuge at all, it is desperate ground.몯


This passage introduces an additional piece: 몬critical ground.몭 Mei Yaochen comments: 몮This refers to a situation in which one cannot reach facile ground by moving forward, yet also cannot reach dispersive ground by retreating; critical ground is between these two other types of terrain.몯 When you몭re a short distance inside enemy territory, you are no longer in dispersive ground, but you also have not yet reached facile ground.
Areas with easy transportation links in all directions are 몬ground of intersecting highways,몭 areas deep within enemy territory are 몬serious ground,몭 and areas only a short distance inside enemy territory are 몬shallow ground.몭 Terrain characterized by impregnable, dangerous terrain behind and narrow, obstructed passages in front is 몬hemmed-in ground,몭 and areas where there is no way out is 몬desperate ground.몭
What몭s the right way to deal with each of these different terrain types?

몮Therefore, on dispersive ground, I would inspire my men with unity of purpose.몯

Li Quan comments: 몮Mind of a single soldier.몯 Bring together an army and make them of one mind and one will.
Du Mu comments: 몮When defending, the army몭s will is as one; when fighting a battle, it is easy to become dispersed.몯 When you몭re holding a defensive position behind a fortified wall, everyone in your army will be unified in their intent to prevent the enemy from breaking in. But, if you come out from behind the walls to fight, the idea will occur to some of your men that this is an opportunity to run away and go home. This is the logic behind the earlier passage: 몮On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not.몯 Hold your ground and don몭t go looking for a fight.

몮On facile ground, I would see that there is close connection between all parts of my army.몯

When you enter facile ground, make sure the various campsites of the different units in your army are close to each other and connected. There are two reasons for this. First, it몭s a way to defend against enemy attack, because it makes it easier for different units to support and rescue each other. Second, it몭s a way to defend against your own men running away.


Ask yourself: 몬What have I learned?몭 멨 Don몭t get caught up in words and their meanings

When you study ancient treatises, or when you have an experience, ask yourself: 몬What have I learned?몯 Try to understand the writer몭s thinking, not the meaning of the words.

Extract from the original text:
몮When invading hostile territory, the general principle is that penetrating deeply brings cohesion; penetrating but a short way means dispersion. When you leave your own country behind, and take your army across neighborhood territory, you find yourself on critical ground. When there are means of communication on all four sides, the ground is one of intersecting highways. When you penetrate deeply into a country, it is serious ground. When you penetrate but a little way, it is facile ground. When you have the enemy몭s strongholds on your rear, and narrow passes in front, it is hemmed-in ground. When there is no place of refuge at all, it is desperate ground. Therefore, on dispersive ground, I would inspire my men with unity of purpose. On facile ground, I would see that there is close connection between all parts of my army. On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear. On open ground, I would keep a vigilant eye on my defenses. On ground of intersecting highways, I would consolidate my alliances. On serious ground, I would try to ensure a continuous stream of supplies. On difficult ground, I would keep pushing on along the road. On hemmed-in ground, I would block any way of retreat. On desperate ground, I would proclaim to my soldiers the hopelessness of keeping their lives.몯

Analysis:
몮On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear.몯
This line causes some problems. All of our commentators have a different interpretation.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Favourable ground lies ahead. One should order one몭s rear units to advance quickly.몯 This is effectively a non-comment, because he몭s saying exactly the same thing as Sun Tzu. Cao Cao understands, but the others don몭t. The issue is, what does 몬rear몭 mean? Does it mean you should maneuver your army behind the enemy?
Du Mu comments: 몮On terrain which is vital to the point that it must be contended over, if I am behind then I must rush forward to contend for it; is this any less true if I do not start from behind?몯
Chen Hao tells us that Du Mu몭s comment is incorrect. Chen Hao comments: 몮Both statements are incorrect. If the enemy occupies the favourable ground and I come from behind to contend for it, would this not be exhausting my army by coming to fight when the battleground is already held by the enemy? What is meant here about the vital importance of hurrying up the rear when on contentious ground is that if the favourable ground is in front, then one should first select one몭s best soldiers and send them to occupy it. Then, if the enemy comes to contend for it with the whole mass of his army, one should come with the main part of one몭s army and strike the enemy몭s rear; then it would be impossible not to overcome the enemy.몯
Chen Hao claims that the commentators who came before him were wrong, but his own logic doesn몭t stand up to scrutiny. In fact, Du Mu was saying that if the enemy has gotten ahead of you, you should chase after him, and try to get ahead, so you can be the first to arrive at the contentious ground. Du Mu was not saying that in this scenario the enemy has already occupied the contentious ground.
Chen Hao몭s comment argues that if the favourable terrain is ahead of you, you should send a small unit of elite soldiers to occupy it. Then, if the enemy attacks their position in force, you can send your main army to attack them from behind.
Chen Hao seems once again to have put too much of his own thinking into his comment. With contentious ground, if you get hold of it, it몭s yours, and that몭s all. Sun Tzu probably wasn몭t saying that after you몭ve taken the contentious ground you should come up behind the enemy and strike their rear.
Du You comments: 몮With favourable terrain ahead, one should enter into it from behind. On contentious ground, victory belongs to whoever occupies it first, and defeat falls to whoever fails to do so. Therefore, bring your rear units close after the remainder of your forces so that the different parts of your army remain connected.몯 The first part of what Du You said was right 멪 the nature of contentious ground is that whoever occupies it first will win, and the other side will lose. That몭s exactly why it몭s called 몬contentious ground.몭 This makes what you do after you hold the contentious ground, or whether you should hit the enemy with a sneak attack from behind, a moot point. But, the second part of Du You몭s comment 멪 몮Therefore, bring your rear units close after the remainder of your forces so that the different parts of your army are connected몯 멪 shows that he also didn몭t understand the original text. Does he want the rear units to catch up and link together with the forward units so that the army doesn몭t fall apart?
Zhang Yu doubles down on Du You몭s view: 몮In contentious ground speed is a commodity of the highest value; it is not acceptable for your forward units to move quickly ahead while your rear units fail to keep up. Therefore, you should quickly move your rear units forward so that the head and tail of your army arrive together.몯 So, Zhang Yu is interpreting the 몬rear몭 from Sun Tzu몭s original text to mean not the enemy몭s rear, but your own rear. He몭s saying you shouldn몭t get yourself in a situation where your forward units make it to the contentious ground, but your rear units can몭t keep up. He몭s saying that your rear units have to move quickly, too.
By my reckoning, this is much more complicated than what Sun Tzu was actually trying to say.
Zhang Yu also provides an alternative explanation: 몮몬Hurrying up the rear몭 means that although you set out after the enemy, you arrive before him.몯 So, according to this explanation, the 몬rear몭 means that your enemy set out first and you came after 멪 in other words, you followed after the enemy몭s rear. I think it몭s even less likely that Sun Tzu was saying this. What would the point be? He didn몭t care whether you set out before or after the enemy. The point is that you need to get to the destination first.
To sum up, we shouldn몭t over-think things and make them more complicated than necessary. Keep things simple and direct. 몮On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear.몯 All this means is that when it comes to contentious ground, you need to get there as quickly as possible, find a way to get behind enemy lines, and arrive at the destination before the enemy. Whenever you study ancient texts, or have a real-life experience, ask yourself: 몬What have I learned?몭 Try to understand the writer몭s thinking, not necessarily the literal meaning of the words. You can find the writer몭s thinking in the context and by looking at the book as a whole. If you get it, you get it. But, if you get caught up in entanglements and debates and different interpretations of the meaning of a certain line, or even a handful of words, you몭re doing pointless mental labor. There몭s not much meaning to be found in this kind of work. In particular, don몭t make it into a contest that you have to win 멪 don몭t single-mindedly fixate on coming up with a new theory or an innovative angle to beat other people over the head with.

몮On open ground, I would keep a vigilant eye on my defenses.몯

몮Ground on which each side has liberty of movement몯 멪 this is 몬open ground.몭 These are places where you need to carefully guard your fortifications and cut off the enemy몭s transportation routes.
Du Mu comments: 몮This is about diligently seeing to your fortifications.몯 If the enemy can come at you from any direction, you need to build strong fortifications, dig deep moats and guard them vigilantly.

몮On ground of intersecting highways, I would consolidate my alliances.몯

Make sure your enemies don몭t secure alliances with your neighbors before you do, and don몭t let them break up your alliances.
Wang Xi comments: 몮To solidify alliances, use moral virtue and courtesy, prestige and trust, and show them the 몬benefit-and-harm gambit.몭몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Use riches and money to show them benefits, use oaths of alliance to secure the alliance, be firm and consistent; then, they are bound to help you.몯

몮On serious ground, I would try to ensure a continuous stream of supplies.몯

The crucial thing about serious ground is to take care of your army. Basically, you need grain, animal fodder and other supplies. That몭s because once you몭re deep in enemy territory, your rear units can몭t keep up, and you몭ll need to feed yourself from the enemies몭 resources. In other words, you need to find a local solution to the problem of keeping your army fed and supplied. Cao Cao comments: 몮It is about plundering from the enemy.몯
When we talk about the Second World War, why do people say that China made an enormous sacrifice and contribution? It몭s because China consistently and firmly refused to surrender. As a result, Japan couldn몭t secure all of China몭s resources for its war effort and instead had to spend a huge amount of its own resources fighting there.

몮On difficult ground, I would keep pushing on along the road.몯

When you몭re in difficult ground 멪 terrain with mountains and forests, other obstructions, or dangerous terrain features, marshes and swamps 멪 you need to quickly pass through the area.
Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about passing quickly through and leaving.몯
Li Quan comments: 몮It is not permissible to stay in such places.몯
In summary, make your way through these places quickly. You mustn몭t delay. If you do, and your enemy strands you, you몭re in serious trouble.

몮On hemmed-in ground, I would block any way of retreat.몯

If you find yourself in hemmed-in ground and surrounded by the enemy, you need to block whatever gap in the encirclement might offer escape.
But why would you want to block your one chance for escape? The Art of War tells us: 몮When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.몯 When your enemy surrounds you, they leave a gap for you to escape through because they몭re worried that otherwise you몭ll fight like a cornered animal. If your men have a way out, they몭ll lose their will to fight to the death and instead head straight for the escape route that the enemy has intentionally left open. As soon as your men run, the enemy will capitalize on their eagerness to make it home alive, cutting off groups of your soldiers, walling them in and attacking until there몭s nothing left of your army. That몭s why you should block up the hole yourself and tell your men that there몭s nowhere to run, and the only option is to fight like madmen. If you do that, you can turn the situation around and actually have a chance to hit the enemy so hard that their lines shatter. Also, the fact that the enemy intentionally left a gap for you means that it will be surrounded by enemy troops waiting to ambush you. If you block it up, the enemy has no way to know from which direction you몭ll try to break through the encirclement.
When Gao Huan, also known as Emperor Shenwu of Northern Qi, first raised his army in Hebei, he fought a battle at Yenan against the combined forces of Erzhu Zhao, Erzhu Tianguang, Erzhu Dulu and Erzhu Zhongyuan. At the time, the army of Erzhu, Erzhu and Erzhu was a formidable force known as the 몬Great Army of 200,000.몭 It managed to surround Gao Huan몭s army of 2,000 cavalry and 30,000 infantry at Nanling Mountain. The Erzhus left a single way out for Gao Huan몭s army, so that his men would have an escape route, and then they got ready to annihilate him. But that didn몭t happen. Instead, Gao Huan gathered his army몭s cattle and donkeys, tied them all together, and put them right in the way of the escape route, blocking it off. His men could see there was nowhere to run, so they fought for their lives, striking the enemy hard on all sides and ultimately inflicting a heavy defeat on the Erzhus.

몮On desperate ground, I would proclaim to my soldiers the hopelessness of keeping their lives.몯

When on desperate ground, you need to show your men that you몭ve made up your mind to embrace death.
Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about rousing the soldiers몭 spirits.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮This is about making clear to the soldiers that death is inevitable; make them stoke their inner fire so that they may seek life.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Burn the heavy wagons, throw out the food, block the wells and demolish the cooking ranges so as to show the soldiers that there is no hope of survival and to incite them to fight unto death.몯
Shout something along the lines of, 몮The wagons and the food are burned, the well is blocked, the cooking ranges are smashed; there몭s no life for us now. Now fight with me!몯


The way of hegemons and kings: To strike iron, make yourself harder than iron

Extract from the original text:
몮For it is the soldier몭s disposition to offer an obstinate resistance when surrounded, to fight hard when he cannot help himself, and to obey promptly when he has fallen into danger. We cannot enter into alliance with neighboring lords until we are acquainted with their designs. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country 멪 its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and precipices, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantages to account unless we make use of local guides. To be ignorant of any one of the following four and five principles is inconsistent with the way that hegemons and kings use military force. When a hegemon or a king attacks a powerful state, his generalship shows itself in preventing the concentration of the enemy몭s forces. He overawes his opponents, and their allies are prevented from joining against him. Hence he does not strive to ally himself with all and sundry, nor does he foster the power of other states. He unfurls his own personal designs, keeping his antagonists in awe. Thus he is able to capture their cities and overthrow their kingdoms.몯

Analysis:
몮For it is the soldier몭s disposition to offer an obstinate resistance when surrounded, to fight hard when he cannot help himself, and to obey promptly when he has fallen into danger.몯
These are 몬the fundamental laws of human natures몭 from the passage: 몮The different measures suited to the nine varieties of ground; the expediency of aggressive or defensive tactics; and the fundamental laws of human nature: these are things that must most certainly be studied.몯 You need to gain control over your men몭s psychological state, because psychology determines an army몭s will to fight, and the will to fight determines an army몭s battle capability.

몮멞 to offer an obstinate resistance when surrounded.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about resisting the enemy when in deadlock.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮Keep strict discipline among the soldiers when in hemmed-in ground, and then all of the men will have the will to resist the enemy and find a road to victory; this is resisting the enemy when in deadlock. When in dire circumstances, make your army of a single mind and hold your position.몯
몮멞 to fight hard when he cannot help himself.몯 

Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about scenarios in which the circumstances leave no choice.몯

몮멞 to obey promptly when he has fallen into danger.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮In situations of excessive danger, soldiers will obey and follow the plan.몯
Meng Shi comments: 몮When sunk in peril, none of the soldiers will not obey.몯 There몭s nothing they can do, except do exactly what you tell them to.
Zhang Yu writes about a historical example of this principle: Ban Chao몭s diplomatic expedition, which we looked at earlier in the book. Ban Chao was sent as an envoy to the Western Regions, to the kingdom of Shanshan. When he and a small contingent of men first arrived, they were treated with warm hospitality by the King of Shanshan. However, the sovereign suddenly turned cold. Ban Chao made some enquiries and found out that another foreign emissary had arrived in Shanshan, from the Xiongnu nomadic confederation. So, was Shanshan going to go with the Xiongnu, or with the Han Emperor? If Shanshan made an alliance with the Xiongnu, Ban Chao and his men likely would have been executed as a gift to the Xiongnu diplomat. Ban Chao had just 36 men with him, and they were definitely 몬sunk in peril.몭
Faced with this situation, Ban Chao assembled his men and told them his plan. Frankly, it was startling. They would launch a direct attack on the Xiongnu diplomatic team and kill every last one of them. The King of Shanshan would never be able to explain to the Xiongnu leaders how their men ended up dead on his watch, so his only choice would be to ally with the Han Emperor.
Hundreds of miles from home, in the capital city of a foreign country, Ban Chao was asking the handful of men under his command to do something truly audacious. He was daring enough to do it, but what about his men? Ban Chao treated them to wine, and then explained clearly to them the danger they were in. He asked what they wanted to do: let the King of Shanshan hand them over to the Xiongnu, so that the jackals and wolves could gnaw on their bones, or do something truly great, which would make them rich in this life and immortal heroes in the history books. The men said: 몮Today we are in the land of death. We will follow you into battle, whether we are to live or die.몯 They handed their lives over to Ban Chao. Under cover of night they launched a surprise attack, setting fire to the Xiongnu diplomat몭s campsite and killing the men inside. The next day, they took the diplomat몭s head to the King of Shanshan. Terrified, the king decided to send his son as a hostage to the Han Emperor. He had accepted an alliance with the Han Empire.

몮We cannot enter into alliance with neighboring lords until we are acquainted with their designs. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country 멪 its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and precipices, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantages to account unless we make use of local guides.몯


So, if you don몭t know what other countries are planning, or what they want, you can몭t design a foreign policy. In the story of Ban Chao, if he hadn몭t known about the King of Shanshan몭s situation, or the movements of the Xiongnu, he could never have acted so decisively.
