If you don몭t know the lay of the local mountains, forests, marshes, swamps and other dangerous terrain features, you can몭t move your army through the area. If you don몭t employ a local guide, you won몭t be able to take advantage of the best terrain.
Cao Cao comments: 몮These three matters have already been expounded upon above. Here, they are repeated, so as to vigorously express that one must absolutely not take military action.몯
The reason these three principles are repeated is to emphasize their importance.

몮To be ignorant of any one of the following four and five principles is inconsistent with the way that hegemons and kings use military force.몯

What exactly is meant by 몬the following four or five principles?몭 Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about the benefits and dangers inherent in the nine terrain situations. An alternative formulation is: 몬the four and five issues.몭몯 Four plus five equals nine, so 몬the four and five principles몭 means 몬the nine terrain types.몭 Some people have a different interpretation, suggesting that it몭s not a reference specifically to 몬the nine terrain types,몭 but a more general reference to the various principles introduced above.
In the original text, this passage could be interpreted either to mean 몬hegemonic kings몭 or 몬hegemons and kings.몭 The correct meaning is 몬hegemons and kings.몭 A hegemon is a regional lord, while a king is someone who can claim to rule the known world. So, hegemons and kings are different categories, with differing status and existing within different boundaries. A hegemon is someone who is feared, someone who everyone submits to and obeys. He몭s in charge, and his role is like that of the oldest brother in a clan. Separately, a king is someone who the whole populace recognizes as their lord; he몭s like the father of his country.

몮When a hegemon or a king attacks a powerful state, his generalship shows itself in preventing the concentration of the enemy몭s forces. He overawes his opponents, and their allies are prevented from joining against him.몯

By attacking a powerful country in the manner of a hegemon or a king, you cause the enemy몭s country to collapse from the inside, rendering them unable to assemble their army. Make a show of force to psychologically dominate them, and they몭ll be unable to build friendly relations with other countries.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮When invading large countries, being able to divide the populace ensures you can command an abundance of authority and power, and then you can impose your authoritativeness upon the enemy, inspiring fear in neighboring countries and rendering it impossible for your enemy to seek allies.몯 
When you command military strength that is truly earthshaking, your enemy fears your power, and this fear handicaps their ability to raise an army. As word of your power reverberates through the land, nearby countries will be paralyzed and horrified at the thought of getting on your bad side. So, nobody will be eager to hold out a hand of friendship to your enemy.
For example, when the states of Jin and Chu went to war over control of the state of Zheng, if Jin won, Zheng would become a Jin vassal. If Chu won, Zheng would turn its back on Jin and become a Chu vassal. This is how a big country practices The Way of the Hegemon 멪 by winning wars and annexing smaller countries, thus becoming even stronger.

몮Hence he does not strive to ally himself with all and sundry, nor does he foster the power of other states. He unfurls his own personal designs, keeping his antagonists in awe. Thus he is able to capture their cities and overthrow their kingdoms.몯

Therefore, there몭s no need to spend time and effort building alliances with other countries, or to help build up another country몭s military strength. Just flex your muscles and let your intentions be known. Exert your aura of power on your enemy, and then you can easily take their cities and reduce their country to rubble.
Du Mu comments: 몮The character 몬xin몭 (which usually means 몬trust몭) here means 몬shen몭 (몬unfurl몭).몯 This passage tells the general to not form ties with foreign forces, nor to use the stratagem of building power, but to flaunt the power of his army and exert the pressure that arises from it upon enemy countries. High importance is placed on carrying out one몭s personal desires; if you do this, the enemy몭s cities can be plucked from their hands and their country destroyed.몯
Jia Lin comments: 몮The various feudal princes will fear you. They will be unable to bring their people together and they will not dare to ally with other countries. You can call upon an abundance of authoritativeness and intelligent planning capabilities, and the various feudal princes will naturally align with you. What need is there to foster alliances?몯
Chen Hao comments: 몮Commanding ample wisdom and strength, authority rests in your hands. Foster only your own soldiers; this is how to make yourself invincible, and all the feudal princes in the world will have no authority to call upon. Benevolence, righteousness and wisdom will be your personal assets, owned by nobody else, and you can use them to unite the people. Thus, it is said: 몬Unfurling my personal designs, my authority shakes all under heaven, my moral virtue shines over the four seas, my grace blesses all things, and trust in me pervades all beings even unto pigs and fishes. The hearts of the common people are mine and nobody even entertains the notion of not submitting to me. Thus, I will inevitably take the enemy몭s cities; when I invade, their country is bound to fall.몯
Chen Hao is talking about The Way of Kings, which applies to all living things in the world, not just to the people of one몭s own country. Even the birds and beasts are included. An example of this, which we discussed earlier in the book, is the story of Shang Tang, the legendary founder of the ancient Shang dynasty (1600-1046 BCE), and how he 몬left the net open on three sides.몭
Shang Tang was outside of the city when he saw a hunter putting up nets to catch birds. The hunter was arranging the nets in a square shape, with no way out. He muttered while he worked: 몮Any bird that comes from the sky and any beast that comes from the earth; any creature coming from any direction; here they all come, straight into my net.몯 From the tempo of the hunter몭s work, it seemed he was hell-bent on catching as many animals as he possibly could. Shang Tang approached him, and said: 몮If you act this way, you will hunt the animals until there are none left! This is the evil influence of King Jie of Xia; if it were not for his example, who would behave in this way?몯 Shang Tang told the hunter to take down his nets on three sides, leaving only one side remaining. Then, he taught the hunter a new song. Loosely translated into a more modern form, it reads like this:
몮When a spider weaves its web,
It only weaves on one side!
Let me be like the spider
To set my nets and catch the birds!
When I go setting nets
And hunting birds!
Go left, if you like,
Or right, if you like,
Or up high, if you like,
Or down low, if you like.
Three sides free to fly,
One side for my net.
Fly into my net,
If you insist,
And if that is your lousy fate.
I몭ll take the birds
Who throw their life away,
And to the rest I say,
Fly free and godspeed!몯

News of Shang Tang몭s good deed spread, and when people in other countries heard about it, they exclaimed: 몮Tang몭s virtue reaches even the birds and the beasts!몯 If Shang Tang몭s good deeds extended even to animals, imagine how kind he must be in his dealings with human beings! After that, 40 countries and states submitted to him.
The moral of the story is that, even if you set up nets on four sides, you won몭t necessarily catch any birds. Shang Tang removed the nets on three sides and managed to catch 40 countries in his one remaining net. He wasn몭t in the business of catching birds!
There몭s another story about Shang Tang. He was once building a house, and while digging the foundation his shovel unearthed a human skeleton. The workers made as if to dispose of it, but Shang Tang said: 몮This is our countryman, you know!몯 Then, treating the nameless skeleton with the utmost dignity and respect, he gave it a proper burial. When this story spread, people all over the world exclaimed: 몮If Tang몭s virtue reaches even the dead, then imagine how well he must treat the living!몯 
Then, the common people gave their hearts to Shang Tang, and there was nobody who even considered not submitting to him. And what was the result? When Shang Tang began launching military campaigns all over China, if he attacked countries in the east, people in the west would be unhappy: 몮What몭s Tang doing fighting in the east? Why isn몭t he attacking us? How we wish that he would come and be our ruler!몯 Then, after Shang Tang turned his armies west, the people in the east were most displeased: 몮He hasn몭t finished the job over here yet! Why몭s he going west?몯
And that is how Shang Tang unified all the lands of China.
The lesson is that if you몭re going to strike iron, the key is to make yourself harder than iron. This is The Way of Hegemons and Kings. Once your economy, culture, military and government administration are more advanced than your rivals몭, you can roll out The Way of Hegemons and Kings around the world. You won몭t need to bother with building alliances or calculating who to fight and who to seduce into a partnership 멪 that몭s not what hegemons and kings do. For example, at one time the United States had ambitions to win over the hearts and minds of the common people: The Way of Kings. When the US first invaded Iraq, I몭d guess that many Libyans wished the American military was coming to their country. In fact, America was unable to continue to bear the responsibility it had taken upon itself.
US President Barack Obama didn몭t understand the one rule that is the bare minimum for anyone wishing to be a world leader. Being a world leader means sacrificing yourself for the sake of the world. If you sacrifice nothing at all, what qualifies you to lead others?  If you refuse to make any kind of blood sacrifice, and instead try to rule the world purely through diplomacy and building up other countries, you몭re doomed to be nothing more than a world-class laughingstock.


To emerge victorious, you must lay aside all fear and doubt

Extract from the original text:
몮Bestow rewards without regard to rule, issue orders without regard to previous arrangements; and you will be able to handle a whole army as though you had to do with but a single man. Use them only to achieve things; never tell them your design. When the outlook is bright, bring it before their eyes; but tell them nothing when the situation is gloomy.몯

Analysis:
몮Bestow rewards without regard to law, issue orders without regard to previous arrangements멞몯
Acting 몬without regard to rule몭 or to 몬previous arrangements몭 is about breaking with convention.
Jia Lin comments: 몮If you wish to take an enemy city or destroy an enemy country, then dangle rewards before your men that exceed your established laws; give commands which are infused with your authoritativeness and which transcend your normal administration. This is about breaking with the ordinary rules and administration, and thus it is said: 몬Act without regard to law or previous arrangements.몭몯
The prospect of massive reward brings daring men out of the woodwork. That몭s why you have to offer rewards that seem to go beyond the remit of your laws and rules when you want to take a city. War is a time of extraordinary circumstances, so you have to command in an extraordinary manner; you have to go against the usual way of doing things.
This is all for the sake of victory. Don몭t tie yourself to the normal rules; make up whatever 몬special몭 rules the circumstances demand.

몮멞 and you will be able to handle a whole army as though you had to do with but a single man.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮The character 몬fan몭 (which normally means 몬violate몭) here means 몬yong몭 (몬use몭). This passage says that one must make clear what the rewards are, and to use your army as though it were only a single man, even if it is of great size.몯
This is a principle we몭ve come across many times already: to command a large number of men, lead them as though they몭re few in number.

몮Use them only to achieve things; never tell them your design.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Use soldiers only to fight battles; do not tell them your plans.몯
Wang Xi comments: 몮When information is leaked, plans go awry.몯
When you몭re trying to accomplish something, only tell your soldiers what to do. Don몭t explain why. If more than a handful of people know why you몭re doing something, an intelligence leak becomes highly likely. If that happens, your enemy can work out what your next move will be.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Use them to fight battles, do not discuss matters of planning and authority. When people know your plan, they are prone to doubt.몯
This brings us to the second issue. If you tell your men why you몭re making such-and-such a move, they몭ll start thinking and analyzing, and it will be impossible to stop them from doubting your plan. Once your men have doubts, they몭ll lose their determination to get on with their job.
In an earlier example, we saw how General Pei Xingjian몭s men had just finished setting up camp when he ordered them to take down their tents and move to higher ground. He didn몭t give them any reason for this command, and his men were reluctant to obey. They did, though, and that night a huge rainstorm came and flooded the campsite they몭d abandoned. After that, everyone in the army had nothing but admiration for Pei Xingjian!
Now, let몭s imagine that Pei Xingjian had explained his reasoning when he gave the order to move camp: 몮It몭s possible there will be a big rainstorm tonight. That몭s why I몭m telling you to hurry up and move to higher ground.몯 Then the troops would have started talking among themselves. Some of them would have argued that Pei was right and it was indeed going to rain; others would insist it wasn몭t going to rain. And, if it wasn몭t going to rain, they몭d figure they should rest instead of making life hard for themselves멞 and so on. Tongues would start wagging.
If the rainstorm did materialize that evening, General Pei would come off as a wise man. If it didn몭t, getting his men to do as he said would become much more difficult the next time round. By not telling them a reason, even if it didn몭t rain, they몭d never make the connection between being ordered to move camp and whether or not it would rain that night. In the minds of the soldiers, their general would be an inscrutable leader, impossible to second guess and always acting for his own reasons. Their role is to do as he says, and nothing more.
As a general, you have to make your soldiers trust you completely; leave no room for doubt in their minds. There몭s a relation between trust and not doubting 멪 trust is the reason, and soldiers who never doubt you is the objective. So, the best course of action is to not give your soldiers the choice between trusting and not trusting; go straight to making sure they never doubt you.
Confucius made the same point when he said: 몮The people may be made to follow a path of action, but they may not be made to understand it.몯 Don몭t get everyone in your organization involved in analyzing decisions. The more they analyze, the more ideas they have and the more they start to worry. Then, everything turns into an opaque muddle.

몮When the outlook is bright, bring it before their eyes; but tell them nothing when the situation is gloomy.몯


Cao Cao comments: 몮Do not make them aware of danger.몯
Wang Xi comments: 몮This is about worry, doubt and fear.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮It is the human disposition to advance upon seeing gain and to hide upon gaining knowledge of danger; thus, do not tell them about danger.몯
In the previous passage 멪 몮Use them only to achieve things; never tell them your design몯 멪 Sun Tzu advises us not to let the soldiers think, and not to let them make their own judgments or feel doubt. Get them to do their job with single-minded focus. This passage 멪 몮When the outlook is bright, bring it before their eyes; but tell them nothing when the situation is gloomy몯 멪 instructs us only to tell our soldiers about things that they can get some gain from and not to tell them about danger. It몭s human nature to go after attractive things and stay well away from the bad. You need to make your men see only gain, so that they put aside their attachment to life. You mustn몭t let them see danger, or they몭ll get scared and have doubts, and they won몭t have the courage to move forward.
Ideally, make sure your men feel no doubt and no fear.


Walking out alive from a death trap: Who truly has what it takes?

Extract from the original text:
몮Place your army in deadly peril, and it will survive; plunge it into desperate straits, and it will come off in safety. For it is precisely when a force has fallen into harm몭s way that is capable of striking a blow for victory.몯

Analysis:
The only way to keep your army whole is to place it in a deathtrap, and the only way to survive is to put it in a desperate situation. This is because the only way to seize the wheel of victory and failure is to plunge your troops into a place of certain death.
Cao Cao comments: 몮You must engage in life-and-death battles; you cannot be defeated when you are in a desperate situation. Sun Bin said: 몬The most frightening proposition for an army is to not be plunged into desperate straits.몭 Without being in a place of danger and difficulty, the soldiers몭 minds will not be focused. Being in a situation of danger and difficulty, then victory and defeat are in the hands of your men.몯
Unless your men are in mortal peril, they몭ll never be able to focus their wills and their minds, transcend the questions of life and death, and fight as though their lives depends on it. That몭s because unless they몭re in mortal peril, they몭ll always have other choices open to them. That is why you have to put them in a situation of certain death; it몭s the only way for them to break out from their own personal little worlds and defeat your enemies.
Of course, if we몭re going to talk about historical examples of 몬walking out alive from a death trap,몭 we have to once again mention Han Xin몭s gambit, fighting with his back to a deep river. However, although Han Xin plunged his soldiers into a situation of certain death, he also had other plans: 2,000 cavalry waiting elsewhere. He was very clear that he몭d left himself an out. 
But there was a general who really did plunge all of his own men, and all of the enemy몭s men, into mortal peril. That general is Chen Qingzhi, and it happened at the Battle of Guoyang.
Chen Qingzhi was a famous general of the Liang dynasty, during the Dynasties period (386멨589 CE). People called him 몬The God of War,몭 and it몭s said that Mao Zedong revered him above any other ancient general. Chen몭s wartime achievements are so dazzling that they beggar belief. As a result, there몭s an ongoing debate about whether what the history books say about him is true.
Chen Qingzhi laid siege to the Northern Wei city of Guoyang, which today is the city of Mengcheng in Anhui Province. From spring to winter, the two armies fought dozens of battles, and eventually Chen몭s men grew dispirited, officers and soldiers alike tottering at the brink of total exhaustion. Then, a Northern Wei relief force showed up and built a camp behind the Liang army몭s position. Chen몭s officers were horrified 멪 facing the prospect of being hit in the belly and the back at the same time, they were all anxious to retreat. Then, Chen Qingzhi spoke: 몮Since we came here, we have spent a year fighting, at great expense of money and grain. And yet, you all have lost your appetite for fighting, and now you want to cower away. The enemy has surrounded us. What could be better! As I see it, we are now in a situation of certain death, and so we will survive. Once they have us completely surrounded, then the soldier will be ready to fight to the death. That will be the moment of our victory!몯
Throughout the history of war, generals all feared being 몬wrapped up like a dumpling,몭 but Chen Qingzhi actually welcomed the idea, because he thought that it was the only way to unleash his soldiers몭 ferocity.
Sure enough, the Northern Wei army built 13 camps in a tight circle around the Liang army. Chen Qingzhi led his men into action under the cover of night, knocked out four of the enemy camps, and secured the surrender of the Guoyang garrison commander, Wang Wei. Then, Chen picked out 13 enemy prisoners and released them to go back to the Northern Wei camps and spread the news of the Northern Wei defeat. At the same time, Chen and his army followed close on the heels of the surrendered enemy troops, taking advantage of their momentum to attack and destroy the remaining nine enemy camps. The entire Northern Wei army was wiped out.


Loyal advice: you might not want to hear it, but it몭s to your own advantage to act on It; Beware of advisors who scrape and bow, they have treachery in their hearts

Extract from the original text:
몮Success in warfare is gained by carefully accommodating ourselves to the enemy몭s purpose. By massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy, we shall succeed in the long run in killing the commander-in-chief. This is called the ability to accomplish a thing by sheer cunning. On the day that you take up your command, block the frontier passes, destroy the official tallies, and stop the passage of all emissaries. Be stern in the council-chamber, so that you may control the situation. If the enemy leaves a door open, you must rush in. Forestall your opponent by seizing what he holds dear, and do not fight on any fixed day or time. Tread the inked line and follow the enemy, and accommodate yourself to the enemy until you can fight a decisive battle. At first, then, exhibit the coyness of a maiden, until the enemy gives you an opening; afterwards, emulate the rapidity of a running hare, and it will be too late for the enemy to oppose you.몯

Analysis:
몮Success in warfare is gained by accommodating ourselves to the enemy몭s purpose.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮An alternative formulation is: 몬If the enemy is poised to advance, set an ambush and retreat; if the enemy is poised to withdraw, open up and strike.몭몯
Basically, to get something you have to give something. Directing the course of a battle is about going along with the enemy몭s desires, giving them a sense of accomplishment, getting them to let their guard down, and then attacking.
Du Mu comments: 몮Accommodate yourself to the enemy몭s purpose. That is why Sun Tzu says that if you want to strike the enemy but see no vulnerabilities, then you must hide your army and conceal all traces of yourself. Whatever the enemy might do, accommodate him and do nothing to startle him. If he tries to overawe you with aggression, then you must make yourself seem cowardly and hide. Accommodate his aggression in order to make him arrogant. Wait until his vigilance slackens and then attack. If the enemy wants to withdraw whence he came, then open a gap in your encirclement so that he may depart. Pursue and strike him as he retreats. The purpose in all of these actions is to accommodate the enemy.몯
If you want to inflict damage on the enemy, the principle is always the same: go along with what they want and let them be the makers of their own undoing. That몭s why, although it can be unpleasant to hear honest advice from a loyal advisor, evil advisors always fawn over you and go along with whatever you say.


몮By massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy, we shall succeed in the long run in killing the commander-in-chief. This is called the ability to accomplish a thing by sheer cunning.몯

몮Massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy몯 is about throwing the full force of your entire army at a single point in the enemy lines.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy, we shall be able to capture their general even if we must first travel 1,000 li to reach him. This is what is called the ability to accomplish things through sheer cunning.몯
The knack of dictating how a battle unfolds is about pretending to go along with what the enemy wants, making him drop his guard, and then stealthily massing your forces and striking with speed and in a single direction, capturing and killing the enemy officers and soldiers. This is how to use cunning to get things done.
Our historical example for this section is one we몭ve seen before: the story of how the Xiongnu chieftain Modun defeated the Donghu people. Modun had seized the throne after killing his father, Chanyu Touman. While he was still new on the throne, the Donghu thought they could bully him. They sent an envoy with this message: 몮Your father, Touman, had a terrific horse, a very fast horse. How about you hand it over?몯 Modun몭s advisors said that the Donghu had no manners, but Modun replied: 몮It몭s just a horse, why shouldn몭t we give it as a gift to our friends?몯 So, he gave away the horse.
Another Donghu envoy arrived and asked if Modun would give them one of his wives, since he had so many. His advisors were furious and exclaimed that this was a terrible insult, and an army must be sent to punish the Donghu. But Modun said: 몮It몭s just a woman, why not give one to our Donghu brothers?몯
So, he gave away one of this wives.
Now it wasn몭t just the Donghu who thought Modun was weak and an easy target; even Modun몭s own advisors gave up on him. After a while, another Donghu envoy arrived. The envoy said that there was a 1,000-li stretch of deserted land between the Xiongnu and Donghu territories. This land had no owner, so would Modun be willing to draw a new border and recognize it as Donghu territory?
Modun called another meeting of his advisors. Some of them thought: since you didn몭t have any problems giving away your own wife, what몭s a piece of deserted land worth? You might as well give it away; why are you even asking us? 
Modun flew into a rage:
몮The land is the very substance of our country! How could I give it away?몯 He killed the advisors who몭d suggested giving up the land, immediately raised an army, and launched a long-distance surprise attack on the Donghu, who were totally unprepared. The Donghu king was killed, and their land, people and livestock became Modun몭s property.

몮On the day that you take up your command, block the frontier passes, destroy the official tallies, and stop the passage of enemy emissaries.몯

This is about the need to keep your secrets. Cao Cao comments: 몮Having determined your plan, close the passes, every transmission of enemy travel, and do not allow passage to their emissaries.몯
Once you몭ve decided to go to war, close the mountain passes, cancel and invalidate all travel documents, forbid all travel by civilians, and don몭t let any enemy agents into your territory. This is how to prevent leaks of military intelligence and stop the enemy from finding out anything about your situation.

몮Be stern in the council-chamber, so that you may control the situation.몯

When making major military decisions, do it in the temple, in conditions of strict secrecy.
Du Mu comments: 몮Hold discussions in the temple, control the whole process. Having already established what the outcome will be, mobilize your armies.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Major military issues must not be discussed lightly; they ought to be discussed in the temple, with the proper reverence and sternness. Control the situation; information about important plans must not be allowed to circulate outside the temple.몯
So, there are two levels of meaning here. First, plan first and act later, or win first and fight later. Second, do your planning in seclusion and make absolutely sure to keep it secret.

몮If the enemy leaves a door open, you must rush in.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮If there is a vulnerability in the enemy lines, rush in.몯
However, this can also result in your own defeat. The enemy몭s 몬vulnerability몭 might be a trick designed to lure you in.

몮Forestall your opponent by seizing what he holds dear, and do not fight on any fixed day or time.몯


몮Seizing what he holds dear몯 is about occupying whichever strategic location the enemy is most attached to. For example, when Li Shimin went to war against Dou Jiande, he occupied Hulao Pass and blocked Dou Jiande from entering his territory through the pass. Cao Cao comments: 몮This is about controlling the most advantageous and expedient factors.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮This is about seizing whatever the enemy몭s war effort depends upon.몯 This could be a strategic location, or it could also be food, fodder and supply wagons. 
The next part, 몮do not fight on any fixed day or time,몯 requires quite a lot of explaining.
Cao Cao comments: 몮Setting out after the enemy but arriving before him.몯 That몭s all well and good, but Cao Cao hasn몭t explained the meaning of the passage.
Du Mu comments: 몮Here, 몬subtly,몭 a misinterpretation of the character wei (윫[bd44]), refers to concealment. The character qi refers to a location to which the enemy is attached for the advantages it offers; the general must occupy this location, and so he must secretly travel there so as not to make the enemy aware.몯
Du Mu몭s interpretation of 몬subtly,몭 as referring to concealment, makes perfect sense. There are several Chinese words and terms in which this character (wei) is used to mean 몬in concealment.몭 However, his claim that qi means 몬that which is desired몭 doesn몭t match up with the grammar of the sentence. The subject of the verb qi is 몬the general,몭 not the enemy. So, this interpretation doesn몭t fully make sense.
Du Mu isn몭t the only commentator to interpret the passage this way. Chen Hao, Mei Yaochen and Wang Xi all agree with him, and all four of them were influenced by Cao Cao몭s comment. But, what connection is there between Cao Cao몭s comment 멪 몬setting out after the enemy but arriving before him몭 멪 and 몬subtly contrive?몯 The commentators argue that 몬subtly몭 is about casually leaking information to the enemy. The reasoning is that if you occupy a location, but the enemy doesn몭t know you몭re there, he won몭t come. And what are you supposed to do then? You have to subtly leak information to the enemy so that he몭ll come, and only then can you fight him.
With all due respect, I think the four commentators overthought this one. Their explanations, along with Du Mu몭s and Cao Cao몭s, left me unsatisfied. So, I went to the Academy of Military Science of the Chinese People몭s Liberation Army to look for the book, A Translation of Sun Tzu몭s Art of War with Annotations, by academy vice president General Guo Huaruo. His comment on this passage was very simple: don몭t arrange with the enemy to set a date for the battle.
After further investigation, I found that the words conventionally translated as 몬subtly contrive몭 (wei yu) actually mean 몬don몭t do it this way.몭 There몭s a well-known phrase in Chinese, 몭Poor man come; here몭s food,몭 which means food that is donated with contempt.몯 Originally, it comes from a passage of the ancient text, The Book of Rites, from the chapter entitled Tan Gong II.  This is the relevant passage:
몮During a great famine in Qi, Qian Ao had food prepared on the roads, to wait the approach of hungry people and give to them. (One day), there came a famished man, looking as if he could hardly see, his face covered with his sleeve, and dragging his feet together. Qian Ao, carrying with his left hand some rice, and holding some drink with the other, said to him, 'Poor man! Come and eat.' The man, opening his eyes with a stare, and looking at him, said, 'It was because I would not eat (when told) 몬Poor man come; here's food,몭 that I am come to this state.' Qian Ao immediately apologized for his words, but the man would not take the food and died. When Zengzi heard the circumstances, he said, 몬Do not behave like this! When the other expressed his pity as he did, the man could have gone away. When he apologized, the man could have taken the food.몭몯
When the starving man refused to eat the 몬poor man, come몭 food that Zengzi had offered, Zengzi used the same phrase from the Sun Tzu passage (wei yu), followed by: 몮You몭re within your rights to turn down the offer when a man calls you 몬poor man,몭 but it also would have been perfectly acceptable to eat the food after he apologizes.몯 A commentator on the text named Zheng Xuan wrote: 몮Wei is used in the same way as the word 몬don몭t.몭 The intent of the passage is to tell the starving man not to speak so imprudently.몯 The scholar Kong Yingda commented: 몮Wei means 몬do not.몭 Yu is merely an auxiliary word. The passage means: 몬Starving people should not behave in such a way!몭몯
So, wei yu means 몬don몭t.몭 There are further examples of wei being used in this way, such as in Memorial to Yueyang Tower, by Fan Zhongyan.
The relevant passage from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War is typically translated as, 몮Subtly contrive to time his arrival on the ground몯 actually means, 몬War isn몭t a gentleman몭s duel; don몭t arrange with your enemy to set a time and place for the battle.몭 You need to be prepared to take the enemy by surprise at any moment, and to attack where he몭s unprepared. This explanation is the only one that makes sense in the context of the rest of The Art of War.

몮Tread the inked line and follow the enemy, and accommodate yourself to the enemy until you can fight a decisive battle.몯

몮Tread the inked line and follow the enemy.몯 This line raises more questions. The 몬inked line몭 means 몬convention몭 or 몬customary rules.몭 When a carpenter needs to cut wood to make a piece of furniture, the first thing he does is draw an inked line on the wood, which he then cuts along. But, in the original Chinese, it몭s unclear whether 몬tread몭 means that you should follow the rules or go against them.
You몭d think that it would mean you should follow the rules. After all, that몭s the normal meaning of 몬tread the line.몭 But in ancient Chinese, the word for tread is interchangeable with another word of the same pronunciation that means to cut or eliminate. So, it would also be correct to interpret it as meaning 몬don몭t follow the rules.몭 
Du Mu says that it means you should follow the customary rules: 몮The word 몬ink몭 here refers to 몬customary rules.몭 The meaning is that you must always tread the line of the customary rules, staunchly follow the system of rules and follow enemy몭s situation closely; if there is any opportunity to exploit, advance and prepare to fight a decisive battle.몯
But, Jia Lin interprets it to mean that you shouldn몭t follow the rules: 몮Here, the word 몬tread몭 means 몬to tread on.몭 The word 몬ink몭 means 몬rules.몭 Follow closely the enemy몭s plans in order to engage in a decisive battle and accomplish your task. Advantageous conditions are what bring victory; you must not base all of your actions upon conforming to the rules.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮When treading the inked line, do not always act the same way.몯 He doesn몭t say whether 몬treading the inked line몭 means 몬obey the rules몭 or 몬disobey the rules.몭 He몭s saying that when you do obey the rules, don몭t always stick to convention.
General Guo Huaruo comments: 몮When implementing your war plans, you need to be flexible in following changes in the enemy몭s situation and correct your plans accordingly. This should inform your decisions about what course of military action to take.몯 This is the correct explanation.

몮At first, then, exhibit the coyness of a maiden, until the enemy gives you an opening; afterwards, emulate the rapidity of a running hare, and it will be too late for the enemy to oppose you.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮Make yourself seem weak like a maiden, then fly like a hare on the run.몯


Appendix: Complete text of The Nine Situations

Sun Tzu said: 몮The art of war recognizes nine varieties of ground: (1) Dispersive ground; (2) Facile ground; (3) Contentious ground; (4) Open ground; (5) Ground of intersecting highways; (6) Serious ground; (7) Difficult ground; (8) Hemmed-in ground; (9) Desperate ground. When a chieftain is fighting in his own territory, it is dispersive ground. When he has penetrated into hostile territory, but to no great distance, it is facile ground. Ground the possession of which imports great advantage to either side is contentious ground. Ground on which each side has liberty of movement is open ground. Ground which forms the key to three contiguous states, so that he who occupies it first has the world at his command, is a ground of intersecting highways. When an army has penetrated into the heart of a hostile country, leaving a number of fortified cities in its rear, it is serious ground. Mountain forests, rugged steeps, marshes and fens 멪 all country that is hard to traverse 멪 this is difficult ground. Ground which is reached through narrow gorges, and from which we can only retire by tortuous paths so that a small number of the enemy would suffice to crush a large body of our men: this is hemmed-in ground. Ground on which we can only be saved from destruction by fighting without delay is desperate ground. On dispersive ground, therefore, fight not. On facile ground, halt not. On contentious ground, attack not. On open ground, do not try to block the enemy몭s way. On the ground of intersecting highways, join hands with your allies. On serious ground, gather in plunder. In difficult ground, keep steadily on the march. On hemmed-in ground, resort to stratagem. On desperate ground, fight. Those who were called skillful leaders of old knew how to drive a wedge between the enemy몭s front and rear; to prevent co-operation between his large and small divisions; to hinder the good troops from rescuing the bad, the officers from rallying their men. When the enemy troops were scattered, they prevented them from assembling, and when the enemy몭s men were pressed together, they prevented them from uniting. When it was to their advantage, they made a forward move; when otherwise, they stopped still. If asked how to cope with a great host of the enemy in orderly array and on the point of marching to the attack, I should say: 몬Begin by seizing something which your opponent holds dear; then he will be amenable to your will.몭 Rapidity is the essence of war: take advantage of the enemy몭s unreadiness, make your way by unexpected routes, and attack unguarded spots. The following are the principles to be observed by an invading force: The further you penetrate into a country, the greater will be the solidarity of your troops, and thus the defenders will not prevail against you. Make forays in fertile country in order to supply your army with food. Carefully study the well-being of your men, and do not overtax them. Concentrate your energy and hoard your strength. Keep your army continually on the move, and devise unfathomable plans. Throw your soldiers into positions whence there is no escape, and they will prefer death to flight. If they will face death, there is nothing they may not achieve. Officers and men alike will put forth their utmost strength. Soldiers when in desperate straits lose the sense of fear. If there is no place of refuge, they will stand firm. If they are in hostile country, they will show a stubborn front. If there is no help for it, they will fight hard. Thus, without waiting to be marshaled, the soldiers will be constantly on the alert; without waiting to be asked, they will do your will; without restrictions, they will be faithful; without giving orders, they can be trusted. Prohibit the taking of omens, and do away with superstitious doubts. Then, until death itself comes, no calamity need be feared. If our soldiers are not overburdened with money, it is not because they have a distaste for riches; if their lives are not unduly long, it is not because they are disinclined to longevity. On the day they are ordered out to battle, your soldiers may weep, those sitting up bedewing their garments, and those lying down letting the tears run down their cheeks. But let them once be brought to bay, and they will display the courage of a Chu or a Gui. The skillful tactician may be likened to the shuairan. Now, the shuairan is a snake that is found in the Chang Mountains. Strike at its head, and you will be attacked by its tail; strike at its tail, and you will be attacked by its head; strike at its middle, and you will be attacked by head and tail both. Asked if an army can be made to imitate the shuairan, I should answer, 몬Yes.몭 For the men of Wu and the men of Yue are enemies; yet if they are crossing a river in the same boat and are caught by a storm, they will come to each other몭s assistance just as the left hand helps the right. Hence it is not enough to put one몭s trust in the squaring of horses, and the burying of chariot wheels in the ground. The principle on which to manage an army is to set up one standard of courage which all must reach. How to make the best of both strong and weak 멪 that is a question involving the proper use of ground. Thus, the skillful general conducts his army just as though he were leading a single man, whether he likes it or not, by the hand. It is the business of a general to be quiet and thus ensure secrecy; upright and just, and thus maintain order. He must be able to mystify his officers and men by false reports and appearances, and thus keep them in total ignorance. By altering his arrangements and changing his plans, he keeps the enemy without definite knowledge. By shifting his camp and taking circuitous routes, he prevents the enemy from anticipating his purpose. At the critical moment, the leader of an army acts like one who has climbed up a height and then kicks away the ladder behind him. He carries his men deep into hostile territory before he shows his hand. He burns his boats and breaks his cooking pots; like a shepherd driving a flock of sheep, he drives his men this way and that, and nobody knows whither he is going. To muster his host and bring it into danger: this may be termed the business of the general. The different measures suited to the nine varieties of ground; the expediency of aggressive or defensive tactics; and the fundamental laws of human nature: these are things that must most certainly be studied. On contentious ground, I would hurry up the rear. On open ground, I would keep a vigilant eye on my defenses. On ground of intersecting highways, I would consolidate my alliances. On serious ground, I would try to ensure a continuous stream of supplies. On difficult ground, I would keep pushing on along the road. On hemmed-in ground, I would block any way of retreat. On desperate ground, I would proclaim to my soldiers the hopelessness of keeping their lives. For it is the soldier몭s disposition to offer an obstinate resistance when surrounded, to fight hard when he cannot help himself, and to obey promptly when he has fallen into danger. We cannot enter into alliance with neighboring lords until we are acquainted with their designs. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the country 멪 its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and precipices, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantages to account unless we make use of local guides. To be ignorant of any one of the following four and five principles is inconsistent with the way that hegemons and kings use military force. When a hegemon or a king attacks a powerful state, his generalship shows itself in preventing the concentration of the enemy몭s forces. He overawes his opponents, and their allies are prevented from joining against him. Hence he does not strive to ally himself with all and sundry, nor does he foster the power of other states. He unfurls his own personal designs, keeping his antagonists in awe. Thus he is able to capture their cities and overthrow their kingdoms. Bestow rewards without regard to rule, issue orders without regard to previous arrangements; and you will be able to handle a whole army as though you had to do with but a single man. Use them only to achieve things; never tell them your design. When the outlook is bright, bring it before their eyes; but tell them nothing when the situation is gloomy. Place your army in deadly peril, and it will survive; plunge it into desperate straits, and it will come off in safety. For it is precisely when a force has fallen into harm몭s way that is capable of striking a blow for victory. Success in warfare is gained by carefully accommodating ourselves to the enemy몭s purpose. By massing our soldiers in a single direction and advancing upon the enemy, we shall succeed in the long run in killing the commander-in-chief. This is called the ability to accomplish a thing by sheer cunning. On the day that you take up your command, block the frontier passes, destroy the official tallies, and stop the passage of all emissaries. Be stern in the council-chamber, so that you may control the situation. If the enemy leaves a door open, you must rush in. Forestall your opponent by seizing what he holds dear, and do not fight on any fixed day or time. Tread the inked line and follow the enemy, and accommodate yourself to the enemy until you can fight a decisive battle. At first, then, exhibit the coyness of a maiden, until the enemy gives you an opening; afterwards, emulate the rapidity of a running hare, and it will be too late for the enemy to oppose you.몯


Chapter Twelve: Attack by Fire

Targets to attack with fire

Extract from the original text:
몮There are five ways of attacking with fire. The first is to burn soldiers in their camp; the second is to burn stores; the third is to burn baggage trains; the fourth is to burn depots; the fifth is to hurl dropping fire amongst enemy units.몯

Analysis:
These five 몬ways of attacking with fire몭 correspond to five types of target: personnel, supplies, supply wagons, weapon stores and 몬armed units.몭
Attacking personnel with fire means setting fire to enemy camps and burning enemy soldiers.
After Guan Yu was killed during the Three Kingdoms period, his ally Liu Bei was hungry for revenge. He mobilized his troops and invaded the kingdom of Wu, but his camps were set on fire by Lu Xun and he fled back home, defeated. Soon after, he vomited blood and died. This is an example of targeting enemy personnel with fire. But, this method doesn몭t necessarily involve setting fire to enemy camps. During the chaotic final years of the Tang dynasty, Zhu Wen, who later became Emperor Taizu of the dynasty, found himself with an army in an untamed grassland wilderness, facing off against the combined armies of the military governor of Tianping Circuit, Zhu Xuan, and his brother, Zhu Jin. At first, wind was blowing from the southeast into the face of Zhu Wen몭s army, which frightened his men. After a while, the wind suddenly changed direction; it was now blowing from the northwest. Immediately, Zhu Wen gave the order to start a fire, and soon flames and smoke were billowing into the sky and churning towards the enemy Tianping army. Zhu Wen pressed his advantage, launching a blistering attack, decimating the Tianping army and killing Zhu Xuan.
몬Burning stores몭 is about burning the enemy몭s equipment, food, fodder and whatever other supplies they might have.
During the Chu-Han Contention (206-202 BCE), Liu Bang and Xiang Yu once found themselves in a standoff at Chenggao. Liu Bang몭s Han army had seized a granary, and he wasn몭t worried about running out of food or water. Meanwhile, he sent General Liu Jia with 20,000 infantry and several hundred cavalry to cross White Horse Ford, drive into Chu territory and go about reaping destruction and burning Xiang Yu몭s grain stores. The Chu army was left with even less to eat than before.
During the early years of the Sui dynasty (581-617 CE), Gao Jiong presented a plan to Emperor Wen.  Gao Jiong wanted to destroy the state of Chen, one of the Southern Dynasties, and his plan was to burn Chen몭s supplies. Gao Jiong pointed out that in the southern areas of China, people lived in thatched grass houses, and unlike northern storehouses, which tended to be built underground, southern storehouses were elevated above ground on wooden and bamboo stilts. This was because the south몭s moist ground made it impossible to preserve supplies in underground cellars. These elevated, wooden storehouses were extremely vulnerable to fire. So, Gao Jiong dispatched special forces to go around the state of Chen starting storehouse fires. The southerners would rebuild the structures after they were burned down, but soon after they몭d be burned down again. This constant harassment left the people of Chen in a state of desperate poverty.
A passage from earlier in The Art of War says: 몮An army without bases of supplies is lost.몯 몬Burning stores몭 is about leaving your enemy without any supplies.

몬Burning baggage trains몭 and 몬burning depots몭 are both about burning the same kind of things: supplies. The only difference is that the former is about burning supplies while they몭re being transported, while the latter is about burning them while they몭re in storage.
Du Mu comments: 몮Weapons, equipment, supplies, money and clothes; when in transit on wagons, it is referred to as 몬baggage trains.몭 When in storage inside cities or camps, it is referred to as 몬depots.몭 In both cases, the items are the same.몯
In the Battle of Guandu (200 CE) Cao Cao defeated Yuan Shao by burning his depots.
The most important items under the umbrella of 몬baggage trains몭 and 몬depots몭 aren몭t limited to weapons and foodstuffs; money and its equivalents are also important. Cao Cao wrote: 몮If the army has no funds, the soldiers won몭t come.몯 If you몭re unable to give soldiers cash rewards, you몭ll have a hard time fighting battles.
There are a few different explanations for 몬burning armed units.몭
Li Quan comments: 몮Burning enemy units몭 weaponry.몯
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Burning enemy units몭 weaponry in order to seize their implements of war.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Burning enemy units몭 weaponry in order to render them disunified and lacking implements of war. Hence it is said: 몬Without sharp weapons, it is difficult to contend with the enemy.몭몯
If you burn their flags, they have no signal system for relaying commands; if you burn their weapons, they can몭t fight. It몭s just like in the movies, when soldiers sneak into the enemy camp while everyone몭s asleep and steal all the guns. When they have no guns, all you have to do is send in a single soldier with a gun, and the enemy soldiers will all surrender.
Jia Lin and He Shi몭s comments are different from the others. In their interpretation, 몬army unit몭 should actually be translated as 몬passages,몭 meaning 몬roads.몭 So, the meaning becomes 몬burn the enemy몭s supply routes and destroy their transport links.몭
Other commentators say that it몭s about burning the enemy몭s logistical units, including transport facilities.
So, what did Sun Tzu actually mean? I tend to think it몭s about burning enemy units몭 weaponry, but General Guo Huaruo thinks it몭s about burning enemy supply routes. Sun Tzu can몭t stand up and tell us what the right answer is, but I think that if you manage to set fire to any of the suggestions above, you몭re doing well. If you succeed at burning something of the enemy몭s, you몭ve done a good job. If you don몭t, knowing what the right answer is won몭t do you any good.


When you attack with fire, you몭re basically giving your enemy moxibustion therapy

Extract from the original text:
몮In order to carry out an attack, we must have means available. The material for raising fire should always be kept in readiness. There is a proper season for making attacks with fire, and special days for starting a conflagration. The proper season is when the weather is very dry; the special days are those when the moon is in the constellations of the Sieve, the Wall, the Wing or the Cross-bar; for these four are all days of rising wind.몯

Analysis:
몮In order to carry out an attack, we must have means available.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮The 몬means몭 are 몬guileful people.몭몯 You need to plant agents on the inside.
Li Quan also thinks it몭s about having men on the inside: 몮The 몬means몭 refers to placing guileful people within enemy ranks.몯
Chen Hao comments: 몮You must command factors that are beneficial to you, not only 몬guileful people.몭몯 The key is to have the various things needed for war, not necessarily just men on the inside.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮In any assault involving attack by fire, dry weather is a requirement. If the enemy몭s shelters and structures are built of grass or bamboo, if their stores are concentrated or kept close to undergrowth and brush, then make use of the wind to set fire to them.몯
In the previous historical example, we talked about how Lu Xun defeated Liu Bei by burning down his camps. This happened because Lu Xun realized that the other army몭s structures were built of grass and bamboo, and his stores were concentrated and kept close to undergrowth and brush. In other words, all the preconditions that Sun Tzu mentions were there. When Zhu Wen was preparing to fight Zhu Xuan and Zhu Jin, their armies were positioned in an overgrown grassland. As soon as the wind changed, and began blowing towards Zhu Xuan and Zhu Jin, Zhu Wen seized his chance and started a fire.
In both of the cases above there was no need to plant a 몬guileful man몭 on the inside. So, when Sun Tzu writes that 몮in order to carry out an attack, we must have means available,몯 the main point is that you need to have the preconditions in order, and you don몭t necessarily need an agent behind enemy lines. Situations that call for planting an agent often revolve around attacking cities. An agent inside an enemy city can start fires as a way to spread chaos, and use the pandemonium as cover to open the city gates and let your soldiers come rushing in from outside.
So, if you몭re defending a city and a fire starts inside your walls, the first thing to do is not to rush to put it out. Instead, secure the gates as your first priority, because that fire was likely started by an enemy agent who몭s trying to distract you.


몮The material for raising fire should always be kept in readiness.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮Materials such as mugwort, reeds and rushes, dry grass, and oil must be prepared in advance. Methods which can be used to fight in this way include rockets, fire sickles, 몬fire apricots,몭 몬fire troops,몭 몬fire animals,몭 몬fire birds,몭 몬fire bandits,몭 and 몬fire crossbows.몭몯
몬Fire rockets몭 are made by attaching a small pouch of oil to an arrow. When you hit an enemy building or boat with a fire rocket, the oil pouch bursts, spraying the oil all around. Then, you ignite it by shooting a fire arrow at the same spot. Once a fire has started, you can shoot more fire rockets at the same spot to feed the flames and burn the target to ashes.
몬Fire sickles몭 are objects used to make sparks and start fires. It몭s called a 몬sickle몭 because of its shape, which is curved. When you strike it with a flint, it makes sparks.
몬Fire apricots몭 were another device used in ancient Chinese warfare to hit the enemy with fire. When besieging a city, the attackers would stuff a bundle of mugwort grass inside an apricot pit, light it, tie it onto a bird몭s foot, and let the bird go. The bird takes shelter under the eaves of a building, by which point the apricot pit has completely burned up and the flames catch on the building. With enough fire apricots, you can start fires at many locations, all over an enemy city. The mugwort grass used in fire apricots is the same as the mugwort used today in moxibustion therapy, a traditional Chinese medical treatment. It burns slowly and steadily, and the fire doesn몭t go out until there몭s no mugwort left to burn. If you want to use fire as a weapon, mugwort is an essential item. When you attack with fire, you몭re basically giving your enemy moxibustion therapy.
몬Fire birds몭 are used in combination with fire apricots. They몭re a way to carry a fire source (the fire apricot) and weaponize it.
몬Fire animals몭 employ the same approach as fire birds, using mugwort grass as a fire source. The idea is to catch a wild pig, deer or something similar, light the mugwort, tie it to the animal몭s neck and drive it towards the enemy camp.
There몭s a story from the Spring and Autumn period of making a whole battle line with 몬fire oxen.몭 The state of Yan had invaded the state of Qi, and had already captured over 70 towns and cities. A Qi general named Tian Dan, who led the defense of the city of Jimo, gathered over 1,000 oxen, tied knives onto their horns and oil-dipped reeds to their tails, dressed them in colorful dragon pattern coats, and lit the reeds. Maddened by terrible pain, the oxen charged toward the Yan camp, closely followed by 5,000 of the best Qi warriors. That charge smashed the Yan army to splinters, and soon after the 70 lost cities were recovered. But, does this count as an example of 몬fire animals?몭 Perhaps this could be written up as one especially innovative way to use fire animals, but not what Sun Tzu originally meant.
몬Fire bandits몭 are agents sent behind enemy lines to start fires.
몬Fire troops몭 are cavalry units tasked with starting fires. Equipped with flammable materials and fire starters, they move directly into the enemy camp and set things ablaze.
During the Battle of Guandu, Cao Cao personally led 5,000 infantry and cavalry with a bundle of grass for every man. Using the enemy commander Yuan Shao몭s own flag signals to conceal their identity, they advanced quickly along back roads, under the cover of night, and launched a surprise attack on the town of Wuchao. When they arrived there, they immediately surrounded the place and attacked with fire. This is a classic example of using 몬fire troops.몭
몬Fire crossbows몭 are basically a means of launching fire arrows. At night, prime the crossbows, set the tips of the arrows on fire, shoot several hundred of them at once into the enemy camp, wait for your opponents몭 supplies to burn and for their forces to descend into chaos멞 and then attack.

몮There is a proper season for making attacks with fire, and special days for starting a conflagration.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Do not use this indiscriminately.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮You must not use this randomly, but should wait for the right time.몯
Being able to start a fire depends on the weather. You can몭t just use fire whenever you want. It몭s important to make sure that all the preconditions are in order, and only then to attack with fire.

몮The proper season is when the weather is very dry; the special days are those when the moon is in the constellations of the Sieve, the Wall, the Wing or the Cross-bar; for these four are all days of rising wind.몯

Zhang Yu comments: 몮When the weather is dry, it is easy to start fires.몯 The right time to start a fire is when both the weather and the materials to be burned are completely dry.
When choosing a day, you need to choose one when the moon is in either 몬The Winnowing Basket,몭 몬The Wall,몭 몬The Wings,몭 or 몬The Chariot,몭 all of which are names of constellations. In ancient Chinese astronomy, 28 constellations were used as reference points when observing the positions of various celestial bodies.
All 28 are close to the equator, and are divided into four groups of seven: 1) In the east, the Azure Dragon, consisting of The Horn, The Neck, The Root, The Room, The Heart, The Tail and The Winnowing Basket; 2) In the north, the Black Tortoise, consisting of The Dipper, The Ox, The Girl, The Emptiness, The Rooftop, The Encampment and the Wall; 3) In the west, the White Tiger, consisting of The Legs, The Bond, The Stomach, The Hairy Head, The Net, The Turtle Beak and The Three Stars; 4) And in the West, the Vermilion Bird, consisting of The Well, The Ghost, The Willow, The Star, The Extended Net, The Wings and The Chariot. It was believed in ancient China that windy weather came while the moon was passing through The Winnowing Basket, The Wall, The Wings and The Chariot. Together, they were known as 몬the four windy constellations.몭 There are similar myths in western culture 멪 for example, the ancient Babylonian name for The Chariot was 몬The Wind Star.몭


Attacking by fire: Five changes

Extract from the original text:
몮In attacking with fire, one should be prepared to meet five possible developments: (1) When fire breaks out inside to enemy몭s camp, respond at once with an attack from without; (2) If there is an outbreak of fire, but the enemy몭s soldiers remain quiet, bide your time and do not attack; (3) If it is possible to make an assault with fire from without, do not wait for it to break out within, but deliver your attack at a favourable moment; (4) When you start a fire, be to windward of it. Do not attack from the leeward; (5) A wind that rises in the daytime lasts long, but a night breeze soon falls. In every army, the five developments connected with fire must be known, and a watch kept for the proper days. Hence those who use fire as an aid to the attack show intelligence; those who use water as an aid to the attack show strength. By means of water, an enemy may be intercepted, but not robbed.몯

Analysis:
몮In attacking with fire, one should be prepared to meet five possible developments멞몯
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮As the fire develops, maneuver your forces in response.몯
Whenever you use fire as part of an attack, you need to coordinate your troop movements with the fire as it develops.
The 몬five developments몭 correspond to the five ways of attacking with fire that we looked at earlier: burning personnel, burning stores, burning baggage trains, burning depots and burning enemy units.
So, how do you coordinate troop movements with fire? Sun Tzu writes about each of the five in turn, so it makes sense to explain the 몬five possible developments (of attacking by fire)몭 one by one:

1. 몮When fire breaks out inside the enemy몭s camp, respond at once with an attack from without.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮In all cases involving fire, spread panic and confusion among the enemy and, availing yourself of this, strike. It is not for nothing that fire is said to be a way to defeat one몭s enemies. As soon as you hear that a fire has started, attack immediately. If the fire is extinguished and the enemy soldiers are calm when you attack, then there is no advantage for you. Hence it is said 몬respond at once.몭몯

When you use fire, you몭re not necessarily pinning all your hopes on literally burning the enemy to death. Use it to panic the enemy and then take advantage of the confusion to attack. You should move in as soon as you hear a disturbance in the enemy camp. If you wait until the fire has been put out and the enemy soldiers have calmed down, you might as well not have started a fire in the first place. That몭s why you have to 몬respond at once.몭

2. 몮If there is an outbreak of fire, but the enemy몭s soldiers remain quiet, bide your time and do not attack.몯

If a fire starts in the enemy camp but the enemy soldiers remain remarkably calm and quiet, that shows that the opposing general has tight control over his army, that his men are highly trained, and that they were prepared for this scenario. In this case, don몭t attack. Wait for a while and try to make the fire bigger. If you see an opportunity, attack. If you don몭t, you몭d better forget about it.

There is no situation where the only good choice is to attack. Don몭t feel that you몭re wasting your time. It몭s a stronger move to waste your time than to take a beating and limp home, let alone taking a beating and getting trapped, unable to make your way home. If you can attack, then attack. If you can몭t, don몭t. It몭s necessary to know when to stop. A general who by his nature can몭t accept the idea of getting no return on his work 멪 who won몭t stop until he몭s had a 몬proper fight몭 멪 is just lining up for defeat.

3. 몮If it is possible to make an assault with fire from without, do not wait for it to break out within, but deliver your attack at a favourable moment.몯

If you start a fire from the outside, you don몭t need to plant an inside man. All you have to do is choose the right time to start the fire.

Li Quan comments: 몮Cao Cao used this stratagem at the Battle of Guandu, to set fire to over ten thousand wagons in Yuan Shao몭s baggage train and defeat him. This demonstrates the meaning of this passage.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮The preceding text says that the five developments of attacking by fire must occur within. But if the enemy camp is situated in a grassy wilderness area, or if the camp몭s stockades of walls can be burned, then you must start a fire immediately rather than wait for an agent behind enemy lines to act. Otherwise, there is a risk that the enemy will take the initiative to burn down the grass around his camp, depriving you of the opportunity to start a fire.몯

If the enemy pre-emptively burns down the grass around his camp, any fire you start won몭t be able to reach their camp.

When a Han dynasty general named Li Ling fought a campaign against the Xiongnu, the Xiongnu forces started a fire upwind of his position. Li Ling rushed to burn down the grass around the perimeter of his camp so that the enemy몭s fire couldn몭t reach him. This is a method to rescue yourself from grassland wildfires.

During the final years of the Eastern Han dynasty, General Huangfu Song finally did battle with Bo Cai, a leader of the Yellow Turban Rebellion. Huangfu Song had taken a defensive position in the city of Changshe (located to the northeast of present-day Changge County City, in Henan Province), and Bo Cai came to lay siege to Changshe at the head of a large army. There were precious few soldiers in the Changshe garrison, and facing attackers who massively outnumbered them fear spread through the ranks of the city몭s defenders. Huangpu Song declared: 몮All manner of strange developments occur in war, and not because of one army having more or less troops than the other. The bandits who oppose us are currently encamped in a grassy area where a fire could easily be started with some assistance from the wind. If a fire is lit under cover of night, then the enemy army is sure to fall into panic and mayhem. At that time, I will send out our forces to attack and we can thus recreate the effect of Tian Dan몭s 몬fire oxen.몭몯

The weather was on his side. That night, a strong wind began to blow. Huangpu Song ordered his men to take unlit torches and assemble atop the city walls, and then sent a squad of elite troops out of the city to start a fire and wildly yell and shout. Then, the men on the city walls lit their torches and joined in the shouting. Huangpu Song rode the momentum his men had created, sounding the war drums and charging forth. The Yellow Turbans panicked and fled in disarray.

4. 몮When you start a fire, be to windward of it. Do not attack from the leeward.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮To do so would not be convenient.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮If the wind blows from the east, then set the fire eastward of the enemy position. Then, launch an attack following the wind and come from the east. If the fire comes from the east, but you attack from the west, then you will suffer the fire몭s depredations just as the enemy does.몯

Du Mu몭s comment explains why Cao Cao says: 몮To do so would be inconvenient.몯

Actually, it would be more than just inconvenient. Zhang Yu comments: 몮When you burn the enemy, they are sure to flee before the fire. If you attack from the direction toward which they몭re fleeing, a fight to the death will surely ensue.몯 If you stand between the enemy and their escape route away from the flames, they몭ll fight for their lives and almost certainly defeat you. Think about it: when an 80-storey building catches fire, people jump from the windows to their certain death rather than being roasted alive. So, of course men fleeing from a fire would be prepared to fight like animals against anyone standing in their way.

That몭s why you set a fire from upwind and don몭t attack from downwind. You can attack from the same direction the fire is moving, or you can attack from the left or the right. Wang Xi comments: 몮One may also strike the enemy몭s left or right flank.몯

During the chaos that enveloped China during the final years of the Sui dynasty, one of the warriors who rose up was a man named Liu Yuanjin. Liu proclaimed himself Son of Heaven, destined to be Emperor, and he commanded a powerful army. To deal with him, Emperor Yang of Sui dispatched his general, Wang Shichong, but Wang was unable to best Liu in battle. Liu Yuanjin was adept at attacking with fire, and every one of his soldiers was always equipped with a handful of reeds because, as Su Tzu wrote, 몮If it is possible to make an assault with fire from without, do not wait for it to break out within, but deliver your attack at a favourable moment.몯 He kept his army ready to start a fire at a moment몭s notice. The two sides fought a significant battle at Yanling, where Wang Shichong몭s men were so startled by the fire Liu Yuanjin started that they were about to abandon their camp and flee. Suddenly, the wind changed and began driving the fire back towards Liu몭s own army. Liu몭s camp was burned down and Wang Shichong took advantage of this opportunity to take the fight to his enemy, inflicting a heavy defeat on Liu Yuanjin. Liu never recovered from this setback, suffered a string of defeats, and was eventually beheaded by Wang Shichong.

When you use fire as a weapon, remember that the wind can change.

5. 몮A wind that rises in the daytime lasts long, but a night breeze soon falls.몯

This observation comes from experience. Cao Cao comments: 몮One should be mindful of this.몯

There몭s a passage from Lao Tzu몭s Tao Te Ching that reads: 몮High winds do not last all morning. Heavy rain does not last all day.몯 It means that anything that moves with frenzied force will not last long. 몮One should be mindful of this.몯

Wind and rain, an army몭s morale, a man몭s vigilance 멪 all of these things are variable, and none of them are unlimited. The art of war is about studying, understanding, balancing and making use of the ebb and flow of these 몬variables,몭 both in your own army and in the enemy몭s.


몮In every army, the five developments connected with fire must be known, and a watch kept for the proper days.몯


So, it몭s necessary to understand the five different changes that can occur when using fire, stay mindful of these changes and take a flexible approach to using fire.

몮Hence those who use fire as an aid to the attack show intelligence; those who use water as an aid to the attack show strength. By means of water, an enemy may be intercepted, but not robbed.몯

This is saying that it몭s better to attack with fire than with water.
몮Those who use fire as an aid to the attack show intelligence.몯 Clearly, generals who use fire to aid their attack gain an easier path to victory.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮One can understand how to easily secure victory.몯
몮Those who use water as an aid to the attack show strength.몯 It is possible to strengthen your attacking position by using water as an aid. So, if you can use fire, you can understand how to win easily, while using water merely strengthens your attack. Why? 
몮By means of water, an enemy may be intercepted, but not robbed.몯 Water can be used to cut off an enemy army몭s movements, but it can몭t deprive them of their supply stores.
But what exactly is the meaning of 몬robbed몭 in this passage? According to all 11 of our commentators, it means 몬robbed of their stores.몭
Cao Cao comments: 몮By using water as an aid, one can sever supply routes and separate enemy forces, but one cannot rob the enemy of their stores.몯 Unlike fire, water cannot burn the enemy몭s grain and wagons.
Personally, I think that the objects being 몬robbed몭 also include the lives of enemy troops. Fire몭s 
몬killing power몭 is much greater than water몭s. Many people can swim, but I몭ve never heard of anyone who can swim through fire. When Japan invaded China in the 1930s, Chiang Kai-shek blew up the levees on the Yellow River at Huayuankou, which only succeeded in slightly delaying the Japanese army and came at a massive cost in lives of the Chinese people.
A lot of stories that involve attacking with water should be taken with a grain of salt. For example, the story of Han Xin drowning Long Qie몭s army 멪 which was cited earlier in the book 멪 is very suspect. According to the tale, Han Xin ordered his soldiers to dam a river using over 10,000 sandbags. While Long Qie몭s army was crossing the depleted river downstream, Han Xin ordered his men to remove the sandbags, releasing the river and drowning Long Qie몭s men. Zeng Guofan researched this story and came to the conclusion that it was physically impossible. If it were possible, Zeng would have very much liked to use the stratagem himself. As noted previously, how could it possible to build a dam capable of holding back enough water to drown a large army with sandbags, and then tear it down with just a few moments몭 work? In hydropower station construction, completing a dam capable of holding back the water is a major engineering project 멪 how could something like that be accomplished with a group of men carrying sandbags? Even if it were possible to build a dam in this way, it would never have been possible to demolish it  at a moment몭s notice. Gunpowder, which could conceivably have been used to blast open a dam, hadn몭t yet been invented.
It would, however, be possible to drown an enemy city if you could surround it and channel a river into the city. During the Spring and Autumn period, Zhi Bo of Jin once coerced the noble houses of Han and Wei into surrounding the house of Zhao, and channeled the Fen River in an attempt to submerge the city of Jincheng. However, Zhi Bo didn몭t get his way in the end. The Zhao leaders persuaded the leaders of Han and Wei to unite, and together they destroyed Zhi Bo. Ultimately, the state of Jin was divided between the three noble houses and became the states of Han, Wei and Zhao, which were three of the seven contending states during the Warring States period.
In conclusion, fire is fast and water is slow.


The key to winning a fight: Can you afford to win?

Being able to afford victory is just as important as being able to afford to lose. If you win a battle but can몭t afford victory, you몭re in serious trouble.
That몭s why generals who always win end up dead. As we몭ve said so often, the key is to settle the war with a single battle.

Extract from the original text:
몮Unhappy is the fate of one who tries to win his battles and succeed in his attacks without cultivating the spirit of enterprise; for the result is waste and general stagnation. Hence the saying: The enlightened ruler lays his plans well ahead; the good general cultivates his resources. Move not unless you see an advantage; use not your troops unless there is something to be gained; fight not unless the position is critical. No ruler should put troops into the field merely to gratify his own spleen; no general should fight a battle simply out of pique. If it is to your advantage, make a forward move; if not, stay where you are. Anger may in time change to gladness; vexation may be succeeded by contentment. But a kingdom that has once been destroyed can never come again into being; nor can the dead ever be brought back to life. Hence the enlightened ruler is heedful and the good general full of caution. This is the way to keep a country at peace and an army intact.몯

Analysis:
몮Unhappy is the fate of one who tries to win his battles and succeed in his attacks without cultivating the spirit of enterprise; for the result is waste and general stagnation.몯
Our 11 commentators seem to have agreed on how to interpret 몬cultivating the spirit of enterprise몭 and 몬waste and general stagnation.몭 They explain it as referring to a situation where, after a battle, the general doesn몭t hand out rewards quickly enough, which leaves the soldiers wondering what they몭re supposed to do. The army becomes stuck, unable to return home, and all the while the money dwindles and the troops grow old waiting. Cao Cao was the first commentator, and his interpretation may have influenced the others몭 observations. 
Cao Cao comments: 몮Just like water that flows away, it is impossible to return things to their previous state. It could also be expressed like this: the rewards are not dispensed in a timely manner; to make effective use of rewards, one cannot delay until the next day.몯
Cao Cao is saying that you have to give out rewards on the same day as the battle. Any delay will lead to waste and 몬general stagnation.몭
Comments by Li Quan, Jia Lin, Du Mu and Zhang Yu are almost the same as Cao Cao몭s, although with one or two minor differences. Later scholars weren몭t satisfied with this interpretation, and neither am I. The 몬spirit of enterprise몭 that must be cultivated isn몭t just about rewarding soldiers for their service; this is only one small part of it. What this passage is really about is consolidating gains after battle and clarifying the political situation.
It bodes poorly for any general to not consolidate his gains after winning a battle, or to fail to clarify the political situation. It will lead to disaster 몬waste and general stagnation몭 멪 in other words, disaster.
After winning a battle, it몭s crucial to win the political battle. Otherwise, the 몬victory몭 you just won on the battlefield will turn into a disaster. Active battlegrounds are quagmires, and when the fighting몭s done they become black holes, sucking up your money and your troops몭 stamina. If you stay there, you몭re setting yourself up for catastrophe.
A classic example of 몬waste and general stagnation몭 is the Wu invasion of Chu during the Spring and Autumn period. Sun Tzu himself was involved in the war. King Helu of Wu came to power by killing King Liao and seizing the throne. He was an enthusiastic reformer, and his army grew stronger. He went head to head with the state of Chu, aiming to become the dominant power among the various Chinese states. In the third year of his reign, he invaded Chu together with the strategists Wu Zixu, Bo Pi and Sun Tzu. They won a great victory, and King Helu want to push on immediately and capture the city of Ying, capital of Chu. But, Sun Tzu told him that the people were worn out, and the time was not right to attack Ying. They should wait for an opportunity. Only when Sun Tzu spoke out did King Helu let go of his burning desire to move on Ying immediately.
Wu scored two more major victories over Chu, once in the fourth year of King Helu몭s reign and again during the sixth year. Between these campaigns, Wu also defeated the state of Yue during the fifth year of the king몭s reign. By the ninth year of his reign, King Helu could no longer hold himself back. He went for advice to Wu Zixu and Sun Tzu: 몮You both were against invading Ying all those years back. Well, what about now?몯 Wu Zixu and Sun Tzu were unanimous: if alliances with the states of Tang and Cai could be secured, an invasion of Ying could go ahead. The Wu army once again invaded Chu, and this time took the city of Ying in one fell swoop. The King of Chu fled his country, and this became the first example of a state capturing the capital city of another major state during the Spring and Autumn period.
