The war between Wu and Chu lasted nine years. What was the prevailing state of affairs? Waste and general stagnation. Why? Because the sole focus was war; nobody was thinking about politics. Not only did King Helu fail to take any political action or 몬cultivate the spirit of enterprise몭 after occupying Chu, he didn몭t even have a coherent approach to politics in his own country. While he wallowed in waste and stagnation in the city of Ying, the leaders of Yue saw their chance and invaded Wu. Meanwhile, the remaining Chu forces requested assistance from the state of Qin, whose leaders sent their army to attack the Wu forces. Fighting a war on two fronts, the Wu forces were defeated in their battles against both the Qin and the Yue forces. Helu몭s younger brother, Fugai, saw how Helu was idling away his time in Ying, with no intention of returning to Wu, so he went back alone and proclaimed himself the new king.
With the country in chaos, Helu rushed back from the city of Ying with his army to attack Fugai, which allowed the Chu forces to retake the now empty city of Ying. Fugai, coming under attack from his older brother, fled and surrendered to the Chu authorities.
After years of war, Helu had nothing to show for it. Despite that, he invaded Chu again the very next year and won another big victory.
Helu몭s army was always a force to be reckoned with. Its power reverberated across the lands of China. However, nothing lasts forever. In the 19th year of King Helu몭s reign he suffered a serious injury while fighting against Yue forces, and later died of his wounds. He was succeeded by his son, Fuchai. When Helu was on his deathbed, he told Fuchai to never forget the man who killed his father 멪 King Gou Jian of Yue. 
The story of Fuchai and Gou Jian is well known among Chinese people. It ends with Fuchai and his country being destroyed by Gou Jian, making Wu one of the first major states during the Spring and Autumn period to be tossed into the dustbin of history.
몮Unhappy is the fate of one who tries to win his battles and succeed in his attacks without cultivating the spirit of enterprise.몯 The most classic example of this is the state of Wu, from the same time period as Sun Tzu몭s life. In ancient China, there was the idea that 몬He who wins many victories is doomed.몭 If you win 100 battles, you몭re going to die. Isn몭t that a strange idea? This saying actually originated as a comment on the state of Wu.
Marquess Wen of Wei once said to Li Ke: 몮Why was the state of Wu destroyed?몯 Li Ke replied: 몮Because Wu fought many battles and won many victories.몯 Marquess Wen said: 몮It is a blessing for a country to fight many battles and win many victories. So why was the state of Wu defeated?몯 Li Ke told him: 몮Many battles make the people poor; many victories make the lord arrogant. The state of Wu was destroyed because an arrogant lord ruled over an impoverished people.몯
The strategist Wu Qi had a similar understanding:
몮Attacking and winning is easy, maintaining one몭s victorious position is difficult. Hence it is said: 몬Among all the warring states of the world, those who win five victories suffer great catastrophe, those who win four victories face many problems, those who win three victories become regional hegemons, those who win two victories become king, those who win one victory become Emperor.몭 Hence, rare are those states who conquer the world by winning many victories, yet many such states suffer destruction.몯
Xiang Yu fought and won dozens of battles, while his rival Liu Bang only won a single battle, at Gaixia.
Attacking and winning is easy; maintaining one몭s victorious position is difficult. This is the case today for the United States. Invading Iraq was as easy as cutting up a rotten tree, but holding onto victory is another story. The US has been unable to hold its position in Iraq, in Libya, and indeed anywhere else. In Iraq, America fell into 몬waste and general stagnation.몭 Obama was[bd45][TT46] unwilling to stay mired in this state because it would only lead to more losses. But if you have a girlfriend, you can몭t just break off your relationship the moment you feel like it, and you certainly can몭t undo the invasion of a foreign country the moment you feel like it. These conflicts started with chaotic invasions and ended with the United States running away.
Victory isn몭t easy!

몮Hence the saying: The enlightened ruler lays his plans well ahead; the good general cultivates his resources. Move not unless you see an advantage; use not your troops unless there is something to be gained; fight not unless the position is critical. No ruler should put troops into the field merely to gratify his own spleen; no general should fight a battle simply out of pique. If it is to your advantage, make a forward move; if not, stay where you are. Anger may in time change to gladness; vexation may be succeeded by content. But a kingdom that has once been destroyed can never come again into being; nor can the dead ever be brought back to life. Hence the enlightened ruler is heedful and the good general full of caution. This is the way to keep a country at peace and an army intact.몯

So, a wise ruler thinks through these things very carefully, and exceptional generals are obligated to do their research thoroughly. If there몭s no benefit to be gained, don몭t take action. Don몭t raise an army if you can몭t win, and don몭t fight unless the situation demands it. Rulers can몭t go on the warpath just because they몭re angry, nor can generals start a battle merely because they몭re enraged. Action should only be taken if there몭s some benefit to be gained for the country, and war should be stopped the moment it becomes unbeneficial for the country. Joy can be restored after an episode of anger, but a destroyed country cannot be revived, and the dead cannot be brought back to life. A wise ruler has to be cautious and a good general has to stay vigilant.
This is the only way to keep your country safe and your army intact!


Appendix: Complete text of Attacking by Fire

Sun Tzu said: 몮There are five ways of attacking with fire. The first is to burn soldiers in their camp; the second is to burn stores; the third is to burn baggage trains; the fourth is to burn depots; the fifth is to hurl dropping fire amongst enemy units. In order to carry out an attack, we must have means available. The material for raising fire should always be kept in readiness. There is a proper season for making attacks with fire, and special days for starting a conflagration. The proper season is when the weather is very dry; the special days are those when the moon is in the constellations of the Sieve, the Wall, the Wing or the Cross-bar; for these four are all days of rising wind. In attacking with fire, one should be prepared to meet five possible developments: (1) When fire breaks out inside the enemy몭s camp, respond at once with an attack from without; (2) If there is an outbreak of fire, but the enemy몭s soldiers remain quiet, bide your time and do not attack; (3) If it is possible to make an assault with fire from without, do not wait for it to break out within, but deliver your attack at a favourable moment; (4) When you start a fire, be to windward of it 멪 do not attack from the leeward; (5) A wind that rises in the daytime lasts long, but a night breeze soon falls. In every army, the five developments connected with fire must be known, and a watch kept for the proper days. Hence those who use fire as an aid to the attack show intelligence; those who use water as an aid to the attack show strength. By means of water, an enemy may be intercepted, but not robbed. Unhappy is the fate of one who tries to win his battles and succeed in his attacks without cultivating the spirit of enterprise; for the result is waste and general stagnation. Hence the saying: The enlightened ruler lays his plans well ahead; the good general cultivates his resources. Move not unless you see an advantage; use not your troops unless there is something to be gained; fight not unless the position is critical. No ruler should put troops into the field merely to gratify his own spleen; no general should fight a battle simply out of pique. If it is to your advantage, make a forward move; if not, stay where you are. Anger may in time change to gladness; vexation may be succeeded by contentment. But a kingdom that has once been destroyed can never come again into being; nor can the dead ever be brought back to life. Hence the enlightened ruler is heedful and the good general full of caution. This is the way to keep a country at peace and an army intact.몯


Chapter Thirteen: The Use of Spies

Giving money to other people isn몭t the same as stating their value; It몭s stating your own value

Extract from the original text:
몮Raising a host of a hundred thousand men and marching them great distances entails heavy loss on the people and a drain on the resources of the State. The daily expenditure will amount to a thousand ounces of silver. There will be commotion at home and abroad, and men will drop down exhausted on the highways. As many as seven hundred thousand families will be impeded in their labor. Hostile armies may face each other for years, striving for the victory which is decided in a single day. This being so, to remain in ignorance of the enemy몭s condition, simply because one grudges the outlay of a hundred ounces of silver in honors and emoluments, is the height of inhumanity. One who acts thus is no leader of men, no present help to his sovereign, no master of victory. Thus, what enables the wise sovereign and the good general to strike and conquer, and achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men, is foreknowledge. Now this foreknowledge cannot be elicited from spirits; it cannot be obtained inductively from experience, nor by any deductive calculation. Knowledge of the enemy몭s dispositions can only be obtained from other men.몯

Analysis:
Cao Cao몭s first comment is about 몬the use of spies.몭 몮Those engaged in warfare,몯 he wrote, 몮must use spies in order to learn the actual situation of the enemy.몯

몮Raising a host of a hundred thousand men and marching them great distances entails heavy loss on the people and a drain on the resources of the State. The daily expenditure will amount to a thousand ounces of silver. There will be commotion at home and abroad, and men will drop down exhausted on the highways. As many as seven hundred thousand families will be impeded in their labor.몯

Cao Cao comments: 몮In ancient times, eight households formed one lin. In each lin, one household would contribute soldiers for the army, and the remaining seven would work in supporting roles. This passage says than when an army of 100,000 soldiers is raised, 700,000 households will be left unable to farm their fields.몯
Why did one lin consist of eight households? Du Mu comments: 몮In ancient times, the amount of land one man could farm was called one qing. In any area of nine qing, a well would be dug and dwellings erected in the center-most qing. Eight households would live and farm there, and this area was called a well field. This passage says that 700,000 households will suffer exhaustion on the roads while transporting supplies.몯
The well field that Du Mu mentions is not quite the same as the 몬well field system몭 that Chinese middle school pupils learn about in history class. In history textbooks, the well field system is explained as being a way of dividing land into sets of nine squares, organized in a grid. The size of each square was 100 mu, and the eight squares along the perimeter of the grid were privately owned and farmed by individual families 멪 one per household. The central square was common land. The eight families had to finish working the common land before they could start farming their own private squares. The harvest from the private squares was kept by the families, while the harvest from the common land went to the state. But 몬the state몭 back then wasn몭t the same as now. It didn몭t refer to the whole country, but to noble houses like those of Duke Mu of Qin and Duke Xiang of Song.
But what몭s the difference between this and what Du Mu said? According to Du Mu, the center-most square wasn몭t common land, but comprised the village where the eight families had their houses, their well, and other communal facilities.
There몭s no way to verify whether the well field system of the Zhou dynasty consisted of private fields surrounding one common field. Personally, I have my doubts. For example, the idea of one common field where everyone works together is similar to the People몭s Communes of the collective agriculture era, beginning in the 1950s. In this system, it몭s difficult to monitor and control how much work and effort each person is contributing. Also, why should the harvest from the central common field go to the state? What if there몭s a good harvest for the private fields, but a poor harvest for the common field? It몭s vastly better to just collect tax from each family.
That몭s why I tend to think that the well field system wasn몭t just about drawing up a nine-square grid (in the shape of the character for 몬well,몭 뱖[bd47]). I agree with Du Mu몭s description 멪 farmland around the perimeter with a well and village in the middle.
Eight families in one well field; one family provides soldiers, the remaining seven provide labor and help transporting supplies. So, in total, an army of 100,000 soldiers actually requires the labor of 700,000 families. This is a massive expense.
The expense of mounting a war was covered in great detail in Chapter Two, Waging War. Here, Sun Tzu emphasizes it once more, showing that his value system involves being extremely cautious in matters involving expenses of war and the cost of victory. This is quite different for some people today, who say 몬no matter the cost몭 without thinking. Deng Xiaoping put it succinctly when he said: 몮People say so many empty words.몯 Everything has a cost. The most important calculation to make, whenever you want to do something, is to estimate the cost. If there몭s a potential profit, go ahead. If not, quit while you몭re ahead.

몮Hostile armies may face each other for years, striving for the victory which is decided in a single day. This being so, to remain in ignorance of the enemy몭s condition, simply because one grudges the outlay of a hundred ounces of silver in honors and emoluments, is the height of inhumanity. One who acts thus is no leader of men, no present help to his sovereign, no master of victory.몯

What a resource-intensive thing war is! Armies really do spend years lined up opposite one another, all for the sake of a single day, the day of victory! If you accept the massive expense of keeping an army in the field day after day, yet remain clueless about what몭s going on in the enemy camp just because you can몭t bring yourself to spend money on spies, you are a supremely irresponsible 멪 and even inhumane 멪 general. You몭re not a pillar of your country, and you몭re definitely not a 몬master of victory.몭
Sun Tzu put 몬the height of inhumanity몭 at the top of the list of negative adjectives that describe such behavior, because a general who acts in this way shows disregard for the good of his country and his people. The core values in The Art of War are 몬use benevolence몭 and 몬take whatever action the situation calls for.몭 For any student, it몭s necessary to remember that benevolence and humanity come first, and 몬taking whatever action the situation calls for몭 comes last. Too often, people think that the art of war is essentially about doing whatever is necessary, including using underhanded tricks. If that몭s your interpretation, you몭ll never really understand the art of war.
During the Chu-Han Contention, nobody was more willing to spend money than Liu Bang, and nobody was more reluctant to spend money than Xiang Yu. As the war reached its most intense phase, Xiang Yu trapped Liu Bang behind the walls of Xingyang city. Liu Bang spent a year unable to free himself and totally cut off from reinforcement and supplies. But his advisor, Chen Ping, had a plan 멪 he told Liu Bang to take 40,000 jin of gold from his reserves and bribe some of the Chu generals. The idea was to spread division among the Chu ranks and create distance between Xiang Yu and his general, Zhong Limei, while also removing General Fan Zeng from Xiang Yu몭s inner circle. In the end, by making these strategic expenditures, Liu Bang was able to break out from Xiang Yu몭s siege.
Years later, when Liu Bang was surrounded by the Xiongyu chieftain Modun몭s forces at Baideng, Chen Ping once again came forward with a plan: to offer a large bribe to Modun몭s wife and have her persuade Modun to let Liu Bang go.
Xiang Yu and Liu Bang were on opposite ends of the spectrum when it came to the value they attached to spending money. Xiang Yu had the ability to truly love his people, as if they were his own children, but he had even greater love for the people몭s money. Han Xin gives us some particularly vivid musings about Xiang Yu: 몮When King Xiang saw his people he bestowed compassion, respect and love; he spoke softly to them and whenever one of his people fell ill he would weep and sob and feed them with his own food. When a subject performed some good deed meriting reward of noble title, he would carve an official seal to mark the ennoblement, yet feel loathe to give it to his subject. This is what is known as 몬the benevolence of a woman.몭몯
If you have a problem that can be dealt with by just spending money, that몭s always the lowest-cost solution. If you spend more money on spies than on anything else, it몭s also the most cost-saving investment you could make. Zhang Yu comments: 몮When armies spend long periods of time facing one another in the field and 700,000 households exhaust their wealth and their strength, if the leader has no care for these expenses and yet begrudges the cost of dispensing rewards and noble titles to spies who uncover information about the enemy, then this is the height of inhumanity.몯
This idea seems simple, when you read it in a book. But, in reality, it몭s extremely difficult to apply it in your work process. In fact, it몭s the hardest part of all. What makes it so difficult? The problem is human nature. Specifically, four types of mentality get in the way:
Mentality type one: You몭ve gotten used to spending large sums of money on certain expenses without thinking about it, but any additional small expenses that aren몭t in your budget make you feel extremely uneasy, to the point that you몭re completely unable to spend these small sums.
For example, if you몭re spending money every day on 700,000 households, perhaps one piece of gold per household, that adds up to 700,000 pieces of gold per day. And yet, you don몭t mentally register this expense. It seems like a river 멪 it몭s just there, and it just keeps flowing. But, if you몭re called upon to spend an extra 50,000 per day, you won몭t even consider doing it.
Mentality type two: You keep track of other people몭s money, but not your own.
You don몭t keep track of your own expenses, and you don몭t even know how much money you몭re spending every day on the 700,000 men working for you. But, you do keep a close eye on other people몭s money. When dealing with people you work with, you have thoughts like: 몬So, you몭re really asking for this much money? Do you really have a good reason for asking me for this much? Are you really worth that much to me? Does it match the value you몭ve given me?몭 You don몭t take it well when people ask for money. You feel resentful and reluctant, and you몭d rather make things harder for yourself than let others take advantage of you financially. Xiang Yu is a classic example of this mentality. In his mind, his followers were freeloaders profiting from his military success, and he thought they had no right to want rewards from him.
There몭s one cure for this mentality: understand that giving other people money doesn몭t mean you몭re making a statement about their value 멪 it몭s actually a statement about your own value. You need to give people a lot of money not because they몭re extremely valuable, but because you몭re extremely valuable, and the things you몭re trying to accomplish are extremely valuable.
It몭s like a large corporation that spends a billion dollars to acquire a start-up company, even if the acquisition target has only been running for a year or less and may not even be generating income. Is the start-up really worth a billion dollars? The deal would instantly make the start-up founder richer than the CEO of the corporation that몭s acquiring it. However, if the corporation doesn몭t buy the start-up today, tomorrow it might become a competitor and completely overturn your whole market. From that perspective, a billion dollars suddenly seems like a bargain!
Mentality type three: How do I know it몭s the right move to give that person the money? It몭s possible that I몭ll ultimately realize I gave away my money for something that has no value, or that I gave it to the wrong person entirely!
For example, imagine giving an enemy general a sum of money as a bribe, but after taking your payoff he still refuses to turn against his commander. In your attempt to sow division among the enemy, you몭ve actually played into your opponent몭s hands and caused division in your own organization. So, hasn몭t the money you spent actually made your situation worse?
This is an extremely common mentality. It seems to be rational, but in fact it몭s a dead end. You should have started off by considering the possibility that spending the money might lead you into a trap. If there were 100% certainty that you could solve your problem by spending money, it would be too easy! The world몭s not that simple.
Spending money is sometimes just a way of creating or eliminating certain possible outcomes. There몭s never a guaranteed outcome. Consider again the example of the big corporation acquiring the small start-up. There몭s every chance that if the corporation didn몭t acquire it, the new business would never take off and would never become a competitive threat. Or, a similar start-up might spring up the day after the first one had been acquired. In both cases, there몭s nothing to be done about it, because the start-up is simply worth too much money.
Mentality type four: I only want to spend my money where it really counts.
There몭s an especially effective antidote for this mentality: to believe that the only way to 몬spend money where it really counts몭 is to spend on things that you don몭t want to spend money on.
The only way to increase the odds of spending money where it counts is to spread your spending over a wide enough area. If you succeed in spending just one percent of your money where it counts 멪 on the cutting edge of your operations 멪it will yield a thousand-fold in return. The principle is exactly the same as in investing. Putting long-term work into large-scale angel investing is an integral part of business intelligence-gathering operations.
If you want to spend all of your money 몬where it really counts,몭 you몭re deluding yourself. It will never happen.

몮Thus, what enables the wise sovereign and the good general to strike and conquer, and achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men, is foreknowledge.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮The lord does not move recklessly. When he moves, he is certain of vanquishing the foe. The general does not act negligently in the pursuit of achievements, and so he is sure to achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men. What makes these things possible? Foreknowledge of the enemy몭s situation.몯
A famous general of the Northern Zhou dynasty (557-581 CE), Cavalry General-in-Chief Wei Xiaokuan, led the defence of Yubi Fortress. His greatest skill was keeping the people he worked with happy, and he also knew how to make good use of spies. All of the agents he sent to spy on the state of Northern Qi knew how to execute commands and complete tasks to the best of their ability. There were also subjects of Northern Qi who took his money and passed on information, which helped keep the Northern Zhou fully informed on the latest happenings in Northern Qi. Wei Xiaokuan sent one of his men, a high-ranking general named Xu Pen, to take command of the garrison in a key city. Wei Xiaokuan trusted this man completely, but to his surprise Xu Pen surrendered himself and the city he was responsible for to the Northern Qi authorities. Wei Xiaokuan was enraged, and sent an agent to assassinate Xu Pen. The assassin soon returned, carrying Xu Pen몭s head. Clearly, Wei Xiaokuan had the ability to use spies to accomplish anything his heart desired.

몮Now this foreknowledge cannot be elicited from spirits멞몯

If you want to understand what몭s going on, you mustn몭t use divination or ask ghosts and spirits to help you.

몮멞 it cannot be obtained inductively from experience멞몯

You can몭t make assumptions by drawing on parallels between the current situation and your past experiences.
Du Mu comments: 몮This is about analogy. This passage says that you cannot seek to compare different situations using analogy.몯 This is an important comment, with a lot of information to unpack.
Throughout Chinese history, analogies have always been one of the favorite tools of political advisors and lobbyists, and the same is true today in commercial advertising. For example, in one toothpaste advertisement, an analogy is made between winter snow covering trees in a white coat and the ability of toothpaste to prevent tooth decay. But, what몭s the connection between these two things? Actually, there몭s no connection at all. Can the analogy prove that this brand of toothpaste can prevent tooth decay? Not in the slightest. However, the connection seems reasonable on the surface, and the visual impact of the image makes a strong impression. Sparkling, white teeth appear to be clean, healthy and strong. This is the influence analogies can have on people몭s thinking.
So, when the time comes for us to make a major decision, it몭s necessary to cleanse yourself of the influence of analogy-based thinking. In meetings, speak with precision and discuss each agenda item only in terms of its own merits. Don몭t allow anyone to use analogies, because they can stealthily divert the conversation and make it about something else entirely. They can make people deceive themselves and pass the deception on to others.

몮멞 nor by any deductive calculation.몯

This is another line that has been interpreted in different ways.
Cao Cao comments: 몮It cannot be gauged by reference to other things.몯 You can몭t use the normal way of things, or patterns you have observed from your own experience, to make predictions about what will happen, because exceptions to any rule are always possible.
In fact, Cao Cao got this one wrong in his own career. During the Battle of Red Cliffs, he deployed his boats in a long, linked-up line. When his men reminded him to take precautions, in case the enemy attacked with fire, he gauged the situation 몬with reference to other things몭 멪 he said that because it was winter the wind wouldn몭t blow from the southeast. In the end, though, that몭s exactly what happened.
Li Quan comments: 몮Here, 몬calculation몭 refers to counting and measuring. This passage could be referring to counting and measuring anything, including length, width, distance and size. People몭s emotions are fickle, and it is impossible to gain knowledge from counting and measuring.몯
The later commentators all said more or less the same thing, but none of them asked the most crucial question.  Namely, what is 몬counting and measuring?몭
Later scholars offer an explanation, suggesting that 몬counting and measuring몭 is about measuring the movements (positions) of the sun, moon and stars. Their explanation for this line is that you can몭t use the positions of celestial bodies to learn about the enemy몭s situation. In the classic novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms, we often see Zhuge Liang spending his nights stargazing and trying to calculate whether the heavens are showing him omens fair or ill. But, Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War tells us, this is not reliable.
So, the ancient leaders understood all of this, and none of them indulged in superstition. They recognized that 몬Knowledge of the enemy몭s dispositions can only be obtained from other men.몭 In other words, the only way to gain this knowledge is to have eyes and ears on the ground.
When you read and study, you need to ground yourself in the correct values. From the explanations we몭ve seen about the meaning of 몬deductive calculations,몭 we know there are various ways to understand it. There몭s making deductions based on 몬the normal way of things,몭 counting and measuring data, and reading the stars. But which one is right? It몭s actually not important which one is 몬right.몭 Each provides a different perspective from which to look at problems, and each of these perspectives is extremely valuable 멪 they lead us to think and reflect, and through them we can learn many new things.
Many people look for the answer to this question by analyzing, critiquing and cross-referencing other ancient texts. Yet, all such attempts can only unearth different usages for the word translated as 몬deductive calculation,몭 which they then insert into this passage of The Art of War. You can몭t say that the old writers were wrong, and presume to come up with a new 몬correct answer.몭 The Ming dynasty philosopher Wang Yangming addressed precisely this problem. He said that reading and studying are about what you can get out of them, not about trying to find the 몬right answer몭 by digging through reams of ancient writings.


Five ways to use spies (parts one, two, and three): All doubts ultimately are doubts you have about yourself

Extract from the original text:
몮Hence the use of spies, of whom there are five classes: (1) Local spies; (2) Inward spies; (3) Converted spies; (4) Doomed spies; (5) Surviving spies. When these five kinds of spy are all at work, none can discover the secret system. This is called 몬divine manipulation of the threads.몭 It is the sovereign몭s most precious faculty. Having local spies means employing the services of the inhabitants of a district. Having inward spies means making use of the enemy몭s own officials. Having converted spies means getting hold of the enemy몭s spies and using them for our own purposes. Having doomed spies refers to doing certain things openly for purposes of deception, and allowing our spies to know of them and report them to the enemy. Surviving spies, finally, are those who bring back news from the enemy몭s camp.몯

Analysis:
몮Hence the use of spies, of whom there are five classes: (1) Local spies; (2) Inward spies; (3) Converted spies; (4) Doomed spies; (5) Surviving spies. When these five kinds of spy are all at work, none can discover the secret system. This is called 몬divine manipulation of the threads.몭 It is the sovereign몭s most precious faculty.몯
When you use these five types of spies simultaneously, the enemy is unable to work out how information is leaking out.

몮Having local spies means employing the services of the inhabitants of a district.몯

Our 11 commentators몭 remarks about 몬inhabitants of a district몭 are simple. They don몭t go out of their way to explain what it means 멪 it just means local people in the enemy몭s country.
Du Mu comments: 몮Village people of the enemy몭s country.몯
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Avail yourself of the country몭s people and make use of them by providing them with benefits.몯
Jia Lin comments: 몮Interpret 몬local spies몭 as 몬enemy villagers.몭몯
However, General Guo Huaruo has his own, differing explanation. He says that the word translated here as 몬local몭 (xiang) had different meaning in the ancient Chinese language of the Spring and Autumn period. According to General Guo, it refers to the enemy몭s local government officials and noblemen. In the state of Qi, such people were referred to as xiang liangren, and in the state of Song they were called xiang zheng. According to a subchapter in The Rites of Zhou, entitled Xiang Dafu, those who held the official rank of 몬xiang dafu몭 were positioned between the Minister of Education and the Rural Officer.
General Guo몭s explanation makes an important contribution. He asserted that for a spy to be capable of producing valuable intelligence, they have to have a certain level of status and involvement in local affairs.
A good example of someone who knew how to use local spies is Zu Ti, well known in China for his strong work ethic. Zu Ti came from a high-status northern family, but then the Uprising of the Five Barbarians turned the Chinese world upside down. The Han Chinese people of northern China fled south, the Western Jin dynasty ended, and the Eastern Jin dynasty took its place. Zu Ti was possessed by a burning desire to retake the Central Plain from the barbarians. He was optimistic by nature, much more interested in justice and righteousness than the details of finance. He was also a hard worker, devoted both to academic studies and military training, and an accomplished warrior and thinker. Zu TI was brave, wise and inspired trust in all around him.
Zu Ti loved his men, and in return his men pledged their lives to him. There was no 몬principal몭 he wasn몭t willing to set aside for the sake of his soldiers. His army was sizeable, and included no shortage of rogues and thieves. When famine broke out in Yang Prefecture, some soldiers went around robbing rich families, and when they were occasionally arrested by local authorities, Zu Ti used his local connections to secure their release. Not only did he not criticize them, he would even say things like: 몮How about we go down to Nantang and do a heist together?몯 These actions ensured that every soldier in the land thought their lives would be complete if only they could serve under Zu Ti.
Leaders like Zu Ti, who form close, even brotherly, bonds with their men and are able to make their soldiers absolutely committed to them, are only suited to being regional strongmen. They can never become Emperor, or even a major court minister or advisor. If an Emperor or a prime minister treated the men under their command as their own brothers, willing to cover for their illegal behavior and sloppy discipline 멪 as long as they do whatever is asked of them and ask no questions 멪 they몭re indulging in corruption in exchange for loyalty. They are in effect governing their country using corruption, and the country will fall. A good example of this is Emperor Wu of Liang. 
Zu Ti eventually became a target of the court몭s jealousy and suspicion, and later died in a cloud of anger and resentment. Is it any wonder that a lawless maverick like Zu Ti would attract the enmity of others?
Looking back for a moment at how Zu Ti made use of 몬local spies,몭 he treated them the same way as his own men, like they were his sworn brothers.  His attitude was that, as long as you몭re with me, I몭ll protect you no matter what. While Zu Ti was serving as Governor of Yu Prefecture, he shared a border with Shi Le of the Later Zhao dynasty. China was experiencing a chaotic period at the time, and in the borderlands of the Jin and Zhao states (in modern-day Henan Province), the local strongmen were focused only on protecting their own necks. The border fort commanders all had sons living in Zhao captivity as hostages, so Zu Ti made exceptions for them and let them maintain good relations on both sides of the border. He treated them with special courtesy and got them to provide him with intelligence from contacts in Later Zhao. Occasionally, he would launch a pretend attack against one of the Jin forts to show the Later Zhao authorities that the garrisons had nothing to do with him. Because of this, the fort commanders felt extremely grateful to Zu Ti, so they kept him up to date on all the latest happenings across the border, in the lands of Later Zhao. This was a major factor in Zu Ti몭s success in retaking large swathes of land in the Henan area.

몮Having inward spies means making use of the enemy몭s own officials.몯

Du Mu wrote about seven types of people, and the categories he came up with can be applied to 몬inward spies.몭 Here are his descriptions of the types of officials who might be co-opted:
1. Among enemy officials, there are capable men who have lost their posts.
2. There are those who have made mistakes and been punished.
3. There are those who harbor proclivities or lust after wealth.
4. There are those who are wasting away in lowly positions.
5. There are those who are unable to secure appointments as envoys.
6. There are those who, having suffered defeat and loss, develop their talents and skills.
There are deceptive turncoats who habitually act as double agents.7. 
Du Mu comments: 몮You may secretly approach all of these types of officials and make enquiries. Give them generous presents of gold and silks to form ties with them. In order to acquire intelligence from their country, and investigate any schemes they may be plotting against you, make repeated enquiries about their lord, and the ministers of their country, and spread disharmony in their country.몯
You can find all kinds of people among enemy officials: talented men who have made mistakes and whose career is in jeopardy as a result; people who몭ve been punished and feel resentful; those whose father was punished and as a result of this face roadblocks in their own career. There will be those who are particularly fond of their wives or concubines, or who have some other 몬special interest,몭 and who are also hungry for money. Some will be unsatisfied with their station in life; some feel blocked from realizing their potential; others want their own side to lose because they think it몭s the only way they몭ll get opportunities. And, there are individuals who are constantly changing sides. All of these types of men can be turned into 몬inward spies.몭
However, if you decide to use 몬inward spies,몭 understand that the enemy will try to put on shows for you. For example, when Zhou Yu attacked Huang Gai, he only did it so that Cao Cao would see him doing it. It made Cao Cao think that Huang Gai would be filled with hate and willing to surrender to him; that his defenses would be lowered. In the end, this led to Cao Cao몭s ships being burned by Huang Gai at Red Cliffs.
Sun Tzu himself once fell prey to enemies taking advantage of some of his officials몭 fondness for money and other interests to bribe them. Fuchai of Wu had surrounded Gou Jian of Yue and 5,000 exhausted Yue troops, remnants of a defeated army, at Huiji Mountain. Yue몭s destruction seemed imminent. At the time, there were three high-ranking advisors in King Fuchai몭s entourage: Wu Zixu, Sun Tzu and Bo Pi. Gou Jian sent a messenger to tell King Fuchai that he wanted to surrender, but Wu Zixu urged Fuchai not to give Gou Jian any chances. He advised destroying Yue outright. Meanwhile, Gou Jian sent a man named Wen Zhong to bribe Bo Pi with gold and beautiful women, and to tell him that, despite appearances suggesting that Yue was surrendering to King Fuchai, the real surrender was actually being offered to him, Bo Pi. Wen Zhong also told Bo Pi that, from then on, any time gold, silks or women were sent to the Wu king, Bo Pi would get the first pick. The wealth of Yue was to be at Bo Pi몭s disposal. This convinced Bo Pi to throw all his strength into assisting Yue.
There are certain skills that dishonest advisors have and loyal advisors don몭t. The King of Wu ignored Wu Zixu몭s and Sun Tzu몭s counsel on this matter. He gave his ear exclusively to Bo Pi. Later, Bo Pi worked together with Gou Jian to murder Wu Zixu, despite the favor Wu Zixu had done Bo Pi by recommending him to the King of Wu when Bo Pi had fallen on hard times. The reason Gou Jian later had the nerve to deliver himself as a hostage to the Kingdom of Wu, in a bid to lull Fuchai into a false sense of security, was to a large extent because he had Bo Pi몭s protection. Again, it was Bo Pi who later persuaded Fuchai to release Gou Jian and give him safe passage back home to Yue. And, it was through Bo Pi that Gou Jian sent two famously beautiful women, Xi Shi and Zheng Dan, as gifts to Fuchai. It was also Bo Pi who caused Fuchai to squander his people몭s energy and his kingdom몭s riches by not only suggesting that he rebuild the Gusu Tower, but also arranging for the finest Yue timber to be made available for the job.
Gou Jian made full use of spies, and he used almost the entire contents of The Art of War.  He embraced the notion that 몬all warfare is based on deception몭 in Chapter One, Calculations, through to the concepts of 몬make yourself weak to make the enemy arrogant멞 if he is taking his ease give him no rest멞 and if his forces are united, separate them.몭 Sun Tzu was left with no moves to make; all he could do was watch wide-eyed as the kingdom of Wu was destroyed.
Spies were also a factor in LI Shimin몭s defeat of Dou Jiande.
Li Shimin had surrounded Wang Shichong and Dou Jiande was on the move, intending to rescue Wang. Li Shimin seized the initiative by taking Hulao Pass, and Dou Jiande was unable to break through Li몭s position. Each time Dou attacked the pass, Li몭s soldiers came charging out to beat them back. Dou몭s forces suffered many casualties. Li Shimin weak spot was his fear that Dou Jiande would refuse to fight him at Hulao Pass and instead turn around and attack him from the rear. Doesn몭t The Art of War talk precisely about this? Sun Tzu made it clear that when the enemy has control of 몬contentious ground,몭 don몭t attack. Instead, you should lead your army away and attack places and things that are important to your opponent, which he몭s bound to defend. Draw the enemy out and then ambush him on the road. So what if Li had control of Hulao Pass? Dou should have just left him to it.
This is clearly a simple principle. There were undoubtedly people in Dou Jiande몭s camp who were aware of it. Indeed, an advisor named Ling Jing told Dou Jiande: 몮We should cross the Yellow River with the entire army and move north, attack and seize Heyang in Huai Prefecture, and place a general in charge of defending the city. Then, you should lead the bulk of your forces and, with drums beating and battle flags raised, cross through the Taihang Mountains and move into Shangdang County. But this will be a ruse, and you will hide your true intention. You need not trouble yourself by actually fighting battles. Accelerate the pace of your army몭s march, make for Hukou Pass and, taking Pu Jin by surprise and harassing his forces, seize the land to the east of the river. This is the best strategy, and it offers three benefits: first, by pivoting your army to a position undefended by the enemy, your forces cannot lose; second, by expanding the territory under your control you can recruit more soldiers; and third, the enemy Tang army will then, of its own accord, lift its siege of Wang Shichong몭s position.몯
Ling Jing몭s plan was a textbook application of standard operating procedures for 몬contentious ground,몭 and it also embodied the strategy of relieving a besieged ally by attacking the besiegers in a different location. There몭s nothing particularly cunning about this plan 멪 it was straight from the playbook. Dou Jiande thought this approach made sense, and he initially planned to use it. If he had, though, Li Shimin would have been in big trouble.
But what happened next? Who gave Li Shimin a helping hand? It was Wang Shichong himself. Besieged and desperate, Wang Shichong saw Dou Jiande moving his army away, and the city of Luoyang fell. Wang몭s senior emissary, Sun Anshi, secretly sent gold, silver and pearls to various generals in Dou Jiande몭s army and asked them to persuade Dou not to leave. They said to Dou: 몮Ling Jing is nothing but a student of books, how can you seriously consider his opinions about matters of war?몯
Dou Jiande folded. How could the opinion of a 몬student of books몭 hold up against so many senior generals? So, Dou changed his plan. This decision ultimately ruined him. He was run ragged at Hulao Pass by Li Shimin, captured and sent to Chang몭an, where he was beheaded.
Dou몭s generals had willingly served as agents for Wang Shichong, and they ended up hurting themselves, Dou Jiande and Wang Shichong.
This is the pain of being a leader. Everyone has advice, but while some are loyal servants to their country, others conceal ulterior motives behind their words: desire for power and material gain. How are you supposed to tell the difference? Even the people giving advice can몭t tell! In the case of Dou Jiande, Ling Jing had loyalty and patriotism in his heart, and he spoke plainly and objectively. Meanwhile, the senior generals were in the pockets of Wang Shichong. However, when they spoke to Dou Jiande on behalf of Wang Shichong, they spoke with conviction and strength; in their minds, they didn몭t say what they said only because of the money. So, what was the other reason? It몭s part of the human condition, and as universal now as it always has been 멪 people fool themselves and then fool others. Once the generals believed what they had to say was right and fair, they assured themselves that reason was on their side. They argued that there was no reason to run away from LI Shimin몭s puny force of 3,500 men when Dou commanded an army of 100,000. Yet, in their wisdom they failed to recognize just how brutal and dangerous war truly is.
There are simply too many examples of the use of spies in war. You couldn몭t fit all of them into a single book, even if you wrote about nothing else. It몭s not at all true that all spies always intend to betray their country. In many cases, they aren몭t aware of just how much harm their lies can do. They몭re simply jealous of other, more talented men, and they want to thwart them and ruin their chances of being credited for their national service. Or, they want to feel that their existence has meaning by expressing by their own unique way of seeing a situation. In doing so, they몭re dragged down into murky depths by their country몭s enemies.
People like to sigh over kings and lords who are led astray by the words of petty, immoral men. Yet, such men are not all bad people like Bo Pi was. More often than not, they몭re simply people operating without much understanding of the world. They might believe themselves to be highly loyal to their lord, and their lord also might believe them to be loyal. This is precisely the type of person who is most easily turned into a spy or an agent, because they remain unaware that they몭re serving as a spy. They don몭t understand why the person grooming them to be a spy is giving them gifts, or what that person몭s goal is. These people who have limited vision and understanding, and who become spies, are even more destructive to their country than those who are truly bad! This is because kings and lords don몭t put up any defenses against these kinds of people, in the belief that they don몭t have it in their hearts to do anything bad.
During the infamous Feast at Hongmen, the key factor that allowed Liu Bang to escape was that he had bought off Xiang Yu몭s uncle, Xiang Bo. Did Xiang Bo believe he was doing anything to hurt Xiang Yu? No, he didn몭t. Did Xiang Bo know that, through his actions, he was serving as Liu Bang몭s agent? No. He was just a well-meaning fellow, and he certainly had no malice in him. It never would have occurred to Xiang Yu that he needed to protect himself against Xiang Bo. And yet, Xiang Bo had agreed to marry one of his family members to one of Liu Bang몭s family. As such, before the Feast at Hongmen, Xiang Bo was already kin with Liu Bang.
This is why the state cannot use people who are supposedly of 몬good morals,몭 but who lack talent. Issues that effect an entire country can only be understood by people who have a certain amount of ability 멪 they몭re the only ones who belong in high-level discussions of national importance. Anyway, true morality always comes as a package with talent and ability, because morality is the highest form of insight and understanding. There몭s no such thing as people who are virtuous but untalented. Talent is a precondition for virtue; it몭s impossible for a person with no talent to have moral power.
There몭s another common, and highly dangerous, situation: people who want others to fail so that they have a chance to 몬prove themselves.몭 Initially, everyone on your team might be loyal, patriotic servants of their country, but the moment the king decides to use Advisor A몭s strategy, and not Advisor B몭s, what happens? Will Advisor B want the plan to succeed, or will he want it to fail? In many cases, he몭ll want the plan to fail because then he몭ll have a chance to prove he was right. A certain percentage of advisors will end up serving as an enemy accomplice, precisely because of this.
Those who play turncoat and change sides often play both sides. When people regularly switch their allegiances, both sides want them for their own. However, neither side trusts them, and might cast them out at any moment. General Lu Bu, also known as 몬the slave of three surnames,몭 is a classic example of this. Where did the 몬three surnames몭 come from? His original surname was Lu, so that몭s one. Later, he showed his loyalty to the warlord Ding Yuan by ceremonially recognizing him as his father, making Ding his second surname. He was later bribed by Dong Zhuo, and killed Ding Yuan. He proclaimed that Dong Zhuo was his new father, and so Dong became his third surname. But, it didn몭t stop there. He later killed Dong Zhuo on behalf of Diaochan. So, when Lu Bu offered his fealty to Cao Cao, Cao Cao didn몭t dare trust him. Instead, he sentenced him to death.
It was the same story with Meng Da, another general of the Three Kingdoms period. He started off as a general for the kingdom of Shu but later switched his allegiance to Wei, before finally going back to Shu after being lured back by Zhuge Liang. It was part of Zhuge Liang몭s plan 멪 he leaked information that Meng Da was in contact with Shu leaders so that Wei general Sima Yi would find out, leaving Meng Da with no way back and no option except to work for Shu. Sima Yi knew what kind of man Meng Da was 멪 he knew that he liked to play both sides 멪 so he also wrote letters to him, tempting him to reconsider. Then, Sima Yi moved his army rapidly, and within eight days had arrived at Meng Da몭s city, where he defeated and executed him. Sima Yi managed to deal with the instability Meng Da had created and secure the city, all without taking any losses. Meanwhile, Zhuge Liang also made some small gains: he몭d eliminated one of Wei몭s generals, and he몭d also taken Sima Yi for a ride. And that몭s how Meng Da was cast aside.

몮Having converted spies, getting hold of the enemy몭s spies and using them for our own purposes.몯

몬Converting spies몭 is about enticing enemy spies into working for you. Du Mu tells us there are two ways of enticing enemy spies: 몮If the enemy has spies sent to spy on me, you must know the situation beforehand. You can either entice them with lavish gifts or pretend you are unaware and furnish them with false information by way of contriving performances. Thus, the enemy몭s spies work for you.몯
Either lavish them with gifts to make them willing to work for you, or pretend you don몭t know what몭s going on, put on a show for them, and let them send back misleading information to their master.
During the Chu-Han Contention, Liu Bang managed to catch Xiang Yu using the strategy of 몬converting몭 enemy spies. Liu Bang had the idea to eliminate one of Xiang Yu몭s key men, and his honorary 몬father,몭 Fan Zeng. To achieve this, he first played the 몬inward spies몭 card, using his man Chen Ping to pay 40,000 liang of gold to generals under Xiang Yu몭s command. These generals then spread rumors that Fan Zeng, Zhong Li and other advisors were disgruntled about their supposedly inadequate compensation, and that they were plotting to team up with Liu Bang to destroy King Xiang Yu. It was true that Xiang Yu wasn몭t particularly generous when it came to handing out rewards, so although he didn몭t fully believe the rumors, they still lodged inside his mind. The groundwork was now laid. As we described earlier in the book, when an envoy sent by Xiang Yu arrived at the Han camp, Chen Ping initially greeted him like an honored guest, with all the trimmings, laying out good wine and plenty of meat. But, just as the envoy sat down and began to speak, Chen Ping put on a surprised expression and said: 몮What? You몭re Xiang Yu몭s man? Why did I think it was Fan Zeng who sent you?몯 Immediately, he ordered a servant to clear away the meat and the wine, and began treating the envoy much less respectfully. When the messenger returned to his camp to report, Xiang Yu was furious. He sent Fan Zeng away.
This story seems ridiculous, as if Xiang Yu was a toddler distracted by an adult making silly noises. And yet, somehow Xiang Yu fell for it. Why? One reason is that Chen Ping laid thorough groundwork by spreading rumors and influencing public opinion in Xiang Yu몭s camp. The second reason also had to do with Xiang Yu 멪 he wasn몭t generous enough to the people he worked with. This filled him with secret guilt; he felt uneasy and suspected that any of his men could betray him and go over to Liu Bang.
Suspicion always comes down to self-doubt.
Xiang Yu was by no means wrong to be suspicious. After all, his own uncle, Xiang Bo, had protected Liu Bang at the Feast of Hongmen. He몭d served as Liu Bang몭s 몬inward spy,몭 and it was he who persuaded Xiang Yu not to kill Liu Bang몭s father when the man was in his grasp. When Liu Bang became Emperor of all China, he allowed Xiang Bo to change his surname to Liu as a gift, and granted him the title of Duke of Sheyang.
Liu Bang also fell victim to the stratagem of 몬converting spies몭 at the hands of that bitter foe: Modun, chieftain of the Xiongnu.
Later, General Han Wangxin launched a rebellion against the Han Empire, joining forces with the Xiongnu. Liu Bang, in an attempt to wipe out the Xiongnu with a single blow, sent a dozen or more groups of trusted men to gather intelligence about the enemy몭s strengths and weaknesses. Modun hid his strongest men and horses and made sure the Han envoys saw only the oldest, weakest and most decrepit of his forces. So, the Han scouting parties reported that the Xiongnu were feeble, and that the time to strike was now. Only the lone voice of Lou Jing spoke up to say that this was a trick 멪 he saw that the Xiongnu were using the strategy of 몬converting spies몭 as a misdirection tactic. But, Liu Bang was hell-bent on fighting and flush with confidence. He cursed Lou Jing, saying that he was upsetting his men몭s focus, and locked him up with the threat that he몭d deal with him upon his triumphant return. 
In the end, Liu Bang was surrounded by 400,000 of Modun몭s men on the Baideng plateau, and barely escaped with his life. The only reason he managed to get a peace treaty and safe passage home was that Chen Ping came up with a plan to bribe Modun몭s favorite wife. To Liu Bang몭s credit, he immediately freed Lou Jing, made him Duke of Guannei, and granted him income in perpetuity from the taxation of 2,000 families. As for the dozen or so others who몭d said that it was safe to attack the Xiongnu, he executed them all.
No matter how deeply you read into The Art of War, and try to apply its lessons in the real world, you can never guarantee you won몭t be fooled, because you몭re always dealing with different situations and all kinds of different possibilities.


Five ways to use spies (parts four and five): 몬Doomed spies몭 and 몬Surviving spies몭

Extract from the original text:
몮Having doomed spies, doing certain things openly for purposes of deception, and allowing our spies to know of them and report them to the enemy. Surviving spies, finally, are those who bring back news from the enemy몭s camp.

Analysis:
몮Having doomed spies, doing certain things openly for purposes of deception, and allowing our spies to know of them and report them to the enemy.몯
It doesn몭t get much worse than being a 몬doomed spy.몭 When they몭re sent out on a mission, their own side has already sold them out. What defines a 몬doomed spy?몭 They몭re envoys or agents to whom you hand false information and order to pass it on to the enemy. They몭re not told that the information is false because, first of all, this makes it impossible for the mission to be compromised by an intelligence leak. Second, it makes them better able to win the enemy몭s trust. And third, of course, it means the thought never occurs to them that they should protect themselves. So, when the truth finally comes out for all to see, the unwitting spy is inevitably killed by the enemy. That몭s what makes him a 몬doomed spy.몭
Perhaps the most famous doomed spy was Li Shiqi. He worked for Liu Bang, and he was given the mission of going to the state of Qi and talking their leaders into surrendering. Blessed with a silver tongue, he did actually manage to persuade the King of Qi to give up. Holding his hand over his heart, he assured the king that if anything he몭d said was a lie, the king had his consent to boil him alive. The talks concluded with both the King of Qi and Li Shiqi enjoying a rowdy evening of drinking together. 
Things took a turn when Han Xin, unwilling to let a civilian with a big mouth like Li Shiqi overshadow everything he achieved on the battlefield, turned the tables. Han sent a force to attack Qi, which was totally unprepared. Now Li Shiqi was in a real pickle; he몭d become a doomed spy. Just before Han Xin destroyed Qi entirely, the King of Qi filled a massive cauldron with hot water and boiled Li Shiqi alive.
Another famous example of a doomed spy comes from the Spring and Autumn period. Duke Wu of Zheng had designs on invading the state of Hu. So what did he do? First, he set up a marriage alliance with Hu, arranging for his son to be married to a Hu woman. Then, at a meeting of his court, he told his advisors and ministers that he desired to expand his kingdom, and asked which direction would be the best for him to set his sights on. A senior official named Guan Qisi said: 몮The state of Hu is an appropriate target.몯 It was a good judgment call, but tragically, he didn몭t know that the reason his lord had asked this question was that he wanted a 몬doomed spy.몭 By being the first to put his hand up, Guan Qisi had unwittingly volunteered for the role.  Duke Wu flew into a rage, and said: 몮The people of Hu are our brothers, how dare you suggest we attack them?몯 He had Guan Qisi hauled from the court and executed.
Naturally, news of this episode soon reached the lord of Hu, and he felt full of gratitude! So, he let his guard down, and Duke Wu promptly raised an army and used it to utterly destroy Hu.
In a later era, there was a war between Northern Song and Western Xia. An agent was disguised as a monk, made to swallow a wax pellet and sent into Western Xia territory. He was caught by the local authorities and, after being interrogated, confessed that he had a wax pellet in his stomach. The pellet was taken out, and found to contain a secret message for a senior Western Xia strategist. The strategist was executed, and of course, the 몬monk몭 had to die, too. And so, yet another 몬doomed spy몭 met his cruel fate.

몮Surviving spies, finally, are those who bring back news from the enemy몭s camp.몯

Doomed spies never come back from their missions. 몬Surviving spies몭 are their opposite 멪 they return from their missions alive, bearing information to report to their superiors.
Li Quan comments: 몮They are envoys who return.몯
According to Li Quan몭s interpretation, all diplomatic envoys and messengers are, in a broad sense, spies. They몭re spies who survive.
Du Mu comments: 몮They are messengers who return and deliver reports. When choosing men to be 몬surviving spies,몭 you must select those who are inwardly intelligent but outwardly foolish. They must appear weak but be mentally strong; they must be athletic and brave, unmoved by base concerns, and able to endure hunger, cold, dirtiness and humiliation.몯
During the Northern and Southern Dynasties period (420-589 CE), there was a war between Eastern Wei and Western Wei. Yuwen Tai of Western Wei sent an agent named Daxi Wu to spy on an Eastern Wei military camp at Gaohuan. He dressed in an enemy uniform and took three mounted soldiers with him. When evening fell, he was just a few hundred paces away from the enemy camp. He got down from his horse, listened, and learned the enemy몭s communication signals. Then, he got back on his horse and made his way around all of the nearby enemy camps, posing as a night sentry. He even whipped enemy soldiers who he found breaking the rules. And that몭s how Daxi Wu learned all the ins and outs of the enemy몭s situation, which he reported to Yuwen Tai upon his return home.


What special skill does a person like Chen Ping have? The skill of 몬Dividing up the pork몭

The skill of 몬dividing up the pork몭 is having the ability to weigh the interest of everyone involved, giving full play to each person몭s productivity, and coordinate the relationships between all involved. Being able to divide up the pork is something that political leaders and chief ministers must be able to do.

Extract from the original text:
몮Hence it is that with none in the whole army are more intimate relations to be maintained than with spies. None should be more liberally rewarded. In no other business should greater secrecy be preserved. Spies cannot be usefully employed without a certain intuitive sagacity. They cannot be properly managed without benevolence and straightforwardness. Without subtle ingenuity of mind, one cannot make certain of the truth of their reports. Oh, how subtle! There is nothing for which spies cannot be used.몯

Analysis:
몮Hence it is that with none in the whole army are more intimate relations to be maintained than with spies.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮The soldiers of the army are all to be kept close and treated as intimates, but only spies are to be kept closest to your heart, and you shall be most intimate with spies.몯
Du Mu comments: 몮They receive audiences and commands are issued to them in the inner chambers.몯
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮They enter into your chambers to receive your words; they are your closest relations.몯
Du You comments: 몮If you do not treat them with the utmost closeness and if you do not reward them handsomely, then they will become servants of the enemy and divulge information to them.몯
Any spy you send into the field has the potential to be groomed by the enemy as a 몬converted spy.몭 If you don몭t bind them to you by treating them well, giving them generous rewards and bringing them under your personal leadership, they could be used by the enemy and reveal information about your army몭s situation.
몮None should be more liberally rewarded.몯

Be willing to spend money. Spending on spy operations, no matter how expensive, comes down to pennies when you realize what you몭re buying with that money. You몭re buying the world, and you몭re buying your own life. When you choose whether or not to spend that money, you몭re choosing between gaining control of the entire world and throwing away your life. For example, during the Chu-Han Contention, when Liu Bang was surrounded by Xiang Yu몭s forces, Chen Ping said to him: 몮Are you willing to spend 40,000 gold pieces to buy spies in the chambers of the Chu council?몯 Liu Bang handed over the money immediately, without asking what the plan was, how the money would be spent, or why the price was 40,000 in gold, rather than 30,000 or 50,000.

몮In no other business should greater secrecy be preserved.몯

There몭s no other area of operations where secrecy is more important than in spying. This work belongs underground, cloaked in strict secrecy.
Du Mu comments: 몮What comes out from the mouth enters directly into the ear.몯
Du You comments: 몮If spy work is not conducted in secrecy, you will come to harm.몯
When Chen Ping was planning to pay some of Xiang Yu몭s men to spread rumors, if he hadn몭t kept tight secrecy, he definitely would have ended up dead.

몮Spies cannot be usefully employed without a certain intuitive sagacity.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮First, gauge the character of the person to be employed as a spy. They must be honest, resourceful and wise. Having assured yourself of this, only then take them into your service. They must appear innocent yet be hard to judge, and they must be willing to brave the dangers of wilderness travel. Anybody who is not a sage will fall short.몯
You can feel like you 몬know몭 someone, and yet that knowledge might only be skin-deep. With spies, you have to know their minds, their abilities and intelligence, and you have to be capable of handling them. To manage a spy, you have to be extremely wise.
Wang Xi comments: 몮Being possessed of wisdom and sagacity, you have the ability to know people.몯
Chen Ping took charge of all spy work for his lord, Liu Bang, and many people cast doubts on his character. The most famous rumor about Chen Ping was that he had an affair with his sister-in-law, even though his older brother, her husband, had always treated him well. There was no clear proof that this was true, but the rumor spread far and wide nonetheless. According to another rumor, he몭d taken bribes from his subordinates while serving as an officer in Liu Bang몭s army. He even admitted it when Liu Bang accused him, but he had an explanation  멪 he was new in the army, he had no money, and without money he couldn몭t get anything done. That몭s why he took a bribe, he said. Plenty of people spoke against him, but Liu Bang trusted him and gave him control of the most important, confidential spy work.
So, was Chen Ping a wise man? There are no historical records of his intelligence reports, of who he employed or how he did his business. However, the records do talk about something he did as a young man. In his hometown, the locals were willing to let Chen Ping be in charge of the annual offerings to the gods at the communal shrine; to act as the 몬minister of sacrifices.몭 He directed the event, and was in charge of dividing up the pork among the villagers. The reason they were happy to let Chen Ping take charge was that he always cut the meat up in exactly equal portions. As such, it was common to hear the elders and other villagers saying: 몮Bravo! Chen the scholar is our man, our minister of sacrifices!몯 Young Chen had already mastered the dividing up of the pork.
Chen Ping would get emotional and say: 몮Oh my! If I were to be made prime minister of all China, I would set about my task in the same way as cutting up this meat!몯
So, what is the main skill that people like Chen Ping have? It몭s the skill of 몬dividing up the pork.몭 What this means is having the ability to weigh the interests of everyone involved, giving full play to everyone몭s productivity, and coordinating the relationships between everyone involved. Being able to divide up the pork is something that political leaders and chief ministers must be able to do.
Chen Ping didn몭t just provide Liu Bang with a constant supply of brilliant strategy, helping him take control of all China. He also managed to protect himself after the deaths of both Liu Bang and his wife, Empress Lu, deal with the threat posed by the dead Empress몭 various relatives, keep a steady hand on the Han court and maintain the country몭s stability as prime minister of the Han Empire.

몮They cannot be properly managed without benevolence and straightforwardness.몯

How should we interpret the concepts of 몬benevolence and straightforwardness?몭
Chen Hao comments: 몮Benevolent men touch other people with their grace; straightforward men manage affairs in the proper way. Commanders-in-chief must be able to both bind men to them using benevolence and put them to use by using straightforwardness. Having achieved this, spies will conduct their work to the best of their abilities and serve you happily.몯
Wang Xi comments: 몮Benevolence to bind their hearts to you; straightforwardness to awaken their moral integrity.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Benevolence means being not stingy when dispensing noble rank and rewards; straightforwardness means being resolute and free of doubt. One must both entice men using generous rewards and treat them with the utmost sincerity. Thus, spies will devote all their strength to their work.몯
So, benevolence and straightforwardness are leadership qualities 멨 they enable leaders to close any emotional distance between themselves and their men, and to not hold back when giving out rewards, while also making decisions and dealing with problems decisively, without hesitating. People bend to your will because they see your character, your openness, your generosity, your sense of justice and your powers of insight. This is the way to keep your people grounded, passionately committed to serving you and blissfully unoccupied by other thoughts.

몮Without subtle ingenuity of mind, one cannot make certain of the truth of their reports.몯

Spy work goes so deep and takes place amid such terrible danger, and any spy can be bought over to the enemy몭s side or otherwise fall under enemy control. When you몭re in the business of handling spies, you have to give them your absolute confidence and form strong, emotional bonds with them, while at the same time remembering to trust no one. The dynamic between these two opposing needs is extremely subtle.
When a spy returns home to report, is he telling the truth? The only way to get the truth is to have spies who think and analyze at an extremely sophisticated level. It몭s possible that a spy thinks he몭s telling the truth, but actually he몭s just regurgitating false information fed to him by the enemy. Among those who fell into this trap was Liu Bang, who was otherwise such a brilliant example of using spies. For instance, he fell into a trap set for him by Modun.  As discussed earlier, he listened to the scouting parties who told him the Xiongnu were weak and vulnerable to attack, instead of listening to Lou Jing when he said the Xiongnu were only pretending to be weak as part of a strategy to draw them in. For all Liu Bang몭s wisdom, he somehow still decided to lock up Lou Jing and believe the men who told him to attack. As a result, Liu Bang almost didn몭t make it back from that war.
As is always the case with trickery, Modun몭s ruse could have come from any textbook 멪 you can find clear descriptions of what he did in any 몬Complete Guide to Trickery and Deception.몭 It couldn몭t be any simpler; it몭s even clumsy in its simplicity. Anyone could come up with something similar, and it몭s so obvious that you몭d see through it with a single glance. So, why did Liu Bang fall for it? Wasn몭t he too clever to make such a basic mistake? It was because the false information Modun fed him appealed to his desires and expectations: he was chomping at the bit to destroy the Xiongnu and win even more glory. If you have specific expectations, and if you몭re influenced by greed, you몭ll fall for people몭s tricks.
People sometimes believe things only because they want them to be true.

몮Oh, how subtle! There is nothing for which spies cannot be used.몯


Pay special attention to the low-status people who hang around major actors 멨 These are the people who can help you do big things

Extract from the original text:
몮If a secret piece of news is divulged by a spy before the time is ripe, he must be put to death together with the man to whom the secret was told. Whether the object be to crush an army, to storm a city, or to assassinate an individual, it is always necessary to begin by finding out the names of the attendants, the aides-de-camp, and doorkeepers and sentries of the general in command. Our spies must be commissioned to ascertain these.몯

Analysis:
몮If a secret piece of news is divulged by a spy before the time is ripe, he must be put to death together with the man to whom the secret was told.몯
The spy is put to death as punishment for leaking information, while the person who received the leaked information is put to death to keep him quiet.
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮The spy is killed as a response to his heinous act of divulging information; the person to whom he divulged the information is killed in order to prevent him from telling the information to others.몯
In any confidential work, it몭s necessary to keep tight discipline throughout your organization. Don몭t say a word to anyone, not even your family members. The people who worked on China몭s projects to launch the country몭s first satellite and build its first atomic bomb were separated from their families for years. Their family members didn몭t even know where they몭d gone or when they몭d come back; they weren몭t even allowed to send letters to them. This is the nature of confidential work 멪 if you want people to keep a secret, the best strategy is to make sure they don몭t know the secret in the first place.
Sima Yi pretended to be sick twice in his life. The second time he did it, he tricked Cao Shuang and seized control of the state of Wei. The first time, he몭d been staying home and biding his time, hiding his strength. Cao Cao summoned him to return to work, but he didn몭t yet feel he had a clear enough understanding of the political landscape. He didn몭t want to come out of the political wilderness, so what did he do? He pretended to be sick. Specifically, he said he had rheumatism, but Cao Cao didn몭t buy it and sent a man to his house in the middle of the night to investigate. What he observed was Sima Yi lying motionless inside, his body painfully contorted. After that, Cao Cao believed him. So, whether you몭re pretending to be sick or pretending to be crazy, it몭s important to put on a consistent show, including when you몭re 몬backstage몭 and don몭t think anybody몭s watching. You can몭t afford to be careless, because an investigator could show up at any time and monitor you in secret.
One day, Sima Yi was lying on his side indoors. Meanwhile, he몭d had some of his books made of bamboo slips spread out in the courtyard, to dry in the sun. Suddenly, rain began to hammer down. Sima Yi forgot about his pretend illness the moment he realized his books were about to be ruined, and leapt up to bring them inside. After all, he was a man of learning and a lover of books. But, he몭d been spotted by one of his own serving girls. She was so shocked that her mouth hung open. Sima Yi몭s wife, Zhang Chunhua, was in the house at the time, and she made an instant decision to kill the girl on the spot. She did it with her own hands. Sima Yi wasn몭t the only wolf in his family; his wife was also quite the cold-blooded killer.

몮Whether the object be to crush an army, to storm a city, or to assassinate an individual, it is always necessary to begin by finding out the names of the attendants, the aides-de-camp, and doorkeepers and sentries of the general in command. Our spies must be commissioned to ascertain these.몯

There몭s a lot of information to pick through here, and it explains a lot.
The first thing mentioned in this passage is that you have to know who the enemy commander is. This is the easiest part to understand. When you fight a war, you몭re fighting against the enemy commander, and it is this man몭s competence that decides the fighting capabilities of his army. There몭s a saying that an individual soldier might fight like a lion, but when a powerful general is calling the shots, his army becomes a whole pride of lions. For example, Han Xin had the ability to gather a rag-tag band of sub-par soldiers and turn them into an elite fighting unit. Han Xin was the kind of man who could go into a market and come out again with an army at his back. In other words, he knew how to round up a mob, build it into an army and lead them into a life-and-death battle. General Zhao Kuo, on the other hand, could be given a huge army of 400,000 fighters and somehow still manage to get slaughtered on the battlefield. That몭s why, during the time leading up to the Battle of Changping, the Qin commanders focused on coming up with a way to get the leaders of Zhao to recall General Lian Po from the front lines and replace him with Zhao Kuo. Meanwhile, the Qin leaders quietly put General Bai Qi in charge of their forces, under strict secrecy. It was decreed that anyone who leaked information that Bai Qi had been made commander would be beheaded.
Just like that, the pieces on the chessboard were switched. The original matchup between Lian Po for Zhao, and Wang He for Qin, had become Zhao Kuo for Zhao and Bai Qi for Qin. This led directly to Zhao몭s defeat.
Liu Bang once sent Han Xin, Cao Can and Guan Ying to attack Wei Bao. Liu Bang asked: 몮Who is the greatest general of Wei?몯 
The answer he was given: 몮Bo Zhi.몯
Liu Bang said: 몮Bo Zhi? He몭s barely weaned from his mother몭s teat! He몭s no match for Han Xin.몯
Then Liu Bang asked another question: 몮Who is the commander of their cavalry forces?몯
The answer he was given: 몮Xiang Ta.몯 
Liu Bang said: 몮He can몭t beat Cao Can. Clearly, I have nothing to worry about!몯
So, as a commander-in-chief, you not only need to know everything about the people under your command, you must also have a thorough understanding of the personal background, military abilities, personality traits and even the hobbies and interests of each and every one of the enemy몭s generals.
We몭ve just talked about how a commander needs to understand the enemy commander, but why is it also necessary to understand his attendants, aides-de-camp, doorkeepers and sentries? Zhang Yu elaborates on this by writing about an historical example, and once again it몭s about Liu Bang. Once, Liu Bang was defeated in battle and fled, taking refuge in Han Xin몭s camp. He went straight to Han Xin몭s sleeping quarters, took possession of Han Xin몭s official seal and seized command of his forces. If he hadn몭t done meticulous groundwork beforehand, he could never have marched straight into Han Xin몭s bedchambers without startling the man, regardless of his status as commander-in-chief.
There몭s a similar historical example, except unlike Liu Bang bursting into the sleeping quarters of one of his own men, it involved someone bursting in on the enemy commander-in-chief while he was in bed. This story comes from the Spring and Autumn period, during a time when the states of Chu and Song were at war. The Chu army had been besieging the city of Handan for about a year, and the situation had deteriorated to the point that residents had begun eating one another. Despite that, the defenders of the city were hell-bent on to the death. There would be no surrender. Meanwhile, the Chu soldiers outside the city walls were exhausted. The Song forces were attempting to outlast them 멪 to wait until they몭d burned through all their resources and would be forced to leave. So, the Chu forces began to build houses, plough fields and get ready to plant crops, to show that they were prepared to settle in for the long haul. Their message was clear: they weren몭t going anywhere. Faced with this reality, the Song leader Hua Yuan snuck into the Chu camp at night, went straight to the bed of Zi Fan, the Chu commander-in-chief, and took him captive. There in Zi Fan몭s bed, the two men negotiated. The Chu forces would withdraw, and in return Hua Yuan would travel to Chu as a hostage and sign a peace treaty.
