If it weren몭t for the detailed spy work he did before he made this move 멪 he몭d acquainted himself closely with Zi Fan몭s attendants, aides-de-camp, doorkeepers and sentries, and even come to a silent agreement of sorts with them 멪 how could Hua Yuan have made it to Zi Fan몭s bed?
There몭s one more example. During the Republic of China period (1912-1949 CE), there was a network of underground cells dedicated to resisting the Japanese occupation. As part of their operations, an agent named Dai Li planned to eliminate the Mayor of occupied Shanghai, Fu Xiao몭an. Who did Dai Li go through to accomplish this mission? He used a man who Fu Xiao몭an trusted completely, who몭d served him for decades and whose service spanned a regime change. He was a cook named Zhu Shengyuan. While Fu Xiao몭an was fast asleep in his official residence in Hongkou, Zhu Shengyuan cut his head off with a kitchen knife. It was true that Zhu had been a loyal servant to his master, but his loyalty to his country outweighed that.
That몭s why it몭s important to pay special attention to the low-status people who hang around major actors. These are the people who can help you accomplish big things.


There are five types of spy, but 몬Converted spies몭 are key

Extract from the original text:
몮The enemy몭s spies who have come to spy on us must be sought out, tempted with bribes, led away and comfortably housed. Thus they will become converted spies and available for our service. It is through the information brought by the converted spy that we are able to acquire and employ local and inward spies. It is owing to his information, again, that we can cause the doomed spy to carry false tidings to the enemy. Lastly, it is by his information that the surviving spy can be used on appointed occasions. The end and aim of spying in all its five varieties is knowledge of the enemy; and this knowledge can only be derived, in the first instance, from the converted spy. Hence it is essential that the converted spy be treated with the utmost liberality.몯

Analysis:
몮The enemy몭s spies who have come to spy on us must be sought out, tempted with bribes, led away and comfortably housed. Thus they will become converted spies and available for our service.몯
This part emphasizes that, although there are five different types of spy, the most crucial of these is 몬converted spies.몭
The idea of 몬comfortably housing몭 enemy spies is actually a form of house arrest. Once they몭re safely inside a house, then you can begin to tempt them, corrupt them and bring them over to your side.
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Seek out enemy spies who have come to spy on you, and turn him into your agent by means of generous gifts, temptations and housing. In this case, the meaning of 몬housing몭 is actually detainment. The longer he is kept there, the more he will talk, and thus you will gain intelligence about the enemy.몯
The Han dynasty court and the Xiongnu often sent envoys to each other몭s seat of power, and the vast majority of these envoys also were assigned spy duties. It was common practice for both sides to detain the other몭s envoys. One of them, a man named Su Wu, was held for nineteen years and never gave in to the enemy. The story of Su Wu and how he raised sheep on the plateau later became a famous legend.

몮It is through the information brought by the converted spy that we are able to acquire and employ local and inward spies.몯

Mei Yaochen comments: 몮It becomes possible to make use of subjects and officials of the enemy state, and this is all because of knowledge acquired from converted spies.몯
Zhang Yu comments: 몮Through converted spies, you learn which of the enemy몭s people are susceptible to greedy desires, and you learn which officials of the enemy court are at odds with one another. Then, you can bring them into your service by means of enticements.몯
So, a converted spy is not necessarily someone who fully comes over to your side. It might be someone who you keep detained, who you keep wining and dining and chatting with, until eventually, inevitably, he lets something slip. As Zhang Yu writes: 몮The longer he is kept there, the more he will talk, and thus you will gain intelligence about the enemy.몯

몮It is owing to his information, again, that we can cause the doomed spy to carry false tidings to the enemy.몯

Through the information you learn from converted spies, you can find out exactly what kind of false information can undermine the enemy with the greatest effectiveness. Then, you can dispatch 몬doomed spies몭 to deliver the message.

몮Lastly, it is by his information that the surviving spy can be used on appointed occasions.몯

From information gained from converted spies, you can find out details about the enemy몭s troop density, and use this intelligence to arrange times for 몬surviving spies몭 to return home and report on what they몭ve learned.

몮The end and aim of spying in all its five varieties is knowledge of the enemy; and this knowledge can only be derived, in the first instance, from the converted spy. Hence it is essential that the converted spy be treated with the utmost liberality.몯

In sum, converted spies are at the root of all spy work. You have to spend a lot of money on spy work, and the lion몭s share of that money needs to be spent on converted spies.


The key to 몬Winning first and fighting later몭 is: If you can몭t win, don몭t fight

Extract from the original text:
몮Of old, the rise of the Yin dynasty was due to Yi Zhi who had served under the Xia. Likewise, the rise of the Zhou dynasty was due to Lu Ya who had served under the Yin. Hence it is only the enlightened ruler and the wise general who will use the highest intelligence of the army for purposes of spying and thereby they achieve great results. Spies are a most important element in war, because on them depends an army's ability to move.몯

Analysis:
몮Of old, the rise of the Yin dynasty was due to Yi Zhi who had served under the Xia.몯
Cao Cao comments: 몮Yi Zhi is the same person as Yi Yin.몯
Yi Zhi, also known as Yi Yin, is singled out by Sun Tzu as the first Chinese historical example of a spy. The details of Yi Yin몭s background are a little complicated. It seems he was a chef, a private tutor, a royal teacher, a spy, a general, a prime minister and a sage.
Yi Zhi몭s first role was as a chef, and he몭s considered as one of the fathers of Chinese cuisine. There몭s a concept in Chinese cooking that can be translated as 몬heat control몭 (huohou). It몭s a way of talking about the strength of the cooking flame and the duration of cooking time in relation to one another. Heat control theory was Yi Zhi몭s invention, and he also came up with the idea that taste can be divided into five flavor categories. His approach to cooking had deep theoretical underpinnings.
Yi Zhi served as chef to the lord of the state of Shen, which existed during the Xia Dynasty (2070-1600 BCE), and he also served as a tutor to the children of noble families. He was devoted to the study of two fields of knowledge: crafting delicacies in the kitchen, and effective governance of large states. I have my suspicions that that a phrase coined by Lao Tzu 멪 몬Governing a large state is like cooking tiny delicacies몭 멪 might have been inspired by Yi Zhi. This seems likely to me because Lao Tzu just wrote the words, whereas Yi Zhi could in all fairness be hailed as the father of Chinese cuisine and statecraft. He has been called 몬the original sage of Shang.몭
The founder of the Shang Dynasty (1600-1046 BCE), Shang Tang, was so intent on bringing Yi Zhi into his service that he married a daughter of the lord of Shen. Yi Zhi was sent to Shang as part of the dowry. There몭s a passage in the ancient text, The Book of Mencius, that reads: 몮Shang Tang learned from Yi Yin and later made a minister of him. Hence, he became king easily and without toil.몯 Shang Tang honored Yi Zhi by appointing him royal teacher and taught him the ways of the legendary ancient Emperors Yao and Shun. Shang Tang also assigned Yi Zhi to five different diplomatic missions to visit the last King of Xia, Xia Jie, in the state of Jin. Yi Zhi몭s duties included befriending Xia Jie몭s favorite concubine, Mei Xi, and extracting large quantities of intelligence about the Xia dynasty. His work during these missions was pivotal to Shang Tang몭s success in finally crushing the Xia dynasty.


몮Likewise, the rise of the Zhou dynasty was due to Lu Ya who had served under the Yin.몯

Here, Sun Tzu gives us another example of a historical spy. This time, it was Jiang Ziya, a man from Yin Shang who was pivotal to the rise of the Zhou Dynasty. Jiang Ziya once worked for King Zhou of Shang, and when he came into the service of King Wen of Zhou, he brought with him a huge amount of insider knowledge about the Shang royal court.
Over the millennia since Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War was written, many scholars have struggled to understand why he cited these two men, Yi Zhi and Jiang Ziya, as examples of spies. Some have even been downright disgruntled about it. This is because the majority of people who read, or write commentary about, The Art of War are bookish types, generally with a Confucianist bent. Within the Confucian tradition, both Yi Zhi and Jiang Ziya are venerated as sages and models of Confucian values, and the fact that Sun Tzu describes them as spies doesn몭t sit well with those values. Spies might be important, but in the framework of Confucianism, a true gentleman of noble character would never consider doing the kind of things that are routine tasks in spy work. On top of that, both Yi Zhi and Jiang Ziya played crucial roles in the founding of a new dynasty. How could their glorious contributions be chalked up as spy work?
Mei Yaochen comments: 몮Yi Yin and Lu Ya did not betray their countries. In the case of the former, the Xia dynasty was no longer fit to rule, and so the Shang dynasty rose up; in the case of the latter, the Shang dynasty was no longer fit to rule, and so the Zhou dynasty rose up. The great deeds that these men accomplished were done for the good of the people.몯 They weren몭t treacherous spies, they were moral servants of the country who chose to serve the greater good and promote the betterment of the common people몭s lives.
Zhang Yu wasn몭t happy about the choice of Zhi Yi and Jiang Ziya as examples of spies, either. He writes: 몮Yi Yin was a minister of Xia who later joined Shang; Lu Wang was a minister of Shang who later joined Zhou. Yi and Lu respectively assisted Tang and Wu to restore stability to the world through force of arms. This was in accordance with heaven and with the people of the earth. Their cases are not the same as when Bo Zhouli fled to Chu or when Miao Benhuang went over to Jin.몯
Bo Zhouli and Miao Benhuang are the two standard examples from Chinese history of men who betrayed their countries.
Bo Zhouli was a nobleman from the state of Jin whose father, Bo Zong, was persecuted by 몬the three Xis.몭 He fled his home and went to Chu, where he was appointed prime minister.
Miao Benhuang was a nobleman from the state of Chu. He had the surname Mi, and the clan name Dou. He was in the same clan as Ruo Aoshi, and was the son of Yin Doujiao, who held the official rank of guoling. During the ninth year of the reign of King Zhuang of Chu, Yin Doujia launched a rebellion that soon failed, after which King Zhuang set about exterminating all members of his clan. That was when Miao Benhuang fled to Jin, where the rulers appointed him Chief Strategist and he became one of the venerated 몬eight good ministers of Jin.몭
During the Battle of Yanling, between Jin and Chu, the two men were standing by their respective lords몭 sides, feeding them insider intelligence about the opposing army and making suggestions. Miao Benhaung was the most talented, and the Jin army prevailed.
The Battle of Yanling is a classic example of a major Spring and Autumn period military campaign, and the history books contain vivid records about both of these treacherous officials:
In one such account, Bo Zhouli accompanied King Gong of Chu on an excursion to observe the Jin army camp.
The King of Chu asked: 몮The Jin soldiers are driving their chariots and moving all around at high speed. What are they doing?몯
Bo Zhouli said: 몮They are assembling their officers.몯
The King of Chu said: 몮Those people have gathered in the middle of the camp.몯
Bo Zhouli said: 몮They are holding a meeting. They are discussing among themselves.몯
The King of Chu said: 몮They have erected tents.몯
Bo Zhouli said: 몮They are communing with the late king to divine whether the omens are good or bad.몯
The King of Chu said: 몮Now they have taken down the tents.몯
Bo Zhouli said: 몮They will soon issue commands.몯
The King of Chu said: 몮How noisy it is, and there is dust flying around.몯
Bo Zhouli said: 몮That is because they are preparing to fill in their wells and smash their cooking ranges. They will soon form battle lines.몯
The King of Chu said: 몮They have mounted their war chariots and the men to left and right have taken up weapons and lined up in formation.몯
Bo Zhouli said: 몮They are listening to their commander몭s instructions and commands.몯
The King of Chu asked: 몮Do they mean to start the battle?몯
Bo Zhouli said: 몮I do not know yet.몯
The King of Chu said: 몮Now they have once more mounted their war chariots, and the people to left and right have come down.몯
Bo Zhouli said: 몮They are now making their pre-battle prayers to the gods.몯
Reading this dialogue, we can see why spies are to be feared! Because of them, your enemy can see straight through every little move you make.
Bo Zhouli also told King Gong of Chu where Duke Li of Jin몭s personal unit was located. With this information, the Chu forces knew exactly where they could find the enemy leader.
Of course, Miao Benhuang was providing the same services to the other side, so Chu and Jin were in much the same situation 멪 the Jin forces also knew where the personal forces of King Gong of Chu were located. However, the information Miao Benhuang provided to his side wasn몭t as detailed or vividly expressed, or even as gossipy as Bo Zhouli몭s. But gossipy tidbits don몭t serve much practical use; unlike Bo Zhouli, Miao Benhuang몭s information cut straight to the most crucial details. One of his suggestions for Duke Li of Jin went like this: 몮The Chu forces몭 elite unit is located in the middle of their army, and for the most part they consist of the Chu king몭s personal soldiers. If you allocate some of our elite soldiers to attack and pin down the Chu forces on both flanks of their army, and then focus our entire attacking power on an assault against the personal unit of the Chu king, then we will surely be able to inflict a heavy defeat upon them.몯
Duke Li of Jin did as Miao advised. The Chu army was defeated and withdrew.
King Gong of Chu decided to fight again the next day. On the Jin side, Miao Benhuang informed the entire army that they must prepare to fight again the following day, and then he deliberately let the Chu prisoners of war get away so that they would rejoin their armies and report to their leaders that the Jin forces were preparing to fight. When King Gong found out that the Jin forces were already prepared, he immediately summoned Zi Fan for a consultation about how to respond. But it was nighttime, and Zi Fan was drunk. He couldn몭t answer his lord몭s summons. With no other options, King Gong withdrew his army under the cover of darkness. And that몭s how the Battle of Yanling ended in victory for the Jin forces.
This is why Sun Tzu emphasizes the importance of spies. If you talk about the most valuable personnel you could acquire, nobody몭s more valuable than people from within the enemy몭s organization. But, when you recruit enemy personnel, you have to make sure you get the right people. If you don몭t, you still won몭t be able to defeat your enemies.

몮Hence it is only the enlightened ruler and the wise general who will use the highest intelligence of the army for purposes of spying and thereby they achieve great results. Spies are a most important element in war, because on them depends an army's ability to move.몯

Du Mu comments: 몮Without information about the actual situation of the enemy, your army cannot move. There is no way to gain information about the enemy that does not require the use of spies. Hence it is said: 몬On them depends an army's ability to move.몭몯
Li Quan comments: 몮Sun Tzu몭s treatise about war begins with calculations and ends with spies, for attacking is not the most important thing. How could those who would be generals not reflect upon this with the utmost care?몯
This comment from Li Quan serves well as a conclusion for this book. The essential core of Sun Tzu몭s way of thinking is expressed in just four words:
몮Win first, fight later.몯
The purpose of making calculations is to win before fighting, and to only raise an army once you몭re sure of victory. Likewise, the purpose of spies is also to win before fighting. Once you have information about the enemy몭s situation, and if you know both yourself and your enemy, it몭s time to go out and fight.
And what is the key to winning first and fighting later? Don몭t fight if you can몭t win.
If you can몭t see a clear path to victory, don몭t move. The art of war is mainly about learning how not to fight, not how to fight. You need to be able to stay out of fights and protect yourself, and you also need to be able to settle a conflict in a single engagement. If you can do that, you몭ve fully understood the opening words from the first chapter of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War: 몮The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin. Hence it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected.몯
Regardless of what we몭re trying to achieve, we need to adopt 몬win first, fight later몭 as our way of thinking. Work everything out at the planning stage, and only then take action. If you don몭t do anything, that doesn몭t matter. In many situations, waiting is the best strategy. Among all the factors that effect developing events, there몭s one that plays the ultimate role in deciding outcomes. That factor is time. You need to understand how to wait; you need patience. You need the ability to observe and exploit the changes that time brings. You also need to exploit time itself, in order to manufacture changes.
It was time that took Chairman Mao away and gave us Deng Xiaoping, the man who brought reform to China. If you try to resist the effects of time and impose yourself, you몭ll end up with nothing.
Don몭t always be itching to do something. Many so-called 몬strategic measures몭 are just reflections of strategists몭 anxieties and nerves. You might feel that, unless you do something, you몭re being 몬passive.몭 Or, you might worry that your commander will think you몭re useless, and your king might think you몭re negligent, so you end up beside yourself with anxiety. In that worried state, you may conclude that the only way you can get some relief from these intense emotions is to do something, anything! But, as soon as you move, you become another example of the saying: 몬If you don몭t put yourself in death몭s way, you won몭t die.몭


Appendix: Complete text of The Use of Spies

Sun Tzu said: 몮Raising a host of a hundred thousand men and marching them great distances entails heavy loss on the people and a drain on the resources of the State. The daily expenditure will amount to a thousand ounces of silver. There will be commotion at home and abroad, and men will drop down exhausted on the highways. As many as seven hundred thousand families will be impeded in their labor. Hostile armies may face each other for years, striving for the victory which is decided in a single day. This being so, to remain in ignorance of the enemy몭s condition, simply because one grudges the outlay of a hundred ounces of silver in honors and emoluments, is the height of inhumanity. One who acts thus is no leader of men, no present help to his sovereign, no master of victory. Thus, what enables the wise sovereign and the good general to strike and conquer, and achieve things beyond the reach of ordinary men, is foreknowledge. Now this foreknowledge cannot be elicited from spirits; it cannot be obtained inductively from experience, nor by any deductive calculation. Knowledge of the enemy몭s dispositions can only be obtained from other men.
몮Hence the use of spies, of whom there are five classes: (1) Local spies; (2) Inward spies; (3) Converted spies; (4) Doomed spies; (5) Surviving spies. When these five kinds of spy are all at work, none can discover the secret system. This is called 몬divine manipulation of the threads.몭 It is the sovereign몭s most precious faculty. Having local spies means employing the services of the inhabitants of a district. Having inward spies means making use of officials of the enemy. Having converted spies, getting hold of the enemy몭s spies and using them for our own purposes. Having doomed spies, doing certain things openly for purposes of deception, and allowing our spies to know of them and report them to the enemy. Surviving spies, finally, are those who bring back news from the enemy몭s camp.
몮Hence it is that with none in the whole army are more intimate relations to be maintained than with spies. None should be more liberally rewarded. In no other business should greater secrecy be preserved. Spies cannot be usefully employed without a certain intuitive sagacity. They cannot be properly managed without benevolence and straightforwardness. Without subtle ingenuity of mind, one cannot make certain of the truth of their reports. Oh, how subtle! There is nothing for which spies cannot be used.
몮If a secret piece of news is divulged by a spy before the time is ripe, he must be put to death together with the man to whom the secret was told. Whether the object be to crush an army, to storm a city, or to assassinate an individual, it is always necessary to begin by finding out the names of the attendants, the aides-de-camp, and doorkeepers and sentries of the general in command. Our spies must be commissioned to ascertain these.
몮The enemy몭s spies who have come to spy on us must be sought out, tempted with bribes, led away and comfortably housed. Thus they will become converted spies and available for our service. It is through the information brought by the converted spy that we are able to acquire and employ local and inward spies. It is owing to his information, again, that we can cause the doomed spy to carry false tidings to the enemy. Lastly, it is by his information that the surviving spy can be used on appointed occasions. The end and aim of spying in all its five varieties is knowledge of the enemy; and this knowledge can only be derived, in the first instance, from the converted spy. Hence it is essential that the converted spy be treated with the utmost liberality. Of old, the rise of the Yin dynasty was due to Yi Zhi who had served under the Xia. Likewise, the rise of the Zhou dynasty was due to Lu Ya who had served under the Yin. Hence it is only the enlightened ruler and the wise general who will use the highest intelligence of the army for purposes of spying and thereby they achieve great results. Spies are a most important element in war, because on them depends an army's ability to move.몯


Epilogue: The final conclusion 멨 The nine essential threads of the thinking behind Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War

By the time you finish reading through The Art of War, you will have realized that it몭s not as mysterious as it몭s made out to be. It몭s not some kind of secret scroll; it몭s a vessel for simple, ordinary principles, expressed in clear, sensible terms. As it turns out, simplicity has always been 몬The Way of Sages.몭 The reason we can몭t become powerful, mighty beings is that we don몭t like the idea of ordinariness. We always make things so complicated, because we don몭t believe in simplicity.
As my final summary of Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, I have organized the core threads of his way of thinking into nine points:

1) The art of war is about strength trumping weakness, not weakness trumping strength.
The first chapter is about 몬calculations,몭 not to be confused with 몬ingenious strategems,몭 which is another possible translation of the root Chinese character ji (?[bd49]). It corresponds to the modern-day SWOT analytical framework: Strength, Weakness, Opportunity and Threat. The idea of 몬carrying out calculations in the temple몭 is about weighing and comparing both sides몭 political, economic and military strengths, while you몭re still safely at home, before you decide to go to war. There몭s also the framework of 몬The five factors and the seven considerations,몭 which is a system for assigning scores to the various items up for comparison. Whichever side scores more points will win; whichever side scores fewer points will lose. Once you finish these evaluations, you몭ll know who몭s going to win. 

And then, once you know you can win, you can summon your officers, mobilize your army and go to war.

If your calculations give you a score lower than your enemy몭s, don몭t fight. This is why Sun Tzu didn몭t believe in trying to beat strength with weakness 멪there몭s a low probability of a successful outcome. 몮The art of war is of vital importance to the State. It is a matter of life and death, a road either to safety or to ruin. Hence it is a subject of inquiry which can on no account be neglected.몯 Sun Tzu would never have bet the fate of his country몭s people on a low probability outcome.


2) Even if you can win a war, you still need to calculate the cost of victory.

Every action comes with a price, and the price of war is enormous. Don몭t think only about winning; you need to keep count of the costs you몭ll rack up along the way and decide whether it몭s worth it. Li Ke said; 몮For Marquis Wen of Wei, many victories will lead to his certain ruin.몯 You can win a lot of battles, and yet all those victories can lead to your country몭s destruction. This is because constant fighting leaves the people exhausted, while frequent victories tend to make lords arrogant. An arrogant lord leading an exhausted populace is a recipe for a failed state.

The great Emperor Wu of the Han dynasty was a true example of this, as represented by his immortal words: 몮Any who dare use force against Han will surely be brought to the executioner, no matter how far away they may be.몯 The arrogance is breathtaking! Emperor Wu spent his life hacking away at the borders of his empire and expanding his territory, and for his efforts he won himself a glittering military record. But, what was the end result? Both the government and the people of China were bankrupt, he drove the country to the brink of destruction, and in his later years he was forced under heavy political pressure from his government, and made to kneel and confess his guilt. This is what he said during his self-criticism: 몮Since the time when I ascended the throne, I have engaged in many wanton acts, and have caused distress to all under heaven. It is now too late for regret. Starting from today, there will be a halt to all activities being detrimental to the common folk and squandering the resources of all under heaven.몯

3) Win first, fight later.

Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War is primarily about ways to strengthen yourself. First and foremost, you have to train and improve yourself instead of always thinking about other people and how to defeat them.

Sun Tzu wrote: 몮The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy. To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself.몯 He also wrote: 몮One may know how to obtain victory without being able to achieve it,몯 and 몮Those who are skilled in war obtain victory first, and then fight.몯 Don몭t look for victory on the battlefield; look for a battle after you몭ve already won.

Train and practice until you몭re strong. Make yourself undefeatable, leave no chinks in your armor, and then wait until a chink appears in your enemy몭s armor. If the enemy isn몭t weaker than you, or if you몭re evenly matched 멪 and if they don몭t make any mistakes, or leave any gaps in their defenses 멪 you can몭t attack. 몮The opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself.몯 In other words, victory comes the moment the enemy makes a mistake.

If the enemy doesn몭t make a mistake, there몭s no way you can win.

So, it몭s possible to judge and know ahead of time whether the outcome will be victory or defeat, but you can몭t make victory happen. As soon as the opportunity for victory appears, grab it and fight. You can몭t turn this formula around 멪 if you charge into a fight casually, and look for a path to victory once the battle has already started, you몭re putting yourself in danger.


4) You have to be able to wait; patience is a necessity.

These days, people often repeat the saying, 몬If you don몭t go looking for death, you won몭t die.몭 The Art of War talks about this more than anything else. In war, the profits and the costs are totally disproportionate to each other. If you kill 1,000 enemy soldiers, but lose 800 of your own, there isn몭t necessarily any significant benefit in it for you. But if you lose, you face the prospect of your country몭s destruction, the death of your entire family and the loss of your own life. That몭s why it몭s crucial to be able to wait. You mustn몭t get twitchy and move around a lot just because you feel anxious. When Shuge Han was holding Tongguan Pass, he knew he was in no position to fight. But although he had the ability to wait, Emperor Xuanzong didn몭t 멪 the anxious Emperor forced Shuge Han to leave the safety of the pass and start a fight, which led to the total destruction of his army. When Wang Jian of Qin invaded Chu, he had the ability wait, and he also had the ability to sooth the nerves of the first Emperor of Qin and prevent him from becoming anxious. This enabled Wang Jian to lead a massive army of 600,000 soldiers into Chu territory, set up camp, and while away the days holding contests for his soldiers until finally the people of Chu grew anxious and began to move about, which opened up gaps in their defenses. Then, Wang Jian pounced and destroyed the state of Chu in a single move.

Waiting is the best strategy in many different situations. And yet, people often believe that if you wait, you몭re being passive. They think waiting is unacceptable.

This is what people need to understand: it몭s perfectly acceptable to be 몬passive,몭 even for your entire lifetime, because the consequences of taking action might include your own death.

Look at Japan몭s Tokugawa Ieyasu[bd51], for example. He perfected the waiting game. Nobody had greater patience than him, and nobody was better at compromising. When Oda Nobunaga was in power, Tokugawa was a young boy; when Toyotomi Hideyoshi came to power, Tokugawa had become a powerful regional lord. Did Tokugawa at any point try to force his ambitions, to make them a reality? No, he didn몭t. He could wait and he could compromise. While Toyotomi Hideyoshi was strong, Tokugawa was content to maintain his status as just another regional lord, for as long as it took. In the end, he outlived his rivals and his road to total power came unblocked. Even so, he bided his time for another 17 years after Toyotomi Hideyoshi몭s death before steadily taking control of all Japan. After him, his descendants ruled over Japan for more than 200 years.

5) Settle the score in a single move. If you win a battle without ending the war, your victory is meaningless.

Victory is a tool, not an objective. The objective is stability. It몭s possible to win a war and yet not secure a stable outcome. If you win 100 battles, and yet still have to keep fighting, what몭s the point in the hundred victories? Even when you win, people still die. And even if it몭s only the enemy몭s men who die, it would still be better for them to have lived and come over to your side. That몭s how you defeat your enemy and make yourself stronger at the same time. Sun Tzu몭s way of thinking has a strong emphasis on preservation 멪 self-preservation, preservation of the people, preservation of cities, preservation of wealth and, ideally, preservation of enemy subjects so that you can bring them over to work for you. Only by doing all these things can you create universal stability.

During the Warring States period, the Zhao general Li Mu was assigned to command a border garrison, to defend against Xiongnu raids. His strategy was to close the gates and focus entirely on training his troops. For years he didn몭t venture out to fight the enemy, which didn몭t please the King of Zhao. And so, the king decided to replace Li Mu with a different general. Just over a year after the new general took up his post, there was 몬a new normal.몭 The signal fires were constantly lit, there was fighting each and every day. The lives of the Chinese people living in the borderlands was so disrupted that they couldn몭t take proper care of their farms, the Xiongnu people couldn몭t take proper care of their herds, and both sides suffered terrible loss of life. Resentment between the two sides spiraled, and soon there was no peace to be had.

The King of Zhao ultimately reinstated Li Mu. Frankly, he had no other options. Back in his post, Li Mu went on with his old strategy of avoiding battle and cutting off all contact with the Xiongnu. Several uneventful years went by at the border. The Xiongnu, without anything to steal, gradually let down their guard. Suddenly, Li Mu launched a major attack and wiped out over 100,000 Xiongnu fighters in one fell swoop, stabilizing the frontier and securing peace for the next dozen or more years.

6) 몮Use the regular to engage the enemy, and the irregular to defeat him.몯
	
This is one of the best-known lines in Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War. Earlier in this book, we looked in detail at many examples of these words from Chinese military history. We talked about how the word 몬irregular몭 is the correct translation of the root Chinese character, although it is often mistakenly interpreted to mean 몬extraordinary.몭 It means 몬irregular몭 in the mathematical sense of 몬odd,몭 as in 몬even numbers and odd numbers.몭 It몭s the part of the army that몭s left over or kept in reserve 멪 the card you keep up your sleeve until the crucial moment, before finally pulling it out and securing victory.

This is known as 몬The art of dividing forces,몭 and it몭s one of the most fundamental principles of battle tactics. It몭s indispensable in any armed conflict, whether you have an army of a million troops or, like Xiang Yu during his last stand by the River Wu, you몭re down to your last 28 cavalry soldiers. In both scenarios, you have to divide up your army into two forces that can cover each other. Don몭t mass all your men together in a single unit. When Han Xin fought that famous battle with his back to a deep river, he didn몭t put his entire army up against the river. If he had, he really would have ended up as fish food that day. Before the action started, he split off an auxiliary force and used it to set up an ambush. Then, at the crucial moment 멪 when the battle hung in the balance 멪 he suddenly sprang them into action. That was how he secured his victory.

People tend to believe that by using surprise attacks you can defeat a much larger force, but this is the mentality of people who trust in their own luck. They몭re always thinking about what kind of fancy maneuver they can pull out of the bag, but Sun Tzu is here to tell them that there is no luck in the art of war. Fancy maneuvers go wrong, and the only way to do things is by following the rules of combat and the lessons from the art of war.

7) The Way of Deception just isn몭t important.

몮The art of war is the way of deception.몯 These words are from Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, and that misleads a lot of people. They might think that the art of war is about the same kind of thing as The Thirty-Six Stratagems 멪 namely, the use of deception to win wars. But, if your opponent doesn몭t bite, you can use deception until you몭re blue in the face and it won몭t do you any good. The art of deception is not a major part of the. These days, lots of publishing houses combine Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War and The Thirty-Six Stratagems into a single book, which makes it seem like the art of war is all about clever stratagems and tricks. This is a mistake.

8) Know yourself and know your enemy, but remember that the key is to know yourself.

몮If you know the enemy and you know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles.몯 When people repeat these words, they tend to think more about knowing their enemy, and that it goes without saying that they know themselves. 몬How could I not know myself,몭 they think. But in reality, the crucial part of this formula is knowing yourself. This is because being undefeatable is entirely up to you. If you몭re strong and don몭t make mistakes, nobody else can do anything to get to you. Yet, even if you do everything you can to know your enemy, you still might fall prey to their tricks.

Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War covers a lot of ground, but it all comes back to getting your fundamentals right. Manage your own affairs properly, make yourself strong and wait until an opportunity presents itself. Wait until you have the strongest possible grasp of the situation, and then make your move. Win first, fight later. Settle the score in a single move.

If you몭re not strong, don몭t pretend to be.

9) The art of war doesn몭t teach you how to win. More than anything, it teaches you how to admit defeat.

Why do people thrill to the words, 몬I몭ll never surrender!몭 It몭s because they don몭t like to hear bad news; they몭re not willing to hear the truth when it doesn몭t fit their interests. Then there몭s the phrase, 몬Admitting defeat is the only way to win!몭 People can, at a stretch, just about accept this concept, because the end result is still a win.

But, what if the end result wasn몭t a win? What if it was still a loss?

Can you accept losing?

Before you began to seriously study Sun Tzu몭s The Art of War, you might have thought of it as a profound book about how to win in war. This is true, of course. Information about how to win wars and deep profundity 멪 it몭s all here in this book.

However, if by studying the art of war you can learn how to accept failure, then and only then have you truly stepped through the gates of wisdom.
